, (S, O,) inf. n. fatorapN (Msb) and futuwrN, (S, O, Msb,) (tropical:) The heat remitted after vehemence; became gentle after violence: (Msb, TA:) the heat remitted, abated, or flagged; became languid and faint: and the verb is used in like manner of other things; (S;) for instance, of a price: (Fr, in TA, art. qT:) and of a man, signifying he was, or became, [languid, languid and faint, or] lax in the joints; (Ham p. 799;) [as also tftRr↓, occurring in the K in art. xtr, &c.]. And fatara Albarodu (tropical:) The cold abated, or remitted; or became allayed. (TA.)
And fatara AlmaMCu [The water abated in heat so as to become tepid, or lukewarm, or between hot and cold; (see faAtirN;)] the water ceased to be hot. (M, K.)

fatara jisomuhu, (M, K,) aor.
fatura
, (M,) inf. n. futuwrN, (M, K,) (assumed tropical:) His body became [languid; or] lax in the joints, and weak. (M, K.)
And fatara AlTRarofu (assumed tropical:) The look of the eye, or eyes, became languishing, or languid; expl. by Ainokasara naZaruhu. (IKtt, TA.) [See TarofN faAtirN, below; and see also 4.]
fatarahu He measured it by the fitor: (M, O, K:) like Xabarahu “ he measured it by the Xibor. ” (M, O.)
2. ftRrhu, inf. n. tafotiyrN, He made it (a thing, M, O) to remit, or become allayed or still, after vehemence; and to become gentle after violence. (M, O, * K.)
(tropical:) He made him (a worker) to remit, flag, or become remiss, or languid. (TA.)

ftRr QllRehu AlHarRa, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) God made the heat to remit after vehemence; to become gentle after violence: (Msb, TA:) made it to remit, abate, or flag; to become languid and faint. (S.) [And ftRr Albaroda (tropical:) He made the cold to remit, or become allayed.
ftRr AlmaMCa He made the water to abate in heat so as to become tepid. See 1.]

ftRr jasadahu (assumed tropical:) It (beverage) heated his body, and made it to become languid, or lax in the joints, and weak; or, as some say, ftRrhu and Aftrhu↓ both signify the same, i. e., it made him, or it, [a man's body,] to become languid, or lax in the joints, and weak: (TA:) or the latter, it (disease, M, K, and intoxication, M) rendered him weak, or faint: (M, K:) and Aftr also signifies [without its objective complement's being expressed] it (beverage) rendered its drinker languid, or lax in the joints, and weak; (K;) or it may have this meaning. (O.)

ftRr AlsRaHaAbu, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) The cloud continued motionless, and prepared to discharge rain: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) or rained, and discharged all its water, and left off, and continued motionless: (As, TA:) or became motionless: so
expl. by Hammád Er-Ráwiyeh, in the following verse of Ibn-Mukbil, describing rain, (T,) or a cloud: (TA:)

L.foreign: taOamRalo xaliyliI halo taraI DawoCa baAriqK

sense.s: [Look attentively, O my friend; dost thou see the light of a cloud emitting lightning from El-Yemen, from which the wind of Nejd has drawn rain, and which has then continued motionless?]. (T, TA.)
4. Aftr: see 2, where three significations are mentioned.

Also, (assumed tropical:) His (a man's, T, O) eyelids became weak, so that his eyes, or sight, became languishing, or languid, or not sharp, (Ainokasara Tarofuhu [see TarofN faAtirN, below]). (T, O, K.)
5: see 1, latter half.

10. Astftr, said of a horse, i. q. AisotajamRa (tropical:) [i. e. He abstained from covering, so that his seminal fluid collected]: (A, TA:) in the copies of the K, [and in the O,] erroneously, AisotajarRa. (TA.)
futorN A nabiyRap, (O,) [i. e.] a thing like the suforap [q. v.] made of palm-leaves, upon which flour, or meal, is sifted. (Ibn-' Abbád, O, K.)

fitorN The space between the extremity of the thumb and that of the fore finger (S, O, Msb, K) when they are stretched out asunder (S, O, Msb, TA) in the usual manner [for measuring]: (Msb:) pl. OafotaArN. (TA.)
fatarN: see fatorapN.

Alfataru expl. in the K as signifyfying “ the muscles, ” and also as signifying “ a certain well-known measure, or quantity, of wheat, ” is a mistake for AlfaOoru, mentioned in both of these senses in art. fOr in the TS [and in the O]. (TA. [See art. fOr.])

fatorapN Languor, or remissness; and weakness, feebleness, or faintness; (S, O;) an affection like a weakness, feebleness, or faintness: (T:) and fatarN↓ also signifies weakness, feebleness, or faintness. (M, K.) One says, Oajidu fiI nafosiI fatorapF I experience in myself an affection like a weakness, &c. (T.)

An interval of time [between things: (S and K in art. wtr; &c.:) or] between any two prophets, (M, K,) or between two of God's apostles, (S, O, TA,) during which there is a cessation of the apostolic function: (TA:) or a cessation of the mission of apostles, and a state of effacement of the signs of their religion: so in the Kur v. 22. (Msb.)
See also what next follows.

fitarRN and fatorapN↓ A certain fish, (O, K,) speckled, and having upon it a blackness, (O,) such that when a man treads upon it, he is affected with a languor (in some copies of the K a tremour) in his legs, (O, K,) so that he becomes drowned, thus described by Ibn-' Abbád, (O,) or so that he sweats: (thus in copies of the K:) it is the raERaAdap [or torpedo], found in the Nile of Egypt. (TA.)
futaArN [A languor which is the] beginning of intoxication. (AHn, M, K.)
Alfutuwru The soft and rising parts of the frogs of horses' hoofs. (Ibn-' Abbád, O.)
maMCN faAtirN, (T, M, O, K,) and faAtuwrN↓, (M, K,) Water between hot and cold; lukewarm; tepid; (T, O;) water ceasing to be hot. (M, K.)

TarofN faAtirN (assumed tropical:) An eye, or eyes, in which is a weakness that is deemed beautiful; (B, TA;) [i. e., languishing,] in which is languish, or languidness; (T;) not having a sharp look: (T, M, K;) or not sharp. (S, O.) [See 4.]
maXoIN faAtirN A weak walking. (O.)
faAtuwrN: see the next preceding paragraph.
tafotarN i. q. dafotarN, (O, K,) in the dial. of the BenooAsad: (Fr, O, TA:) mentioned in this art. by Sgh [in the O]. (TA.)

muqotirN, (so accord. to the O,) or mufatRirN, (so in the L,) Beverage which renders languid the drinker; (O, L, TA;) or which heats the body, and occasions in it a languor, or laxity of the joints, and weakness: such beverage is prohibited. (L, TA.)

1. fataXa AlXRaIoCa, (S, O, Msb,) aor.
fatiXa
, (Msb,) inf. n. fatoXN; (S, O, Msb;) and ftRXhu↓, (S, O, Msb,) inf. n. tafotiyXN; (S, O;) both signify the same; (S, O, Msb;) He examined, looked into, scrutinized, or investigated, the thing; but the latter verb is that which is commonly used. (Msb.) And fataXa Eanohu, and ftRX↓, He inquired respecting it, and searched to the utmost after it. (Msb.) fatoXN and tafotiyXN↓ signify The seeking with inquiry or examination or scrutiny or investigation. (Lth, IF, A, O, K.) You say, walaA fatRiXo↓ tufanRiXo Seek thou with inquiry &c., and be not thou lax, or remiss. (A, TA.)
2: see above, in four places.
3. fAtXhu, inf. n. mufaAtaXapN, [He inquired of him, or examined him, diligently.] (Sh, TA in art. vwr.)

[fatRaAXN One who examines things, looks into them, scrutinizes them, or investigates them, much, or diligently; who inquires much, or diligently, and searches to the utmost; who seeks much, or diligently, with inquiry, examination, scrutiny, or investigation.]

1. fataqahu, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
fatuqa
and
fatiqa
, [the former of which is the more common,] (Msb, TA,) inf. n. fatoqN, (S, O, Msb,) He slit it, rent it, rent it asunder or open, or divided it lengthwise: (S, O, K:) disjoined it, or disunited it: (TA:) or undid the sewing of it, unsewed it, or unstitched it: (Msb:) contr. of rataqahu: (O, TA:) and ftRqhu↓, (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. tafotiyqN, (S, O,) is like it in signification, (S, O, Msb, K,) but means he did so much, or many times. (Msb.) It is said of the heavens and the earth, in the Kur [xxi. 31], kaAnataA ratoqFA fafataqonaAhumaA [expl. in art. rtq]. (O, TA.)

And (hence, TA) Alfatoqu signifies (tropical:) The effecting of disunion and dissension among the community (T, S, O, K, TA) of the Muslims, (T, TA,) and the befalling of war (S, O, K, TA) among them, (S, O,) after verbal agreement respecting war on the frontier, or some other thing, (T, TA,) with the occurring of wounds and bloodsheddings. (TA.) One says, fataqa fulaAnN bayonahumo Such a one effected disunion, &c., between them, or among them, (TK.)
And sometimes it means (tropical:) The dissolving of a compact, or covenant. (TA.)
fataqa AlEajiyna He put leaven such as is termed fitaAq [q. v.] into the dough. (Lth, O, K.)

fataqa Almisoka, (S, O, TA,) aor.
fatuqa
, (PS, [in the TA in the next following instance
fataqa
, an evident mistranscription,]) inf. n. fatoqN, He drew forth the odour of the musk [or increased its fragrance] bigayorihi by the admixture of some other thing: (S, O, TA:) and fataqa AlTRiyba, and AldRuhona, he rendered fragrant, and mixed, [or rendered fragrant by mixing,] with aloes-wood &c., the perfume, and the oil. (TA.)

fatiqati AlmaroOapu, aor.
fataqa
, (TK,) inf. n. fataqN, (S, Mgh, O, K, TK,) The woman was, or became, such as is termed fatoqaMC; (S, Mgh, O, K;) contr. of ratiqat. (TK.)

And fatiqa AlEaAmu, aor.
fataqa
, inf. n. fataqN, (tropical:) The year was, or became, abundant with herbage. (S, * O, * K, TA.) It is related by Abu-l-Jowzà that the people were afflicted with drought, and complained to 'Áïsheh, who directed them to make an aperture towards the sky in the tomb of the Prophet, and they did so, and thereupon it rained so that the herbage grew, and the camels became fat to such a degree that they became swollen, or inflated, in the flanks (tafatRaqato); whence it [the year] was called EaAmu Alfataqi. (O, TA.)
2: see the preceding paragraph, first sentence:
and see also futuqN.
ftRq AlkalaAma (tropical:) He rectified the language; or trimmed it, and removed its faults, or defects: or, as Zj says, he made its meaning clear. (TA.)

4. Aftq, said of a man, (TA,) or of a party of men, (O,) He was one, or they were persons, whose beasts were become fat (O, K, TA) so that they became swollen, or inflated, in the flanks (tafatRaqato) (O, TA) by reason of the abundance of the herbage: (TA:) mentioned by AA. (O, TA.)

Said of the upper limb (qaron) of the sun [app. when a little above the eastern horizon], It reached a rent (fatoq) in the clouds, and appeared therefrom. (ISk, S, O, K.) And, said of the moon, It appeared, after concealment, between two black clouds. (IAar, TA.)
Also, said of a party of men, They had the clouds parted asunder from [over] them. (S, O, K.)

And OafotaqonaA We found, or lighted on a fatoq, i. e. a place upon which rain had not fallen when it had fallen upon what was around it. (S, O, K. *) And We had no rain fallen upon our parts of the country when other parts had rain fallen upon them. (TA.)
And Aftq (tropical:) He went forth to a fatoq, or an open, and a spacious, place: (O, K, TA:) a verb, in this sense, similar to OaSoHara and OafoDaI. (O, TA.)
Also (tropical:) He became harassed by futuwq↓, meaning such evils as poverty and debt (O, K, TA) and hunger (O, TA) and disease. (K, TA.)
And He cleaned his teeth with the fitaAq, or stem, or lower part, of the raceme of a palm-tree. (IAar, O, K. *)
5: see 7.

tftRqt AlmaAXiyapu and Anftqt↓ (assumed tropical:) The cattle became swollen, or inflated, in the flanks, by reason of fatness: in consequence of their becoming so, they die; or, sometimes, they become free from the disease: (TA:) one says of a camel, tftRq simanFA. (As, S, O, K.) And tftRqt xawaASiru Alganami (assumed tropical:) The flanks of the sheep, or goats, became dilated by reason of much pasturing upon herbs, or leguminous plants. (TA.) It is said in a description of the Prophet, kaAna fiI xaASiratayohi QnofitaAqN↓, (O, TA,) meaning (assumed tropical:) [There was in his flanks] a flaccidity, or laxness: or a swollen, or an inflated, state: (O:) or a dilatation, which is approved in men, but disapproved in women. (TA.)
tftRq biAlkalaAmi [see futuqN] (tropical:) He was diffuse, or profuse, in speech [as though bursting therewith]. (TA.)

7. Anftq quasi-pass. of fataqahu [i. e. it signifies It became slit, rent, rent asunder or open, or divided lengthwise: became disjoined, or disunited: or became unsewed, or unstitched]: (S, * O, Msb, K: *) and tftRq↓ is quasi-pass. of ftRqhu [i. e. it signifies it became slit, &c., much, or in many places, or it is said of a number of things]. (S, * O, K. *)
Anftqt MbaATuhu is said of a fat child [meaning His armpits became chapped, or cracked]. (S in art. Db.)

Anftq Algayomu Eani AlXRamosi (O, K, TA) i. e. [The clouds became parted asunder, or] became removed, or cleared away, from [before] the sun: (TA:) and Eani Alqawomi [from over the party of men]. (S, O, K.)
Anftqt Ealayohi baAYiqapN (assumed tropical:) [A calamity, misfortune, or disaster, burst upon him]. (S and K in art. bwq, &c.)

Anftqt said of a she-camel, She was seized with a disease, (AZ, O, K,) termed fataqN↓, (TA,) between her udder and her navel, (AZ, O, K,) occasioned by fatness: sometimes in this case she recovers, (AZ, O,) and sometimes she dies. (AZ, O, K.)
See also 5, in two places.
fatoqN inf. n. of fataqahu. (S, O, Msb.)
[Used as a simple subst., A rent, slit, or like.

And hence, (tropical:) A breach in society.] One says, rataqa fatoqahumo, meaning (tropical:) [He closed up the breach that was between them; he reconciled them; or] he reformed, or amended, the circumstances subsisting between them. (TA in art. rtq.)

[Hence also A rupture; a hernia;] a certain malady; a protrusion in the thin, or delicate, and soft part of the belly; (S, O;) a malady in the SifaAq [meaning peritonæum], consisting in a solution of the integument so that a rent takes place in it, and through this passes a strange body, or substance, that was confined within it before the rent; and there is no cure for it, except for that which happens, rarely, to children: (K:) a disease that befalls a man in his intestines, consisting in a disruption of a place between these and his scrotum, in consequence of which a flatus collects between the two testicles and they become enlarged; in which case one says, OaSaAbatohu riyHu Alfatoqi: or a severing of the fat [or cellular substance] that encloses the testicles: in the “ Ghareebáni, ” it is termed fataq↓, with fet-h to the t: (Mgh:) and thus it is said to be by Az, and thus it is expl. by him: (O:) or it is a rending of the skin between the scrotum and the lower part of the belly, in consequence of which [some of] the intestines fall into the scrotum: (TA:) accord. to Ibráheem El-Harbee, a rupture of the bladder. (O, TA.)
[And A rent in the clouds: see 4:] and fataqN↓ [likewise] signifies a gap of the clouds: pl. futuwqN. (TA.)
And (assumed tropical:) An open, and a spacious, place. (O, K.)

And A place upon which rain has not fallen when it has fallen upon what is around it; (S, O, K;) and fataqapN↓ signifies thus, applied to a land: pl. of the former futuwqN. (TA.) [Hence,] EaAmN cuw Alfutuwqi A year of little rain. (S, O, See an ex., from a rájiz, in the first paragraph of art. zl.)

And (tropical:) The dawn; (O, K, TA;) and so fataqN↓: (S, O, K, TA:) signifying also the rising [or rather breaking] of the dawn; as in the saying, AunoZuro UilaI fataqi Alfajori [Look thou at the rising, or breaking, of the dawn]: and Alfatiyqu↓ likewise signifies the dawn; mentioned by El-Isbahánee, and in the B. (TA.)
See also 4, last sentence but one, for a meaning of the pl. futuwqN.
fataqN [inf. n. of fatiqat said of a woman:
and of fatiqa said of a year:] as a subst.: see fatoqN, in three places:
and see also 7.

futuqN, applied to a woman, signifies mutafatRiqapN↓ biAlkalaAmi (tropical:) [Diffuse, or profuse, in speech, as though bursting therewith]: (S, O, K, TA; [in the CK munofatiqap;]) or loquacious: (TK:) or, accord. to ISk, so applied, that mars (tufatRiqu↓ [lit. rends]) in [performing] affairs. (TA.)
fataqapN: see fatoqN, last quarter.
fatoqaMCu, applied to a woman, means Having the faroj dehiscent; [or wide; not constringed;] Alfaroji munofatiqapu↓; (S, O, K;) contr. of ratoqaMCu [q. v.]. (S, O.)
fitaAqN The parting asunder (AinofitaAq) of the clouds from [before] the sun, (O, K, TA,) and their becoming removed, or cleared away, therefrom. (TA.)
And The upper limb (qaron), and the disk (Eayon), of the sun, (O, K, TA,) when it is covered over and then somewhat of it appears. (TA.)

Also The base, or lowest portion, of the white [membranous fibres of the palm-tree which are termed] liyf, (O, K, TA,) such as have not yet appeared: (TA:) the face is likened thereto, because of its clearness. (O, TA.)
And (accord. to IAar, O, TA) The main stem, or the lower part of the main stem when the fruit-stalks have been cut off, of the raceme of a palm-tree. (O, K, TA.)
And (tropical:) The leaven of dough: (ISd, TA:) a large lump of leaven, that soon causes the dough to become mature (O, K, TA) when it is put therein. (O, TA.)
And Mixtures of medicaments compounded (O, K, TA) with oil of jasmine or the like thereof, in order that the odour may diffuse itself: (O, TA:) or musk compounded with ambergris. (TA.)

fatiyqN [i. q. mafotuwqN↓ i. e. Slit, rent, &c.]. naSolN fatiyqu AlXRaforatayoni means [An arrow-head] having two forking portions; (Lth, O, K;) as though [each] one of them were slit [from the other]: (Lth, O:) [or it may mean sharp in the two edges: for] sayofN fatiyqu AlgiraArayoni signifies A sword sharp [in the two edges]: and sayofN fatiyqN, A sharp sword: (TA:) [whence,] rajulN fatiyqu AllRisaAni A sharp-tongued man: (S, O, K:) or chaste, or eloquent, and sharp, of tongue: or chaste, or eloquent, of tongue, perspicuous in speech. (TA.)
AlSRuboHu Alfatiyqu (tropical:) The shining dawn. (As, S, O, K.)
See also fatoqN, last sentence but one.
jamalN fatiyqN (tropical:) A camel swollen, or inflated, in the flanks, by reason of fatness; tafatRaqa simanFA: (As, S, O, K:) and naAqapN fatiyqapN a fat she-camel. (TA.)
And fatiyqN is used in the sense of fatoqN: thus in the saying of 'Amr Ibn-El-Ahtam,
[app. describing a she-camel: I can only conjecture the meaning to be, Having, in the part before the shoulders, a crease like a gash, occasioned by fatness]. (O.)
faAtiqN [Slitting, rending, &c.].

[Hence,] one says, huwa AlfaAtiqu AlrRaAtiqu meaning (assumed tropical:) He is the possessor of command or rule, so that he opens and closes, and straitens and widens [or rather widens and straitens]. (Har p. 208.)
fayotaqN, of the measure fayoEalN, (S, TA,) from Alfatoqu [“ the act of slitting ” &c.], (TA,) A carpenter. (S, O, K.)
And A HadRaAd [which signifies a worker in iron: but it also has the meaning here next following, which may therefore be intended by him who first gave this explanation of fayotaqN]. (AZ, O, K.)
And A bawRaAb [i. e. door-keeper]. (O, K.)
And A king. (AZ, O, K.)
mafotaqN A place of slitting, or of the slit, of a shirt. (O, K.)
mafotuwqN: see fatiyqN.
mutafatRiqapN biAlkalaAmi: see futuqN.
munofatiqapu Alfaroji: see fatoqaMCu.

1. fataka bihi, (S, MA, O, Msb, K,) aor.
fatuka
and
fatika
, inf. n. fatokN and futokN and fitokN (S, O, Msb, K *) and futuwkN (MA, K *) and fataAkapN, (MA,) He assassinated him; i. e. he came to him when he (the latter) was inadvertent, and assaulted him and slew him; (S, MA, * O;) thus it signifies accord. to an explanation of Alfatoku by A' Obeyd;
and this is the primary signification: (Az, TA:) if he have not given him [for OaEoTaAnaA in my original (an obvious mistranscription) I read OaEoTaAhu] assurance of safety, it behooves him to make that known to him: (A' Obeyd, TA:) he assaulted him; or he slew him at unawares; and Aftk↓ is a dial. var. thereof: (Msb:) he seized an opportunity that he (another) offered him (K, TA) by his inadvertence, (TA,) and slew him: or he wounded him openly: (K, TA:) or it has a more general meaning with respect to both of these acts: (K, * TA:) Fr says that Alfatoku signifies the man's slaying openly. (TA.) It is said in a trad., qayRada AlUiymaAnu Alfatoka laA yafotuiku muWominN [i. e. The giving assurance of safety has inhibited (or, emphatically, inhibits) the slaying at unawares, &c.: one who gives assurance of safety shall not slay at unawares, &c.: the like has been said above: see also an explanation of the former clause of the trad. in art. qyd]. (S, O.)

And fataka, aor.
fatuka
and
fatika
, inf. n. fatokN and futokN and fitokN (O, K) and futuwkN, (K,) He purposed an affair and executed it: (O:) or he embarked in, or performed, an affair that occasioned uneasiness, and to which the mind invited; as also Aftk↓: (K:) the latter verb is said by Fr to be a dial. var. of the former. (O.)

[Hence,] fataka fiI AlOamori, (K, TA,) inf. n. fatokN, (TA,) (tropical:) He persisted, or persevered, in the affair; syn. lajRa, or OalaHRa. (Accord. to different copies of the K; in the TA the former. [The same meaning is also assigned to fanaka.])
And fataka fiI Alxubovi, [in the CK fI Alxunobuvi,] inf. n. futuwkN, (O, K, TA,) (tropical:) He exceeded the usual bounds in that which was evil, abominable, foul, or unlawful. (K, TA.)
fataka fiI SinaAEatihi (assumed tropical:) He was skilful in his art, or craft. (TA.)
And fatakato said of a girl, or young woman, means (tropical:) She cared not for what she did nor for what was said to her. (O, K, TA.) [See also fatakato.]

2. fatRakotu AlquTona, (IDrd, O,) inf. n. tafotiykN, (IDrd, O, K,) I separated, plucked asunder, or loosened, the cotton: (IDrd, O, K: *) so in one of the dials.; (IDrd, O;) it is of the dial. of Asd. (TA.)

3. AlmufaAtakapu signifies AlmumaAharapu; (O, K, TA;) so says Ibn-' Abbád, (O, TA,) and so Z; (TA;) i. e. (tropical:) The making a show of skill, one with another: (TK:) [but for AlmumaAharapu, the CK has AlmujaAharapu:] one says, fAtk SaAHibahu i. e. maAharahu (tropical:) [He made a show of skill, app. in competition, with his companion]. (TA.)

And (tropical:) The falling to the thing (muwaAqaEapu AlXRaIoCi) with vehemence; such as eating, (K, TA,) and drinking, (TA,) and the like. (K, TA.) And fAtk AlOamora (assumed tropical:) He threw himself, or plunged, into the affair; syn. waAqaEahu: (K, TA:) and the subst. is fitaAkN↓ [having the meaning of the inf. n.: but why this is not called the inf. n. (for such it is accord. to analogy) I do not see]. (TA.)
And fAtk fulaAnFA (inf. n. mufaAtakapN, TA) i. q. daAwamahu (tropical:) [app. as meaning (tropical:) He kept continually, or constantly, to such a one: agreeably with what here follows]. (O, K, TA.)

fAtkt AlUibilu AlHamoDa (assumed tropical:) The camels [kept continually, or constantly, to the plants called HamoD, desiring them as food and finding them wholesome: (see the part. n., below:) or] confined themselves to the HmD, not pasturing upon anything therewith. (TA.) And fAtkt AlUibilu AlmaroEaI (assumed tropical:) The camels consumed with their mouths [or devoured] the pasture. (TA.)

fAtk fulaAnFA He gave to such a one that which he mentioned as the price of what he had to sell: in the case of his bargaining with him and not giving him anything, one says fAtHhu. (IAar, O, K.) fAtk AltRaAjiru fiI AlbayoEi is expl. in the A as meaning The trader exceeded the due bounds, or acted unjustly, in offering the thing for sale and naming the price. (TA.)
4: see 1, in two places.
maA Oafotakahu means How persistent, or persevering, is he! (TA.)
5. tftRk biOamorihi He executed, or performed, his affair; or kept, or applied himself, constantly, or perseveringly, to it; not consulting any one. (ISh, O, K.)
fitaAkN: see 3, former half.

faAtikN [act. part. n. of 1; generally meaning Assassinating; or an assassin:] one who comes upon another suddenly, or at unawares, or takes him by surprise, with some evil, or hateful, act, or [more commonly] with slaughter: and accord. to IDrd, one who, when he purposes a thing, does [it]: (Ham p. 43:) any one who attempts, or ventures upon, great, or formidable, affairs: (Az, TA:) bold, or daring; (S, O, K;) courageous: (K:) pl. futRaAkN. (S, O, K.)
[Hence,] faAtiku Alqalobi (assumed tropical:) Penetrating, sharp, or vigorous, and effective, in mind. (TA.)
And HayRapN faAtikapN lilsRabuEi (tropical:) [A serpent that attacks the beast of prey]. (TA.)
And jaAriyapN faAtikapN (tropical:) A young woman who cares not for what she does nor for what is said to her. (TA.)

tafotiykN [app. from the Pers. tafotiyk signifying “ fine, soft, wool, ” and “ soft, downy, kids' hair, ”] A compress of rags which is put upon a wound in order that the moisture may become absorbed [thereby]: a subst. like tamotiynN and tanobiytN: and post-classical. (TA.)
UibilN mufaAtikapN liloHamoDi Camels that keep continually, or constantly, to the [plants called] HamoD, desiring them as food and finding them wholesome. (O, TA. [See also 3.])
fitokirN and fitakorN: see what follows.

fitakoriyn and futakoriyn (S, O, K) and fatakoriyn and fitokariyn and fitokirN↓ (O, K) and fitakorN↓ (K) A calamity, or misfortune; (O, K;) and [in the CK “ or ”] a wonderful, and great, or formidable, affair, or event: (K:) or the n is the characteristic of the pl.; and one says, laqiytu minohu Alfitakoriyna and Alfutakoriyna, meaning [I experienced from him, or it,] difficulties, or distresses, and calamities, or misfortunes. (S.)

1. fatalahu, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) aor.
fatila
, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. fatolN; (T, M, Msb;) and ftRlhu↓, (M, K, TA,) [but this has teshdeed given to it to denote muchness of the action, or multiplicity of the objects, (see its pass. part. n. below,)] inf. n. tafotiylN; (TA;) He twisted it, (T, M, K, TA,) i. e. a thing, (T, M,) like as one twists (T) a rope (T, S, O, Msb) &c., (S, O, Msb,) and like as one twists a wick. (T.)
[Hence] one says rajulN muHokamu Alfatoli (tropical:) [A man firm, or compact, in respect of make; as though firmly twisted]. (K and TA voce majoduwlN. [See the pass. part. n. below.])

And fatala cuWaAbatahu, (K,) or fatala fiI cuWaAbatihi, (O, TA,) (tropical:) [lit. He twisted his pendent lock of hair;] meaning he made him to turn, or swerve, from his opinion, or judgment, or sentiment, (O, K, TA,) by deceiving, or deluding, him. (TA.) And jaMCa waqado futilato cuWaAbatuhu (tropical:) He came, having been deceived, or beguiled, and turned from his opinion, &c. (TA.) And maA zaAla yafotilu mino fulaAnK fiI AlcRirowapi waAlgaAribi, (tropical:) meaning, yaduwru mino waraMCi xadiyEatihi [i. e. He ceased not to be going about seeking, or endeavouring, after the deceiving, or beguiling, of such a one]: (S, O, K:) originating from a saying in a trad. of Ez-Zubeyr, cited and expl. voce gaAribN [q. v.]. (O, TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 200.])

fatalahu Eano HaAjatihi, (T,) or Eano wajohihi, (S, O,) means He turned him [from the object of his want, or from his way, or course], like lafatahu, (T, S, O,) from which it is [said to be] formed by transposition. (S, O.) And fatala wajohahu Eanohumo [also] means He turned his face from them, (M, K,) like lafatahu. (M.)

fatilati AlnRaAqapu, [aor.
fatala
,] inf. n. fatalN, (assumed tropical:) The she-camel was smooth, or sleek, and flaccid, in the skin of her armpit, it not having in it Earok nor HaAzR nor xaAliE [which words see in their proper arts.]. (T, TA.) [See also fatalN below.]
2: see the preceding paragraph, first sentence.

4. Aftl said of [trees of the species termed] salam and samur, (K,) or Aftlt said of a samurap (M, O) and of a salamap, (M,) They, or it, put forth, or produced, the fatolap [q. v.] thereof. (M, O, K.)
5: see the paragraph here following.
7. Anftl, and tftRl↓, [but the latter, as quasipass. of 2, denotes, or implies, muchness, or multiplicity,] It [a rope, &c.,] became twisted. (M, K.)
And the former, He turned away (T, S, Mgh) from his prayer, (T,) or from prayer, (Mgh,) or from his way, or course. (S.) And Anftl raAjiEFA [He turned away, returning]. (S, O, K, in art. SwE.)
fatolN: see its n. un. fatolapN:
and see also fatalN.
Also The cry, or crying, of the fatRaAl, i. e. bulobul. (IAar, T, O, TA. [Said in the TA to be an inf. n.: but its verb, if it have one, is not mentioned.])

fatalN an inf. n. of fatilat [q. v.] said of a she-camel. (T, TA.) [It is also expl. as signifying] (tropical:) Wideness between the elbows and sides of a she-camel: (S, O, TA:) or a state of firm, or concealed, insertion, (AinodimaAjN,) in the elbow of a camel, (M, K, TA,) and its being apart from the side; (M, TA;) as also fatolN↓: (M: [thus in the TT as from the M; being there written fatoal:]) this [or rather the like of this] in the shank and foot of the camel is a fault. (M, TA.)
fatolapN [as an inf. n. un., A twisting.

And hence, app., (assumed tropical:) An intense firmness of compacture of the flesh of the fore arm: expl. in the TT, as from the M, by the words Xidp EaSob AldibAg; for which, I doubt not, we should read XidRapu EaSobi AlcRiraAEi: see mafotuwlN.
And A twist.
And particularly A twisted slip, formed by slitting, of the ear of a she-camel. (See 4 in art. dbr, in the last quarter of the paragraph.)
And, as used in the present day, A needleful of thread.

Also] The seed-vessel of the salam and of the samur, peculiarly, (M, K,) resembling the pods of the bean, (M,) when they first come forth. (M, K.) And The blossom of the samurap: (M:) or the fruit of the samur and of the EurofuT: (TA:) or the blossom of the [kind of trees called] EiDaAh, (O, TA,) when it has become compactly organized: (TA:) or it signifies also, (M, K,) and so does fatalapN↓, (K,) or peculiarly this latter, bAltRaHoriyki, as AHn says on the authority of some one or more of the relaters, (O,) the fruit (baramap) of the EurofuT, (M, O, K,) because its filaments, or fringe-like appertenances, are as though they were cotton, and it is white, like the button of the shirt, or somewhat larger: (AHn, M, O:) or it signifies one of what are termed fatolN↓, which means what are [as though they were] twisted, of the waraq [properly signifying leaves of simple and common kinds] of trees, such as the wrq of the [tamarisks called] TarofaMC and Oavol and the like; (TA;) or, (M, K, TA,) as AHn says, (M, TA,) this word fatolN signifies what are not waraq, but are substitutes for these: (M, K, TA:) and, (K,) as some say, (M,) what do not expand, of [the appertenances of] plants, but are [as though they were] twisted; (M, K;) so that they are like hudob [thus in the TT as from the M, perhaps a mistranscription for hadab, q. v.]; being like the hdb [i. e. hadab] of the TarofaMC and Oavol and OaroTI. (M.)
See also fatiylN, last sentence.
fitolapN [A manner of twisting]. You say fitolapN baAriHapN, meaning XazorapN [i. e. A manner of twisting contrary to that which is usual]. (A in art. brH.)
fatalapN: see fatolapN, near the middle:
and see the paragraph here following, last sentence.
fatiylN Twisted; [applied to a rope, &c.;] as also mafotuwlN↓. (M, K.)

And A slender cord, of [the fibres called] liyf, (M, K,) or of [the bark termed] xazam, or of Earaq [meaning plaited palmleaves], or of thongs, (M,) which is bound upon the ring (M, K) called EiyaAn which is at the end (munotahI), (M,) or which is at the place of meeting (mulotaqaI), (K,) of the dujoraAni [two pieces of wood to which the share of the plough is attached]. (M, K.)
[And A tent for a wound: a term used by surgeons: see dasama AljuroHa, in art. dsm.]

And What one twists [or rolls] (S, M, O, K) between his fingers (M, K) or between the two fingers [meaning the thumb and fore finger], (S, O,) of dirt [that has collected upon the skin when it has not been recently washed]; (S, O, K;) as also fatiylapN↓. (M, K.) So says I' Ab in explaining the saying in the Kur [iv. 52, and 79 also accord. to some readers, and xvii. 73], walaA yuZolamuwna fatiylFA [meaning (tropical:) And they shall not be wronged by their being deprived of the most paltry right; or they shall not be wronged a whit]: (O, TA:) or the [primary, or proper,] meaning in this phrase is what here follows. (TA; and in like manner Bd says in iv. 52.)

And The saHaAp [or integument, meaning the pellicle], (M, K, TA,) or the xayoT [or thread, meaning the filament], (Bd in iv. 52,) that is in the XaqR [or cleft, resembling a crease, which extends along one side] of the datestone: (M, K, TA: but for XaqR, the CK has XiqR:) ISk says, the qiTomiyr is the thin integument upon the date-stone, and, he adds, (T, TA, *) the fatiyl is what is in the XaqR of the date-stone. (T, S, O, Msb, TA.) Hence, (M,) one says, maA OugoniI Eanohu fatiylFA, (M, and so in the K except that the latter has Eanoka instead of Eanohu,) meaning [I do not avail, or profit, him, (or accord. to the K, thee,) or I do not stand, or serve, him (or thee) in stead,] as much as that saHaAp, (M,) or a whit; (K;) and in like manner, fatolapF↓, (Th, M, K, [in the CK, erroneously, fatiylapF,]) and fatalapF↓. (IAar, M, K.)
fatiylapN A wick (S, O, K) of a lamp: (T, Msb:) pl. fataAYilu and fatiylaAtN. (Msb.) [Hence, Hajaru Alfatiylapi Amiantus, or flexible asbestus, of which wicks are sometimes made.
And in the present day, fatiylapN also signifies A hempen match.
And A suppository.]
fataAYilu AlrRuhobaAni is the name of A certain plant, the leaves of which are like [those of] the senna (AlsRanaA), and its blossom is yellow. (TA.)
See also fatiylN.
AlfatRaAlN The [bird called] bulobul [q. v.]. (T, O, K.)

Oafotalu, (S, M, O, K,) applied to the elbow, (S, M, O,) of a camel, (S, O,) or of a she-camel, (M,) [and app. to a he-camel,] Having what is termed fatalN [expl. above]: (S, M, O, K:) fem. fatolaMCu, (T, M, K,) applied to a she-camel, meaning having, in her arm, a wide separation from the side: (T, * TA:) or, so applied, heavy, and curved in the kind legs: (M, K:) [the pl. is futolN:] and one says qawomN futolu AlOayodiI [app. meaning Persons having the arms widely separated from the sides]. (S, O.)
cubaAlN mufatRalN [Twisted wicks]: the epithet in this case is with teshdeed because applied to many things. (S, O, K.)
mafotuwlN: see fatiylN.

[It also signifies (tropical:) Compact, or firm, in make; as though twisted; like majoduwlN and maEoSuwbN:] you say rajulN mafotuwlu AlsRaAEidi A man strong [or firm or compact] in the sAEd [or fore arm]; as though it were twisted. (TA.)

1. fatanahu, (T, S, M, &c.,) aor.
fatina
, (M,) inf. n. fatonN, (S, M, K,) [and quasi-inf. n., in this and other senses, fitonapN,] He burned it (T, * S, * M, K *) in the fire. (M.) Hence, [in the Kur li. 13,] yawoma humo EalaI QlnRaAri yufotanuwna (T, * S, M, K *) i. e. [The day, or on the day, accord. to two different readings, (yawomu and yawoma, the latter of which is the more common,)] when they shall be burned (T, S, M, K) with the fire [of Hell]. (T.) And [in the Kur lxxxv. 10,] UinRa QlRaciyna fatanuwA QlomuWominiyna waQlomuWominaAti Verily they who burned the believing men and the believing women (T, S *) in the fire kindled in the trench, or pit; throwing them therein. (T.) This is said to be the primary signification of the verb. (TA.)

And He melted it with fire, (T,) or put it into the fire, (S, Msb,) namely, gold, (T, S, Msb,) and silver, in order to separate, or distinguish, (T, Msb,) the bad from the good, (T,) or the good from the bad, (Msb,) or to see what was its [degree of] goodness. (S.)

And hence, accord. to Er-Rághib, Alfatonu is used as meaning The causing a man to enter into fire [app. by way of trial, or probation], and [in like manner] into a state of punishment, or affliction: (TA:) [and it is also used as meaning the slaying another; whence, in the Kur iv. 102,] Uino xifotumo Oano yafotinakumu QlRaciyna kafaruwA means [If ye fear that those who have disbelieved] may slay you; and in like manner in the Chapter of Yoonus [i. e. in x. 83], Oano yafotinahumo means An yaqotulahumo. (T. [In the TA, these two exs. are misplaced, or something has been omitted before them by a copyist.])

[Hence also,] one says, fatanahu, aor.
fatina
, (K, TA,) inf. n. fatonN, (TA,) He, or it, caused him to fall into Alfitonap; (K, TA;) i. e. trial; and affliction, distress, or hardship; [generally meaning an affliction whereby some good or evil quality is put to the test;] (TA;) as also Aifotatanahu↓; and ftRnhu↓; (K, TA;) but this, of which the inf. n. is tafotiynN, has an intensive signification; (S;) and Oafotanahu↓; (K, TA;) which last is rare, or rather, accord. to As, [though app. not in this sense, but in another, to be mentioned in what follows,] is not allowable: (TA:) the first of these verbs is trans. and intrans.: (S, K, TA:) you say also, fatana, (AZ, T, S, K, TA,) aor.
fatina
, (AZ, T, K,) inf. n. futuwnN, (AZ, T, S, TA,) He fell into fitonap [i. e.
trial, or affliction, &c.]; (AZ, T, K;) as also Aifotatana↓: (K:) or the former signifies he shifted from a good, to an evil, state or condition: or, accord. to En-Nadr, one says Aifotatana↓ and Aufotutina, both meaning the same; and this is correct; but fatana as quasi-pass. of fatanotuhu [i. e. as intrans.] is of weak authority: (T:) and Aufotutina↓, said of a man, [as also Aifotatana,] and futina, signify the same, (S, M,) accord. to AZ, (M,) i. e. he was smitten by a fitonap [or trial, &c.,] so that his wealth, or property, or his intellect, departed: and likewise he was tried, or tested: (S:) and accord. to AZ, one says, of a man, Oufotina↓, [if not a mistranscription for Aufotutina, as above,] with damm, meaning futina: (TA:) [and fatanahu has futuwnN also as an inf. n.:] it is said in the Kur [xx. 41], wafatanRaAka futuwnFA (S) i. e. And we tried thee with a [severe] trying: or the noun in this instance is pl. of fatonN; or of fitonapN, formed by disregard of the p, like HujuwzN and buduwrN which are [said to be] pls. of HujozapN and badorapN; so that the meaning is, we tried thee with several sorts of trying: (Bd:) or, as some say, and we purified thee with a [thorough or an effectual] purifying [like that of gold, or silver, by means of fire]: (TA:) [in many instances] fatanahu, aor.
fatina
, [inf. n. fatonN,] signifies He tried, or tested, him; whence, in the Kur ix. 127, yufotanuwna means They are tried, or tested, by being summoned to war, against unbelievers or the like; or, as some say, by the infliction of punishment or of some evil thing. (M.) fatanotumo Oanofusakumo, in the Kur [lvii. 13], means Ye caused yourselves to fall into trial and punishment. (TA.) And wahumo laA yufotanuwna, in the Kur xxix. 1, is expl. as meaning While they are not tried in their persons and their possessions so that he who has true faith may be known from others by his patient endurance of trial. (T.) And the saying, in a trad., UinRakumo tufotanuwna fiI Alqubuwri means [Verily ye shall be tried, or tested, in the graves by] the questioning of [the two angels] Munkar and Nekeer. (TA.) [See also mafotuwnN, which is said to be an inf. n., and syn. with fitonapN, meaning xiborapN, or with futuwnN (mentioned above as an inf. n. of the intrans. v. fatana), meaning junuwnN; as well as a pass. part. n.]

And fatanahN, (M, TA,) inf. n. fatonN, (TA, [or perhaps futuwnN, as in the next following sentence]) also signifies He made him (a man, M) to turn from, or quit, (M, TA,) the predicament in which he was, (M,) or the right course: (TA:) whence, in the Kur [xvii. 75], waUino kaAduwA layafotinuwnaka Eani QlRaciI OawoHayonaA Uilayoka (M, TA) i. e. [And verily they were near to] their making thee to turn [from that which we had revealed to thee]: thus this saying has been explained. (TA.) [And He, or it, seduced him; or tempted him: thus it may often be well rendered, agreeably with what next precedes and what next follows, and with explanations of its act. part. n. and of fitonapN.] And one says, fatana AlmaAlu AlnRaAsa, aor.
fatina
, inf. n. futuwnN, [or perhaps fatonN, as in the next preceding sentence,] meaning Wealth, or property, inclined, or attracted, to it, men, or mankind: and futina fiI diynihi and Aufotutina↓, both in the pass. form, He declined [or was made to decline] from [the right way in] his religion. (Msb.) And fatanahu, aor,
fatina
, inf. n. fatonN and futuwnN, (M, K,) He, or it induced in him admiration, or pleasure; (M, * K, * TA;) as also Oafotanahu↓ [respecting which see what here follows]: (M, K:) and one says, of a woman, fatanatohu, (T, S,) meaning [She enamoured him; or captivated his heart; i. e.] she bereaved him of his heart, or reason, (dalRahatohu, [thus in several copies of the S, in one of my copies balRahatohu,] and [so affected him that] he loved her; (S;) as also Oafotanatohu↓; (T, S;) the former of the dial. of El-Hijáz, and the latter of the dial. of Nejd; (T, S; *) but Aftnthu↓, (T, S,) or Aftnhu, (M,) was disallowed by As, (T, S, M,) and he paid no regard to a verse mentioned to him as an ex. thereof, (T,) [or] he ignored a verse cited to him as an ex. of the pass. part. n. from an Ourojuwzap of Ru-beh, not knowing it therein; (M;) most of the lexicologists, however, allow both: (T:) Sb says that fatanahu signifies he put [or occasioned] in him fitonap; and Aftnhu↓, he caused Alfitonap to come to him [or to affect him]; (M;) or he said that the latter means he made him to be faAtin: (TA voce Hazanahu:) and one says also, of a man, futina bQlomaroOapi and Aufotutina↓ [both meaning He was enamoured by the woman]. (T.)

And one says also, of a man, fatana, aor.
fatina
, inf. n. futuwnN, meaning He desired Alfujuwr [i. e. the committing of adultery or fornication]: (AZ, TA:) or fatana UilaI AlnRisaMCi, inf. n. futuwnN, he desired Alfujuwr (T, M, K, TA) with women or the women; as also futina UilayohinRa. (M, K, TA.)
2: see the preceding paragraph, former half.
3. mufaAtanapN [The occasioning fitonap (meaning conflict, or discord, or the like,) with another]. (TA in art. Erm: see 3 in that art.)
4: see 1, former half, in two places: and also in the latter half, in four places.
5. banuw vaqiyfK yatafatRanuwna OabadFA means yataHaArabuwna [i. e. The sons of Thakeef (the tribe so called) contend in war, one with another, ever].
tafatRananiI: see 5 in art. Ejb, where it is said to be syn. with taSabRaAniI.
8: see 1, former half, in four places: and also in the latter half, in two places.
fatonN A sort, or species; and a state, or condition; syn. DarobN, (T, M, K,) and fanRN, (T, K,) and lawonN, (M, K,) and HaAlN. (T, K.) Hence the saying of 'Amr Ibn-Ahmar El-Báhilee,

And AlfatonaAni, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, AlfutonAni,]) dual of Alfatonu, (TA,) signifies The first and last parts of the day; or the early part of the morning and the late part of the evening: (K, TA:) because they are two states, or conditions, and two sorts. (TA.)
fitonN: see the next preceding paragraph.
fitonapN A burning with fire. (T.)
And The melting of gold and of silver (K, TA) in order to separate, or distinguish, the bad from the good. (TA.)

And [hence, or] from fatana signifying “ he melted, ” (T,) or from that verb as signifying “ he put into the fire, “ (Msb,) gold, and silver, “ for that purpose, ” (T, Msb,) it signifies A trial, or probation; (IAar, T, S, M, K, TA;) and affliction, distress, or hardship; (TA;) and [particularly] an affliction whereby one is tried, proved, or tested: (IAar, T, S, K, TA:) this is the sum of its meaning in the language of the Arabs: (T, TA: *) or the trial whereby the condition of a man may be evinced: this, accord. to Zj, may be the meaning in the Kur v. 45: (M:) or a mean whereby the condition of a man is evinced, in respect of good and of evil: (Kull:) [hence it often means a temptation:] and mafotuwnN↓ signifies the same as fitonapN, (S, M, K,) meaning a trial: (K:) the pl. of fitonapN is fitanN. (Msb.) It proceeds from God and from man: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [there are many instances of its proceeding from God in the Kur; for ex., in xxxvii. 61,] UinRaA jaEalonaAhaA fitonapF lilZRaAlimiyna i. e. [Verily we have made it to be] a trial [to the wrongdoers] is said in relation to the tree Ez-Zakkoom; the existence of which they disbelieved; for when they heard that it comes forth in the bottom of Hell, they said, Trees become burned in the fire; then how can they grow therein? (M.) [And hence] it signifies also Punishment, castigation, or chastisement. (T, M, K.) And Slaughter: (T:) and civil war, or conflict occurring among people: (M:) and slaughter, and war, and faction, or sedition, among the parties of the Muslims when they form themselves into parties: (T:) and discord, dissension, or difference of opinions, among the people. (IAar, T, K.) A misleading; or causing to err, or go astray: (T, K:) [seduction; or temptation: or a cause thereof; such as] the ornature, finery, show, or pomp, and the desires, or lusts, of the present life or world, whereby one is tried: (T:) and wealth, or children; (T, K, TA;) because one is tried thereby: (TA:) and women; than whom, the Prophet said, there is no fitonap more harmful to men: (T:) and a cause of one's being pleased with a thing; (T, M, K;) as in the saying laA tajoEalonaA fitonapF liloqawomi QlZRaAlimiyna [in the Kur x. 85, i. e. Make not us to be a cause of pleasure
to the wrongdoing people]; meaning, make not them to prevail over us, so as to become pleased with their unbelief and to think that they are better than we. (T.) Also Madness, insanity, or diabolical possession; (T, K;) and so futuwnN↓ and mafotuwnN↓. (T.) And Error; or deviation from the right way. (M, K.) And Infidelity; or unbelief: (T, M, K:) thus in the saying, [in the Kur ii. 187,] waQlofitonapu OaXadRu mina Qloqatoli [And infidelity, or unbelief, is more excessive than slaughter: and the like is said in ii. 214]. (T.) And A sin, a crime; or an act of disobedience for which one deserves punishment. (M, K.) And Disgrace, shame, or ignominy. (M, K.) fitonapu AlSRadori signifies AlwasowaAsu [app. as meaning The devil's prompting, or suggesting, of some evil idea]: fitonapu AlmaHoyaA, The being turned from the [right] road: fitonapu AlmamaAti, The being questioned in the grave [by the two angels Munkar and Nekeer]: fitonapu AlDRurRi, The sword: and fitotapu AlsRurRi, Women. (TA.) [And Alfitonapu AlEamoyaA is a phrase used in the present day as meaning Incurable evil or trouble.]
[It is also the name now commonly given to The mimosa farnesiana of Linn.; (Delile's Floræ Ægypt. Illustr. no. 962;) called by Forskål (Flora Ægypt. Arab. p. lxxvii.) mimosa scorpioïdes.]
fitaAnN A covering, of leather, for the [camel's saddle called] raHol: (T, M, K:) pl. futunN. (M.)
futuwnN: see fitonapN, latter half. [It is an inf. n. of 1 in several senses.]
fatiynN, applied to silver (wariq, i. e. fiDRap), Burnt. (S.)

[Hence,] Black stones; as though burnt with fire. (T.) And A [stony tract such as is called] HarRap, (S,) or like a HarRap, (Sh, T,) as though the stones thereof were burnt: (Sh, T, S:) or a black HarRap: (K:) or a HarRap wholly covered by black stones, as though they were burnt: (M:) pl. futunN: (Sh, T, M, K:) and fataAYinu signifies black HiraAr [pl. of HarRapN]; (TA; [and the same is app. indicated in the T;]) as though its sing. were fatiynapN↓; and some say that this is a sing. [or n. un.], and that fatiyn is the pl. [or coll. gen. n.]; but as some relate a verse of El-Kumeyt which is cited as an ex. of fatiynap with the p elided because ending the verse, it is fitiyna, and said to be pl. of fitapN, like as Eiziyna is of EizapN. (T.)
In the dial. of El-Yemen it signifies Short; and small. (TA.)
fatiynapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
fatRaAnN is an intensive epithet. (TA.)
And signifies A goldsmith or silversmith: (S, K, TA:) because of his melting the gold and the silver in the fire. (TA.)
And AlfatRaAnapu signifies [The touch-stone; i. e.] the stone with which gold and silver are tried, or tested. (KT.)

And the former, A man who tries, or tempts, much. (TA.) And AlfatRaAnu, The devil; (T, S, K;) who tries, or tempts, men, by his deceit, and his embellishing acts of disobedience; (T;) as also AlfaAtinu↓; (M, K;) [each] an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates: (M:) pl. of the former futRaAnN. (T, S.) And AlfatRaAnataAni, The dirhem and the deenár; (K, TA;) as though they tried, or tempted, men. (TA.) And likewise, (K,) or fatRaAnaA Alqabori, (M,) [The two angels] Munkar and Nekeer [who are said to examine and question the dead in the graves]. (M, K.)
And A thief, or robber, (T. K,) who opposes himself to the company of travellers in their road. (T.)

faAtinN [is the act. part. n. of the trans. v. fatana; and as such] signifies Causing to err, or go astray, (T, S, M,) from the truth: (S:) hence the saying in the Kur [xxxvii. 162], maA Oanotumo Ealayohi bifaAtiniyna, (T, S, * M, *) which, accord. to Fr, means, Ye have not power [over him] to cause him to err, except him against whom it has been decreed that he shall enter the fire [of Hell]; fAtnyn being made trans. by means of EalaI because it implies the meaning of qaAdiriyna, which is thus made trans.: (M:) Fr says, the people of El- Hijáz say maA Oanotumo Ealayohi bifaAtiniyna; and the people of Nejd, bimufotiniyna↓, from Oafotanotu. (S.)
See also fatRaAnN.
It is also an epithet from the intrans. v. fatana; and as such is applied to a heart as signifying Falling into fitonap [i. e. trial, or affliction, &c.; or in a state of trial, &c.]. (S, * TA.)
fayotanN A carpenter. (K.)
mufotanN: see mafotuwnN. [And see also the different explanations of its verb.]
mufotinN: see an ex. of its pl. voce faAtinN.
mafotuwnN [pass. part. n. of 1; signifying Burned: &c.].
It is applied as an epithet to a deenár as meaning Put into the fire in order that one may see what is its [degree of] goodness. (S.)

It signifies also Smitten by a fitonap [or trial, &c.,] so that his wealth, or property, or his intellect, has departed: and likewise tried, or tested: (S:) or caused to fall into Alfitonap; (K, TA;) i. e. trial; and affliction, distress, or hardship; (TA;) as also mufotanN↓. (K, TA.) And [particularly] Afflicted with madness, insanity, or diabolical possession. (T, K. *) [See also what here follows.]

It is also syn. with fitonapN; (T, S, M, K;) and, thus used, it is an inf. n., like maEoquwlN &c. (T, S, M.) See fitonapN, former half: and again, in the latter half. Hence, (T, M,) as some explain it, (M,) biOayRikumu Qlomafotuwnu, [in the Kur lxviii. 6,] (T, M,) meaning In which of you is madness: (T:) but some say that the b is redundant; (M;) thus says AO; (T;) the meaning being OayRukumu Qlomafotuwnu [Which of you is the afflicted with madness]; (T, M;) but Zj disallowed this: (T:) J says, [in the S,] that the b is redundant, as in kafaI biQllRehi XahiydFA, in the Kur [xiii. last verse, &c.], and [thus in copies of the S, app. a mistake for “ or ”] Almftwn means Alfitonapu, and is an inf. n. [&c.]: IB says, [in remarking upon this passage of the S,] if the b be redundant, Almftwn is the man, and is not an inf. n.; but if you make the b to be not redundant, then Almftwn is an inf. n. in the sense of Alfutuwn. (TA.) [See also art. b; p. 142, second col.; and p. 143, third col.]

mafotuwnapN is [a term] applied to A number of black camels collected together (laAbap sawodaMC), as though they were like the [stony tract called] HarRap, in blackness; as though they were burnt. (T.)

1. fatuwa, aor. yafotuw; (Lth, T;) or fatiIa, aor. yafotaI; (S, TA;) inf. n. fataMCN, (Lth, A 'Obeyd, T, S, * TA,) or fatFI; (TA [and so in one of my copies of the S; but the former, which see below, is that which is commonly known];) He was, or became, such as is termed fatiIRN [i. e. youthful, or in the prime of life]. (Lth, A 'Obeyd, T, S, * TA.)

fatawotuhumo, (K, TA,) aor. Oafotuwhumo, (TA,) I overcame them, or surpassed them, in futuwRap, i. e. generosity. (K, TA.) [Accord. to the TK, one says, fafatawotuhumo faAtawoniI↓, meaning They contended with me for superiority in generosity, and I overcame them, or surpassed them, therein; and the inf. n. of the former verb is mufaAtaApN.]

2. futRiyat, (ISk, T, S, M, K,) inf. n. tafotiyapN, (ISk, T, S, K,) said of a girl (ISk, T, S, M, K) that has nearly attained to puberty, (ISk, T,) She was prohibited from playing with the boys, (ISk, T, S, M, K,) and from running with them, (M,) and was concealed, or kept within, or behind, the curtain, (ISk, T, S, M,) in the house, or tent; (M;) and so tftRt↓: (ISk, T, K:) [or] ↓the latter signifies [or signifies also] she assumed, or affected, a likeness to the young women, being the youngest of them. (S, M. [In text of the latter, as given in the TT, tXbRht bAlftyAn is put for tXbRht biAlfatayaAti, which the context shows to be the right reading.])
3: see 1, last sentence.
AlmufaAtaApu signifies [also] The summoning another to the judge, and litigating; and so AltRafaAtiI↓. (TA.)

4. AftI He (a learned man) notified the decision of the law [in, or respecting, a particular case]. (Msb.) [And the verb in this sense is trans.: you say,] AftAhu fiI AlOamori He notified, made known, or explained, to him, [what he required to know, and particularly what was the decision of the law, in, or respecting,] the case; (M, K, TA;) it being dubious: said of a lawyer. (TA.) And OafotaAniI fiI masoOalapK, (T, S,) inf. n. UifotaMCN, (T,) He (a lawyer) gave me an answer, or a reply, [stating the decision of the law,] respecting a question. (T, S, TA.) And Oafotayotu fulaAnFA fiI ruWoyaA raMhaA I interpreted, or explained, to such a one, a dream that he had seen. (T, TA.)
Also He drank with the futaIR [q. v.]. (IAar, T, TA.)
5. tftRI He affected, or assumed, a likeness to youths, or young men: said of an old, or elderly, man; or one past the prime of life. (TA.)
See also 2, in two places.

And He affected, or endeavoured to acquire, generosity: and also he affected, or made a show of, generosity: (KL:) you say tftRI and tfAtI↓ [app. as signifying the same: but more properly the former verb has the former of these two significations: and ↓the latter verb has the latter of the same two significations]: both from AlfutuwRapu. (S, K, TA.)
6: see the next preceding sentence, in two places:
and see 3. You say, tafaAtawoA UilaI Alfaqiyhi They appealed to the lawyer for the notifying of the decision of the law. (S, TA.)

10. Aisotafotayotu Alfaqiyha fiI masoOalapK I sought, or demanded, of the lawyer, a notification of the decision of the law respecting a question. (T, * S, * Msb, * TA.) And in like manner the verb is used in the Kur iv. 126, and xxxvii. 149. (TA.)
fitapN A [stony tract such as is called] HarRp [for which some copes of the K have jarRap, a mistranscription, as may be seen from a statement voce fatiynN, in art. ftn, q. v.]: pl. fituwna. (K, TA.)

fatFI i. q. XaAbRN, (S, M, K, TA, but omitted in the CK,) or gulaAmN HadavN, (T,) or XaAbRN HadavN: (Msb:) it is a subst. [signifying A youth, or young man; or one in the prime of life]: and an epithet [signifying youthful; or in the prime of life]: (TA:) [as an epithet, similar to fatiIRN, but restricted in application to a human being:] or it signifies, (Mgh,) or signifies also, (Msb,) a strong youth or young man: (Mgh, Msb:) it is said that in the Kur xviii. 59 and 61, it is applied by Moses to Joshua the son of Nun, because he served him: (M, TA:) the fem. is fataApN↓: (S, K:)

and it also means (tropical:) A slave; (T, M, Mgh, Msb, TA;) even if an old man; metaphorically used in this sense; (Mgh, Msb, TA;) and in like manner, fataApN↓ means (tropical:) a female slave, (T, M, Mgh, Msb, TA;) and a female servant: (TA:) the Prophet is related to have said, Let not any of you say EabodiI and OamatiI, but let him say fataAIa and fataAtiI: (T, Mgh:)

and Generous, honourable, liberal, or bountiful: (S, K:) [mostly used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates; meaning a generous man:] a possessor of futuwRap [q. v.]: hence the saying, laA fataI UilRaA EaliIRN [There is no one endowed with generosity but, or other than, (meaning like,) 'Alee]: (TA:)

the dual of fatFI is fatayaAni and fatawaAni; (K, TA;) the former occurring in the Kur xii. 36: (TA:) the pl. of fatFI is fitoyapN, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) a pl. of pauc., (Msb,) not mentioned in the K, though occurring in the Kur xviii. 9 & 12, (TA,) instead of which they did not say OafotaMCN, (Sb, M,) and fitowapN, (M, K,) [also a pl. of pauc.,] mentioned by Lh, (M,) and (of mult., Msb) fitoyaAnN (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and futuwRN (T, S, M, K) and futiIRN: (S, M, K:) the pl. of fataApN↓ is fatayaAtN: (S, M, Msb, K:) the dim. of fatFI is futaIRN↓; and that of fataApN is futayRapN↓. (T.) [It is disputed whether the last radical letter of this and other words mentioned in the present art. be originally w or I.]

AlfatayaAni means (tropical:) The night and the day; (S, M, K, TA;) like AlOajadRaAni and AljadiydaAni: (S, TA:) or, accord. to Seer, the morning and the evening, or the early part of the morning and the late part of the evening, or the forenoon and the afternoon; syn. AlgadaApu waAlEaXiIRu. (Har p. 377.) And you say, Oaqomatu Einodahu fatFI mino nahaArK i. e. (tropical:) I remained, stayed, or abode, with him during a first part of a day. (TA.)
fataApN fem. of fatFI: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

fatowaI (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and futowaI, (M, K, TA,) [but the latter is mentioned by few,] and futoyaA↓, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) substs. from OafotaI, (T, S,) and as such used in the place of [the inf. n.] UifotaMCN [i. e. The giving an answer, or a reply, stating the decision of the law, respecting a question]: (T:) [or rather, as commonly used, a notification of the decision of the law, in, or respecting, a particular case;] a notification, or an explanation, of a case, given by a lawyer; (M, K;) or an answer, or a reply, to a question relating to a dubious judicial decision: (Er-'Rághib, TA:) [fancifully said in the Mgh and Msb to be derived from AlfataI:] the pl. is fataAwK, and fataAwaI is said to be allowable, (Msb, TA,) and another pl. is futFI, mentioned by IKoot. (TA.)
futoyaA: see the next preceding paragraph.

fataMCN [mentioned in the first sentence of this art. as an inf. n.] Youth, or youthfulness; or the prime of life; (T, S, M, K;) and so futawRapN↓, (T, M,) as a subst. from fatFI and from fatiIRN: (M:) or the latter is used in relation to human beings; and the former, to camels [and the like], and also, metaphorically, to human beings: (T:) one says, qado wulida fiI fataMCi sinRihi OawolaAdN [Children had, or have, been born to him in the youthfulness, or prime, of his age]. (S.)
futaIRN dim. of fatFI, q. v., latter half.

Hence, i. e. because of its smallness, (Z, TA,) AlfutaIRu signifies what is called qadaHu AlXRuTRaAri [which may be rendered (tropical:) The cup, or bowl, of the rogues]; (IAar, T, Z, K, TA;) [a cup, or bowl,] with which wine is measured; (TA;) tropically thus called. (Z, TA.)

fatiIRN Youthful; or in the prime of life; (Lth, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) contr. of musinRN; (S, Mgh, Msb;) applied to a camel, (T,) or to a beast, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or to anything [i. e. to a beast and to a human being]; (M, K;) or it is like fatFI [which is applied peculiarly to a human being], but is sometimes applied to a camel: (M:) [this last statement, however, requires confirmation, which I have not been able to find: the epithet is generally known as applied only to a camel or the like:] the fem. is fatiyRapN; (Lth, T, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) of which the dim. is futayRapN↓: (TA:) and the pl. is OafotaMCN (T, S, Mgh, Msb, TA) and fitaMCN. (M, K, TA. [The former pl., though the more common, is not mentioned in the M nor in the K.])
futuwRapN: see fataMCN.
[Also Youthful conduct.] One says, maAla UilaI Aljaholi waAlfutuwRapi [He inclined to ignorant, or foolish, or silly, and youthful, conduct]. (S in art. Sbw).

And Generosity, honourableness, liberality, or bountifulness: (S, K, TA:) used as meaning thus in [treatises on] the law; but not occurring in the Sunneh nor in the Scripture [i. e. the Kur-án]: the earliest mentioner thereof was Jaafar Es-Sádik. (TA.)
futayRapN: see fatFI, latter half: and see also fatiIRN.
OafotaI i. q. OaSogaru [as meaning less, and least, in years, or age]: from AlftI [i. e. AlfataI or AlfatiIRu]. (Ham p. 207.)
OufayotiyapN [an irreg.] dim. of fitoyapN [which is a pl. of fatFI; like as OuSayobiyapN, accord. to Sb, is dim. of SiboyapN, a pl. of SabiIRN]. (TA.)
mufotK [A jurisconsult who notifies the decisions of the law, in, or respecting, cases submitted to him, for the guidance of the qaADiI and others].
[And] AlmufotiI is the name of A certain measure of capacity, called the mikoyaAl of Hishám Ibn-Hubeyreh. (As, T, M, K.)

1. favRa julRatahu, (T, O, K,) [aor.
favuva
,] inf. n. favRN, (T,) He scattered the dates of his julRap [or receptacle made of palm-leaves]. (T, O, * K.)

And favRa AlmaMCa AlHaArRa biAlbaAridi, aor.
favuva
, (M, TA,) inf. n. favRN, (TA,) He abated, or allayed, the heat of the hot water by means of the cold: from Yaakoob. (M, TA.) [See also favaOa.]

7. AnfvR, inf. n. AinofivaAvN, i. q. Ainokasara [accord. to the TK used in its proper sense as signifying It broke, or became broken: but for this I find no authority]. (T, O, K.) So in the saying, AnfvR AlrRajulu mino hamRK OaSaAbahu [The man became broken in spirit, or languid, from anxiety, or solicitude, that befell him]. (T, O.)
8. maA QfotuvRa banuw fulaAnK qaTRu means The sons of such a one have not been overcome, or subdued, hitherto, or ever. (AA, O, K. *)

favRN A certain plant, the grain of which is made into bread, (S, M, O, K,) and eaten, (S, M, O,) in the time of drought, or dearth: (S, M, O, K:) in some of the copies of the K, yuxotabaOu is put for yuxotabazu: (M, F:) the bread made of it is coarse, or thick, resembling the bread that is baked in hot ashes [which is generally made in the form of thick round cakes]: (S, O:) a grain resembling [the species of millet called] jaAwaros, which is made into bread, and eaten: (IAar, T:) it is a wild grain, which the Arabs of the desert take, in the
times of hunger, and pound, or bruise, and make into bread; and it is a bad kind of food, but sometimes, or often, they are content with it for days: (T:) or, as some say, it is [a plant] of the species called najiyl, growing in salt lands, of the [plants termed] HumuwD [pl. of HamoD], of which bread is made: [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. favRapN: (Th, M:) Aboo-Ziyád El-Kilábee says, the favR, like the duEaAE, is a herb (baqolap) in which comes forth grain, and each of them spreads [upon the ground], not growing up high; and when they become dry, the people collect what is dry thereof, then pound, or bruise, it, and winnow it, and take forth from it a sort of black grain, with which they fill sacks, and lade the camels: it is a black sort of grain like the Xahoniyz [q. v.], and they make bread of it, and make EaSiydap (yaEotaSiduwna): (O:) in the Bári' it is said to be a species of tree or plant (XajarN) growing in the plain, or soft, lands, and on the [eminences called] MkaAm, having a sort of grain like the HimRaS [or chick-peas], of which are made bread and sawiyq. (Msb.)

And accord. to IF, AlfavRu signifies The habiyd, (O, Msb,) meaning the pulp of the colocynth, XaHomu AlHanoZali, (O,) or the colocynth-plant, Xajaru AlHanoZali. (Msb: and this is one of the meanings assigned to AlfavRu in the K. [In the TK, XaHomu AlHanoZali is said to be the correct explanation: but from what will be seen voce habiydN, I think it most probable that the right meaning is The seeds of the colocynth.])
IF also says that it signifies The fasiyl [i. e. shoot, or shoots, of the palm-tree,] which is, or are, plucked forth [entire,] from the base thereof. (O.)

tamorN favRN Dates that are scattered; (Lth, Kr, M, K;) not in a provision-bag or other receptacle; like bavRN: (Kr, M:) or dates that are separate, each one from others; not sticking together; (T, O;) and so facRN and bacRN and faDRN. (T.)

mafavRapN Multitude: (T, O, K:) so in the saying, wujida libaniI fulaAnK mafavRapN [Multitude was found to be attributable to the sons of such a one] when they were numbered: (T, O:) and maqavRapN signifies the same. (K and TA in art. qv.)

And [i. q. nuzulN:] one says, maA raOayonaA julRapF Oakovara mafavRapF minohaA, meaning nuzulFA [i. e. We have not seen a receptacle made of palm-leaves, for dates, having more food prepared for the guest than it]: (T, O:) and kaviyru mafavRapK means kaviyru nuzulK [i. e. Abundant in respect of food prepared for the guest]. (So in some copies of the K: in other copies nazalK. [The TA gives the latter reading; and so, therefore, does the TK, which explains it as meaning “ increase, ” and adds that one says TEAm kvyr mfvp, an ex. app. without any authority; for what I have cited from the T and O shows, I think, that the former reading, and not the latter, is unquestionably right.])

1. favaOa Alqidora, aor.
favaAa
, (T, S, M, O, K,) inf. n. favoCN (T, M, K) and fuvuwoCN, (M, K,) both inf. ns. from Lh, (M,) He stilled, or allayed, the boiling of the pot, (T, S, M, O, K,) with water, (S, O,) i. e. with cold water, or by lading out with the ladle: (T:) and vafaOahaA signifies the same. (M.)
[Hence] one says, OaTofaOa fulaAnN AlnRaAYirapa wafavaOa Alquduwra AlfaAYirapa (tropical:) [Such a one extinguished the discord, or rancour, or enmity, and stilled the boiling passions]. (A, TA.)

And favaOa gaDabahu, (M, K, *) aor.
favaAa
, (M, K,) inf. n. favoCN, (M,) (tropical:) He stilled, or quieted, or abated, his anger, (M, K, * TA, *) by words, or otherwise. (TA.) UinRa AlrRaviyoYapa tafovaOu AlgaDaba (assumed tropical:) [Verily what is termed rvyYp stills, or appeases, anger] is one of their provs., (S, O, TA,) expl. in art. rvO. (TA.)

And favaOotu AlrRajula, (S, O,) or favaOotuhu EanRiI, (T, TA,) (assumed tropical:) I averted, or turned back, the man from me, by words, or otherwise. (T, S, O, TA.) And favaOa AlXRaIoCa Eanohu, (M, K,) inf. n. favoCN, (M,) (assumed tropical:) He averted the thing from him. (M, K, TA.) And maA favaOaka EanRaA (assumed tropical:) What withheld, or has withheld, thee from us? (Har p. 180.)

Also favaOa AlXRaIoCa, (M, K,) aor.
favaAa
, inf. n. favoCN and fuvuwoCN, (TA,) He allayed the cold of the thing by heating. (M, K, TA.) And favaOati AlXRamosu AlmaMCa The sun abated, or allayed, the cold of the water. (M.) And favaOahu, inf. n. favoCN, He heated it; namely, water, (AZ, T, O,) &c. (T.) And accord. to MF, the phrase favaOa AllRabana is allowable [as meaning He boiled the milk so that it frothed up and became curdled, or clotted, or dissundered: see what next follows]. (TA.)

favaOa AllRabanu, aor.
favaAa
, The milk was boiled so that it frothed up and became curdled, or clotted, or dissundered: (AHát, M, O, K:) when this is the case, the milk is termed faAviYN↓. (AHát, O.)
faviYati Alqidoru The cookingpot ceased to boil. (O.)
And faviYa [or faviYa gaDabuhu] (assumed tropical:) His anger was, or became, abated; (TA;) [and] so gaDabuhu AnfvO↓. (Har p. 232.)
And maA tafovaOu tafoEalu (assumed tropical:) Thou dost not cease doing [such a thing]; like mA tafotaOu. (A, TA.)
favaOa bisaloHihi: see faTaOa.
4. AfvO (assumed tropical:) It (the heat) became allayed, or assuaged; and remitted, or abated. (S, O.)
And OaTobaqati AlsRamaMCu vumRa OafovaOato (assumed tropical:) [The sky became overcast, and then cleared]. (A, TA.)
AfvO biAlmakaAni (assumed tropical:) He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place. (O, K. *)
EadaA HatRaI OafovaOa (assumed tropical:) He (a man, M) ran until he became tired, (S, M, O, K, *) and out of breath, (S, O,) or and languid. (M, K.) In the saying of El-Khansà,

L.foreign: OalaA mano liEayonK laA tajifRu dumuwEuhaA

sense.s: (assumed tropical:) [Now who will be as a helper for an eye of which the tears will not dry up? when thou sayest, “ They have become tired of flowing, ” they pour, and become copious], she means OafovaOato. (M.)

OafovaWuwA lahu They heated stones for him (i. e. a sick man), and sprinkled water upon them, and he lay prostrate upon them, in order that he might sweat: (O, K:) this they did when they were unable to procure a hot bath. (O.)
7: see 1, last sentence but two.
faAviYN as an epithet applied to milk: see 1, near the end.

1. favaja i. q. naqaSa [accord. to the TK in a trans. sense, for it is there said that favaj AlXRaIoCa, aor.
favuja
, inf. n. favojN, signifies He, or it, diminished the thing]; (AA, O, K;) said in this sense in relation to anything. (AA, O.)

[Hence, app., though perhaps the verb in each of these three phrases may be the aor. of Oufovija↓,] biYorN laA tufovaju means A well that will not become exhausted: and fulaAnN baHorN laA yufovaju Such a one is a sea that will not become exhausted: (S, O:) and maMCN laA yufovaju Water that will not become exhausted; or, accord. to A 'Obeyd, of which the bottom will not be reached [app. by drawing therefrom]. (TA.) And favojN [or favojN maMCK mino mawoDiEK] means A drawing of water from a place. (KL.)
And favaja AlmaMCa AlHaArRa biAlbaAridi He abated, or allayed, somewhat of the heat of the hot water with the cold. (O, K. [Compare favaOa.])

favojN [as inf. n. of favajat] used in relation to a she-camel signifies [The being such as is termed faAvijN in any of the senses assigned to it below: or simply] the being pregnant: as also fasojN. (KL.)

And favaja, (O, K, TA,) inf. n. favojN, (O,) said of a man, (TA,) signifies Oavoqala; (thus in the O and in copies of the K; [but accord. to the TK, Ouvoqila, for it is there said that the meaning is He (a man) was, or became, burdened, or heavy;]) as also favRaja↓, (O, K,) inf. n. tavofiyjN. (O.)
2: see what next precedes.
4. Afvj i. q. taraka: (O, K:) you say, OafovajaniI, meaning He left, or relinquished, me, (tarakaniI,) and left me alone: (O:) and so Afsj EanRiI. (Thus in the O in art. fsj.)

Also, (S, O, K,) accord. to Ks, (S, O,) like OafovaOa, (TA,) and so Oufovija, (O, K,) this last, in the pass. form, mentioned by IAar, (TA,) He (a man, TA) was, or became, tired, and out of breath, (S, O, K,) from running. (S, O.)
See also 1, second sentence.

faAvijN, applied to a she-camel, Pregnant; (As, S, O, K;) and so faAsijN: (As, S:) or youthful, and having conceived: (As, S:) or having conceived, and become goodly: (AO, S:) or having conceived, and become fat, being youthful: (TA:) pl. fawaAviju. (S, O.) And, so applied, i. q. HaAYilN
[i. e. One not conceiving during a year, or two years, or some years], and fat: (O, K:) thus having two contr. significations. (K.) And, (K,) accord. to IDrd, (O,) A she-camel having a large hump, and fat; (O, K;) and so though she be not HaAYil. (O.)

faAvuwrN A [basin such as is termed] Tasot; (M, L, K;) thus it means with the vulgar: (L:) or a Tasot of gold, or of silver: (O:) or the TasotaxaAn, (T, K,) or TaXotaxaAn, (O, and so in some copies of the K,) [i. e. a large circular tray, of brass or other metal, which serves as a table for food, being generally placed upon a stool, the persons who eat sitting on the floor]; (Lth, T, Z, O, K;) thus it means with the vulgar: (Lth, T, Z, O:) or a xiwaAn [or table upon which food is eaten], made of marble, (Lth, T, S, M, O, K,) by the people of Syria, who thus call it, (Lth, T, O,) or of silver, (T, S, M,) and the like, (S,) or of gold: (M, K:) or of any kind accord. to some: (TA:) or a jaAm [q. v.] of silver, (T, Nh, TA,) or of gold: (Nh, TA:) [but this seems to be virtually a repetition; for it is said that] faAvuwriyRapN↓, occurring in a verse of Lebeed, means OaxowinapN [pl. of pauc. of xiwaAnN] (T, O) and jaAmaAtN [which is pl. of jaAmN accord. to IAar, or of jaAmapN accord. to IB, who holds jaAmN to be likewise a pl. of jaAmapN]: (T:) faAvuwrN is a word of the people of Syria and ElJezeereh: (M:) and it signifies (S, O, L) in the dial. of the people of El-Jezeereh, (L,) a maAYidap [sometimes meaning table in an absolute sense, but properly one with food upon it]: (S, O, L:) [hence,] one says, humo EalaI faAvuwrK waAHidK (Lth, T, S, M, O, L, TA) i. e. EalaI maAYidapK waAHidapK, (S, O, L, TA,) and manozilapK waAHidapK, (S, O, TA,) and basaATK waAHidK, (O, TA, [in both of which the former word is without any vowel-sign to the b so that it may be either basaATK or bisaATK,]) or basoTK wAHdK, (TT as from the M,) or as though meaning ElI bsATK wAHdK, thus expl. by Lth, as said of the people of Syria and El-Jezeereh: (TT as from the T:) [it means, app., They are living upon one kind of fare; upon one footing; upon one level or stratum:] in the copies of the K, [or in the generality of the copies thereof,] AlfaAvuwru is expl. as signifying Almanozilapu and AlnRaXaATu; but AlnXAT is a mistake for AlbsAT. (TA. [My MS. copy of the K has the right reading (AlbsAT), without any trace of alteration.])
Also (tropical:) The breast, or bosom: (K:) or a wide breast or bosom; applied by a poet to that of a woman; as being likened to the xiwaAn so called. (M.)
And (tropical:) The disk of the sun (S, * O, K) is called its fAvwr as being likened to the Tasot so called. (O.)
And (tropical:) A [bowl such as is termed] jafonap; (M, K, TA;) thus with [the tribe of] Rabee'ah; (M, TA;) for the like reason. (TA.)
And A [vessel such as is termed] naAjuwd and baATiyap (AA, T, O, K) and miSoHaAp; all which words mean the same thing. (AA, O, TA.)
And, accord. to the R, A [molten piece such as is termed] sabiykap of silver: and some say, a silver Uiboriyq [or ewer]. (TA.)
Also A company of men upon the frontier of a hostile country, that go after the enemy, in pursuit. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
And A spy; syn. jaAsuwsN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
faAvuwriyRapN: see the preceding paragraph, former half.
4. AfvI He was, or became, tired, (K, TA,) and languid; from running [&c.]. (TA. [But this is for OafovaOa: see an ex. in a verse cited in art. fvO.])

1. fajRa, (TA,) [see. pers. fajijota, aor. yafajRu,] inf. n. fajajN, (S, * O, * K, * TA,) He had the feet wide apart: or, said of a man, he had the knees wide apart: and, said of a beast, or quadruped, he had the hocks wide apart: (TA:) fajajN↓ is more ugly than what is termed faHajN. (S, O, K.)
See also 7.

fajRa rijolayohi, (TA,) and fajRa maA bayona rijolayohi, (S, O, K, TA,) aor. yafujRu, inf. n. fajRN, (S, O, TA,) He opened [or parted] his legs (S, O, K, TA) widely; [i. e. he straddled;] (TA;) and so AfjR↓, (K,) or AfjR rijolayohi, he parted his legs widely, said of a man and of a beast; (O;) so too fAjR↓ [alone], and fajaA; (TA;) and one says also tfAjR↓ [meaning the same], of one walking, (S, K, TA,) and meaning he did thus to make water, (Mgh, TA,) as also fAjR↓, inf. n. fijaAjN and mufaAjRapN, both of these verbs said of a man; but tfAjR↓ signifies he parted his legs very widely; (TA;) and tfAjRt↓ is said of a she-camel, (A, O,) liloHalobi [to be milked]; (A;) and of a sheep or goat (XaAp). (O.) walaA yabuwlu maA XaIoCN yufaAjRu↓ [What is a thing that straddles and will not make water?] is an enigma: it is a thing like a couch, having four legs. (A, TA.) AlfajRu in the language of the Arabs is The making an opening, or interval, between two things. (TA.)
And fajajotu Alqawosa, (S, O, K,) aor. OafujRuhaA, (S, O,) inf. n. fajRN, (TA,) I raised the string of the bow [so as to make it distant] from its kabid[q. v.]; (S, O, K;) like fajawotuhaA. (S, O.)
fajRa AlOaroDa, (so in the O,) or AlArDa AfjR↓, (so in the K,) He clave the ground, or earth, with the plough, in a manner not approved. (O, K.)
fajRa said of a horse &c., He purposed, or desired, to run. (TA.)
See also fajaAjapN.
2. tafojiyjN The making [a thing] to be crude [or not thoroughly cooked]. (KL.) [See fijRN.]
3: see 1, in three places.
4. AfjR: see 1, former half.
Also, (L,) or OafajRato, (S, O, L, K,) He, or she, (i. e. an ostrich) muted.
And, the former, He travelled a road such as is termed fajR; (O, L, K;) said of a man; (O;) as also AftjR↓. (L.)
And He, (a man, S, O,) or it, (a thing, Msb,) hastened, went quickly, or was quick; (S, O, Msb, K;) mentioned by IAar. (S.)
See also 1, near the end.
6: see 1, in three places.

7. AnfjRt Alqawosu, (A,) inf. n. AinofijaAjN, (O,) The bow had its string distant from its kabid [q. v.]; (A, O;) [and so, app., fajRat↓, for] fajajN↓, in a bow, signifies the state of having the string distant from the kabid thereof. (S, O.)
8: see 4.

fajRN A wide road between two mountains; (S, A, O, K;) and fujaAjN↓ signifies the same: (O, K:) or, in a mountain: (AHeyth, TA:) or, in the anterior part of a mountain, wider than a XiEob [q. v.]: (TA:) or a depressed road: (Th, TA:) or a conspicuous and wide road: (Msb:) or a far-extending beaten track or road: (AHeyth, TA: [see an ex. in a verse cited voce EimoqN:]) or, accord. to ISh, [a track] as though it were a road; and sometimes it is a road between two mountains, (L, TA,) or having on either side what is termed a faOow [a word variously explained], (so in the L,) or between two walls (HaAYiTayoni), (so in the TA,) and extending to the distance of two days' journey, or three, if a road or not a road; and if a road, abounding with herbage: (L, TA:) pl. [of mult.] fijaAjN (Th, S, O, Msb) and [of pauc.] OafijRapN, which is extr. [with respect to analogy], (Th, TA,) and OafujRN. (Msb.)
See also the next paragraph, in two places.
fijRN, with kesr, The Syrian biTRiyx [i. e. melon or water-melon], (S, A, O, K,) which the Persians call the Indian. (S, A, O.)

And fijRN, (so in the S and A and K,) or fajRN↓, (thus in the O, and by implication in the Msb, [and thus pronounced in the present day,]) signifies Unripe; (S, A, O, Msb, K;) applied to fruit (A, Msb, K) of any kind, (A,) &c.; (Msb;) to anything of melons (biTRiyx) and of other fruits; (S, O;) and so fajaAjapN↓; (O, K;) but fajRN↓ and fajaAjapN↓ are not mentioned by Ed-Deenawaree [i. e. AHn; and the latter (which see below) I think doubtful in the sense expl. above]. (O.)
fujRapN An opening, or intervening space, (O, K, TA,) between two mountains. (TA.)
fajajN an inf. n.: (TA:) see 1, first sentence:
and see also 7.
fujujN [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] i. q. vuqalaMCu [Such as are heavy, slow, sluggish, &c.], (IAar, O, K,) of men. (IAar, O.)
fujaAjN: see fajRN.
fijaAjN A male ostrich which [they assert, like as they say of the domestic cock, (see EuqorN,]) lays one egg. (TA.)
fajaAjapN [app. an inf. n., of which the verb is fajRa↓, sec. pers. fajujota,] The state of being unripe, or not sufficiently cooked. (TA.)
See also fijRN, in two places.
fajRaAnN The stem (Euwd) of the raceme of a palmtree: mentioned by ISd; and held by him to be of the measure faEolaAnN because this is more common than the measure faERaAlN. (TA.)
fajofajN and fujofujN: see fajofaAjN.
fajofajapN Loquacity, or much talking: or frivolous babbling: or much talking, and boasting of abundance which one does not possess: or clamouring: or great and disorderly talking. (TA.)

fajofaAjN, applied to a man, Loquacious; a great talker: (S:) or a frivolous babbler: (TA:) or, as also fajofajN↓ (O, K) and fujofujN↓ (K) and fujaAfijN↓, (O, but there written fajaAfijN,) a great talker, who boasts of abundance which he does not possess: (O, K:) or clamourous: or a great and disorderly talker: fem. with p. (TA.) The poet Aboo-'Árim El-Kilábee applies the first of these epithets to palm-trees (naxiyl) [as meaning (assumed tropical:) Promising much fruit, but not fulfilling the promise]. (L, TA.)
fujaAfijN: see the next preceding paragraph.

OafajRu A man having his legs wide apart; who straddles; (S, * O, * L, K, * TA;) as also mufijRu↓ AlsRaAqayoni; (L, TA;) [and mufaAjRN↓, for] one says yamoXiI mufaAjRFA he walks with his legs wide apart, or straddling: (S, A, K:) or OafajRu signifies having his thighs wide apart. (IAar, TA.)

And qawosN fajRaMCu A bow of which the curved ends are elevated so that its string is distant from the part where it is grasped by the hand: (L:) or of which the string is distant from its kabid [q. v.]; (S, O, K;) as also munofajRapN↓: (A, O, K:) and so qawosN fajowaMCu. (S, O.)
