UifojiyjN A valley: (O, K:) or a wide valley: (K:) or a narrow and deep valley, (IDrd, O, K,) in the dial. of the people of El-Yemen, but others apply this appellation to any valley. (O.)
mufijRu AlsRaAqayoni: see OafajRu.
HaAfirN mufijRN A solid hoof that is round like a cupola, syn. muqabRabN, (S, O, K, TA,) [and] hard: (TA:) such is approved. (S, O.)
mufaAjRN: see OafajRu.
qawosN munofajRapN: see OafajRu.
OaroDN munofajRapN Ground, or earth, that is cleft [app. with the plough, in a manner not approved: see 1, near the end]. (TA.)

1. fajiYahu, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) and fajaOahu, (S, O, Msb, K,) the former of which is the more chaste, (TA,) aor.
fajaAa
, (Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. fujaMCapN↓, (S, O, K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and fajoCN, (K, TA,) or fajoOapN↓, (so accord. to the CK, and Ham p. 44,) or this last also is a simple subst.; (Msb;) and fAjOhu↓, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. mufaAjaOapN (S, O, Msb) and fijaMCN; (S, O;) and AftjOhu↓; (K;) It (an affair, or event, S, O, Msb) came upon him, or happened to him, suddenly, or at unawares, (Mgh, K, TA,) unexpectedly, (Mgh,) without his having knowledge of it, (Mgh, TA,) or without any previous cause; (TA;) or hastily; syn. EaAjalahu: (Msb:) [it surprised him; or took him by surprise:] and [in like manner] one says, fajiYotu AlrRajula, and fajaOotuhu, meaning I came upon the man suddenly, or at unawares. (Msb.)

And fajaOa AlmaroOapa, (O, K,) aor.
fajaAa
, inf. n. fajoCN, (TA,) He compressed the woman. (O, K. *)

fajiYati AlnRaAqapu, (IAmb, O, K,) aor.
fajaAa
, (K,) inf. n. fajaON, (IAmb, O,) The she-camel became big in her belly. (IAmb, O, K.)
And fajaOa is said in the A to be syn. with zaAda [It increased, &c.]. (TA.)
3: see above, first sentence.
[Hence,] fuwjiYa He was taken away by a sudden death; he died suddenly. (S in art. fwt.)
4. AfjO He found, or lighted on, [or surprised,] his friend doing a disgraceful thing. (IAar, TA.)
8: see 1, first sentence.
fajoOapN: see 1, first sentence:
and see also what here follows.
fujaMCapN: see 1, first sentence.

Also A sudden, or an unexpected, event; a thing that comes upon one suddenly, or at unawares. (K, TA.) Hence, mawotu AlfujaMCapi [Sudden death]: written by some AlfajoOapi↓, as an inf. n. of unity. (TA.)
AlmufaAjiYu The lion. (Sgh, in his tract on the names of the lion; and K.)

1. fajara, aor.
fajura
, (T, L, Msb,) inf. n. fajorN, (T, Mgh, L, Msb,) He clave, [a thing]; cut, or divided, [it] lengthwise: this is the primary signification, whence several others, to be mentioned below, are derived: (T, L:) he clave, and opened. (Mgh.) He clave, or cut, a subterranean channel for water. (Msb.) He broke open a dam of a river or the like, that the water might break, burst, or pour, through. (T, L.)

And fajara AlmaMCa, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (S, O;) and fjRrhu↓, (S, O, K,) inf. n. tafojiyrN; (O, TA;) but the latter is with teshdeed to denote muchness, or frequency, or repetition, of the action, or its application to many objects; (S, O, TA;) He opened a way, passage, vent, or channel, for the water to flow forth; gave vent to it; vented it: (S, Mgh, O, Msb:) he made the water to flow, run, or stream: (K:) and in like manner, blood, or other fluid. (TA.) [See also 4.]

fajara, aor.
fajura
, inf. n. fujuwrN, (S, O, Msb, K, &c.,) He, or it, inclined; leant; declined; or deviated. (S, O, TA.) You say, fajara AlrRaAkibu, (K,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (K,) (tropical:) The rider leant, or declined, from his saddle. (K.)
[Hence,] He declined, or deviated, from the truth; (K, * TA;) as also Afjr↓. (IAar, O, K.)
And He erred in answering, or replying. (El-Muärrij.)

Hence also, (S,) He lied; (S, O, Msb, K;) said of a swearer; (Msb;) as also Afjr↓: (IAar, O, K:) in this sense the former has also fajorN for an inf. n., as well as fujuwrN: (TA:) he committed a foul deed; such as swearing a false oath, or lying: in which sense also it has both of these inf. ns. (TA.)

He committed an unlawful action: (ISh:) [or, as it is generally explained, and most frequently used,] he acted vitiously, immorally, unrighteously, sinfully, or wickedly; he transgressed; went forth from, departed from, or quitted, the way of truth, or the right way; forsook, relinquished, or neglected, the command of God; departed from obedience; disobeyed; syn. fasaqa; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) and EaSaI (Mgh, K) and xaAlafa: (K:) and [in like manner] fAjr↓, inf. n. mufaAjarapN and fijaArN, he did that which was vitious, immoral, unrighteous, sinful, or wicked. (R, TA.) In the sense of ESI (Mgh, O, TA) and xAlf (O, TA) it is also trans.: you say fajarahu, meaning He disobeyed him; (Mgh, O, TA;) he opposed him. (O, TA.)
He launched forth into acts of disobedience; in which sense it has both of the inf. ns. mentioned above; (K, TA;) and is [said to be] from fajara in the first of the significations expl. above. (TA.)

He disbelieved; syn. kafara; (TA;) as also Afjr↓: (IAar, O, K:) and fajara bihi he disbelieved in it; syn. kacRab. (O, K. *) The following passage of the Kur, balo yuriydu QloUinosaAnu liyafojura OamaAmahu, [lxxv. 5], is said to mean, [But man desireth, or nay, doth man desire,] to disbelieve in that which is before him, [or that which is to come,] namely, the resurrection and reckoning and retribution: (O, TA:) or to continue in his fujuwr [i. e. vice, immorality, wickedness, unrighteousness, or the like,] in the time to come: (Bd:) or to go on therein undeviatingly: (El-Hasan El-Basree, O:) or to defer repentance, and to do evil deeds first: (O, TA:) or to multiply sins, and to postpone repentance: or to say I will repent at a future time. (TA.)
He did, or committed, an action inducing doubt, or suspicion or evil opinion, or doubt combined with suspicion or evil opinion. (IKtt, TA.)

He committed adultery, or fornication; (Msb, K;) in which sense it has both of the inf. ns. mentioned above; (K;) and Afjr↓ signifies the same; (IAar, K;) and, this latter, he committed an act, or acts, of disobedience with his genital member. (IAar, TA.) You say fajara biQlomaroOapi He committed adultery, or fornication, with the woman: and fajarati QlomaroOapu The woman committed adultery, or fornication. (TA.)
He pursued a headlong, or rash, or random, course, and went away, not caring whither. (El-Muärrij.)

fajara Oamoruhumo
Their case, or state of affairs, became bad. (K.)
And fajara signifies also He became dim, or dull, in his sight. (O, K.)
And fajara mino maraDihi He became free from his disease. (O, K.)
2. fjRrhu: see 1, near the beginning.

Also He attributed or imputed to him, or charged him with, or accused him of, fujuwr [i. e. vice, immorality, unrighteousness, &c. (see 1)]; like fasRaqahu: whence the phrase, in a trad. of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr, fajRarota binafosika [Thou hast attributed to thyself, or accused thyself of, unrighteousness, transgression, or the like]. (TA.)
3. fAjr, inf. n. mufaAjiripN and fijaArN: see 1, in the middle of the paragraph. [And see also fijaArN, below.]
4. AfjrhN He made it (i. e. a spring, or source,) to well forth. (O, K.) [See also 1.]
And [hence, app.,] (assumed tropical:) He made [his gift] large; syn. Oajozala. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)
Afjr as intrans.: see 1, in four places.
Also Afjrhu He found him to be a person such as is termed faAjirN. (O, K.)

And Afjr is like ASbH; (S, O;) signifying He entered upon the time of daybreak, or dawn: (K, TA:) and he was near to entering upon that time. (TA.) One says, kunotu OaHulRu UicaA OasoHarotu waOaroHalu UicaA Oafojarotu [I used to alight when I entered upon the last sixth of the night, and depart when I entered upon the time of daybreak]. (S, TA.) And OuEarRisu UicaA Oafojarotu waOaroHalu UicaA Oasofarotu, i. e., I alight to sleep when I am near to entering upon the time of daybreak, and I depart when [I enter upon the time in which] the dawn shines. (TA, from a trad.)
Also He brought much property; (O, K;) this being termed fajarN. (O.)
5: see the next paragraph, in four places.

7. Anfjr (S, O, Msb, K) and tfjRr↓, (S, O, K,) but the latter is with teshdeed [as quasi-pass. of 2,] to denote muchness, or frequency, or repetition, or application to many subjects of the action, (S, O, *) It (water) had a way, passage, vent, or channel, opened for it to flow forth; it had vent; (S, O, Msb;) it poured out, or forth, as though impelled or propelled; syn. AinobaEava; (TA;) it flowed, ran, or streamed. (Msb, K.)

[Hence,] Anfjr Ealayohimu AlEaduwRu (tropical:) The enemy [poured upon them;] came upon them suddenly, in great number. (L, A.) And Anfjrt Ealayohimu AldRawaAhiI (tropical:) Calamities [poured upon them;] came upon them from every quarter, (K, * TA,) abundantly and suddenly. (TA.)

[Hence also,] Anfjr biQlokarami, and tfjRr↓ bihi (assumed tropical:) [He was profuse of generosity, or liberality]: (K:) and fiI Alxayori tfjRr↓ (assumed tropical:) [he was profuse in bounty, or beneficence]. (S, O, TA.)
And Anfjr AlSRuboHu, and tfjRr↓, [The dawn broke forth]: and Anfjr Eanohu AllRayolu [The night departed from before it; namely, the rising dawn]. (K.)
8. Aftjr fiI AlkalaAmi He forged speech, not having heard it from any one, nor learned it. (O, K.)

fajorN [Daybreak; dawn;] the light of morning; (Mgh, K;) because it is a cleaving of the darkness from before the light; (Mgh;) i. e., the redness of the sun in the darkness of night; (K;) the fajor in the end of the night is like the Xafaq in the beginning thereof: (S, O:) it is twofold: the first is called Alfajoru AlkaAcibu [the false dawn]; that which rises without extending laterally, (AlmusotaTiylu, Mgh, Msb,) which appears black, presenting itself like an obstacle (muEotariDFA) [on the horizon]: (Msb:) [see canabu AlsRiroHaAni, in art. srH:] the second is called Alfajoru AlSRaAdiqu [the true dawn]; which is the rising and spreading [dawn], (AlmusotaTiyru, Mgh, Msb,) which appears rising, and fills the horizon with its whiteness; and this is what is called Eamuwdu AlSRuboHi; rising after the former has disappeared; and by its rising the day commences, and everything by which fasting would be broken becomes unlawful to the faster. (Msb.)
Hence, The time of the fajor. (Mgh.)
And The prayer of that time: the prefixed noun being suppressed. (Mgh.)

Alfajoru and AlbaHoru [in a saying mentioned voce baHorN, the former here written Alfajaru, and said to be muHarRakap, but app. by mistake, for it is afterwards written Alfajoru,] are metonymically applied to (tropical:) The troubles of the present state of existence. (TA.)
fajarN (assumed tropical:) Donation; (K;) generosity; (AO, S, K;) bounty, or munificence; (K;) or large, or ample, bounty or munificence; (AO, TA;) and goodness, or beneficence. (K.)
And Property. (Kr, K.) And Much property. (O.) And Abundance of property. (K, TA.) Aboo-Mihjen EthThakafee says,

L.foreign: faqado Oajuwdu wamaA maAliI biciI fajarK

sense.s: [And verily, or often, I practise liberality, or bounty, while my property is not abundant]. (TA.)
fujaru: see faAjirN, latter half.

fajorapu is a proper name, [i. e. an attributive proper name,] imperfectly decl., like barRapu; [and signifies the same as Alfajorapu and fajaAri;] and fajaAri↓ is altered from fajorapN, (IJ, TA,) or from Alfajorapu, (Sb, TA,) and is a subst. in the sense of Alfujuwru [i. e. Vice, immorality, wickedness, unrighteousness, sin, or transgression, &c., (see 1,)] (S,) or a name for Alfajorapu [which signifies the same], (O,) like qaTaAmi, (S, O,) determinate, (S,) occurring in a verse of En-Nábighah cited in the first paragraph of art. Hml. (S, O.) One says, rakiba fulaAnN fajorapa, (K, * TA, [in the CK fajarapa,]) and fajaAri↓, (TA,) Such a one lied; (K, TA;) and acted vitiously &c. (fajara). (TA.) And Halafa fulaAnN EalaI fajorapa, and AiXotamala EalaI fajorapa, [in the L ElI fajorihi, in both instances, but the former is the right reading,] Such a one commited a foul deed, by swearing falsely, [relating to the former phrase,] or by adultery, or fornication, or lying. (TA.)
fujorapN: see mafojarN, in two places.
fijorapN The last of a woman's children; like as zinoyapN signifies the “ last of a man's children. ” (TA in art. znI.)
fajaAri: see fajorapu, in two places:
and see faAjirN, last sentence but one.
fijaArN [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] Roads, or ways; (K, TA;) like fijaAjN [pl. of fajRN, q. v.]. (TA.)

OayRaAmu AlfijaAri is an appellation applied to Four Oafojirap; (K, TA;) the four Oafojirap meaning days [i. e. conflicts] of the Arabs; the single day thereof being termed AlfijaAru: (S, O, TA:) they took place at 'Okádh; and those engaged therein transgressed, and held to be allowable everything that should be sacred; as is said in the A: they were called fijaAru AlrRajuli and fijaAru AlmaroOapi and fijaAru Alqirodi and fijaAru AlbarRaADi; the last, which was the greatest onslaught, being thus called in relation to El-Barrád Ibn-Keys, who slew 'Orweh Er-Rahhál: (TA:) they were between Kureysh with their associates of Kináneh on the one side and Keys-'Eylán on the other side, (S, O, K,) in the Time of Ignorance; (S, O;) and the [final] defeat befell Keys; it occurred in the sacred months; and when they fought therein, they said fajaronaA; (S, O, K;) therefore Kureysh called this war fijaAr; (S, O, TA; *) fijaArN, like mufaAjarapN, being an inf. n. of faAjara, expl. above, on the authority of the R. (TA.)
And fijaAraAtu AlEarabi signifies The vyings of the Arabs in glorying, or boasting. (TA.)
fajuwrN: see the paragraph here following.
faAjirN Inclining, leaning, declining, or deviating. (S, TA.) Declining (saAqiTN) from the road. (IAar, TA.)

Lying; a liar; because he deviates from the right course: and for the same reason it signifies also mukacRibN [as meaning disbelieving; or a disbeliever; see fajara bihi, in the middle of the first paragraph]. (TA.) And one says yamiynN faAjirapN meaning (tropical:) A false oath: (Mgh in art. gms:) a tropical phrase. (Mgh in the present art.)

faAjirN and fajuwrN↓, (K, TA,) the latter of which is applied to a woman as well as to a man, (TA,) and faAjuwrN↓, (K, TA,) which is mentioned by Sgh, (TA,) are all epithets from fajara, and signify [most frequently Acting vitiously, immorally, unrighteously, sinfully, or wickedly; or vitious, immoral, &c.; transgressing, or a transgressor; quitting, or one who quits, the way of truth, or justice; forsaking, or a forsaker of, the command of God; departing, or a departer, from the right way, or from obedience; disobedient; or] launching forth, or one who launches forth, into acts of disobedience: [but the second and third are intensive epithets:] also committing adultery or fornication; or an adulterer or a fornicator: (K, TA:) and the first signifies also enchanting, or an enchanter: (Sgh, K, TA:) the pl. of the first is fujRaArN and fajarapN; and the pl. of the second
and third is fujurN. (K, TA.) fujaru↓ is altered from faAjirN, for the sake of intensiveness, and is [determinate, and] seldom used except in the vocative form of speech: you say [in addressing a number of men] yaA lafujara [for yaA Mla fujara, like as you say yaA lagudara for yaA Mla gudara, q. v.; and meaning O ye very vitious, &c.]; occurring in a trad. of 'Áïsheh. (TA.) And fajaAri↓, (K, TA,) like qaTaAmi, (TA,) is a noun altered from AlfaAjirapu (K, TA) [or from faAjirapu]: you say (S, O, K) to a woman (S, O) yaA fajaAri (S, O, K) meaning yaA faAjirapu [O vitious woman, &c.]. (S, O.)
And faAjirN signifies also Having much wealth, or property: (K, TA:) in this sense, a possessive epithet [from fajarN, q. v.]. (TA.)
faAjuwrN: see the next preceding paragraph.

mafojarN (TA) and mafojarapN↓ and munofajarN↓ (K) and fujorapN↓ (S, K) A place through which water flows (K, TA) from a watering-trough &c.; (TA;) a place of opening for water: (S, O, TA:) and the second signifies also low ground into which valleys pour their water: (M, K, TA:) pl. mafaAjiru. (TA.) mafaAjiru AlwaAdiI signifies The parts, of the valley, into which the torrent disperses itself: (S, O, TA:) and AlwaAdiI fujorapu↓, (K, TA,) which would seem to be with fet-h [to the f] from its not being restricted by the mention of any syll. signs, [and is so in the CK,] but is correctly with damm, (TA,) the wide part of the valley, into which the water pours. (K, TA.) And mafaAjiru AldRibaAri signifies The places opened for the flowing of the water of the dbAr, pl. of daborapN [q. v.]. (Mgh.)
mafojarapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
munofajarN: see mafojarN.
munofajaru ramolK (tropical:) A road, or way, in sands. (S, O, TA.)

1. fajasa, aor.
fajusa
, (S, TA,) inf. n. fajosN, (S, O, K, TA,) He behaved proudly, or magnified himself; (S, O, K, TA;) as also tfjRs↓; (S, * K;) or this latter signifies he magnified, or exalted, himself, (O, TA,) and boasted: (O, * TA:) and fajozN signifies the same as fajosN, i. e. the “ behaving proudly, or magnifying oneself. ” (TA.)
And He overcame, or subdued, or oppressed. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K: but only the inf. n. of the verb in this and the following sense is mentioned.)
He did an unprecedented act, and only one of an evil kind. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, TA.)
4. Afjs He (a man) boasted vainly, or falsely. (IAar, O, K.)
5: see 1, first sentence. tfjRs AlsRaHaAbu biAlmaTari The clouds burst with rain: (L, TA:) [app. a dial. var. of tbjRs.]

1. fajaEahu, (S, MA, O, K,) aor.
fajaEa
, (O, K,) inf. n. fajoEN (MA, O) and fajiyEapN; (MA; [or this is a simple subst.;]) and fjREhu↓, inf. n. tafojiyEN, (S, K,) or the latter verb has an intensive meaning; (O, TA;) It pained him; (S, MA, O, K;) afflicted, or distressed, him; disordered him, or rendered him diseased: (MA:) one says, fajaEatohu AlmuSiybapu The affliction, calamity, or misfortune, pained him: (S, O:) or fajoEN [expl. as the inf. n. of the pass. verb] signifies a man's being pained by the loss of a thing that is highly esteemed by him (yakorumu Ealayohi); (Lth, O, K, TA;) such as property or cattle, and offspring, and a relation, or person beloved: (TA:) you say, fujiEa bimaAlihi (Lth, O, K) and biwaladihi (Lth, O) [He was pained by the loss of his property or cattle, and his offspring]: and fajaEotuhu fiI maAlihi and Oaholihi [I pained, afflicted, or distressed, him, in, or in respect of, his property or cattle, and his family], aor.
fajaEa
, inf. n. fajoEN. (Msb.)
2: see the preceding paragraph.

5. tfjRE He (a man, S, O) expressed, or manifested, pain, affliction, or distress; or uttered lamentation, or complaint; syn. tawajRaEa; (S, O, K, TA;) lahu [by reason of it]; (S;) or lilomuSiybapi [by reason of the calamity, or misfortune; (O, K, TA;) and writhed, or cried out and writhed; by reason of it. (TA.)
fajuwEN: see faAjiEN, in two places.
fajiyEN: see mafojuwEN.

fajiyEapN, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) of which the pl. is fajaAYiEu, (Msb, TA,) i. q. raziyRapN [i. e. An affliction, a calamity, or a misfortune; or such as is occasioned by the loss of things dear to one: or a great affliction or calamity or misfortune]: (S, O, Msb, K, TA:) accord. to ISd, such as pains by [the loss of] what is highly esteemed: (TA:) and faAjiEapN↓ signifies the same; (S, * O, * Msb, K; *) pl. fawaAjiEu. (O, Msb.)

mawotN faAjiEN and fajuwEN↓ Death that pains [or afflicts or distresses] men by [attendant] calamities: (O, K, TA:) and in like manner, dahorN faAjiEN (O, TA) and fajuwEN↓ [time, or fortune, that pains &c.]. (TA.) And mayRitN faAjiEN [A person dead, or dying, that causes pain or affliction or distress], and [likewise] mfjE↓ [app. mufojiEN], as being from OafojaEa, though this [is a verb which] has not been used: thus in the L. (TA.)

[Hence,] AlfaAjiEu The raven of separation or disunion (guraAbu Albayoni); (O, K, TA;) so called because [they assert that] it pains [or afflicts] men by separation or disunion: (O, TA:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (TA.)

And one says AimoraOapN faAjiEN, (O, K,) mentioned, but not expl., by IDrd, as though he regarded it [i. e. the latter word] as [a possessive epithet, i. e.] of the same class as laAbinN and taAmirN, (O,) meaning A woman having [or suffering] a fajiyEap [q. v.], (O, K,) i. e. a raziyRap. (K.) And rajulN faAjiEN and mutafajRiEN↓ A man grieving, or lamenting, [and] doing so most intensely. (TA.)
faAjiEapN [as a subst.]: see fajiyEapN.
OafojaEu [More, and most, pain-giving or afflicting or distressing]. (O, TA.)
mfjE [app. mufojiEN]: see faAjiEN.
mufajRaEN: see what next follows.

mafojuwEN A man [pained, afflicted, or distressed; or] smitten by an affliction such as is termed raziyRap [and fajiyEap, q. v.]; as also fajiyEN↓, and [in an intensive sense] mufajRaEN↓. (TA.) You say, huwa mafojuwEN fiI maAlihi and Oaholihi [He is pained, &c., in, or in respect of, his property, or cattle, and his family]. (Msb.)
mutafajRiEN: see faAjiEN, last sentence.

1. fajila, aor.
fajala
, inf. n. fajalN; (Msb, K;) and fajula, (O,) or fajala, (K,) aor.
fajula
, (O, K,) inf. n. fajolN; (K;) He, or it, was, or became, thick, and soft, or flaccid: (O, Msb, K:) so says Ibn- 'Abbád. (O.)
2. fjRlhu, inf. n. tafojiylN, He made it broad, or wide. (K.)

8. Aftjl OamorFA, (K,) or Oamorahu, (Ibn-'Abbád, O,) He forged [a case or matter &c., or his case &c.]; syn. Aixotalaqahu; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K;) and invented it, or excogitated it; syn. AixotaraEahu. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

fujolN (S, O, K) and fujulN↓, (O, K,) both mentioned by AHn, (O, TA,) or fijolN↓, (Msb,) thus, with kesr, commonly pronounced by the vulgar, (TA,) [The radish, raphanus sativus; (Forskål's Flora Ægypt. Arab., lxix. no. 327; and Delile's Floræ Ægypt. Illustr., no. 608;)] a certain Oaruwmap [or root of the kind termed rhizoma], (K, TA,) that occasions abominable eructation; (TA;) a herb, (Msb,) well known: (S, Msb:) said by IDrd to be not a genuine Arabic word; and thought by him to be derived from fajila signifying as expl. above: (Msb:) n. un. with p, (K,) i. e. fujolapN (S, O) and fujulapN (O) [and fijolapN]: it is a gardenplant, found in abundance; and there is a Syrian sort, said to be produced by putting together the seeds of the colza and [those of] the fjl: (TA:) it (i. e. each sort, TA) is good for pain of the joints, and jaundice, (K, TA,) and sciatica, and the niqoris [i. e. gout, or specially in the foot or feet], (TA,) and pain of the liver (K, TA) arising from cold, (TA,) and the biting and stinging of vipers and scorpions: (K, TA: [several other supposed properties thereof mentioned in the K, and many more mentioned in the TA, I omit as unimportant:]) what is most potent thereof is its seed; then, its peel; then, its leaf; then, its flesh. (K, TA.) What is called HabRu Alfujoli is Another
remedial thing: (K:) this fjl is not of the species of herb mentioned above: (O, Msb, TA:) so says AHn: the hakeem Dáwood says, it is one of the species of this fjl, a wild species, elongated, abounding in the Sa'eed of Egypt: (TA:) [it is the raphanus oleifer, mentioned by Delile (Floræ Ægypt. Illustr., no. 609,) as cultivated in Nubia and in Egypt, and called in Arabic “ symâgah: ”] from it (or from its seed, TA) is made the oil of the fjl (duhonu Alfuijoli); (Msb, K, TA;) and it is known by the appellation of AlsRayomaEapu [correctly AlsRayomagapu]. (TA.) [Delile, ubi suprà, no. 571, mentions fijol Aljamal, as a name of The cakile maritima of Tournefort; the bunias cakile of Linn.: and in the same, no. 396, he mentions fijol Aljabal as the Arabic name of The rumex spinosus of Linn.; as does also Forskål, in his work cited above, p. lxv., no. 213, and again in p. 76.]
fijolN: see the next preceding paragraph.
fujulN: see the next preceding paragraph.
fajRaAlN A seller of fujol [or radishes]. (TA.)
faAjilN i. q. qaAmirN [Playing, or a player, at a game of hazard]: (O, K, TA:) so says IAar: (O, TA:) accord. to some copies of the K, i. q. faAjirN, which is a mistake. (TA.)
fanojalN: see Oafojalu.
fanojalapN (S, K) and fanojalaI↓ (K) A manner of walking in which is a laxness, or slackness, (S, K,) like that of the old man. (S.)
fanojalaI: see what next precedes.
fayojalN: see fayojanN, in art. fjn.
Oafojalu and fanojalN↓ [A man] having a wide space between the feet (K, TA) and the shanks. (TA.)
4. Afjn He (a man, TA) kept constantly to the eating of fayojan [i. e. rue]. (K, TA.)

fayojanN [ Πήγανον; i. e. rue;] i. q. sacaAbN; (S, K;) as also fyjyn↓: (T in art. xft, and TA in art. xtf:) and so fayojalN: (TA:) IDrd [rightly] says, “ I do not think it to be a genuine Arabic word. ” (TA.)
fyjyn: see the next preceding paragraph.
1. fajaA baAbahu, (K,) [aor. yafojuw,] inf. n. fajowN, (TA,) He opened his door. (K.)
And fajaA Alqawosa, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He raised the string of the bow [or made it distant] from the part called its kabid: (S, K:) and so fajRahaA. (S and K in art. fj.)
And fajaA rijolayohi, or maA bayona rijolayohi, He parted his legs wide, or straddled; or did so to make water: and so fajRa. (TA in art. fj.)

fajiyato, (S, K, TA, [in the CK, and in one of my copies of the S, erroneously, fajiYat,]) aor. tafojaI, inf. n. fajFA, (S, TA,) The bow had its string raised [or distant] from the part called its kabid; (S, K;) and so Ainofajat↓. (ISd, TA.)

And fajiIa, [in the CK, erroneously, fajiYa,] aor. as above, (K, TA,) and so the inf. n., i. e. fajFA, (K, * TA,) He (a man, TA) was wide between the thighs, or between the knees, or between the shanks. (K, TA.) [And it is implied in the S * and K that it is also said of a camel, meaning He was wide between the hocks.]
And fajiyato said of a she-camel, inf. n. fajFA, She was, or became, large in the belly: (K, TA:) mentioned by ISd, but with an expression of uncertainty as to its correctness. (TA.)

2. fjRI, (TA,) inf. n. tafojiyapN, (K, TA,) He removed; put away, or at a distance; (K, * TA;) and pushed, thrust, or drove, away; persons from others; (TA;) syn. of the inf. n. kaXofN; and tanoHiyapN; (K, TA;) and dafoEN. (TA.)
4. AfjI He expended amply, or largely, upon his family, or household. (Az, K.)
And He found his friend to be guilty of a vice, or a disgraceful, or shameful, action. (Az, TA.)
6. tfAjI It (a thing) had [an opening, or intermediate wide space, such as is termed] a fajowap. (S, TA.) [Comp. tafaAjRa, in art. fj.]
7. AnfjI It (a door) opened. (K.)
See also 1.
fajFA inf. n. of fajiyato [q. v.] said of a bow: (S, TA:)
and of fajiIa [q. v.] said of a man, (K, * TA,) or of a camel: (S, * K, TA:)
and of fajiyato [q. v.] said of a she-camel. (K, TA.)

fajowapN An opening, or intervening space, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) in a place, (M, TA,) and an intermediate wide space, (S, Mgh,) between two things. (S, Mgh, Msb, K. *) And A wide tract of land or ground; as also fajowaMCu↓: (K:) or a wide and depressed tract thereof; and thus, accord. to Th, the word means in the Kur xviii. 16. (TA.) And The court, or yard, of a house. (S, Msb, K.) And The part between the two sides of the solid hoof. (ISd, K, TA.) The pl. is fajawaAtN (Msb, K, TA) and fijaMCN. (K, TA. [To these pls. the CK strangely adds, as another, fajaON.])
fajowaMCu [as a subst.]: see the next preceding paragraph. [It is originally the fem. of the epithet OafojaI, q. v.]
fajuwoCN: see the following paragraph.

OafojaI an epithet, of which the fem. is fajowaMCu. (K, TA.) The latter, applied to a bow, Having its string distant from the part called its kabid; (S, K, TA;) as also fajuwoCN↓; and so fajRaMCu [mentioned in art. fj]. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

And the former, (K, TA,) applied to a man, (TA,) Wide between the thighs, or between the knees, or between the shanks: or, applied to a camel, wide between the hocks: (K, TA:) or, accord. to Az, it signifies having the thighs very wide apart. (TA.) [Freytag adds “ Ventrosus, ” applied to a camel, as from the K, in which I do not find it.] [Accord. to the TA, some of the words of this art. have I for the final radical; but for this distinction there is no reason.]

1. faHRati AlOafoEaI, aor.
faHuHa
and
faHiHa
, (S, K,) the former dev. from a general rule, which requires the aor. of a verb of this class when intrans. to be with kesr only, (S,) inf. n. faHiyHN (S, K) and faHRN and tafoHaAHN, (K,) [the last an intensive form,] The viper [hissed, or] made a sound to proceed from its mouth: (S, K, TA: [see a verse cited voce miToHaAnN:]) or what is meant by this verb is [it made a sound by] the rubbing of one part of its skin against another part: or (TA) its making a sound to proceed from its skin is termed kaXiyXN, (S, TA,) or xafiyfN: (As, TA:) some use this verb (fHRt) in relation to any serpent: others, peculiarly in relation to the female of the [serpents called] OasaAwid. (TA.) [J gives here a list of intrans. verbs of this class which have the aor. with damm, anomalously, and also with kesr; and a list of trans. verbs of the same class which have the aor. with kesr, anomalously, and also with damm: but both lists are defective; and it would be difficult to make them complete.]

And faHRa, (L, K,) aor.
faHiHa
, inf. n. faHiyHN; (L;) and faHofaHa↓; said of a man, (assumed tropical:) He blew in his sleep, (L, K,) making a sound like the faHiyH of the viper. (IDrd.)
R. Q. 1. faHofaHa: see the preceding paragraph.
Also, [inf. n. faHofaHapN,] (assumed tropical:) He (a man, TA) was, or became, affected with a hoarseness, roughness, harshness, or gruffness, in his voice. (K.) [See also faHofaHapN, below.]
And He (a man, TA) was, or became, true and sincere in love, or affection. (IAar, K.)
fuHRapN The heat, or burning quality, of pepper. (K.)

fuHuHN Vipers: (L:) or vipers in a state of excitement, (haAYijapN [perhaps meaning initum appetentes], K, TA,) made to come forth [from their lurking-places: so called] from the sounds of their mouths. (TA.)

faHiyHN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, K, &c.) [Freytag explains it as signifying also The first braying of the young camel, which, by reason of its acuteness, is likened to the hissing of the serpent.]
faHofaHapN [inf. n. of faHofaHa, q. v.]
Also The voice's being reiterated in the throat, or fauces, resembling hoarseness, roughness, harshness, or gruffness. (L.)
And Speech, or talk. (Kr, TA.)

faHofaHapu hucayolK means Hudheyl's pronunciation of H as E: [a characteristic of the tribe of Hudheyl, or of some persons of that tribe,] mentioned by Es-Suyootee in the Mz and [by the same author in] the Iktiráh. (MF, TA.)
faHofaAHN A man (L) having a hoarse, harsh, or gruff, voice. (L, K.)
And A man speaking, or talking: or talkative. (TA.)
And AlfaHofaAHu is the name of A river in Paradise. (S, K.)

1. faHava Eanohu, (O, K,) aor.
faHava
, (TA,) inf. n. faHovN, (O, TA,) i. q. faHaSa [He searched, or sought, for, or after, it; inquired, or sought information, respecting it; searched into, inquired into, investigated, scrutinized, or examined, it; &c.]; (IDrd, O, K, TA;) namely, a thing; (IDrd, O;) or news, or a story; (TA;) as also AftHv↓. (O, K.)
8: see what immediately precedes.

faHivN (S, O, K) and faHivapN↓ (TA) The [portion, or appertenance, called] Hafiv (S, O, K) of the stomach of a ruminant animal, also termed the qibRap, which has OaTobaAq: (S, O: [see more in art. Hfv:]) pl. of the former OafoHaAvN. (O, TA.)
And one says, malaA OafoHaAvahu meaning He filled his jawof [i. e. belly]. (IF, O.)
faHivapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1. faHija fiI miXoyatihi, aor.
faHaja
, inf. n. faHajN, (S,) this is the form of the verb commonly known, like other verbs signifying faults, and that it is the correct form, and not faHaja as it is written in the K [and O], is indicated by the forms of the inf. n. faHajN and the epithet OafoHaju; (MF;) as also tfHRj↓, (S,) and fHRj↓, (K,) and AnfHj↓; (TA;) He had the fore parts of his feet near together, and his heels wide apart, [i. e. he turned in his toes, and turned out his heels,] in his gait: (S, K:) or faHajN↓ signifies the having the middle of the legs wide apart, [or having the legs bowed outwards,] in a man, and in a beast (daAbRap): (Mgh, L:) [or the having the shanks wide apart: (see falajN:)] or the having the thighs wide apart: [see also 1 in art. fj:] and the verb is faHija, inf. n. faHajN and fHojp [thus written, app. faHojapN, which is the inf. n. un.]; the latter inf. n. mentioned by Lh. (L.)
And faHaja, (accord. to the K,) or faHija, (accord. to MF,) He magnified himself, or behaved proudly. (K.)
2: see the preceding paragraph: and see also 5.
4. AfHj Haluwbatahu He parted the hind legs of his milch camel; i. e., made an opening, or intervening space, between them; (S, O, K;) in order that he might milk her. (S, O.)
AfHj also signifies He refrained, or desisted, or drew back; syn. OaHojama. (O, K.) And one says, AfHj Eanohu, meaning He turned, or turned away or back, from it, or him; syn. AinovanaI. (O, * K.)

5. tafaHRujN signifies The parting of one's legs, or making an opening between them, (AA, S, O, K,) when sitting; as also tafoHiyjN↓: like tafaXRujN and tafoXiyjN. (AA, S, O.) And one says, tatafaHRaju saAqaAhu [His shanks are parted]. (S, O.) See also 1.
7: see the first paragraph.
faHojN The mode of walking of him who is termed OafoHaju. (S, O.)
faHajN an inf. n.: (S, L, TA:) see 1.

OafoHaju Having the fore parts of the feet near together, and the heels wide apart: (S, O, K:) or having the middle of the legs wide apart: (Mgh, L:) fem. faHojaMCu: the former applied to a man [&c.]; and the latter, to a beast (daAbRap) [&c.]: (S, Mgh, O, L:) or having the thighs wide apart: or having the legs wide apart: or having curved, or bowed, legs. (L.) [See also OafajRu, in art. fj.]

1. faHasa, aor.
faHasa
, inf. n. faHosN, He took a thing from his hand, with his tongue and his mouth; such as water &c.: (Lth, T, O, K:) or he licked up a thing with his tongue, from his hand. (O: but only the inf. n. is mentioned.)

And faHasa AlsRalota, aor. as above, (O,) and so the inf. n., (O, K,) He rubbed [the ears off] the slt, (O, K, TA,) a particular species of barley, (TA,) so that the awn, or beard, [thereof] became removed (O, K, TA) and scattered. (TA.)
4. AfHs He (a man) abraded by degrees, lit., thing after thing. (TA.)
Q. Q. 2. tafayoHasa He carried himself in an elegant and a proud and self-conceited manner, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side, in his gait: (O, K: *) and so tafayosaHa. (O.)

1. faHuXa, aor.
faHuXa
, inf. n. fuHoXN (S, O, Msb, K) and faHaAXapN, (TA,) It (a thing, or an affair, or anything, TA, or any evil thing, S) was, or became, excessive, immoderate, enormous, exorbitant, beyond measure, (S, O, TA,) or overmuch; (O, K, TA;) as also tfAHX↓: (S, TA:) it (a thing) was or became, foul, evil, bad, abominable, or unseemly; [gross, immodest, lewd, or obscene;] as also faHaXa, aor.
faHuXa
: (Msb:) [or excessively, or beyond measure, foul, &c.: (see faAHiXapN:)] and tfAHX↓ it (a thing, or an affair,) increased by degrees (tazaAyada) in foulness, evilness, badness, &c. (A.) And faHuXati AlmaroOapu The woman became foul, or ugly, and old. (IAar.)
See also 4, in two places.
2: see 4, in two places.

3. fAHXhu, (T in art. bcO,) inf. n. mufaAHaXahN, (T and K in that art.,) [He vied with him, or strove to surpass him, in foul, unseemly, gross, or obscene, speech or language: and he held such discourse with him:] the inf. n. is syn. with mubaAcaOapN. (T and K in that art.)

4. AfHX, (Msb, K,) or AfHX fiI AlmanoTiqi, (S,) or fiI AlkalaAmi, (Mgh,) or fiI kalaAmihi, (A,) inf. n. UifoHaAXN and fuHoXN↓, accord. to Lh and Kr, but the latter is correctly a simple subst. [used as an inf. n. of this verb], (TA,) He uttered fuHoX, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) i. e., foul, evil, bad, abominable, unseemly, [gross, immodest, lewd, or obscene,] speech or language; (Mgh, Msb;) as also faHaXa↓ fI AlmnTq, (TA,) and fI AlklAm fHRX↓, (Mgh,) or fI klAmh, (A,) and fI klAmh tfHRX↓: (S, A:) and tafaAHaXa↓ also signifies the same; and he manifested, discovered, or revealed, or he made a show of, such speech or language. (O, * K, * TA.) You say, AfHX Ealayohi fiI AlmanoTiqi [He uttered such speech or language against him]; (S;) and in like manner, faHaXa↓, (TA,) and fHRX↓; (Mgh;) and Ealayohi bilisaAnihi tfHRX↓. (TA.)
Also AfHX He was, or became, niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious. (Msb.)
5: see 4, in two places:
and see 10.
6: see 1, in two places:
and see 4.

10. AstfHXhu [He deemed it foul, evil, bad, abominable, unseemly, immodest, lewd, or obscene: or excessively, or beyond measure, foul, &c.]. (Mgh in art. qcr.) And biAlXRaIoCi tfHRX↓ He deemed the thing foul, evil, &c.: or excessively, or beyond measure, foul, &c. (TA.)
fuHoXN inf. n. of faHuXa [q. v.]. (S, O, &c.)
See also 4.

Excess, exorbitance, or transgression of the proper bounds or limits; (O, TA;) [in anything; (see 1;) and particularly] in speech or language; (TA;) and in reply: (A, * O, K, * TA:) foul, evil, bad, abominable, or unseemly; [gross, immodest, lewd, or obscene;] speech or language; (Mgh, Msb, TA;) as also faHoXaMCu↓. (Msb.)
faHoXaMCu: see faAHiXapN, in three places:
and see also fuHoXN.
faHRaAXN: see the next paragraph.

faAHiXN Anything, (Msb, TA,) or any evil thing, (S,) excessive, immoderate, enormous, exorbitant, beyond measure, exceeding the proper bounds or limits, (S, O, Msb, TA,) or overmuch: (O, K, TA:) anything not agreeable with truth, and with rule or measure: (TA:) foul, evil, bad, abominable, or unseemly; [gross, immodest, lewd, or obscene;] applied to a thing or an affair, (Mgh, Msb,) and to speech or language. (TA.) It is said in a trad., He was asked respecting the blood of fleas, [whether it rendered a garment impure,] and said Uino lamo yakuno faAHiXFA falaA baOosa bihi If it is not excessive, or beyond measure, there is no harm in it. (TA.)

A man who transgresses the proper bounds or limits [in anything: and particularly] in speech or language, (TA,) and in reply: (K, * TA:) who is foul, evil, bad, abominable, or unseemly; [gross, immodest, lewd, or obscene;] in speech or language, (Mgh, TA,) and in action: (TA:) and faHRaAXN↓ signifies the same;
(S, * A, * Mgh;) or has an intensive signification: (TA:) pl. of the former fuHaXaMCu, like as juhalaMCu is pl. of jaAhilN, since fuHoX is a sort of jahol, and contr. of Hilom. (IJ.) It is said in a trad., laA takuwniI faAHiXapF, meaning Be not thou a trangressor of the proper bounds or limits in reply: which words were addressed to 'Áïsheh: (K, TA:) but accord. to one relation, the words were laA taquwliI faAHiXapF. (TA.) [See faAHiXapN, below.]
A man evil in disposition. (IB.)
A man niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious: (A, TA:) or very niggardly: (K, TA:) or excessively, or inordinately, so. (S.)

faAHiXapN [An excess; an enormity; anything exceeding the bounds of rectitude:] a thing excessively, enormously, or beyond measure, foul, evil, bad, abominable, or unseemly; [gross, immodest, lewd, or obscene:] (Mgh:) or anything not agreeable with truth: (Lth, Mgh:) or a sin, or crime, that is very foul, evil, bad, &c.: or anything forbidden by God: (K:) or any saying, or action, that is foul, evil, bad, &c.: (TA:) and faHoXaMCu↓ signifies the same as faAHiXapN; (S;) or an enormity, or excessive sin, beyond measure foul, evil, bad, &c.; or a thing that reason disapproves, and the law regards as foul, evil, bad, &c.: (Bd in ii. 164:) the pl. of faAHiXapN is fawaAHiXu. (Msb, TA.) Also, particularly, Adultery, or fornication; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and so faHoXaMCu↓: (Bd in xii. 24; &c.:) so in the Kur iv. 23 and lxv. 1 [as well as in numerous other instances]: or the fAHXp [or excess] there mentioned is the women's going out without permission: (Mgh, Msb:) or their using foul language against their husband's relations, by reason of the sharpness of their tongues. (Esh-Sháfi'ee.) And faHoXaMCu↓ particularly signifies Niggardliness, tenaciousness, or avarice, (A, K,) in the payment of the poor-rate: or the abstaining [altogether] from paying it. (TA.) So in the Kur ii. 271. (A, TA.)
OafoHaXu [More, and most, excessive, &c.].
mutafaHRiXN One who affects, or takes upon himself, the reviling of others. (TA.)
One who commits excess (faAHiXap) which is forbidden. (TA.)

1. faHaSati AlqaTaApu, aor.
faHaSa
, inf. n. faHoSN, (Msb,) and mafoHaSN is the same as faHoSN, being used transitively, and not only as a n. of place, (TA,) The qTAp [i. e. sand-grouse] dug, or hollowed out, in the ground, a place wherein to lay her eggs: (Msb:) and faHaSati AltRuraAba, aor. as above, she (a qTAp) made for herself an OufoHuwS [q. v.] (A, K) in the earth, or dust. (K.)

Hence you say, (Msb,) faHaSa Eanohu, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
faHaSa
, (A, K,) inf. n. faHoSN; (S;) and tfHRS↓; (S, A, Msb, K;) and AftHS↓; (S, A, K;) He searched, or sought, for, or after, it; inquired respecting it; sought for information respecting it; searched into, inquired into, investigated, scrutinized, or examined, it: (S, A, K:) or did so to the utmost: (Msb:) or faHoSN signifies vigorous searching in the interstices of anything. (TA.) You say also, Ealayoka biAlfaHoSi Eano sirRi hecaA AlHadiyvi (tropical:) [Keep thou to searching for, or after, or into, the secret of this story]. (A, TA.)

Hence also, the saying of Aboo-Bekr, satajidu qawomFA faHaSuwA Eano OawosaATi ruWuwsihimu AlXRaEara, (Az, TA,) or faHaSuwA Eano ruWuwsihimo [alone], (S,) Thou wilt find a people who have made their heads like the nests (OafaAHiyS) of [the birds called] qaTFA: (Az, TA:) or, app., who have shaven the middle of their heads and left them like the OafaAHiyS of qaTFA. (S, TA.) [See also OufoHuwSN.]

faHoSN also signifies The digging, or hollowing out [the ground &c., in any manner]. (TA.) It is said in a trad., fuHiSati AlOaroDu OafaAHiySa The earth was dug into hollows. (Nh, L.) And you say, faHaSa liloxubozapi, aor.
faHaSa
, inf. n. faHoSN, He made, for the cake of bread, or lump of dough, a place in the fire; (TA;) or a place in the hot ashes, or in the fire, to put it therein [for the purpose of baking, or toasting, it]. (L in art. fOd.) [faHaSa is often used intransitively as meaning He made, or scraped, a hollow in the ground, &c.; and so tfHRS↓.] And sometimes they said, (S,) faHaSa AlmaTaru AltRuraAba The rain turned over the dust, or earth, (S, A, K,) and removed one part thereof from another, (A, TA,) making it like the OufoHuwS: (TA:) and in like manner, AlHaSaI the pebbles: (A:) this is when it falls vehemently. (TA.)

faHaSa also signifies He (a gazelle) ran vehemently [app. so as to dig up the ground with his feet]; but the word more known is maHaSa: (TA:) and he (a man) hastened, or went quickly. (K.) You say, marRa fulaAnN yafoHaSu Such a one passed along hastening, or going quickly. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. of Kuss, walaA samiEotu faHoSFA Nor did I hear the falling of a foot, or the sound of walking. (TA.)
You say also, faHaSa AlSRabiIRu, meaning, (assumed tropical:) The child had his central incisors in a wabbling state: (K:) [nearly syn. with Hafara, and still more so with OaHofara.]
And faHoSN also signifies The spreading [a thing] out or open; laying [it] open; exposing or uncovering or discovering [it]. (TA.)

3. faAHaSaniI, (K,) inf. n. mufaAHaSapN, (TK,) [and app. fiHaASN also,] (assumed tropical:) [He did] as though he searched after, or into, my vice, or fault, and my secret, I doing the same with respect to his. (K, TA.)
[Hence, app., the saying,] bayonahumaA fiHaASN (assumed tropical:) Between them two is enmity. (TA.)
5: see 1, in two places.
8: see 1, second sentence.
faHoSN Even ground; an expanded and open tract: pl. fuHuwSN. (TA.)
And hence, (TA,) Any inhabited place. (K, TA.)

In a trad. respecting the intercession [of Mohammad for his people], where it is said, faQnoTalaqa HatRaI OataI AlfaHoSa [And he went away until he came to the fHS], AlfHS is said to signify What is before the EaroX [of God]. (TA.)
faHoSapN The dimple (nuqorap) of the chin (A, K) of a child; (A;) and of each cheek. (TA.)

huwa faHiySiI, and mufaAHiSiI↓, (assumed tropical:) He is a searcher after, or into, my vice, or fault, and secret, I being the same with respect to his: (K, * TK:) both mean the same, like OakiyliI and muWaAkiliI. (TA.)
fulaAnN faHRaASN Eani AlOasoraAri (tropical:) Such a one is a great searcher for, or after, or into, secrets. (A, TA.)

entry.xml:id: AiEolamo OanRa Einoda QllRehi masoOalapF faAHiSapF

form.orth: AiEolamo OanRa Einoda QllRehi masoOalapF faAHiSapF

sense.s: AiEolamo OanRa Einoda QllRehi masoOalapF faAHiSapF (tropical:) [Know thou that with God is a searching interrogation]. (A, TA.)

OufoHuwSN (S, M, A, Mgh, K) and mafoHaSN↓ (the same, and Msb) The [nest, or] place for laying eggs, (M, Mgh, Msb,) or for lying in, (S, K,) of a qaTaAp [or sand-grouse], (S, M, A, Mgh, K,) and of the domestic hen, and sometimes of the ostrich, (M,) dug, or hollowed out, in the ground, (Msb,) or made by clearing away and removing from it the dust or earth; (Mgh;) or because she digs it, or hollows it out: (S, M:) pl. (of the former, TA) OafaAHiySu (S, A) and (of the latter, TA) mafaAHiSu: (A, TA:) [see EuXRN:] you say, lahumo buyuwtN kaOafaAHiySi AlqaTaA and mafaAHiSihaA [They have houses like the nests of the qTA]. (A.) And it is said in a trad., mano banaI lilRehi masojidFA walawo mafoHaSa↓ qaTaApK banaI QllRehu lahu bayotFA fiI AljanRapi [Whoso buildeth for God a place of worship, be it comparatively like a nest of a qTAp, (kamafoHaSi qaTaApK, accord. to another relation,) God buildeth for him a house in Paradise]. (TA.) And in another, in a charge given to the commanders of the army of Mu-teh, wasatajiduwna Mxariyna lilXRayoTaAni fiI ruWuwsihimo mafaAHiSu↓ (tropical:) And ye shall find others in whose heads the devil hath taken up an abode, making them like nests for him: like as one says of a person greatly erring, and obstinately persevering in evil, farRaxa AlXRayoTaAnu fiI raOosihi, and EaXRaXa fiI qalobihi. (TA.)
Also, both words, Any place dug, or hollowed out. (Nh.)
And the former, A place made in hot ashes, or in a fire, in which a cake of bread, or lump of dough, is put [to bake or toast]: pl. as above. (L, in art. fOd; and TA. *)
mafoHaSN, and its pl.: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
huwa mufaAHiSiI: see faHiySiI.
mutafaHRaSN [A place of, or ground for, inquiring, or investigating]. (A and TA voce taEaqRaba.)

1. faHala AlUibila, aor.
faHala
, [inf. n. faHolN,] He sent a male [meaning a stallion-camel] among the [she-] camels. (S, O, K.) The inf. n. faHolN [used alone]
means The putting a he-camel among the she-camels. (KL.)
And faHala Uibilahu faHolFA kariymFA He chose for his [she-] camels a generous male [or stallion]; as also AftHl↓. (K.)
See also the next paragraph.

4. AfHlhu, (S,) or AfHlhu faHolFA, (K, TA,) He gave to him, (S,) or lent to him, (K, TA,) a male [camel] (S, K, TA) to cover among his [she-] camels: (S, TA:) and accord. to Lh, fulaAnaA faHala↓ baEiyrFA and AftHlhu↓ signify he gave to such a one a he-camel; like AfHlhu. (TA.)

5. tfHRl He assumed, or affected, a likeness, or resemblance, to the faHol (S, O, K, TA) i. e. the male (TA) [or rather the manly]: and he affected the quality of the faHol [or manly] in clothing and in food, by making both to be coarse; (O, K, TA;) as did the chiefs of Syria to 'Omar, when he came thither; (O, TA;) i. e., they met him in their ordinary clothing, not having adorned themselves; [in consideration of his simple habits;] self-adornment being an affair of females and of effeminate men. (TA.) [See also its part. n., below.]
8: see 1:
and see also 4.

10. AlAisotifoHaAlu signifies The practice of persons' giving to a man of big make, (O, K, TA,) and comely appearance, (O,) free access to their women, in order that he may beget among them the like of himself; which the unbelievers (Euluwj, O, or OaEolaAj, K) of Kábul do [or used to do] when seeing such a man, of the Arabs: (O, K, TA:) so Lth was told, and thus he has expl. the word, after saying that he errs who says AisotafoHalonaA faHolFA lidawaAbRinaA [app. meaning We sought, or demanded, a stallion for our beasts]. (O, TA.)
AstfHlt AlnRaxolapu The palm-tree became a fuHRaAl [or tree of which the spadix might be used for the purpose of fecundation]. (K. [See also the part. n., below.])
And AstfHl AlOamoru (tropical:) The affair, or case, became great, or formidable, (S, O, K, TA,) and hard, or difficult. (TA.)

faHolN a word of well-known meaning, (S, O,) A male of animals (Mgh, Msb, K) of any kind, (Mgh, K,) [including mankind: and particularly a stallion: generally,] a male [or stallion] camel: (MA:) pl. [of mult.] fuHuwlN (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and fiHaAlN (S, Msb, K) and fuHuwlapN (Mgh, O, Msb, K) and fiHaAlapN (S, O, K) and [pl. of pauc.] OafoHulN: (K:) and faHiylN↓ signifies the same as faHolN; (Kr, TA;) and [particularly] a faHol of the camels. (S, O, TA.)

Hence AlfaHolu is an appellation of (tropical:) Canopus (suhayolN); because it is aloof from the other stars, like the fHl which, when he has covered, goes aloof from the [she-] camels: (S, O, K, TA:) or, as some say, it is so called because of its greatness. (TA.)

rajulN faHiylN↓ means the same as faHolN [i. e. (assumed tropical:) A masculine, as opposed to an effeminate, man]. (K.) And AimoraOapN faHolapN↓ means (assumed tropical:) A clamorous [or, app., masculine] woman. (S, O, K.)

fuHuwlu AlXRuEaraMCi is an appellation applied to (assumed tropical:) The poets (O, K) who have overcome, (O,) or who overcome, (K,) in satirizing, those who have vied with them therein; (O, K;) like Jereer and El-Farezdak, (O, TA,) who used to be called faHolaA muDara: (TA:) and in like manner (tropical:) any one who, when he vies with a poet, is judged to have excelled him [is called a faHol]; (K, TA; [for faDala in the CK, I read fuDRila, as in other copies of the K;]) like 'Alkameh Ibn-'Abadeh; (TA;) who was surnamed AlfaHolu because he took to wife Umm-Jundab when Imrael-Keys divorced her on the occasion of her judging him [i. e. 'Alkameh] to have overcome him [Imra-el-Keys] in poetry. (S, O, K, TA.)
faHolN also means [app. (assumed tropical:) A vigorous orator: see haAdirN.

And] (tropical:) A relater, reciter, or rehearser, by heart, [of poetry, and of traditions, or narratives learned, or heard, or received, from another or others;] syn. raAwK: pl. fuHuwlN: (K, TA:) so in the M. (TA.)
See also fuHRaAlN, in three places. And see mutafaHRilN.
And (tropical:) A mat that is made of the woven leaves of the palm-tree thus called, (Sh, * S, * O, * K, * TA,) i. e., of the palm-tree called fuHRaAl: (S, O, K, TA:) pl. fuHuwlN. (S, O, TA.)
And (assumed tropical:) Rain is thus called [in a verse of Et-Tirimmáh Ibn-El-Hakeem, being likened to the stallion-camel, because of its fertilizing the earth]. (Ham p. 110.)
AimoraOapN faHolapN: see faHolN, former half.

fiHolapN The quality, or state, of being a faHol [or male; and particularly, of being a stallion: and also (assumed tropical:) masculineness, as a quality of a man, opposed to effeminacy: &c.]: (S, O, K:) and fuHuwlapN↓ and fiHaAlapN↓ [both of which are also pls. of faHolN] signify the same. (K.) [Hence,] baEiyrN cuw fiHolapK A camel fit, or meet, for being chosen as a stallion. (TA.)
Also, i. e. fiHolapN, with kesr, A man's choosing a faHol [i. e. stallion] for his beasts. (TA.)
faHiylN: see faHolN, first sentence.
One says also faHolN faHiylN, meaning A generous stallioncamel, that begets generous offspring. (S, K. *) Er-Rá'ee says,

[Their mothers were of the generous camels of Mundhir and Moharrik, and their compressing stallion was a generous one, a begetter of generous offspring]: (S [accord. to one of my copies], and TA:) [some copies of the S have najaAYibu and OumRaAtihinR; and so has the O: but] IB says that the verse is correctly related as above. (TA.)
And kaboXN faHiylN means A ram that resembles the faHol of camels in his excellence (K, TA) and his [comparative] greatness. (TA.)
See also faHolN again, third sentence.
fiHaAlapN: see fiHolapN.
fuHuwlapN: see fiHolapN.

fuHRaAlN and faHolN↓ The male palm-tree, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, TA,) by means of which the fruitbearing palm-trees are fecundated, (S, * Mgh, * Msb, TA,) and which, when they are on the windward side of the latter trees, fecundate these: (TA:) [see what follows:] only the former word is mentioned [in this sense] by Lth; and ISd says, (TA,) the former word is used peculiarly as applied to the male palm-tree: (K, * TA:) AHn cites AA as saying that faHolN↓ is not said except of that which has life, and Aboo-Nasr says the like; but AHn adds that people in general disagree from them as to this: (TA:) the pl. of fuHRaAlN is faHaAHiylu; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and the pl. of faHolN↓ is fuHuwlN (S, Mgh, O, Msb) and fuHuwlapN (Mgh, Msb) and fiHaAlN; (Msb;) of the first of which pls. of faHolN, the following saying, (S, O, Msb, TA,) of Oheihah Ibn-El-Juláh, (O, TA,) presents an ex.:

[Receive thou fecundation, O best of young palmtrees: receive thou fecundation from Hanadh, and show that thou hast received it: (faXuwliI being from XaAlato bicanabihaA said of a she-camel, meaning “ she raised her tail, showing thereby that she was pregnant: ”) since the palm-owners have been niggardly of the spadixes of the male palm-trees]: (S, O, Msb, TA:) the meaning is, that the people of Hanadh were niggardly of the spadixes of their [male] palm-trees, and the east wind blew at the time of the fecundation upon the male trees, bearing off [the pollen of] their spadixes and casting it upon the female trees, so that it served for fecundation: Hanadh is a place about four miles from El-Medeeneh: and it is said to be the town of Oheihah: or to be a water belonging to Suleym and Muzeyneh. (Msb.)
XajarN mutafaHRilN (tropical:) Trees that do not bear fruit; like the faHol↓: (Ibn-'Abbád, A, O, TA:) that become barren. (A, TA.) [See also what follows.]
naxolapN musotafoHilapN (assumed tropical:) A palm-tree that does not bear fruit. (Lh, TA.) [See also what next precedes: and see 10.]

1. faHuma, aor.
faHuma
, inf. n. fuHuwmN (K, TA) and fuHuwmapN, (K, * TA,) said of anything, (TA,) It was, or became, black [app. like faHom i. e. charcoal]. (K, TA.) [See also faAHimN.]
See also faHomN, last sentence.

faHama, (Ks, S, Msb, K,) aor.
faHama
, (Ks, S, Msb, TA,) accord. to the K
faHuma
, which is wrong; (TA;) and faHima; and fuHima; (K;) He (a boy, or child,) wept until his voice became stopped; (Ks, S, Msb;) or until his breath became stopped; as also OufoHima↓. (K.)

And, said of a ram, (K,) or thus faHama and faHima, like manaEa and Ealima, (TA,) He uttered a cry, or cries. (K, TA.) And (TA) one says of a ram, vagaA HatRaI faHama He bleated until
he became hoarse. (S, TA.)

faHama, aor.
faHama
, said of a man, He was unable to answer, (K, TA,) when one had spoken to him. (TA.)

And faHamati Alqaliybu, aor.
faHuma
, inf. n. fuHuwmN, (tropical:) [The well, or old well,] ceased to have a flow of water. (K, TA.)
2. fHRmhu, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. tafoHiymN, (S, A, K,) He blackened it, (S, A, Msb, K,) namely, another's face, (S, A, Msb,) with faHom [i. e. charcoal]. (Msb.)
See also the next paragraph.
4. AfHm He (a man) entered upon the time called faHomapu AlEiXaMCi [q. v.]: like OaEotama. (TA.)

And one says, OafoHimuwA, (S,) or OafoHimuwA Eanokumo, (K,) mina AllRayoli, meaning Abstain ye from journeying in the faHomap (i. e. the most intense blackness, S) of the night; (S, K;) as also faHRimowA↓, (S, * K,) inf. n. tafoHiymN. (S.)

AfHmhu is said of weeping [as meaning It stopped his voice, or his breath]: (TA:) see 1. And He silenced him, (S, Msb, TA,) namely, his adversary (Msb) in a dispute or the like, (S, Msb, TA,) by an argument or evidence, (Msb,) or in some other case. (S, TA.) And, said of anxiety, or disquietude of mind, It prevented him, or withheld him, from uttering poetry, or verse. (K.)

And He found him to be mufoHam, (S, K,) not uttering poetry, or verse. (S.) One says haAjaAhu faOafoHamahu, meaning [He contended with him in satirizing] and he found him to be mufoHam, accord. to the K: (TA:) and haAjayonaAkumo famaA OafoHamonaAkumo (S [in which it is implied that the meaning is We contended with you in satirizing and found you not to be mufoHamuwn]): or, accord. to IB, this means, and we caused you not to hold the tongue from answering, or replying; because AlmuhaAjaApu is between two persons: but you [may] say hajawotuhu faOafoHamotuhu meaning [I satirized him] and I found him to be mufoHam. (TA.)

8: [AlAifotiHaAmu is expl. in some copies of the K as signifying AlAigotibaAqu; in some, AlAiEotinaAqu; and app. in the copy used by Golius, AlAiEotiyaAqu: the first, which is that followed in the TK, is evidently, I think, the right; meaning The drinking an evening draught; such as is termed a gabuwq. See also the next paragraph, second and last sentences.]

faHomN and faHamN↓, (S, Msb, K,) the latter sometimes occurring, (S, Msb,) like nahorN and naharN, (S,) [Charcoal; this is what is meant by its being said to signify] extinct coal; (M, K;) a thing well known; (S, Msb;) as also faHiymN↓; (S, K;) or, accord. to ISd, this may be a pl. of faHomN, [or a quasi-pl. n.,] like as EabiydN is of EabodN, and maEiyzN of maEozN, &c.: (TA:) the n. un. [meaning a piece of charcoal] is faHomapN↓, (S, K, TA,) but not faHamapN. (TA.)

And faHomN signifies also The draught that is drunk in [any one of] the times denoted by the word faHomapN [q. v.]: (K, TA:) like the gabuwq and SabuwH and jaAXiriyRap and qayol: but it is disapproved by Az. (TA.)

[Accord. to the TK, it is an inf. n. of which the verb is faHama↓, aor.
faHama
, signifying He (a man) drank in the faHomap of the EiXaMC: but of this I find not any confirmation.]
faHamN: see the next preceding paragraph.
faHimN: see faAHimN.

faHomapN n. un. of faHomN, q. v. [Hence] one says of a black woman with a red ximaAr [or muffler], kaOanRahaA faHomapN fiI raOosihaA naArN [As though she were a piece of charcoal with fire upon its head]. (TA.)

[And hence,] faHomapu AllRayoli The first part of the night: (K:) or the blackness of the night: (Msb:) or the most intense blackness of the night: (K:) or the blackness of the first part of the night: (TA:) or the most intensely black part of the night: (S, TA:) or the part from the setting of the sun to [the time of] the sleeping of mankind: (K:) so called because of its heat [as well as its darkness]; for the first part of the night is hotter than its last part: (TA:) it is peculiarly in the Sayof [meaning summer]; (K, TA;) not in the winter: (TA:) and faHomapu AlEiXaMCi signifies the darkness of the EXAC [i. e. of the nightfall]: (S:) or the intenseness of the blackness of the night, and its darkness; which is in its first part: or the time next after the EXAC: (TA:) the pl. is fiHaAmN and fuHuwmN: (K, TA:) or the latter of these may mean darkness; as though it were an inf. n. of faHuma. (TA.) faHomapu AlsRaHari means The time of the saHar [or last part of the night]. (K.) And faHomapu bonu jumayorK is [a proper name of] The middle of the night. (K.)
faHuwmN One who will not utter a reply, or an answer. (TA.)
faHiymN: see faHomN:
and see also faAHimN.
faHRaAmN A seller of faHom [i. e. charcoal]. (TA.)
faAHimN Black; (S, K, TA;) applied to hair, (S,) and to anything; (TA;) as also faHiymN↓; (K, TA;) applied to hair and to anything. (TA.) And Black that is beautiful or comely. (TA.)
And one says Oasowadu faAHimN meaning Black in an intense degree. (TA.)
Also A ram uttering a cry, or cries; and so faHimN↓. (K. [But see 1.])
And One who does not speak at all. (TA.)
And, applied to water, (tropical:) Still; not flowing or running. (K, TA.)

mufoHamN [pass. part. n. of 4, q. v.]: i. q. EayiIRN [app. as meaning Unable to express what he would say]; (K, TA;) because his face becomes black from anger, like faHom [i. e. charcoal]. (TA.) One unable to utter verse, or poetry. (S, * K.) And A poet who will not [or cannot] answer, or reply to, him who contends with him in satirizing. (TA.)
mufoHimN And answer, or a reply, [&c.,] that silences. (TA.)

1. faHaA bikalaAmihi UilaI kacaA, (Msb, TA,) aor. yafoHuw [like yaEoluw], the verb being of the class of EalaI, (so in the Msb accord. to the TA,) or yafoHaI [like yanofaEu], the verb being of the class of nafaEa, (so accord. to my copy of the Msb,) or, as in copies of the T, yafoHiI, without teshdeed, the verb being of the class of ramaI, (TA, [but this is app. a mistranscription for yafoHaI, as the last radical letter is w,]) inf. n. faHowN; (Msb, TA;) or bklAmh fHRI↓ AlI kcA, thus accord. to the K, agreeably with what is said by J; (TA;) [but one of my copies of the S has UinRahu layafoHaI bikalaAmihi UilaI kacaA wakacaA; the other copy having layufaHRiI↓;] He meant, or intended, by his saying, or speech, such a thing. (Msb, K, TA. [In the S, the meaning is only indicated by the context.])
bakaI HatRaI faHiIa, like raDiIa, He (a child) wept until he sobbed. (TA.)

2. fHRI Alqidora, inf. n. tafoHiyapN, He made the cooking-pot to have a large quantity of OabaAziyr [or seeds used in cooking, for seasoning the food: from faHFA, q. v.]: (S, * K, TA:) or, accord. to Aboo- 'Alee El-Kálee, he put, or threw, into the cookingpot, OabaAziyr, i. e. tawaAbil. (TA.) It is said, by Z, [but with hardly any reason that I can see,] to be formed by transposition from the letters fwH thus combined. (TA.)
See also 1, in two places.
3. faAHayotuhu, inf. n. mufaAHaApN, I talked, discoursed, or held a colloquy, with him, and understood what he intended, or meant. (A, TA.)

faHFA and fiHFI, (S, K,) the former of which is the more common, (S,) The seeds that are used in cooking, for seasoning the food; (S, K;) as also faHowaMCu↓: or the dry thereof: (K:) pl. OafoHaMCN; (S, K;) which is said by IAth to signify the [seeds called] tawaAbil of the cooking-pot, such as pepper and cumin-seed and the like thereof. (TA.) And it is said to signify particularly The onion, or onions collectively. (TA.) Thus in a trad. of Mo'áwiyeh, in which he is related to have said to a party who came to him, kuluwA mino faHaA OaroDinaA faqalRa maA Oakala qawomN mino faHaA OaroDK faDarRahumo maAWuhaA [Eat ye of the seasoning of our land (meaning of the onions,) for rarely have people eaten of the seasoning of a land and the water thereof has harmed them]. (TA: and the like is said in the S, but not so fully.)

faHowapN i. q. XahodapN [A portion of honey; or a honey-comb; or a portion of a honey-comb]. (K, TA. [It is added in the latter that it is as though it were formed by transposition from fawoHap; which I do not find in this sense in any lexicon.])

faHoyapN, like jaroyapN; (so in some copies of the K, and accord. to the TA, in which it is said to be “ with fet-h; ”) or fiHoyapN, like jiroyapN; (so in other copies of the K; [but I think that both are evidently wrong, because deviating from a common rule of the K, and for more than one other obvious reason; and that the right reading is fiHRiyRapN↓, like jirRiyRapN (accord. to those who hold this to be of the
measure fiERiylapN, not fiEoliyRapN); i. e., that it is originally fiHRiywapN, the w being necessarily changed into I and incorporated into the preceding I;] and also faHiyRapN↓; (K, TA;) the former on the authority of AA, and the latter on that of IAar; (TA;) Thin soup: (K, TA: [in some copies of the K, HaXow is erroneously put for Hasow or HasuwR, the readings in other copies:]) or soup in general. (K, TA.)

faHowaI and faHowaMCu↓, (T, S, Msb, K, &c.,) the latter sometimes used, (Msb,) but AZ is said to have disallowed the pronunciation with the lengthened alif, (TA,) and fuHawaMCu↓, (K, TA,) this last mentioned by ISd and Sgh on the authority of Fr, (TA,) The meaning of a saying, or speech; its intended sense or import; syn. maEonFI; (S, Msb, K;) and macohabN; (K;) and laHonN. (S, Msb.) One says, Earafotuhu, (S, A,) or fahimotuhu, (Msb,) fiI, (S,) or mino, (A, Msb,) faHowaI kalaAmihi and kalaAmihi faHowaMCi↓ (S, A, Msb) i. e. [I knew it, or I understood it, in, or from, the intended sense or import of his saying, or speech; or,] in [or from] what I elicited of his meaning, or intent, in what he said. (A.) [See also EaruwDN, near the middle of the paragraph.]
faHowaMCu: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places:
see also faHFA.
fuHawaMCN: see faHowaI.
faHiyRapN and fiHRiyRapN: see faHoyapN, above.
OafoHaI i. q. OabaHRu [Having a hoarse, rough, harsh, or gruff, voice]. (Sgh, TA.)

1. faxRa, aor.
faxixa
, inf. n. faxiyxN (S, K) and faxRN; and so AftxR↓, (K, TA,) inf. n. AifotixaAxN; (TA;) said of one sleeping, He snored; or made a sound in breathing, audible by persons around him; syn. gaTRa: (S, L, K:) or faxRN in sleep is [the making a sound] less than what is termed gaTiyTN [inf. n. of gaTRa]: and it signifies also a man's sleeping, and blowing in sleep. (L.)
8: see the preceding paragraph.

faxRN A snare, trap, gin, or net, for catching game or any kind of wild animals or birds; syn. miSoyadapN: (S, A, L, Msb, * K:) said to be a Pers., or foreign, word, arabicized: (TA:) [from the Pers. faxo:] AM says that the Arabs called it TaroqN [q. v.; and see also TiboqN]: (TA:) and faxRapN↓ signifies the same: (L:) pl. of the former fixaAxN (S, A, Msb, K) and fuxuwxN. (S, A, K.) wavaba fulaAnN mino faxRi Uiboliysa (tropical:) [lit. Such a one leaped from the snare of Iblees] means such a one repented. (A.)

faxRapN A sleep in which the sleeper snores, or makes a sound in breathing audible by persons around him: (S: [see 1:]) or a sleep in which the sleeper blows: (L:) or a sleep after coïtus: (K:) or a sleep in which the sleeper rests on the back of his head, (IAar, L, K,) and blows by reason of satiety: (IAar, L:) or a sleep in the early part of the morning or of the forenoon, between the time of the prayer of daybreak and sunrise or after sunrise: and, when tired. (A.) One says, huwa yanaAmu AlfaxRapa [He sleeps the sleep termed faxRap]. (A.)
See also faxRN.
1. faxatato, said of a woman, She walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side. (Msb.) [See also 5.]
And, said of the bird called faAxitap, It [cooed, or] uttered a cry or sound. (K.)
And faxata He lied, or uttered a falsehood. (A, TA. [See faAxitapN.])

faxatahu, aor.
faxata
, He cut it off (K, TA) with a sword. (TA.)
faxata raOosahu He smote his head with a sword, (O, K, TA,) and cut it off. (TA.)
faxata AlUinaMCa, (K, TA,) inf. n. faxotN, (TA,) He uncovered the vessel. (K, TA.)

And Alfaxotu signifies also The cook's taking out with the hand a piece of flesh-meat from the cooking-pot: (K, TA:) mina Alqidorapi, the reading found in copies of the K, [in the CK mn Alfidorapi,] is a mistake: it should be mn Alqidori, as in the L [and O] &c. (TA.)

5. tfxRt He walked in the manner of the bird called faAxitap: thus in the K: but in most of the lexicons tafaxRatato: (TA:) i. e. she (a woman) walked as walks the faAxitap: (A:) [or,] accord. to Lth, [in the 'Eyn,] signifying mXt mjnbHp: (TA: in the O, maXato mjnHh; and in the margin thereof, mujanobixapF: [the right reading is maXato mujotaniHapF; thus in the JK, a lexicon founded upon the 'Eyn:] thought by him to be from the walking of the bird called faAxitap: (O, * TA:) he means, she strode in her walking, and held out her arms apart from [her sides beneath] her armpits. (TA.)

And He wondered, syn. taEajRaba, (O, K, TA,) and said, How good, or goodly, is he, or it! (O, TA.) And it is said of a man as signifying tEjRb fiI miXoyatihi [app. meaning He showed Eujob, i. e. self-admiration, &c., in his gait: but I do not find this signification assigned to tEjRb]. (TA.)
And He affected lying; or lied purposely; syn. takacRaba. (A, TA.)
7. Anfxt, said of a roof, It became perforated. (O, K.)

faxotN The light of the moon; moonlight: (S, A, O, K:) or the light of the moon when it first appears: and hence [as some say] the derivation of faAxitapN [as the name of a certain bird], because of its colour: (Msb: [see, however, what follows:]) you say, jalasonaA fiI Alfaxoti [as though meaning We sat in the moonlight]: (A 'Obeyd, S, O:) but Sh says, I have not heard Alfixot except in this instance; and Aboo-Is-hák states that some one of the lexicologists says, I know not whether it be a name of the light of the moon or of its darkness: Abu-l-'Abbás says that the meaning [in the saying above mentioned] is, in the shade of the moon [i. e. in the shade of a moonlight-night; and to this the colour of the faAxitap may be likened]. (TA.)
Also The [snare, or trap, &c., called] faxR, (K, TA,) of the sportsman: (TA:) or [a thing] nearly resembling the faxR. (O.)
And Holes, or perforations, of a round form, in a roof. (O, K.)

faAxitapN A certain well-known bird; (K;) of those having neck-rings [or collars]; (S, O;) a species of pigeon, marked with a neck-ring: (TA:) accord. to Ibn-El-Jawáleekee, (IB, TA,) the name is derived from Alfaxotu, (IB, Msb, TA,) meaning “ the light of the moon, ” (IB, TA,) or “ the light of the moon when it first appears; ” because of its colour: (Msb:) [hence, and from what will be found stated voce qumoriIRN, it seems to be a species of collared turtle-dove, of a dull white colour, marked with a black neck-ring:] or, as some say, the word is a part. n. from faxatato signifying as expl. in the first sentence of this art.: (Msb:) the pl. is fawaAxitu. (S, O, Msb.) Oakocabu mino faAxitapK [More lying than a fákhiteh] is a prov.; because the cry of the fAxtp resembles hecaA OawaAnu AlrRuTabi [This is the season of the fresh ripe dates]; and this it utters when the spadix of the palmtree has not yet come forth. (Meyd. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 383.])

1. faxacahu, (S, O, L, K,) aor.
faxaca
, (TA, and so accord. to some copies of the K, in which the verb is said to be like manaEahu,) or
faxica
, (so in other copies of the K,) inf. n. faxocN, (L,) He hit, or hurt, his (another's) thigh: (S, L, K:) or he broke his thigh: like as one says raOasahu and rajalahu. (O.) And fuxica He was hit, or hurt, in his thigh: (M, L, K:) or his thigh was broken. (A.)
2: see 5, in two places.

fxRc EaXiyratahu (assumed tropical:) He called his EXyrp [or kinsfolk] faxic by faxic [i. e. one small body of families after another], (S, Mgh, * O, L, K, *) inf. n. tafoxiycN: (TA:) from a trad. (S, O, L.)

And faxRacahumo, inf. n. as above; (K;) or fxRc bayonahumo; (L;) (assumed tropical:) He dispersed them, and abstained from aiding them; syn. farRaqahumo waxacalahumo: (L, K: [but see what follows:]) and (L) fxRchm (O, L, Msb) Eano fulaAnK, (O, L,) inf. n. as above, (O, L, Msb,) signifies xclhm, (L, Msb, [in both written without any of the syll. signs,]) or xcRlhm Eanohu [which is evidently the right reading (i. e. he induced them to abstain from aiding such a one), and I believe it to be the right reading also in the explanation given immediately before from the L and K]: (O:) and fxRc bayonahumo he dispersed them. (O, Msb.)
3: see the next paragraph, in two places.

5. tfxRc AlmaroOapa He (a man, Msb) sat between the thighs of the woman (Mgh, Msb) as he sits who performs [or is about to perform] the act of coïtus; as also fAxchA↓, [inf. n. mufaAxacapN;] and fxRchA↓, inf. n. tafoxiycN: (Msb:) or he sat above the thighs of the woman: (Mgh:) AltRafoxiycu↓ signifies the same as AlmufaAxacapu↓ [app. agreeably with the former or the latter of the explanations above]. (S, O, L.)
10. Astfxc i. q. AisotaxocaI, (Fr, O, K, TA,) i. e. He was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive; and so AisotaxocaOa. (TA in arts. xcI and xcO.)

faxicN and faxocN (S, O, L, Msb, K) and fixocN (S, O, L, K) and fixicN, (L, TA,) as Ez-Zarkashee says in his Expos. of El-Bukháree, (TA,) for in the case of every faucial medial radical of a word of the measure faEil, whether a noun like faxicN or a verb like Xahida, there are four dial. vars., namely, faEil and faEol and fiEol and fiEil; (Seer, O, TA;) thus it is said in the Tes-heel of Ibn-Málik; and MF says that the first three forms are common to every word of the measure of katif though without a faucial letter; (TA;) The thigh; i. e. the limb (wSl [i. e. wuiSol, but in the O written waSol,]) between the saAq and the warik; (Mgh, * O, L, K; *) so says Lth; (O;) and in this sense, the first of the forms above mentioned is the most chaste: (MF:) it is of the fem. gender: (Mgh, O, L, Msb, K:) pl. OafoxaAcN, (Sb, L, Msb, K,) the only pl. form. (Sb, L.)

Also (tropical:) A small sub-tribe, or portion of the tribe, consisting of the nearest of the kinsfolk of a man; (Kh, A, * O, L, K; *) less than a baTon; the first [i. e. largest] body being the XaEob, then the qabiylap, then the faSiylap, then the EimaArap, then the baTon, and then the faxoic: (S, O, L:) or it is below the qabiylap but above the baTon; and is pronounced with the x quiescent: (IDrd, O:) or below the faSiylap but above the baTon: (Msb:) or below the baTon and above the faSiylap: (Mgh, Msb:) this last, accord. to IB and Aboo-Usámeh, is the true order; (TA voce XEb, q. v.;) and AM says that the faSiylap is nearer than the fxc: (L:) in this sense, the second of the forms above mentioned is the most chaste: (MF:) and in this sense it is of the masc. gender; (A, Mgh, O, Msb;) because meaning nafarN; (Msb;) wherefore you say, hecaA faxociI: (A:) pl. as above. (A, O, L, K.)

Hulibati AlnRaAqapu fiI faxicihaA is a phrase mentioned by Fr, meaning (assumed tropical:) [The she-camel was milked] in her half-month [app. at the period commencing half a month after her parturition]. (O.)
faxocaMCu A woman that holds a man firmly between her thighs, (Msb, K, TA,) by reason of her strength. (TA.)
mafoxuwcN A man hit, or hurt, in his thigh: (M, L:) or whose thigh is broken. (A.)

1. faxara, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
faxara
, (O, Msb, K,) inf. n. faxorN (S, O, Msb, K) and faxarN (S, O, K) and faxaArN, (K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) or it is a mistake for fixaArN, accord. to some, and this may be an inf. n. either of faxara, for there are many instances of the same kind, or of faAxara, (MF,) or faxaArN, with fet-h, is post-classical, and therefore not allowable, (Th, O,) and faxaArapN and fixRiyraI and fixRiyraMCu; (K;) and Aftxr↓; (S, O, Msb, K;) and tfAxr↓; (L in art. ftH;) [He gloried, or boasted; i. e.] he gloried in, boasted of, boasted himself in, or praised or commended himself for, certain properties, or particular qualities: (K:) he enumerated, or recounted, the particulars of his ancestral nobility or eminence, or his own glorious or honourable deeds or qualities: (S, TA:) or he arrogated to himself greatness and nobility: (TA:) or he contended for superiority by reason of honours arising from memorable deeds or qualities, and from parentage or relationship, and other things relating to himself or to his ancestors: (Msb:) or he contended for superiority by reason of things extrinsic to himself, such as wealth, and rank or station. (TA.) You say faxarotu bihi [I gloried in it, or by reason of it; &c.]. (Msb.) And tfAxr↓ bimaA Einodahu He gloried in, boasted of, or boasted himself in, what he possessed. (L in art. ftH.) And faxara baEoDuhumo EalaI baEoDK One party of them boasted against another [bikacaA in such a thing or quality &c.]. (K.)
Also faxara, inf. n. faxorN, He magnified himself by boasting. (TA.)

faAxarahu fafaxarahu, (S, O, K,) aor.
faxura
, (O, K, [in two copies of the S written
faxara
, contrary to analogy in a verb signifying surpassing in a contest, accord. to most of the grammarians,]) inf. n. faxorN: (S:) see 3.
faxara fulaAnN Alyawoma EalaI fulaAnK fiI AlXRarafi waAljaladi waAlomanoTiqi Such a one excelled to-day such a one in nobleness and hardiness and speech. (ISk, TA.)

faxira, aor.
faxara
, (O, K,) inf. n. faxarN, (TA,) He disdained, or scorned. (IAar, O, K, TA.)
faxarahu Ealayohi: see 4.
2: see 4.

3: faAxarahu fafaxarahu↓, (ISk, S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. of the former mufaAxarapN (Msb, K) and fixaArN, (K,) [and aor. of the latter
faxura
, or, accord. to some,
faxara
, (see 3 in art. xSm,)] He vied, or competed, with him, or contended with him for superiority, in faxor [i. e. glorying, or boasting, &c., or in glory, or excellence, i. e. he emulated, or rivalled, him therein, and he surpassed him, or overcame him, therein; and, simply, he vied with him, and surpassed him]: (Msb, * K:) or he contended with him for superiority in generousness or nobleness of father and mother: (ISk, S:) and he surpassed him, or overcame him, therein. (ISk, S, Msb, K.)

4. Afgrhu Ealayohi; (ISk, S, O, K;) and fxRrhu↓ Elyh, inf. n. tafoxiyrN; (ISk, S, O;) or Elyh faxarahu↓, aor.
faxara
, (AZ, O, * K,) inf. n. faxorN; (AZ, O, TA;) He judged him, or made him, to excel, or to have excelled, him in faxor [or glorying, or boasting, or glory, or excellence]. (ISk, S, O, K.)
Oafoxarato She (a woman) brought forth none but such as was faAxir [or goodly, &c.]. (Lth, O.)

5. tfxRr (S, TA) and tfAxr↓ (TA) He magnified himself; he was, or became, proud, haughty, or disdainful; syn. of the inf. n. of the former taEaZRumN, and takabRurN; (S, TA;) and that of the latter taEaAZumN. (TA.)

6. tfAxrwA [They vied, or competed, or contended for superiority, one with another, in faxor, i. e., glorying, or boasting, or in glory, or excel-lence, i. e. they emulated, or rivalled, one another therein; and, simply, they vied, one with another;] they boasted together, one party against another. (S, * K.) tfAxrwA fiymaA bayonahumo They boasted among themselves of their several causes of boasting. (Msb.)
See also 1, in two places; and 5.
8: see 1, first sentence.
[Hence,] Aftxrt zawaAxiruhu (tropical:) [Its herbs] became tall. (A, TA.)

10. Astfxrhu He bought it faAxirFA [i. e. of a good, a goodly, or an excellent, quality], namely, a garment, or piece of cloth, (Lth, O,) or a thing. (K.) And in like manner the verb is used in relation to the giving [and app. the taking] in marriage. (O.)

faxorN [Glory: excellence: originally an inf. n.: as also fuxorapN.] You say Ealayohimo UinRahu lacuw fuxorapK↓, i. e. faxorK [Verily he possesses glory, or excellence, above them: or perhaps the meaning of this phrase may be verily he has a disposition to boast himself against them]: and hecaA maA laka fuxorapu↓, i. e. faxoruhu [Thou hast not the glory, or excellence, of this]. (Lh, TA.)
fuxorN and fuxurN Thickness of an udder, with contractedness of the orifices of the teats, and with paucity of milk. (TA.)
fuxorapN: see faxorN, in two places.
fixorapN [A manner of glorying, or boasting]. You say faxara fixorapF HasanapF [He gloried, or boasted, in a good manner]. (Lh, TA.)
faxaArN [said in the Msb to be a simple subst.: see 1].
faxuwrN: see faAxirN.

Also A she-camel great in the udder, contracted in the orifices of the teats: (As, S, O:) or great in the udder, having little milk; (K, TA;) and likewise applied to a ewe or she-goat: or that yields thee what she has of milk, and has nothing remaining thereof. (TA.)
And A thick udder, contracted in the orifices of the teats, and having little milk: (K, TA:) erroneously repeated in the K among words ending with z. (TA.)
And A palm-tree great in the trunk, thick in the branches. (S, O, K.)

Also, and fayoxarN↓, (O, K,) which is likewise with z, (TA,) both applied to a horse, (O, K,) and the latter to a man also, (O,) Great in the yard, (O, K,) and long therein: (K:) and the latter, applied
to a penis, great; mentioned by IDrd as with z: (TA:) and the pl. is fayaAxiru. (K, TA.)

faxiyrN One who vies, or competes, or contends, with another in glorying, or boasting, &c., (O, K,) or for superiority in generousness or nobleness of father and mother; (S;) i. q. mufaAxirN; (K;) like xaSiymN (S, TA) in the sense of muxaASimN. (TA.) You say jaMCa fulaAnN faxiyrF vumRa rajaEa OaxiyrFA [Such a one came contending with others in glorying, or boasting, &c.: then returned last, or meanest]. (A.)
Also Overcome in faxor [i. e. glorying, or boasting, &c.]. (K.)
