Alfirosinu, of the camel, is What corresponds to the HaAfir [or hoof] of the horse or a similar beast: (S, K:) or the part which is below the rusog [or pastern] and in which are the bones called sulaAmaI [q. v.]: and sometimes it is (tropical:) of the sheep or goat: it is of the fem. gender: and the pl. is faraAsinu: (TA:) accord. to Ibn-Es-Sarráj, the n is augmentative, because it is from farasotu, (S, TA,) and [therefore] it has been mentioned before [in art. frs, in which see more]. (S.)
AlfirosaAnu: see what next follows.
AlfuraAsinu The lion; (K, TA;) as also AlfirosaAnu↓: and so [AlfuraAnisu and] AlfironaAsu. (TA.) See also the last paragraph below.

AlfuraAsiyuwnu, (K, TA,) with damm, (TA,) The kurRaAv jabaliIR [lit. mountain-leek]: (K, TA:) so it is said to be: it is a four-sided OaSol [app. meaning stem], from which rise many white, foursided, branches, whereon sometimes grow rough leaves like the thumb; and it has a blossom inclining to blueness and yellowness: (TA:) it has the property of clearing the complexion, dissolves thick humours, is diuretic, opens obstructions, and is beneficial as a remedy for the bite of the dog, (K, TA,) i. e. of the mad dog: (TA:) [it is now applied in Cairo to euphrasia: (Forskål, Descr. Anim. &c., p. 145:) and marrubium plicatum. (Idem, Flora Aegypt. Arab., pp. lxviii. and 213.)]
mufarosanu Alwajohi, with fet-h to the s, Having much flesh in the face. (K.) Perhaps the lion is hence called furaAsinu↓. (TA.)

1. faraXahu, (S, A, O, K,) aor.
faruXa
, (S, O,) inf. n. faroXN (O, K) and firaAXN, (S, O, K,) He spread it; expanded it. (S, A, O, K.) You say, faraXtu lahu firaAXFA and faraXotuhu firaAXFA (A, TA) and OaforaXotuhu↓ (TA) ↓and AifotaraXotuhu (A) [I spread for him a bed: or the last signifies I spread it (namely a bed) for myself]. And faraXotu fulaAnFA I spread for such a one. (Lth.) And faraXa fulaAnFA bisaATFA, inf. n. faroXN; and bsATA OaforaXahu↓; and bsATA farRaXahu↓, inf. n. taforiyXN; He spread for such a one a carpet (IAar, K) in his entertainment. (IAar.) And farRaXa↓ AlvRawoba, inf. n. taforiyXN; and AftrXhu↓; [He spread the garment, or piece of cloth: or the latter signifies he spread it for himself.] (TA.) And taHotahu turaAbFA AftrX↓ or vawobFA [He spread, or spread for himself, beneath him, dust, or a garment, or piece of cloth]. (A.) And AlrRamola kunotu OafotariXu↓ waOatawasRadu AlHajara [I used to spread the sand for my bed, and make the stone my pillow]. (A, TA.) And ciraAEayohi AftrX↓, (A, TA,) and yadayohi, (TA,) He (a lion, and a wolf, and a dog, TA, or a beast of prey, A, TA) spread his fore legs upon the ground: (TA:) and the former phrase, he (a man, Msb, TA) spread his fore arms upon the ground, (S, K, TA,) in the same manner, not raising them from the ground; the doing of which in prostrating oneself in prayer, is forbidden: (TA:) or laid his fore arms upon the ground (Mgh, Msb) like a bed for himself. (Msb.) faroXN [as an inf. n. of which the verb is furiXat, as is shown by an explanation of UaqoEaAdN in the S and L, and by the phrase maforuwXapu AlrRijoli mentioned in the S and O and TA,] in the hind leg of a camel [and of a horse as is shown by the explanation above mentioned of AqEAd] signifies The being a little expanded; which is approved: (S, O, K:) when the width [between the shanks] is immoderate, so that the hock-joints knock together, which state is termed EaqalN [inf. n. of Eaqila], it is disapproved: or, as some say, it signifies its not being erect nor much expanded. (S, O.) And faraXa QllRehu AlfaroXa, (Fr, S,) inf. n. faroXN, (Fr, S, K,) means God spread abroad the young camels; syn. bavRa. (Fr, S, K. *)

[Hence,] faraXahu Oamorahu, (S,) or OamorFA, (K,) (tropical:) He made, or rendered, his states, or case, or affair, (S,) or a state, &c., (K,) ample, or free from straitness, to him; and laid it open to him, altogether; [as though he expanded it to him;] syn. OawosaEahu UiyRaAhu, (S, K,) and basaTahu lahu kulRahu. (TA.) And in like manner the saying of 'Alee,
faraXotukumu AlmaEoruwfa, is expl. by Ibn-Abi-l-Hadeed as signifying OawosaEotukumo UiyRaAhu [meaning (tropical:) I largely conferred upon you favour, or kindness]: but MF deems this strange. (TA.) You say also, faraXotuhu OamoriI (tropical:) I displayed, or laid open, to him my state, or case, or affair; [and so OamoriI OaforaXotuhu↓; (see an ex. voce baATinN;)] syn. basaTotuhu lahu. (A.) [And agreeably with this explanation, probably, the saying of 'Alee mentioned above should be rendered in the opinion of MF.]

[Hence also,] fulaAnN yaforuXu nafosahu lilnRaAsi (tropical:) [Such a one lays himself out for the service of men]; (A;) and nafosahu yafotariXu↓ lahumo: (TA:) [or perhaps, makes himself like a victim for them: (see mutafarRiXN, below:) for you say, faraXahu lilcRaboHi, or OaforaXahu↓, (which latter form is mentioned by Freytag in his Lexicon, but without any indication of the authority,) meaning, (assumed tropical:) he threw him down (namely a beast) for slaughter: (see faroXN, below:)] and AftrXhu↓ (tropical:) he prostrated him, and got upon him: (A:) or (tropical:) he overcame him, (meaning another man,) and prostrated him, (O, K, TA,) and got upon him. (TA.)

faraXa AlmakaAna, aor.
faruXa
and
fariXa
, inf. n. faroXN, means He spread the place [with carpets or the like]; as also AfrXhu↓, and frRXhu↓. (Msb.) And AldRaAra frRX↓, inf. n. taforiyXN, He paved the house; (Lth, S, K;) he spread in the house baked bricks, or broad and thin stones. (Az, TA.)
hecaA firaAXN yaforuXuka [This is a bed sufficiently large for thee] is like the saying hecihi XamolapN taXomaluka i. e. tasaEuka. (TA in art. Xml.)
frX Eanohu [app. faraXa] He desired, and prepared himself for, it, or him. (TA.)

And faraXa, aor.
faruXa
, (O, TA,) inf. n. faroXN, (O, K, TA,) He lied: (O, K, * TA:) one says, kamo taforuXu i. e. [How long] wilt thou lie? (O, TA.)
2: see 1, in four places; two near the beginning and two near the end.

frRX AlzRaroEu, inf. n. taforiyXN, (tropical:) The seed-produce spread itself (S, A, TA) upon the surface of the earth. (TA.) You say, farRaxa AlzRaroEu wafarRaXa (tropical:) [The seed-produce put forth its shoots, and spread itself upon the surface of the earth]. (A.) And the latter of these two verbs is also like the former [in signification]. (TA.)

frRX AlTRaAYiru, (A, K,) inf. n. as above; (K;) and tfrRX↓; (S, A, K;) (tropical:) The bird expanded and flapped its wings, (S, A, K, * TA,) EalaI XaIoCK over a thing, (A, K, TA,) without alighting: (A, TA:) and ↓the latter verb, it (a young locust) spread its wings. (Mgh.)
4: see 1, in five places.

AfrXhu also signifies (tropical:) He spoke evil of him; or did so in his absence: (IAar, A, * O, K, TA:) and they say, OaforaXota fiI EiroDiI (tropical:) [Thou spakest evil of me; &c.]. (TA.) [See AftrX EiroDahu.]
And (assumed tropical:) He made it thin; or thin, and fine in the edge; namely, a sword. (O, K.)
AfrX AlXRajaru (tropical:) The trees put forth branches; syn. OagoSana. (A, TA.)

AfrX Eanohu (tropical:) He, or it, left him, or quitted him. (S, A, K.) You say, Darabahu famaA OaforaXa Eanohu HatRaI qatalahu (tropical:) He beat him, or smote him, and left him not until he slew him. (A, * TA.) And AfrX Eanohumu Almawotu (tropical:) Death quitted them; became withdrawn from them. (IAar, O.)
AfrXt said of a mare, (assumed tropical:) She desired to be covered. (O.)
AfrXhu [from faroXN signifying “ young camels ”] He gave him young camels, (O, K,) small or large. (O.)
And AfrX [app. OaforaXa, or perhaps OuXorifa,] He (a man) became a possessor of frX [app. faroX, and meaning young camels]. (IKtt, TA.)
And AfrX said of a place, It abounded with faraAX, (O, K, TA,) i. e., [app., moths, or butterflies, and, as being the cause thereof,] seed-produce. (TA.)
Oaqofala faOaforaXa [He locked, and made fast by means of the catch, or catches, (faraAXap, or faraAX, which see below,) of the lock]. (S, TA.)
5: see 2, last sentence, in two places.
7: see 8, last signification.
8: see 1, first quarter, in five places; and latter half, in two places.
AftrX lisaAnahu [lit.] He expanded his tongue: (S:) i. e. (tropical:) he spoke in whatsoever manner he desired. (S, A, K.)
AftrXhu (tropical:) He trod upon him or it: (S, K, TA:) [as though he made him or it a carpet or a bed:] from AlfaroXu and AlfiraAXu. (TA.)
[Hence,] AftrX AlTRariyqa (tropical:) He went, or travelled, along the road. (TA.)
[Hence also,] AftrX QmoraOapF (assumed tropical:) He compressed a woman. (TA.)
And (assumed tropical:) He took to wife a woman. (O.) One says, AftrX kariymapF (assumed tropical:) He took to wife a female of high birth. (TA.)

[Hence also,] AftrX EiroDahu lit. He made his honour as a bed for himself to tread upon; (O, TA;) i. e., (tropical:) he treated his honour as a thing which it was allowable to attack, by speaking evil of him. (O, K, TA.) [See also 4, second sentence.]
And AifotaraXatonaA AlsRamMCN biAlmaTari (tropical:) The sky assailed us with rain. (A, * O.)
And AftrX AlmaAla (tropical:) He took the mAl [i. e. property, or cattle, &c.,] wrongfully, or by force. (K, TA.)
And AftrX Oavarahu (tropical:) He followed his footsteps; he tracked him. (A, O, K.)

AifotaraXa [in one of my copies of the S, AufoturiXa, which is also allowable, as the verb in the act. form is trans. as well as intrans.,] It became spread, or expanded; (S, K, TA;) as also AnfrX↓; said of a garment or the like. (TA.)
faroXN [an inf. n. of 1, q. v. passim.

Also, used in the sense of a pass. part. n. in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] What is spread, of household furniture, (S, K,) [such as carpets and mattresses and the like. See also firaAXN.]

(tropical:) Seed-produce when it spreads itself (S, K, TA) upon the ground: (TA:) in [some of] the copies of the K, instead of UicaA farRaXa, which is the right reading, we find AcA furiXa: accord. to some, the word signifies seed-produce when it has become three-leaved, or four-leaved. (TA.)
(assumed tropical:) A place abounding with plants or herbage. (O, K.)

(tropical:) A wide, or spacious, plain, or tract of land, or place: (S, K, TA:) or land that is plain, or even, and soft, and unobstructed by mountains: (TA:) or a depressed tract of land in which are trees of the kinds called EurofuT and salam, (IAar, O,) which cause the mouths of the camels that eat them to become relaxed. (O.) [Hence, app., the saying,] mina AlEaroXi UilaI AlfaroXi, meaning, [From the highest sphere, or the empyrean, to] the earth. (A in art. ErX.)
(assumed tropical:) A collection of trees of the kind called EiDaAh: and a round plot of trees of the kind called TaloH. (TA.)
(tropical:) Shrubs, or small trees: (Lth, A, K:) and small fire-wood. (Lth, K.)

(tropical:) Young camels; or the young of camels; (Fr, S, A, * K;) and fariyXN↓ is said to have this meaning; but accord. to Aboo-Bekr, erroneously: (TA:) so the former signifies in the Kur vi. 143: (S, K:) Fr says, I have heard no pl. of it: and he adds, that it may here be an inf. n. used as a subst., from the saying, faraXahaA QllRehu faroXFA, meaning, bavRahaA bavRFA: [see 1:] (S, TA:) but it is said in the K that in all of the above-mentioned senses that are assigned to it in that work, it has no sing.; meaning that it is used alike as sing. and pl.: (TA:) and bulls or cows: and sheep or goats: (K:) so accord. to some of the expositors of the Kur: (TA:) and such as are fit for nothing but slaughter, (K, TA,) of camels, and of bulls or cows, and of sheep or goats; as some say: (TA:) or such as is thrown down (yuforaXu, i. e., yuloqaI,) for slaughter, of the young of camels, and bulls or cows, and sheep or goats; used alike as sing. and pl.: (Mgh:) and faroXu AlUibili also signifies old camels. (Th, TA.)

faroXapN A track, somewhat depressed, extending to the distance [of the journey] of a day and a night, and the like thereof, and only in land that is wide and level and like the [desert termed] SaHoraMC: pl. furuwXN. (AHn, TA.)
firoXapN Form; appearance; garb; or the like; syn. hayoYapN: so in the saying, huwa Hasanu AlfiroXapi [He is goodly in form, &c.]. (O, K.)
faroXiIRN A seller of faroX [meaning household furniture such as carpets and mattresses and the like]. (TA.)

faraAXN [Moths, and the like, that fly into the flame of a lamp &c.;] the flying things (S, TA) that fall one after another into the lamp, or lighted wick, (S, K, TA,) to burn themselves: (TA:) [and accord. to modern usage, butterflies also:] a pl., [or rather a coll. gen. n.,] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is ↓with p: (S, K:) the former mentioned in the Kur ci. 3: (TA:) or the former signifies what one sees, resembling small gnats, falling, one after another, into the fire: (Zj:) or young locusts, when their wings grow, (Fr, Mgh, Jel,) and they spread them forth, (Mgh,) and mount, one upon another: (Fr, Mgh:) and silk-worms; app. so called because they become like these when they come forth from the cocoon. (Mgh.) It is said in a prov., OaToyaXu mino faraAXapK↓ [More light, or unsteady, or light-witted, than a moth that flies into the flame of the lamp]. (S.) And faraAXapN↓ is used
to signify (tropical:) A man who is light (A, K) in head; (A, TA;) light-witted, or unsteady; (TA;) such being likened to the frAXp of the lamp, in respect of lightness, or unsteadiness, and contemptibleness. (A, * TA.)

Also Thin pieces of bone, such as fly off from any bone when it is struck: or any crusts, or coverings, that are upon bone, exclusive of the flesh: or the bone of the eyebrow: or what is thin, of the bone of the head: or the bones that come forth from the head of a man when it is broken: (TA:) or faraAXu AlrRaOosi signifies certain thin bones that are next to the bone that covers the brain: (S, TA:) and faraAXapN↓, any thin bone: (S, K:) and AlrRaOosi faraAXapu↓, the thin bones, or pieces of bone, of the head, such as fly off in consequence of a blow. (TA.)
Also, faraAXu AlZRahori The place where the upper parts of the ribs are infixed in [the spine of] the back. (TA.)
And AlfaraAXaAni The two extremities of the haunches, in [or at] the nuqorap, q. v. (TA.)
And The parts of the upper portions (furuwE) of the two shoulder-blades that rise towards the base of the neck and the even part of the back. (AO, O.)

And Two veins, green, or of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour, (OaxoDaraAni,) beneath the tongue. (En-Nadr, O, K. * [In the last of these, this signification and the next are erroneously assigned to the sing. word. See also AlfiraAXu.])

Also, (TA,) or faraAXaA AllRijaAmi (En-Nadr, O,) or faraAXataAhu↓, (IDrd in his Book on the Saddle and Bridle,) The two iron things with which are made fast the check-straps of the headstall. (En-Nadr, O, K.)
And faraAXN and faraAXapN↓ also signify The edge of anything. (Aboo-Sa'eed, in TA, art. nsr.)
And The former, Mud that has dried, after the water, upon the ground. (S, O, K.)
And it is said to signify A little water in pools left by torrents: n. un. faraAXapN↓ [q. v.]. (TA.)
And [Little] bubbles (Habab) upon the surface of [the beverage called] nabiyc: (S, O, K:) and likewise of the water of sweat: (S, * L:) or a little sweat: so says IAar. (L.)

faraAXu qufolK signifies The manaAXib [or catches] of a lock; [app. meaning the little pins which fall into corresponding holes in the bolt of the Arabian wooden lock of a door, (which see figured and described in the Introduction to my work on the Modern Egyptians,) when it is pushed into the hole or staple of the door-post, preventing its being drawn back until they are raised by the key, which has small pins, made to correspond with the holes, so that, being introduced into these, they push up the catching pins:] n. un. ↓with p: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) or qufolK faraAXapu↓ signifies what catches, or sticks fast, in a lock; (S, K;) [or, as expl. in the Arabic Dictionary of Farhát, what enters into a lock and makes it fast;] meaning its teeth; (TK;) [which are the little pins described above:] the word is thought by IDrd to be not Arabic: or, thus applied, it is from the same word as signifying “ a thin bone, ” because of the thinness of the frAXp of the lock. (TA.)

firaAXN A thing that is spread (Mgh, K) upon the ground: (Mgh:) a thing that is spread for one to sit or lie upon; in which sense it is used in the Kur ii. 20: (TA:) and particularly, a bed, upon which one sleeps: (AA, Mgh:) pl. [of pauc.] OaforiXapN (TA) and [of mult.] furuXN, (S, K,) for which one may say, in the dial. of the Benoo-Temeem, furoXN. (Sb.) [See also faroXN: and see what is quoted below from a trad.]
Hence, (TA,) (tropical:) A man's wife; (AA, S, O, K;) as also UizaArN and liHaAfN: (O, TA:) pl. furuXN; so used, accord. to some, in the Kur lvi. 33. (K.)

Also (tropical:) A woman's husband: (AA, Er-Rághib:) and a female slave's master, or owner. (TA.) So, accord. to some, in the words of a trad., Alwaladu lilofiraAXi walilEaAhiri AlHajaru, meaning The child is for the husband; (Er-Rághib, TA;) or for the master of the bed, who is the husband, or the owner of the woman; (Mgh, TA;) or for the bed, so that there is no ellipsis; (TA;) and for the adulterer, or fornicator, shall be stones, like as you say he shall have dust, meaning, nothing; i. e., he shall have no right of relationship; or, accord. to some, stoning. (Mgh.) [See also EaAhirN.]
(assumed tropical:) The nest of a bird. (O, K, * TA.)
(assumed tropical:) A house, or tent. (AA.)

And AlfiraAXu signifies The place against which the tongue goes in the furthest, or innermost, part of the mouth; (AA, O, K, TA;) or, as some say, in the lower part of the Hanak [which word app. here, as it often does, means the palate]: or firaAXu AllRisaAni signifies the portion of skin (Aljilodapu [to which is here added AlXRanRaMC, app. a mistranscription which I am unable to rectify,] that covers the bases of the upper teeth. (TA. [In the TA voce maHaArapu, in art. Hwr, q. v., q. v., it is written AlfiraAXapu.])
fariyXN A plant, or herbage, that becomes spread upon the ground, not standing up upon a stem. (TA.) [See also mufarRiXN.]

And (assumed tropical:) A girl, or young woman, compressed by a man; (O, K; *) an instance of faEiylN from AifotaEala; (O;) [being from AifotaraXa;] but not heard by Az on any other authority than that of Lth. (TA.)

And (assumed tropical:) An Arabian Bull [or perhaps it is properly an epithet applied to that animal as meaning] having no hump: (TA:) [see also mufarRaXN as applied to a camel:] or firaAXN, which is pl. of fariyXN, signifies a sort of oxen, between the diraAb and EiraAb having small humps, and their AEyAb [a mistranscription for OagobaAb, i. e. dewlaps, pl. of gababN,] are flaccid, or pendulous. (TA voce darabaAniyRapN.)

Also (tropical:) A mare, (As, O, K,) or any solid-hoofed animal, (S,) seven days, (As, S, K,) or seven nights, (O,) after her having foaled; (As, S, O, K, TA;) which is the best of times for putting a burden upon her: (O, K:) and that has recently brought forth; (O, K, TA;) so says Kt; like the nufasaM of women; or like the muEowic of she-camels: (TA:) pl. faraAYiXu. (S, O, K.)
See also faroXN, latter half.
faraAXapN: see faraAXN, in ten places.

Also (tropical:) A small quantity of water: (A, O, K, TA:) one says, lamo yaboqa fiI AlUinaMCi UilRaA faraAXapN [There remained not in the vessel save a small quantity of water]. (O, TA.) And A small quantity of water remaining in pools left by torrents, the ground beneath which is seen, by reason of its clearness: and some say, a place where water collects and remains in a smooth, or hard and smooth, rock. (TA.)
And Great stones, like mill-stones, which are laid first [as a foundation] and upon which is then built a tarokiyb, i. e. an enclosure for palm-trees. (TA.)
And AlfaraAXataAni signifies Two cartilages near, or by, the lahaAp [which generally means the uvula; but also, the arches, or pillars, of the soft palate; or the furthest part of the mouth]. (TA.)
farRaAXN One who spreads the carpets and similar furniture [such as beds, or mattresses, and the like, and keeps them in order: app. a post-classical word: fem. with p]. (KL.)

miforaXN A thing resembling the XaAcakuwnap [a kind of thick quilted stuff made in El-Yemen]; (O, K;) i. e. a thing that is put upon the SufRap [or covering next the saddle] to sit upon; (TA;) as also miforaXapN↓: (A, TA:) or the latter is smaller than the former, (O, K,) and is put upon the SufRap of the camel's saddle, (A,) or upon the camel's saddle [itself], to sit upon: (O, K:) [pl. mafaAriXu.]

[Hence,] mafaAriXu is applied to signify (tropical:) Women, or wives. (A, TA.) One says, fulaAnN kariymu AlmafaAriXi (tropical:) Such a one is a person who has highborn wives or women; (A;) or who takes as his wives high-born women. (S, O, K.) One says also of a man who has never married, UinRahu lahaAliku AlmiforaXi, meaning (assumed tropical:) Verily his life has passed away lost. (TA.) And huloku AlmafaAriXi is said to mean (assumed tropical:) Persons who will not die upon their beds, and will not die otherwise than by slaughter. (TA.)
miforaXapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

jamalN mufarRaXN, (O, K,) [and] jamalN mufotariXu↓ AlOaroDi, (T, TA,) or AlZRahori mufotaraXu↓, (A, TA,) (tropical:) A camel having no hump. (T, A, O, K, TA.) [See also fariyXN.] And AlZRahori OakamapN mufotariXapu↓, (S, TA,) or AlZhr mufotaraXapu↓, (as in one of my copies of the S and in a copy of the A,) (tropical:) A flat-topped [hill, or eminence, of the kind termed] Akmp. (S, A, TA.)
mufarRiXN Seed-produce spreading itself (S, K, TA) upon the ground. (TA.) [See also fariyXN.]
XajRapN mufarRiXapN A wound of the head that reaches to the faraAX [q. v.]; as also mufotariXapN↓: (L:) or that cracks the bone but does not crush. (S, O, K.)

maforuwXapu AlrRijoli (S, O, TA) applied to a she-camel, (TA,) Having what is termed faroXN in the kind leg; (thus, by implication, in the S and O; [see 1;]) or having a [certain] bending in the kind leg. (TA.)
mufotaraXN; and its fem., with p: see mufarRaXN.
mufotariXN; and its fem., with p: see mufarRaXN:
and for the latter, see also mufarRiXN.

fulaAnN mutafarRiXN lilnRaAsi (tropical:) Such a one is a person who lays himself out for the service of men, or makes himself like a victim for them, (yaforuXu lahumo nafosahu,) in kindness for them. (A.) And fulaAnN kariymN mutafarRiXN liOaSoHaAbihi (tropical:) Such a one is a generous person, who lays himself out for the service of his companions, &c.; expl. by the words yafotariXu nafosahu lahumo. (TA.)

Q. 1. faroXaHa, inf. n. faroXaHapN (S, K) and faroXaHaI, (K,) He (a man, S) parted his legs; (K:) or he parted his legs in sitting; and so faroXaTa: (Lh, S:) or he spread his legs wide apart: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) and he stood with his legs wide apart in prayer; (Ks, S;) and so frXH rijolayohi: (S:) or he sat in a relaxed state, with his thighs cleaving to the ground; (K;) and so faroXaTa: (TA:) or he leaped, or jumped; (K;) or made short leaps or jumps. (TA.) And faroXaHato, (S, L, and so in some copies of the K,) or tafaroXaHato↓, (thus in other copies of the K, and thus in the CK,) She (a camel) parted her kind legs to be milked (S, L, K) and to stale. (L.)
Q. 2. tafaroXaHato: see what immediately precedes.

firoXaAHN A broad, or wide, land: (K, TA:) accord. to the K, syn. with firosaAHN; but Sh says that the latter is a mistranscription; the former being the correct word, from faroXaHa fiI jilosatihi: and Az mentions the latter as from the Jm, but not found by him as on trustworthy authority. (TA in art. frsH.)
And A spreading, or wide, solid hoof. (S, K.)
And Clouds (saHaAb) in which is no rain. (K.)
And An unseemly, or ugly, and old, woman, and she-camel. (K.)
AlfiroXiyHu (tropical:) The penis: (K, TA:) a tropical term. (TA.)

1. faraSahu, (M, K,) aor.
faruSa
, (TA,) or
fariSa
, (O in art. frs,) inf. n. faroSN, (S, M,) He cut it; (S, M, K;) namely, skin, or a skin, (M,) [and metal; (see miforaSN;)] or it signifies, (TA,) or signifies also, (S, K,) sometimes, (S,) he slit it, or cut or divided it lengthwise: and he made a hole in it: (S, K, TA:) namely, skin, or a skin: (TA:) or he slit it, namely, a skin, with an iron instrument having a wide end, like as the maker of sandals slits the two ears of the sandal at the heel, to put into them the XiraAk [or the two arms of the XrAk]: (Lth, TA:) or faraSotu AlnRaEola signifies I made a hole in each of the two ears of the sandal, for the XrAk [or for the two arms of the XrAk]. (S.)

Also, (S, M, K,) aor.
fariSa
, [so in a copy of the M, but accord. to a rule of the K it should rather be
faruSa
,] inf. n. as above, (M,) He hit, or hurt, his fariySap [q. v.]; (M, K; and so in a copy of the S;) or, accord. to [other copies of] the S, his fariyS [q. v.]; (TA;) which is a place where a wound causes death. (S.)

And fariSa, [aor.
faraSa
,] inf. n. faraSN; and furiSa, inf. n. faroSN; He had a complaint of his fariySap. (M.)
faraSa AlfuroSapa: see 8.

2. taforiySu naEoli AlqiraAbi, (L,) or tforiySu Oasofali AlnRaEoli (O, K, TA) [i. e.] naEoli AlqiraAbi, (TA, [in the O baEoda AlqiraAbi, which is an evident mistranscription,]) signifies The ornamenting, or engraving, (tanoqiyX, O, L, K, TA,) of the nEl [i. e. shoe of iron or silver, at the bottom of the scabbard of a sword] (L,) or of the lower part of the nEl (O, K, TA) of the scabbard, (O, * TA,) with the extremity of the [instrument of] iron. (O, L, K, TA.)

3. faAraSaniI fiI AlmaMCi, (A,) inf. n. mafaAraSapN, (K,) He took of the water with me, each of us taking his turn. (A.) The inf. n. signifies The doing, or taking, with another, each in his turn. (K.)
4. OaforaSatohu AlfuroSapu The opportunity gave him power or ability [to do a thing]. (M, A, K.)
5. tfrRS AlfuroSapa: see 8.
6. tfArSwA AlmaMCa They shared the water among themselves by turns. (M, A, * Msb.) And tfArSwA biYorahumo They took, or drew, of the water of their well by turns. (S, K.)

8. AftrS AlfuroSapa He took, or seized, the opportunity; or he arose and hastened to be before another, or others, in taking, or seizing, the opportunity; syn. AinotahazahaA; (O, K;) or AigotanamahaA: (TA:) or he got, or took, the opportunity; as also tfrRShA↓; and faraSahaA↓, (M, TA,) aor.
fariSa
, (so in a copy of the M,) inf. n. faroSN. (TA.) You say also, AftrS AlOumuwra [He took, or seized, opportunities to do things]. (A.) And fulaAnN laA yufotaraSu UaHosaAnuhu wabirRuhu [Such a one's beneficence and kindness are not caught at]; because there is no fear that his beneficence and kindness will become beyond one's reach. (A, TA. [See also 8 in art. frT.])

mani QfotaraSa musolimFA, occurring in a trad., is an instance of the verb derived from faroSN signifying the “ act of cutting, ” or from furoSapN signifying “ an opportunity; ” and the meaning is [Such as] detracts, or, literally, cuts off, somewhat [from the honour of a Muslim wrongfully]: or assumes authority over the honour of a Muslim wrongfully, by speaking evil of him behind his back, or otherwise, or defaming him. (IAth, L, TA. *)
AftrSt Alwaraqapu [from AlfariySapu, “ the quivering muscle ” so called,] The leaf was caused to quiver. (M, TA.)
faroSN The stones of the muqol [or fruit of the Theban palm]: n. un. with p. (AA, O, K.)
faroSapN: see firoSapN.

Also, AlfaroSapu, The riyH [or flatus] from which results gibbosity [of the back] (AlHadabu): (S, M, O, K:) and Alfarosapu is a dial. var. thereof: (M, TA:) or, accord. to A 'Obeyd, the latter [q. v.] is vulgar. (TA.)

furoSapN A turn; a time at which, or during which, a thing is, or is to be, done, or had, in succession: (S, A, K:) or a turn, or time, for persons' coming to water in succession, (Yaakoob, S, * M, A, * Msb, K, *) in the cases of the periodical drinkings of their camels, such as the ximos and the riboE and the sidos &c., (Yaakoob, M,) when the water is little; (Msb;) as also firoSapN↓ (M) and fariySapN↓: (Yaakoob, M:) a dial. var. of the same is with s; (IAar, M;) and rufoSapN is another: (TA:) pl. furaSN. (M, Msb.) You say, jaMCato furoSatuka mina AlbiYori Thy turn, or time, for watering from the well has come. (As, S, * Msb. *)
A portion, or share, of what falls to one's lot, of water; syn. XirobN. (S, K.)

An opportunity; a time at which, or during which, a thing may be done, or had; syn. nuhozapN; (S, M, TA;) and furosapN is a dial. var. of the same. (M.) You say, Ainotahaza AlfuroSapa, i. e. AigotanamahaA [expl. above: see 8]. (S.) And OayRaAmuka furaSN [Thy days are opportunities]. (A, TA.)
See also firoSapN.
Also The temper (sajiyRap), and outstripping, and strength, of a horse. (M.)

firoSapN A piece of wool, (As, M,) or of cotton, (As, S, M, O, Msb, K,) or of rag, (S, O, Msb, K,) with which a woman wipes herself, to purify herself from the catamenia; (S, M, * O, Msb, K;) as also faroSapN↓ and furoSapN↓: (Kr, M:) from faraSa meaning “ he cut ” a thing: (As, TA:) pl. firaASN: (K:) or they say firaASN, as though pl. of firoSapN. (IDrd, O.)
And, accord. to AAF, A piece, or bit, of mush. (M.)
See also furoSapN.
faroSaMCu A she-camel that remains aside, and when the trough for watering is vacant, comes and drinks: (O, K, * TA:) from furoSapN signifying nuhozapN. (Az, TA.)
firaASN Strong; (O, K;) as expl. by El-Umawee: (O:) and thick and red; (O, K;) as expl. by Ez-Ziyádee. (O.)
maA Ealayohi firaASN, (O,) or mino firaASK, (K,) means There is not upon him a garment: (O, K:) so says El-Umawee. (O.)

fariySN One who shares in water with another, each taking of it in turn. (S, K.) You say, huwa fariySiI [He is my sharer in water, each of us taking thereof in turn]; and in like manner, mufaAriSiI↓. (TA.)

fariySN is also, like faraAYiSu, pl. of fariySapN; (S;) [or, rather, fariySN is a coll. gen. n., whereof the n. un. is fariySapN↓;] which signifies The portion of flesh [or muscle] between the side and the shoulder-blade which incessantly trembles, or quakes, (As, S, K,) in a beast: (As, S:) or the portion of flesh which is in the part extending from the marojiE [or lower part, next the armpit,] of the shoulder-blade to the arm, on either side, and which trembles, or quakes, when the man, or beast, is frightened: (Zj, in his “ Khalk el-Insán: ”) or the portion of flesh which is by the nagoD of the katif, [which may app. be here rendered with sufficient exactness the cartilage of
the shoulder-blade; or the part of it where it moves to and fro;] in the middle of the side, by the place where the heart beats: there are two such portions, each of them thus called, which tremble, or quake, on an occasion of fright: and the piece of flesh that is between the breast (vadoI) and the marojiE [expl. above] of the shoulder-blade, of a man and of a beast: or, as some say, the lower part (OaSol) of the marojiEu Almirofaqayoni [or place to which either elbow returns, in a beast, when, having been removed from the usual place, it is brought back thereto]: (M:) or a small piece of flesh which is in the heart, and which trembles, or quakes, by reason of a calamity, when one is frightened: (A 'Obeyd:) or a piece of flesh [or muscle] in the side, which trembles, or quakes, when one is frightened. (A.) [Hence the saying,] huwa Daxomu AlfariySapi↓ (tropical:) He is bold and strong. (A, TA.)

fariySu AlEunuqi The external jugular veins (OawodaAj) of the neck: n. un. with p: (A 'Obeyd, S, K:) or the tendons, or sinews, (EaSab,) and veins, of the neck: so, app., says A 'Obeyd, in the following words of a trad.: UinRiI laOakorahu Oano OaraI AlrRajulu vaAYirFA fariySu raqabatihi qaAYimFA EalaI murayoYatihi yaDoribuhaA [Verily I hate to see the man having the tendons, or sinews, and veins, of his neck swelling with anger, rising against his little wife, beating her]: for these are what swell out in anger: (S:) or, accord. to IAar, the meaning is, the hair of the fryS, which term is metaphorically used in relation to the neck, though it [really] has no faraAYiS, because anger causes its veins to swell out [like as fright causes the fariyS properly so called to tremble or quake]: (Az, TA:) fariysN is a dial. var. of the same. (TA.) [See faraSahu, last signification.]
fariySapN: see fariySN, in two places.
AlfariySapu i. q. OumRu suwayodi, (IDrd, O, K,) i. e., AlAisotu. (TA.)
See also furoSapN.
OaforaSu Humpbacked; as also Oaforazu and Oaforasu. (Fr in TA voce OaEojaru.)
miforaSN: see what next follows.

miforaASN (IDrd, S, M, A, O, K) and maforaSN↓ (IDrd, S, O, K) A thing with which silver is cut, (S, A,) and gold: (A:) or a broad iron instrument with which one cuts: (M:) or the iron with which iron is cut, or silver: (K:) or a broad iron instrument with which iron is cut: (IDrd, O:) or the iron with which silver is cut: (O:) [see also miqoraADN:] or, as some say, i. q. UiXofFI [q. v.] with a broad head, with which sandals are sewed. (IDrd, O.) El-Aashà says,

[And I defend your honours, and lend to you a tongue like the mfrAS of the Khafájee, sharp]. (S.) And you say, bayona janobayohi miforaASu AlxafaAjiIRi (tropical:) [Between his two sides is an intellect sharp as the mfrAS of the Khafájee]. (A.) [Hence it seems that among the tribe of Khafájeh were expert workers with the instrument thus called.]
huwa mufaAriSiI: see fariySN, second sentence.
firoSidN and firoSiyodN↓ The stones of raisins and of grapes; (M, O, L, K;) as also firoSaAdN↓. (M, L, K.)

firoSaAdN The [mulberry called] tuwt [q. v.]: (AO, AHn, O, Msb:) or the [tree called] tuwt: or its fruit: (M, K:) or the red twt: (S, Msb:) [or, accord. to Zeyn el-'Attár, the sweet and white mulberry: so says Golius: see tuwtN:] Lth says that it is a well-known tree; that the people of ElBasrah call the tree thus, and call its fruit tuwtN: (T, O, * Msb:) and by firoSaAdN the lawyers mean the tree that bears the [fruit called] tuwt. (Msb.)
Also A red dye; (K:) or redness. (M, L.)
See also firoSidN.
firoSiydN: see firoSidN.

1. faraDahu, (S, A, O, Msb, &c.,) aor.
fariDa
, (Msb, TA, &c.,) inf. n. faroDN, (S, O, Msb, K, &c.,) He made a mark in it, or upon it, by notching, or otherwise: (O:) he notched it: made a notch, or an incision, in it; (S, O, Msb, K;) namely, a piece of wood, (Msb,) a zanod, [or rather faraDahaA said of a zanodap, from which fire is produced,] and a siwaAk [or toothstick], (S, O,) and in like manner a bow; (A;) as also [AftrDhu↓; (see this verb below;) and] frRDhu↓, inf. n. taforiyDN: (K:) or this last signifies he notched it much; or made notches in it; (S, O, TA;) or you say, faraDa qawosahu and farRaDa qisiyRahu: (A:) and faraDahu signifies he notched it with his teeth; namely, a tooth-stick: (As:) and he cut it; namely, a thing; or a hard thing; which is said by some to be the primary signification: (TA:) and he (a tailor) cut it out; namely a garment: (Kull p. 275:) and he cut it out and made it round; namely a shield: (TA:) and faroDN also signifies the cutting, or dividing, lengthwise; cleaving; or the like; applied in a general manner; or the making a trench, or an oblong excavation, in the middle of a grave; faraDotu lilomayRiti signifying I made a trench, or an oblong excavation, in the middle of a grave, for the corpse. (TA.)

faraDa lahu, [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (K, &c.,) He apportioned to him [a thing]: he appointed to him [a thing]: (Bd in xxxiii. 38, and TA: *) because that which is apportioned, or appointed, [to a person] is cut off from the thing from which it is apportioned, or appointed: (TA:) he made [a thing] lawful, or allowable, to him; (Jel in xxxiii. 38, and Kull in p. 275, and TA; *) relating to a case into which a man has brought himself: (Kull:) this is said to be the meaning when the phrase faraDa QllRehu lahu occurs in the Kur: (TA:) he appointed, or assigned, to him a definite portion; (K;) as also lh AfrD↓. (O, L, K.) You say faraDa lahu fiI AlEaTaMCi [He appointed, or assigned, to him a definite portion in the gift]. (As, S.) And faraDa lahu fiI AldRiywaAni (As, S, A) [He appointed, or assigned, to him a definite portion in the register of soldiers or pensioners; or] he registered his stipend therein. (As, A, TA.) And faraDahu, (S,) and AfrDhu↓, (S, K,) He gave to him. (S, O, K.)

faraDa, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (Msb, TA,) also signifies He (God, S, A, Mgh, Msb) made a thing, (S, TA,) or prayer, (A, Mgh,) or statutes or ordinances, (Msb,) obligatory, or binding, syn. Oawojaba, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, TA,) by a known decree, (TA,) [or He imposed a thing &c.,] EalaI UinosaAnK on a man, (TA,) or EalayonaA on us; (S;) and so AifotaraDa↓: (S, A, Mgh, O, K:) or faroDN is like UiyjaAbN; but the latter is so termed in consideration of its befalling; and the former is so called in consideration of the sentence, or decree, respecting it: (B:) [this is said in books on the law, in explanation of the opinion of Aboo-Haneefeh, as opposed to that of Esh-Sháfi'ee: for] accord. to Esh-Sháfi'ee, these two terms are alike; (L, TA;) but accord. to Aboo-Haneefeh, the difference between AlwaAjibu and AlfaroDu is like the difference between heaven and earth: (TA:) this distinction, however, is founded upon contested derivations of the two terms: (Kull p. 276:) and it is said that wherever the phrase faraDa QllRehu Ealayohi occurs, it means UiyjaAbN. (TA.) Also He (the apostle of God) instituted, or prescribed, [a thing as a statute, or an ordinance, or a command or prohibition;] syn. sanRa; (O, K;) on the authority of IAar alone: (O, TA:) but accord. to others, he made necessarily obligatory or binding; and this, says Az, is the obvious meaning. (TA.) Also He (a judge) decreed, or adjudged, [TA.) Also He (a judge) decreed, or adjudged, [a thing, as, for instance,] expenses [&c.]. (Msb.) Also He assigned, or appointed, a particular time for doing a thing; or he determined, defined, or limited, a thing as to time, or otherwise; the inf. n., faroDN, being syn. with tawoqiytN: (Ibn-'Arafeh, A, O, K:) as in the phrase famano faraDa fiyhinRa AlHajRa [And whoso determineth the performance of the pilgrimage therein]; (Ibn-'Arafeh, O, K;) occurring in the Kur [ii. 193]; and in like manner it is expl. by Ibn- 'Arafeh as occurring in xxxiii. 38 of the Kur (O, TA:) but the phrase quoted above is also expl. as meaning and whoso maketh it obligatory, or binding, on himself to perform the pilgrimage therein, by his entering upon the state of UiHoraAm. (TA.)

suwrapN OanozalonaAhaA wafaraDonaAhaA, (K,) in the Kur, [commencing chap. xxiv.,] (TA,) means [This is a chapter which we have revealed and] in which we have set down the obligatory statutes: (O, K:) or in which we have bound you to do according to what is made obligatory therein: (Az, O:) or, as some read, wafarRaDonaAhaA↓, (S, O, K, *) meaning and in which we have set down obligatory statutes, (O, L, K,) one after another: (O, K:) or which we have distinctly explained: (Az, S, O, K:) or we
have distinctly explained what is in it, of lawful and unlawful [things]. (T, TA.)
faroDN also signifies The act of reading, or reciting. (IAar, O, K.) You say, faraDotu juzoYiI I read, or recited, my portion. (O, TA.)

faruDa, inf. n. faraADapN, He was, or became, skilled in the faraAYiD; (A, O, K, TA;) i. e. in the science of the division of inheritances. (TA.) MF says that, accord. to IKtt, the verb is also written faraDa, like kataba: but [says SM] what I find in his “ Kitáb el-Abniyeh ” is the mention of the two modes of writing in the instance of frDt said of a cow; and the verb applied to a man he has not mentioned. (TA.)

faraDato, aor.
fariDa
, inf. n. furuwDN; and faruDato, inf. n. faraADapN; She (a cow) became old, aged, far advanced in age, (S, O, K,) or extremely old. (TA.)
And faraDa, inf. n. furuwDN, signifies It (a thing) became wide; it widened, or dilated. (TA.)
2: see 1, first sentence: and again, in the last quarter of the paragraph.
frRD, inf. n. taforiyDN, said of a man, He had a fariyDap [to give from] among his camels. (O, K.)
4. AfrD lahu: and AfrDhu: see 1, latter part of the first half of the paragraph.
OaforaDati AlmaAXiyapu The beasts amounted to the number which rendered it obligatory on the owner to give from among them a fariyDap. (S, O, K. *)
8. AftrDhu: see 1, first sentence.
lamo yafotariDohaA waladN, occurring in a trad., means [A child had not been brought forth by her; lit.] lamo yaHuzRahaA, and lamo yuwCatRirohaA [a mistake for lm yuwCaXRirohaA]. (TA.)
See also 1, latter part of the first half of the paragraph.
AftrD AljunodN The soldiers received their stipends. (A, K.)
AftrD Alqawomu The people, or company of men, perished, none of them remaining; syn. AnqrD. (K.)

faroDN A mark [made by notching, or otherwise; as is shown by the first explanation of 1]: (TA:) a notch, or an incision, in a thing: (O, TA:) of a bow, (S, A, K,) the place of the string; (K;) the notch (S, A, O) in the curved extremity thereof, (A,) into which the string falls; (S, O;) as also furoDapN↓; (A, TA;) or this is the place of the notch for the string thereof: (Msb:) pl. of the former firaADN (S, O, K) and furuwDN; (TA;) and of the latter furaDN (Msb, TA) and firaADN: (Msb:) also, of a zanod, (S, K,) or [rather] of a zanodap, (A,) the notch; (K;) or the place, or part, whence the fire is produced; (S, K;) the hole, or perforation, that is made in the head thereof, into which the zanod is put, and then twisted round, in producing fire; also called wakorN; (A;) and furoDapN↓ signifies the same: (TA:) and furaDN also signifies notches in an unfeathered and headless arrow [such as is used in the game called Almayosir]. (TA.)

I. q. maforuwDN↓ (A, Msb, K) [Apportioned: appointed; made lawful, or allowable: and] a thing made obligatory, or binding, by God; (S, A, O, K;) for neglecting which one will be punished; like waAjibN; accord. to EshSháfi'ee; (TA in art. wjb;) because it has marks and limits; (S, O, TA;) said to be from the same word signifying “ a mark, ” because it inseparably pertains to a man, like a mark; (TA;) or, as some say, because it necessarily pertains to a man like as does the faroD, i. e. notch, to the arrow; (O, TA;) as also mufotaraDN↓: (TA:) pl. furuwDN. (Msb.) As a law-term, it is of two sorts, faroDu EayonK and faroDu kifaAyapK: the former is That whereof the observance is obligatory on every one, and does not become of no force in respect of some in consequence of the observance [thereof] by some [others]; as religious belief, and the like: the latter is That whereof the observance is obligatory on the collective body of the Muslims, and, in consequence of the observance [thereof] by some, becomes of no force in respect of the rest; as warring against unbelievers, and the prayer over the dead in the bier. (KT.) You say, hecaA OamorN faroDN Ealayohimo, and maforuwDN↓, and mufotaraDN↓, This is [a thing] made obligatory, or binding, on them by God. (TA.) And HaqRuka faroDN, and maforuwDN↓, and mufotaraDN↓, Thy right, or due, is [a thing] made obligatory, or binding, by God. (A.) naSiybFA maforuwDFA↓, in the Kur [iv. 8 and 118], means A share, or portion, determined, defined, or limited, as to time, or otherwise: (Zj, Ibn-'Arafeh:) or, in iv. 118, a share, or portion, cut off and limited. (S, O.) [See also fariyDapN.]

A statute, an ordinance, a command or prohibition, of the Apostle of God; syn. sunRapN. (IAar, O, K.) [But faroDN is generally distinguished from sunRapN: the former, for instance, being applied to prayer appointed in the Kur-án; and the latter, to prayer appointed by Mohammad without allegation of a divine order.]

A gift, or a soldier's stipend or pay, syn. EaTaMCN, (A,) or EaTiyRapN, (S, O, K,) assigned, or appointed. (S, O, K. *) In the copies of the K, mawosuwmap is put by mistake for marosuwmap. (TA.) You say, maA OaSabotu minohu faroDFA walaA qaroDFA I did not obtain from him an assigned, or appointed, gift, or soldier's stipend, (S, O, TA,) nor a gift to be requited, or a loan. (O, TA.) And faroDN also signifies A thing which one makes obligatory, or binding, on himself, and freely gives: or a thing which one gives liberally, not for a recompense. (IDrd, O, K.)

Also Soldiers who receive stipends; (K:) so accord. to Lth, as related by Az; but [Sgh says] I have not found it in the book of Lth: (O:) or soldiers having definite portions assigned to them: (A:) pl. furuwDN. (A, TA.) You say, Einodahu miAYapN mina AlfaroDi He has with him a hundred soldiers &c. (A.)

A shield. (S, O, K.) Sakhr-el-Gheí says, describing lightning, (O, TA,) likening it to a light shield which an announcer of tidings was turning over and over with his hands that a party might see it and be gladdened [by the signal], (TA,)

[I was sleepless by reason of it, it being (in its flickering) like the signalling of the announcer of tidings turning over and over with the hand a light shield]: one should not say quroSFA xfyfA. (S, O, TA: but my copies of the S have qalRaba instead of yuqalRibu.) [See also what follows.]

And A stick, or piece of wood; syn. EuwdN; thus [it means] in the verse (fiI Albayoti) accord. to El-Jumahee, (O, TA,) i. e. in the verse above-cited: (TA:) he says, AlfaroDu fiI Albayoti EuwdN: (O, TA:) whence the author of the K has been misled to explain AlfaroDu as meaning EuwdN mino OaEowaAdi Albayoti. (TA.)

And An arrow before it has been furnished with feathers and a head: (Akh, S, O, TA:) a meaning also heard by El-Jumahee: (O, TA:) and to this, in the hand of the player, 'Abeed ElAbras has likened lightning, accord. to the S; but Sgh says, in the TS, that he did not find the verse cited by J in the poetry of 'Abeed. (TA.)
And A piece of rag: another explanation heard by El-Jumahee. (O.)
And A garment, or piece of cloth: (O, K:) a meaning mentioned by As on the authority of some one or more of the Arabs of the desert, of Hudheyl. (O.) [See also firaADN.]
And it is said that in the verse cited above it means the notch in the zanod [or rather zanodap, mentioned in the first sentence of this paragraph]. (O, TA.)

A sort of dates (S, O, Msb, K) of 'Omán: (Msb:) As says that the best dates of 'Omán are these and the baloEaq: (S, O:) and AHn says, Certain of the desertArabs of 'Omán informed me that when the tree thereof has its fruit ripened, and the gathering is delayed, the fruit falls from its stones, and the raceme remains with nothing upon it but stones hanging to the vafaAriyq [by which they are attached to the ends of the stalks]. (TA.)
firoDN The fruit of the dawom [or Theban palm] while continuing red. (AA, O, * K.)
furoDapN: see faroDN, first sentence, in two places,
A gap, or an opening, in a wall and the like: pl. furaDN. (Msb.)

A gap, or breach, in the bank of a river, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) whence one draws water, (S, O, K,) or by which one descends to the water, (Mgh, Msb,) and by which the ships, or boats, ascend; (Msb;) i. e. (Mgh) its maXoraEap: (As, A, Mgh:) pl., in this and the following senses, furaDN (TA) and firaADN. (A, TA.) Hence the saying, in a trad., faQjoEaluwA AlsRuyuwfa lilomanaAyaA furaDFA (assumed tropical:) Therefore make ye the swords to be maXaAriE [here used in the sense of means of access] to death; (O, TA;) and offer, or expose, yourselves to martyrdom. (TA.) Hence also, firaADN is used in the sense of vuguwrN [pl. of vagorN, q. v.]. (TA.)
Of a sea, or great river, The place where ships unload; syn. maHaTRu AlsRufuni: (S, O, K:) or where they are stationed, near the bank of a river, or near the land. (Mgh.)
Of a receptacle for ink, The place of the ink. (S, O, K.)
Of a door, The najoraAn [or piece of wood in which is the foot; i. e. upon which turns the foot]. (S, O, K.)

Of a mountain, A part sloping down
from the middle and side. (TA.)
furoDataAni i. q. fariyDataAni, q. v., accord. to ISk. (IB.)

faraDiIRN and faAriDN↓ (S, A, Mgh, O, K) and farRaADN↓ (A, Mgh, B) and fariyDN↓ (A, O, L, K) A man skilled in the science of the faraAYiD; (S, * A, Mgh, O, K, * B;) i. e. in the science of questions relating to inheritance; (Mgh;) or in the science of the division of inheritances. (TA.)
firaADN The mouth of a river or rivulet. (S, O, K. *)
And Roads, or ways. (Lth, O, K.) [In this latter sense, app., (as well as in others shown above,) pl. of furoDapN, q. v.]
Also The fire that is elicited from the zanodap. (AHn, TA.) [See also faroDN (of which it is a pl.), first sentence.]
And Clothing: (S, O, K:) one says, maA Ealayohi firaADN There is not upon him any clothing; (S, O;) or, accord. to AHeyth, covering. (TA.) [See also faroDN, near the end.]
fariyDN An arrow having its notch cut; (S, A, O, K;) as also maforuwDN↓. (TA.)
See also faraDiIRN:
and see faAriDN.
Also The cud of the camel; accord. to Kr: but accord. to others this is called, qariyD [q. v.], with q. (TA.)

fariyDapN, of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN: pl. faraAYiDu: said by some to be derived from faroDN signifying the act of “ apportioning, ” or “ appointing; ” because frAYD are apportioned, or appointed: by others said to be from faroDN in relation to a bow. (Msb.) [These remarks apply to the word in all the senses here following.]
A subst. signifying A thing made obligatory, or binding, on a person or persons, (S, Mgh, TA) by God; (S, TA;) an obligatory statute or ordinance of God, in a general sense: pl. as above. (TA.)

A portion, or share, made obligatory, or binding, (K, * TA,) on a man: (TA:) or anything apportioned, or appointed: [and particularly a primarily-apportioned inheritance: (see an ex. in the first paragraph of art. Ewl:)] and hence, faraAYiDu is applied to the portions, or shares, of inheritances; [i. e. the fixed primary portions of inheritances assigned by the Kur-án; which are a half, third, fourth, sixth, and eighth;] because they are apportioned, or appointed, to their several owners. (Mgh.) And hence, (Mgh,) Eilomu AlfaraAYiDi, and elliptically AlfaraAYiDu, (S, * Mgh, O, * Msb,) The science of the division of inheritances; (S, O, TA;) or the science of questions relating to inheritance. (Mgh.) It is said in a trad., (Mgh,) taEalRamuwA AlfaraAYiDa waEalRimuwhaA AlnRaAsa faUinRahaA niSofu AlEilomi, accord. to the relation commonly followed, with the pron. fem., referring to AlfrAYD; and waEalRimuwhu faUinRahu, with the pron. masc., referring to Eilom understood as prefixed to AlfrAYD; [i. e. Learn ye the science of the division of inheritances, &c., and teach ye it to (other) men, for it is the half of science:] it is said to be called the half of science in consideration of the division of statutes into those which pertain to the living and those which pertain to the dead; or by way of amplification. (Mgh, * Msb.) The phrase AlfariyDapu AlEaAdilapu [The equitable portion of inheritance], in a trad. of Ibn-'Omár, is that respecting which the Muslims have agreed: or that for which the authority is elicited from the Kur-án and the Sunneh without there being in these any express statute respecting it: or that is equitably divided, agreeably with the portions and shares mentioned in the Kur-án and the Sunneh. (TA.)

What is made obligatory, or binding, [on the owner, to give,] of pasturing beasts, [i. e. camels,] in payment of the poor-rate; (S, O, K;) the camel that is taken in payment of the poor-rate: so termed because it is made obligatory to be given, of a certain number of camels: the p is added because the word is made a subst., not an epithet: pl. faraAYiDu: (TA:) faraAYiDu AlUibili signifying the dues of the poor-rate, of camels: (A, Mgh: *) the fryDp of twenty-five camels is a binot maxaAD, (Mgh,) or she-camel one year old; (AHeyth;) that of thirty-six, a binot labuwn, (AHeyth, Mgh,) or she-camel two years old; (AHeyth;) that of forty-six, a HiqRap, or she-camel three years old; and that of sixty-one, a jacaEap, or she-camel four years old. (AHeyth.) AlfariyDataAni signifies The jacaEap of sheep, or goats, with the HiqRap of camels; (ISk, S, O, K;) and AlfuroDataAni↓ signifies the same, accord. to ISk. (IB.) And fariyDapN, by an extension of its meaning, is applied to A camel, in other cases than those of the poor-rate. (TA.)
See also faAriDN.
firoyaADN Wide, or broad. (O, K.)
farRaADN: see faraDiIRN.
faAriDN: see faraDiIRN.

Old, aged, or advanced in age; applied to a cow; (S, A, O;) in the Kur ii. 63; (S, O;) and to a ram: (TA:) or extremely aged; or old and weak; applied to a cow; (Fr, Katádeh;) as also faAriDapN and fariyDN↓ (TA) and fariyDapN↓: (K, TA: [but to what these are applied is not shown further than by their being mentioned as fem. epithets:]) or large and fat; applied to a cow: pl. fawaAriDu: (AZ:) and the pl. also signifies sound, or healthy, and large; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TS, K;) not small, nor diseased: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TS:) and, contr., diseased. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, TS, K.)

(tropical:) Old, aged, or advanced in age, and large, big, or bulky; applied to a man: (TA:) or large, big, or bulky; applied to a man; (S, A, O, K;) and to a full-grown unripe date (busorap); (A, TA;) and to the bursa faucium of a camel (XiqoXiqap); and to a uvula (lahaAp); (O, K;) and to a skin for water or milk (siqaMC); (IB;) and to a beard (liHoyap); (A, O, K;) or, applied to this last, it is with p; (Akh, S;) or with and without p: (L:) and without p, applied in the same sense to anything; (S, O, K;) being masc. and fem.: (As, O:) pl. furRaDN, (IAar, S, A, O, K,) applied to men; (IAar, S, A, O;) or this, so applied, signifies goodly, or handsome: (TA:) and fawaAriDu is applied to dates [&c.]. (A, TA.) Also (assumed tropical:) Old, or ancient; (K;) applied to a thing. (TA.) You say DigonN faAriDN (tropical:) Great rancour, or malevolence, or malice; (L;) as also DagiynapN faAriDN: (A, L:) or old rancour, &c. (O.) And DabRN faAriDN (tropical:) Great enmity. (IAar.)

OaforaDu The most [and more] skilled, of men, in the science of the faraAYiD; (S, Mgh, O, K; *) i. e. in the science of the division of inheritances; (S, O, TA;) or in the science of questions relating to inheritance. (Mgh.) It is said in a trad., OaforaDukumo zayodN The most skilled, of you, &c., is Zeyd. (S, Mgh.)
miforaDN An iron instrument with which notches, or incisions, are made. (S, O, K.)
mufarRaDN Notched much, or in many places; serrated; or jagged. (El-Báhilee.)
And hence, The [kind of beetle called] juEal: (El-Báhilee:) or the male of the [beetles called] xanaAfis. (IAar.)
maforuwDN: see fariyDN:
and see also faroDN, as syn. with maforuwDN, in four places.
mufotaraDN: see faroDN, as syn. with maforuwDN, in three places.

1. faraTa, (O, K,) aor.
faruTa
, (TA,) inf. n. furuwTN, (K,) He (a man, TA) preceded; went before; was, or became, before, beforehand, first, or foremost; had, or got, priority, or precedence; (O, K, TA;) as also fariTa, aor.
faraTa
, [inf. n. faraTN; which is therefore used as an epithet applied to one and to more;] (O, TA;) and so AftrT↓, in the phrase AftrT Uilayohi fiI hecaA AlOamori [He was foremost in attaining to him in this affair]. (TA.) [See mufotariTN.]

faraTa Alqawoma, (S, O, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
faruTa
, (S, Msb,) or
fariTa
, (K,) inf. n. faroTN, (S,) or furuwTN, (Msb,) or both, (O,) or the former and faraATapN, (M, K,) He preceded, or went before, the people, or company of men, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) to the water, (S, O,) or in search of water, (Msb,) or to come to water, (M, K,) for the purpose of preparing the buckets and ropes, (Msb,) or for the purpose of putting into a right state the watering-trough (M, K) and ropes (M, O) and buckets, (M, O, K,) i. e. to prepare these for them. (TA.) [See also 5.]

An Arab of the desert said to El-Hasan, EalRimoniI diynFA wasuwTFA laA caAhibFA furuwTFA walaA saAqiTFA suquwTFA, meaning Teach thou me a religion of the middle sort, not passing beyond the due mean, nor falling short of it. (TA.)

faraTa minohu It proceeded from him hastily, before reflection, or without premeditation; [as thought it preceded his judgment;] syn. badara, and sabaqa, and taqadRama. (TA.) [See 3.] You say, faraTa minohu kalaAmN, aor.
faruTa
, Speech proceeded from him hastily, before reflection, or without premeditation; syn. sabaqa, and taqadRama. (Msb.) And faraTa Uilayohi minRiI qawolN A saying proceeded to him from me hastily, before reflection, or without premeditation; syn. sabaqa. (S.) And in like manner you say of an evil action. (TA.)

faraTa Ealayohi He hasted to do him an evil action: (O, TA:) he acted hastily and unjustly towards him. (S, O,
TA.) Hence, in the Kur [xx. 47], UinRaA naxaAfu Oano yaforuTa EalayonaA Verily we fear that he may act hastily and unjustly towards us: (S:) or that he may hastily do to us an evil action: (Ibn-'Arafeh, O:) or that he may hasten to punish us. (Fr, Bd, O, Jel.) [See also 4.] faraTa Ealayohi also signifies He did to him what was disagreeable, or hateful, or evil; he annoyed him. (TA.) And faraTa, inf. n. furuwTN, He reviled. (IKtt.) You say also faraTa Ealayohi fiI Alqawoli: see 4, latter half.
faraTa fiyhi: see 2, near the middle.
faraTa fiI HawoDihi: see 4, last sentence but one.
faraTati AlnRaxolapu The palm-tree was left without being fecundated until its spadix became dry and hard (EasaA, in the CK EaXA, and in the O yaEosuw). (O, K, * TA.)
And faraTati AlbiYoru The well was left until its water had collected again. (Sh, TA.)
faraTa Uilayohi rasuwlahu: see 2.
faraTa wulodFA, or waladFA, and faraTa waladahu: see 4.
2. frRThu, inf. n. taforiyTN, He, or it, made him to precede; to be, or become, before, beforehand, first, or foremost; to have, or get, priority, or precedence; (TA;) as also AfrThu↓. (O, TA.)

He emboldened him, in contention, or altercation; as also AfrThu↓. (TA.) frRT Uilayohi rasuwlFA, (IDrd, O, K,) inf. n. as above, (IDrd,) He sent to him a messenger (IDrd, O, K) among his particular, or special, friends; sent him forward, or in advance, to him: (IDrd, O:) or he made him his deputy in a litigation: (O:) and rasuwlFA AfrT↓ he sent a messenger specially and expressly respecting his needful affairs: (IAar, O, L, K: *) and Uilayohi rasuwlahu faraTa↓ he sent forward, or in advance, his messenger to him, and hastened him: (K, TA: [in the CK, instead of waOaEojalahu, we find wAarosalahu:]) but [SM says,] I do not find this last form mentioned by any of the leading authorities. (TA.)

frRThu also signifies He sent it before, remaining behind it: or he quitted it, and sent it before: (TA:) he left it, and quitted it: (S:) he left him; (AA;) as also AfrThu↓: (Ks, S:) he left him, and became behind him; as also AfrThu↓: (TA:) he left him, and went before him: (S, O, K:) and AfrThu↓ [has a similar meaning,] he left him behind, and forgot him: (Fr:) and he forgot it, namely a thing, or an affair: (K:) firaATN, also, [inf. n. of fArT↓,] signifies the act of leaving: (TA:) and frRT Eanohu he left, forsook, or relinquished, him, or it; or he abstained, or desisted, from it: (TA:) and frRT fiyhi he neglected it; and preferred backwardness (qadRama AlEajozi) in it, or with respect to it; and failed, or fell short, of doing what he ought, or flagged, or was remiss, with respect to it; as also frRThu; (K; [but accord. to the TA, only the former of these two phrases signifies “ he failed of doing what he ought, ” &c.;]) or simply he neglected it; (ISd, TA;) or he failed of doing what he ought, or flagged, or was remiss, with respect to it, and neglected it, (S, O, Msb,) so that it escaped him; (S, O;) as also fyh faraTa↓, (S, O, K, * [in the K, the words rendered “ so that it escaped him ” are omitted,]) aor.
faruTa
, (S, O,) inf. n. faroTN: (S, O, K:) and frRT alone, he flagged, or was remiss; was lazy, or indolent: (TA:) its second pers. sing. is used in cautioning a man against a thing before him, or in commanding him to go forward, or to advance; and is intransitive. (Sb, TA.) Sakhr-el-Gheí says,

That is my weapon, and I will not send it before, remaining behind it: [I fear lest they perform that which they have threatened:] or I will not quit it, nor send it before: or I will not be behind it: (TA:) or I will not neglect it. (ISd, TA.) And Sá'ideh Ibn-Ju-eiyeh says,

With him is a skin, the carrying of which he will not leave, nor quit. (S.) You say also, farRaTotuka fiI kacaA wa kacaA I left thee in such and such [a state, &c.]: (AA, O:) and mina Alqawomi OaHadFA OaforaTotu↓ I did not leave, of the people, or company of men, any one. (Ks, S, O.) And frRT fiI janobi QllRehi He neglected the things of God, and did them not: (TA:) or the command of God. (O, TA.) [See also art. jnb.] And it is said in a trad., layosa fiI AlnRawomi taforiyTN UinRamaA AltRaforiyTu Oano laA yaSoHaI HatRaI yadoxula waqotu AlOuxoraI [There is no falling short of one's duty in sleeping: the falling short of one's duty is only the not awaking until the time of the other (prayer) commences]. (TA.)

Also He let him alone, or left him, for a while; or granted him a delay, or respite; [and so fArThu↓; for] OaTalotu firaATahumo means I long let them alone, or left them, or granted them delay or respite. (TA.)
You say also, frRT QllReh Eanohu maA yakorahu God put away, or removed, or averted, from him what he dislikes, or hates: (Kh, S, O, K:) but this expression is seldom used except in poetry. (S, O.)

frRThu, (O, K,) inf. n. taforiyTN, (TA,) also signifies He praised him immoderately; (O, K, TA;) like qrRZhu: (O, TA:) Sgh has expressed, in the TS, his fear that the former may be a mistranscription for the latter; but seems to have afterwards conceded the correctness of the former, from his mention of it in the O. (TA.)

3. faAraTahumo, (S, O, * K, * in the O and K fArThu,) inf. n. mufaAraTapN and firaATN, (S,) He vied, or strove, with them, to precede them; to outgo, or outstrip, them; to get before them. (S, O, * K. *)

takalRama firaATFA, (S, O, Msb, K,) the latter word being an inf. n. of fArT, (TA,) He spoke hastily; without premeditation; expl. by sabaqato minohu kalimapN; (S, O, K;) he let fall hasty, or unpremeditated, sayings or expressions; expl. by saqaTa minohu bawaAdiru. (Msb.)
See also 2, in two places:
and see 6.
fArThu also signifies He found him; syn. OalofaAhu and SaAdafahu: (O, K, TA:) and so fAlThu and lAfThu. (TA.)
4: see 2, in seven places.

OaforaTato OawolaAdFA, (S, O,) or AwlAdA AftrTt↓, (TA,) said of a woman, She sent children before her [to Paradise, by their dying in infancy]; syn. qadRamatohumo: (S, O, TA:) and AwlAdA AftrT↓, said of a man, in like manner signifies qadRamahumo. (TA.) And you say also, faraTa↓ waladahu He was preceded by his child to Paradise. (IKtt.) And wulodFA faraTa↓, (K, TA,) or waladFA, (CK,) He lost children by their dying young: (K, TA;) as though they preceded him to Paradise; (TA;) and so faraTFA AftrT↓; (Msb;) and waladFA AftrT↓; which also signifies he lost a young child by death: (TA:) or the last of these phrases, (K,) or the last but one, (S, O,) signifies he lost his child, or children, (K,) or a young child, (S, O,) by death before attaining to puberty. (S, O, K.) [See AiHotasaba.] And Alwaladu AufoturiTa↓ The child's death was hastened; or was made to happen early. (Th.)

AfrThu He hastened him; or made him to hasten. (S, O.) And you say also, AlsRaHaAbapF tuforiTu AlmaMCa (assumed tropical:) The cloud hastens and forwards the water in the beginning of the [autumnal rain called] wasomiIR. (TA.) And AfrTt AlsRaHaAbapu biAlwasomiyRi (tropical:) The cloud hastened with the [rain called] wasomiIR. (S, O, and the like is said in the K.) And AfrT biyadihi UilaI sayofihi liyasotalRahu He put his hand hastily to his sword to draw it forth. (IAar, O, K.) And AfrT [alone] He hastened with an affair. (K, * TA.) And He advanced, or went forward, before tarrying, or waiting, or pausing, fiI AlOamori in the affair. (TA.)

AfrT also [very frequently] signifies He exceeded the due bounds, or just limits; or acted extravagantly, or immoderately; (S, O, Msb, K, TA;) fiI AlOamori in the affair; (S, O, TA;) and fI HubRihi in loving him; and fI bugoDihi in hating him; (O, TA;) and fI madoHihi in praising him: (K:) it is likewise said of anything exceeding the due bounds; [meaning it was, or became, excessive, or immoderate:] and also signifies he did more than he was commanded. (TA.) You say also, Ealayohi fiI Alqawoli faraTa↓ He exceeded the due bounds, or just limits, towards him in speech. (K, TA.) And AfrT fiI Alqawoli He talked [excessively, exceedingly, immoderately, or] much. (TA.) [And, AfrT Ealayohi He acted insolently, or presumptuously, towards him.]

Also AfrT Ealayohi He loaded him (namely a camel, IKtt) with that which he was unable to bear. (IKtt, K.) And AfrT He filled (S, O, K) a mazaAdap (S) or a qirobap (O) so that he made the water to flow: (O, K:) or a watering-trough or vessel (TA) so that it overflowed: (K, TA:) and fiI HawoDihi faraTa↓, (O, TA,) aor.
faruTa
, (O,) inf. n. faroTN, (TA,) he filled his watering-trough: (O, TA:) or poured much water into it. (TA.)
And AfrT AlnRaxolapa He left the palm-tree without fecundation until its spadix became dry and hard. (O, L, K. [See 1, near the end.])
5. tfrRT He (a horse) outwent, or got before, other horses. (S, TA.) [See also 1.]
See also the next paragraph.
6. tfArTwA They vied, or strove, one with another, to precede, outgo, outstrip, or get before. (S, O. *) Bishr says, [using the verb transitively,]
[They contend with the reins, being unbroken and refractory, like as the pigeons vie, one with another, in striving to get first to the scanty remains of rainwater]. (S.)
[Hence,] tfArT fulaAnN Such a one preceded, or got before, and made haste. (O, K, TA.)

And hence, (TA,) tafaAraTatohu Alhumuwmu, (O, K, TA,) and AlOumuwru, (O, TA,) (assumed tropical:) Anxieties, and affairs, or events, came to him [as though] vying, one with another, to be first: (K, TA:) or befell him at an indefinite time, (O, * K, * TA,) but only at such a time. (O, TA.) You say also, faAraTatohu↓ Alhumuwmu (assumed tropical:) Anxieties ceased not to come to him at one indefinite time after another. (TA.)

tfArT AlXRaIoCu The time of the thing past; as also tfrRT↓, which occurs in a trad., relating to a time of prayer, and meaning its time passed before its being performed: (TA:) and both of these verbs are used in the sense next following in relation to a warring, or warring and plundering, expedition. (O.) The time of the thing became postponed, or delayed, so that he who desired it did not attain it. (K.) You say, tafaAraTati AlSRalaApu Eano waqotihaA The prayer became delayed after its time. (TA.)
8: see 1, first sentence:
and see 4, in five places.

fulaAnN laA yufotaraTu UiHosaAnuhu wabirRuhu (S, K *) Such a one's beneficence and kindness are not caught at, (laA yufotaraSu, as in a copy of the S and in the TA,) or do not pass away, (laA yanoqariDu, as in another copy of the S,) and (S, TA) their passing away, so that one cannot avail himself of them, is not to be feared: (S, K, TA:) a saying of one of the Arabs of the desert. (TA.)

faroTN Excess; extravagance; exorbitance; an exceeding degree; an exceeding of the due bounds, or just limits. (S, O, K, * TA.) You say, UiyRaAka waAlfaroTa fiI AlOamori [Avoid thou, or beware thou of, excess in the affair]. (S, O.)
Mastery, ascendency, prevalence, or predominance: (K, TA:) as, for instance, of eager desire, and of grief. (TA.)

A time, whether long or short; an indefinite time; syn. HiynN. (S, O, K.) You say, laqiytuhu fiI AlfaroTi baEoda AlfaroTi I met him time after time. (S, O.) And OanaA Mtiyhi AlfaroTa I come to him, or will come to him, at some time. (TA.)

It also denotes one's meeting a man, (TA,) or coming to him, (K,) after some days, (K, TA,) accord. to A 'Obeyd; (TA;) not more than fifteen days, (K,) or than fifteen nights, accord. to the same, (S, O,) nor less than three. (K.) You say, OanaA OaloqaAhu fiI AlfaroTi [I meet him, or will meet him, or shall meet him, after some days]. (TA.) [But the above-mentioned restriction does not apply when it is prefixed to a noun signifying a period of time: for] you say also, Oatayotuhu faroTa yawomK Oawo yawomayoni [app. meaning I came to him after a day or two days]. (S, O.) [It is said in the TA that, accord. to ISk, it is used in the saying Mtiyka faroTa yawomK Oawo yawomayoni, and that it is a day between two days; but this seems to me to be a mistake for between a day and two days: it is afterwards said in the TA that faroTa yawomK Oawo yawomayoni means after two days; but the complete explanation should doubtless be after a day or two days.] Lebeed says,

[Is the soul aught but a borrowed thing to be enjoyed, which is lent, and goes to its Lord after some months?]. (S.) And an Arab said, maDayotu faroTa saAEapK walamo Ouwmino Oano Oanofalita; and being asked “ What is frT sAEp? ” he answered, “ Like since thou begannest to speak: ” he meant [I went away after a little while, or a little while ago, and] by lm and what follows it, I did not feel sure of my escaping. (TA.)
Also A small mountain; (K;) pl., accord. to Kr, furuTN [q. v.]: (TA:) or the head of an [eminence such as is termed] Oakamap. (K.)

And the same, (K,) or faraTN↓, (thus as written in the O,) An erect way-mark, or thing set up for guidance to the right way: (O, K:) pl. OaforuTN and OaforaATN: (K:) [but] it is said in the A that badato lanaA OaforaATu AlmafaAzapi is a tropical saying, signifying maA Qsotaqodama mino OaEolaAmihaA [as though meaning (tropical:) The foremost of the way-marks of the desert, or waterless desert, appeared to us]. (TA.)
furoTN: see furuTN, near the end.

faraTN A person who goes before, or in advance of, others, to the water, (S, Mgh, K,) or who is sent before, or in advance, to seek water, (Msb,) and who prepares for them the ropes and buckets, (S, O, Msb,) and plasters with mud [in one copy of the S and fills] the watering-troughs, and draws water for them; (S, TA;) as also faAriTN↓; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, TA;) being of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure faAEilN, (S, Msb, TA,) like tabaEN in the sense of taAbiEN: (S, TA:) and a number of persons who perform that office; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also furRaATN↓, (S, Msb, K, TA,) pl. of faAriTN: (Msb, TA:) you say rajulN faraTN and qawomN faraTN. (S, Msb.) It is said in a trad., OanaA faraTukumo EalaI AlHawoDi [I shall be your preceder to the pool of Paradise]. (S, O.)
See also faAriTN.
[Hence,] (tropical:) A child [that dies] not having attained to puberty: (K, TA:) [whence the phrase AifotaraTa faraTFA: see 4:] pl. OaforaATN: or faraTN is both sing. and pl. [in this sense]. (TA.)

Hence also, (S, Msb,) (tropical:) A reward, or recompense, prepared in advance, or beforehand: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) and a work, or an action, of the same kind. (K.) You say, of an infant that has died, (S, Msb,) AallRehumRa QjoEalohu lanaA faraTFA O God, make him to be a [cause of] reward, or recompense, prepared in advance, or beforehand, for us. (S, Mgh, Msb.)
[Hence also,] (tropical:) Water [at which one arrives] in advance of other waters. (K, TA.)

[Hence also,] OaforaATu AlSRuboHi, (S, O,) or AlSRabaAHi, (K,) (tropical:) The annunciations, or foretokens, (K,) or the beginnings of the annunciations or foretokens, (S, O,) of the daybreak: (S, O, K:) sing. faraTN. (Lth, TA.)
See also faroTN, last sentence.
Also Haste. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph.
furuTN A swift horse; (S, O, K;) one that precedes, outgoes, outstrips, or gets before, others: (S, A, O:) pl. OaforaATN. (L, TA.)

A case, or an affair, in which the due bounds, or just limits, are exceeded: (S, O, K:) or neglected; (S, * TA;) as also faraTN↓: (TA:) or despised and neglected. (AHeyth, O, TA.) You say, kulRu Oamori fulaAnK furuTN The whole of the case of such a person is one in which the due bounds, or just limits, are exceeded. (A, TA.) And it is said in the Kur [xviii. 27], wakaAna Oamoruhu furuTFA, meaning, And whose case is one in which the due bounds, or just limits, are exceeded: (S, O:) or in which obedience is neglected and unheeded: (TA:) or [one of] preference of backwardness (taqodiymu AlEajozi): (Zj:) or [one of] repentance: or, accord. to some, the meaning is that which here next follows: (O, TA:) wrongdoing; injustice; transgression: (O, K, TA:) some say also, that it means hastening, or acceleration. (TA.)

furuTN (S, O) and furoTN↓ (O) An [eminence such as is termed] Oakamap, resembling a mountain: (S, O:) or the second, accord. to Zbd, the base (safoH) of a mountain: (TA:) pl. OaforaATN (Zbd, S, O) and OaforuTN. (O.) [See also faroTN, last sentence but one.]
faroTapN A single act of going forth; (S, O, K;) and of preceding, or going before. (S, O.)

[A hasty, or an unpremeditated, saying, or action: pl. faraTaAtN. (See 1 and 3.)] You say, AallRehumRa Qgofiro liI faraTaAtiI, i. e. maA faraTa minRiI [meaning, O God, forgive me my hasty, or unpremeditated, sayings, or actions]: (TA:) [or my acts of hastiness, or forwardness, and transgression: for] AlfaroTapu fiI AldRiyni [unless we should in this instance read AlfuroTap, as the Turkish translator of the K has done,] signifies hastiness, or forwardness, and transgression, in religion. (TA.)

furoTapN The act of going forth; (S, O, K; *) and of preceding, or going before. (S, O.) Hence the saying of Umm-Selemeh, to 'Áïsheh, nahaAki Eani AlfuroTapi fiI AlbilaAdi [He (referring to Mohammad) forbade thee from going forth into the country, or provinces]. (S, O.) And fulaAnN cuw furoTapK fiI AlbilaAdi Such a one is a person who makes many journeys. (TA.)

faraTiIRN and furaTiIRN, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) but the latter is said in the Moheet to be with damm, [which most probably means that it is furoTiIRN, and it is thus written in the O,] (TA,) applied to a camel and to a man, Untractable, refractory, or stubborn; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) not rendered manageable or submissive. (TA.)

firaATN (S, O) and furaATapN↓, like vumaAmapN, or firaATapN↓, (so in the O,) Water that is for him, of the tribes, who first arrives at it; (S, O;) water that is common property among a number of tribes, and is for him who first arrives at it: (O, K:) and in like manner the latter word applied to a well. (TA.) You say, bayona baniI fulaAnK hecaA mMCN furaATapN↓ wabaniI fulaAnK, meaning, [This is water between the sons of such a one and the sons of such a one, so that] whichever of them arrives at it first waters [his beasts] and the others do not throng him. (TA.)
fuiraATapN: see firaATN, in three places.
faAriTN Preceding; going before; being, or becoming, before, beforehand, first, or foremost; having, or getting, priority, or precedence: pl. furRaATN. (TA.)
See the sing. and pl. voce faraTN, first sentence.
furRaATu AlqaTaA The foremost of the [birds called] qTA [meaning sand-grouse], who precede the others to the valley and the water. (S, TA.)
faAriTN also signifies One who goes before to dig the grave: pl. as above, and also fawaAriTu, which latter is extr., like fawaArisu, pl. of faArisN, as is said in the O. (TA.)

And hence, (Lth, TA,) AlfaAriTaAni, (Lth, S, O, K,) in the A AlfaraTaAni↓, (TA,) (tropical:) Two stars, (Lth, S, O, K,) separate, each from the other, (Lth, S, O,) before [the stars in the tail of the Bear, app. meaning the Greater Bear, called] banaAt naEoX, (K,) or before the bier (sariyr) of bnAt nEX: [each] being likened to the fArT who goes before a company of men to dig the grave. (Lth, O, TA.)

muforaTN Sent before, or first, or foremost. (TA.) Hence the saying in the Kur [xvi. 64], (TA,) waOanRahumo muforaTuwna And that they shall be sent before, or first, or foremost, to the fire [of Hell], and hastened thither; (Az, O, K, TA;) this being the primary signification: (Az, O, TA:) or forgotten (Mujáhid, Fr, O) in the fire [of Hell]: (Fr:) or neglected, or left: (TA:) or forgotten, and neglected or left, in the fire: and another reading is muforiTuwna↓, meaning [they are] exceeding the limits assigned to them: (O, K:) and another is mufarRiTuwna↓, meaning [falling short of their duty] to themselves, in respect of sins. (TA.)
[Filled, or] full; applied to a pool of water left by a torrent. (S, TA.)

muforiTN Exceeding the due bounds, or just limits; acting extravagantly; applied to a man: excessive; applied to anything; as, for instance, tallness, and shortness. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of 'Alee, laA taraI AljaAhila UalRaA muforiTFA Oawo mufarRiTFA↓ Thou wilt not see the ignorant otherwise than exceeding the due bounds in what he doth or falling short of what he ought therein. (TA.) See also muforaTN.
mufarRiTN: see muforaTN and muforiTN.
mafaAriTN The extremities of a country or the like. (TA.)

fulaAnN mufotariTu AlsRijaAli UilaI AlEulaI [Such a one's emulation is foremost in attaining to eminence]; i. e. he has precedence therein: [see 1, first sentence:] (TA:) said in praise of a man. (TA in art. rnq.)

Q. 1. faroTaHa He made broad, or wide, (K,) or he spread out, or expanded, anything: and so faloTaHa. (L.) Hence, furoTiHa said of a round cake of bread, It was made broad, or wide: (S, L:) said by IB to be correctly fuloTiHa, and to be thus in a verse as related by El-Ámidee. (TA. [But see the pass. part. n., below.])
firoTaAHN: see what follows.

raOosN mufaroTaHN A broad, or wide, head; (S, K;) as also firoTaAHN↓: the former is thus accord. to J; but it is [said to be] correctly mufaloTaHN, with l: (K:) [or] both are correct; r being a letter which replaces l. (MF.)

1. faraEa [He, or it, overtopped, or surpassed in height or tallness: this seems to be the primary signification]. It is said in a trad., yakaAdu yaforaEu AlnRaAsa TuwlFA (O, TA) He is, or was, near to overtopping the people, or surpassing them in tallness. (TA.) And one says, faraEa fiI qawomihi i. e. TaAla [app. meaning He surpassed in tallness among his people or party]; as also AfrE↓. (TA.) And faraEa Alqawoma, (K,) or faraEotu qawomiI, (S, O,) inf. n. faroEN and furuwEN, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, superior to the people or party, (K,) or I was, or became, superior to my people or party, (S, O,) in eminence, or nobility, or in beauty, or goodliness. (S, O, K.) And faraEa SaAHibahu (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, superior to his companion; he excelled him. (IAar, TA in art. brE.) [See also 5.]

And faraEa, (O, K,) aor.
faraEa
, (K,) inf. n. faroEN (TK [as is indicated in the K, and, in the former of the two senses here following, furuwEN also, said in the TA to be syn. with SuEuwdN]), (tropical:) He (a man, O) ascended: and also he descended: thus having two contr. significations: (O, K, TA:) or, accord. to IAar, it has the former meaning, and AfrE↓ has the latter meaning: (TA: [but see what follows:]) you say, faraEotu Aljabala (S, TA) and fiI Aljabali, (TA,) I ascended the mountain; (S, TA;) as also farRaEotuhu↓, (S, O, * K, *) inf. n. taforiyEN: (S, O, K:) and fiI Aljabali farRaEotu↓ I descended the mountain; as also fiyhi OaforaEotu↓: (S, O, K:) or, as IB says, on the authority of A 'Obeyd, fiI Aljabali AfrE↓ means he ascended the mountain: and minohu AfrE↓ he descended it. (TA.)

And faraEotu raOosahu biAlEaSaA, (S, O, K, * TA, *) inf. n. faroEN; (O, TA;) as also qaraEotuhu, (S, O,) inf. n. qaroEN; (O;) (tropical:) I smote his head, [or assailed it, smiting,] syn. Ealawotuhu (S, O, K, * TA) bihaA (K, TA) DarobFA, (TA,) [with the staff, or stick], and biAlsRayofi [with the sword]. (TA.)

faraEotu farasiI biAllRijaAmi, (S, O, K, *) aor.
faraEa
, inf. n. faroEN, (S, O,) (assumed tropical:) I pulled in my horse by the bridle and bit, to stop him. (S, O, K.)

faraEotu bayonahumaA, (S, O,) or bayonahumo, (K, TA,) aor.
faraEa
, inf. n. faroEN, (TA,) (tropical:) I interposed, or intervened as a barrier, (S, O, K, TA,) between them two, (S, O, TA,) or between them, (K, TA,) and restrained (S, O, K, TA) them two, (S, O, TA,) or them, and made peace, or effected a reconciliation, between them: (K, TA:) and frRE↓ bayona Alqawomi, inf. n. taforiyEN, (assumed tropical:) He made a separation, and interposed, or intervened as a barrier, between the people, or party: and hence the saying in a trad., bayona Alganami kaAna yufarRiEu↓ i. e. He was making a separation between the sheep, or goats: IAth says that Hr has mentioned it as with q; but, he adds, Aboo-Moosà says, it is one of his mistakes. (TA.)
