hecaA OawRalu SayodK faraEahu means This is the first object of the chase of which he shed, or has shed, the blood. (TA. [See also 4.])
See also 8.
faraEa AlOaroDa: see 4.

fariEa, [aor.
faraEa
,] (TA,) inf. n. faraEN, (S, O, K, TA,) He (a man) was, or became, abundant, (TA,) or free from deficiency, (S, O, K,) in respect of the hair [of the head]. (S, O, K, TA.) [See OaforaEu.]
2: see 1, near the middle, in two places.

farRaEotu mino hecaA AlOaSoli masaAYila, (Msb, K, but in the latter farRaEa,) inf. n. taforiyEN, (TA,) (tropical:) I derived, or deduced, questions, or problems, or propositions, from this fundamental axiom or principle; (Msb;) or made questions to be the furuwE [i. e. the branches, meaning derivatives,] of this fundamental axiom or principle: (K, TA:) a tropical phrase. (TA.)
See again 1, latter half, in two places.
And see also 4, former half, in three places.
3. fArE AlrRajula He sufficed the man; and bore, or took upon himself, a responsibility for him. (TA.)
4: see 1, in five places.

You say AfrE bihim meaning He alighted at their abode [as a guest]; syn. nazala. (K.) And OaforaEonaA bifulaAnK famaA OaHomadonaAhu i. e. nazalonaA bihi [We alighted as guests at the abode of such a one, and we did not find him to be such as should be commended]. (S, O.)

And AfrE fI lwmh [app. fiI luWomihi] i. e. AinoHadara [as though meaning (tropical:) He lowered himself in his meanness, or sordidness; but I suspect it to be a mistranscription]; a tropical phrase. (TA.)

AfrE AlOaroDa He went round, or about, or round about, (S, O, K, TA,) or did so much, (S, O, TA,) in the land, (S, O, K, TA,) as also faraEahaA↓, and frREhA↓, (TA,) and consequently knew its state, or case, or circumstances. (S, O, K, TA.)
AfrEt AlUibilu The camels brought forth the [firstlings, or] first offspring (AlfaraEa). (O, K.)

And OaforaEuwA, (O,) or Alqawomu AfrE, (K,) They, (O,) or the people, or
party, (K,) were, or became, persons whose camels had brought forth the first offspring. (O, K.)

And AfrE Alqawomu The people, or party, sacrificed the faraE [or firstling of a camel, or of a sheep or goat]: (S, Msb:) or AfrE AlfaraEapa he sacrificed the faraEap, (O, K,) which signifies the same as the faraE; (Mgh, Msb;) and so AlfaraEapa AstfrE↓; (O;) or [simply] AstfrE↓; (K;) and AfrE [alone]; (O;) and frRE↓, (O, K,) inf. n. taforiyEN; (K;) he sacrificed the faraEa; (O, K;) whence the trad., farRiEuwA↓ Uino XaYotumo walekino laA tacobaHuwA garaApF HatRaI yakobara i. e. Slaughter ye the firstling [of a camel, or of a sheep or goat], but slaughter not one that is little, whose flesh is like glue, [until it be full-grown.] (O, TA. *)

And [hence, perhaps,] OaforaEotuhu I made him to bleed. (Msb.) And OaforaEati AlDRabuEu Alganama, (O, K, TA,) so says Ibn-'Abbád, (O, TA,) or fiI Alganami, so in the L, (TA,) The hyena, or female hyena, injured, and made to bleed, (O, K, TA,) or killed, and injured, (L, TA,) the sheep or goats. (O, L, K, TA.) And AfrE AllRijaAmu Alfarasa The bit made the mouth of the horse to bleed. (O, K. [See also 1, near the end.]) And AfrE AlmaroOapa, said of menstruating, It made the woman to bleed. (TA.) And [hence, app.,] AfrE AlEaruwsa He accomplished his want in respect of the compressing of the bride. (AA, O, K. * [See also 8.])

And AfrEt She (a woman) saw blood on the occasion of childbirth: (O, K:) or, as some say, before childbirth: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or at the first of her menstruating: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) or she menstruated: (A'Obeyd, L, TA:) or she (a woman, or a beast,) first saw blood when taken with the pains of parturition, or near to bringing forth: and AfrE lahaA AldRamu the blood appeared to her. (L, TA.)

And AfrE He began, or commenced, discourse, or a narration; (K;) and so AstfrE↓; (Sh, O, K, TA;) and AftrE↓: (Sh, TA:) and likewise, as also AstfrE↓, a thing. (K.) One says, biYosa maA OaforaEota bihi Very evil is that with which thou hast begun, or commenced: (S, O:) and niEoma maA OaforaEota [or OaforaEota bihi] Very good is that which [or with which] thou hast begun. (Msb.) And AfrE safarahu, and HaAjatahu, He began, commenced, or entered upon, his journey, and his needful affair. (TA.) And AfrEwA mino safarihimo They came, or arrived, from their journey when it was not the proper time for their coming. (TA.)
And AfrEwA They sought after herbage in its place (AinotajaEuwA) among the first, or foremost, of the people. (S, O, K.)

AfrE Oaholahu, thus in all the copies of the K, expl. as meaning kafalahumo, and likewise in the O, is a mistranscription by Sgh, whom the author of the K has here followed: it is correctly, AfrE AlawAdiI Oaholahu i. e. The valley sufficed its people; syn. kafaAhumo. (TA.)
OuforiEa bisayRidi baniI fulaAnK, (O, K,) with damm, (K,) means The chief of the sons of such a one was taken (O, K, TA) and slain. (TA.)
5. tfrREt OagoSaAnu AlXRajari The branches of the trees became abundant. (S, O, K. *)
And [hence,] tfrRE AlwaAdiI (assumed tropical:) [The valley branched forth]. (TA.)
[See also an ex. in a verse cited voce faZiyEN.]

tafarRaEato mino hecaA AlOaSoli masaAYilu (O, Msb, K, TA) (tropical:) Questions, or problems, or propositions, were derived, or deduced, from this fundamental axiom or principle; (Msb;) or were made to be the furuwE [i. e. the branches, meaning derivatives,] thereof; (K, TA;) [they ramified therefrom;] is a tropical phrase. (TA.)

tafarRaEahumo (tropical:) He set upon them (O, K, TA) with reviling and the like; as in the A and L: (TA:) and he was, or became, superior to them, (O, K, TA,) in eminence, or nobility; and excelled them: (TA: [see also 1:]) or it signifies, (S, K, TA,) or signifies also, (O,) (tropical:) he married, or took to wife, the chief of their women, (S, O, K, TA,) and the highest of them: (TA:) and tafarRaEotu bibaniI fulaAnK (tropical:) I married among the noble and high of the sons of such a one; like tacarRayotuhumo and tanaSRayotuhumo. (TA.)
8. AftrE: see 4, latter half.
Hence, (TA,) He devirginated a maid; (S, O, Msb, K, TA;) as also faraEahaA↓. (K.)

And hence, AftrE qaSiydapa kacaA (tropical:) [He broached such an ode], and maEaAniIa kacaA [such meanings]: (Har p. 61:) and yafotariEu OabokaAra AlmaEaAniI (tropical:) [He broaches virgin meanings]. (TA, and Har ubi suprà.)
10: see 4, former half, in two places:
and the same again, latter half, in two places.

faroEN The upper, or uppermost, part of anything; (S, O, Msb, K;) the faroE being what branches forth (yatafarRaEu) from the lower, or lowest, part thereof: (Msb:) pl. furuwEN only. (TA.) It is said in a trad. OaIRu AlXRajari OaboEadu mina AlxaArifi qaAluwA faroEuhaA qaAla wakacelika AlSRafRu AlOawRalu [What part of trees is furthest from the plucker of the fruit? they said, The uppermost part thereof; he said, And such like is the first row of the persons worshipping in the mosque]. (TA.) Thus faroEu AlOucuni signifies The upper, or uppermost, part of the ear; (K, * MF, TA;) pl. as above. (TA.) And furuwEu Almuqolatayoni The upper, or uppermost, parts of the two eyeballs. (TA.)
[Hence,] A branch of a tree or plant: (KL, TA:) or the head of a branch: or a great branch: and a branch of anything. (MA.)

[And hence, (assumed tropical:) A branch, or subdivision, or derivative, of anything that is regarded as a fundamental or a whole;] a thing that is built, or founded, upon another thing; opposed to OaSolN: (K, TA:) [the pl. furuwEN, as opposed to OuSuwlN meaning “ fundamentals, ” signifies, in the conventional language of the lawyers and the men of science in general, the derivative institutes of the law, &c.: see 2:] Eilomu AlfuruwEi [the science of the derivative institutes of the law] is what is commonly known by the appellation of Eilomu Alfiqohi [the science of jurisprudence; because it is mainly concerned with institutes derived from fundamentals]. (Hájjee Khaleefeh.)

And (tropical:) The hair of a woman: pl. as above [app. used in a collective sense like the French “ cheveux ”]: (K, TA:) one says AimoraOapN Tawiylapu AlfuruwEi [meaning (tropical:) A long-haired woman]. (TA.) And (K) (tropical:) Full [or abundant] hair. (S, O, K, TA.)

And (tropical:) The noble, or man of eminence, of a people or party: (S, O, K, TA:) pl. as above: (TA:) one says, huwa faroEu qawomihi (tropical:) He is the noble, or man of eminence, of his people or party, (S, O, TA, *) and mino furuwEihim of their nobles, &c. (TA.)

And [app. from the same word as signifying “ a branch of a tree, ”] (assumed tropical:) A valley branching off. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) A channel in which water runs to the XiEob (K, TA) i. e. the waAdiI [here meaning the water-course in a low tract or between the two acclivities of two mountains]: (TA:) [but] in this sense its pl. is firaAEN. (K, TA.)

Also [or qawosN faroEN] A bow that is made from the extreme portion of a branch, (As, S, O, K, TA,) from the head thereof: (As, TA:) and (K) a bow that is not [made from a branch] divided lengthwise (S, O, K, TA) is called qawosN faroEN; (S, O, TA;) such as is [made from a branch] divided lengthwise being called qawosN filoqN: (S, O:) or the faroE is [one] of the best of bows: (AHn, K, TA:) and [this word is used as an epithet, i. e.] one says qawosN faroEN and faroEapN. (K.)

Also, i. e. faroEN, Property that is beneficial, or serviceable, and made ready, or prepared: (O, K, TA:) or, accord. to the S, it is faraEN↓ which has this signification; but this is said by Sgh [app. in the TS], and after him by the author of the K, to be a mistake; and a verse in which it occurs with the r quiescent is cited in the O and K as an ex. of it in this sense: it may be, however, that the poet has made the r quiescent of necessity [by poetic license, for the sake of the metre]; or it may here [properly] signify “ a branch, ” and be metonymically used as meaning recent property. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph, latter half.

faraEN The firstling of the camel, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) or of the sheep or goat, (L, K,) which they used to sacrifice to their gods, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) looking for a blessing thereby; (S, O, Msb;) and faraEapN↓ signifies the same: (Mgh, Msb:) hence, (Mgh, O, K,) it is said in a trad., [implying the prohibition of this custom,] laA faraEa walaA EatiyrapN, (S, O, K, *) or walaA Eatiyrapa laA faraEapa↓: (Mgh: [see EatiyrapN:]) or when the camels amounted to the number for which their owner wished, they sacrificed [a firstling]: (TA:) or when one's camels amounted to a complete hundred, (K, TA,) he sacrificed a he-camel thereof every year, and gave it to the people to eat, neither he nor his family tasting it, or rather, it is said, (TA,) he sacrificed a young, or youthful, he-camel to his idol: and
the Muslims used to do it in the first part of ElIslám: then it was abrogated: (K, TA:) accord. to the Bári' and the Mj, the firstling of camels and also that of sheep or goats are thus called: (Msb:) the pl. [of faraEN] is furuEN, with two dammehs. (K.) It is said in a prov., OawRalu AlSRayodi faraEN [The first of what are taken by the chase or the like is a frE] as being likened to a firstling: so says Yezeed Ibn-Murrah. (TA. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 35.])

The poet Ows Ibn- Hajar, (S, O,) or Bishr Ibn-Abee-Kházim, has used it as meaning The skin of a faraE; (S, O; *) suppressing the prefix jilod: (S:) for they used to clothe with its skin another young one of a camel, in order that the mother of the one sacrificed might incline to it [and yield her milk]. (O; and the like is said in the TA.)
Also, and faroEN↓, Lice: (S, K:) or, as some say, small lice: (TA:) and one thereof is termed faraEapN↓ and faroEapN↓: (S, K:) or, accord. to some, frEp signifies a large louse. (TA.)

And the former (faraEN), Food that is prepared [app. for persons invited to partake of it] on the occasion of camels' bringing forth; like as xurosN signifies such as is on the occasion of a woman's bringing forth. (TA.)
And A portion, or share; syn. qisomN: (O, K, TA:) accord. to some, peculiarly of water. (TA.)
See also faroEN, last quarter.
It is also the inf. n. of fariEa. (TA. [See 1, last sentence.])

faroEapN A high, or an elevated, place of a mountain: pl. firaAEN: so in the saying, Aiyoti faroEapF mino firaAEi Aljabali faQnozilohaA [Come thou to one of the high places of the mountain and descend it]: (S, TA:) or, as some say, it signifies particularly the head of a mountain. (TA. [See also faAriEapN.])
And faroEapu AljulRapi The highest, or uppermost, of the dates of the [receptacle called] julRap [q. v.]. (TA.)

And frEp AlTryq [i. e. faroEapu AlTRariyqi] and frEth [sic, app. faraEatuhu↓,] and faroEaAWuhu↓ and faAriEatuhu↓ all signify The highest part of the road, and the place where it ends: or the conspicuous and elevated part thereof: or faAriEatuhu↓ signifies the sides, or borders, thereof. (TA. [See also qaAriEapu AlTRariyqi.])
And one says, Oatayotuhu fiI faroEapK mina AlnRahaAri (tropical:) I came to him in a first part of the day. (TA.)
See also faraEN, latter half.
furoEapN The blood of the virgin on the occasion of devirgination.
faraEapN: see faroEapN.
[Also] A piece of skin that is added in the qirobap [or water-skin] when the latter is not full-sized, or complete. (O, K.)
See also faraEN, first quarter, in two places:
and the same again, latter half, in one place.
It is also a pl. of faAriEN [q. v.]. (O, K.)

furuwEu AljawozaMCi means The most intense degree of heat: (S, O, TA:) [or rather AlfuruwEu is a name of a certain asterism of AljawozaMCu (which is an appel-lation of Orion and of Gemini, either whereof may be here appropriately meant,) at the season of the auroral rising of which the heat becomes most intense:] Aboo-Khirásh says,

L.foreign: cakaA AlnRaAri mino najomi AlfuruwEi Tawiylu

sense.s: [And a day continued to them, the heat whereof was as though it were the blazing of fire, from the asterism of the furuwEi; a long day]: (S, * O, TA:) in the S, waZalRa lanaA; but correctly lahaA, meaning to the she-asses: (TA:) and Aboo-Sa'eed related it as above with the unpointed E in AlfrwE: (S, * TA:) in the same manner, also, it is expl. by him as used in the phrase fayoHu najomi AlfuruwEi [which I would render the vehement raging of the heat of the asterism of the frwE] in a verse of Umeiyeh Ibn-Abee-'Áïdh: El-Jumahee related it differently, with g; but the furuwg [or rather the farogaAni] are of the stars of Aquarius; and the season thereof [i. e. of their auroral rising] is cold; there is then no fyH. (TA.)

furayoEN, occurring [with tenween, perfectly decl.,] in a verse of Umeiyeh Ibn-Abi-s-Salt, (O, K,) i. q. firoEawonu↓, (O,) which is a proper name of such as was King of the Amalekites [or rather of the ancient Egyptians, in general], like as qayoSar was of the Room [or Greeks of the Lower Empire], and kisoraI of the Persians, (Ksh in ii. 46,) [and also] a foreign word, (Msb,) [wherefore it is imperfectly decl., in Hebr. פַּרְעֹה, i. e. Pharaoh,] a dial. var. of firoEawonu, or used by poetic license: (K:) the pl. of the latter is faraAEinapN. (Msb.)
firoEawonu: see the next preceding paragraph.
faAriEN [Overtopping, or surpassing in height or tallness: this seems to be the primary signification]. You say jabalN faAriEN A mountain higher, or taller, than what is next to it. (S, O.)
And High, or tall; applied to a man, and to an extended gibbous piece of sand. (TA.)

And High, or elevated; goodly in form or aspect or appearance; beautiful: (Aboo-'Adnán, O, K:) or [simply] high [app. in rank or dignity]: (IAar, O:) and also low, ignoble, or mean: (IAar, O, K:) thus having two contr. significations. (O, K.)
And a man of the Arabs said, laqiytu fulaAnFA faAriEFA muforiEFA↓, meaning [I met such a one] one of us ascending and the other descending. (S, O, TA.)
Also sing. of faraEapN, which signifies The armed attendants, or guards, of the Sultán, or sovereign: (O, K, TA:) it is like waAziEN. (TA.)

faAriEapN The higher, or highest, part of a mountain [and of a valley]: one says, Ainozilo bifaAriEapi AlwaAdiI waQHocaro Oasofalahu [Alight thou in the higher, or highest, part of the valley, and beware of its lower, or lowest, part]. (S, O.) See also faroEapN, in two places.

AlfaAriEapu mina AlganaAYimi means The surplus that is deducted [so I render AlmurotafiEapu AlSRaAEidapu, app. such things as cannot be divided and are therefore removed,] from the main stock of the spoils before they are divided into fifths. (TA.)

And fawaAriEN, (pl. of faAriEapN, TA,) applied to tilaAE, [a word variously explained, here, I think, used as signifying either high, or low, grounds, (see its sing. taloEapN,)] (S, O, * K, *) means Of which the channels wherein the torrents flow are in high, or elevated, parts. (S, O, K.)
fayofaroEN (K, TA) and fayofaraEN (TA) A species of trees. (K, TA.)

OaforaEu Free from deficiency in the hair [of the head]; (S, O, K;) contr. of OaSolaEu; (IDrd, S, O, K;) used only in this sense; not applied to a man who is large in the beard or in the whole head of hair: (IDrd, S, O:) the Prophet was OaforaE, (S, O,) and so was Aboo-Bekr, (O, K,) and 'Omar was OaSolaE: (O:) fem. faroEaMCu; (S, O, K;) accord. to IDrd, applied to a woman as meaning having much hair: (S, O:) pl. furoEaAnN, (O, K,) like its contr. SuloEaAnN; (O;) and also furoEN. (K.) 'Omar, being asked, “ Are the SuloEaAn better or the furoEaAn, ” said “ The frEAn are better, ” meaning to assert the superior excellence of Aboo-Bekr over himself. (O.)
faroEaMCu AlTRariyqi: see faroEapN.

Also i. q. muwasowisu [app. as meaning Such as is subject to diabolical promptings or suggestions]: so in the trad., laA yaWumRanRakumu AlOaforaEu [The AfrE shall by no means act as your Imám]. (Nh, K, TA.)
muforaEN Anything tall. (TA.)
muforaEu Alkatifi A man broad in the shoulder-blade: (S, O, TA:) or high therein. (TA.) And katifN muforaEapN A shoulder-blade high, projecting, and broad. (TA.)
muforiEN: see faAriEN, last sentence but one.
miforaEN One who interposes as a restrainer between persons [at variance], (O, K, TA,) and makes peace, or effects a reconciliation, between them: (TA:) pl. mafaAriEu. (S, O, K.)

Q. 2. tafaroEana He (a man, TA) affected the nature, or disposition, of the faraAEinap [pl. of firoEawonu, and here meaning such as are inordinately proud or corrupt or unbelieving, &c., as were the Pharaohs]. (S, * K, TA.)
faroEanapN Cunning; i. e. intelligence, or sagacity; or intelligence mixed with craft and forecast; (S, K, TA;) and pride, haughtiness, or insolence. (TA.)

firoEawonu [Pharaoh;] the surname of El-Weleed Ibn-Mus'ab, king of Egypt: (S:) or the surname of every king of Egypt: (K:) or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (S,) [app. used as a proper name,] anyone inordinately proud or corrupt or
unbelieving; (S, K;) insolent and audacious in acts of rebellion or disobedience, or extravagant therein and in wrongdoing: as also furoEuwnu and furoEawonu; (K;) the last mentioned by IKh, from Fr, and anomalous: (TA:) pl. faraAEinipN. (Msb, K, TA.) It is said in a trad., OaHadunaA firoEawonu hecihi AlOumRapi [app. meaning One of us is the Pharaoh of this people, or nation]. (S: in one of my copies of the S, OaxaconaA and firoEawona.)
And [it is said that] AlfiroEawonu signifies The crocodile, (K, TA,) in the language of the Copts. (TA.)
AldRuruwEu AlfiroEawoniyRipu Certain coats of mail so called in relation to the firoEawon [or Pharaoh] of Moses. (Sh, TA.)

1. faraga, [aor.
faruga
; and app. fariga, aor.
faraga
and
faruga
, as below; inf. n. furuwgN and faraAgN; or, accord. to some, the latter is a simple subst., but it is more commonly used than the former;] said of a thing, It was, or became, empty, vacant, void, devoid, destitute, or unoccupied; syn. xalaA. (Msb.) [You say, faraga mino kacaA It was, or became, empty, vacant, void, devoid, or destitute, of such a thing; or unoccupied thereby.] And faraga laka AlXRaIoCu [The thing was, or became, vacant, or unoccupied, for thee; as though it were a place, or a vessel: and hence, the thing was, or became, exclusively for thee]. (TA voce xalaA.)
[Hence,] faraga (O, * K, * TA) said of a man, (TA,) [and app. fariga also, as below,] inf. n. furuwgN, (tropical:) He died; (O, K, TA;) because his body became devoid of his soul, or spirit. (TA.)

And faraga mina AlXRugoli, (S, O, Msb, K, *) aor.
faruga
, inf. n. furuwgN (S, O, Msb, K) and [more commonly] faraAgN, (S, O, K,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (Msb;) and farag, aor.
faraga
, (O, K,) mentioned by Yoo; (O;) and fariga, aor.
faraga
, (O, Msb, K,) of the dial. of Temeem; (Msb;) and fariga, aor.
faruga
, a compound of two dial. vars.; (O, Msb;) He was, or became, vacant from, devoid of, or free from, business, occupation, or employment; unoccupied, unemployed, or at leisure. (K, * TA.) [See also 5.]
[And hence, faraga mina AlOamori He ceased from, ended, or finished, the affair.]

And faraga lahu and Uilayohi, (O, Msb, K, TA,) aor.
faruga
and
faraga
; (TA;) and fariga, (O, * Msb, K, * TA,) aor.
faraga
; inf. n. furuwgN and [more commonly] faraAgN; (TA;) He made him, or it, his object, or the object to which he directed himself; syn. qaSada: (O, Msb, K, TA:) [or he made him, or it, his exclusive object; agreeably with an explanation of the phrase here following]: whence, in the Kur [lv. 31], lakumo sanaforugu We will make you our object; expl. by IAar as meaning sanaEomidu [which is syn. with sanaqoSidu]; (TA;) and some read sanaforagu; (O, TA;) and some, saniforagu; (O;) and some, saniforigu, asserting that Temeem say niEolimu; (O, TA;) and some, sanaforagu Uilayokumo, meaning sanaqoSidu Uilayokumo; or sanaforugu lakumo means We will apply ourself exclusively (sanatajarRadu) to the reckoning with, and the requiting of, you; and it is said to be a threat; (Bd;) a metaphorical phrase, from a man's saying to him whom he threatens, saOaforugu laka, (Ksh, Bd,) meaning I will apply myself exclusively to the making an assault upon thee: (Ksh:) one says [also] in threatening, laOaforuganRa laka [meaning in like manner I will assuredly apply myself &c.]. (TA.) [See, again, 5.]

fariga AlmaMCu, (S, O, K,) aor.
faraga
, (S, K,) inf. n. faraAgN, (S, TA,) The water poured out or forth, or became poured out or forth. (S, O, K.)

faruga, [aor.
faruga
,] inf. n. faraAgapN, (tropical:) He (a horse) was easy, or good, and quick, in pace, and wide in step. (TA.)
farugati AlDRarobapu (tropical:) The [wound made by a] stroke, or blow, was wide; (O, K, TA;) likened to the farog of the leathern bucket. (TA.)
And faraAgapN (as an inf. n. of which the verb is faruga, TK) signifies The being impatient, and disquieted or disturbed or agitated. (O, K.)
faraga as trans.: see 4.

2. farRagotuhu I made it empty, vacant, void, devoid, destitute, or unoccupied; as also Oaforagotuhu↓. (Msb.) taforiygu AlZRuruwfi signifies The making the receptacles empty. (S, O, K.) And some read [in the Kur xxxiv. 22], HatRaI UicaA furRiga Eano quluwbihimo, (O, TA,) expl. as meaning Until, when their hearts shall be made void of fear, or fright: or, accord. to IJ, furRiga and fuzRiEa and QforanoqaEa [which are all mentioned as readings in the same passage] have one meaning. (TA. [See 2 in art. fzE.])

[Hence one says, frRghu likacaA He made him to be, or become, or he left him, vacant from, devoid of, or free from, business, occupation, or employment; or made him to be unoccupied, unemployed, or at leisure; so that he might apply himself exclusively to such a thing.]
See also the next paragraph.
4: see 2, first sentence.

Afrghu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. UiforaAgN and muforagN, (O,) signifies [also] He poured it out, or forth; (S, O, K;) namely, water [&c.]; (S;) as also frRghu↓, (S, O, K,) inf. n. taforiygN; (S, O;) and Afrg likewise signifies he poured forth blood; (S, O, K;) and Ealayohi faraga↓ AlmaMCa, meaning he poured out, or forth, upon him, the water, is mentioned by Th, who has cited as an ex.,

L.foreign: faragona AlhawaI fiI Alqalobi vumRa saqayonahu

sense.s: [They (referring to women) poured desirous love into the heart; then they gave him to drink the remains of the water of grief, by looking with the wide eyes: but perhaps faragona is here used for farRagona, by poetic license, for the sake of the metre]: (TA:) UiforaAgapN signifies A single act of UiforaAg; and hence the trad. kaAna yuforigu EalaI raOosihi valaAva UiforaAgaAtK [He used to pour upon his head three pourings]. (TA.)

[Hence,] rabRanaA Oaforigo EalayonaA SaborFA, in the Kur [ii. 251 and vii. 123], means (tropical:) O our Lord, pour forth upon us patience, like as [the water of] the leathern bucket is poured forth: (O, TA:) or send down upon us patience (Msb, * TA) that shall envelop us: (TA:) or Oaforaga QllRehu Ealayohi AlSRabora means (assumed tropical:) God inspired him with patience. (Msb in art. rbT.)

[Hence, also,] Oaforaga Ealayohi canuwbFA [lit. He poured forth upon him a bucketful of water] means (tropical:) he talked with him of that in consequence of which he was confounded, or perplexed, by shame. (TA.)

Afrg also signifies He poured metal, such as gold and silver &c., in a molten state, into a mould. (TA.) And He cast a thing, i. e. formed it by pouring molten metal into a mould. (Msb. [See its pass. part. n., muforagN.])
And Afrg Einoda AljimaAEi He poured forth his maMC [or sperma] on the occasion of jmAE. (TA.)

5. tfrRg He was, or became, or he made himself to be, vacant from, devoid of, or free from, business, occupation, or employment; unoccupied, unemployed, or at leisure; syn. taxalRaI mina AlXRugoli. (O, K.) [See also faraga mina AlXRugoli.] Hence the trad. of the Prophet, tafarRaguwA mino humuwmi AldRunoyaA maA QsotaTaEotumo [Be ye, or make yourselves to be, vacant, or free, from the anxieties of the present state of existence as much as ye are able]. (O.)

And tafarRagotu likacaA [I was, or became, or I made myself to be, vacant, or free, from business, occupation, or employment; or unoccupied, unemployed, or at leisure; for such a thing: and I applied myself exclusively to such a thing]: (S: [these meanings are there indicated, but not expressed; and are well known:]) one says, tfrRg liloEibaAdapi [He applied himself exclusively to religious service]: (Msb in art. btl:) and tafarRagotu liloOamori means [also, simply,] taSadRayotu lahu [i. e. I addressed, or applied, or directed, myself, or my regard, or attention, or mind, to the affair]. (Msb in art. Sd.) [See also faraga lahu and Uilayohi.]
And tfrRg bihi signifies taxalRaI bihi [meaning He confined himself exclusively to it; or contented himself with it exclusively of other things]. (K and TA in art. xlw.)

8. Aifotaragotu I poured forth upon myself (S, O) water: (S:) [and so Aftrgt EalaI nafosiI; for one says,] raOayotuhu yagotarifu AlmaMCa vumRa yafotariguhu EalaI nafosihi [I saw him taking, or lading out, the water; then pouring it forth upon himself]. (A, TA.) And Aifotaragotu linafosiI maMCF I poured out for myself water. (O, K.)

10. Astfrgi [He drew forth water &c.]. One says, Astfrg maA fiI AlrRaAwiyapi mina AlmaMCi [He drew forth what was in the leathern water-bag, or pair of leathern water-bags, of water]. (TA in art. Ezl.) El-Akhtal said respecting Esh-Shaabee, meaning to denote the largeness of the latter's retentive faculty, OanaA Oasotaforigu mino UinaMCK waAHidK wahuwa yasotaforigu mino OawaAniIa XatRaI (tropical:) [I draw from one vessel, and he
draws from divers vessels]. (TA.)
Also He vomited intentionally; or constrained himself to vomit: (O, K:) thus it signifies in the conventional language of the physicians. (O.)
Aisotaforaga fulaAnN maA fiI SaHofatihi is a prov., meaning Such a one [exhausted, or] chose for himself, as his share, [the whole of] what was in his SHfp [or large bowl]. (TA in art. SHf.)

And one says, Astfrg fulaAnN majohuwdahu (tropical:) Such a one exhausted his power, or ability; or exerted it unsparingly, or to the utmost; (S, * O, Msb, * K, * TA;) fiI kacaA [in such a thing]. (S, TA.)
farogN Width, breadth, or ampleness. (S, O, TA.)

And The place whence the water pours forth, between the cross-pieces of wood (AlEaraAqiI), of the leathern-bucket; (S, O, K;) as also firaAgN↓: (K: [expl. in the O as signifying the side of the leathern bucket from which the water pours forth:]) pl. of the former furuwgN (TA) and mafaArigu, [which is anomalous, like maXaAbihu and maHaAsinu &c.,] (A, TA,) or this is pl. of maforagN↓. (TA.)

Hence AlfarogaAni, (S, O,) farogu AldRalowi AlmuqadRamu and farogu AldRalowi AlmuWaxRaru, (S, O, K,) or Alfarogu AlOawRalu and Alfarogu AlvRaAniI, (Kzw,) Two of the Mansions of the Moon, (S, O, K,) the Twenty-sixth Mansion and the Twentyseventh; four stars, wide apart, forming the corners of a square, or four-sided figure; (Kzw;) each consisting of two stars, (S, O, K, and Kzw,) of two bright stars, (S,) the apparent distance between each two stars being the measure of five cubits, (S, O, L,) or the measure of a spear; (K;) [see ciraAEN and rumoHN; the former pair consists of the stars a and b of Pegasus; and the latter, of g in Pegasus together with the bright star in the head of Andromeda; as is shown by what here follows:] the Arabs name AldRalowu the four bright stars in Pegasus which form a square, or four-sided figure; i. e., that at the extremity of the neck, which is called matonu Alfarasi, and that which is called manokibu Alfarasi, and that which is called janaAHu Alfarasi, and the star that belongs to both Pegasus and Andromeda: (Kzw, descr. of Pegasus:) [these two pairs of stars are what are commonly known as the farogaAni; and are plainly indicated by the periods assigned to the auroral settings thereof: but the periods assigned to their auroral risings would lead us to apply the appel-lation of the frgAn to some other stars, not easily determinable, in Aquarius: see nawoCN: and see also manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl.] The pl. Alfuruwgu is said to be applied to The farogaAni with the stars around them: (O, TA:) and (accord. to El-Jumahee, O, TA) Alfuruwgu [in the CK erroneously written Alfaruwgu] signifies [The constellation called] AljawozaMCu. (O, K, TA. [But see furuwEu AljawozaMCi, in art. frE.])
farogN also signifies A vessel in which is [the exuded, or expressed, juice termed] dibos, (O, K,) and Saqor. (O.)
Also Land affected with drought, or barrenness. (IB, TA.)
See also the next paragraph.
firogN: see faArigN.

cahaba damuhu firogFA and farogFA↓ mean His blood went for nothing, as a thing of no account, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct, (S, O, K,) and retaliation for it was not sought: (S, O:) and in like manner one says, cahabato dimaAWuhumo firgFA [Their bloods went for nothing, &c.]. (Z, TA.) Hence, in the Kur xxviii. 9, accord. to one reading, waOaSobaHa fuWaAdu OumRi muwsaI firogFA (Ksh and Bd) i. e. And the heart, or mind, of the mother of Moses became [as though it were] a thing that was lost, or that had gone away. (Ksh. [See faArigN.])
farigN: see faArigN, first quarter.

furugN i. q. mufarRagN [Made empty, vacant, void, &c.]: (O, TA:) so in the phrase UinaMCN furugN [An emptied vessel]: (TA:) and so in the saying [in the Kur xxviii. 9], accord. to the reading of Kh, waOaSobaHa fuWaAdu OumRi muwsaI furugFA [And the heart of the mother of Moses became rendered void of patience, or of anxiety, &c.: see faArigN]. (O, TA.)
Applied to a bow, as also firaAgN↓, it means Without a string: or, as some say, without an arrow. (TA.)
farogaAn [whether with or without tenween is not shown] A wide, or capacious, vessel. (TA.)
faraAgN [generally mentioned as an inf. n., and much used as such; but accord. to the Msb, a simple subst.: as a simple subst., it means Emptiness, vacancy, or vacuity, &c.:
and vacancy, or freedom, from business, &c.; or contr. of XugolN, as is said in the K, in art. Xgl: and cessation from an affair:
&c.: see 1].
[bayotu AlfaraAgi means The privy.]
firaAgN A great bowl, that cannot be carried: pl. OaforigapN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
A wide, or capacious, large, watering-trough, of hides. (As, O, K.)
A vessel (IAar, T, O, K) of any kind. (IAar, T, O.)
An udder. (O.)
The half of a load, such as is on either of the two sides of a camel: (AA, O, K:) so in the dial. of Teiyi. (AA, O.)
See also farogN, second sentence.
[As a pl.,] Valleys, or torrent-beds: from IAar, who has not mentioned a sing. thereof, nor the derivation. (TA.)
And [probably as pl. of fariygN↓, agreeably with analogy,] Broad niSaAl [or arrow-heads; the word nSAl being app. understood]. (O, K.)
[As a sing. epithet,] A she-camel having no brand, or mark made with a hot iron. (TA.)
Also A she-camel having much milk, ample in the integument of the udder. (AZ, O, L, K.)
And A bow of which the arrowhead makes a wide wound: or of which the arrow goes far. (O, K.)
See also furugN.
And see the next paragraph, in two places.

fariygN Broad, or wide. (TA.) See firaAgN. [Hence,] DarobapN fariygN (S) or fariygapN (O, K) (tropical:) A wide [wound made by a] stroke, or blow; (S, O, K, TA;) likened to the farog of the leathern bucket: (TA:) and TaEonapN farogaMCu↓, likewise, signifies (tropical:) a wide [wound made by a] piercing [with a spear &c.], (S, O, K, TA,) of which the blood flows. (TA.)
And fariygapN (tropical:) A mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag] that takes in much water; (O, K, TA;) as though having farog, i. e. width. (TA.)

And friygN signifies also (tropical:) Land, or ground, that is even, or flat, as though it were a road, (O, K, TA,) and wide: (TA:) or that is marked by much treading: to such Aboo-Kebeer El-Hudhalee likens the whiteness of the Oavor, i. e. firinod, of a sword. (O, TA.)

And (tropical:) A horse wide in step, (S, O, K, TA,) easy, or good, and quick, in pace; as also firaAgN↓: (O, K, TA:) or swift and excellent, wide in step: or quick in pace, wide in step, applied to a horse or the like; and so firaAgN↓, applied to an ass, and likewise to a man: and, accord. to Z, fariygN applied to an ass signifies wide in step. (TA.)
Also Sharp, applied to an arrow, and likewise to a knife. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) Sharp-tongued, applied to a man. (TA.)
furaAgapN The sperma of a man. (S, ISd, K.)

faArigN Empty, vacant, void, devoid, destitute, or unoccupied; syn. xaAlK; as in the phrase UinaMCN fArigN [an empty vessel]: (O, TA:) and likewise applied to a man, (O, TA, *) meaning vacant from, devoid of, or free from, business, occupation, or employment; (K, * TA;) as also farigN↓: (O, K, TA:) [and often, used elliptically, meaning vacant from, devoid of, or free from, business &c., and care or anxiety or disquietude; unoccupied, unemployed, or at leisure:] and Oaforagu↓ is syn. with faArigN; (O, K;) as in the phrase, of Ru-beh, maA AlmaXoguwlu mivolu AlOaforagi [The busied is not like the free from business]: (O, TA:) [furRaAgN is pl. of faArigN: and] firogN↓ is syn. with furRaAgN; (O, K; [in the former, as is often the case, the sign of tesh-deed in this word has been carelessly omitted; and in the CK, Alfragu is put for AlfurRaAgu, and has been erroneously supposed to be for AlfaraAgu;]) for ex., Tuleyhah Ibn-Khuweylid El-Asadee says, in relation to the slaying of his brother's son, Hibál Ibn-Selemeh Ibn-Khuweylid,

[And what is your opinion of the party when ye slay them? Are they not (though they have not become Muslims) men? And if some small numbers of camels have been smitten (and carried off). and some women, ye will not go away free from care by reason of the slaying of Hibál]. (O, TA.) It is said in the Kur [xxviii. 9], waOaSobaHa fWaAdu OumRi muwsaI faArigFA, meaning And the heart, or mind, of the mother of Moses became devoid of patience: or devoid of everything except remembering of Moses: or devoid of anxiety; because of God's having promised to restore him to her, (O, TA,)
by words in the next but one of the preceding verses. (O.) [See also another reading voce firogN; and another, voce furugN.] And it is said in a form of prayer, AallRehumRa UinRiI OasoOaluka AlEayoXi AlrRaAfigi waAlmaAla AlfaAriga [O God, I ask of Thee ample, or abundant, and pleasant, or good, means of subsistence, and cattle free from labour]. (TA.) And one says, fulaAnN faArigN maXoguwlN, meaning (assumed tropical:) Such a one is devoted to that which is unprofitable. (TA in art. Xgl.) And hecaA kalaAmN faArigN (tropical:) [This is empty talk or language]. (TA.)

Oaforagu [More, and most, empty &c.: and more, and most, free from business &c.]. Oaforagu mino fuWaAdi OumRi muwsaI [More void than the heart, or mind, of the mother of Moses] is a prov. (Meyd. [See faArigN, latter half.]) See also another prov., voce HajRaAmN.
Also i. q. faArigN, q. v.: (O, K:) fem. farogaMCu: see fariygN.
maforagN A place of pouring out or forth: (O, TA:) and [particularly] the part of the leathern bucket that is next to the fore part of the wateringtrough. (TA.) See farogN, second sentence.
Also i. q. sylAn [app. sayalaAnN i. e. The flowing of water &c.; as an inf. n. of fariga said of water]. (TA.)

dirohamN muforagN A dirhem [cast, i. e.] poured into a mould; not maDoruwb [coined or minted]. (TA.) And HaloqapN muforagapN A ring that is solid (S, O, K, TA) in the sides [that compose the round], (S, O,) and [continuous,] not cut. (TA.) One says, humo kaQloHaloqapi Almuforagapi laA yudoraI Oayona TarafaAhaA [They are like the solid and continuous ring, of which it is not known where are the two ends]: (A, TA:) a prov., applied to a company of men united in words and action. (TA in art. Hlq.)
muforagN is also an inf. n. of Oaforagahu [q. v.]. (O.)
musotaforigapN A she-camel having much milk. (O, K. [See also firaAgN.])
And musotaforigN (tropical:) A horse that does not reserve aught of his run [i. e. of his power of running, for the time of need; that exhausts his power thereof]. (O, K, TA.)

farofaxN (S, A, L, K) and farofaxapN↓, (L,) [the former app. a coll. gen. n., and the latter the n. un., Purslane, or garden purslane;] the herb called Albaqolapu AlHamoqaMCu, (S, A, L,) which does not grow in Nejd, (L,) also called farofiynN, (S, A,) i. q. rijolapN: (S, L, K:) an arabicized word, from the Pers. ParoPahon, which signifies “ broad-winged. ” (AHn, L, K.)
Also, the former, The kaEaAbir [which are things that are taken forth, or picked out, and thrown away, in the clearing] of wheat. (K.)
farofaxapN: see the preceding paragraph.

1. faraqa bayona AlXRayoYayoni, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, *) aor.
faruqa
, (S, Mgh, O, Msb,) and in one dial.
fariqa
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. farogN and furoqaAnN, (S, O, Msb, K,) the latter of which has a more intensive signification, (TA,) He made a separation, or a distinction, or difference, (Msb, K, TA,) between the two things, (K, * TA,) or between the parts of the two things: (Msb:) relating alike to objects of sight and to objects of mental perception: (TA:) IAar, by exs. that he mentions, makes it to relate particularly to objects of the mind, such as sayings; and frRq↓, to persons, or material things: (Msb: [and it is stated in the Mgh that the same distinction is mentioned by Az:]) others, however, state that the two verbs are syn.; but that the latter has an intensive signification. (Msb.) It is said in the Kur [v. 28], faQforuqo bayonanaA wabayona Qloqawomi AlfaAsiqiyna [Therefore decide Thou, or make Thou a distinction, between us and the unrighteous people]: accord. to one reading, faQforiqo. (Msb, TA.) fiyhaA yuforaqu kulRu OamorK HakiymK, in the Kur [xliv. 3], means [Wherein] is made distinct [every firm decree]: (Lth, TA:) or is decided; (O, K, TA;) thus expl. by Katádeh. (O, TA.) And in the phrase waqurMnFA faraqonaAhu, (S, O, K, TA,) in the same [xvii. 107], (S, O, TA,) by faraqonaAhu is meant We have made it distinct, (S, O, K, TA,) and rendered it free from defect, (O, K, TA,) and explained the ordinances therein: (TA:) but some read farRaqonaAhu↓, meaning We have sent it down in sundry portions, in a number of days. (S, TA.) waUico faraqonaA bikumu QlobaHora, (O, K, TA,) in the Kur [ii. 47], (O, TA,) means And when we clave because of you the sea; i. q. falaqonaAhu: (O, K, TA:) another reading, farRaqonaA↓, meaning we divided into several portions, is mentioned by IJ; but this is unusual. (TA.) It is also said that Alfaroqu is for rectification; and AltRaforiyqu↓, for vitiation: and IJ says that diyonahumo UinRa QlRaciyna farRaquwA↓, in the Kur [vi. 160, and the like occurs in xxx. 31], means Verily those who have divided their religion into sundry parts, and dismembered it, and have disagreed respecting it among themselves: but that some read faraquwA diyonahumo, without teshdeed, meaning, have severed their religion from the other religions [app. by taking it in part, or parts, therefrom]; or this, he says, may mean the same as the former reading, for sometimes faEala has the same meaning as faERala. (TA.) IJ also says that faraqa lahu Eani AlXRaIoCi signifies He made the thing distinct, or plain, to him. (TA.)

faraqa AlXRaEora biAlmuXoTi, aor.
faruqa
and
fariqa
, inf. n. faroqN, He separated his hair with the comb: and raOosahu biAlmuXoTi farRaqa↓, inf. n. taforiyqN, He separated the hair of his head with the comb. (TA.) [And it is implied in a trad. cited in the O and TA that faraqahu signifies the same as the latter of the two phrases in the next preceding sentence.]

faraqa lahu AlTRariyqu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. furuwqN, (K,) The road presented itself to him divided into two roads: (S, O, K, TA:) or [it means] an affair presented itself, or occurred, to him, and he knew the mode, or manner, thereof: (TA, as from the K: [but not in the CK nor in my MS. copy of the K:]) and hence, in a trad. of I'Ab, faraqa liI raOoIN An idea, or opinion, appeared [or occurred] to me: (TA:) [or] one says, faraqa liI hecaA AlOamoru, inf. n. furuwqN, This affair became, or has become, distinct, apparent, or manifest, to me: and hence the saying, faUino lamo yuforuqo liloUimaAmi raOoIN [And if an idea, or an opinion, appear not, or occur not, to the Imám]. (Mgh.)

faraqato said of a she-camel, and of a she-ass, (S, O, K,) aor.
faruqa
, (S, O,) inf. n. furuwqN, She, being taken with the pains of parturition, went away at random in the land. (S, O, K.)

faraqa, (O, K,) aor.
faruqa
, (K,) He voided dung; syn. caraqa [which is said of a bird, and sometimes of a man]. (O, K. [See also Oaforaqa.])
And He possessed a firoq [q. v.] (O, K, TA) of sheep or goats: (O, TA:) accord. to the K, of date-stones with which to feed camels: but the former explanation is the right. (TA.)
faraqahaA, (K,) inf. n. faroqN, (TA,) He fed her (i. e. a woman) with fariyqap [q. v.]; as also AfrqhA↓, (K,) inf. n. UiforaAqN. (TA.)

fafaraqotuhu faAraqaniI↓, aor.
faruqa
, [He vied with me in fear and] I exceeded him in fear. (Lh, L, TA.)
See also 2, last sentence.

fariqa, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
faraqa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. faraqN, (S, O, Msb,) He feared; or was, or became, in fear, afraid, or frightened. (S, O, Msb, K.) You say, fariqotu minoka [I feared thee, or was in fear of thee]: (S, O, Msb: *) but you should not say, fariqotuka: (S, O:) Sb [however] mentions fariqahu, suppressing mino. (TA.) And you say also, fariqa Ealayohi [He feared for him]. (TA.)

And fariqa, aor.
faraqa
, He entered into a wave, [which is termed firoqN,] and dived therein. (K.)
And the same verb accord. to the K, but accord. to Sgh [in the O] it seems, from the context to be faraqa, (TA,) He drank (O, K) the measure called faraq, (O,) or with the faraq. (K, TA.)

2. frRqhu, inf. n. taforiyqN and taforiqapN, (S, O, K,) He separated it [into several, or many, portions]; disunited it [i. e. a thing, or a collection of things]; or dispersed, or dissipated, it; or did so much [or greatly or widely]; syn. badRadahu. (K.) And frRq bayona AlOaXoyaMCi [He made, or caused, a separation &c., or much, or a wide, separation, &c., between the things]. (Mgh.) [And fiyhimo frRqhu and Ealayohimo He scattered, or distributed, it among them, and to them.] See 1, former half, in five places. It is said in a trad. of 'Omar, farRiquwA Eani AlmaniyRapi waQjoEaluwA AlrRaOosa raOosayoni, (Mgh, O, *) meaning Separate ye your cattle by way of preservation from death, [and make the one head two head,] by buying two animals with the price of one, that, when one dies, the second may remain. (Mgh, O.) And it is said in a trad. respecting the poor-rate, laA yufarRaqu bayona mujotamiEK walaA yujomaEu bayona mufotariqK There shall be no separating what is put together, nor shall
there be a putting together what is separate. (TA. [The reason is, that by either of these acts, in the case of cattle, the amount of the poor-rate may be diminished.]) yufarRiquwna bihi bayona QlomaroCi wazawojihi [in the Kur ii. 96, meaning Whereby they might dissolve, break up, discompose, derange, disorganize, disorder, or unsettle, the state of union subsisting between the man and his wife, in respect of affairs and of the expression of opinion, or, briefly, whereby they might cause division and dissension between the man and his wife,] is from Altaforiyqu as meaning taXotiytu AlXRamoli waAlkalimapi. (El-Isbahánee, TA.) One says also, frRq AlOamora, meaning XatRatahu [i. e. He discomposed, deranged, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled, the state of affairs]. (S in art. Xt.) And frRq EalayonaA AlkalaAma [lit. He scattered speech (app. meaning he jabbered) at us, or against us]. (K in art. bq: see R. Q. 1 in that art.) In the saying in the Kur [ii. 130 and iii. 78], laA nufarRiqu bayona OaHadK minohumo [We will not make a distinction between any of them], the verb is allowably made to relate to AHd because this word [in negative phrases] imports a pl. meaning. (TA. [See p. 27, 3rd col.]) See, again, 1, near the middle.

frRqhu, (O, TA,) inf. n. taforiyqN, (O, K, TA,) also signifies He made him to fear, or be afraid; put him in fear; or frightened him: (O, K, * TA:) and minohu Oaforaqotuhu↓ I made him to fear, or be afraid of, him, or it: (Msb:) and Lh mentions AlSabiIRa faraqotu↓ as meaning I frightened the boy, or child; but ISd says, I think it to be farRaqotu. (TA.)

3. fArqhu, inf. n. mufaAriqapN and firaAqN, (S, Msb, TA,) He separated himself from him, or it; or left, forsook, or abandoned, him, or it: or he forsook, or abandoned, him, being forsaken, or abandoned, by him: syn. baAyanahu; (TA;) and qaATaEahu, and faArazahu; (A in art. frz;) and tarakahu. (Msb in art. trk.) And fArq QmoraOatahu He separated himself from his wife. (TA.)

faAraqotu fulaAnFA mino HisaAbiI EalaI kacaA wakacaA I released such a one from my reckoning with him on such and such terms agreed upon by both: and so SaAdarotuhu EalaI kacaA wakacaA. (TA.) And fuwriqa EalaI maAlK yuWadRiyhi He (an agent) was released from being reckoned with on the condition of his paying certain property for which he became responsible. (TA in art. Sdr.)
faAraqaniI fafaraqotuhu: see 1, last quarter.
4. AfrqwA Uibilahumo They left their camels in the place of pasture, and did not assist them in bringing forth, nor have them got with young. (IAar, O, K.)
And Afrq ganamahu He made, or caused, his sheep, or goats, to stray; and neglected them, or caused them to become lost, or to perish. (TA.)
And Afrq He lost a portion of his sheep or goats. (IKh, TA.)
And His sheep, or goats, became a fariyqap [q. v.]. (IKh, TA.)

Afrq He recovered; (Lth, As, Az, S, O, K;) or recovered, but not completely; (As, O, K;) to which IKh adds, quickly; (TA;) i. e., a sick person from (mino) his sickness; (As, Az, S, O, K;) and one fevered from his fever; (As, S;) and one smitten with the plague: (Lth, TA:) or (K) it is not said except in the case of a disease that does not attack one more than once, as the small-pox, (O, K,) and the measles. (O.)
Afrqt She (a camel) had a return of some of her milk. (O, K.)
Afrq said of a man, and of a bird, and of a beast of prey, and of a fox, He voided dung, or thin dung. (Lh, TA. [See also 1, last quarter.])
And Afrqhu He, or it, caused him to void dung; syn. Oacoraqahu. (K. [But I do not find Acrq mentioned except as an intrans. v.]) See also firoqapN, last sentence.
AfrqhA: see 1, last quarter.
Oaforaqotuhu minohu: see 2, last sentence.

5. tfrRq, inf. n. tafarRaqN (O, K) and tifirRaAqN, (K, TA,) with two kesrehs, but accord. to the “ Nawádir ” of Lh taforiyqN, (TA,) [and in the CK taforAq,] It was, or became, separated, or disunited: or separated much, or greatly, or widely, or into several, or many, portions; or dispersed, or dissipated: contr. of tajamRaEa: and Aftrq↓ signifies the same: (K, TA:) and so does Anfrq↓: (TA:) all are quasi-pass. of farRaqotuhu: (S, * TA:) [or rather the second and third have the former of the meanings mentioned above: and tfrRq has the latter of those meanings:] or AifotaraqaA↓ is said of two sayings, as quasi-pass. of faraqotu bayonahumaA: and tafarRaqaA, of two men, as quasi-pass. of farRaqotu bayonahamaA: (Mgh, * Msb, TA:) so says IAar: (Msb:) [but] one says also, Aftrq Alqawomu [The party, or company of men, became separated; or they separated themselves:] (Msb:) and Esh-Sháfi'ee has used AifotaraqaA↓ as relating to two persons buying and selling; (Msb, TA;) and so have Ahmad [Ibn-Hambal] and Aboo-Haneefeh and Málik and others. (TA.) It is said in a trad., AlbayRaEaAni biAlxiyaAri maA yatafarRaqaA i. e. [The buyer and seller have the option to annul their contract] as long as they have not become separated bodily; (Mgh, Msb;) originally, maA lamo yatafarRaqo OabodaAnuhumaA; for this is the proper meaning. (Msb.) tafarRaqato bihimu AlTRuruqu [properly The roads became separate with them,] means every one of them went one [separate] way. (TA.) [And one says, tfrRqt AlOagoSaAnu (S in art. Xcb, &c.,) The branches were, or became, or grew out, apart, one from another; divaricated; diverged; forked; straggled; or spread widely and dispersedly. And tfrRq Oamoruhu His affair, or state of affairs, became discomposed, deranged, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled, so that he considered what might be its issues, or results, saying at one time, I will do thus, and at another time, I will do thus: see OajomaEa; and XatRa: and Aftrq↓ signifies the same: see an ex. voce faXaA, in art. fXw. And tfrRqt kalimatuhumo (K voce XaAla, in art. Xwl,) Their expression of opinion was, or became, discordant: and tfrRqt MraAWuhumo Their opinions were, or became, so.]
6. tfArqwA They separated themselves, one from another; or left, forsook, or abandoned, one another. (TA.)

7. Anfrq, of which munofaraqN may be an inf. n. [like AinofiraAqN], as well as a n. of place, It was, or became, separated, or divided. (O, K.) See also 5. [Hence,] Anfrq Alfajoru i. q. Ainofalaqa [The dawn broke]. (TA.)
8. Aftrq: see 5, first sentence, in three places: and also in the last sentence but one.
faroqN [is originally an inf. n.: but is often used as a simple subst. meaning A distinction, or difference, between two things.

Hence,] The line [or division] in the hair of the head: (K: [see also maforaqN:]) or, as some say, the part, of the head, extending from the side of the forehead to the spiral curl upon the crown: an ex. occurs in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb cited voce maTorabN. (TA.)
[And app. A blaze on a horse's forehead. (See an ex. voce muEotadilN.)]

And [hence, perhaps,] one says, baAnato fiI qacaAlihi furuwqN mina AlXRayobi i. e. OawoDaAHN [app. meaning There appeared in the back of his head portions of white, or hoary, hair, distinct from the rest]. (TA.)

One says also of the female comber and dresser of the hair, tamoXuiTu kacaA wakacaA faroqFA i. e. [She combs and dresses the hair] with such and such a mode or manner [app. of combing and dressing or of dividing]. (L. [But the last word, which seems to be in this case an inf. n., is there written without any vowel-sign.])
Also A certain bird or flying thing; (TaAYirN O, K;) not mentioned by AHát in “ the Book of Birds. ” (O, TA.)
And Flax. (K.)
See also faraqN, in nine places.
Alfuroqu: see AlfuroqaAnu.
It also signifies A certain vessel with which one measures. (TA. [See also faraqN.])

And [it is said that] AlfuroqaAni signifies qdHAn mftrqAn [app. meaning Two separate bowls, or milking-vessels, supposing the former word to be qadaHaAni; the latter word being mufotariqaAni]. (TA. [This is app. said in explanation of furoqaAni ending a verse in which it means “ milkingvessels: ” but it is said in the S, and in one place in the TA, that it is in that instance pl. of faroqN or faraqN, q. v.])

firoqN A piece, or portion, that is split from a thing, or cleft therefrom; (S, O, K;) whence its usage in the Kur xxvi. 63: (S, O:) and a portion of anything (K, TA) when it is separated; and the pl. is firaqN: (TA:) or a portion that is separated, or dispersed, of a thing; and thus it is said to mean in the Kur ubi suprá; and the pl. is OaforaAqN, like OaHomaAlN as pl. of HimolN. (Msb.) See also firoqapN.

Also A great flock or herd, of sheep or goats: (S, O, K:) and (as some say, TA) of the bovine kind: or of gazelles: or of sheep, or goats, only: or of straying sheep or goats; as also fariyqN↓, (K, TA,) and fariyqapN↓: (TA:) or less than a hundred, (K, TA,) of sheep or goats. (TA.) firoqaAni mino TayorK SawaAfRa, occurring in a trad., in which the second and third chapters of the Kur-án are likened thereto, (L,) means Two flocks [of birds expanding their wings without moving them in flight]. (L, TA: but the first word, in both, is without any vowel-sign.) See, again, firoqapN.

And A set of boys. (O, K.) An
Arab of the desert said of some boys whom he saw, heWulaMCi firoqu sawoCK [These are a bad set of boys]. (O.)
And A distinct quantity of date-stones with which the camel is fed. (K.)
[And app. Any feed for one's beast: see an ex. in art. jl, conj. 4.]
Also A mountain. (IAar, O, K.) And A [hill, or mountain, or the like, such as is termed] haDobap. (IAar, O, K.)
And A wave, billow, or surge. (IAar, O, K.)
And Alfiroqu is the name applied by the Arabs to The star [a] upon the right shoulder of Cepheus. (Kzw.)

faraqN Wideness of the space between the two central incisors, (IKh, S, O, K, TA,) of a man: (TA:) and likewise between the two toe-nails of the camel. (Yaakoob, S, O, K, TA.) And A division in the Eurof [or comb] of the cock: and likewise in the forelock, and in the beard, of a man: (S, O, K:) pl. OaforaAqN. (S, O.) And sparseness, or a scattered state, of the plants, or herbage, of a land. (S, O, K.)

In a horse, The state of the hips when one of them is more prominent than the other; which is disapproved: (S, O, K, TA:) or a deficiency in one of the thighs, in comparison with the other: or a deficiency in one of the hips. (TA.)

Also The dawn: or Alfaraqu signifies falaqu AlSRuboHi: (K:) or what has broken of the bright gleam of dawn; of the dawn that rises and spreads, filling the horizon with its whiteness; (maA Qnofalaqa mino Eamuwdi AlSRuboHi [which is one of the explanations of Alfalaqu in the K];) because it has become separated from the blackness of the night: (TA:) one says, Oaboyanu mino faraqi AlSRuboHi a dial. var. of falaqi AlSRuboHi [i. e. More distinct than what has broken of the bright gleam of dawn]. (S, O, Msb, * TA.)
It is also the inf. n. of fariqa [q. v.: when used as a simple subst., signifying Fear, or fright]. (S, O, Msb.)

Also, and faroqN↓, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) the latte accord. to the usage of the relaters of traditions, (Az, Mgh, O, Msb, TA,) but the former accord. to the usage of the Arabs, (Az, Mgh, O, * TA,) or the former is the more chaste (K, TA) accord. to Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà and Khálid Ibn-Yezeed, (TA,) A certain vessel, (T, Mgh, O, Msb,) a measure of capacity, (S, O, K, TA,) of large size, (TA,) well known, (S,) in El-Medeeneh, (S, Msb, K,) holding three MSuE [a pl. of SaAEN], (Mgh, O, Msb, K, TA,) or, (K, [app. referring to faroqN↓ only,]) which is the same quantity, sixteen pints, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, * TA,) i. e. twelve times the quantity termed mudR by the people of El-Hijáz: (TA:) or, accord. to El-Kutabee, the faroq↓ is sixteen pints, and the SAE is one third of the faroq; but the faraq is eighty pints: or the faroq↓, he adds, is, as some say, four pints: (Mgh:) or it is four OarobaAE [pl. of ruboEN, q. v.]; (K, TA;) thus accord. to AHát: and IAth says, the faraq is said to be five OaqosaAT; [or six; (see qisoTN;)] the qisoT being the half of a SAE: but the faroq↓ is a hundred and twenty pints: (TA:) in the “ Nawádir ” of Hishám, on the authority of [the Imám] Mohammad, the faroq↓ is said to be thirty-six pints; but [Mtr says] this I have not found in any of the lexicons in my possession; and so what is said in the Moheet, that it is sixty pints: (Mgh:) the pl. is furoqaAnN, (S, Mgh, O, K, TA,) which is of faroqN↓ and of faraqN; (S, Mgh, O, TA;) and OaforuqN occurs in a trad. as a pl. [of pauc.] of faraqN meaning the measure thus called. (TA.) 'Áïsheh is related to have said that she and the Prophet used to wash themselves from a vessel called the faroq↓. (O, Msb.) [In a verse of which a hemistich is cited in the S and TA, the pl. furoqaAn is used as meaning Milking-vessels. (See also Alfuroqu.) Respecting a modern signification of faroq↓ (A bale, or sack, of merchandise), see De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., iii., 378-9 and 382.]
faruqN: see faruwqapN, in two places.

fariqN is applied to plants, or herbage, (nabotN,) as meaning [In a sparse, or scattered, state; or] small, not covering the ground: (AHn, K, TA:) or (K) fariqapN is applied to land, (OaroDN,) meaning of which the plants, or herbage, are in a sparse, or scattered, state; (S, O, K, TA;) not contiguous: (S, O, TA:) thus used, it is a possessive epithet, having no verb. (TA.)
See also faruwqapN, in two places.

furoqapN the subst. from faAraqahu; (S, MA, * TA;) or from Aifotaraqa, (Msb,) [i. e.] a quasi-inf. n. used in the sense of AifotiraAqN; (TA;) signifying Separation, disunion, or abandonment; (MA, KL, PS;) and faraAqN↓ is syn. therewith, whence the reading [in the Kur xviii. 77], hecaA faraAqu bayoniI wabayonika [This shall be the separation of my and thy union]; and so is firaAqN↓, (O, * K, TA,) which [is an inf. n. of fArqh, and], in the Kur lxxv. 28, means the time of the quitting of the present world by death. (TA.)

firoqapN A TaAYifap [or party, portion, division, sect, or distinct body or class,] of men, (S, O, Msb, K,) and of other things; as also firoqN↓; (Msb;) and so, accord. to IB, fariyqN↓: (TA: [but see this last word:]) [and a separate herd or the like of cattle:] pl. firaqN (O, Msb, K) and OaforaAqN (S, O, K) is pl. of firaqN (O, K) and OafaAriyqu is pl. of OaforaAqN, (S, O, K,) and OafaAriqapN occurs in poetry; (O, K;) or OafaAriyqu may be of the class of OabaATiylu, a pl. without a sing. (O, TA.)
Also A portion of a thing in a state of dispersion; and so firoqN↓ and fariyqN↓. (L, TA.)
And A skin that is full [of milk], that cannot be agitated to make butter HatRaI OaIo yucoraqa yuforaqa↓ [app. a tropical phrase meaning until it is made to void some of its contents]. (K.)
furoqaAnN, originally an inf. n. (Msb. [See 1, first sentence.]) Anything that makes a separation, or distinction, between truth and falsity. (S, O, K.)
Hence, (TA,) AlfuroqaAnu signifies The Kur-án; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also Alfuroqu↓. (S, O, K.)
And The Book of the Law revealed to Moses, (Az, O, K,) in which a distinction is made between that which is allowable and that which is forbidden. (O.)
And Proof, evidence, or demonstration. (O, K.)
And The time a little before daybreak: (AA, O, K:) or the dawn. (O, K.) One says, TalaEa AlfuroqaAnu [The dawn rose]. (O.)

And Aid, or victory: (IDrd, O, K:) so, accord. to IDrd, in the phrase yawoma AlfuroqaAni in the Kur [viii. 42]: (O:) or by this phrase is meant The day of Bedr, (O, K,) in which a distinction was made between right and wrong. (O.)
And The cleaving of the sea: so it means [accord. to some] in the Kur ii. 50. (O, K.)
And Boys: (O, K:) such the people of the olden time used to make witnesses [in law-suits or the like]. (O.)
It is also pl. of faroqN (S, M, O, K) and of faraqN. (S, Mgh, O.)
faraAqN and firaAqN: see furoqapN.
faruwqN: see faruwqapN, in two places:
and Oaforaqu, last sentence but two.

fariyqN A TaAYifap [or party, &c.,] (S, Msb, K) more in number, (S, K, *) or larger, (Msb,) than a firoqap: (S, Msb, K:) pl. [of pauc.] OaforiqapN and [of mult.] OaforiqaMCu and furuwqN (K, TA) and furuqN: (CK:) see also firoqapN, in two places; and see firoqN: AHei says that it is itself a quasi-pl. n., applied to few and to many: 'Abd-el-Hakeem, that it occurs in the sense of a TaAYifap [or party, &c.], and in the sense of a single man: and El-Isbahánee, that it signifies a company of men apart from others [i. e. a party of men]: (MF, TA:) or [simply] a company [of men]. (O.)
And A separator of himself. (IB, TA.) Hence the saying, huwa OasoraEu mino fariyqi Alxayoli i. e. [He is swifter] than the outgoer, or outrunner, of the horses. (TA.)
niyRapN farayqN means mufarRiqN [i. e. A place to which one purposes journeying that separates widely]: a poet says,

[Is it true that our neighbours have gone away, so that the place to which we purpose journeying and the place to which they purpose journeying are such as separate widely]: he says fariyq in like manner as one applies [the epithet] SadiyqN to a company of men. (Sb, TA.)
Also A palm-tree (naxolapN) in which is [app. meaning out of which grows] another. (AA, AHn, O, TA.)

faruwqapN, applied to a man and to a woman, (IDrd, S, O, K,) and having no pl., (S, O,) and farRuwqapN↓, applied to a man (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K) and to a woman, (K,) and faAruwqapN↓, applied to a man (O, K,) and to a woman, or, as epithets applied to a man, faruwqapN, (K,) and farRuwqapN↓, (CK,) and faAruwqapN↓, and faruwqN↓, (K,) but this last is also applied to a woman, (IB, TA,) and farRuwqN↓, and faAruwqN↓, One who fears much, or vehemently; [or rather the epithets with the affix p are doubly intensive, meaning one who fears very much;]
(S, * O, * K, TA;) and fariqN↓ and faruqN↓ signify the same as the other epithets above; or faruqN↓ signifies fearing, or fearful, by nature; and fariqN↓, [simply,] fearing a thing. (K.) It is said in a prov., rubRa EajalapK tahabu rayovFA warubRa faruwqapK yudoEaI layovFA warubRa gayovK lamo yakuno gayovFA [Many an act of haste causes (lit. gives) slowness, and many a very fearful man is called a lion, and many a collection of clouds has not been productive of rain]: (S, * O:) said by Málik Ibn-'Amr Ibn-Mohallam, when Leyth, his brother, looked hopefully at the clouds from afar, and desired to avail himself of the benefit thereof; whereupon Málik said to him, “ Do not, for I fear for thee some of the troops of the Arabs: ” but he disobeyed him, and journeyed with his family; and he had not stayed [away] a little while when he came [back], and his family had been taken. (O. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 535.])

And Alfaruwqapu signifies AlHuromapu [meaning Honour, or reputation; or that which one is under an obligation to respect and defend]: (O, K, TA: [in the CK AlHuzomapu:]) so Sh was told: and [so, app., Alfaruwqu↓, for] he cites as an ex.,
[His foolishness and his stupidity quitted him not, and meanness, so that his honour, &c., was violated]. (O, TA.)
And The fat of the kidneys: (O, K:) so says A'Obeyd, on the authority of El-Umawee; but Sh disallowed this meaning, and knew it not. (O, TA.)
fariyqapN: see firoqN.

Also Some (S, O, K) one or two or three (S, O) of a flock or herd, of sheep or goats, becoming separate therefrom, (S, O, K,) being shut out from the rest by the like of a mountain or a space of sand or some other thing, as is said in the “ Kitáb Leysa, ” (TA,) and going away, (S, O, K,) in the “ Kitáb Leysa ” straying, (TA,) in the night, from the main aggregate. (S, O, K,)

And Dates cooked with fenugreek (Hulobap), for the woman in the state following childbirth: (S, O, K:) or fenugreek (Hulobap) cooked with grains (Hubuwb) [or kernels?], (O, K, TA,) such as maHolabo [q. v.], and byr [app. a mistranscription], and other things, (TA,) for her: (K, TA:) or, accord. to IKh, a soup that is made for him who is affected with a chronic disease, or emaciated by disease so as to be at the point of death. (TA.) [See also faliyqapN.]
farRuwqN: see faruwqapN, first sentence.
farRuwqapN: see faruwqapN, first sentence, in two places.

faAriqN [act. part. n. of faraqa, q. v.]. AlfaAriqaAtu, mentioned in the Kur lxxvii. 4, means Those angels that descend with what makes a distinction between truth and falsity: (Fr, O, K:) or that distinguish between that which is allowable and that which is forbidden: (Th, TA:) or that make a distinction between things according as God has commanded them. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

Also, faAriqN, A she-camel, and a she-ass, in consequence of her being taken with the pains of parturition, going away at random in the land; (S, O, K;) and so faAriqapN, as in the “ Mufradát: ” or a she-camel that separates herself from her mate, and brings forth alone: or a she-camel that runs (taXotadRu), and then casts her young one by reason of the pain that befalls her; thus expl. by IAar: (TA:) pl. fawaAriqu and furRaqN (S, O, K) and furuqN (K) and furRaAqN, which is thus used by El-Aashà, applied to she-camels, and mafaAriyqu↓ is [an irreg. pl.] likewise applied to she-camels as syn. with fawaAriqu. (TA.)

And hence, as being likened to such a she-camel, applied to a cloud (saHaAbapN) as meaning (tropical:) Apart from the other clouds; (S, O, K;) cut off from the main aggregate of the clouds: (ISd, TA:) or an isolated cloud, that will not break its promise [of giving rain], and sometimes preceded by thunder and lighting: (TA:) thus applied, also, having for pl. fawaAriqu and furRaqN [&c.]. (O.)

faAruwqN A thing that makes a distinction between two things: and a man who makes a distinction between truth and falsity: (TA:) or one who makes a distinction between affairs, or cases. (Msb.) AlfaAruwqu is an appellation that was given to 'Omar Ibn-El-Khattáb, (S, O, K, TA,) the second of the Khaleefehs; (TA;) because a distinction was made by him between truth and falsity. (Ibráheem El-Harbee, O, K, * TA.)

tiroyaAqN faAruwqN, (O,) or AltRiroyaAqu AlfaAruwqu, (K,) The most approved sort of theriac, (O, K,) and the most esteemed of compounds; because it makes a distinction between disease and health: (K:) called by the vulgar tiroyaAqa faAruwqiIR. (TA.)
See also faruwqapN, first sentence.
faAruwqapN: see faruwqapN, first sentence, in two places.

Oaforaqu, applied to a man, Having a wide space between the two central incisors: (IKh, TA:) [or] i. q. Oafolaju [app. as meaning the same, or having a similar meaning]: (K, TA: [but the CK has AlOafolaHu instead of AlOafolaju:]) or, accord. to Lth, the Oaforaq is like the Oafolaj, except that the Aflj is such as has been rendered so, and the Afrq is such naturally. (O, TA.) And A camel having a wide space between the two toe-nails. (Yaakoob, TA.) And Having a wide space between the buttocks. (TA.) And A he-goat having a wide space between his horns. (IKh, TA.) And A ram, or he-goat, having a wide space between his testicles: and [the fem.] faroqaMCu a ewe, or she-goat, having a wide space between the two teats. (Lth, O, K, TA.)
A camel having two humps. (TA.)

A man whose forelock is as though it were divided; and in like manner, whose beard is so. (S, O, K. *) A cock whose Eurof [or comb] is divided: (S, O, K:) and (accord. to Lth, O) a white cock: (O, K:) or, as some say, having two combs (cuw Eurofayoni). (O.)

A horse having one of the hips more prominent than the other; which is disapproved: (S, K, TA:) or having a deficiency in one of his thighs, in comparison with the other: or having a deficiency in one of the hips: or, accord. to the T, a beast having one of his elbows prominent, and the other depressed. (TA.) And A horse having one testicle. (Lth, O, K, TA.) The pl. is furoqN. (TA, in which it is here mentioned: also mentioned in the K after Oaforaqu as applied to a ram or he-goat: in the CK [erroneously] furuqN) And faruwqN↓ applied to a horse signifies the same as Oaforaqu. (O, TA.)
TariyqN Oaforaqu A road that is distinct, apparent, or manifest. (TA.) And sayolN Oaforaqu A torrent that is as though it were the firoq [app. as meaning wave, billow, or surge]. (TA.)

tafaAriyqu [Sundry, or separate, or scattered, portions or things: and sundry times]. You say, Oaxacotu HaqRiI minohu biAltRafaAriyqi (S, O, K, * TA) i. e. [I took my right, or due, from him in sundry portions: or] at sundry times. (TA.) And DamRa tafaAriyqa mataAEihi i. e. [He put together] what were scattered [of his household goods, or furniture and utensils]. (TA.)

[Verily thou art better than the several portions of the staff], (S, O, K,) which is a prov., (O,) was said by a poet, (S,) or by Ghaneeyeh, (O,) or Ghuneiyeh, (K,) El-Aarábeeyeh, to her son; for he was evil in disposition, [EAzimFA in the CK is a mistake for EaArimFA,] very mischievous, notwithstanding his weakness, (O, K,) and slenderness of bone; (O;) and he assaulted one day a young man, who thereupon cut off his nose, and his mother took the mulct for it; so her condition became good after abasing poverty; then he assaulted another, who cut off his ear; and another, who cut off his lip; and his mother took the mulct for each; and when she saw the goodness of her condition, (O, K,) the camels and the sheep or goats and the household goods that she had acquired, (O,) she said thus: (O, K:) for from the staff (S, O, K) when it is broken (S) is made a saAjuwr [q. v.], and from this are made tent-pegs, and from the tent-peg is made an EiraAn [q. v.], and from this are made tawaAdK [pl. of tawodiyapN, q. v.]. (S, O, K.)

maforaqN (S, O, K) and maforiqN (S, O, Msb, K) The middle of the head; (S, O, K;) the place where the hair of the head is separated: (S, O, Msb, K:) pl. mafaAriqu; which is used also in the sense of the sing., as though the sing. applied to every part thereof: (S, O:) one says, XaAbato mafaAriqu raOosihi [meaning The place (lit. places) of the separation of the hair of his head became white, or hoary]. (Mgh voce cakarN.) [See also faroqN.]
Also The place, of a road, where another road branches off: (S, O, Msb, K:) both words are used in this sense likewise: (S, O, K: *) pl. as above. (K.)

And [hence] one says, waqafotuhu EalaI mafaAriqi AlHadiyvi (tropical:) [I made him to know] the modes, or manners, [of the narrative, or discourse,] or the manifest, plain, or obvious, modes or manners [thereof]. (TA.)
muforiqN A she-camel whose young one has become separated from her, (S, O, K, TA,) as some say, (TA,) by death: (S, O, K, TA:) pl. mafaAriyqN↓. (TA. [Thus in my original, not mafaAriqu.])
And A she-camel that tarries two years, or three, without conceiving. (TA.)
And A she-camel having a return of some of her milk. (TA.)
And Anyone recovering from his disease. (Lh, TA.)
And Deviating from the right way or course, or from that which is right. (TA.)

And muforiqu Aljisomi, (thus accord. to the K, there said to be like muHosinN,) or Aljisomi mufarRaqu↓, (thus in the O,) A man (O) having little flesh: or fat, or plump: (O, K:) two contr. meanings. (K.)
mufarRaqu: see what next precedes.

mufarRiqu [The disperser of the camels or cattle;] the [small, stinking beast called] ZaribaAni; because when it emits a noiseless wind from the anus among the cattle, they disperse themselves. (S, O, K.)
mafaAriyqu: see muforiqN:
and faAriqN, latter half.
munofaraqN is a n. of place, as well as an inf. n. [of Ainofaraqa]: (O, K:) and is used by Ru-beh as meaning A place where a road divides. (O.)
faroqadN A calf: (S:) accord. to Aboo-Kheyreh, after he has become about two months old: (TA voce EijolN:) or the calf of a wild cow; as also furoquwdN↓: (IAar, O, L, K:) fem. faroqadapN. (L.)

And Alfaroqadu (O, L, K) and Alfuroquwdu↓ (O, K) (assumed tropical:) The asterism (najom) by which one directs his course (O, K) by sea and by land; (O;) two stars [b and y of Ursa Minor]; (L, K;) also called (in poetry, O, K, [and generally in prose,]) AlfaroqadaAni; (O, L, K;) thus in a verse cited voce UilRaA; (O;) they are two stars near the quTob [or pole-star]; (S, L;) two stars that never set, revolving round the jadoI [or pole-star], both in Ursa Minor; (L;) the two bright stars of the four that form the angles of a quadrilateral figure in Ursa Minor; (Kzw;) also called by the Arabs AlfaraAqidu [which is the pl. of Alfaroqadu]. (L.)
And faroqadu signifies also A level, or an even, land. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O.)
furoquwdN: see above, first and second sentences.

Q. 1. faroqaEa AlOaSaAbiEa i. q. naqRaDahaA, (S, * O, * K, [in copies of the K written naqaDahaA, but correctly with teshdeed, as is shown by what here follows,]) inf. n. faroqaEapN i. q. tanoqiyDN (S, O) and tafoqiyEN, (TA,) [He cracked the joints of his fingers;] i. e. he pressed his fingers so that a sound was heard to proceed from their joints: (TA:) the doing of which is forbidden, (O, TA,) in prayer. (TA. [See also 2 in art. fqE.]) And one says, samiEotu faroqaEapF lirajulK and SaroqaEapF [I heard a cracking of the joints of the fingers of a man]: both signify the same. (TA.)
And faroqaEapu He twisted his (a man's, K) neck. (O, K.)
faroqaEa [as an intrans. v.], (O, K, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He ran vehemently, (O, K, TA,) going back, or retreating: so in the Tekmileh. (TA.)
And firoqaAEN (as an inf. n. of which the verb is faroqaEa, TK) signifies The emitting of wind from the anus with a sound: (O, K:) mentioned by IDrd as from some one or more of the Arabs. (O.)
See also faroqaEapN in what next follows.

Q. 2. tafaroqaEato AlOaSaAbiEu The fingers produced a sound or sounds [by their joints' being cracked]; (O;) quasi-pass. of 1 in the first of the senses expl. above; (S, K;) as also AiforanoqaEat↓, (K, TA,) inf. n. AiforinoqaAEu and [quasi-inf. n., being app. the inf. n. in this case of furoqiEat,] faroqaEapN↓, (TA,) [and this is app. what is meant by its being said that] AlAiforinoqaAEu↓ is [syn. with] AlfaroqaEapu. (K.)
Accord. to IDrd, tafaroquEN signifies The sounding of two things striking against each other. (O.)
And tfrqE AlrRajulu The man drew himself together, or shrank; like taqaroEafa [which is mentioned in the K in the same sense, as also taqarofaEa]. (L, TA.)
Q. 3: see Q. 2, in two places.

AlAiforinoqaAEu also signifies The withdrawing, or removing, and going away, from a thing (Eano XaIoCK); (K;) and the dispersing of itself, or becoming dispersed. (IAth, TA.) AiforanoqiEuwA EanRiI, a phrase used by 'Eesà Ibn- 'Omar, (S, O,) to people who had congregated about him on an occasion of his having fallen from his ass, (O,) means Withdraw ye, or remove, (S,) or disperse yourselves, (O,) from me, (S,) and go away. (S, O.) And 'Eesà Ibn-'Omar is related to have read, [in the Kur xxxiv. 22,] HatRaI UicaA QforanoqaEa Eano quluwbihimo; meaning, kuXifa; [AlfazaEu, or the like, being understood;] but the common reading is fuzRiEa, q. v. (TA.)
AlfuroqaEapa The Aisot [here app. meaning anus (see 1)]; (Lth, IAar, K;) of the dial. of ElYemen: (O:) also called AlqurofuEapu. (TA.)

1. farokN, as expl. by Lth, signifies (O, TA) primarily (TA) One's rubbing, or rubbing and pressing, a thing [with the hand] so that its integument becomes stripped off (O, TA) from its kernel; as, for instance, a [shelled] walnut. (TA.) One says, faraka AlsRunobula, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
faruka
, inf. n. farokN, (S, Msb,) He rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, the ears of corn (K, TA) with his hand [so that the kernels became divested of their husks]. (S, O, Msb, TA.) And faraka AlvRawoba (S, O, Msb, K) He rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, the garment (K, TA) with his hand [to remove a soil]. (S, O, Msb, TA.) And faraka AlmaniIRa mina AlvRawobi (Mgh, O, Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Mgh,) He rubbed, (Msb,) or rubbed and pressed, (Mgh,) with his hand, the [dry soil of] sperma, so that it crumbled, and came off from the garment; (Mgh, Msb;) like HatRahu: and in like manner AlTRiyna [i. e. the dry mud]. (Msb.) [And faraka Alqamolapa He rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, the louse, between his finger and thumb, or otherwise, to kill it. (See the pass. part. n., below.)]

farikato zawojahaA, and farikahaA zawojuhaA, aor.
faraka
; (S, O, K;) and farakatohu, and farakahaA, aor.
faruka
, but this form of the verb is extr.; (K;) inf. n. firokN (S, O, K) and farokN and furuwkN; (K;) She hated her husband, and her husband hated her; (S, O;) or she hated her husband vehemently, and her husband hated her vehemently: (K:) the verb has not been heard otherwise than as relating to the husband and wife: (S, O:) Lh has mentioned farakatohu, aor. taforukuhu; but it is not well known: (TA:) all of the nouns mentioned above as inf. ns. signify [hatred, or] vehement hatred, in a general sense, as also furukRaAnN↓, (K, TA,) which is [app. a simple subst.] mentioned on the authority of Seer, and also mentioned as with two kesrehs and the teshdeed [i. e. firikRaAnN↓]: (TA:) or all relate peculiarly to the hatred of the husband and wife; (K, TA;) i. e., to the man's hating his wife; or to her hating him, which is the better known: it is said in a trad. of Ibn-Mes'ood, UinRa AlHubRa mina QllRehi waAlfiroka mina AlXRayoTaAni [Verily love of the husband is from God, and hatred of the husband is from the Devil]: A'Obeyd says that Alfiroku signifies the woman's hating her husband; that it relates peculiarly to the wife and the husband, and that it had not been heard by him as used in relation to any but them two: and IAar says that the sons of a man by a wife who hates him, which sons are termed OawolaAdu Alfiroki, possess generosity, because the sons thus called are most like to their fathers, and do not resemble her: and when the husband hates the wife, one says SlfhA [i. e. SalafahaA or SalifahaA] and Slft Endh [i. e. Salifato Einodahu]. (TA.)

farikati AlOucuni, aor.
faraka
, (K,) inf. n. farakN, (S, O, K,) The ear had a flaccidity in its OaSol [or base, meaning the part surrounding the entrance of the meatus auditorius]. (S, * O, * K.)
2. taforiykN [inf. n. of frRk] The causing to be hated, or much hated. (O.)

3. fArkhu, (AZ, O, K, TA,) inf. n. mufaArakapN, (TA,) i. q. taArakahu [i. e. He left, forsook, or abandoned, him; or he did so being left &c. by him]; (AZ, O, K, TA;) namely, his companion; (AZ, O;) said by IF to be formed by substitution [of f for t]: (O, TA:) expl. in the A as meaning faAraqahu [which is syn. with tArkh]. (TA.)

4. Afrk AlsRunobulu The ears of corn became fariyk↓, i. e. in the state in which they were fit to be rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, with the hand [so as to divest the kernels of their husks], and then to be eaten: (S, O:) and Afrk AlzRaroEu, (TA,) and AlHabRu, (K,) The seed-produce, and the grain, attained to the state in which it was fit to be rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, (K, TA,) with the
hand: or the grain became hard, or firm, and attained to its utmost state of growth; before which it is forbidden to sell it. (TA.)
5. tfrRk He (an effeminate man, O) affected languor, or languidness, (takasRara) in his speech, (O, K,) and in his walk: (K:) so says IDrd. (O.)

7. Anfrk AlsRunobulu The ears of corn were rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, (K, TA,) with the hand [so that the kernels became divested of their husks]. (TA.) And Anfrk AlvRawobu The garment became rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, (K, TA,) with the hand [to remove a soil]. (TA.) [See 1.]

And Anfrk Almanokibu The shoulder-joint became lax, or slack: (S, * TA:) or Anfrk manokibuhu, (Lth, O, K, *) as also Anfrkt waAbilatuhu, (Lth, O,) signifies the waAbilap [or head] of his humerus became dislocated (Lth, O, K) from the Sadafap [or socket] of the scapula, so that the shoulder-joint became lax, or slack: but when the like thereof happens in the wAblp of the femur, one does not say Anfrk, but Huriqa, and the epithet maHoruwqN is applied to it [i. e. to the hip-joint]. (Lth, O.)
And Anfrk Eano Eahodihi He became released from his compact, engagement, or promise; syn. AinofakRa. (TA.)
