10. Astfrk AlHabRu fiI AlsRunobulapi The grain became full (samina [q. v.]), and hard, or firm, [as though demanding to be rubbed with the hand so as to be divested of the husks, and eaten,] in the ear of corn. (K, * TA.)
farokN: see what next follows.

farikN, (O, K,) like katifN, (K,) or correctly, as written in the L and A. farokN↓, (TA, [but this I think doubtful,]) [A fruit or the like] of which the integument becomes rubbed off [with the hand]: (O, K: [I read Almunofariku qiXoruhu, as in the CK, for AlmutafarRiku qiXoruhu in other copies of the K and in the O:]) thus applied to an almond, and likewise to a peach. (TA.)
See also what next follows.
OucunN faroqaMCu An ear having a flaccidity in its OaSol [or base]; as also farikapN↓. (S, O, K. [See 1, last sentence.])
furukRaAnN and firikRaAnN: see 1, latter half.
firaAkN a term for HayoDN [or Menstruation]: mentioned by MF. (TA.)
faruwkN: see faArikN, first sentence.

fariykN, applied to grain (HabR), i. q. maforuwkN↓ [i. e. Rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, with the hand, so that the integument becomes stripped off from the kernel]: (K:) or wheat (burR) that is rubbed, &c., and picked, or cleared. (O.) See also 4.
And Wheat rubbed, &c., and moistened with clarified butter &c.; (K, TA;) also termed maforuwkapN↓. (TA.)
The fariykaAni, or, as in some copies of the K, fariykataAni↓, (TA,) Two bones [app. the two greater cornua of the os hyoides] in, or at, (fiI,) the root of the tongue. (K, TA.)
fariykataAni: see what next precedes.

faArikN A woman hating, or who hates, her husband; [app. accord. to the K, vehemently;] as also faruwkN↓ [but app. in an intensive sense]: (S, O, K:) pl. of the former fawaArikN. (O, * TA.) Dhur-Rummeh says, (O, TA,) describing camels, (TA,)

L.foreign: UicaA AllRayolu Eano naXozK tajalRaI ramayonahu

sense.s: [When the night clears away from an elevated piece of ground, they cast at it the like of the eyes of the women that hate their husbands]: (O, TA:) he likens them to the women that hate their husbands because these raise their eyes towards men, not confining the look to the husbands: he says, these camels enter upon the time of dawn, having journeyed all their night; and whenever an elevated piece of ground becomes within their view, they cast their eyes at it by reason of sprightliness and strength for the journeying. (TA.)

mufarRakN [Caused to be hated, or to be much hated: see its verb. And] A man hated by women: (S, O, K:) such was Imra-el-Keys: (S, O:) [and accord. to Freytag, maforuwkN↓ occurs in this sense in the Deewán of Jereer.] And mufarRakapN A woman hated by men. (IAar, K.)
Also Left, forsaken, or abandoned, and hated. (Fr, TA.)
maforuwkN: see fariykN. One says also qamolapN maforuwkapN [A louse rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, between the finger and thumb, or otherwise, to be killed]. (S, O.)

Applied to a camel, (En-Nadr, O, K,) it means Such as is termed OafakRu [q. v.]; (En-Nadr, O;) whose shoulder is slit [so I render Ainoxarama, but I incline to think that it here means is splayed, or dislocated, as though rent without being separated (see taxarRama)], and the EaSabap [which I suppose to signify in this case either tendon or ligament] that is in the interior of the Oaxorama [q. v., app. here meaning the glenoid cavity of the scapula] detached. (En-Nadr, O, K. [See also Anfrk manokibuhu.])
And A garment, or piece of cloth, (TA,) strongly dyed (K, TA) with saffron &c. (TA.)
See also mufarRakN.
maforuwkapN, as a subst.: see fariykN.

2. taforiymN [as an inf. n. of which the verb is farRamat] signifies A woman's contracting her faloham (or qubul, TA) [i. e. vulva or vagina] with the stones of raisins [which were supposed to have an astringent property, or with some other medicament: see faromN: and see also 10]: and so taforiybN. (IAar, T.)

3. firaAmN [app. as an inf. n. of which the verb is faAramat] signifies A woman's menstruating, and stuffing her vulva with a piece of rag: and one says of her who has done this, Aifotaramat↓ [and app. also faAaramat]. (T, K.) [See also firaAmapN.]
It occurs in a trad. [as an inf. n.] used in the sense of mujaAmaEap [meaning (tropical:) The act of compressing]. (IAth, TA.)
4. Afrm He filled (T, S, K) a watering-trough (T, K) or a vessel: (S:) of the dial. of Hudheyl. (T, S.)
8. Aifotaramat, said of a woman: see 3.

10. Aisotaforamat She (a woman) applied a medicament to her vulva, or vagina, to contract it: (S, K: *) or she stuffed her vulva, or vagina, (T, TA,) with the stones of raisins, and the like: (TA:) the women of [the tribe of] Thakeef, having a wideness in that part, made this use of the stones of raisins, desiring thereby to contract it: (M, TA: *) [see also 2: and see faromN:] the epithet faromaMCu↓ is applied to her who does thus; as also musotaforimapN↓. (M, K.)

And [hence] one says of a mare, Aisotaforamato biAlHaSaI, meaning (assumed tropical:) She caused the pebbles to enter her vulva by her vehement running. (TA. [And the same is implied in the S by an ex. and explanation of the part. n.])

faromN, (T, S, M, K,) and faromapN↓, (S, K,) and firaAmN↓, (M, K,) A medicament, or remedial application, (T, S, M, K,) such as the stones of raisins, (T, M,) used by a woman for the purpose of contracting her vulva, or vagina. (T, S, M, K.)

faramN The rag that is used on the occasion of menstruation: (IAth, TA:) and mafaArimu↓ signifies the rags used on the occasion thereof; and [may be an irreg. pl. of faramN, like as maXaAbihu is held to be of XabahN, but it is said that it] is a pl. having no sing.: (M, TA:) [in the K, in art. HXw, the mafaArimu↓ (there in the CK erroneously written maqaArim) are said to be used by the musotaHaADap: see 8 in that art.]
faromapN: see faromN.
faromaMCu: see 10.
firaAmN: see faromN:
and see also the next following paragraph.

firaAmapN The piece of rag which a woman bears [stuffed] in her vulva, or vagina: (AZ, T, K:) or her menstruating, and stuffing her vulva with a piece of rag; like firaAmN↓ [as expl. above: see 3]. (K.)
Oaforamu A man (TA) whose teeth become much broken. (K, TA.)

muforamN Filled with water (T, M) &c.: (M:) mentioned by A'Obeyd, as applied to a wateringtrough: (T:) and applied also to a XiEob [or road in a mountain, &c.,] as meaning filled with men, or people: (M:) of the dial. of Hudheyl. (T, M.)
mafaArimu: see faramN, in two places.
musotaforimapN: see 10.

furonN [app. from, or cognate with, the Latin
“ furnus ”] An oven, (IDrd, * S, * M, K,) syn. maxobazN, (M, K,) [or one] in which one bakes bread such as is termed furoniIR; (S, K;) differing from the tanRuwr [q. v.]: (S:) a word of the dial. of Syria: (M:) thought by IDrd to be not Arabic [in origin]: (TA:) pl. OaforaAnN. (M.)

furoniIRN Thick, (S, K,) round, or circular, (K,) bread; (S, K;) so called in relation to its place [in which it is baked, i. e. the furon]: (S:) or (K) a sort of bread having a raised and pointed, or hollowed, head, the lateral portions thereof being drawn together to, or towards, the middle, (M, K,) and being intermingled, one part thereof in another, (M,) roasted, or fried, (K,) then well moistened with milk and clarified butter and sugar: (M, K:) n. un. furoniyRapN↓: which signifies also a round, or circular, great cake of bread: (M:) [whence, app.,] faUicaA hiIa mivolu AlfaroniyRapi AlHamoraMCi [And lo, she, or it, was like the red frnyRp; but to what this refers I know not]: a saying of some of the Arabs. (S, TA.)
And (as being likened thereto, TA) (tropical:) A thick, bulky, man: (M, K, TA:) and (K) a bulky dog. (IB, K, TA.)
Also A baker; as a rel. n. of furonN: (Msb:) and so farRaAnN↓, in the dial. of the vulgar. (TA.)
furoniyRapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
farRaAnN: see furoniIRN, last sentence. [It is applied in the present day to A baker of bread and of meat &c.]
faArinapN A female baker (T, K) of the bread termed furoniIR. (T.)
fironibN A rat, or mouse; syn. faOorapN: (IAar, O, K:) or the young one generated between it and a jerboa: (K:) or [as a coll. gen. n.] the rat, or mouse; syn. faOorN. (T.) [See also qaronabN.]
Alfiranoju, n. un. firanojiIRN: see what follows.

AlUiforanojapu (O, K) [and AlUiforanoju, which is the more common,] and Alfiranoju↓, (MF, TA, [but in the Commentary of MF written without any of the syll. signs,]) in which last manner it is correctly written accord. to the sheykhs of El-Andalus, who are the nearest to, and the best acquainted with, the country of the people thus called, and so written by Suh, (MF,) A certain people; [the Franks; an appellation given originally, by the Arabs, to the French; and afterwards to all Europeans except those of the Turkish Empire:] an arabicized word from Uiforanok, (K,) or AfrnG, (O,) or from frnk [or firanoG]: (Suh, MF:) accord. to general analogy, it should be AlUiforinojapu, with kesr to the r: (O, K:) so called because the seat of their dominion is [named] frnjp or frAnsp [i. e. France]; and their king is called AlfrnsPs, [more properly AlfaranosiyosiIRu,] which is likewise an arabicized word. (Suh, as cited by MF.) [The n. un., or appellation given to a single person of this people, is UiforanojiIRN and firanojiIRN.]
firinodN A sort of cloth, or garment, (Lth, T, O, K,) well known: (K:) an adventitious word, (Lth, T, O,) [from the Pers. Paranod,] arabicized. (O, K.)

And [hence, app.,] firinodu AlsRayofi, (T, S, M, O, K,) and Uiforinoduhu↓, (S, O, K,) The diversified wavy marks, streaks, grain, or water, of the sword; syn. waXoyuhu, (T, S, M, O, K,) and jawoharuhu, (T, O, K,) and rubaduhu [q. v.], (S, O,) and maAWuhu AlRaciI yajoriI fiyhi, (T, O, *) and TaraAYiquhu, (T, O,) i. e. safaAsiquhu. (T.)
And Alfirinodu signifies The sword itself. (M, L, K.)
And The Hawojam; (K, TA;) i. e. (TA) the red rose. (M, TA.)
And The grains of the pomegranate. (AA, O, K.)
fironidN i. q. OabozaArN [Seeds that are used in cooking, for seasoning food; &c.]: pl. faraAnidu. (IAar, O, K.)
firinodaApN A qaTaAp [or sand-grouse]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
Uiforinodu AlsRayofi: see firinodN, second sentence.

dictScrap.label: frns: For words mentioned in some of the lexicons under this head, see art. frs.

sense.s: Q. 2. tafaronaqa He was, or became, bad; (K, TA;) said of a camel: (TA:) and so tafaronaqat said of a sheep or goat (XaAp). (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TA.)
And Oucunuhu tafaronaqato His ear became raised. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.)
furonuqN Bad; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K;) applied to the Eariyf [or chief, superintendent, or manager of the affairs,] of a people or party: and so mutafaroniqu↓ applied to a camel. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

furaAniqN The bariyd, i. e., (IDrd, S, O,) the warner before the lion; (S, O, K;) a certain beast of prey, [sometimes called by us the lion's provider,] that cries out before the lion, as though warning men of his presence; said to resemble the jackal (Aibonu MwaI); (IDrd, TA;) and said to be the jackal [itself]; but some say otherwise: (TA voce bariydN:) a Pers. word, (IDrd, S, O,) arabicized, (IDrd, S, O, K,) originally farowaAnahu [or ParowaAnah], (IDrd, TA,) or originally ParowaAnak: (S, O, K:) said by AHát to be [also] called the waEowaE. (TA.)
And (hence, TA) The guide of the messenger on a beast of the post. (O, K, TA.) And sometimes The guide of an army was thus called. (S, TA.)
And, (O, K,) accord. to some, (O,) it signifies The lion [himself]. (O, K.)
mutafaroniqN: see furonuqN.

1. faruha, aor.
faruha
, (S, K,) inf. n. faraAhapN and faraAhiyapN (K) [and app. also furuwhapN, expl. below as a simple subst.], He was, or became, skilled, or skilful. (S, K.)

And faruha and faraha, aor. of each
faruha
, [inf. n. app. furuwhapN and faraAhapN and faraAhiyapN, expl. below as simple substs.,] said of a horse or similar beast, &c., He was, or became, brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, or light. (Msb.)
[And faruha, inf. n. faraAhapN, (of which see an explanation below,) probably signifies He was, or became, beautiful, comely, pretty, or elegant; like SabuHa, inf. n. SabaAHapN.]

And fariha, (S, K,) aor.
faraha
, (K,) inf. n. farahN, (TK,) He exulted, or rejoiced above measure; or he exulted greatly, and behaved insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: (S, K:) the h in this verb, accord. to Fr, is substituted for the H in fariHa, which has this meaning. (TA.)
2: see what next follows.

4. Oaforahat She (a camel) brought forth [young ones such as are termed] furohN (S) or furRahN (K) [i. e. such as were brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, or light]; as also frRht↓, inf. n. taforiyhN. (K.)
And She (a woman) brought forth beautiful children. (TA.)
And Afrh He (a man) took for himself a gulaAm [i. e. youth, young man, or male slave,] such as is termed faArihN (IAar, K) meaning beautiful, or comely, of countenance. (IAar, TA.)

10. huwa yasotaforihu AlOaforaAsa means yasotakorimuhaA [i. e. He seeks the horses, or mares, that are of generous race]: (aK, TA:) and the like is said in the A, but with AldRawaAbRa in the place of AlAfrAs. (TA.)

farihN [part. n. of fariha, meaning Exulting, or rejoicing above measure; &c.]. In the Kur xxvi. 149, some read farihiyna, from fariha, signifying as expl. above: others reading faArihiyna, which is from faruha: (S, TA:)
but farihN is also syn. with faArihN, as an epithet applied to a youth, or young man, or male slave; and thus the reading of farihiyna in the Kur has been expl. as meaning Possessing skill. (TA.)
furaAhN i. q. furaAtN, as an epithet applied to water, signifying Sweet, &c.: both are chaste forms, and well known, like taAbuwhN and taAbuwtN: so in the Towsheeh. (MF and TA in art. frt.)
faraAhapN [mentioned in the first paragraph as an inf. n. is also expl. as a simple subst.]: see furuwhapN.
Also Beauty, or comeliness. (Msb, TA.)
furuwhapN [app. an inf. n., but mentioned as a simple subst., meaning] Skilfulness. (K.)

And furuwhahN and faraAhapN↓ and faraAhiyapN↓ denote a
quality of a hackney and of a mule and of an ass, (S,) or of a horse, or similar beast, &c., (Msb,) all signifying Briskness, liveliness, sprightliness, activity, agility, or lightness. (Msb, TA. *)
faraAhiyapN [mentioned in the first paragraph as an inf. n.]: see what next precedes.

faArihN Skilful, or possessing skill; (S, Msb, K;) part. n. of faruha, irregularly formed, for by rule it should be fariyhN: (S:) accord. to Z, it is applied to a man; and also, without p, to a qayonap [i. e. female slave, or slave-songstress]. (Msb.)

And it is applied as an epithet to a hackney, (Az, S, Msb,) and a mule, (S,) and an ass, (Az, S, Msb,) or to a horse, or similar beast, (Az,) meaning Brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, or light; (Az, * Msb;) sharp; strong; that goes, or journeys, much; a great goer: (Az, TA:) it is not applied to a faras, (Az, S,) i. e. to an Arabian horse; (Az, Msb;) such being termed jawaAdN, (Az, S, Msb,) and raAYiEN: (S:) 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd has applied it to the latter; but As has charged him with error in so doing; saying that he possessed not knowledge of horses: (S:) the pl. is furohN, (S, Msb,) like buzolN and HuwlN pls. of baAzilN and HaAYilN, (S,) or furuhN, like kutubN, (K,) and farahapN, with two fet-hahs, (Msb,) or furohapN, (S, K,) but this is held by Sb to be a quasi-pl. n., (ISd, TA,) and furRahN, like rukRaEN, and furRahapN, like sukRarapN, (K,) as in the A, but MF says that no pl. of this measure is known. (TA.)

Also, applied to a gulaAm [i. e. youth, young man, or male slave], Beautiful, or comely, of countenance. (IAar, TA.) And [the fem.] faArihapN signifies A beautiful, or comely, girl, or young woman: (K:) [and] so farohaMCu↓, [of which the masc. is Oaforahu, and] of which the pl. is furohN; but Az says, I do not think that they use this word in relation to girls, or young women, though they may apply it peculiarly to female slaves like as they apply faArihN and faArihapN peculiarly to hackneys and mules and jades, exclusively of Arabian horses. (Msb.)

And faArihapN is also syn. with fatiyRapN [i. e. A youthful females, or one in the prime of life]: (thus accord. to several copies of the K and accord. to the TA:) or qayonapN [i. e. a female slave, or a slave-songstress: see the first sentence of this paragraph]. (Thus in the CK.)
And it signifies also [A woman] who eats vehemently: (K:) and faArihN applied to man, A vehement eater. (IAar, TA.)
Oaforahu: see its fem., farohaMCu, in the next preceding paragraph.
fulaAnN Oaforahu mino fulaAnK means Such a one is more beautiful, or comely, than such a one. (Msb.)
muforihN and muforihapN (S, K) and mufarRihapN (S) are epithets applied to a she-camel, meaning Bringing forth [young ones such as are termed] furohN (S) or furRahN. (K.) [See 4.]
Q. 2. tafarohada, said of a boy, or youth, not of a man, He became fat. (TA. [See also furohudN, and mufarohadN.])
farohadN: see the next paragraph, in three places.

furohadN (S, M, O, L, K) and furohuwdN↓ (M, L, K) A boy, or youth, (L,) fat, or compact in make, (HaAdirN,) and thick; (S, M, O, L, K;) as also farohadN↓: (O:) and soft, thin-skinned, and plump: (M, O, * K:) some assign this meaning to qurohadN, but others say that this is a corruption, and it is correctly with f: and one says also gulaAmN fulohudN, meaning a plump boy or youth: (L:) also, (K,) or furohudN [only], (TA,) or furohuwdN↓, (IDrd, O,) a boy, or youth, (IDrd, O, K, TA) not a man, (IDrd, O,) plump (IDrd, O, K, TA) in body, (TA,) and beautiful (IDrd, O, K, TA) in face; (TA;) as also farohadN↓: (K:) and furohudN and farohadN↓ signify a boy, or youth, that has nearly attained to puberty. (O. [See also falohadN and fawohadN.])

Also, i. e. the first and second, (L, K,) or furohuwdN↓, which is of the dial. of Azd, (O,) The whelp of a lion; (O, L, K;) of the dial. of 'Omán: the pl. [of furohuwdN↓, or] of furohudN, accord. to Kr, is faraAhiydN; but ISd distrusts his authority on a matter of this kind. (L.)
furohuwdN: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.
Also A young mountain-kid. (L, K.)
And [the pl.] faraAhiydu signifies Young lambs or kids. (O, K.)
mufarohadN A fat boy or youth. (TA.)
2. frRI AljubRapa, inf. n. taforiyapN, He furred, or lined with fur, the garment called jubRap: see the pass. part. n., below.]
4. AfrI He was, or became, abundant in cattle, or other property: like OavoraI. (M in art. vrw. [See farowapN, last sentence.])
8. AftrI farowFA He wore farow [i. e. fur]: (S, M, K:) [and so, app., AftrI alone: see mufotarK, below.]

farowN signifies A certain thing that is worn; (S, Msb;) as also farowapN↓: (Msb:) each of these is a word of well-known meaning: (M:) [but the former is properly a coll. gen. n., and farowapN↓ is its n. un.; agreeably with what here follows:] Alfarowu is well known [as being fur]; and farowapN↓ is the appellation applied when it is [a furred garment] like the jubRip: (Lth, T:) and signifies also a skin, but not unless having upon it wabar [i. e. fur, or soft hair,] or wool: (T:) [in general,] this latter word signifies, (K, TA,) and some say the former also, (TA,) a kind of garment, well known, (K, TA,) lined with the skins of various species of animals, the most highly esteemed whereof is the samRawr [or sable], tanned, and sewed together; this garment being worn for preservation from the cold: (TA:) firaMCN is the pl. (S, M, Msb, TA) of mult., and the pl. of pauc. is OaforK: so says Aboo- 'Alee El-Kálee. (TA.)
farowapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

Also The scalp, or skin of the head: (S, Msb, K:) or farowapu AlrRaOosi signifies the scalp, or skin of the head, with the hair thereof, (Lth, T, M, Mgh,) of a man, and of other than man: (M:) or the upper part of the head: (M, TA:) and one says, Darabahu EalaI OumRi farowatihi meaning [He struck him upon] his haAmap [crown, &c.]. (TA.) [Hence,] it is metaphorically applied, in a trad., to (tropical:) The skin of the face. (TA.)
And (tropical:) A woman's [head-covering such as is called] ximaAr, (Mgh, K, TA,) or [such as is called] qinaAE; occurring in a trad.; (Mgh, TA;) metaphorically applied thereto. (Mgh.)
And (assumed tropical:) A crown, such as is worn by a king: (Z, K, * TA:) [said to be] so called because made of skins. (TA.)
And A [garment of the kind called] jubRap of which the two sleeves have been tucked up. (K.)
And The half of a [garment such as is called] kisaMC made of the soft hair of camels; (K, TA;) now known by the appellation of jbp [evidently a mistranscription, app. for xibRap, q. v.]. (TA.)

And A [bag such as is termed] wafoDap [q. v.], (K, TA,) [i. e.] like the xariyTap, made of skin, (TA,) in which the beggar puts his alms. (K, TA.) And hence, (TA,) cuw Alfarowap means The beggar. (K, TA.)
And A portion of herbage collected together and dry. (S, K.)
And Waste, or uncultivated, land, having in it no herbage (T, K) and no baraX [or maculæ, or spots differing in colour from the rest]. (T.)

Oabuw farowapK signifies The balRuwT [here meaning chestnut, which is called in Egypt Abw frwp in the present day]; of the dial. of Egypt: it is thus called because within its husk is what resembles the soft hair of camels. (TA.)

Also i. q. varowapN, (Fr, As, ISk, T, S, M, Msb, K,) and ginFI; (S, K;) [i. e. Abundance, and richness &c.;] accord. to Yaakoob [i. e. ISk], (M,) formed from varowapN by substitution (S, M) of f for v: (M:) one says, UinRahu lacuw varowapK mina AlmaAli and farowapK, both meaning the same [i. e. Verily he is a possessor of abundance of property]; (T, S; [in some copies of the latter, fiI AlmaAli;]) so says ISk, (T,) or Fr; (S;) and As says the like: (S:) the latter says, fulaAnN cuw farowapK and varowapK, meaning Such a one is a possessor of abundant property. (T.)
farRaMCN A manufacturer of firaMC [i. e. furs, or furred garments]:
and A seller thereof. (TA.)
jubRapN mufarRaApN [A furred jbRp;] a [garment of the kind called] jbRp upon which is a farowap [or fur, i. e., that is lined therewith].
mufotarK [act. part. n. of 8]. AlmufotariI laA yajida Albaroda [The wearer of fur will not feel the cold] is a saying of the Arabs. (TA.)
Q. Q. 1. farowaza see in art. frz.

1. faraAhu, (M, K,) aor. yaforiyhi, (K,) inf. n. faroIN, (K,) He slit it, or cut it lengthwise, ill, or improperly; or well, or properly; as also frRAhu↓ and AfrAhu↓ [both relating to both of the foregoing explanations]: (K:) or he slit it, or cut it lengthwise, and made it bad, or improper; as also frRAhu↓: or, accord. to the sound lexicologists, the former has this meaning: but AfrI↓ signifies he slit, or cut lengthwise, and made good, or proper: (M:) or AfrAhu↓ (M, K) signifies, (M,) or signifies also, (K,) he made it good, or proper: or he ordered [another] to make it so: (M, K:) as though he removed from it unsoundness, or imperfection: but some say that this signifies he slit it, or cut it lengthwise, and made it bad, or improper: and when you mean he measured it, and cut it, to make it good, or proper, you say faraAhu, inf. n. faroIN: (M:) [thus, accord. to J,] faraI, aor. and inf. n. as above, signifies he cut a thing in order to make it good, or proper: (S:) or he cut a skin, or hide, in a good, or proper, manner: (Ks, S, Msb:) and AfrI↓ he cut it in a bad, or an improper, manner: (Ks, S:) or this signifies he slit much, in a bad, or an improper, manner: and AfrI Aljiloda, accord. to As, he rent, tore, or slit, the skin, and made holes in it, and spoiled it: and AfrI signifies also he slit a thing (S, M, Msb) of any kind; (as also frRAhu↓:]) thus you say, AfrI AlOawdaAja he slit the AwdAj [or external jugular veins], (T, M, Mgh, Msb,) and made what was in them, of the blood, to come forth; (T, Mgh, Msb;) and in like manner one says of a garment, or piece of cloth, and of a julRap [or receptacle for dates, made of palm-leaves woven together]; (T;) or he cut the AwdAj: (S:) IAar alone mentions faraI OawodaAjahu and AfrAhA↓: (M:) [but it is also said that faraI signifies he cut a niTaE [or the like]: (K in art. xlq: [see an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph of that art.; also cited in the T after the first of the explanations here following, and in the M after the second thereof:]) or faraI, aor. and inf. n. as above, signifies he measured, and worked, or manufactured, and made good, or proper, a thing, such as a sandal, or a niTaE [q. v.], or a water-skin, and the like: (T:) or he measured it, and cut it, to make it good, or proper: (M:) and he measured and manufactured a mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag]: (S, K:) or he sewed, and made well, or properly, a mzAdp: (T:) [it is said that] the difference between AlUiforaQCu↓ an AlfaroIu is this, that the former signifies the cutting so as to render bad, or improper, and the slitting like as the slaughterer and the wild beast slit [their victims]; and the latter, the cutting so as to make good, or proper, like the act of cutting of the sewer of the hide, or of leather: but faraI sometimes occurs in the sense of AfrI: (Mgh:) one says, raOosahu Oaforayotu↓, meaning I split, or clave, his head with a sword; like Oaforarotuhu: (Yz, T &c. in art. fr:) and AfrI AljuroHa he slit the wound: (T:) and AfrI AlcRiYobu baTona AlXRaApi [the wolf slit, or rent, the belly of the sheep, or goat]: (S:) and one says, qado Oaforayota wamaA farayota i. e. thou hast done ill, or improperly, and hast not done well, or properly. (A, TA.)
faraAhu, aor. as above, [and so the inf. n.,] is sometimes metonymically used [as meaning (tropical:) He slaughtered him, or butchered him; i. e.] as denoting vehemence, or excess, in slaying. (TA.)
And it means also (assumed tropical:) He cut him with censure, or satire: (TA:) and AfrI↓ means he blamed, or censured, a man. (M, K.)
And you say, farayotu AlOaroDa (tropical:) I traversed, or crossed, (lit. travelled and cut,) the land, or country; (T, S, K, TA;) inf. n. as above. (TA.)

huwa yaforiI AlfariIRa↓ means (assumed tropical:) He effects what is wonderful in his deed. (S, K.) OaHadN maA yaforiI fariyRahu↓, thus, with teshdeed [to the I in fryh] as related by A'Obeyd, is said of a courageous man [as meaning No one does his deed, or the like]: but it is said [by Kh] to be correctly faroyahu, [as an inf. n.,] without tesh-deed. (M. [See, however, what follows.]) They say, tarakotuhu yaforiI AlfariIRa↓, meaning [I left him] doing well, or excellently, in a deed, or in watering: [an explanation relating to what here follows:] the Prophet said, respecting 'Omar, whom he saw in a dream drawing water at a well with a great bucket, falamo Oara EaboqariyRFA yaforiI fariyRahu↓ [And I have not seen a chief of a people do his deed, &c.]: (T:) or, as some relate it, he said faroyahu: (TA:) [but] A'Obeyd says, this is like thy saying yaEomalu Eamalahu and yaquwlu qawolahu; and Fr cited to us [as an ex.]

meaning [Verily] thou didst multiply and magnify thy words respecting it: (T: and in like manner this hemistich [which shows, by the measure, that AlfariyRaA cannot be here a mistake for AlfaroyaA,] is expl. in the S:) it is said that fariIR↓ thus used is of the measure faEylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, from faraI signifying “ he cut ” [or “ cut lengthwise ” or “ slit ”] a hide, or leather; (Har p. 257; [where see more;]) [and this assertion is corroborated by the fact that] one says of a man strenuous, or vigorous, in an affair, and strong, wayaqudRu tarakotuhu yaforiI AlfariIRa↓ [lit. I left him slitting, or cutting, the slit, or cut, thing, and shaping]. (T.)
faraI is also synonymous with AftrI: see the latter, in two places.
faraI Albaroqu, aor. and inf. n. as above, signifies The lightning shone, or glistened, or shone with flickering light, and continued, in the sky. (T, TA.)

fariIa, (T, S, M, K,) aor. yaforaI, (T, S,) inf. n. farFI, (T, S, K, but omitted in the CK,) He was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; syn. bahita, (T,) and dahiXa, (T, S, M, K,) and taHayRara, (S, K,) and baTira: (Skr, on the verse here following:) El-Aalam El-Hudhalee says,

[And I became confounded, &c., by reason of fright, so that I did not shoot an arrow, nor bade I farewell to a friend]: (T, M:) or, accord. to As, fariIa, aor. yaforaI, signifies he looked, and knew not what he should do: (T:) and fariytu signifies also I wondered; from AlfariIRu↓ meaning “ that which is wonderful. ” (Skr, on the verse above-cited.)
2: see 1, first quarter, in three places.
4: see 1, former half, in seven places:
and also in the latter half, near the middle of the paragraph.

5. tfrRI It became slit, or cut lengthwise; (S, M, Msb, K;) as also AnfrI↓; (S, M, Msb;) both said of a skin, (M,) or of a thing: (S:) or it became much slit, or rent; said of the sewing of a leathern water-skin. (T.) And tfrRI Eanohu vawobuhu His garment became much slit, or rent, from him. (T.) And tfrRt AlEayonu (tropical:) The spring of water burst forth: (K, TA:) or tfrRt AlOaroDu biAlEuyuwni (tropical:) The earth, or ground, burst with the springs. (S, M, A, TA.)
[Hence,] the saying of Kabeesah Ibn-Jábir,

i. e. (assumed tropical:) Its eggs (the pronoun in byDhA denoting the earth) burst from us [so as to disclose us], so that we were the sons of the hard tracts thereof and of the soft tracts, or plains, [or of the sands,] means only their numerousness, and the wide extent of their districts. (Ham p. 341.)
And tfrRI AllRayolu Eano SuboHihi (tropical:) [The night became distinct, as though cleft, from its dawn]. (TA.)
7: see the next preceding paragraph.

8: AftrIkacibFA He forged, or fabricated, a lie, or falsehood; (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) you say, AftrI Ealayohi kacibFA [he forged against him a lie]; (Mgh, Msb;) and kacibFA faraI↓ signifies the same, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) aor. yaforiI, (Msb,) inf. n. faroIN; (M;) and this verb likewise is followed by Ealayohi: (Msb:) faraI↓ in this sense is mentioned as said by Lth; others saying AftrI. (T.) AftrI is used in the Kur in relation also to the attributing a copartner to God: thus in the saying [in iv. 51], wamano yuXoriko biQllRehi faqadi QfotariIUivmFA EaZiymFA [And whoso attributeth a copartner to God, hath devised an enormous sin]. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

faroyapN Clamour; or a confusion, or mixture, of cries or shouts or noises. (M, K, TA. [AlHalobapu in the CK is a mistake for Aljalabapu.]) firoyapN A lie, or falsehood; (S, * M, Mgh, * Msb, * K, TA;) a subst. from AifotaraI: (S, Mgh, Msb, TA:) and meaning [also] a defamation: (Mgh:) pl. firFI. (TA.)
And An affair, or a case, of great magnitude or moment or gravity. (M, TA.)

friIRN Slit, or cut lengthwise; applied to a skin (jilodN): and so fariyRapN [app. as applied to a qirobap or
the like, as being fem. of fariIRN]. (M, TA.)
And A wide dalow [or leathern bucket]; (M, K;) as though it were slit; (M;) as also fariyRapN. (K.)

And A thing forged, or fabricated; (S, K, TA;) thus [or rather as hence meaning unknown, or unheard of,] in the saying, laqadojiYoti XayoYFA fariyRFA, in the Kur [xix. 28], (S, TA,) i. e. [Thou hast done] a thing hitherto unknown; a thing deemed strange: (Bd:) or a thing of great magnitude or moment or gravity; (S, K, TA;) and thus it is said to mean in the phrase above cited: (S, TA:) or wonderful; (T, TA;) thus as expl. by Er-Rághib; (TA;) and thus it is also said to mean in that phrase. (T, TA.)
See also 1, latter half, in eight places.
Also, applied to a man, A forger, or fabricator, of lies; and so miforFI↓. (Lh, M, TA.)
And Milk of the time when it is milked. (K.)

And they say, AlfariIRa AlfariIRa, meaning AlEajalapa AlEajalapa [i. e. Haste: haste: used in an imperative sense; as inf. ns. are often thus used; but they are] both like ganiIR [in measure]: mentioned by Sgh. (TA.)
OaforaI AlfiraI occurs in a trad. as meaning The most lying of lies: AlfiraI is the pl. of firoyapN. (TA.)
miforRaI: see fariIRN.
maforiyRapN A mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag] made in a good, or proper, manner; well made. (T, TA.)

1. fazRa, (A, O, K,) aor.
faziza
, inf. n. fazRN, (TA,) He (a gazelle) was, or became, frightened, or afraid. (A, O, K.)
fazRa qalobuhu His heart heaved by reason of fear. (O.)
fazRa Eanohu He (a man, O) turned away from him. (A, O, K.) And He separated himself from him, and became alone. (A, O, K.)

fazRa, aor.
faziza
, inf. n. fazaAzapN and fuzuwzapN, He (a man, O) became excited with ardour, or eagerness. (O, K.)

fazRa fulaAnFA Eano mawoDiEihi, (A, O, * K,) inf. n. fazRN, (O,) He disturbed, removed, or unsettled, such a one from his place: (A, O, * K:) or he frightened, and disturbed, or removed, or unsettled, such a one from his place, and made his courage (lit. his heart) to fly away: (IDrd, TA:) and [in like manner] OafazRahu↓ he frightened him; (K;) or, as in some copies of the K, he disturbed or disquieted him; (TA;) or he frightened him, and disturbed or disquieted or unsettled him, and made his courage (lit. his heart) to fly away. (S, O. *) [See also 10.]

fazRa, aor.
faziza
, inf. n. faziyzN (S, O, K, TA) and fazRN, (TA,) said of a wound, It became moist, and flowed, (S, O, K, TA,) discharging its contents; and so faSRa: and in like manner it is said of water [app. as meaning it oozed forth]: (TA:) and of sweat, meaning It exuded; and so faSRa. (TA in art. fS.)
2. fzRzhu He (a man) rendered him powerful, or strong, and made him to overcome. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)
4: see 1, latter half.
8. AftzR He (a man, O) overcame; (K;) or was, or became, powerful, or strong, and overcame: (O:) and AbtzR and AbtcR signify the same: so in the Nawádir. (O, TA.)

10. AstfzRhu It (fear, S, A, O) excited him to lightness and unsteadiness; unsettled him. (S, A, O, K.) waQsotafozizo mani QsotaTaEta minohumo biSawotika, in the Kur [xvii. 66], is expl. by Fr as meaning And excite thou to lightness and unsteadiness, or unsettle thou, when thou canst, with thy voice. (O, TA.) And in like manner, waUino kaAduwA layasotafizRuwnaka mina AlOaroDi, in the same [xvii. 78], is expl. by him (O, TA) as meaning, And verily they were near to unsettling thee from the land: (TA:) but some say the meaning is, they were near to frightening thee so as to excite thee to promptness of flight from the land. (O, TA.) And AstfzRhu Eano raOoyihi He incited him, or excited him, to ignorance, foolishness, or wrong conduct, and levity, or unsteadiness, so as to make him swerve from his right sentiment, opinion, or judgment; like AisotaxafRahu En rOyh. (Az and TA in art. xf.)
He incited him, or excited him, to be promptly obedient and submissive to him and to that which he desired of him; like AstxfRhu. (Ksh in xliii. 54.)

He expelled him (Jel in xvii. 105, and K) from the land, (Jel,) or from his abode, and disturbed, or disquieted, or unsettled, him, (K,) so as to excite him to lightness and unsteadiness. (TA.) [See also 1, latter half.]
He, or it, deceived him, or beguiled him, so as to cast him into destruction. (TA.)
He slew him: so the verb is expl. by some in the Kur xvii. 78, quoted above. (TA.)
fazRN A light, or an active, man. (S, A, O, K.)
And The offspring of the cow; (S;) [meaning,] of the wild cow: (O, K:) because of its restlessness: (TA:) pl. OafozaAzN. (S, O, K.)
fazRapN A leap with disquietude [or fright]. (TA.)
qaEada musotafazRFA [so in a copy of the S, but without the vowel-signs: in two other copies of the same, musotawofizFA, which belongs to art. wfz:] He sat in an uneasy posture. (S.)

farasN musotafizRN lilowavobi waAlEadowi [so in two copies of the S, in art. Tmr; in the O, in that art., musotafizRu Alwavobi waAlEadowi; probably a mistake for musotafazR; app. meaning, A horse in a state of excitement to leap and run.]

1. fazara, (S, O, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
fazura
, (M, O, TA,) or
fazira
, (Msb,) inf. n. fazorN, (S, * O, * Msb,) He rent, or slit, a garment, or piece of cloth: (K:) he dissundered (S, * O, * Msb) the same. (S, O.)
He split, slit, or cracked, a thing. (S, O, TA.)
He struck a man's nose with a thing so as to split it. (O, * TA.)
He struck one with a stick, or staff: (TA:) or he struck him with a stick, or staff, on his back, (K, TA,) so as to break it. (TA.)
He separated, disunited, sundered, or dispersed, a thing. (TA.)
He separated, or divided, a thing from another thing. (TA.)

He broke [a thing]. (Sh, O, Msb.) Sh says, I was in the desert, and, seeing some small round tents (qibaAb) pitched, I said to an Arab of the desert, “ To whom belong these qbAb? ” and he answered, libaniI fazaArapa fazara QllRehu Zuhuwrahumo: whereupon I said to him, “ What meanest thou by it? ” and he answered, “ [To Benoo-Fezárah:] may God break [their backs]. ” (TA.)
He crumbled, or broke into small pieces, a julRap [or round piece of camel's or similar dung]; as also fzRr↓, (TA,) and Afzr↓. (O, K, TA. [In the CK, AlHulRap is put for AljulRap.])
See also 5.

Also, as implied in the K, but correctly fazira, aor.
fazara
, inf. n. fazarN [q. v.], He was, or became, such as is termed Oafozar [expl. below]. (TA.)
2: and 4: see 1, last signification but one.

5. tfzRr It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) became rent, or slit; (K;) as also Anfzr↓; (O, * K;) and fazara↓, inf. n. fuzuwrN; (Msb; [but see fazarN, below;]) and so the like thereof; (Msb;) and the same is said of a wall: (TA:) and it (a garment, or piece of cloth,) became dissundered, ragged, tattered, or shabby, and old and worn out; (S, TA;) as also Anfzr↓. (TA.)
7: see 5, in two places.
fazorN inf. n. of the trans. v. fazara. (Msb.)
[And app. used as a simple subst., having for its pl. fuzuwrN: see fizarN.]
[Also] A man possessing little, or no, good, or goodness; or little, or no, wealth; like nazorN. (AZ, TA in art. nzr.)

fizorN A flock of sheep, or herd of goats: (S, O:) or a flock of sheep from ten to forty: (AZ, A'Obeyd, S, O, K:) or from three to ten; thus in the copies of the K; but in the L, to twenty: (TA:) and two, and more: (S, O, K:) and hence, (S, O,) Alfizoru was a surname of Saad Ibn-ZeydMenáh: he came to the mawosim [or fair, and place of meeting, app. of the pilgrims,] with some goats, and allowed them to be taken as spoil, saying, “ Whoso takes of them one, it shall be his, but a fizor [i. e. a pair or more] of them shall not be taken; ” fizorN here meaning two and more: whence the prov., laA Mtiyka miEozaI Alfizori, meaning [I will not come to thee] until the goats of El-Fizr shall become gathered together; and [that means never, for] those goats will never become gathered together: (S, O, K:) or, accord. to ISd, this surname was given to him because he said to his sons, one after another, “ Pasture ye these goats, ” and they were incompliant to him; so he called to the people, “ Collect yourselves together; ” and they did so; and he said, “ Take ye them as spoil; but I do not allow to any one more than one; ” therefore they separated them at once, and they became scattered in the country: this was the origin of the prov.: and one of their provs. relating to leaving a thing undone is the saying, laA OafoEalu calika miEozaIAlfizori [I will not do that until the goats of El-Fizr shall become gathered together. (TA.) Accord. to AO, (S, O, TA,) fizorN means The kid (S, O, K, TA) itself: (S, O, TA:)
and one says, laAOafoEaluhu maA nazaA fizorN [I will not do it as long as a kid leaps]. (TA.)

And The male young one of the namir [or leopard]: (TA:) or the male young one of the [beast of prey called] babor [q. v.], (O, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, bayor,]) as is said in the T, and likewise in the Tekmileh: (TA:) and fizorapN signifies the female young one thereof; (O, K, TA;) or, as some say, the sister thereof: (TA:) and fazaArapN↓ signifies the female of the babor; (O, Msb, TA;) thus says IAar, (O,) [and] thus is said in the T: (TA:) or the mother of the babor is called fzArp; and also the female of the namir; (K, TA;) thus says IAar. (TA.)
Also The OSol [or origin, &c.,] (O, K) of a thing. (O.)

And A small thing, (O, K,) like a naboxap [or blister], in the root of the thigh, (O,) below the extremity of the pubes, resembling a gudRap [or ganglion], from an ulcer that comes forth in a man, (O, K,) or from a wound. (O.)

fazarN an inf. n. [of which the verb, accord. to a general rule, is fazira], A garment's being old and worn out; and rent, or slit. (KL. [See also 5, with which the verb fazara, inf. n. fuzuwrN, is mentioned in a similar sense.])
And [app. The being open, or wide, or broad,] meaning in Pers. frAx Xdn. (KL.)
Also The being such as is termed Oafozar [expl. below]. (S. [See 1, last sentence.])

fizarN Slits, rents, or fissures: (K:) but this word perhaps occurred to the author of the K mistranscribed; for it is said in the L that fuzuwrN [a pl. of which the sing. is app. fazorN, originally an inf. n.,] signifies slits, rents, or fissures, and clefts, or cracks. (TA.)
fuzorapN: see faAzirN.
Also A great protuberance upon the back, or upon the chest. (K.)
fazaArapN: see fizorN, last quarter of the paragraph.

faAzirN A wide road; (S, O, K;) as also fuzorapN↓: (O, K:) or a wide and conspicuous road: or, accord. to ISh, a road that passes over the [eminences termed] nijaAf [pl. of najafN] and the [hills, or small mountains termed] quwr [pl. of qaArapN], and cleaves them as though it made furrows upon their heads: you say, OaxaconaAAlfaAzira and OaxaconaATariyqa AlfaAziri, meaning [We took] the road that made a track upon the heads and the base of the mountains. (TA.) And faAzirapN↓ [or TariyqN faAzirapN] signifies A road taking its course in a tract of sand amid sands that are compact and cleaving to the ground, (K, TA,) and soft; appearing like an extended, long, natural cleft in the ground: (TA:) the same meaning is also assigned to faArizapN. (K * and TA in art. frz.)
Also A species of ants, (O,) black ants, (K,) in which is a redness: (O, K:) mentioned also among words of which the final radical is z [as being called faArizN]. (TA.)
And The round black thing [app. a species of animalcule] found in [dried] dates. (O.)
faAzirapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

Oafozaru and mafozuwrN↓ A man humpbacked; (S, O;) having a great protuberance upon his back; (S, O, K:) or having such a protuberance upon his chest: (K:) or, accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, the former signifies the same as OaqoEasu [having a protuberant breast, or chest, and a hollow, or receding, back]. (O. [See also Oaforazu.])
And [the fem. of the former] fazoraMCu A female, (K,) or girl, or young woman, (TA,) full of fat and flesh: or that has nearly attained to puberty. (K, TA.)
mafozuwru AlOanofi A man having his nose struck with a thing so as to be split. (TA.)
See also Oafozaru.

1. faziEa, (S, O, Msb, K,) and fazaEa, (K,) aor.
fazaEa
, of the former verb, (Msb, K,) and of the latter also, (K,) inf. n. fazaEN, (S, O, Msb, K,) which is of the former verb, (S, * O, Msb, TA,) and [of the latter verb] fazoEN [fazaEFA in the CK being a mistake for fazoEFA] and fizoEn (K, TA,) He feared; or was, or became, in fear, afraid, frightened, or terrified; (S, O, Msb, K, TA;) and so tfzRE↓: (TA in art. rwE:) you say, faziEa minohu he feared him, or it; or was, or became, in fear, &c., of him, or it: (MA, Msb, TA:) accord. to Er-Rághib, fazaEN signifies a shrinking, and an aversion, that comes upon a man, from a thing causing fear or fright; and is a kind of jazaE [q. v.]; and one should not say faziEotu mina QllRehi like as one says xifotu minohu: or, as Mbr says, in the “ Kámil, ” its primary signification is the fearing, or being in fear or afraid or frightened or terrified: then, by a metonymical application, it signifies a people's going forth quickly to repel an enemy, or the like, that has come upon them suddenly; and this meaning has become [conventionally regarded as] proper. (TA.)

fazaEN signifies also The seeking, or demanding, aid, or succour: (Az, K, TA:) and the aiding, or succouring; (Az, S, O, K, TA;) this latter being likewise a signification of UifozaAEN↓: (S, O:) an ex. of the former word (S, O, TA) in the latter sense (O, TA) occurs in the saying of the Prophet to the Ansár, UinRakumo latakovuruwna Einoda AlfazaEi wa taqilRuwna Einoda AlTRamaEi [Verily ye are many on the occasion of aiding, or succouring, and ye are few on the occasion of coveting, or greed]; (S, O, TA;) or in this saying the implied meaning may be, on the occasion of men's betaking themselves to you in fear (Einoda fazaEi AlnRaAsi Uilayokumo) in order that ye may aid or succour them [which is virtually the same as their seeking your aid or succour]: (TA:) thus [it is said] fazaEN has two contr. significations: (K:) and both of these significations are expressed by the verb faziEa: (O:) you say faziEa Uilayohi and faziEa minohu; (K in continuation of what has been last cited therefrom above, and TA; [app. meant to indicate that both of these phrases signify he sought, or demanded, aid, or succour, of him; and he aided, or succoured, him; or that the former phrase has the former signification; and the latter phrase, the latter signification; though accord. to the TK, both phrases have the former signification, and the former phrase has also the latter signification;]) but you should not say fazaEahu, (K, TA,) i. e. like manaEahu: (TA:) [or] from AlfazaEu as signifying “ fear, ” or “ fright, ” you say faziEotu Uilayoka and faziEotu minoka; [app. meant to indicate that the former phrase signifies I betook myself to thee in fear, which is a meaning thereof well known, and nearly agreeing with an explanation of the verb followed by Uilayohi which will be found below in this paragraph; and that the latter phrase signifies I feared thee, or I was, or became, in fear, &c., of thee, the only meaning, of this phrase, for which I find any explicit authority, and one for which I have given three authorities in the first sentence of this art.;] but you should not say faziEotuka: (S: [thus in my copies, faziEotuka, not fazaEotuka:]) or faziEa Uilayohimo signifies he sought, or demanded, of them, aid, or succour; and fazaEahumo and faziEahumo signify he aided, or succoured, them, syn. OagaAvahumo [in the CK AaEAnahumo] and naSarahumo, like OafozaEahumo↓: (K, TA:) accord. to IB, faziEotuhu meaning Oagavotuhu is originally faziEotu lh [primarily signifying I feared, or became in fear &c., for him]; then the l was dropped; for one says faziEotuhu and faziEotu lahu: (TA:) or faziEa, like fariHa, signifies AinotaSara: (K: [thus in the copies of the K, and hence in the TA, app. a mistranscription for AisotanoSara, he sought, or demanded, aid, or aid against an enemy:]) and faziEa Uilayohi he betook himself, or had recourse, to him, or it, for refuge, protection, or preservation, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) by reason of fear, or fright, (S,) and sought, or demanded, aid, or succour, by him, or it; whence, in a trad. respecting the eclipse of the sun, faQfozaEuwAUilaI AlSRalaAp i. e. Then betake yourselves, &c., to prayer, and seek, or demand, aid, or succour, by it. (TA.)

faziEa mino nawomihi means He became roused from his sleep; (O, K;) because he who is roused is not free from some fear, or fright: occurring in a trad. in this sense. (O.) And one says, faziEotu bimajiIoCi fulaAnK, meaning I prepared [or roused] myself by reason of the coming of such a one, by a change of state, or condition, like as the sleeper passes from the state of sleeping to that of waking. (TA.)
fazaEahu in the phrase fafazaEahu faAzaEahu↓ means He exceeded him in fear, or fright. (TA.)
fuziEa Eano quluwbihimo: see the next paragraph.
2. fzREhu: see 4.
[It also app. signifies He made a fearful event, or fearful events, to befall him: see its pass. part. n. below.]

fazRaEa Eanohu He removed from him fear, or fright: (O, in two places:) it is implied by the context in the K that Enh AfzE↓ has this meaning; but in the O and other lexicons it is fazRaEa. (TA.) And fuzRiEa Eanohu, (S, K,) inf. n. tafoziyEN, (K,) Fear, or fright, was removed from him. (S, K.) It is said in the
Kur [xxxiv. 22], HatRaI UicaAfuzRiEa Eano quluwbihimo, meaning Until, when fear, or fright, shall be removed from their hearts: (S, O:) this is the common reading: another reading is fazRaEa, i. e. fazRaEa QllRehu: and El-Hasan reads fuziEa↓: and he says that in this reading and the first, the prep. with its noun are [regarded as supplying the place of the agent and therefore virtually] in the nom. case, as in the phrase siyra Eani Albaladi: (TA:) some read furRiga [q. v.]: (O and TA in art. frg:) and 'Eesà Ibn- 'Omar is related to have read UicaA QforanoqaEa. (TA in art. frqE.)
3. fAzEhu fafazaEahu [He vied with him in fear, or fright,] and he exceeded him therein. (TA. See 1, last sentence but one.)

4. AfzEhu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. UifozaAEN, (S, O,) He made him to fear, or to be afraid; frightened him; or terrified him; (S, * O, * Msb, K;) as also fzREhu↓, (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. tafoziyEN. (S, O.) And you say, yufozaEu minohu [One is made to fear, or be afraid of, or is frightened, or terrified, at, it, or him], (S, O, K,) and mino Oajolihi [on account of him, or for the sake of him], (O, K,) and bihi [by him, or by means of him]. (O.)
[Hence,] He housed him from his sleep. (K, TA. [See 1, last quarter.])
Also He aided, or succoured, him. (S, K.) See 1, former half; and again, in the latter half.
See also 2.
5: see 1, first sentence.
fazaEN Fear, or fright: (S, O, K:) originally (S) an inf. n.; but notwithstanding this, (S, * O, K,) sometimes, (S, O,) having a pl., which is OafozaAEN. (S, O, K.)
[And, as seems to be indicated by an explanation of mufazRaEN (q. v.), A fearful event: pl. as above.]

faziEN Fearing; being afraid or frightened or terrified; (Er-Rághib, MA, Msb, TA;) thus in a verse cited voce ZunobuwbN; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and mufaAziEN↓ is syn. therewith: (O, K:) and one says also rajulN faAziEN↓, pl. fazaEapN; and mafozuwEN↓; meaning a man put in fear; made afraid; frightened, or terrified. (TA.) And In a state of disquiet, disturbance, or agitation: whence an extraordinary reading, of four readers, in the Kur xxviii. 9, [i. e. faziEFA] for faArigFA, relating to the heart of the mother of Moses, meaning in a state of disquiet, &c., almost quitting its pericardium. (TA.) It has no broken pl.; its only pl. being faziEuwna. (TA.)

Also Seeking, or demanding, aid, or succour; and Sgh thus explains it [in the O] as used in the verse above mentioned; but Er-Rághib says that this is an explanation of the intended meaning, not of the literal signification: (TA:) and it has also the contr. meaning, aiding, or succouring; thus being trans., though of the measure faEilN; but it may be altered from faAziEN↓, like as HacirN is [said to be] altered from HaAcirN. (IB, TA,)
fazoEapN: see fazaEapN.

fuzoEapN A man whom one is made to fear, of whom one is made afraid, or at whom one is frightened: (O, K:) [like mafozaEapN as expl. by Lth and others:] and by whom, or by means of whom, one is made afraid, or frightened. (O.)

fazaEapN sing. of fazaEaAt in the phrase fazaEaAtu AlrRuwEi [app. meaning The fears, or frights, of the heart]. (TA. [The sing., as well as the pl., is there said to be thus, biAltRaHoriyk; but if the former be, as I think it is, an inf. n. un., it should by rule be fazoEapN↓.])
fuzaEapN One who fears men, or is frightened at them: (K:) or one who fears, or is frightened, much, or often; (O;) [and] so fazRaAEapN↓. (TA. [But see what next follows.])
fazRaAEapN One who makes men to fear, or frightens them, much, or often. (O, K.) See also fuzaEapN.
faAzigN: see faziEN, in two places.

mafozaEN i. q. malojaOo [as meaning A refuge, i. e. a place to which, or a person to whom, one betakes himself, or has recourse, for refuge, protection, or preservation,] (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) on the occasion of the befalling of an affliction or a calamity; (TA;) applied to a sing. and a pl. (S, O, K) and a dual (S, O) and a masc. and a fem.; (S, O, K;) one says, fulaAnN mafozaEN lilnRaAsi Such a one is a refuge to men when an event comes upon them suddenly, and humaAmafozaEN lilnRaAsi, and humo mafozaEN, &c.; (S, O;) and mafozaEapN↓ is the same in signification and in its applications; (K;) expl. by IF as signifying a place to which one who is in fear, or frightened, betakes himself, or has recourse, for refuge, protection, or preservation: (TA:) or mafozaEN signifies one of whom aid, or succour, is sought, or demanded: (K:) and mafozaEapN↓, [a cause of fear or fright; being a word of the class of maboxalapN and majobanapN; i. e.] a thing that one is made to fear, or at which one is frightened; (S;) or a person whom one is made to fear, or at whom one is frightened; [like fuzoEapN;] or on account of whom, or for the sake of whom, one is made to fear, or is frightened: (Lth, O, K:) you say, fulaAnN lanaA mafozaEapN [Such a one is to us a person whom we are made to fear, &c.], and in like manner you say of a female, and of a pl. number. (O.)
mafozaEapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

mufazRaEN Cowardly; (Fr, O, K;) as being made to fear, or to be frightened at, everything: (Fr, O:) and courageous; (Fr, O, K;) as being one the like of whom fearful events are made to befall (bimivolihi tunozalu AlOafozaAEu). (Fr, O. [But what here follows suggests another reason, and I think a better, for the latter meaning.]) mufazRaEapN applied by 'Amr Ibn-Maadee-Kerib as an epithet to his Aisot, in replying to a threat of El-Ash-'ath, who had said to him, lawo danawota laOuDarRiTanRaka, means Secure from being overcome by fear, or fright, and [therefore] not lax so as to break wind [in consequence of fear]; being from fazRaEa Eanohu meaning “ he removed fear, or fright, from him; ” or it may be for the same reason as that for which mufazRaEN is applied to a courageous man. (O.)
mafozuwEN: see faziEN, first sentence.
mufaAziEN: see faziEN, first sentence.
fisofisapN i. q. fiSofiSapN, i. e. raTobapN: (K:) the second of these is more known than the first; both of which are arabicized, from the Persian UisoPisot [or Uisofisot]. (TA.)
1. fasaOahu: see 2.

Also, (M, K,) or fasaOahu biAlEaSaA, (AZ, O,) aor.
fasaAa
, inf. n. fasoCN, (M,) He struck, or beat, (AZ, M, O, K,) him, (O,) or his back, (AZ, M, K,) with the staff, or stick; (AZ, M, O, K;) as also tfsROhu↓, (K,) or tfsROhu bAlESA. (O.)
And fasaOa fulaAnFA Eanohu He restrained, withheld, or debarred, such a one from him. (O, * K.)

fasiYa, aor.
fasaAa
, [inf. n., app., fasaON, q. v. infrà,] He was, or became, such as is termed OafosaOu [q. v.]. (K.)

2. fsROhu, namely, a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, M, O, K,) inf. n. tafosiYapN (S, O) and tafosiIoCN, (S,) He stretched it so that it rent, or became ragged, or dissundered: (S, O:) or he rent it; as also fasaOahu↓, aor.
fasaAa
, (M, K,) inf. n. fasoCN (M.)

5. tfsRO, said of a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, M, O, K,) It became ragged, or dissundered, (S, O,) and worn out: (S:) like tqDRO, or tfSRO: (accord. to different copies of the S: the latter in the L:) or it became rent. (M, O.)
tfsRO fiyhimo, (K,) or bihimo, (O,) said of a disease, It spread among them, (O, K,) and became common among them: (TA:) like tfXRO. (O, K.)
tfsRO: see 1.
6. tfAsO, and tfAsI, (M, O, TA,) He (a man) protruded (M, O, TA) his posteriors, (M,) or his back, (O,) or both. (TA.)
fasaON a subst. signifying The state of such as is termed OafosaOu [q. v.]: (M, TA:) or a hollowness, or incurvity, of the spine. (TA in art. fqO.) [See also 1, last sentence.]

OafosaOu i. q. Oabozaxu [i. e. Having a protuberant breast, or chest, and hollow back; &c.]: or having a protuberant breast, or chest, and the lower part of the belly prominent: (M, K:) fem. fasaMCu: (M:) and (M, in the K “ or ”) he who, when he walks, is as though his posteriors were in pain (in the M tawojaEu; in some copies of the K tawajRaEu [as though for tatawajRaEu], and in some yrjE); as also mafosuwoCN↓: (M, K:) or he who, when he sits, cannot rise but with an effort: (O, K:) or whose spine enters into [or turns inwards between] his haunches. (K.)
mafosuwoCN: see the next preceding paragraph.
fusotaAtN, also written fisotaAtN: see fusoTaATN.
fusotaATN, also written fisotaATN: see fusoTaATN, in art. fsT, to which it belongs; for the t is a substitute for the [former] T in fsTAT, or for the [latter] s in fisRaATN. (M and TA in art. fsT.)

fusotuqN and fusotaqN, (O, Msb, K,) the latter the more agreeable with the original, (O,) which is Pisotah, (O, K,) a Pers. word, (O,) for from this each is arabicized; (O, Msb, * K;) [The pistachio-nut, pistacia vera of Linn.;] a certain fruit; (O;) [in the Msb bql; perhaps a mistranscription for nql, i. e. naqolN, a certain fruit that is eaten with wine;] well known: (K:) said in a verse of Aboo-Nukheyleh to be mina Albuquwli: thus, and thus only, with b, the phrase is related: if it were mn AlnRuquwli, the mistake would be removed: (O:) Az says that the fstqp [which is the n. un.] is a fruit of a well-known tree: and AHn says, “ It has not come to my knowledge that it grows in the land of the Arabs: ” (TA:) it is good for the liver, and the mouth of the stomach, and the colic, and the odour of the mouth. (K. [In the CK, AlnRahakapi is put for AlnRakohapi.]) The vulgar pronounce the word with fet-h [to the f, saying fasotuq: and many of them say fisotuq]. (Msb.)
vawobN fusotuqiIRN [meaning A garment of the colour of the fusotuq] is [thus] with damm [to the f and t]. (Msb.)

1. fasuHa, (MA, Msb, K, [in the CK fasaHa, a misprint,]) with damm, (Msb,) like karuma, (K,) [aor.
fasuHa
,] inf. n. fusaAHapN, (L,) or fasaAHapN [for which the former is app. a mistranscription] and fusoHapN, (MA,) It (a place) was, or became, spacious, roomy, wide, or ample; (MA, Msb, K;) as also AfsH↓, (Msb, K,) and tfsRH↓, and AnfsH↓. (K.)

fasaHa lahu, (S, MA, Msb, K,) aor.
fasaHa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. fasoHN (MA, Msb, TA) and fusuwHN; (TA;) as also tfsRH↓, (A, K,) and AfsH↓; (A;) He made room, or ample room, for him, (S, MA, Msb, K,) fiI Almajolisi (S, MA, Msb) in the sitting-place, or in the assembly. (MA.) You say, fiI Almajolisi tafasRaHuwA↓, (S, Msb, *) and tafaA saHuwA↓, (S, K,) Make ye room, or ample space, [in the sitting-place, or in the assembly,] syn. tawasRaEuwA: (S, K:) both of these verbs have nearly the same signification: [each may be rendered, but the latter more properly, make ye room, or ample space, one for another:] the latter occurs, accord. to the reading of El-Hasan, and the former accord. to that of others, in the Kur lviii. 12. (Fr, TA.)
And AifosaHo EanRiI Remove thou, withdraw, or retire to a distance, from me. (Ksh and Bd in lviii. 12.)

fasoHN [as inf. n. of fasaHa] also signifies The making wide steps; and so fayosaHaI. (K.) [Hence,] AifosaHi AlxuTaI, said by an Arab of the Desert, of the Benoo-'Okeyl, to one who was sewing for him a water-skin, and mentioned in the T, as heard by its author, meaning (assumed tropical:) Make wide the spaces between each two punctures of the needle, lest the punctures should rend. (L.)
And fasaHa lahu AlOamiyru fiI AlsRafari means The commander, or governor, wrote for him a fasoH [q. v.]. (K.)
2. fsRH He made a place spacious, roomy, wide, or ample. (Msb.)
4: see 1, first and second sentences.
5: see 1, in three places.
[tfsRH also signifies He expatiated, or ranged at large: and he had ample room or scope: see mutafasRaHN.]
6: see 1, third sentence.
7: see 1, first sentence.
[Hence,] AnfsH muraAHuhumo [lit. The nightly resting-place of their camels was, or became, spacious,] means (assumed tropical:) their camels became numerous. (TA.)
And AnfsH Sadoruhu (assumed tropical:) His bosom became dilated [with joy]. (S, A.)
And AnfsH Tarofuhu (assumed tropical:) His eye had an unobstructed view, nothing hindering its seeing far. (L.)
Q. Q. 2. tafayosaHa: see tafayoHasa, in art. fHs.
fasoHN A writing like a jawaAz [or traveller's pass]. (K.) [See 1, last sentence.]
fusuHN: see fasiyHN, in three places.
fusoHapN Spaciousness, roominess, width, or ampleness; (S, A, L, K;) [particularly, or generally,] with respect to the ground. (L.) [In the MA it is mentioned as an inf. n. of fasuHa.]
And [Ample scope for action &c.] in an affair. (Msb in art. rxw.) [And A state in which is ample scope for acting &c.: see nafasN.]
AlfusoHataAni signifies The two spaces without hair on the two sides of the hair that grows immediately beneath the middle of the lower lip. (L.)
fusoHumN: see fasiyHN, in two places.
fulaAnN Qbonu fusoHumK is a phrase mentioned by Lh, thought by him to be from AlfusoHapu and AlAinofisaAHu, but the meaning is unknown. (L.)
Also The glans of the penis. (K in art. fsHm; where the word is mentioned again in the S likewise.)
fusaAHN: see the paragraph here following.

fasiyHN (S, A, Msb, K) and fusaAHN↓, (K,) like TawiylN and TuwaAlN, (TA,) Spacious, roomy, wide, or ample; applied to a place; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also fusuHN↓ and fusoHumN↓: (K:) or fusuHN↓ signifies thus applied to a sitting-place: (S:) and fusoHumN↓, (S, K,) in which the m is augmentative, (S,) signifies (S, K) also (K) waAsiEu AlSRadori [meaning free from distress of mind or from narrowness of mind], (S, K,) as does also fusuHN↓ [in the CK in this sense written fusoHN]; both being applied in this sense to a man. (K.)
sayorN fasiyHN [means A pace in which the steps are wide: see 1, latter half].
jamalN mafosuwHu AlDRuluwEi i. q. masofuwH [i. e. A camel wide in the ribs]. (TA.)
maA laka fiI hecaA mutafasRaHN [There is not for thee ample scope (lit. a place in which one has ample scope) in this]. (A.)
munofasaHN waAdK [The place of expanding of a valley]. (JK and K in art. xrq, &c.)
muraAHN munofasiHN (assumed tropical:) A nightly resting-place of camels, or of camels and other cattle, in which they are numerous. (As, K.)

1. fasaxa, (S, A, L, K,) aor.
fasaxa
, (S, L, K,) inf. n. fasoxN; (S, L;) and fsRx↓; (L; [but this has an intensive signification;]) He dislocated, luxated, or disjointed, (A, L, K,) one's arm, or hand, (S, A, L, K,) or a limb, without breaking: (L:) [and] fasaxotu AlmafoSila Eano mawoDiEihi I removed the joint from its place. (Msb.)
And the former v., aor. and inf. n. as above, He removed a stick, or twig, or branch, from its place with his hand. (Msb.)

And the same v., (S, Msb,) aor. as above, (A,) and so the inf. n., (K,) He cast, or cast off, (S, Msb, K,) a garment, (S, Msb,) or his garments. (A.) You say, fasaxotu EanRiI vawobiI I cast, or cast off, from me my garment. (S.)
And the same v., (L, Msb,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (K,) He separated, disunited, sundered, dissundered, or dispersed, (L, Msb, K,) a thing. (L, Msb.)

Also, the same verb, (S, A, L, Msb,) aor. as above, (L,) and so the inf. n., (L, Msb, K,) (tropical:) He undid, dissolved, or annulled, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) a sale, (S, A, L, Msb,) and a determination, resolution, or decision, (S,) and a marriage, (S, A, L,) and a contract, compact, or covenant, and an affair. (Msb.)
And the same v., (L, Msb,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (L, K,) (assumed tropical:) He (a man, Msb) corrupted, or disordered, the judgment, or opinion. (L, Msb, K.)

fasixa, aor.
fasaxa
, (L, K,) inf. n. fasaxN; (L;) or fasaxa, this v. being intrans. as well as trans.; (Msb;) (assumed tropical:) It (the judgment, or opinion,) was, or became, corrupt, or disordered. (L, Msb, K.)

[And, accord. to the TK, fasixa, (but this I think to be a mistake for fasaxa,) inf. n. fasoxN, signifies DaEufa ((assumed tropical:) He was, or became, weak, app. in intellect and in body; see fasoxN below); said of a man: and jahila (app. intrans., meaning (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, ignorant; but accord. to the TK trans., meaning he knew not a thing).]

In the conventional language of the philosophers, Alfasoxu [as an inf. n.] signifies (assumed tropical:) The transmigration of the rational soul of a human being from his body to [some one of] the inanimate,
not increasing, bodies, such as the minerals, or metals, and the simple elements: (Dict. of Technical Terms used in the Sciences of the Musalmans:) or, to a plant: the former meaning being that of AlrRasoxu. (So in a marginal note in a copy of the TK.)
2: see the preceding paragraph, first sentence.
3. fAsxhu AlbayoEa (tropical:) [He agreed with him in undoing, dissolving, or annulling, the sale]. (A. [See 6.])
4. Afsx AlquroMna (assumed tropical:) He forgot the Kur-án. (Fr, S.)
5: see 7, in two places.

tfsRx AlXRaEaru Eani Aljilodi The hair fell off and became scattered from the skin, peculiarly of a dead body: (L, K:) and in like manner, AllRaHomu Eani AlEaZomi the flesh from the bone. (A, L.) And tafasRaxati AlfaOarapu fiI AlmaMCi The rat, or mouse, became dissundered, [or fell in pieces, through putrefaction,] in the water. (S.)

tfsRx taHota AlHimoli AlvRaqiyli, said of a [young camel such as is termed] rubaE, (S, K, *) He was, or became, weak beneath the heavy load, (K,) and unable to bear it: (S, K:) and [in like manner] one says of a man, tfsRx taHota AlEiboCi AlvRaqiyli. (A.)

6. tfAsxwA AlEaqoda (assumed tropical:) They agreed together in undoing, dissolving, or annulling, the contract, compact, or covenant. (Msb.) And tfAsxA AlbayoEa (tropical:) [They two agreed in dissolving, or annulling, the sale]. (A.)
And tfAsxt AlOaqaAwiylu (tropical:) The sayings annulled, or contradicted, one another. (TA.)

7. Anfsx It (a limb, L, such as an arm, or a hand, A, L) became dislocated, luxated, or disjointed; (A, L;) as also tfsRx↓. (L.) One says, waqaEa fulaAnN faQnofasaxato qadamuhu Such a one fell, and his foot became dislocated. (L. [And the like is said in the A.])
It (a stick, or twig, or branch,) became removed from its place by the hand. (Msb.)
It (flesh) became dissundered by putrefaction; as also tfsRx↓. (L.)

And, said of a sale, (S, A, K,) and a determination, resolution, or decision, (S, K,) and a marriage, (S, A, K,) [and a contract, compact, or covenant, (see 1,)] and an affair, (L,) (tropical:) It became undone, dissolved, or annulled. (S, A, L, K.)
Also said of a weak man, [app. as meaning (assumed tropical:) He became unnerved,] on an occasion of difficulty. (L: see fasiyxN.)
fasoxN [mentioned above as the inf. n. of 1 in most of its senses] (assumed tropical:) Weakness (L, K) in intellect and in body; as also fasoxapN↓. (L.)
And (assumed tropical:) Ignorance: (K:) which is referrible to weakness of intellect. (TA.)
And (assumed tropical:) Weak in intellect and in body; as also fasoxapN↓. (K.)
See also fasiyxN.
fasixN (assumed tropical:) A corrupt, or disordered, judgment, or opinion. (L.)
fasoxapN: see fasoxN, in two places.
fasiyxN [applied to flesh-meat, Parting in pieces, and easily resolvable, by reason of much cooking. (Golius, from Meyd.)

And] (assumed tropical:) A weak man, who becomes unnerved (yanofasixu↓) on an accasion of difficulty: (L:) a man who does not attain that which he wants, (S, L, K,) and is not fit for his affair, or business; as also fasoxN↓ [q. v.]. (K.)
vawobN faAsixN [(assumed tropical:) A faded garment: so in the language of the present day: perhaps post-classical]. (A in art. rmd.)
[AlfaAsixu is a name given by the Jews to their festival of The Passover: see De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., i. 291, and p. 97 of the Ar. text: and see also AlfiSoHu.]

1. fasada, aor.
fasuda
, (S, M, A, O, L, Msb, K, &c.,) which is the aor. commonly known, (TA,) and
fasida
, (IDrd, M, O, L, K,) which is of weak authority; (IDrd, O, TA;) and fasuda, aor.
fasuda
; (S, M, O, L, K;) inf. n. fasaAdN (S. M, A, O, L, K) and fusuwdN, (M, O, L, K,) the former being inf. n. of fasada, aor.
fasuda
, (S, A, O,) and so the latter, and the former being also inf. n. of fasuda, (O,) or the former is of fasuda and the latter is of fasada, (TA,) or the former is a simple subst., and the latter is the inf. n.; (Msb;) It (a thing, S, A, O) [and he (a man)] was, or became, bad, evil, corrupt, unsound, wrong, wrongful, improper, unrighteous, wicked, vitious, depraved, or dishonest; devoid of virtue, or efficacy; in a corrupted, vitiated, perverted, marred, spoiled, injured, impaired, deteriorated, tainted, or infected, state; in a state of disorder or disturbance, destruction, annihilation, consumption, waste, or ruin; (MA, KL, PS, &c.;) and so Astfsd↓: (KL:) contr. of SalaHa: (M, * L, K:) it became altered in its state [for the worse]: and it became null, void, of no force, or of no account; or it came to nought, or perished; accord. to the explanation by most of the expositors of the ex. in the Kur xxi. 22. (MF.)
2: see 4, first sentence.

3. fAsdhu He became at variance with him; he cut, severed, or broke, the tie of friendship [or kindred] with him. (L in art. kXH.) And fulaAnN yufaAsidu rahoTahu [Such a one cuts the ties of friendship, or kindred, with his people, tribe, or near kinsfolk]. (A.)

4. Afsd, (S, M, O, L, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. UfosaAdN and [quasi-inf.n.] fasaAdN; (L;) and fsRd↓, (O, L, Msb, K,) inf. n. tafosiydN; (O, K;) He, or it, made, or rendered, bad, evil, corrupt, unsound, wrong, wrongful, improper, unrighteous, wicked, vitious, depraved, or dishonest; deprived of virtue, or efficacy; corrupted, vitiated, perverted, marred, spoiled, injured, impaired, deteriorated, tainted, or infected; [constituted, disposed, arranged, or qualified, ill, wrongly, or improperly;] disordered, or disturbed, [disorganized,] destroyed, annihilated, consumed, wasted, or ruined; (MA, KL, &c.;) contr. of OSolaHa. (M, L, K.) One says, Afsd AlmaAla [He rendered the property in a bad state; marred, impaired, consumed, or wasted, it]. (L.) [And Afsd Ealayohimo He corrupted, perverted, or marred, their state, case, affair, scheme, plot, or the like; Oamorahumo, or the like, being understood. And Afsdhu EalaIRa He corrupted him and rendered him disaffected towards me.] UifosaAdu SabiIRK, occurring in a trad., means The injuring a child by rendering its mother pregnant while she is suckling it and so vitiating her milk: which act is also termed Algiylahu. (L.) [And Afsd as contr. of OaSolaHa signifies also He acted in a bad, an evil, or a corrupt, manner; acted ill, corruptly, wrongly, wrongfully, improperly, unrighteously, wickedly, vitiously, or dishonestly; or did evil, or mischief; Uilayohi to him: and he created, or excited, disorder, disturbance, disagreement, discord, dissension, strife, or quarrel-ling; or made, or did, mischief; bayona Alqawomi between, or among, the people, or party. (See also 10.)]
6. tfAsdwA They became at variance, one with another; (M, L;) they cut, severed, or broke, the tie of kindred, (M, L, K,) and of friendship, (L,) one with another. (M, L, K.)
7. Anfsd [as quasi-pass. of Oafosadahu] is not allowable, (S, L,) or has not been heard. (K.)

10. Astfsd contr. of AisotaSolaHa. (S, O, L, K.) [Hence, He regarded, or esteemed, a thing, or man, as bad, evil, corrupt, unsound, wrong, wrongful, improper, unrighteous, wicked, vitious, depraved, or dishonest; &c.: see 1.
And] He wished, or desired, [a thing, or man,] to be bad, evil, corrupt, &c. (KL.)
[And He sought to render bad, evil, corrupt, &c.

And hence, He treated in such a manner as to render disaffected, or rebellious.] One says, AlOamiyru yasotafosidu raEiyRatahu [The prince, or governor, treats his subjects in such a manner as to render them disaffected, or rebel-lious]. (A.) And AstfsdAlsRuloTaAnu qaAYidahu The Sultán provoked the leader of his forces to rebel-lion by his evil conduct to him. (L.)

[And He sought to act in a bad, an evil, or a corrupt, manner; to act ill, corruptly, wrongly, wrongfully, improperly, unrighteously, or dishonestly.] One says, Astfsd fulaAnN UilaI fulaAnK [Such a one sought to act in a bad, an evil, or a corrupt, manner, or to act ill, &c., to such a one]. (M.)
[And He sought discord, or dissension.
And It (an event) happened in a bad, or an evil, manner.]
See also 1.

fasaAdN an inf. n. of 1: (S, M, A, &c.:) or a simple subst.: (Msb:) [as a subst. signifying] Badness, evilness, corruptness, unsoundness, wrongness, wrongfulness, impropriety, unrighteousness, wickedness, vitiousness, depravity, or dishonesty; the state of being devoid of virtue or efficacy; a corrupted, vitiated, perverted, marred, spoiled, deteriorated, or tainted, state; a state of disorder or disturbance, or of destruction, annihilation, consumption, waste, or ruin: (MA, KL, PS, &c.:) contr. of SalaAHN. (Lth, M, Msb.) And it is also [frequently used as a quasi-inf. n.] syn. with UifosaAdN
[signifying The making, or rendering, bad, evil, corrupt, &c.: (see 4:) and, oftener, the acting ill, corruptly, wrong, wrongfully, improperly, unrighteously, wickedly, vitiously, or dishonestly; doing evil, or mischief; and creating, or exciting, disorder, disturbance, disagreement, discord, dissension, strife, or quarrelling]: (L:) and [particularly] the taking property wrongfully. (O, K.) [Hence,] Harobu AlfasaAdi [The war of evildoing]: thus was termed a war that happened between [the two sub-tribes] banuwXk [in which the latter word is app. a mistranscription for XibokK] and gawov, of the tribe of TaIRiC: it was so termed because one party patched their sandals with the cars of the other, and one party drank wine out of the skulls of the other. (MF.)

Also Drought, barrenness, dearth, or scarcity of good: (M, L, K:) so in the Kur [xxx. 40], Zahara QlofasaAdu fiI AlbarRi wa QlobaHori i. e. Drought, &c., hath appeared in the land, and in the cities that are upon the rivers; (M, L, TA;) accord. to Zj; (M;) or accord. to Ez-Zejjájee. (L, TA.)
fasiydN: see the next paragraph.

faAsidN, (S, M, A, O, L, Msb, K, &c.,) part. n. of fasada; (S, M, A, &c.;) and fasiydN↓, (S, M, O, L, K,) part. n. of fasuda; (S, O;) Bad, evil, corrupt, unsound, wrong, wrongful, improper, unrighteous, wicked, vitious, depraved, or dishonest; devoid of virtue, or efficacy; in a corrupted, vitiated, perverted, marred, spoiled, injured, impaired, deteriorated, tainted, or infected, state; in a state of disorder or disturbance, destruction, annihilation, consumption, waste, or ruin: (MA, KL, PS, &c.: [contr. of SaAliHN and SaliyHN, as is indicated in the S and M &c.:]) pl. (of the former, S, O, Msb, [dev. from general analogy, and of the latter agreeably therewith,]) fasodaI, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) applied to a people, (S, M, O,) like as they said saAqiTN and saqoTaI; (S, O;) the pl. being made of the same form as halokaI because these two words are nearly the same in meaning. (Sb, M.)

Oafosadu is [a noun denoting the comparative and superlative degrees] from AlfasaAdu; as in the prov., Oafosadu mino bayoDapi Albaladi i. e. [More corrupt, or unsound, &c.,] than the egg that the ostrich leaves in the desert, not returning to it, in consequence of which it becomes corrupt, or unsound, &c.: and, anomalously, from AlUifosaAdu; as in the prov., Oafosada mina AljaraAdi [i. e. More corrupting, or marring, &c., than the locust], because it strips the trees and the herbage; and as in other provs. (Meyd.)

mafosadapN A cause, or means, or an occasion, of fasaAd [i. e. badness, evilness, corruptness, unsoundness, &c.; or making, or rendering, bad, evil, corrupt, &c.]; (M, A;) contr. of maSolaHapN: (S, O, Msb, K:) pl. mafaAsidu. (A, Msb.) One says, hecaA AlOamori mafosadapN likacaA [This affair, or event, is cause of evil, &c., to such a thing]. (M.) And humo mino Oaholi AlmafaAsidi laA AlmaSaAliHi [They are of the people who do actions that are causes of evil, not actions that are causes of good]. (A.)

1. fasara, aor.
fasira
(S, M, O, Msb, K) and
fasura
, (M, K,) inf. n. fasorN; (S, M, O, Msb, K;) and fsRr↓, (S, M, K,) inf. n. tafosiyrN; (S, K;) which latter is the more common; (IKtt;) or the latter has an intensive signification; (Msb;) He discovered, detected, revealed, developed, or disclosed, a thing that was concealed or obscured; (IAar, O, K;) or a meaning perceived by the intellect: (B:) he rendered a thing apparent, plain, or clear; explained, expounded, or interpreted, it: (S, M, O, Msb, K:) accord. to Th (O, K, TA) and IAar, (TA,) tafosiyrN↓ and taOowiylN signify the same; (O, K, TA;) and so these and maEonFI: (O, TA:) or tfsyr↓ signifies the discovering, detecting, revealing, developing, or disclosing, what is meant by a dubious expression; and tOwyl signifies the “ reducing one of two senses, or interpretations, which an expression bears, or admits, to that which suits the apparent meaning: ” (O, L, K, TA:) or the latter, the “ turning a verse of the Kur-án from its apparent meaning to a meaning which it bears, or admits, when the latter is agreeable with the Kur-án and the Sunneh: ” for instance, in the phrase in the Kur [vi. 95, &c.], yuxoriju QloHaIRa mina QlomayRiti, if the meaning be [thus explained], “ He produceth the bird from the egg, ” this is tfsyr↓: and if the meaning be [thus explained], “ He produceth the believer from the unbeliever, ” or “ the knowing from the ignorant, ” this is tOwyl: (KT:) or tfsyr↓ signifies the expounding, explaining, or interpreting, the narratives that occur collected without discrimination in the Kur-án, and making known the significations of the strange words or expressions, and explaining the occasions on which the verses were revealed; and tOwyl, the “ explaining the meaning of that which is mutaXaAbih, [or what is equivocal, or ambiguous,] i. e., what is not understood without repeated consideration. ” (TA.)

Also fasara, inf. n. fasorN; and fsRr↓, inf. n. tafosirapN, (S, O, K,) like tacokirapN; (TA;) or tafosirapN has the last of the significations assigned to it below as a subst.; (O, K, TA;) or it is postclassical; (S, O, K;) He (a physician) examined, or inspected, urine, (S, O, K, [but the inf. ns. only are mentioned,]) that he might judge, by its colour, of the disease of the person from whom it came. (TA.)
2: see the preceding paragraph, in six places.
5: see the next following paragraph.
10. Astfsrhu kacaA He asked him to explain, expound, or interpret, such a thing to him: (S, Msb, TA:) and tafasRurN↓ is like AisotifosaArN. (TA.)
tafosirapN Anything by which is known the explanation and meaning of a thing: (O, TA:) or anything which interprets, or explains, the state, or condition, of a thing. (B, TA.)

Urine by means of which, (M, O, K,) or by means of the colour of which, (TA,) one seeks to obtain an indication of the disease (M, O, K, TA) of a patient: (O, TA:) or it is an inf. n., as mentioned above. (O, K.) [See 1, last sentence.]
Oaworada kalaAmahu gayora mufasRarK: see EaAhinN.

fusoTaATN and fisoTaATN (S, M, Msb, K) and fusRaATN and fisRaATN and fusotaATN and fisotaATN, (S, M, K,) the t in the last two, as it is not found in the pl., being a substitute for the [former] T in fsTAT, or rather for the [latter] s in fsRAT, because it is more regular to change the latter of two identical letters than to change the former, and because the two identical letters in fsRAT are together, whereas the two identical letters in fsTAT are separated, (M,) and fusotaAtN and fisotaAtN, (K,) altogether eight different forms, but MF observes that Esh-Shiháb El-Kastalánee gives twelve, [which, however, he does not transcribe, the remaining four being probably with fet-h to the f,] (TA,) A tent of hair [-cloth]: (S, Msb:) or a great tent: (Mgh:) or a kind of structure (M, Z) used in travelling, less than the suraAdiq: (Z:) or the kind of structure called suraAdiq: (K:) pl. fasaATiyTu; (M, Msb, TA;) for which they did not say fasaAtiyTu. (M, TA:)

Hence fusoTaATN is applied to A city: (Z, TA:) any city: and particularly a city in which is the general place of assemblage of people: (TA:) a populous, or comprehensive, city; accord. to some: (Msb:) the place of assemblage of the people of a kuwrap [which means a city, and a district, or region], (Lth, Az, K,) around their general mosque: (Az, TA:) or you say, fusoTaATu AlmiSori, meaning the place of assemblage of the people of the mSr [or city], around their congregational mosque. (M.) fusoTaATu [so in two copies of the S] is [a name of] The city of miSor [the metropolis of Egypt]: (S:) or AlfusoTaATu is also the proper name of miSoruAlEatiyqapu, (K, TA,) the city so called, (TA,) which was built by 'Amr Ibn-El- 'Ás; (K, TA;) the city of mSr in old times; as also AlfisoTaATu: (Msb:) and AlbaSorapu. (TA.)
