1. fasaqa is said to signify primarily It (a thing) went forth, from another thing, in a bad, or corrupt, manner. (Msb.) One says, fasaqati AlrRuTabapu, (S, O, Msb,) or fasaqati AlrRuTabapu Eano qiXorihaA, (K,) The fresh ripe date came forth from its skin; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also Anfsqt↓: (IDrd, O, K:) and in like manner fasaqa is said of anything as meaning it came forth from its integument: so says EsSarakustee. (Msb.)

[Hence] fasaqa, aor.
fasuqa
and
fasiqa
, (S, O, Msb, K) the latter aor. mentioned by Akh, (S, O, Msb,) inf. n. fusuwqN (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and fisoqN, (S, O, K,) or this latter is a simple subst.; (Msb;) and likewise fasuqa, like karuma, (K, TA,) mentioned by Lh, but not known by Ks; (TA;) He went forth from, departed from, or quitted, (Mgh, Msb, K,) the right way, (Mgh, K,) or the way of truth, (K,) and the limits of the law, (Mgh,) [or the bounds of] obedience; (Msb;) he forsook, relinquished, or neglected, the command of God; he disobeyed; (K;) or i. q. fajara [meaning
as above; or he transgressed; or acted unrighteously, sinfully, wickedly, vitiously, or immorally]. (S, O, K. [See also fisoqN below.]) fasaqa Eano OamorirabRihi (in the Kur [xviii. 48], O, TA) means He departed (xaraja) from the command of his Lord: (Th, S, O, K:) or from the obeying [of the command] of his Lord: (Fr, O, TA:) and Akh says that this phrase is like AitRaxama En AlTRaEAmi, (S, O,) meaning Eano maOokalihi, (S,) or Eano Oakolihi AlTRaEaAma; but Th says that there is no need of this [explanation]: or, accord. to AO, it means he declined, or deviated, from obeying the command of his Lord: (O:) for fasaqa signifies also he declined, or deviated: (K:) and hence the saying, fasaqati AlrRikaAbu Eano qaSodi AlsRabiyli i. e. [The ridden camels] declined [from the right direction of the way]. (TA.) Sometimes fusuwqN may mean The believing in a plurality of gods: and it may mean the committing sin. (A Heyth, O.) And it is said to mean The calling one another by names of reproach: (Zj, * Mgh, TA:) or the saying “ O Jew, ” and “ O Christian, ” after one has become a believer: thus in the Kur xlix. 11. (TA.)

One says also, fasaqa fiI AldRunoyaA, inf. n. fisoqN, meaning He had a wide, or an ample, range in respect of worldly things, and made them light and easy to himself, being without restraint in his management of them, not making them strait to him. (Ktr, Sh, TA.)
And fasaqa maAlahu He made away with his property; and disposed of it, or spent it. (TA.)

2. tafosiyqN is the contr. of taEodiylN: (O, K, TA:) one says fsRqhu, (O, TA,) inf. n. tafosiyqN, (TA,) He (the judge) pronounced him to be characterized by fisoq [q. v.]: (O, TA:) he attributed to him fisoq. (TA.)
7: see 1, second sentence.
[Hence,] Anfsq mina Alxayori, said of the faAsiq, He divested himself, or became divested, of good. IDrd, O.)

fisoqN is an inf. n., (S, O, K,) or a simple subst., (Msb,) from fasaqa [q. v]: (S, O, Msb, K:) unless as signifying [simply] A going forth, or a departure, it is said to be a word unknown before ElIslám, and to have become so much used in its legal acceptation as to be, when so used, conventionally regarded as proper (MF, TA:) [thus used,] it signifies a going forth, or departure, from the right way, (K, TA,) which is said to be the primary meaning, (TA,) or from the way of truth; (K, TA;) or from the truth, or that which is right, as in the phrase waUinRahu lafisoqN, (O, K, [in the CK lafasiqN, a strange mistake,]) in the Kur [vi. 121]; (O;) or a relinquishment, or neglect, of the command of God; (Lth, O, K;) and an inclining to disobedience; (Lth, O;) or also disobedience [itself]; (K;) or i. q. fujuwrN [meaning as above; or transgression; or unrighteous, sinful, wicked, vitious, or immoral, conduct]: (O, K:) it is said by El-Isbahánee to be a more general term than kuforN; applying to few sins, misdeeds, transgressions, or acts of disobedience, or to little thereof; and also, to many, or much thereof; but is commonly known as applying to the latter: and it is related on the authority of Málik that in the Kur vi. 146 it means such as is slaughtered: (TA:) [being used as a subst.,] it sometimes has a pl., which is fusuwqN. (TA.)
fusaqN (Lth, O, K) and fisRiyqN↓, (Lth, S, O, K,) applied to a man, Always characterized by fisoq. (Lth, S, O, K.)

yaAfusaqu means yaA OayRuhaA AlfaAsiqu [O thou faAsiq]; (S, O, K;) like yaA xubavu, meaning yaA OayRuhaA Anxabiyvu; fusaqu being determinate, as is shown by their saying yaA fusaqu Alxabiyvu, thus prefixing Al to xbyv: (S, O:) and to a woman they say yaA fasaAqi↓, like qaTaAmi, (S, O, K,) meaning yaA faAsiqapu (K) [or rather yaA OayRuhaA AlfaAsiqapu].

fasoqiyRapN, with fet-h, [often pronounced fisoqiyRap,] a post-classical word, [arabicized, from the Lat. “ piscina, ”] i. q. mutawaDRaON [properly A place, here meaning a tank, or basin, in which the ablution termed wuDuwoC is performed: now commonly applied to a basin, or shallow pool, of water, in the court of a house, or in a room, generally having in the centre a fountain that throws up water:] pl. fasaAqiyRu. (TA.)
fasaAqi: see fusaqN
fisRiyqN: see fusaqN

faAsiqN Going forth, or departing, or one who goes forth, or departs, [from the right way, or the way of truth, and the limits of the law, or] from [the bounds of] obedience; (Msb;) disobedient [to God]; (Mgh, TA;) [transgressing, or a transgressor; unrighteous, sinful, wicked, vitious, or immoral;] mostly applied to one who has taken upon himself to observe what the law ordains, and has acknowledged its authority, and then fallen short of observance in respect of all, or of some, of its ordinances: and when the person fundamentally, or utterly, an unbeliever is thus termed, it is because he falls short of observing the ordinance that the intellect renders obligatory on him and that the natural constitution with which he was created in his mother's womb requires to be conceded; hence the believer is contrasted with him in the Kur xxxii. 18; so faAsiqN is a more general term than kaAfirN; and ZaAlimN is a more general term than faAsiqN: (El-Isbahánee, TA:) accord. to IDrd, (O,) the faAsiq is thus called because of his divesting himself, or becoming divested, of good: (O, K:) the word has not been heard in the speech of the people of the Time of Ignorance, (IAar, S, O, Msb, K,) nor in their poetry, (IAar, S, O, K,) though it is an Arabic word, (IAar, S, O, Msb, K,) and a chaste one, and the Kur-án has used it: (IAar, Msb:) the pl. is fasaqapN and fusRaAqN: (Msb:) fawaAsiqu, [pl. of faAsiqapN,] applied to women, signifies fawaAjiru [generally meaning adulteresses, or fornicatresses]. (TA.)

The five animals, or living things, (AlHayawaAnaAtu Alxamosu, [specified voce HayawaAnN,]) are metaphorically termed fawaAsiqu [as though meaning (tropical:) Transgressors] (Mgh, Msb) because of their noxiousness, (Mgh,) or because of their much, or frequent, noxiousness and harmfulness, so that they may be killed in the case of freedom from UiHoraAm and in the state of UiHoraAm, and in prayer, which is not rendered ineffectual thereby: (Msb:) or because of their being out of the pale of inviolability: or, as some [unreasonably] say, because the eating of them is forbidden. (Mgh.)
faAsiqiyRapN A certain mode of attiring oneself with the turban. (Z, O, K.) One says, taEamRama fulaAnN AlfaAsiqyRapa [Such a one attired himself with the turban in the mode termed AlfAsqyRp]. (TA.)

Alfuwayosiqapu The rat, or mouse; syn. AlfaOorapu: (S, O, K:) so called because it comes forth from its hole upon people: (O, K:) or, accord. to Z, because it does mischief in houses: and it is said in a trad. that it is to be killed: the word is the dim. of faAsiqapN. (TA.)

Oafosaqu [More, or most, characterized by fisoq]. The Arabs say, laEana QllRehu OafosaqiI wOafosaqaka, meaning, AlOafosaqa minRaA [i. e. May God curse the more characterized by fisoq, of us, or of me and thee]. (Fr, O.)
Q. 1. fasokalahu He postponed him; i. e., made him, or asserted him, to be behind, or posterior, or last, (Sh, O, K,) in rank, or estimation. (O.)
And fasokala He was, or became, behind, &c.: the verb being intrans. as well as trans. [unless fasokala be a mistake for fusokila, the pass. form, of which an ex. occurs in the O and TA]. (K.)
Accord. to IAar, a foreign word (EajamiyRap), arabicized. (O.)
fusokulN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

fisokilN The last, in coming in, of the horses in a race; (S, O, K;) as also fusokulN↓ and fusokuwlN↓ and fasokawolN↓: (K:) also called the sukRayot [q. v.] and the qaAXuwr. (S, O. [In a copy of the S, in art. skt, AlfisokilRu is put for Alfisokilu.])
And hence, (S, O,) applied to a man, (assumed tropical:) Low, base, ignoble, vile, or mean: (S, O, K:) the vulgar say fusokulN↓. (S, O.)
fusokuwlN and fisokawolN: see fisokilN.
Both also signify (assumed tropical:) Occupying the hinder, or latter, or last, place [in rank, or estimation: see Q. 1, above]; (K, TA;) as epithets applied to a man. (TA.)

1. fasula, (S, M, O, K,) with damm, (S, O,) like karuma; (K;) and fasila, (M, K,) like Ealima; (K;) and fusila, (M, K,) of the form of that whereof the agent is not named, (M,) like EuniIa; (K;) inf. n. fasaAlapN and fusuwlapN (S, M, O, K) and fusuwlN; (M, TA;) He (a man, S, O) was, or became, low, base, ignoble, vile, or mean; (S, M, O, K;) such as had no manliness, or manly virtue, (M, K,) and no hardiness. (TA.)
And fasala AlSRabiIRa He weaned the boy; (AA, O, K;) as though a dial. var. of faSala. (TA.)
2: see the paragraph here following.

4. Afsl Ealayohi mataAEahu He pronounced against him (i. e. against another man, Lth, O) that his goods
were bad; syn. Arclh: (Lth, O, K:) and Afsl Ealayohi daraAhimahu he pronounced against him that his dirhems, or pieces of money, were bad, or were such as are termed zuyuwf; (Lth, O, K; *) syn. zayRafahaA, (Lth, O, K, TA,) and OarocalahaA: (TA:) and [in like manner] fsRlhu↓, inf. n. tafosiylN, signifies Oarocalahu and zayRafahu. (TA.)
See also what next follows.

8. Aftsl Alfasiylapa, (M,) inf. n. AifotisaAlN; (O, TA;) or OafosalahaA↓; (K; [app. a mistranscription for AifotasalahaA, as it is outweighed by the latter in authority;]) He plucked the young palm-tree from its mother, and planted it (M, O, K) in another place. (O.)

fasolN and mafosuwlN↓, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) as epithets applied to a man, (S, O, Msb,) Low, base, ignoble, vile, or mean; (S, M, O, Msb, K;) such as has no manliness, or manly virtue, (M, K,) and no hardiness: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OafosaAlN, (S, O,) or OafosulN, (M, K,) or both, (TA,) and [of mult.] fisaAlN and fusuwlN (S, M, O, K) and fusuwlapN (Kr, M, K) and fusolN (M, K) and fusalMCu, (S, M, O, K,) which last is anomalous, as though they imagined it to have as its sing. fasiylN. (M.)
Also, the former, Anything bad, corrupt, vile, base, abominable, or disapproved. (TA.) [The pl.] fusuwlN, applied to dirhems, or pieces of money, means Bad; or such as are termed zuyuwf. (TA.)
And fasolN signifies also Cuttings from grape-vines, for planting. (AHn, M, K. *)
fisolN Foolish, stupid, or unsound in intellect or understanding. (AA, O, K.)

fasiylN The young ones, or small ones, of palmtrees, like wadiIRN; (S, O, Msb;) as also fasiylapN↓: (S, O:) [or] the former signifies such as are cut from the mother-tree, or plucked from the ground, (Mgh, * Msb,) of the young ones, or small ones, of palm-trees, (Mgh,) and then planted; (Mgh, Msb;) and fsylp↓ signifies one thereof: (Msb:) [i. e.] fasiylapN↓ signifies [a sucker, or an offset, of a palm-tree: or] a small palm-tree: and fasiylN is its pl., as also fasaAYilu, (M, K,) and fusolaAnN, (S, O, K,) or this last is a pl. pl., (M,) or [rather] it is pl. of fasiylN [which is properly speaking a coll. gen. n.], like as rugofaAnN is pl. of zagiyfN. (Msb.)
fusaAlapN The filings (suHaAlap) of iron: (S, O:) or the portions that become scattered about, on the occasion of beating [or hammering], in the manufacturing, of iron and the like thereof. (M, K.)
fasiylapN: see fasiylN, in three places.

mufasRilapN A woman who, when her husband is desirous of compressing her, (S, M, O, K,) urges an excuse to him, (S, O,) or says to him OanaAHaAYiDN, (M, K, *) and the like thereof, (M,) in order to repel him (M, K) thereby: (M:) such, and the musawRifap [which belongs to the same category] the Prophet cursed. (O.)
mafosuwlN: see fasolN.

1. fasaA, (aor. yafosuw, Msb,) inf. n. fasowN (S, M, Msb, K) and fusaMCN, (M, K,) or this latter is a simple subst., (S, Msb,) He emitted a noiseless wind [or a puff of wind] (Msb, K, TA) from his anus. (K, * TA.) [Hence the saying, fasaAbayonanaA AlZRaribaAnu, or bayonahum, expl. in art. Zrb.]

6. tfAsI, said of a man, He protruded his posteriors: (M, TA:) and tafaAsato, said of the [beetle called] xunofasaMC, It protruded its podex for the purpose of emitting a noiseless wind: (S, TA:) but As says that it is with hemz. (TA. See 6 in art. fsO.)
AlfasaA is a dial. var. of AlfasaOu [i. e. fasFA is a dial. var. of fasaON, expl. in art. fsO]. (K.)
AlfusaApu: see the paragraph here following.

fasowapN [is the inf. n. of unity of fasaA, as such signifying A single noiseless emission of wind from the anus: and] has for its pl. [fasawaAtN, agreeably with rule, and also] fusFI, which is [anomalous,] like XuhFI pl. of XahowapN, which see. (TA.)

layosa lahu UilRaA fasowapu AlDRabuEi [the lit. signification of which is sufficiently plain] occurs in a trad. as meaning (assumed tropical:) There is not any benefit, or profit, or utility, attributable to it; [or rather, it is worse than useless;] the DbE [or hyena] being particularized because of its stupidity and its evil nature: or, some say, it [i. e. fswp AlDbE, and app. AlfusaApu↓ also (mentioned among the addenda to this art. in the TA),] is a plant (XajarapN) like the xaXxaAX [or poppy], from the fruit of which no great utility is derived: so says IAth. (TA.) [See also xamoTN, in two places.]

fasawaAtu AlDRibaAEi is an appellation of Certain truffles (kamoOapN); (K;) a species of kamoOap; (M;) said by AHn to be the species thereof called AlqaEobalu; (M, TA;) and the like is said in the Minháj; and further, that it is a plant of disagreeable odour, having a head which is cooked, and eaten with milk; and when it dries, there comes forth from it what resembles waros [q. v.]. (TA.)
fasaMCN an inf. n. of 1; (M, K;) or a subst. therefrom [signifying A noiseless wind from the anus]. (S, Msb.)
fasuwRN A man who often emits a noiseless wind from the anus; (S, M, K;) as also fasRaMCN↓. (M, K.)
fusayRapN [originally fusayowapN] dim. of fasowapN. (TA.)
fasRaMCN: see fasuwRN.
And AlfasRaMCapu: see what here follows.

AlfaAsiyapu (S, M, K) and AlfaAsiyaMCu↓ (M, K) and AlfasRaMCapu↓ (TA) The [beetle called] xunofasaMC; (S, M, K;) which emits a noiseless wind, and makes the party to stink by its foul odour: (M:) the pl. of the first is AlfawaAsiI. (TA.) Hence the prov., OafoHaXu mino faAsiyapK i. e. [More foul than] a xnfsAC. (S, M.)
AlfaAsiyaMCu: see the next preceding paragraph.

[Aibonu AlfaAsiyaMCi is an appellation of The insect called qaranobaI, resembling the beetle called xunofasaMC, or somewhat larger than the latter, with long hind legs, and with a speckled back: for AlqaranobaI, as the explanation of A, the TA, in art. bnI, has AlqrynI; and the TT, in that art., as from the T,. AlfuranaI: what I have here substituted for these is evidently, in my opinion, right.]
OafosaI mina AlZRaribaAni [More wont to emit noiseless wind from the anus than the ZrbAn, a small stinking beast, described in art. Zrb,] is a saying of the Arabs. (TA.)

AlmafosaI The anus [as being the place of emission of the fusaMC]. (TA.) maA Oaqoraba maHosaAhu mino mafosaAhu [How near is his mouth to his anus!] is a prov. [expressive of wonder at a man's shortness: see maHosFI, in art. Hsw]. (S.)

1. faXRa AlwaToba, (S, A, K,) aor.
faXuXa
, inf. n. faXRN, (S, TA,) He made the wind, (S, A, K,) and the butter, (TA,) to come forth from the milk-skin, or butterskin, (S, A, K, TA,) by loosing the tie round its mouth. (TA.) And faXRa AlsRiqaMCa He loosed the tie of the skin, and opened its mouth, after blowing into it, so that the wind came forth from it. (Mgh.) [Hence the prov.,] lOafuXRanRaka faXRa AlwaTobi (assumed tropical:) I will assuredly make thine anger to come forth from thy head, as one makes the wind to come forth from the milk-skin, or butter-skin: said to a man who is angry: (T, S:) or I will assuredly remove thy boastfulness, &c.: (TA:) or I will assuredly take away thy pride, and thy vanity, or vain glory, or conceit, &c.: (Th:) or the meaning is laOaHolubanRaka [I will assuredly mulet thee, &c.; lit., milk thee]. (Kr.) See also faXaAXi.
[Hence,] faXRa AlnRaAqapa, (S, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (S, TA,) He milked the she-camel quickly. (S, K.) And faXRa AlDRaroEa He exhausted all the milk of the udder. (TA.)
[Hence also, faXRa Alwarama It (a medicament) caused the swelling, or tumour, to subside.] (See also 7.)

And faXRa Alqufola, (IKtt, L,) or AlbaAba, (Mgh, Msb,) [aor.
faXuXa
,] inf. n. faXRN, (IKtt, L,) He opened the lock, (IKtt, L,) or the lock of the door, by artifice, (Mgh, Msb,) without a key, (IKtt, L,) or without its key: (Msb:) from faXRa AlsRiqaMCa. (Mgh.)

And accord to Lth, (O,) AlfaXRu signifies tatabRuEu AlsRariqapi AldRuwni [app. meaning The seeking repeatedly, or in a leisurely manner, after pilfering, or petty theft]: (O, Msb, K:) it is the inf. n. of faXRahu, aor.
faXuXa
: (O, Msb:) and Lth, (O,) or Az, (Msb,) cites as an ex.,
[which seems to mean We have had charge of it, and we will not seek repeatedly, or in a leisurely manner, bit by bit, after pilfering from it]. (O, Msb.)

And faXRa, aor.
faXuXa
, inf. n. faXRN, He compressed a woman. (IKtt, TA.)
And He ate; as a trans. verb. (TA.)

And faXRa AlrRajulu, (S, O, K,) aor.
faXuXa
, (O,) [inf. n. faXRN,] The man eructed, or belched. (S, O, K. [A meaning assigned by Freytag to 4 also, as on the authority of the S,
in which I find it assigned to faXRa only.])
And AlfaXRu also signifies The blowing gently, or softly. (TA.)
And The breaking wind gently, or softly. (IAar, TA.)
And The uttering calumny; (O, K;) thus accord. to IAar, with f, (O,) bayona AlnRaAsi [among the people]. (TK.)
And faXRa Alqawomu, inf. n. fuXuwXN, The people, or party, became in good condition, or fat, after leanness: mentioned here, and also in art. qX, in the L. (TA.)
And faXRa is syn. with faAXa as meaning He gloried, or boasted, and magnified himself, imagining [in himself] what he did not possess. (TA in art. fyX.)
4. AfXR Alqawomu The people, or party, went away, and fled quickly: and so with q. (TA.)
7. AnfXRti AlrRiyaAHu The blasts of wind came forth from the skin, (S, Mgh, *) on its being felt, (Mgh,) and from the like thereof. (S.)
AnfXR AllRabanu The milk flowed forth by reason of the wideness of the orifice of the teat. (TA.)
AnfXR AljuroHu [and Alwaramu, and likewise faXRa↓ accord. to modern usage,] The wound [and the swelling or tumour] ceased to swell, or be inflated. (ISk, S)
AnfeXR Eani AlOamori He (a man) became remiss and indolent in the affair: (S:) he turned back from it through weakness and impotence; like tfyRX. (TA in art. fyX.)
And AnfXR He was, or became, cowardly; weak-hearted. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. faXofaXa, (K,) inf. n. faXofaXapN, (Fr, O,) He was, or became, weak in judgment. (Fr, O, K.)
And He was, or became, extravagant, immoderate, or excessive, in lying: (IDrd, O, K:) or so fXfX fiI qawolihi. (TA.)
And fXfX bibawolihi He sprinkled his urine; (IDrd, O, K;) as also XafoXafa. (IDrd, O.)

faXRN The fruit of the yanobuwt [q. v., a kind of trees, of which one species is said to be also called xarRuwb; but see the next sentence]; (S, O, K;) not mentioned by AHn in the Book of Plants: (O, TA:) n. un. faXRapN: and pl. fiXaAXN. (TA.)

And The [species of trees called] xarRuwb [which name is now commonly applied to the carob, or locust-tree; ceratonia siliqua]; as also faXuwXN↓, (O, K,) and faXofaXapN↓, (TA as from the K, but not in the CK nor in my MS. copy of the K,) or this last signifies a xarRuwbap [n. un. of xarRuwbN], accord. to AA. (O.)
Also Foolish, or stupid. (IAar, O, K.)

And Places in which water collects and remains: and a depressed piece of ground into which water pours and where it remains: (O, K:) so says Ibn-'Abbád: [but] ISh says that hajolN faXRN means [a wide, depressed, piece of ground,] such as is not very deep. (O.)

Also, and faXuwXN↓, and faXofaAXN↓, [this last said in the TA to be written by Sgh with kesr, but it is not so in the O,] A [garment of the kind called] kisaMC such as is thick (IAar, O, K, TA) in texture, (TA,) fine in the yarn; (IAar, O, K, TA;) called by the vulgar faXRaAXN↓; (O; in the TA fiXRAX;) or, as some say, faXRaAXN↓ signifies a thick ksMC; and faXuwXN↓, a thin, or flimsy, ksMC, such as is scanty in the yarn. (TA.)

faXaAXi, like qaTaAmi, [indecl.,] means AlfaAXRapu↓ [i. e. She who makes the wind to come forth from a skin, by loosing the tie round its mouth: in the TA expl. only as signifying AlDRaruwTu EinodaAljimaAEi, which may be a secondary meaning, but is not the meaning in what here follows]. (O, K.) faXaAXi mini Qsotihi UilaI fiyhi fuXRiyhi↓ [lit. O woman discharging the confined wind of the skin, discharge thou its confined wind, from its anus to its mouth, i. e., from end to end], (Meyd, O, K,) which is a prov., (Meyd, O,) means (assumed tropical:) [O woman] do thou with it, or him, what thou wilt, for it, or he, has no means of self-defence (Meyd, O, L, K) nor of becoming altered; and it is said in relation to an angry man who is not able to become altered: (L:) AlfaXRu is the making the wind to come forth from a waTob. (Meyd.)
fiXaAXN: see the next paragraph.

faXuwXN A female slave who emits noiseless wind from the anus; as also faAXRAC [an evident mistranscription for faAXRapN↓]: (IAar, in TA:) [or] a woman from whom wind issues on the occasion of AljimaAE: (IDrd, O, K, TA:) or, accord. to the K, applied to a woman, sonum submissum genitalibus edens in congressu: and also, applied to a man, who glories, or boasts, vainly: but these two explanations are there wrongly assigned: (TA:) the former of them applies to najRaAxap; and the latter, to fayuwX; two epithets occurring, with faXuwX, in a verse of Ru-beh. (O, TA.)
And, applied to a woman, i. q. xalRaAbapN [i. e. Very deceitful]: (O, CK, TA:) thus correctly, with x: in some copies of the K with H; and in others, with j. (TA.)
And A woman who sits upon the jurodaAn. (TA.)

Also, (O, K,) applied to a she-camel, (S, O, TA,) and to a ewe, or she-goat, (O, TA,) it signifies munotaXirapu AlXRuxobi, (S, O, K, TA,) meaning Whose milk flows forth without its being drawn, by reason of the wideness of the orifice of the teat: or whose milk flows forth in separate jets, like the rays of the rising sun, into the vessel, so as not to make froth: and fiXaAXN↓ signifies the quality, or state, that is denoted by this epithet thus applied. (TA.)
And A skin, such as is used for water or milk, that sweats, or exudes moisture. (O, K.)
See also faXRN, in three places.
faXiyXN The sound of a gentle emission of wind from the anus. (TA.)
And The sound of the skin of a viper when it moves along upon a dry, or rigid, substance. (TA.)
faXRaAXN One who opens locks by artifice, (Mgh, Msb,) without their keys. (Msb.)
See also faXRN, last sentence, in two places.
faAXRapN: see faXaAXi and faXuwXN.
faXofaXapN: see faXRN, second sentence.
faXofaAXN A man who inflates himself with lying, and arrogates to himself that which belongs to another. (TA.)
See also faXRN, last sentence.
munofaXRu Almanoxirayoni A man inflated in the nostrils, with shortness and expansion of the cartilaginous portion of the nose, which are characteristics of the noses of the Zenj. (TA.)

1. faXaOa, (O, K,) aor.
faXaAa
, (K,) [inf. n. faXoCN;] as also AfXO↓; He magnified himself; or behaved proudly, or haughtily: (O, K:) [or he gloried, or boasted: for] AlfaXoCu is from Alfaxoru, (Ibn-Buzurj, O,) [or] syn. with Alfaxoru. (K.)
4: see what here precedes.

5. tfXRO It (a thing) spread. (S, O.) One says of a disease, tfXRObihimo, (AZ, S, O,) or fiyhimo, (K,) [and tfXRI, and tfsRO,] It spread among them: (AZ, S, O, K:) and tfXROhm it became common, or general, or universal, among them. (O.)
tfXRO bihi He mocked at him, or derided him. (O, K.)

1. faXaja, aor.
faXija
, (S, O, K,) inf. n. faXojN, (A'Obeyd, TA,) He parted his legs, or made an opening between them, (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K,) but less than is denoted by tafaAjRa, (A 'Obeyd, TA,) previously to making water; as also fXRj↓, (S, O, K,) inf. n. tafoXiyjN; (S, O;) or the latter signifies he did so [much, i. e.,] in a greater degree than is denoted by the former verb: (TA:) [and faXaHa and fXRH signify the same:] and tfXRj↓ [likewise] is syn. with nafaHRaja [signifying the same as faXaja]; (Lth, S, K;) or he did so at the fire. (Lth, L.) And faXajato (T, TA) and tfXRjt↓ and AnfXjt↓, (T, O, TA,) as also AnfXHt, with H, (IAar, O,) are said of a she-camel, (T, O, TA,) meaning She parted her [hind] legs widely, to be milked or to stale. (T, TA.)
And faXaja Eanohu, and fXRj↓ He declined, deviated, or turned aside or away, from him, or it; like faXaHa and fXRH. (TA in art. fXH.)
2: see the foregoing paragraph, in two places.
5: see the same paragraph, in two places.
7: see the same paragraph.

1. faXaHa, aor.
faXaHa
, (K,) inf. n. faXoHN, (TK,) He (a man, TK) parted his legs, or made an opening between them; (K;) like faXaja; both mentioned by Th, on the authority of IAar; (TA;) as also fXRH↓, (K,) inf. n. tafoXiyHN; and likewise with j, as mentioned by Th. (TA.)
And faXaHa Eanohu, and fXRH↓, He declined, deviated, or turned aside or away, from him, or it; (K;) and so faXaja and fXRj. (TA.)
2: see above, in two places:
and see also what here follows.
5. tfXRHt She (a camel) parted her [hind] legs widely; syn. tafaAjRato; (K, TA;) [to be milked, or] to stale; as also fXRHt↓; (TA;) and so AnfXHt↓. (K.)
And tfXRH jaAriyatahu He compressed his young woman. (K.)
7: see the next preceding paragraph.
faXaAHi, [indecl.,] like qaTaAmi, The DabuE [or hyena, or female hyena]. (K.)

1. faXagahu, (S, O, K,) aor.
faXaga
, (K,) inf. n. faXogN, (TA,) It overspread it and covered it; (S, O, K;) as also fXRghu↓, (K,) inf. n. tafoXiygN. (TA.) And faXagato said of the naASiyap [or forelock (of a horse)], and of the quSRap [which has the same, or a similar, meaning], It covered the eye. (TA.) And faXaga It (a thing) was, or became, wide and spreading; as also AnfXg↓: and tafaXRagato↓ said of the gurRap [or blaze on a horse's forehead] is like faXagato [signifying it was wide and spreading]. (TA.) [See also 5.]

faXagahu biAlsRawoTi, (S, O, TA,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He set upon him, or assailed him, or struck him, with the whip, syn. EalaAhu bihi, (S, O, TA,) and Darabahu bihi; (TA;) and biAlsRawoTi AfXghu↓ signifies in like manner he struck him with the whip; (S;) or so AlsRawoTa AfXghu↓. (O, K.)
2: see 1, first sentence.
[Hence,] fXRghu AlnRawomu, inf. n. tafoXiygN, Sleep came upon him and overpowered him; (As, O, K, * TA;) and rendered him heavy, lazy, or torpid. (O, TA.)
4: see 1, last sentence.
5. tfXRghA, said of the he-camel, He overcame her, and mounted upon her; namely, the she-camel. (O.)
And in like manner, tfXRghu, said of debt, (O,) It overcame him, and lay as a burden upon him. (O, K.)

And, said of hoariness, i. q. tXyREhu and tXyRmhu and tsnRmhu [i. e. It became abundant upon him, and spread]: (IAar, TA:) or tfXRE fiyhi said of hoariness, or of the blood, it spread in him, and became abundant: (K:) or this, said of hoariness, it became abundant in him, and spread: and, said of the blood, it overcame him, and pervaded his body. (S, O.) See also 1. tfXRE Alwaladu, occurring in a trad., means Children were, or became, numerous. (O.) And in another trad. occur the words, maA hecihi AlfutoyaA AlRatiI qado tafaXRagato, meaning [What is this judicial decision] that has spread abroad? (O: [and the like is said in the Mgh, in which the verb thus used is said to be from faXaAgN signifying a certain plant:]) but this is differently related; some saying thus; and some, tXgRft [q. v.]; and some tXERft [app. a mistranscription, perhaps for XaEabota, q. v.]. (TA.) One says also, tfXRg AlxayorufiI baniI fulaAnK i. e. [Good, or prosperity,] became abundant, and arose, or betided, among the sons of such a one. (TA.)
And tfXRg Albuyuwta He (a man, S, O) entered among the houses, or tents; (S, O, K;) and disappeared among them. (K, * TA.)
And tfRXg AlmaroOapa He devirginated the woman. (S, O, K: more fully expl. in all of these by the words daxala bayona rijolayohaA waQfotaraEahaA.)
7. AnfXg It (a thing, TA) appeared, and became abundant. (O, K, TA.) See also 1.

faXogapN A [substance like] cotton (quTonapN [in the L qaSabapN]) in the interior of the reed, or cane: and also a substance that flies about from the interior of the SwSlAp [in the O SawoSalRaAp, and in the K without the teshdeed], i. e. the plant, or herb, thus called, (Lth, O, K,) which is the SaASulRaI; (O;) and this is that whereof the children of El-' Irák eat the interior. (TA.)
And The [species of convolvulus called] labolaAb [q. v.], (K, TA,) which mounts upon trees, and twines upon them. (TA.)

faXaAgN, (S, [thus written in my copies and others also,] and so in the Mgh,) or fuXaAgN↓ and fuXRaAgN↓, (O, K, said in the former to be like SuraAxN and mukRaMCN, and in the K to be like guraAbN and also with teshdeed,) thus accord. to IB on the authority of Az, and thus also accord. to Hr, but mentioned by Z as with the unpointed E, (TA,) A certain plant, (S, Mgh, O, K,) [said by Golius to be the rough smilax,] that spreads, (S, K,) or mounts, (Mgh, O,) and twines, upon trees, (S, Mgh, O, K,) and mars them, (O, K, [in some copies of the latter of which it is mentioned in two places,]) and has no leaves [?]. (Mgh.)
fuXaAgN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Also A piece of hide, or leather, with which a skin for water or milk is patched. (O, K.)
fuXRaAgN: see faXaAgN.
naASiyapN faAXigapN: see the following paragraph.
OafoXagu A ram (K) whose horns go this way and that [app. meaning widely, or dissimilarly]. (O, K.)
And naASiyapN faXogaMC A spreading forelock [of a horse]; (S, O, K;) as also faAXigapN↓. (O, K.)

And rajulN OafoXagu AlvRaniyRapi A man having the fore tooth projecting. (Lth, O, K.) And OafoXagu AlOasonaAni Having the teeth disparted; (Lth, O, K;) having wide interstices between the teeth. (Lth, O.)

1. faXila, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor
faXala
, (O, Msb, K,) inf. n. faXalN; (S, O, Msb;) a verb of which exs. occur in the Kur iii. 118 and viii. 48; and faXala, aor.
faXula
; and faXala, aor.
faXila
; two dial. vars., the former of these agreeable with a reading of the latter verse of the Kur-án, and the latter agreeable with a reading of the same verse by El- Hasan El-Basree; (O;) He was, or became, cowardly, (S, O, Msb, K,) and weak, (O, K,) or weak-hearted, (Msb,) and flagging, remiss, or languid, (K,) and timorous. (TA.)

faXalato, and faXalato mifoXalahaA, (O,) or faXalato fiXolahaA, (K, * TA, [in the CK faXRalatohu↓, the pronoun relating to AlfiXol,]) inf. n. faXolN; (TA;) and AifotaXalatohu↓, (O, K, * TA,) thus accord. to the M as well as the O, (TA,) i. e. mifoXalahaA, (O,) or fiXolahaA; (TA;) [in the K AifotaXalato alone, i. e. without any complement, as though it were intrans.; or AfXlt↓, which is said in the TA to be the reading in the copies of the K, but which I have not found in any;] and tfXRlt↓ [mentioned without any complement, as though intrans.]; (K, TA;) said of a woman, (O, K, TA,) in relation to the fiXol, (K,) which is also called mifoXal, (IAar, O,) meaning She hung a vawob [or piece of cloth] (thus in the O, in the TA her vwb,) upon the [camel-vehicle called] hawodaj, then put it [or drew it, or the main part thereof,] within it, and bound its extremities to the qawaAEid [or four pieces of wood that form a square frame upon which it is fixed (see its sing. qaAEidapN)]; this being [beneath her (see fiXolN) so as to be to her] a preservative from the heads of the [curved pieces of wood called] OaHonaMC [pl. of HinowN q. v.] and the [apparatus called] OaqotaAb [pl. of qitobN q. v.] and the knots of the cord called EuSom [pl. of EiSaAmN q. v.]: (O, TA:) so says ISh. (TA.)
2: and 4: see the preceding paragraph.
5. tfXRl, said of water, It flowed. (S, O, K.)
And He took a wife (ISh, O, K) minohumo [from among them, probably meaning persons not of his own kindred: see mifoXalN]. (ISh, O.)
See also 1.
8: see 1, latter sentence.

faXolN Weak; (S, O, K;) or weak-hearted; (Msb;) cowardly; (S, Msb, K;) flagging, remiss, or languid; (K;) and accord. to the K, faXilN↓ signifies the same, and one says, rajulN xaXolN faXolN and xaXilN faXilN↓; but [SM says that] this is a mistake, and [incorrectly] taken from a passage of the M, in which it is stated that one says rajulN xaXolN faXolN and xasol fasolN; i. e., with X in both and with s in both; not that it is with fet-h in both and like katifN: (TA:) [I find, however, xaXilN faXilN↓ mentioned in art. xXl in the K, and also, as from Ibn-'Abbád, in the same art. in the O; and as faXilN↓ is agreeable with a general rule as part. n. of faXila, I think it probably correct;] the pl. is OafoXaAlN, (S,) or fuXolN, (K,) or both. (TA.) In the following verse, occurring in a trad. respecting the prayer for rain, (O, TA,) uttered to the Prophet by an Arab of the desert, (O,)

L.foreign: walaA XaIoCa mimRaA yaOokulu AlnRaAsu EinodanaA

sense.s:
by AlEilohizi AlfaXoli is meant AlEilohizi AlfaXoli Mkiluhu wamudRaxiruhu, i. e. AlDRaEiyfi; (O, TA; *) the phrase being like AlXRajarapa AlmaloEuwnapa in the Kur [xvii. 62], i. e., MkiluwhaA: [so that the verse means, And there
is nothing, of what men eat, in our possession, save the colocynth that is a year old, and therefore dry, or that has been laid up for the year of drought or barrenness, and the food made of blood and the fur of camels, the eater, and the storer, whereof is weak]: (O, TA:) but it is also related with s, [i. e. Alfasoli,] and thus does not need any paraphrastic interpretation. (TA.)
See also what next follows.

fiXolN (O, K,) or faXolN↓, (S,) [but said to be] with kesr, (O, K,) A certain thing (S, K) of the apparatus of the [women's camel-vehicle called] hawodaj, (S,) which the woman puts beneath her in the hwdj: (K:) or the curtain (sitor) of the hwdj; as also mifoXalN↓. (IAar, O, K.) [See a description thereof in the latter sentence of the first paragraph.]
faXilN: see faXolN, in four places.
fayoXilN: see the paragraph here following.

AlfayoXalapu The HaXafap; (K;) [i. e.] the head [or glans] of the penis: (S, O:) and the head of any muHawRaq [or penis having a large glans]: (CK: in the text of the K as given in the TA, mujawRaf: [and thus in my MS. copy of the K; but it has been there altered, app. to agree with the TA, as have many other words in that copy; and the former reading is evidently, I think, the right:] some say that its l is augmentative, like the l in EabodalN and in [the proper name] zayodalN: but it may be from some other word than fayoXapN, though this has nearly the same meaning, [or, as is said in the TA in art. fyX, both have the same meaning,] and, if so, the I may be augmentative, which is more agreeable with analogy: (TA:) the pl. is fayaAXilu, (K,) and fayoXalN↓ is another pl. [or rather a coll. gen. n.] thereof, used as such in a verse of Jereer. (TA.)
[The pl.] fayaAXilu signifies also a name of Certain trees. (K.)
[Freytag adds as other meanings what belong to a description of the proper name of a certain water and of hills surrounding it, called AlfayaAXilu.]
tafoXiylN Milk remaining in the udder: (Fr, O, K:) and so tamoXiylN. (Fr, O.)
mifoXalN: see fiXolN.
Also One who takes a wife from among persons not of his own kindred, lest the offspring should come forth spare in body, or weak. (IAar, O, K, TA.)

mifoXalapN The kyArjp [i. e. kayaArijap], (ISh, TA,) which is an arabicized word from the Pers. krAjh, in Turkish qwrsq [also written quwroSaq, i. e. the gizzard, or the crop, of a bird]. (TK voce miXofalapN [which is said in the K to signify thus, and also the stomach of a ruminant animal: one of the two words thus expl. may be a mistranscription for the other].)

1. faXaA, (aor. yafoXuw, S,) inf. n. fuXuwRN (S, MA, Msb, K) and fuXiIRN (K) and faXowN, (Msb, K,) It (a thing, Msb, or a secret, MA, or information, news, or tidings, S, K, and a man's beneficence, or bounty, K) became revealed, disclosed, or divulged, (S, MA, Msb, K, *) and spread. (S, * Msb, K.)
[It (a saying or the like) became common; or obtained extensively.]
faXati AlmaAXiyapu The cattle pastured [at large], where they pleased. (Msb.)

faXato DayoEatuhu, (TA in art. DyE,) or faXato Ealayohi DayoEatuhu, (TA in the present art.,) or faXato Ealayohi AlDRayoEapu, (Ham p. 33,) said to mean His property was, or became, large, or abundant, [or widespread,] so that he was unable to collect it together: and [hence] his means of attaining his object, or his affairs, became disordered so that he knew not with which of them to begin: (TA in art. DyE and in the present art.;) or he took to doing an affair that did not concern him. (TA in art. DyE, and Ham p. 33.)
And faXato Oumuwru AlnRaAsi The affairs of the people became discomposed, or disordered; syn. Aifotaraqato. (Msb.)

4. AfXAhu He revealed, disclosed, or divulged, it, (S, MA, Msb, K,) and spread it; (S, * Msb, K;) namely, a thing, (Msb,) or a secret, (MA,) or information, news, or tidings, (S, K,) and a man's beneficence, or bounty. (K.)
AfXI QllRehu DayoEatahu, occurring in a trad., means God made, or may God make, his means of subsistence to be abundant. (TA in art. DyE.)
And AfXI, said of a man, He had numerous cattle, (T, K, TA,) such as sheep or goats, and camels, &c., pasturing at large, (K, TA.)
5. tfXRI It (a thing) became wide. (S.) And tfXRt AlqaroHapu The ulcer, or sore, became wide, (K, TA,) and blistered, and corrupt, by reason of third purulent matter. (TA.)

tafaXRaAhumo, and tfXRI bihimo, said of a disease, It became much among them, (K, TA,) and spread: or, as in the T, became common, or general, or universal, among them: AZ mentions the verb as with hemz. (TA. [See 5 in art. fXO.])
And tfXRI AlHiborufiI AlkaAgadi The ink infiltrated into the paper upon which one had written, it (the paper) being thin. (TA.)
faXoyaAnN, accord. to the K, but in the book of Az [i. e. the T] faXayaAnN, (TA,) A swoon (gaXoyapN) that betides a man; termed in Pers. taAsaA. (K, TA:) mentioned by Lth. (TA.)
faXaMCN The multiplication by propagation, and the numerousness, of cattle. (K.)

faAXiyapN sing. of fawaAXK, (TA,) which signifies Such as spread themselves, of cattle pasturing at large, of sheep or goats, and of camels, &c. (S, K, TA.) Hence, (TA,) it is said in a trad., DumRuwA fawaAXiyakumo HatRaI tacohaba faHomapu AlEiXaMCi [Draw ye together your cattle pasturing at large, until the darkness, or intense blackness, of, or after, nightfall pass away]. (S, TA.)
Also A sleep which a person takes during a portion of the night, after which he rises. (TA.)

1. faSRahu, [aor., accord. to rule,
faSuSa
, and inf. n., accord. to Golius, faSRN,] (tropical:) He separated it from (mino) another thing; (S, A, K;) as also AftSRhu↓: (S, K:) and he pulled it out, or up, or off; or removed it; or displaced it; from another thing; (S, K;) as also ↓the latter. (S.)
faSRa, inf. n. faSaSN: see 7.

faSRa AljuroHu, aor.
faSiSa
, inf. n. faSiySN, (S, M, O, K,) like fazRa; (S, O;) The wound became moist, and flowed: (S, O, K:) or flowed: or flowed with somewhat, not much. (M.) And faSRa AlEaraqu The sweat exuded; (M, TA;) and so fizRa. (TA.)

faSRa said of the [locust, or cricket, called] junodab, (Sh, O, K,) inf. n. faSiySN (M, O) and faSRN, (M,) It uttered a sound. (Sh, M, O, K.) And, said of a child, (AA, O, K,) inf. n. faSiySN, (AA, O,) He uttered a weak weeping, (AA, O, K, TA,) like whistling. (TA.)
And faSiySN signifies also The being in a state of commotion; and twisting, or winding. (M.)

And one says, maA faSRa fiI yadi I XaIoCN, (IAar, M, O, K,) aor.
faSiSa
, inf. n. faSRN, (M,) Nothing remained, or became permanent, (IAar, O, K,) or accrued, (M,) [in my hand,] minohu, [thereof, or therefrom]. (M.)
2. fSRS AlxaAtama [He set a faSR (q. v.) in the ring, or signet]. (A.)
fSRS biEayonihi, (A,) inf. n. tafoSiySN, (O, K,) (tropical:) He looked intently, or hardly: (A:) or he opened his eyes and looked intently, or hardly. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
4: AfSR Uilayohi mino HaqRihi XayoOF (assumed tropical:) He produced, or gave forth, (Fr, S, K,) or gave, (M,) to him somewhat of his right, or due. (Fr, S, M, K.)

7. AnfSR (tropical:) It became separated from (mino) another thing: (S, M, K, TA:) it became parted asunder, severed, disjoined, or disunited: (TA:) and i. q. Ainofaraja [app. as meaning it opened, so as to form an interval, an interstice, or a gap]; (L;) [and so, app., faSRa↓, aor.
faSaSa
, inf. n. faSaSN; for] faSaSN is syn, with AinofiraAjN. (TA.) And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) He got out of or from (mn) a thing, and severed himself therefrom. (Mtr, in De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, 2nd ed., tome iii., p. 232.) And AnofaSaSotu Eani AlkalaAmi means Ainofarajotu [i. e., app., I broke off from, or intermitted, speaking]. (L.)
8: see 1, in two places.
10. maA AstfSR minohu XayoOF (assumed tropical:) He did not extract, get out, or elicit, from him, or it, anything. (S, K.)
R. Q. 1. faSofaSa He told a narrative, or story, truly; (IAar, K, TA;) as though from its faSR, [q. v.,] and kunoh. (TA.)
And [the inf. n.] signifies The being hasty in speech, (Ibn-'Abbád, 'O, K,) and quick therein. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)
Also He fed a beast, or horse or the like, with fiSofiSap [q. v.]. (M.)

R. Q. 2. tafaSofaSuwA Eanohu, (K, TA,) mino HawaAlayohi, (O, TA,) They dispersed themselves, and took themselves away, from him, (K, TA,) from around him; and took fright, and ran away at random. (O, TA.)

faSRN, of a ring, or signet, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) signifies [The stone, or gem, or] what is set therein, (Lth, M, L, Msb,) of a different substance therefrom; (Msb;) and is also written fiSRN↓, (M, A, K,) thus pronounced by the vulgar, (Lth, S,) but J's saying this does not necessarily mean that it is incorrect, which, as in opposition to what is said by J, it is asserted not to be in the K [and A], (TA,) or the latter form is bad, accord. to ISk and El-Fárábee; (Msb;) and fuSRN↓; (A, K;) all of which three forms are mentioned by Ibn-Málik and others; but they assert that the first is the most correct and the most commonly known: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OafuSRN (Lth, M) and [of mult.] fuSuwSN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and fiSaASN. (Lth, M.)
[Also, Any gem, or similar stone, rare or common, and natural or factitious: and any hard stone cut for inlaying or for construction.
A die, such as is used in the game of tables, or backgammon: and an ossicle that is used in like manner: see kaEobN.]
(tropical:) A clove (sinRN) of garlic; (Lth, A, O, K;) [and] so faSRapN↓. (S and L in art. sn.)
(assumed tropical:) The yolk of an egg. (M, voce muHRN.)
(assumed tropical:) The bubbles of water. (M.)
(assumed tropical:) What leaps, or leap, up, [i. e., the particles that leap up, in effervescence,] of wine. (M.)

(tropical:) The black (Hadaqap) of the eye: (M, K:) [or the pupil: for] you say, Earafotu AlbagoDaMCa fiI faSRi Hadaqatihi (tropical:) [I knew vehement hatred in the pupil of the black of his eye]: and ramawohu bifuSuwSi OaEoyunihimo (tropical:) [they cast piercing glances at him with their eyeballs]. (A, TA.)

(tropical:) A joint, or place of separation between two parts of an animal: (M, A:) or any joint, (AZ, M,) or any place of meeting of two bones, (ISk, S, Msb, K,) except (of) the fingers, (AZ, M,) for the joints thereof are not so called: (M:) pl., in this and all the other senses which we have mentioned, [of pauc.] OafuSRN (M) and [of mult.] fuSuwSN: (S, M, A, Msb:) or, as some say, contradicting AZ, the fSwS are the baraAjim and the sulaAmayaAt: [see these two words:] (Sh, TA:) and ISh says, in the “ Book of Horses, ” that the fSwS of the horse are the joints of the knee and pasterns, in which latter are the sulaAmayaAt, these being the bones of the pasterns. (TA.) One says of a horse, UinRa fuSuwSahu laZimaMCN (tropical:) Verily his joints are hard; not flabby nor fleshy. (S, A.) [And hence, app., from the place in which it is mentioned by Z in this art., the saying,] fulaAnN HazRaAzu AlfuSuwSi [in a copy of the A, HazRaAru; and in the TA, DrAr; but I have no doubt that the right reading is that which I have given; lit., Such a one is the great cutter of joints;] meaning, (tropical:) Such a one is often right in his judgment, or opinion, and in his answer. (A, TA.)

Hence, [immediately,] accord. to Abu-l-'Abbás; or [originally] from faSRN in the first of the senses expl. above, accord. to IDrd; (Mtr, cited in De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, see. ed. iii. 232;) faSRu OamorK (tropical:) The point upon which a thing, or an affair, turns, or hinges; or the point in which it is distinguished, or discriminated, from other things; syn. mafoSiluhu; (Abu-l- 'Abbás ubi suprà, S, Msb, K;) or maHazRuhN: (Mtr ubi suprá:) [or its utmost point, or particular; syn. munotahaAhu: (Msb in art. fSl, in explanation of mafoSilu OmorK:)] or its origin, or source; syn. OaSoluh; (M; and Mtr ubi suprà, and L;) and maxorajuhu AlRacI qado xaraja minohu: (L, TA:) and its essence, or very essence; its substance; its most essential, or elementary, part; its pith; the ultimate element to which it can be reduced or resolved; syn. Haqiyqatuhu, (M, L, TA,) and kunohuhu, i. e. jawoharuhu, and nihaAyatuhu: (L, TA:) or its real, as opposed to its apparent, state; syn. maxobaruhu. (A, TA.) Hence the saying, (S, Msb, TA,) of a poet, (S, TA,) or of Ez-Zubeyr Ibn-El-'Owwám, (TA,) or of 'AbdAllah Ibn-Jaafar Ibn-Abee-Tálib, (Mtr ubi suprà, and TA,)

(tropical:) [And he will tell thee the thing, or affair, tracing it from the point on which it turns, or hinges; &c.: but it appears to be originally without wa; forming an incomplete hemistich: see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 918]: (S, M, * A, * Mtr, TA:) or he will tell thee the thing, or affair, distinctly. (Msb, TA. *) You say also, qaraOotu fiI faSRi AlkitaAbi kacaA (tropical:) [I read, in the most essential part of the book or writing, such a thing]. (A, TA.) And hence, fuSuwSu AlOaxobaAri (tropical:) [The most essential parts or particulars of narrations]. (A.)
fuSRN: see faSRN, first signification.
fiSRN: see faSRN, first signification.
faSRapN: see faSRN, former half.
faSiySN [as an inf. n.: see 1.
Also] Datestones (nawFI) clean, as though oiled. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
faSRaASN [A cutter, or an engraver, or a seller, of fuSuwS, or stones, or gems, for rings or signets]. (TA.)
faSofiSN: see what next follows.

fSofiSapN (S, M, Msb, K) and fiSofiSN↓ (M) A certain plant; (K;) i. q. raTobapN [a species of trefoil, or clover], (S, M, Msb,) a food for beasts, or horses and the like, (TA,) before it dries up; after which it is called qatR: (Msb:) or i. q. qatRN: or qatR in its fresh state: (M:) also written with s: (TA:) originally, (S, M,) in Pers., (S, M, K,) Uisofisoto, (so in copies of the S,) or Uisobisoto, (so in a copy of the S and one of the M) or Uisobisoto, (K, and so, accord. to the TA, in the hand writing of Az,) or UisoPisoto: (CK:) pl. faSaAfiSu. (S, M, Msb.)
fuSaAfiSN Hardy; strong; (O, K, TA;) applied to a man. (TA.)
AlfuSaAfSapu The lion. (O, K.)
xaAtamN mufaSRaSN [A ring, or signet, having a faSR set in it]. (A.)

1. faSuHa, (S, A, Mz in the 9th nwE, and so in some copies of the K as stated in the TA,) [aor.
faSuHa
,] inf. n. faSaAHapN, (KL,) or faSoHN; (Mz ubi suprà, on the authority of Er-Rághib;) or fSRH↓; (so in other copies of the K;) or the latter also; (A;) and AfSH↓; (A, K, Mz;) said of milk, It became divested of the froth, (S, A, K, Mz,) which is the primary signification accord. to Er-Rághib; (Mz;) and clear of its biestings: (A:) or AfSH↓ has this latter signification. (S, L, K.) And faSoHN, accord. to Er-Rághib, signifies [also] A thing's becoming clear of what was mixed with it. (Mz ubi suprà.)

And [hence] faSuHa, (S, Msb, K, and Mz ubi suprà,) [aor.
faSuHa
,] inf. n. faSaAHapN (S, K) and faSoHN, (K,) (tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, good in his language, or dialect; a metaphorical signification from the same verb as said of milk; so accord. to Er-Rághib: (Mz: see also 4: [and see faSaAHahN below:]) or he (a foreigner) was, or became, good and correct in his language, or dialect: (S, Msb:) or he [a man] was, or became, clear, perspicuous, or distinct, in speech, or language: and he (a foreigner) spoke Arabic intelligibly: but this signification seems to belong more properly to OafoSaHa, q. v.:] or he [a man] was an Arab [by birth, and therefore in speech], and he increased in faSaAHap [q. v.]; like tfSRH↓: (K:) and he was, or became, eloquent; (L;) thus used as syn. with baluga [from which it is properly distinct]. (MF.)

qado faSaHaka AlSRuboHu [is said to mean] (assumed tropical:) Daybreak has become apparent to thee, and its light has overcome thee: (K, * TA:) and some say, faDaHaka: [or,] accord. to Lh, faSaHahu AlSRuboHu means daybreak came upon him suddenly. (TA.)
2. fSRH: see 1, first sentence.
Also, (tropical:) He (a foreigner) made his tongue to speak Arabic. (A.)
4. AfSH: see 1, first sentence, in two places.
It is also said of urine, (K, TA,) as mentioned by IAar, but not expl. by him, (TA,) meaning It became clear, or free from turbidness. (K.)

And AfSHt is said of a ewe, or she-goat, (S, A, K,) and of a she-camel, (TA,) meaning Her milk became free from admixture; (K;) or free from froth, and clear of its biestings: (A:) or her biestings ceased, and the milk came after: (Lh, TA:) or her biestings ceased, and her milk became free from admixture. (S.)

And [hence] AfSH signifies also (tropical:) He spoke with faSaAHap; (K, TA;) [i. e. clearness, perspicuousness, or distinctness; accord. to the explanation of fSAHp in the K, and the usage of this verb in numerous exs.; or with chasteness, or correctness;] as also AfSH AlkalaAma and AfSH bihi, and AfSH Alqawola; but when the verb became in frequent use, and commonly known, the objective complement became dropped, as in the case of OaHosana, &c.: (TA:) (assumed tropical:) he spoke clearly, or plainly, (A, * K, *
TA,) to another; (A, TA;) without indistinctness, or without concealment: (TA:) [and] (tropical:) he (a foreigner) spoke Arabic: (S, A, Msb:) or (assumed tropical:) spoke Arabic correctly: (ISk, Msb:) [and] (assumed tropical:) he (a man of barbarous or vitious or indistinct speech) spoke intelligibly. (L.) And one says, AfSH fiI manoTiqihi (tropical:) He (a child) began to speak intelligibly. (A, L.) And AfSH fulaAnN vumRa faSuHa↓ (tropical:) [He spoke Arabic, and then became good in his language, or dialect: so accord. to Er-Rághib, as cited in the Mz, 9th nwE; in which it is said that some, but not so correctly, use these two verbs in the converse manner: or he spoke clearly, or intelligibly, and then became chaste, or good and correct, or eloquent, in his speech, or language]. (A.) And AfSH is also used in poetry as signifying (assumed tropical:) He (an animal not endowed with speech) uttered a sound, or cry, clearly. (L.) And one says, AfSH Eano XaIoCK, inf. n. UifoSaAHN [in this and the preceding senses], meaning (tropical:) He explained a thing. (A, * TA.) And AfSH Eano muraAdihi (assumed tropical:) He showed or revealed [his desire or his meaning]. (Msb.)

Also (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) became clearly apparent, manifest, or evident. (K.) One says, AfSH AlSRuboHu (tropical:) The daybreak became clearly apparent; (A, * K;) the light of daybreak appeared. (S.)

And AfSH AlrRajulu mino kacaA (assumed tropical:) The man got clear out of such a thing; or escaped from it. (S, TA.) You say, nufoSiHu mino XitaAYinaA (tropical:) We shall get clear out of our winter. (A.)

And OafoSaHuwA (tropical:) They (the Christians, S, A, K) entered upon, (S, K,) or celebrated, (A,) the festival called AlfiSoH [or Easter], (S, A, K,) and broke their fast, eating flesh-meat. (TA.) [And said also of Jews, meaning They celebrated the Passover: see AlfiSoHu.]

5. tfSRH (tropical:) He affected (takalRafa) the faculty, or quality, of faSaAHap [q. v.] (S, A, TA) fiI kalaAmihi [in his speech]; as also tfASH↓: (S:) or he made use of the faculty of faSaAHap: or, as some say, [but accord. to general analogy, this signification seems to belong more properly to tfASH↓,] he affected a resemblance to those endowed with that faculty; [or made a show of fSAHp;] like taHalRama as meaning “ he made a show of AlHilom ” [i. e. “ forbearance, ” &c.; in which sense taHaAlama is more commonly used]. (TA.) See also 1, latter part.
6: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

10: [AstfSHhu (assumed tropical:) He deemed it faSiyH as meaning chaste, or free from barbarousness, &c.; namely, a word, or phrase: and probably used in a similar sense in relation to a man: but perhaps post-classical: its pass. part. n. occurs in the Mgh, in art. bnI.]
AisotafoSaHotuhu Eano kacaA (assumed tropical:) [I asked him, or desired him, to explain such a thing: see 4, latter half]. (O and K in art. snH.)
faSoHN: see faSiyHN.
fiSoHN: see faSiyHN, first sentence.
Also (tropical:) A day cloudless by reason of cold; (ISh, T, TA,) or a day without clouds and without cold; as also mufoSiHN↓. (K.)

And AlfiSoHu [or Eiydu AlfiSoHi] (vulgarly pronounced AlfaSoH, ISk, Msb) (tropical:) The festival of the Christians, (S, A, Msb, K,) [namely, Easter,] when they break their fast, and eat flesh-meat, (S, Msb,) after haring fasted eight and forty days, the Sunday after these days being their festival: (TA:) [and the Passover of the Jews; also called AlfaAsixa; thus with s and x; more properly called Eiydu AlfaTiyri:] pl. fuSuwHN. (Msb, TA.)
faSiyHN Milk divested of the froth, (S, A,) and clear of its biestings; (A:) or milk that has come after the ceasing of the biestings; as also fiSoHN↓. (Lh, TA.)

[And hence,] (tropical:) Chaste, as meaning free from barbarousness: applied in this sense to a word, or an expression, and to language in general, and to a speaker, or writer: i. e.,] as applied to a word, or an expression, it means [free from an incongruous combination of letters and from strangeness and from contrariety to analogy not sanctioned by frequency of usage among the Arabs of pure speech; (see faSaAHapN, below:) or] of which the beauty is perceived by hearing: (K:) and as applied to language in general, [free from weakness of construction and from incongruity of works, with faSaAHap (which see again) in the words themselves:] as used by the vulgar, it means in which the rules of desinential syntax are observed: syn. muEorabN: (L;) [and sometimes it means] eloquent; syn. baliygN. [from which it is properly distinct]: (S:) and as applied to a man, [possessing a faculty whereby he is enabled to express what he desires, with faSaAHap (which see again) in languages or] clear, perspicuous, or distinct, in speech, or language; as also faSoHN↓; (K;) but this latter is an intensive epithet, [being originally an inf. n.,] like EadolN: (TA:) [and sometimes it signifies] eloquent; syn. balaygN [respecting which see what precedes]: (S, A:) or munoTaliqu AllRisaAni [i. e. free from impediment of the tongue, or eloquent, or chaste,] in speech, who knows how to distinguish what is good in language from what is bad: (TA;) the pl. as applied to men is fuSaHaMCi and fiSaAHN and fuSuHN, (K, TA,) the last formed in the manner of the broken pl. of a subst., like quDubN pl. of qaDiybN: (Sb, TA:) the fem. is faSiyHapN; of which the pl. is fiSaAHN and faSaAYiHu. (K, TA.) And you say rajulN faSiyHu AllRisaAni (assumed tropical:) A man whose tongue speaks Arabic correctly. (Msb.) And lisaAnN faSiyHN i. q. TaloqN (assumed tropical:) [A tongue free from impediment, or eloquent, or chaste in speech]: (S:) or (tropical:) an eloquent tongue. (A.) And faSiyHN signifies also (assumed tropical:) Any one having the faculty of speech; (S;) [i. e.] a human being; (TA:) OaEojamu meaning that which is “ destitute of the faculty of speech; ” (S;) [i. e.] “ a beast; ” as also SaAmtN: whence the saying, lahu maAlN faSiyHN waSaAmitN (tropical:) [as though meaning He has property consisting of human beings and of beasts: but see SaAmitN]. (TA.) And it also occurs in poetry as meaning (assumed tropical:) Clear, applied to the cry of an ass. (L.)

faSaAHapN, [an inf. n. of faSuHa, q. v.: as denoting a quality of a word, and of language in general, and of a speaker or writer, from the same word as relating to milk, it signifies (tropical:) Chasteness, as meaning freedom from barbarousness: i. e.,] in a word, freedom from an incongruous combination of letters and from strangeness and from contrariety to analogy [not sanctioned by frequency of usage among the Arabs of pure speech; (KT, and Mz in the 9th nwE;) [for] the point upon which it turns is the frequency of the use of a word by the Arabs [of pure speech]; (Mz ibid.;) a word being known to have this quality by its being frequently used by the Arabs in whose Arabic confidence is placed, or by its being used by them more frequently than one synonymous therewith: (El-Kazweenee in the “ Eedáh, ” cited in the same nwE of the Mz:) and in language [in general], freedom from weakness of construction (ZaEofu AltRaOoliyfi q. v.) and from incongruity of words, combined with faSaAHap in the words themselves: (KT:) and in a speaker [or writer] a faculty whereby one is enabled to express what he desires, with faSaAHap in language: (KT:) or goodness and correctness in language, or dialect: (S:) or clearness, perspicuousness, or distinctness, in speech, or language: (K:) and [agreeably with an explanation of faSiyHN in the S and A &c.] it is sometimes used as meaning eloquence; syn. balaAgapN [from which it is properly distinct]. (MF.)
OafoSaHu [More, and most, chaste, as meaning fra from barbarousness; &c.]: in the Kur xxviii. 34, it means more clear or perspicuous or distinct [in tongue] (Jel.)
[OafoSaHiyRapN The quality of being more, and most, chaste, as meaning free from barbarousness: &c.]

mufoSaHN [or as a n. of place from OafoSaHuwA (see 4, last two sentences)] A place where the Christians celebrate the festival called AlfiSoHu [or Easter (A.) [And app. also A place where the Jews celebrate the festival so called by them, i. e. the Passover.]
mufoSiHN: see fiSoHN.
Also Anything clearly apparent, manifest, or evident. (S.)

1. faSada, (S, O, K,) aor
faSida
, (K,) inf. n. faSodN (S, O, K) and fiSaAdN, (O, K,) [or the latter is a simple subst.,] He cut, (S, O,) or slit, (K,) [or opened,] a vein; (S, O, K,) as also AftSd↓. (S, * K.)

And faSadahu, aor.
faSida
, inf. n. faSodN (M, L, Msb) and fiSaAdN, (M, L,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) He cut, or slit, [or opened,] it, namely, a vein, (M, L.) [And app., accord. to
the Msb, He bled him by opening a vein; agreeably with what here follows.] And one says also, faSada AlnRaAqapa He slit [or opened] a vein of the she-camel to draw forth the blood therefrom and to drink it [or to put it in a gut and broil it: see faSiydN]. (M L.)

lamo yuHoramo mano fuSoda lahu He has not been denied the entertainment of a guest for whom a camel has been bled by the slitting [or opening] of a vein and who has had the blood so obtained, (M, A, * K,) is a prov.; (S, M, A, O;) fuSoda being for fuSida, (S, M, O, K,) like Duroba for Duriba, and qutola for qutila; (M;) and some, also, say fuzoda; (S, M, O, K;) for every quiescent S before d may be changed into z; and every movent S before d may have somewhat of the sound of z given to it, (S, M, O,) but may not in this case be altogether changed into z; so that for Sadara and Sadafa you may not say zadara and zadafa: (M:) some, also, say mano quSida lahu, with q, meaning mano OuEoTiIa qaSodFA i. e. [who has been given] a little: (S, O, K:) the origin of the saying was this: two men passed the night at the abode of an Arab of the desert, and, meeting in the morning, one of them asked his companion respecting the entertainment given by the host, and the latter answered, “ I was not entertained as a guest, but only a vein [of a camel] was slit [or opened] to draw blood for me; ” whereupon the other replied in the words above: (O, K:) or a man used to entertain another as his guest in a time of scarcity, and, having no food to offer him, and being unwilling to slaughter his camel, bled it by slitting [or opening] a vein, and heated the blood that came forth, for his guest, until it became thick, and gave it to him to eat; and hence this prov.: (M, L:) it is applied to him who has obtained a part of that which he wanted. (Yaakoob, M, O, L, K.) [See faSiydN.]

One says also, faSada lahu EaTaMCF, (O, L, K,) aor.
faSida
, inf. n. faSodN, (L,) meaning He apportioned to him a gift, or stipend, and caused it to be transmitted to him. (O, L, K.)

entry.xml:id: raOayotu fiI AlOaroDi tafoSiydFA mina AlsRayoli

form.orth: raOayotu fiI AlOaroDi tafoSiydFA mina AlsRayoli

sense.s: 2. raOayotu fiI AlOaroDi tafoSiydFA mina AlsRayoli means I saw, in the ground, a cleft, or furrowed, state, resulting from the torrent. (ISh, O, L, K. * [Here tafoSiydFA is a pass. inf. n., used as a subst.])
And tafoSiydN, also, signifies The macerating [a thing] with a little water. (ADk, O, K.)
4. AfSd AlXRajaru, and AnfSd↓, The trees opened their gems, (M, K,) and disclosed the extremities of their leaves. (M.)

5: see 7. [Hence,] tfSRd jabiynuhu EaraqFA His jbyn [i. e. forehead, or side of the forehead,] flowed with sweat: (M, O:) the last word is here put in the accus. case as a specificative; and has the force of an agent; the meaning being, the sweat of his jbyn flowed. (M.)
7: see 4.
Also, and tfSRd↓, It flowed: (S, O:) or both signify it flowed in small quantity; said of blood. (A.)
See also what next follows.
8: He (a man) had his vein cut [or opened; i. e. he had blood taken from him by the opening of a vein; and so AnfSd↓ as used in the present day]. (Lth, L, Msb. *)
See also 1, first sentence.
fuSodapN: see faSiydapN.
fiSaAdN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]: (M, O, L, K:) or a simple subst. [signifying The act of bleeding by opening a vein]. (Msb.)
faSiydN and mafoSuwdN↓ A vein slit [or opened]. (M, K.)
And both signify also A man bled by the opening of a vein. (TK.)

Also, the former, Blood (S, M, O, L, K) obtained by the cutting [or opening] of a vein (S, O, L) of a camel, (L,) and put into a gut, (S, M, O, K,) in the Time of Ignorance, (M,) and broiled: (S, M, K:) the Arabs in the Time of Ignorance used to eat it, (M, A, * L,) and to give it to the guest to eat, in a season of dearth. (S, O, * L.)
faSiydapN Dates kneaded and mixed with blood; (Ibn-Kuthweh, O, L, K;) as also fuSodapN↓; (O, K;) thus termed by Ibn-'Abbád: (O:) a medicine given to children. (Ibn-Kuthweh, O, L.)
faSRaAdN A phlebotomist, or bleeder. (MA. [See also what next follows.])
faASidN [Bleeding, or (like faSRaAdN) one who bleeds, by opening a vein]. (Msb.)
And AlfaASidaAni signifies The place [or the two places] of the running of the tears upon the cheek. (O.)
AiEoSibo mafoSidahu [Bind thou his place of bloodletting]. (A.)
mifoSadN [A lancet;] the instrument with which a vein is slit [or opened]. (O, Msb, K.)
mafoSuwdN: see faSiydN.
mutafaSRidN: see what follows.
munofaSidN and mutafaSRidN↓ Flowing; (M, K;) running: (K:) [or flowing in small quantity: see 7.]

1. faSaEa, aor.
faSaEa
, (Lth, O, K,) inf. n. faSoEN, (Lth, S, O,) He squeezed, or pressed, a fresh ripe date, (Lth, S, O, K,) with his two fingers [or his thumb and a finger], (Lth, O,) so that it should become divested of its skin; (Lth, S, O;) and in like manner, a fig: (Lth, O:) or he made it (i. e. a fresh ripe date) to come forth from its skin, (A'Obeyd, O,) [to which SM adds, as from A' Obeyd,] in order that it might ripen quickly. (TA.) The act thus explained is forbidden in a trad.; [but I have not found for what reason.] (S, O.)
And He rubbed a thing with his two fingers, (in the K, erroneously, with his finger, TA,) in order that it might become soft, and open so as to disclose what was in it. (IDrd, O, K, TA.)
And He pulled or stripped, or put off, [a garment or the like]. (O, TA.) You say, faSaEa EimaAmatahu (O, K,) Eano raOosihi (K) He removed, or took off, his turban from his head. (O, K.)
Said of a boy [not yet circumcised], He withdrew his prepuce from his glans; and so AftSE↓. (S, O, K.)
faSaEato said of a mare; She disclosed and concealed alternately her vulva on the occasion of staling. (Ibn-' Abbád, O, K.)

faSaEa liI bikacaA, (K,) inf. n. faSoEN, (TA,) He gave to me such a thing: (K:) [or] liI biHaqRiI fSRE↓, inf. n. tafoSiyEN, he gave to me my right, or due: (Ibn-' Abbád, O:) and faSaEa lahu biQlomaAli he gave to him the property; as also fSRE↓. (K.)
2. faSRaEotuhu mino kacaA, inf. n. tafoSiyEN, I made it to go, or come, forth from such a thing. (IAar, S, L, TA.)
See also 1, last sentence, in two places.

Accord. to Lth, fSRE, inf. n. as above, is also used in relation to a stink, and the ordure of a child, and a noiseless emission of wind from the anus: (O:) [or] it means He emitted wind from the anus with a sound: or without a sound. (K.)
7. AnfSE It went, or came, forth from a thing; or was made to do so; quasi-pass. of faSRaEotuhu mino kacaA (S.)

8. AifotaSaEotu minohu HaqRiI I took from him my right, or due, (O, K, *) all of it, (K,) by force, (O, K,) not leaving of it anything: (O:) or I took from him my right, or due, all of it, on the spot. (S, O.)
See also 1, latter half.

fuSoEapN The prepuce of a boy, (IDrd, T, O, K, TA,) when it is wide, so that the glans protrudes from it, (IDrd, O, K, TA,) or when he withdraws it from over the glans, before he is circumcised. (T, TA.)
faSoEaAnu Having the head always uncovered, by reason of heat and inflammation. (IAar, O, K.)
OafoSaEu A boy having the prepuce appearing (S, O, K) withdrawn from the glans. (S, O.)
And AlfaSoEaMCu [fem. of AlOafoSaEu] signifies AlfaOorapu [app. as n. un., or fem., of AlfaOoru q. v.; but it may here have some other of the meanings expl. in art. fOr]. (IAar, K.)

1. faSala, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) aor.
faSila
, inf. n. faSolN, (M, Msb, K,) He separated, or divided, (S, O, Msb, K,) and put apart, (Msb,) a thing, (S, O, Msb, *) Eano gayorihi [from another thing], (Msb,) and baEoDahu mino baEoDK [or Eano baEoDK i. e. part thereof from part]. (M and TA in art. myz.) And (K,) He made a separation, or partition, (M, K, TA,) bayonahumaA (M, TA *) i. e. between them two, meaning, two things, making it known that the former had come to an end: so says Er-Rághib: (TA:) and faSala AlHadRu bayona AlOaroDayoni, [aor. and] inf. n. as above, The limit, or boundary, made, or formed, a separation between the two lands: (Msb:) and faSalotu bayona Alqawomi I made a division, or separation, between, or among, the people, or party. (O.)

[Hence,] faSala AlrRDiyEa Eano OumRihi, (S, Mgh, O,) or Almawoluwda (M, K) Eani AlrRaDaAEi, (M,) aor. as above,
(M, K,) inf. n. fiSaAlN, (S, O,) or faSolN, and the former is a simple subst., (M, K,) or both, (Mgh,) He weaned [the suckling from his mother, or the young infant from sucking the breast]; (S, M, Mgh, O, K;) as also AftSlhu↓: (S, M, O:) or faSalati AlmaroOapu raDiyEahaA, inf. n. faSolN, and fiSaAlN is the subst., the woman weaned her suckling. (Msb.)

Hence also, i. e. from faSala as first expl. above, faSolu AlxuSuwmaAti The deciding of litigations, altercations, or disputes: like faSolu AlxiTaAbi: (Msb:) or this latter means distinct, or plain speech; which he to whom it is addressed distinctly, or plainly, understands; which is not confused, or dubious, to him: (Ksh in explanation of it in the Kur xxxviii. 19, and Mgh:) or such as decides, or distinguishes, between what is true and what is false, (Ksh ibid., Mgh, O, K,) and what is sound and what is corrupt, (Ksh, Mgh,) and what is correct and what is erroneous: (Ksh:) or such as decides the judgment, or judicial sentence: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the evidence, or proof, that is obligatory [as a condition of his justification] upon the claimant, or plaintiff, and the oath that is obligatory [in like manner] upon him against whom the claim, or plaint, is urged; (Ksh, O, K; [an explanation of which a part is dropped in the CK;]) thus accord. to 'Alee: (Ksh:) or the [using of the] phrase OamRaA baEodu. (Ksh, O, K. [Respecting this phrase, and for other explanations, see 3 in art xTb.]) kalimapu AlfaSoli in the Kur xlii. 20 means The sentence of God's deciding between mankind on the day of resurrection, (O,) which is called yawomu AlfaSoli. (TA.) And AlfaSolu [alone] means The deciding judicially between what is true and what is false; (M, O, K;) and, (O, K,) sometimes, (O,) so AlfayoSalu↓; (S, O, K;) or this latter is [a simple subst, i. e.,] a name for such decision; (TA;) and is also an epithet [expl. below]. (M, O, K.) hecaA yawomu QldRiyni hecaA yawomu QlofaSoli, in the Kur xxxvii. 20 and 21, means [This is the day of requital:] this is the day wherein a decision, or a distinction, shall be made (yufoSalu fiyhi) between the doer of good and the doer of evil, and every one shall be requited for his work and with that wherewith God will favour his servant the Muslim. (M.) And UinRa rabRaka huwa yafoSilu bayonahumo yawoma QloqiyaAmapi fiymaA kaAnuwA fiyhi yaxotalifuwna, in the Kur xxxii. 25, means [Verily thy Lord] He shall decide [between them], and distinguish what is true from what is false, [on the day of resurrection,] by distinguishing the speaker of what is true from the speaker of what is false, in respect of that wherein they used to disagree, of what concerned religion. (Bd.) And one says also faSala AlHukoma [He decided the judgment, or judicial sentence]. (M.) faSala AlnRaZoma, in the K, is a mistake: see 2. (TA.)

faSala mina AlnRaAHiyapi, (S, O,) or mino Albaladi (K,) or Eano baladikacaA, aor.
faSula
, (M,) inf. n. fuSuwlN, (M, K,) He went forth [from the part of the country, or from the town or country, or from such a town or country]. (S, O, K.) And faSala AlEasokaru Eani Albaladi [The army went forth from the town or country]: whence the saying of the Prophet respecting Ibn-Rawáhah, kaAna OawRalanaA fuSuwlFA waMxirunaAqufuwlFA i. e. He was the first of us in going away (AinofiSaAlFA↓) from his house and his family and the last of us in returning to [it and] them. (Mgh.) And faSala fulaAnN mino EinodiI, inf. n. fuSuwlN, Such a one went forth [from my presence or vicinage, or from me]. (TA.) And faSala minRiI kitaAbu Uilayohi [A letter] passed from me to him. (TA.) Thus the verb is intrans, as well as trans.; its inf. n. when it is trans, being faSolN; when intrans., fuSuwlN. (TA.)
And faSala Alkaromu The vine put forth small grapes, resembling lentils or a grain similar thereto. (M, K.)

2. fSRl AlnRaZoma, (M, TA,) thus correctly, with teshdeed, bat in the K faSala, like naSara, (TA,) [inf. n. tafoSiylN,] He put between every two of the strung beads [or pearls] a bead such as is termed faASilapN [q. v., or what is described voce mufaSRlN as an epithet applied to a necklace]. (M, K, TA.)
And fSRltu AlXRIoCa inf. n. tafoSiylN, I made the thing to consist of distinct portions or sections. (Msb.)
And fSRl AlXRApa, (inf. n. as above, TA.) He (a butcher) divided the sheep, or goal, into limbs, or members. (S, O, TA.)
[Hence fSRl means also He cut a piece of cloth for a garment: and he cut out a garment:
whence tafoSiylN means The cut of a garment (See also De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., see. ed., i. 86-7.)]

And [hence, likewise,] tafoSiylN also signifies [The dissecting, or analyzing, of speech, or language: the explaining distinctly, or in detail: and] the making distinct, clear, plain, manifest, or perspicuous; i. q. taboyiynN. (S, O, K.) faSRalonaAhu in the Kur vii. 50 [referring to the book of the Kur an] means byRnRaAhu [Which we have made distinct, &c.]: or, as some say, whereof we have divided the verses by means of the fawaASil [pl. of faASilpN, q. v.]. (TA.)
3: fASl Xariykahu, (S, K, TA,) inf. n. mufaASalapN, (TA,) He separated himself from his partner, with the latter's concurrence; syn. baAyanahu, (K, TA,) and faArazahu. (S and O and K in art. frz.)
7. AnfSl It became separated, or divided, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) and put apart (Msb.)
[And He went forth, or away; like the intrans. faSala.] See 1, near the end.
8: see 1, former half.

AftSl AlnRaxolapa Eano mawoDiEihaA He transplanted the palm-tree. (AHn, M, K.) A man of Hejer [which is famous for its dates] said that the best of palm-trees is that of which the young one has been removed from its place of growth, which young one is called faSolapN↓. (TA.)
faSolN inf. n. of the trans. v. faSala [q. v. passim]. (M, Msb, K, TA.) [As a simple subst., it has various significations here following: and is] sing. of fuSuwlN. (S, O.)
A separation, division, or partition, between two things. (M, K.)

The place of the mafoSil [i. e. joint, or articulation, and therefore of the division, of two bones] of the body: between every one such and another [that is the next to it] is a wiSol [or limb, in the CK, erroneously, waSol]. (Lth, O, K.) See also mafoSilN.

As used by the Basrees, [in grammar,] it is [A disconnective] like EimaAdN as used by the Koofees: (O, K:) thus in the saying in the Kur [viii. 32], Uno kaAna hecaA huwa QloHaqRa mino Einodika [lit. If this, it, be the truth from Thee], hw is termed fSl and EmAd, [more commonly the former,] and AlHqR is in the accus. case as being the predicate of kAn. (O.)
Also sing. of fuSuwl in the phrase fuSuwlu AlsRanapi [The four divisions of the year: namely autumn, winter, spring, and summer], expl. in art. zmn. (Msb: see zamanN.)

And A division, or section, of a bAb [or chapter]; as being divided from others, or as forming a division between itself and others, so that it has the meaning of the measure mafoEuwlN or that of the measure faAEilN. (MF, TA.)

And The contr. of OaSolN [as denoting relationship]: there are OuSuwl of relationship and fuSuwl thereof; [the former meaning the stocks and] the latter meaning the branches. (Msb. [See also other explanations of faSolN as opposed to OSolN under the latter of these words;)

[It is also used as an epithet;] One says
faSolN qawolN A true say or saying: (M, K;) not false: thus in the Kur [lxxxvi. 15]: (M.) or faSolN The final character is unclear in the original text. there means distinguishing between what is true and what is false: and relates to the Kur án [itself]. (Ksh, Bd, Jel.) And it is said of the speech of the Prophet that it was faSalN laAnazorN walaA hacarN, (O, TA, but in the latter hacorN [to assimilate it in form to nazorN],) meaning Distinct, (O, TA,) clear, or plain, distinguishing between what is true and what is false; (TA;) not little are much. (O.)
And A general TaAEuwn [i. e. plague or pestilence] (TA.)
faSolapN A transplanted palm-tree; (AHn, M, K;) a young palm-tree removed from its place of growth [meaning from its mother-tree]: pl. faSalaAtN. (TA.) See 8.

fiSaAlN an inf. n., (S, Mgh, O,) or a simple subst., (M, Msb, K,) The weaning of a sucking infant. (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K.) It is said in the Kur [xlvi. 14], waHamoluhu wafiSaAluhu valaAvuwna XahorFA, (O, TA,) meaning And the period of the bearing of him in the womb and thenceforward to the end of the time of the weaning of him is thirty months. (TA.) And one says, hecaA zamanu fiSaAlihi This is the time of the weaning of him. (Msb.)

fSiylN A young camel when weaned from his mother: (S, M, Mgh, * O, K, TA:) and some times such a young one of the bovine kind: (TA:) [and by a proleptic application,] a young camel [in a general sense], because he is, or will be, weaned from his mother: (Msb:) [in the T, voce HuwaArN,
and in other lexicons &c., it is applied to a young, newly-born, camel: and in the L, voce suxodN, to a fœtus in a she-camel's belly: see an ex. of its meaning a young sucking camel (one of many such exs.) in the first paragraph of art. rjl; and a strange similar usage of the first of the following pls. in a verse cited voce xasofN:] the pl. is fuSolaAnN, (Sb, S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) agreeably with rule, (Sb, M,) and fiSolaAnN, (Sb, Fr, M, Msb, K,) formed by likening the sing. to guraAbN, of which girobaAnN is a pl., (Sb, M,) and fiSaAlN, (Sb, S, M, Msb, K,) as though it were an epithet, (Sb, M, Msb,) like kariymN, of which kiraAmN, is a pl.: (Msb:) and the female is termed faSiylapN. (M, K.)

Also A HaAYiT [or wall of enclosure], (M, O, K,) having little height, (O, K,) before, or in front of, a fortress; (M, K;) or (K) before, or in front of, the [main] wall of a city or town. (O, K.) One says, wavRaquwA suwra Almadiynapi bikibaAXK wafaSiylK [They strengthened the wall of the city by means of buttresses and a low wall in front of it]. (TA.)
And A piece of stone; of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN. (TA.)
faSiylapN A piece of the flesh of the faxic [or thigh]: (Hr, IAth, O, K, TA:) or, accord. to Th, (O, in the K “ and ”) a piece of the limbs, or members, of the body. (O, K, TA.)

And A man's nearer, or nearest, rahoT (S, M, O, K) and EaXiyrap (M, K) [i. e. kinsfolk, or sub-tribe, &c.]: or [some] of the nearest of the EaXiyrap of a man: from the first of the significations mentioned in this paragraph: (IAth, TA:) it signifies less than the faxic: (Mgh, Msb:) or less than the qabiylap: (TA:) [see XaEobN in two places:] or the nearest to him of the MbaMC [meaning male ancestors and including paternal uncles] of a man: (Th, M, K, TA:) [or any one of such persons; for] El-'Abbás [one of Mohammad's paternal uncles] was called faSiylapu AlnRabiyRi: the term is like the mafoSil in relation to the human foot. (TA.) jaAWuwA bifaSiylatihimo means They came, all of them, or all together. (S, O.)
faSRaAlN and epithet applied to a man, (O,) Who praises men much in order that they may bestow upon him: an adventitious, not indigenous, word: (O, K:) [and] loquacious in every place. (MA.)
faASilN [as an act. part. n.] Separating; dividing; or making a separation, or partition. (Msb.)

It is said in a trad., mano Oanofaqa nafaqapF faASilapF fiI sabiyl QllRehi fahiIa bisaboEimiAYap DiEafK, (S, * O, K, *) meaning [Whoso expends expense] such as distinguishes between his belief and his unbelief [i. e. such as distinguishes him as a believer, it shall be rewarded with seven hundred fold]: (S, O, K, TA:) or, as some say, such as he cuts off from his property. (TA.) And one says kalaAmN faASilN (K and TA in art. frz) and fayoSalN↓ (A ibid.) i. q. faArizN (O and K, and TA ibid.) i. e. Discriminating language. (TA ibid.) And HukomN faASilN and fayoSalN↓ [A judgment, or judicial sentence, that is decisive, and therefore meaning,] that has effect; and in like manner, HukuwmapN fayoSalN↓: and TaEonapN fayoSalN↓ [An act of piercing or thrusting with a spear or the like] that decides between the two antagonists. (M, K, TA.) As an epithet applied to God, AlfaASilu means The Decider between the xaloq [i. e. the human race, or these and other created beings,] on the day of resurrection. (Zj, TA.)
fayoSalN: see 1, near the middle. It also signifies A cut, or severance, (O, TA,) such as is complete, (TA,) between two persons. (O, TA.)
And it is also an epithet: see faASilN, in four places.

And [hence] it signifies (assumed tropical:) A judge, one who decides judicially, an arbiter, or arbitrator; (S, O, K;) and so fayoSaliIRN↓: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) in the Expos. of the “ Miftáh ” [of Es-Sekkákee] by the seyyid [El-Jurjánee] it is implied that it is in this sense a tropical intensive appellation. (TA.)
