faASilapN A bead [or a bead of gold or a gem] that forms a separation, or division, between the pair of [other] beads [i. e. between every two other beads] in a string thereof. (M, K. [See also mufaSRalN.])

And [hence] fawaASilu, of which it is the sing., (assumed tropical:) The final words of the verses of the Kur-án, (O, K,) and of the clauses of rhyming prose [in general], (Msb and K and TA in art. sjE,) that are like the rhymes of verses; (O and K in the present art., and Msb and TA in art. sjE;) and [the final words] of verses. (TA in art. sjE.)
fayoSaliIRN: see fayoSalN.

mafoSilN Any place of meeting [or juncture, as being a place of separation,] of two bones of the body and limbs or members; as also faSolN↓: (M, K:) a single one of the mafaASil of the limbs or members: (S, O, Msb, K:) [a joint such as the elbow and knee and knuckle: and sometimes a joint as meaning a bone having an articulation at each end, or at one end, together with the flesh that is upon it:] in a trad. in which it is said that the mulct for any mafoSil of a human being is the third of the mulct for the [whole] finger, it means the mafoSil of any of the fingers or toes; i. e. the portion between any OanomalataAni [here meaning two knuckles; but this is a loose and an imperfect explanation; for to it should be added, and also the ungual portion, or portion in which is the nail; for the word is here applied to denote any of the phalanges with the flesh that is upon it: in the T &c., in art. nml, one of the explanations of AlOanomalapu is “ the mafoSil in which is the nail ”]. (TA.)

And [hence] one says, yaOotiyka biAlOamori mino mafoSilihi (assumed tropical:) [He will tell thee the thing, or affair, tracing it from the point on which it turns, or hinges; (like as one says, mino faSRihi, q. v.;) or], from its utmost point or particular, i. e., munotahaAhu. (Msb.) [This saying may be originally a hemistich, thus:
like the similar saying ending with faSRihi.]
In the following saying of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, [the former half of which I give from art. Tfl in the S, the latter half only being cited in the present art. in the S and M and O,]

L.foreign: janaI AlnRaHoli fiI OalobaAni EuwcK maTaAfili

sense.s: [And verily discourse from thee, if thou wouldst bestow it, would be (like) gathered honey of bees in the milk (lit. milks) of camels such as have recently brought forth, having young ones with them, such as have young ones with them [and] that have brought forth but once, whose bringing forth has been recent, such milk being mixed with water like the water of the mfASl], AlmafaASil (which is pl. of mafoSilN, S, O) signifies (accord. to As, S, O) the place of separation (munofaSal↓) of the mountain from the tract of sand, these two having between them crushed and small pebbles, so that the water thereof is clear, (S, M, O,) and glistens, (wayaboruqu, S, O,) or and is shallow; (wayariqRu;) the poet meaning to describe the clearness of the water because of its descending from the mountain and not passing by dust nor earth: (M:) or it signifies hard stones (M, K) compactly disposed, or heaped up: (M, K: in the former, mutaraASifap: in the latter, mutaraAkimap:) and (M, K) it is said to signify (M) what is between two mountains, (M, K,) consisting of sand and crushed pebbles, the water whereof is clear: (K:) or, accord. to AO, the water-courses of a valley: (O:) accord. to Abu-l-'Omeythil, the clefts in mountains, from which water flows; and only said of what are between two mountains: in the T, the mafoSil is said to be any place, in a mountain, upon which the sun does not rise: (TA:) and it is said that maMCu AlmafaASili means what flows from between the two joints (mino bayoni AlmafoSilayoni) when one of them is cut from the other; like clear water; and the sing. is mafoSilN: (M:) AA says that the mfASl in the verse are the mfASl of the bones; and that it likens that water to the mMC of the flesh: (O, TA:) and IAar says the like thereof. (TA.)
AlmifoSalN (assumed tropical:) The tongue; (S, M, O, Msb, K;) as being likened to an instrument. (Msb.)

EiqodN mufaSRalN A necklace between every two pearls [or other beads] of which is put a bead [of another kind], (S, O, TA,) or a Xacorap [or bead of gold, &c.], or a gem, to form a division between every two of the same colour, or sort. (TA.)
MyaAtK mufaSRalaAtK, in the Kur [vii. 130] means [Signs, or miracles,] between every two whereof was made a separation by a period of delay: or which were made distinct, plain, or manifest. (TA.)

And AlmufaSRalu is an appellation of The portion of the Kur-án from [the chapter entitled] AlHujuraAt [i. e. ch. xlix.] to the end; accord. to the most correct opinion: or from AljaAviyap [ch. xlv.]: or from AlqitaAl [ch. xlvii.]:
or from qaAf [ch. l.]: or from AlSRaAfRaAt [ch. xxxvii.]: or from AlSRafR [ch. lxi.]: or from tabaAraka [ch. lxvii.]: or from UinRaA fataHonaA [ch. xlviii.]: or from sabRiHi Qsoma rabRika [ch. lxxxvii.]: or from AlDRuHaI [ch. xciii.]: (K:) this portion is thus called because of its many divisions between its chapters: (Msb, K:) or because of the few abrogations therein: (K:) accord. to the A, it is the portion next after that called AlmavaAniI. (TA.)
munofaSalN: see mafoSilN, latter half.

1. faSamahu, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
faSima
, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. faSomN, (S, M, Msb,) He broke it (S, M, Msb, K) without separating: (S, M, Msb:) [i. e. he cracked it:] and fSRmhu↓ [he cracked it much, or in several places], (M, TA,) inf. n. tafoSiymN. (TA.) And faSama Alxurozapa [He cracked, or tore without separating, the seam, or suture, of a skin] (K and TA in art. xrm: in the CK qaSama and Alxarazapa.) AlqaSomu, with q, signifies “ the breaking so as to separate. (TA.)
See also 4.
fuSima. said of a house, or tent, (K,) or of the side thereof, (M,) It became thrown down, or demolished. (M, K.)
And waSomN signifies A thing's being cracked. (A'Obeyd, TA.)
2: see the preceding paragraph.

4. AfSm AlmaTaru The rain passed away, or ceased. (S, M, K.) And AfSmt Eanohu AlHumRaI The fever quitted him: (S, K, * TA:) in the K, erroneously. AfSm AlHumRaI. (TA.) And one says, daMCN yafoSimu↓ walaA yufoSamu A disease that breaks and does not pass away. (TA.)
And AfSm is said of a stallion [camel], meaning He ceased, or abstained, from covering. (TA.)
5: see the next paragraph.

7. AnfSm It broke (S, M, Msb, K) without becoming separated: (S. M, Msb:) [i. e. it be came cracked:] and tfSRm↓ has a similar meaning [i. e. it became cracked much, or in several places]. (S, M, K.) You say, AnfSm Zahoruhu His back cracked. (TA.) And AnfSmt AldRurRapu The pearl cracked in one part thereof. (TA.)
And It broke, or became severed, or cut off. (K.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 257], laA QnofiSaAma lahaA (S, M, Msb, TA) meaning There shall be no breaking incident to it. (M, TA.)
And It opened so as to form an interstice, or a gap. (TA in art. XZI.)
fSm AlsRiwaAki [app. faSom, originally an inf. n., but probably, I think, a mistranscription for qaSom,] A fragment [of the stick with which the teeth are cleaned]. (TA.)
faSomapN A crack in a wall. (TA.)
faOosN faSiymo A large [hoe, or adz, or the like]. (Fr, K.)
OafoSamu An anklet much cracked. (El-Hejeree, M, K. *)
dumolujN mafoSuwmN [A cracked armlet of silver: to this, thrown down and neglected, Dhu-r-Rummeh likens a sleeping gazelle]. (S, TA.)

1. faSaIa AlXRaIoCa mina AlXRaIoCi, (M, K,) or Eani AlXRaIoCi, (Msb, and so in the TA,) improperly written in the copies of the K fSA, (TA,) aor. yafoSiyhi, (Msb, K,) inf. n. faSoIN, (M, Msb,) He separated the thing from the thing; (M, K;) or removed it therefrom: (Msb:) whence fSI AllHm En AlEZm [evidently meaning faSaI AlRaHoma Eani AlEaZomi i. e. He separated, or removed, the flesh from the bone]: (TA:) [but in both of my copies of the S, I find faSaIa AlRaHomu Eani AlEaZomi, as though faSaI were used as syn. with tfSRI and AnfSI, meaning The flesh became freed, or cleared, from the bone: perhaps a mistake of copyists; though it is immediately added,] and minohu faSRayotuhu↓, inf. n. tafoSiypN, i. e. I freed it, or cleared it, from it; (S, K;) or, accord, to Fr, this signifies I separated it from it, i. e., anything from another thing. (Har p. 640.)
2: see the preceding paragraph.

3. fASAhu, inf. n. mufaA SaApN, as is related on the authority of Er. Rázee, but accord, to analogy, not on the ground of received usage, means He separated himself from him; left, forsook, or abandoned, him: or forsook, or abandoned, him, being forsaken, or abandoned, by him, syn. faAraqahu. (Har p. 640.)
4: see 5.

AfSI Enoka AlHarRu means The heat departed, or has departed, from thee: but you do not say AfSI Enk Albarodu: (ISk, S, M: but in the M, Enk is omitted in both phrases:) or you say, AfSI EnRaA AlXRitaMCu, and AlHarRu, the winter, and the heat, departed from as; or left, or quitted, us; (K, TA;) so says Az, on the authority of IAar: (TA:) or, accord, to IAar, AfSI Eanoka AlXRitaMCu [the winter departed, or has departed, from thee]; and sqaTa Eanoka AlHrRu. (M, TA.) And AfSI AlmaTaru The rain cleared away. (S, M, K.)
AfSI said of a sportsman, He had no game caught in his snare. (K.)

5. tfSRI, said of flesh, or flesh-meat, It became separated, or detached, Eani AlEaZomi [from the bone]; as also AnfSI↓; (M;) which is said of anything that was sticking. (Lth, TA.) He became freed, free, or released, [and in like manner said of a thing of any kind,] minohu [from him, or it]; S, M, Msb, K;) i. e., from another man, (S,) from his adversary, or antagonist; (Msb;) from a thing; (M;) from debts; (S, Msb; *) from straitness, or difficulty, (S, Msb, TA,) or from trial, or affliction; (S, TA;) or from good, or evil; as also AfSI↓ (K.) And He, or it, went forth, or departed, mina AlXRaIoCi [from the thing]; as also AnfSI↓, and AstfSI↓. (Msb.) OaXadRu tafaSRiyFA means OaXadRutafalRutFA: (Msb, TA:) thus in the trad. respecting the Kur-án, lahuwa UaXadRu tafaSRiyFA mino quluwbi AlrRijaAli mina AlnRaEami [Verily it is more apt to escape from the breasts of men than are pasturing camels, or cattle, from their pastor]. (TA. [In my original, the last word in this saying is without any vowel-sign; but it is not doubtful, as the trad. is well known.])
7: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
10: see 5, last sentence but one.

faSFI, (M, K, * TA,) incorrectly written in the copies of the K with A (TA,) The stones (HabR) of raisins: (M, K:) also mentioned in the K [and M] as with D: (TA:) n. un. faSaApN: (M, K:) of the dial. of El-Hijáz: and they also call the stones of dates fSyp [app. fiSoyapN, pl. of faSI, like as fitoyapN is pl. of fatFI]. (TA.)

faSoyapN the subst, from tafaSRaI as syn. with taxlRaSa; (S, M, Msb, K;) [thus signifying Freedom. or release, from a thing or state;] primarily denoting one's being in a thing and then coming, or going, forth, or departing, from it; (S;) as also fSyRpN↓. (K.) Hence the saying, qaDaI QllRehu liI biAlfaSoyapi mino hecaA AlOamori [God decreed for me, or may God decree for me, freedom, or release, from this affair, or case]. (A, TA.)

faSoypu maA bayona AlHarRi waAlbarodi means An intermission (sakotapN, lit, a quiescence,) between heat and cold: and one says layolapN faSoyapN and yawomN faSoyapN [A night that is, or that was, one of intermission, and a day &c.], and layolapu faSoyapK and yawomu faSoyapK [meaning the same], (M, K.)
faSiyRapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1. faDRahu, (S, Mgh, O, Msb,) aor. yafuDRu, (S, O, Msb,) inf. n. faDRN, (S, A, Mgh, O, Msb, K.) He broke it; namely, the seal (A, Mgh, Msb, K) of a letter; (A, K;) and any other thing; (TA:) he broke it asunder, or into several pieces; he dissundered it; (S, Mgh, O, K;) for instance, the seal from a letter. (S, O.) faSRa AlxaAtama is also a metonymical phrase, meaning (tropical:) Inivit: (TA.) [or rather, i. a.] faDR AlbakaArapa (tropical:) he destroyed the virginity: the virginity being likened to a seal, or this phrase is from faDaDotu AllRuWoluWapa I bored, or perforated, the pearl. (Msb.) [See also 8.] You say also, faDRa QllRehu faAhu, (Msb, TA,) and, accord. to IKtt, OafaDRahu↓, which J disallows, (TA,) God broke, or may God break, his teeth: (TA;) or God scattered, or may God scatter, his teeth. (Msb.) The phrase laA yafoDuDi QllRehu faAka, (S, A.) meaning May God not break thy teeth, (TA,) occurs in a trad.: (S, A:) and J says. (TA,) you should not say yufoDiD↓; (S, TA; [but in
one copy of the S, I find yafoDiD;]) though some allow it: and some say that UifoDaAC [evidently a mistake for UifoDaAD] means the falling out of the teeth from above and below; but the former explanation is the more common. (TA.)

He separated it; dispersed it; scattered it; broke it up; (S, A, Msb, TA;) namely, a thing; (Msb;) or a party of men; (S, O;) or a ring of men, (A, TA,) after they had collected together. (TA.) You say also, faDRa AlmaAla EalaI Alqawomi (Mgh, * TA) He distributed the property among the people, or party of men. (Mgh, TA. *)
faDaDotu maA bayonahumaA I cut [the tie, or bond, that was between them]. (TA.)
faDRa AlmaMCa, [aor. and] inf. n. as above, He poured out, or forth, the water; (TA;) and so AldRumuwEa the tears. (Har p. 57.) [See also 8.]
faDRa AlmaMCu, [aor., accord. to rule, yafiDRu,] The water flowed: (TA:) and AldRumuwEu AnfDRt↓ The tears poured forth. (Har p. 57.)
2: [fDRD He silvered a thing: he ornamented a bit or bridle with silver: from fiDRapN: see the pass. part. n., below.]
4: see 1, in two places.
AfDR AlEaTaMCa He made the gift large. (TA.)
5: see 7.

tafaDRayotu from AlfiDRapu, for tafaDRaDotu, has been mentioned by Sb; but ISd says, I know not what he meant thereby; whether I took for myself, or acquired, fiDRap, [i. e. silver], or I made use of it. (TA.)
7. AnfDR It broke; or became broken; (S, Mgh;) said of a seal, (Mgh,) or thing. (S.)

AnfDR mimRaA SuniEa biQboni EafRaAna, occurring in a trad., means His connections became cut, or sundered, [so that he became clear] from what was done to ['Othmán] Ibn-'Affán, through grief and regret: (O, TA:) but accord. to one relation, the verb is [AnqDR,] with q. (TA.)

AnfDR also signifies It became separated, dispersed, scattered, or broken up; or it separated, dispersed, or scattered, itself, or it broke up; (S, Mgh, O, Msb;) said of a thing, (Msb,) and of a party of men; (S, Mgh, O, Msb;) as also tfDRD↓, said of a thing, (S,) and of a party of men. (TA.) One says, AnfDR Almajolisu [The assembly of persons sitting together broke up]. (Msb in art. jls.)
See also 1 last sentence.
8. AftDRhA He devirginated her: (O, K:) and so AqtDRhA, with q. (O, TA.) [See also 1, second sentence.]

AftDR AlmaMCa He poured out, or forth, the water by little and little, successively: (O, K:) or he obtained the water at the time of its coming forth (S, O, K,) from the spring or from the clouds. (TA.) [See also 1, near the end.]

AftDRti said of a woman, She broke [i. e. ended] her EidRap, (O, K, TA,) meaning a widow's EdRp [during which she may not marry again, nor use perfumes &c., and] which is a period of four months and ten nights, but was before the Prophet's time a year: (TA:) this she did by touching perfume, or by some other act, (K, TA,) such as paring the nail, or plucking out the hair from the face: (TA:) or she rubbed her body with [or against] a beast, (K, TA,) i. e. an ass, or a sheep or goat, (O in art. HfX,) thereby to quit the state of the EdRp: or it was customary with them for her to wipe her qubul with a bird, and to throw it away; in consequence of which it hardly ever, or never, lived: (K, TA:) she used to enter a HifoX [or small tent], and wear the worst of her clothing until a year passed, when a beast or bird was brought to her, and by means thereof she broke her EdRp; then she went forth, and a baEorap [or piece of camel's or similar dung] was given to her, and she threw it: (TA: [see 1 in art. bEr:]) she used not to wash herself, nor to touch water, nor to pare a nail, nor to pluck out hair from her face; then she would go forth, after the year, with the foulest aspect, and break her EdRp by means of a bird, wiping her qubul with it, and throwing it away. (O, TA.) The verb, thus used, occurs in a trad., but, as some relate it, with q and b [i. e. saying taqobiDu instead of tafotaDRu]; and Az mentions that EshSháfi'ee related this trad. [in like manner] pronouncing the word with q and D, from AlqbD. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. faDofaDa He made a garment, and a coat of mail, wide, or ample. (TA.)
[Also, probably, It (a garment, and a diroE and (assumed tropical:) the means of subsistence,) was, or became, wide, or ample: see faDofaDapN, below.]
R. Q. 2. tafaDofaDa bawolu AlnRaAqapi The urine of the she-camel became sprinkled upon her thighs. (TA.)

faDRN, (K,) or faDRN mina AlnRaAsi, (O, TA,) A small number of men (nafarN) in a state of dispersion. (O, K, TA.) And tamorN faDRN Dates in a separate state, not sticking together. (IAar. [See also favRN.]) And HariyrN faDRN Silk scattered, strewn, or thrown dispersedly. (A, TA.) [See also faDaDN, and fuDaADN.]
faDRapN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

fiDRapN [Silver;] a certain thing well known: (S, O, K:) or wrought silver: (IAar, T and K voce tiborN, q. v.:) pl. fiDaDN. (TA.) The phrase qawaAriyra mino fiDRapK, in the Kur [lxxvi. 16], means Such [flasks] as, notwithstanding their clearness, or transparency, will be secure from being broken, and capable of being restored to a sound state if broken, (Az, O, K,) like silver: (Az, O,) being, as Zj says, originally of silver, yet transparent, so that what will be within them will be seen from without; whereas the qwAryr of this world are originally from sand. (Az, O.) [See also art. qr.]
Also An elevated [stony tract such as is termed] HarRap; and so faDRapN↓: pl. fiDaDN and fiDaADN. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.)
And fiDaADu AljibaAli signifies Rocks scattered (manovuwr, in the CK manoXuwr), one upon another: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) sing. faDRapN↓. (TA.)

faDaDN What is separated, dispersed, or scattered; (S, O, K;) as also faDiyDN↓; (O, K, TA;) of rain-water, and of hail, and of sweat: (TA:) and sprinkled: (K:) and particularly what is sprinkled, of water, when one performs ablution with it, (A, O, K,) and what flows upon the limbs on that occasion; (A;) as also faDiyDN↓. (K.) The saying of 'Áïsheh to Marwán, faOanota faDaDN mino laEonapi QllRehi, (A, O, K,) or faDiyDN↓, (A,) or fuDuDN↓, or fuDaADN↓, accord. to different relations, (K,) means So thou art a part [of the object] of the curse of God: (Sh, A, O, K:) for the Apostle of God had cursed the father of Marwán, the latter being at the time [essentially] in his father's loins: (A:) or it means that he came forth in sprinkled seed from his father's loins: (Th, S, * TA:) or, accord. to another relation, she said fuZaAZapN [see faZiyZN]. (TA.) [See also faDRN and fuDaADN.]
fuDuDN: see faDaDN [and faDiyDN].

fuDaADN What is separated, dispersed, or scattered, of a thing, when it is broken; (S, O, K;) as also fiDaADN↓; (O, K;) and fuDaADapN↓. (TA.) You say, TaArato EiZaAmuhu fuDaADFA His bones became scattered in fragments on the occasion of the blow. (TA.) See also faDaDN.
fiDaADN: see the next preceding paragraph.
faDiyDN: see mafoDuwDN:
and see faDaDN, in three places.
Also What is cast forth from the mouth, of date-stones. (TA.)

And Sweet water: (S, O, K:) or flowing water: (A'Obeyd, S, O, K:) or fresh water when it comes forth from the spring or from the clouds: (O:) or water such as is termed gariyDN: pl. fuDuDN. (TA in art. fZ.) And a place abounding with water. (TA.)
naAqapN kaviyrapu faDiyDi AllRabani A she-camel having much milk: and rajulN kaviyru faDiyDi AlkalaAmi a man of much speech or talk. (TA.)

And accord. to El-Khattábee and others, [and among them the author of the K,] A TaloE [or spadix of a palmtree] when it first comes forth: but this is a mistranscription; correctly gaDiyDN, with g (O, TA.)
fuDaADapN: see fuDaADN.
faADRapN A calamity; a misfortune: (Fr, S, O, K:) as though breaking and demolishing that which it befalls: (O, TA:) pl. fawaADRu. (O, K.)
faDofaDapN Wideness, or ampleness, of a garment, and of a diroE [see faDofaADN], and (assumed tropical:) of the means of subsistence. (S, O, K.) [See R. Q. 1.]

faDofaADN Wide, or ample: (S, O, K:) in this sense applied to a garment; (S, O;) and to a diroE; (O, K;) the drE [or shift] of a woman, and the drE [i. e. coat of mail] used in war; (O;) as also faDofaADapN, (S, A, O, K,) and fuDaAfiDapN↓; (TA;) and (assumed tropical:) to the means of subsistence: (S:) also
much, or abundant, and ample: (TA:) and [in this sense] applied to water. (TA.) faDofaADu AlrRidaMCi waAlbadani, in a trad. of Sateeh, means (tropical:) Liberal, or generous, in disposition: or a large giver: (TA:) and rajulN faDofaADN means (tropical:) a man who gives much; likened to water to which the same epithet is applied. (TA.) You say also, jaAriyapN faDofaADapN A fleshy, corpulent, tall, girl. (O, K.) And saHaAbapN faDofaADapN A cloud abounding with rain. (TA.) And OaroDN faDofaADN Land overspread with water from abundance of rain. (O, TA.)
fulaAnN faDofaADapu waladi Oabiyhi, accord. to Lth, means Such a one is the last of the children of his father; but Az says that the word known in this sense is naDonaADap, with n. (TA.)
fuDaAfiDapN: see faDofaADN.
mifaDRapN A thing with which clods of earth are broken; (S, O, K;) as also mifoDaADN↓. (O, K.)
mufaDRaDN A thing silvered: (TA:) a bridle (lijaAm) ornamented with silver. (S, TA.)
mifoDaADN: see mifaDRapN.
mafoDuwDN Broken; as also faDiyDN↓. (TA.)

1. faDaHahu, (S, A, &c.,) aor.
faDaHa
, inf. n. faDoHN, (Msb,) He exposed his vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions; disgraced him; or put him to shame. (S, A, L, Msb, * K.) laA tafoDaHonaA bayona xaloqiki, occurring in a prayer, means Expose not Thou our vices, or faults, among thy creatures: or the meaning may be, protect Thou us, that we may not be disobedient, and so deserve to have our vices, or faults, exposed among thy creatures. (Msb.)

[Hence,] faDaHa Alqamaru AlnRujuwma (tropical:) [The moon put to shame the stars; i. e.] the light of the moon predominated over that of the stars, (A, TA,) so that they were not apparent, or distinct: (TA:) and in like manner, AlSRuboHu the dawn. (A, TA.)

And faDaHaka AlSRuboHu, said to a person sleeping at daybreak, (TA,) (tropical:) Daybreak has shone forth, so as to discover thee to him who may see thee, and to expose thee to shame: (L, TA:) or i. q. faSaHaka [i. e. daybreak has become apparent to thee, and its light has overcome thee: or daybreak has come upon thee suddenly]. (K.)

And faDaHa AlSRuboHu, (so in the S, and in some copies of the K,) or fDRH↓, (so in other copies of the K,) and AfDH↓, (S, K,) (assumed tropical:) The daybreak appeared, (S, K, TA,) and shone forth. (TA.)

faDiHa, aor.
faDaHa
, (K,) inf. n. faDaHN, (TK.) It was, or became, of the colour termed fuDoHapN [q. v.]. (K.)
2: see the last sentence but one above.
3. fADHhu [He exposed his vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions, the other doing the like to him: see also 6]. (A.)
4: see 1, last sentence but one.
AfDH Albusoru (assumed tropical:) The full-grown unripe dates showed in them a redness. (S.) And AfDH AlnRaxolu (assumed tropical:) The palm-trees became red and yellow [in their fruit]. (K.)

6. tfADH AlmurotajizaAni [The two composers, or reciters, of verses of the metre termed rajaz exposed each other's vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions]. (A.) And OaraAduwA Oano yatanaASaHuwA fatafaADaHuwA [They desired, or meant, to give sincere, or faithful, advice or counsel, one to another, and they exposed one another's vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions]. (A.)
8. AftDH His vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions, became exposed; he became disgraced, or put to shame: (S, L, K:) he did evil, and became disgraced thereby. (L.)
And [hence] AifotaDaHonaA fiyka We have been negligent, or have failed of our duty, in respect of visiting thee, and seeking for thee. (A, TA.)
AlSRuboHu AlfaDaHu The dawn that is overspread with redness: (K, TA:) because of its shining forth. (TA.)
See also what next follows.

fuDoHapN, a subst from faDiHa, (L, K, TA,) and faDaHN↓, (S, L, TA,) the inf. n. of faDiH, (TK,) Whiteness, but not in an intense degree: (K, TA: [and the same is implied in the S:]) or, as some say, dust-colour inclining to TuHolap [which is a hue between that of dust and whiteness, with a little blackness, or between that of dust and blackness, with a little whiteness], (S, L, TA,) intermixed with an ugly hue; one of the colours of camels and of pigeons: the epithet is OafoDaHu↓; fem. faDoHaMCu: said by an Arab of the desert, in answer to a question of AA respecting it, to be the colour of cooked flesh-meat. (L, TA.) fuDoHapu AlSRuboHi means The whiteness of the dawn. (TA.)
fiDaAHN: see faDiyHapN.

faDuwHN One who exposes [much, or habitually, or often,] the vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions, of others; who [so] disgraces them, or puts them to shame; as also faDRaAHN↓. (TA.) One says, Alxamoru faDuwHN liXaAribihaA [Wine is a thing that exposes much the vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions, of the drinker thereof]. (A.)
yaA faDuwHu means O thou who act rendered notorious by thy evil character or conduct. (K, * TA.)
fuDuwHN: see faDiyHapN, in two places.
huwa faDiyHN fiI AlmaAli He is a bad manager of property, or cattle; (K, TA;) not taking good care thereof. (TA.)
faDaAHapN: see the paragraph here following.
fuDuwHapN: see the paragraph here following.

faDiyHapN a subst. from faDaHahu, as also fuDuwHN↓, (S, A, L, K,) and fuDuwHapN↓, and faDaAHapN↓, (L, K,) and fiDaAHN↓; (K;) Disgrace, shame, or ignominy; (PS, TA;) a state of exposure of the vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions, of a man: (Har p. 3:) any evil thing that exposes its author to disgrace or shame; any disgraceful, or shameful, thing: (L:) a vice, or fault, or the like; syn. EayobN: pl. faDaAYiHu: (Msb:) [and] a disgracing; putting to shame; or rendering ignominious. (MA and KL; in both of which it is mentioned as an inf. n.) It is said in a trad., AldRunoyaA Oahowanu mino fuDuwHi fuDuwHu↓ AlMxirapi [The disgrace of the present world is easier to bear than the disgrace of the world to come]. (A, TA.)
faDRaAHN: see faDuwHN.

faADH [act. part. n. of 1]. It is said in a prov., AlZRamaOu AlfaAdiHu Oahowanu mina AlrRiIRi AlfaADiHi [Oppressing thirst is easier to bear than the state of satisfaction with drinking that disgraces, or puts to shame] and you say, UicaA kaAna AlEucoru waADiHFA kaAna AlEitaAbu faADiHFA [When the excuse is manifest, reproof is disgracing]. (A, TA.)
And AlfaADiHu signifies (assumed tropical:) The daybreak, or dawn: because it exposes and manifests everything. (Har. p. 556.)
OafoDaHu White, but not intensely so: (S, L, K:) see also explanations of fuDoHapN, indicating other meanings: fem. faDoHaMCu. (L, TA.)
Hence, because of their colours, (S,) AlOafoDaHu signifies The lion: and The camel. (S, K.)

1. faDaxa, aor.
faDaxa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. faDoxN, (Mgh, Msb,) He broke a hollow thing [or the like], (Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) such as a head, and a melon; (A, TA,) syn. kasara: (Msb. K, TA;) as also AftDx↓: (K, TA:) he broke, or crushed, syn. Xadaxa, (S, K, TA,) a person's head, (S, TA,) and a fresh ripe date, and the like; (TA,) as also AftDx↓: (K, TA:) or he struck a person's head [and wounded it] so that the brains came forth: (Msb:) and [particularly] he crushed (Xadaxa) fullgrown unripe dates [to make the beverage called faDiyx]; and so AftDx↓: (S:) or Albusora AftDx↓ he made, or made for himself, the beverage called nabiyc [or faDiyx] of the full-grown unripe dates. (A.)
And He ruptured, or broke, or rent open, an eye, (AZ, K, TA,) and a belly, and any receptacle containing oil or beverage. (AZ, TA.)
And faDoxu AlmaMCi signifies The pouring forth of water, (K, TA,) and of the seminal fluid; occurring in the latter sense in a trad. (TA.)
And yafoDaxu XaAribahu, said of a beverage, (K, TA,) such as is termed faDiyH, (TA,) means (assumed tropical:) It subdues (yakosiru) and intoxicates its drinker. (K, TA.)

4. AfDx, said of a raceme, or bunch, (Eunoquwd,) [of dates or the like,] It attained to the time, (L, K,) and became in a fit state, for the crushing of the fruit and (L) for the expressing of the juice. (L, K.)

7. AnfDx [It (a hollow thing or the like, such as a head, and a melon,) became broken, or
crushed: (see 1:) or] it (a person's head) was struck [and wounded] so that the brains came forth: (Msb:) and it (a camel's hump) became broken, or crushed. (S, K.)

AnfDxt It (an eye) became ruptured, broken, or rent open. (L.) And AnfDx It (a full skin) slit, or burst, and let flow its contents. (L.) And the former, It (a qaAruwrap [i. e. flask, or bottle,]) broke, and became empty. (L.) And It (a dalow [or leathern bucket]) poured forth the water that was in it: (L, K:) and so AnfDjt. (L.) And It (a qaroHap [i. e. purulent pustule, or the like,]) opened, (A, L, K,) and discharged its fluid, (L,) or and became wide. (K.)
And AnfDx said of a man, He wept much, (K, TA,) and shed copious tears. (TA.)
And It (anything) became wide. (L.)
8: see 1, in four places.
faDuwxN Beverage that subdues (yakosiru) and intoxicates its drinker. (L, K.) See the next paragraph.

faDiyHN A beverage (S, A, Mgh, K) of the kind called nabiyc (A) prepared from full-grown unripe dates, (S, A, Mgh, K,) crushed, (K,) without its being touched [i. e. boiled or heated in any degree] by fire: (S:) or prepared by putting dried dates into a vessel, and then pouring upon them hot water, which extracts their sweetness, after which the preparation is boiled, and becomes strong: it is like baAcaq in respect of the legal predicament to which it belongs: but if cooked in the least degree, it is like muvalRav. (KT.) A rájiz says,
expl. in art. bwl. (L.) Ibn-'Omar, being asked respecting faDiyx, said, “ It is not faDiyx, but faDuwx↓; ” meaning that it subdues and intoxicates its drinker. (Mgh, * L.)
Also Expressed juice of grapes. (L, K.)
And Milk mixed with a greater quantity of water, (K, TA,) so that it has become thin, and is white, like DayoHN and xaDaArN &c. (TA.)
mifoDaxapN A stone with which full-grown unripe dates are crushed. (K.)
And mafaADixu [of which it is app. the sing.] signifies Vessels for the beverage called faDiyxu, (L, K,) in which it is left to become [fermented and] strong. (L.)
And the former signifies also A wide dalow [or leathern bucket]. (K.)

1. faDala, aor.
faDula
; and faDila, aor.
faDila
; and faDila, aor.
faDula
; three syn. dial. vars.; (S, O, Msb, K;) the second mentioned by ISk; and the third [said to be] anomalous and unparalleled; (S, O;) [but] it is a compound of two thereof, (S, O, Msb, K,) accord. to the companions of Sb, (S, O,) i. e. a compound of the second and the third, (K,) like naEima having for its aor. yanoEumu, (Sb, S, O, Msb,) and nakila, aor. yanokulu, [but this I do not find in its proper art.,] and HaDira, aor. yaHoDuru, [but this is disallowed by some,] and fariga, aor. yaforugu, among perfect verbs, (Msb,) and mitRa, aor. tamuwtu, and dimota, aor. taduwmu, (Sb, S, O, Msb,) and kidota, aor. takuwdu; (Sb, S;) inf. n. faDolN: (S, * O, * Msb, K: *) all signify It exceeded; or was, or became, redundant, or superfluous; [syn. zaAda;] being used in relation to AlfaDolu (K, MF, TA) meaning AlzRiyaAdapu, as Ibn-Es-Seed says, (MF, TA,) [i. e.] as meaning the contr. of AlnRaqoSu: (K, TA:) or the first of the three, i. e. fDala, aor.
faDula
, inf. n. faDolN, signifies thus, i. q. zaAda, (Msb,) and fuDolN and fuDulN are also inf. ns. [of the same, i. e.] signifying ziyaAdapN, as in the saying, in a trad., accord. to different relaters, UinRa lilRehi malaAYikapF sayRaArapF fuDolFA EalaI AlmalaAYikapi AlmuratRabiyna maEa AlxalaAYiqi and fuDulFA [i. e. Verily to God belong angels who occupy themselves in ranging about, in addition to the angels who are stationed among the created, or human and other, beings]: (TA:) and all the three dial. vars. mentioned above signify it remained [of a greater quantity or number]; syn. baqiIa; (S, * O, * Msb;) you say, faDala minohu XaIoCN, aor.
faDula
; and faDila, aor.
faDala
; and faDila, aor.
faDula
; somewhat remained thereof: (S, O:) or from AlfaDolu as meaning AlbaqiyRapu, you say faDala like naSara, [i. e. aor.
faDula
,] and faDila like Hasiba, [implying that the aor. is
faDala
and
faDila
,] (K,) [accord. to the TK meaning it had somewhat remaining, but accord. to SM,] using these verbs [which are said by him to be like naSara and samiEa and Hasiba, the last as mentioned by Lh,] in the phrase faDala minohu XaIoCN [expl. above]. (TA.)

[faDala is trans. as well as intrans.] One says, faDalahu and faDala Ealayohi, [aor.
faDula
,] inf. ns. faDolN and fuDuwlN, [but see a distinction made between these two words voce faDolN, below,] meaning He, or it, exceeded, or excelled, him, or it. (MA.) See also 4. [And see faDolN below, last signification.] AlfaDolu as meaning The overcoming, or surpassing, in highness, elevation, or eminence, of rank, condition, or estimation, has but one form of verb, faDala, aor.
faDula
, like qaEada, aor. yaqoEudu: he who relates the saying of the poet,

[We found, or have found, that Nahshal (the tribe so called) overcame &c., or have overcome &c., Fukeym (another tribe)], pronouncing the D [in fDlt] with kesr, errs; not distinguishing between the two meanings: so says Ibn-Es-Seed, in the book entitled “ Kitáb el-Fark: ” and Es- Seymuree says, in his book entitled “ Kitáb etTebsireh, ” faDala, aor.
faDula
, like naSara, aor. yanoSuru, is from AlfaDolu meaning the ruling [others] as a chief, lord, or master. (TA.) And faDalahu signifies also [simply] He overcame him; surpassed him; or gained ascendency, or the mastery, over him. (TA.) See also 3.

2. fDRlhu (K, TA) EalaI gayorihi, (TA,) inf. n. tafoDiylN, i. q. mazRaAhu, (K, TA,) i. e. He attributed to him an excellence distinguishing him from [or above] another, or others: (TA:) or faDRalotuhu EalaI gayorihi, inf. n. as above, I judged him (S, O, Msb, * TA) to be more excellent than another, or others: (S, * O, * Msb, TA: *) or I made him (S, O, Msb, * TA) to be so. (S, * O, * Msb, TA.) wafaDRalonaAhumo EalaI kaviyrK mimRano xalaqonaA, in the Kur [xvii. 72, i. e. And we have made them to excel many of those that we have created], has been expl. as meaning that the excellence of the son of Adam consists in his walking erect, whereas the beasts, the camels and the asses and the like, walk pronely; and the son of Adam takes food with his hands, whereas the other animals take it with the mouth. (TA.) And waQllRehu faDRala baEoDakumo EalaI baEoDK, in the Kur [xvi. 73, i. e. And God hath made some of you to excel some others], means, in ability, and wealth, and rank or station, and power; which are excellences that may be acquired. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And you say, fDRlhu bihi, meaning xaSRahu [i. e. He distinguished him particularly, peculiarly, or specially, by it, namely, a thing]. (A and K in art. xS.) And fDRl fiI AlEaTaMCi He gave to some more than to others. (S in art. Afq.)

[An explanation of fDRl given by Golius, as on the authority of the K, (“ i. q. wsx, Sordibus infecit, vel pro sordida habuit, quotidianam vestem, ”) is a strange mistake; app. caused by his finding in a copy of the K AltRafoDiylu AltRawosiyxu instead of AltRafaDRulu AltRawaXRuHu: see 5.

Aisomu AltRafoDiyli The noun of the attribution of excess or excellence is a term applied to the comparative and superlative noun or epithet; also called OafoEalu AltRafoDiyli, because it is regularly of the measure OafoEalu: see exs. voce xayorN.]

3. AlfiDaAlu [and AlmufaADalapu inf. ns. of faADala] and AltRafaADulu↓ [inf. n. of 6 (of which see an ex. in art. swI, conj. 6,)] signify AltRamaAziI fiI AlfaDoli [i. e. The contending for superiority in excellence]; (K, * TA;) AltRamaAziI being of the measure tafaAEul from AlmaziyRapu. (TA.) And you say, faADalotuhu fafaDalotuhu↓, (S, O, K, * in the last faADalaniI,) aor. of the latter
faDula
, (TA,) inf. n. faDolN, (O, TA,) I contended with him for superiority, or vied with him, in excel-lence, (O, TA,) and I surpassed him, or outvied him, therein. (S, O, K, TA.)

And fADl bayona AlXRayoYayoni [app. He made the relation between the two things to be unequal in respect of excellence; i. e. he made the two things to be unequal, or unlike each other, in excellence; contr. of saAwaI bayonahumaA: see also 6]. (TA.)
4. AfDl fiI tijaAratihi He gained; or made gain, or profit; in his traffic; syn. rabiHa. (Az and Msb in art. rbH.)

Eanohu [and Eanohu faDala↓, aor.
faDula
, inf. n. faDolN, (see faDolN below, last signification, and see also faADilN,)] It exceeded it. (K, TA. [See also 1, latter half.]) Ows says, describing a bow,

L.foreign: kaqawosK TilaAEi AlkafRi laA duwna miloYihaA
walaA EajosuhaA Eano mawoDiEi AlkafRi OafoDalaA

sense.s: [Like a bow of which the part that is grasped is sufficient in size for the filling of the hand, not less than suffices to fill it, nor does the part that is grasped thereof extend beyond the place of the hand: the pret. being here used for the aor. to suit the metre]. (TA. [But my original has kaqawomK, an evident mistranscription.])
AfDl Ealayohi: see 5, in two places.
OafoDalotu minohu AlXRaIoCa and AisotafoDalotu↓ signify the same, (S, O, K, TA,) i. e. I left of it the thing remaining, or redundant. (O, TA.)

5. tfDRl Ealayohi [in the CK (erroneously) faDRala] i. q. tamazRaI, (K, TA,) both of which signify He thought himself to be superior to him in excellence; (TA in art. mzw;) whence the saying in the Kur [xxiii. 24], yuriydu Oano yatafaDRala Ealayokumo, meaning He desireth that he may have superiority over you in rank and station: (TA in the present art.) or i. q. Elyh AfDl↓, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) inf. n. UifoDaAlN, (Msb, TA,) i. e. he bestowed, or conferred, a benefit, or benefits, upon him, syn. OaHosana, (S, TA,) or taTawRala, (K, TA,) and gave him of his bounty: (TA:) [and each, followed by biXaIoCK, he presented him, or favoured him, with a thing:] or tfDRl signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (S,) he laid claim to superiority of excellence over his equals, or fellows; (S, K;) whence [accord. to some] the saying in the Kur quoted above: (S:) and [you say] Ealayohi fiI AlHasabi AfDl↓, (K, TA,) meaning he became possessed of eminence. [or superiority, over him, in the grounds of pretension to respect or honour,] as in a verse of Dhu-l-Isba' cited voce Eano, [q. v., p. 2164,] ending with fataxozuwoniI for fataxozuwaniI, [which latter reading I have there given,] because the rhyme of the whole ode requires the former. (TA.)

AltRafaDRulu also signifies AltRawaXRuHu [generally meaning The throwing a portion of one's garment over his left shoulder, and drawing its extremity under his right arm, and tying the two extremities together in a knot upon his bosom]: and the putting, or disposing, the extremities of his two garments, or pieces of cloth, contrariwise, or in contrary directions, upon his EaAtiq [or part between the shoulder and the neck]. (K, TA: but in the former, EalaI EaAtiqayohi is erroneously put for ElI EaAtiqihi. TA.)

And tafaDRalato said of a woman in her tent or chamber or house, She was in a single garment; (S, O, TA;) [she wore a single garment;] such as is termed mifoDalN [q. v.]: (S, TA:) or she (a woman) wore the garments of her service. (TA.)
6: see 3.

AltRafaADulu bayona Alqawomi means The differing in superiority, or excellence, of some over others, among the people, or party. (TA.) And one says, AlOaXoyaMCu tatafaADalu [meaning The things are unequal, or unlike, one to another, in respect of excellence; contr. of tatasaAwaI: see also 3]. (TA.)
10. AstfDl OalofFA He took a thousand [dirhems] in excess of his right, or due. (TA.)
See also 4.

faDolN [an inf. n.: (see 1, throughout:) and also a simple subst., signifying] An exceeding, a redundant, or a superfluous, quantum [of anything, good or evil]; an excess, a redundance, or a superfluity; syn. ziyaAdapN; (Mgh, Msb;) contr. of naqoSN: (S, O, K:) [and often meaning superabundance, or exuberance; and surpassingness, superiority, or excellence. EalaI gayorihi over another, or others, than him, or it: and preponderance:] the pl. is fuDuwlN (Mgh, Msb, K:) and this is sometimes used as a sing.; (Er-Rághib, Msb;) and [thus used] relates to a thing [or quality] in which is no good; (Er-Rághib, Mgh, Msb;) by a predominant application; whence the saying fuDuwlN bilaA faDolK [excess without excellence]; (Mgh;) and hence the rel. n. fuDuwliIRN↓ is formed from it: (Er-Rághib, Msb, TA;) [see this last word, one of the explanations of which shows that a particular meaning of fuDuwlN is the quality of busying oneself with that which does not concern him:] accord. to Er-Rághib, faDolN signifies an excess [in respect of a property or quality, or of an acquisition,] above moderateness; and this is of two sorts; such as is commended, as the fDl of knowledge, or science; and such as is discommended, as the fSl of anger at that whereat it is not necessary: but faDalN is more used in relation to that which is commended; and [the pl.] fuDuwlN, in relation to that which is discommended. when the former is used of an excess [in respect of some attribute, of our of two things above the other, it is of three sorts; fDl of kind, as of the animal kind above the vegetable kind; and of species, as of man above other animals; and of the individual, as of one man above another; the first and second of which three are essential attributes, such that he who is deficient in [either of] them cannot do away with his deficiency and acquire fDl, as, for instance, the horse, and the ass, which cannot acquire the excellence (faDiylap) of the human being; but the third may be accidental, such that the way may be found to acquire it, and of this sort are ability, wealth, rank or station, and power: and it signifies also any gift whereof the giving to the recipient thereof is not obligatory: [i. e. a free gift, or gratuity; and an act of bounty or grace; a favour; a benefit; and bounty as an abstract term;] as in the saying [in the Kur iv. 36], waQsoOaluwA QllReha mino faDolihi [And ask ye God of his free gift, or of his bounty, or (as expl. in the Ksh and by Bd) of his exhaustless treasures]; and in the saying in the Kur [v. 59 and lvii. 21 and lxii. 4], celika faDolu QllRehi yuWotiyhi mano yaXaMCu [That is the free gift of God; He giveth it to whom He willeth]; which comprises the three sorts of excellences (faDaAYil) [mentioned above]: thus says Er-Rághib: El-Muná- wee says, [explaining one of its meanings,] in the “ Towkeef, ” that it is the commencing, or originating, of an act of beneficence without an efficient cause [i. e., app., not by reason of any obligation]. (TA.)

Also A portion remaining, (K, TA,) of a thing, such as food &c., and of water in the leathern water-bag, and of wine or beverage in the vessel; (TA;) and faDolapN↓ and fuDaAlapN↓ signify the same, (K, TA,) or a redundant portion (S and O and Msb in explanation of these two words) of a thing: (S, O:) whence the saying of the vulgar, lilofaDiyli↓ AlfaDolapu↓ i. e. The remaining portion of the wine or beverage [is for the excel-lent]. (TA.) It is said in a trad., laA yumonaEu faDolu AlmaMCi liyumonaEa bihi AlkalaOu [The redundance of water shall not be denied that the herbage be thereby denied]: (TA, in the present art.:) meaning that when there is a well in the desert, with herbage near it, and a person prevents others from drawing water, he thereby prevents the latter from availing themselves of the herbage; for when a man comes with his camels, and pastures them upon that herbage, and does not then water them, thirst kills them. (TA in art klO,) And it is said in another trad., faDolu AlUizaAri fiI AlnRaAri [The redundant portion of the waist-wrapper is in the fire of Hell]; meaning what one drags [thereof] upon the around, by reason of pride. (TA;) And one says, fiI yadihi faDolu AlzRimaAmi, meaning [In his hand is] the end of the zmAm [or nose-rein of the camel]. (TA.) caAtu AlfuDuwli and AlfDuwli↓, with damm and with fet-h, [The thing having redundant portions] is the name of the coat of mail of the Prophet, which was thus called because having redundance and ampleness. (TA.) fuDuwlu AlganaAYimi means The remains of the spoils when they are divided (TA;) such as a single horse, or a single camel (KL.) And by the fuDuwl of women are meant The remains of the menstrual discharge (Ham p. 107: see, there, explanations of a verse in which this occurs.) Hilofu AlfuDuwli [The confederacy, or covenant, of the fDwl, a word which is here of uncertain meaning,] is thus explained: Háshim and Zuhrah and Teym [accord. to the CK Teymà] went in to 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Jud'án, and united in a confederacy to repel wrongdoing, and to exact the due from the wrongdoer; and it was thus called because they bound themselves by their confederacy not to leave in the possession of any one aught remaining [of property] whereof he aught despond any one, without their taking it for him [i. e. the latter] from him [i. e. the former] (O, K, TA: [in the CK, yaZolimuhu OaHadN is a mistake for yZlmh OaHadFA:]) or it was thus called as being likened to a confederacy, or covenant, which was made of old, at Mekkeh, in the days of Jurhum, to act with mutual equity, and to take for the weak from the strong, and for the stranger from the resident, and in which three men, every one of whom was named El-Fadl, joined: and it was also called that of the maTayRabuwn. (TA. [See art. Tyb.])

The saying laA yamoliku dirohamFA faDolFA Eano diynaArK, and the like may be said of other sayings similar to it, means He does not possess a dirhem nor a deenár [or rather much less a deenár]: it is as though one said, he does not possess a dirhem: how then should he possess a deenár? for the negation of that which is much is a necessary consequence of the negation of that which is little: faDolFA is here in the accus case as an inf. n.; the implied meaning being faqada miloka dirohamK faqodFA
yafoDulu Eano faqodi miloki dynaArK [or rather yafoqidu &c., i. e. he lacks the possession of a dirhem with a lacking exceeding the lacking of the possession of a deenár]: (Msb:) Kutb-ed-Deen Esh-Sheerázee says, (Msb, TA,) in the Expos. of the “ Miftáh, ” (TA,) faDolFA is used in a case in which the inferior [of two things] is deemed a thing of which the existence is improbable, and the impossibility of the existence of a thing that is above it is meant thereby; wherefore it occurs between two phrases differing in meaning; and it is mostly used after a particle of negation: (Msb, TA:) AHei says that he had not found any authority for it in the [classical] language of the Arabs. (Msb. [See also baloha, which is used in a somewhat similar manner.])

fuDulN Wearing a single garment, such as is termed mifoDalN; an epithet applied to a woman; (S, Mgh, * O, K;) and also to a man; (S, O, K;) like mutafaDRilN↓: (O, K:) it is of the dial. of Nejd; like furujN in the dial. of El-Yemen. (L in art. frj.)
And A woman proud, or self-conceited, or so in her gait; who makes a portion of her skirt to be redundant [so that it drags upon the ground when she walks]. (TA.)
See also mifoDalN, in three places.
faDolapN: see faDolN, former half, in two places.

[Hence, as used by grammarians,] A dispensable member of a proposition; such as the objective complement of a verb, when the suppression thereof is not detrimental [to the meaning]; contr. of EumodapN. (I'Ak, p. 143) [The pl. is faDalaAtN.]
And The clothes that are used for sleeping [therein]: (K, TA:) [so called] because they are an addition over and above the clothes that are used on various [other] occasions. (TA.)

And Wine; and so fiDaAlN↓ [which see also in what here follows]: (O, K:) AlfaDolapu is mentioned by A'Obeyd as a name for wine: (O:) or it signifies, accord. to AHn, the wine that alters [or has become altered] in colour after oldness; and ISd says that it is so called because the choice, or best, or most excellent, part thereof [for lOnR HmymhA in my original (an obvious mistranscription) I read liOanRa SamiymahaA] is what remains: (TA:) the pl. is faDalaAtN and fiDaAlN [the latter word mentioned above as a syn. of faDolapN]. (K.)

fiDolapN is a n. of the same kind as jilosapN and rikobapN: (AZ, S, O, TA:) one says, UinRahu laHasanu AlfiDolapi, meaning [Verily he is comely in respect of] the manner of wearing a single garment. (S, * O, * K, * TA.)
fiDaAlN: see faDolapN:
and see also mifoDalN.
faDuwlN: see faDolN, latter half.
faDiylN; pl. fuDalaMCu: see faADilN; and see an ex. voce faDolN, former half.
fuDaAlapN: see faDolN, former half.

faDiylapN An excellence, or excellent quality; contr. of naqiySapN; (S, O, Msb;) and contr. of raciylapN: (M and K in art. rcl:) or a high degree in [or of] excellence: (K:) [differing from faADilapN, q. v.:] pl. faDaAYilu. (MA.)
fuDaAlaI [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] i. q. mutafaDRiluwna↓, (O, K, TA,) i. e. [Men] who bestow, or confer, benefits. (TA.)

fuDuwliIRN a rel. n. formed from fuDuwlN as pl. of faDolN but used as a sing.: (Er-Rághib, Msb, TA:) see faDolN, near the beginning: One who busies himself with that which does not concern him. (Er-Rághib, Mgh, O, Msb, TA.) In the conventional language of the lawyers, One who is not a commissioned agent, (Mgh, O, KT, TA,) nor a guardian (waliIR), (KT, TA,) nor a proprietor, (TA,) nor a person of firm judgment (OaSiylN), in a contract. (KT.) The pronunciation with fet-h to the f is a mistake. (Mgh, O.)
Also A tailor. (IAar, O, K.)
faDRaAlN: see mifoDaAlN.

faADilN [act. part. n. of faDala: as such signifying Exceeding; &c.]. One says, maAlu fulaAnK faADilN i. e. [The wealth, or property, of such a one is superfluous; or] abundant, or much in quantity, such as has exceeded the supply of food sufficient to sustain life (faDala Eani Alquwti). (TA.)

And [Excelling; or excellent, as also faDiylN↓, of which the pl. is fuDalaMCu, but which is probably postclassical: or it is] applied to a man as [a possessive epithet] meaning possessing faDol [i. e. excel-lence]. (TA.) [And conventionally, Erudite; or excellent in learning.]
See also mafoDuwlN.

faADilapN is a subst. from faDiylapN [app. as a concrete term, signifying An excellent thing, or an excel-lent action; each as distinguished from an excel-lent quality]; (K, TA;) pl. fawaADilu: (TA:) [but generally] it signifies a gift, or thing that is given: (Ham p. 431, and Har p. 184:) or a benefit, or benefaction: or such as is continual, or uninterrupted: (MA:) pl. as above: (Ham and Har, ubi suprà; and MA:) [or] fawaADilu signifies benefits, or benefactions, that are goodly, or pleasing, (IDrd, O, K,) or such as are great, or large. (K.) And fawaADilu AlmaAli signifies What accrues to one of the proceeds and profits of property, (O, K, TA,) of the increase of lands and palm-trees and the like, and the gains of commercial transactions, and the milk and wool of cattle and sheep. (TA.) The Arabs say, UicaA Eazaba AlmaAlu qalRato fawaADiluhu (O, K,) meaning When the estate is distant, the profits of its owner, accruing therefrom, are small in quantity. (O.)
OafoDalu [More, and most excellent, &c.]; fem. fuDolaI: (TA:) pl. masc. OafaADilu; and pl. fem. fuDalN and fuDolayaAtN. (Msb in art. Axr.)
mifoDalN: see mifoDaAlN.

Also A single garment that is worn [without any other] by a woman (S, O, K, KL) in her tent or house or chamber, such as is called xayoEalN [a garment variously described], or the like of this, (S,) and by a man; (KL;) also called mifoDalapN↓, (K,) and fuDulN↓; (Fr, O, K;) or vawobN fuDulN↓ signifies a single garment, a miloHafap [q. v.], or the like thereof, with which a woman wraps herself (tatawaXRaHu bihi); (Mgh;) and accord. to Lth, fiDaAlN↓ signifies a single garment that is worn by a man in his tent or house or chamber: (TA:) and mifoDalN signifies [also] an every-daygarment: (MA:) fiI viyaAbK fuDulK↓ occurring in a trad. of 'Áïsheh requires consideration [as being questionable]. (Mgh.)
mifoDalapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
mufaDRalN: see what next follows.

rajulN mifoDaAlN and mifoDalN↓ and mufaDRalN↓ and faDRaAlN↓ A man possessing much excellence, or superiority, (K, TA,) and beneficence, and goodness, and liberality, or bounty. (TA.) And (K) rajulN mifoDaAlN (S, O, K) EalaI qawomihi, (K,) and AimoraOapN mifoDaAlapN EalaI qawomihaA, A man, and a woman, possessing excellence, or superiority, [or much thereof, agreeably with the former explanation, over his, and her, people,] and liberal or bountiful [or very liberal or bountiful]. (S, O, K.)

mafoDuwlN [pass. part. n. of faDala: as such signifying Exceeded; &c.: and excelled: and overcome, or surpassed, in highness, elevation, or eminence, of rank, &c.: and simply] overcome, or surpassed: whence the saying, qado yuwjadu fiI AlmafoDuwli maA laA yuwjadufiI AlfaADili↓ [Sometimes, or often, what is not found in the overcomer is found in the overcome]. (TA.)
mutafaDRilN One who lays claim to superiority of excellence over his equals, or fellows. (S.) [See also its verb: and] see fuDaAlaI.
See also fuDulN.

1. faDaA, (M, Msb, K,) aor. yafoDuw, (M, Msb,) inf. n. fuDuwRN (M, Msb, K) and faDaMCN, (M, K,) It (a place) was, or became, wide, or spacious; (M, Msb, K;) as also AfDI↓; (TA as from the K, in which I do not find it;) the latter occurring in a trad., and expl. in the Nh as signifying it became a faDaMC [q. v.]. (TA.)

[And It was, or became, empty, vacant, or void; (for it is said in the TA that AlfDw, by which AlfuDuwRu is evidently meant, signifies AlxuluwRu;) as also AfDI↓, as appears from an explanation of the part. n. mufoDK, q. v.]
faDaA AlXRajaru biAlmakaAni, inf. n. fDw [i. e. fuDuwRN], The trees became numerous, or abundant, [so as to occupy much space,] in the place. (IKtt, TA.)
And faDaA daraAhimahu He did not put his dirhems, or money, into the purse [app. meaning that he left his money strewn]. (K.)
4. AfSI: see the preceding paragraph, in two places.
Also He went forth, (S,) or came, (TA,) to the faDaMC [q. v.]. (S, TA.)

[Hence] AfDI fulaAnN UilaI fulaAnK Such a one came to, or reached, such a one: (M, Mgh, TA:) originally, became in the space, or the place, or quarter, of
such a one: (M:) or properly, became in the faDaMC of such a one. (Mgh.) And in like manner, AfDI Uilayohi AlOamoru [The thing, or event, came to, or reached, him]. (M.) And OafoDayotu UilaI AlXRaIoCi I came to, or reached, the thing. (Msb.) Accord. to IAar, (TA,) AlUifoDaMCu properly signifies AlAinotihaMCu [i. e. The coming at last, or ultimately, or the reaching, to a person or thing]. (IAar, T, Msb, TA.) Hence the saying [in the Kur iv. 25], waqado OafoDaI baEoDukumo UilaI baEoDK i. e. When one of you hath come, and betaken himself, to the other; (TA;) in which the verb is made trans. by means of UilaI because having the meaning [of AinotahaI or] of waSala: (M:) or this means, when one of you hath become alone with the other, agreeably with the original derivation; or, accord. to some, it is an allusion to mutual contact, skin to skin: or to copulation. (Mgh.) You say, AfDI UilaI QmoraOatihi [He went in to his wife: or] he became in contact with his wife, skin to skin: (S, Msb:) or it signifies, (M, K,) or signifies also, (S, Msb,) (tropical:) he compressed his wife: (S, M, Msb, K:) or he was, or became, with her alone in private, whether he compressed her or not. (M, K.)

AfDI bihimo He reached with them, or brought them to, a wide, or spacious, place. (TA.) And AfDI bihi AlTRariyqu UilaI waEorK mina AlOaroDi [The road brought him to a rugged tract of land]. (K * and TA in art. wEr)

AfDI biyadihi UlaI AlOaroDi He touched the ground with the palm of his hand (IF, S, Msb, K) in his prostration [in prayer]. (S, K.) And OafoDayotu Uilayohi biyadiI mino gayori HaAYilK I put my hand to it without anything intervening; i. q. masasotuhu (Msb in art ms.)
OafoDayotu UilaI falaAnK bisiriI [I communicated, or made known, to such a one my secret]: (S;) or OafoDayotu Uilayohi biAlsRirRi I acquainted him with the secret. (Msb. TA.)
AfDI also signifies (assumed tropical:) He became poor: so says IAar: as though he came to the ground. (TA.)
laA yufoDiI QllRehu faAka, occurring in a trad., is a phrase expressive of a prayer, meaning May God not make thy mouth wide and empty. (TA.)

Hence the saying of IAar, AlUifoDaMCu Ono tasoquTa AlvRanaAyaA mino taHotu wamino fawoqu [app. meaning that AifoDaMCN is the inf. n. of OufoDiIa signifying His central incisors, below and above, fell out: or he was caused to lose them]: and hence [the epithet] AlmufoDaApu [and therefore hence also what here follows]. (TA.)

AfDI AlmaroOapa He made the woman's masolakaAni (i. e. her vagina and rectum, Msb) to become one, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) in devirginating her, (Msb,) or in compressing her; (TA;) the intervening part becoming rent: (Mgh, TA:) and so OafaADahaA: (M, in which it is mentioned in art. fDI:) the epithet applied to her is mufoDaApN↓, (M, Mgh, Msb, K,) which is syn. with XariymN. (S.)
5. tafaDRayotu for tafaDRaDotu see in art. fD (conj. 5).

[AltfDRI in a passage of the Fákihet el-Khulafà accord. to several copies thereof is an obvious mistake for AltRafaSRiI, with the unpointed S: see Freytag's Critical Annotations and Corrections in his edition of that work, p. 6.]

faDFA, (S, M, K,) also written faDFI, (TA,) A thing (S, K) mixed. (S, M, K.) You say TaEaAmN faDFA Mixed food: (S:) and tamorN faDFA dates mixed, (AA, * S, M,) as, for instance, (S, TA,) with raisins, (Lh, S, M, TA,) in one vessel, or bag; thus says El-Kálee; (TA;) or scattered, or strewn, and mixed; (M:) and tamoraAni faDayaAni [two sorts of dates mixed]: and tumuwrN OafoDaMCN [several sorts of dates mixed]. (AA, TA.) And mataAEuhomN fawoDaI faDFA Their goods are mixed together: (M:) or are shared in common. (TA.) And Oamoruhumo faDFA bayonahumo [Their case is mixed, or promiscuous, &c., like Oamoruhumo fawoDaI bayonahumo (q. v. in art. fwD); or] their case among themselves is alike; (M, TA;) i. e. they have no commander over them. (S, TA.) And taraka AlOamora faDFA i. e. [He left the affair] in an unsound [or a disordered] state. (TA.) And OaloqaI vawobahu faDFA [He threw down his garment in a disorderly, or cureless, manner;] he did not commit his garment to any one's care. (M, TA.)

[Also One; a single thing or person: and alone; by itself or himself; not having any other with it or him; apart from others: thus it has two contrmeanings.] You say sahomN faDFA One, or a single, arrow. (K:) or an arrow that is alone, by itself, not having any other with it, in the quiver. (AA, TA.) And baqiyta faDFA I remained alone, (Az, K, TA,) of such as were fellows: (Az, TA:) or a part from my brethren and my family. (Akh, TA)
Also, i. e. faDFA, (M, K,) or correctly with I [i. e. faDFI], as written by El-Kálee, (TA,) The stones (HabR) of raisins; (M;) i. q. faDFA [or fSFI]. (K.)
See also what next follows.

faDoyapN Water collecting and stagnating: pl. fiDaACN, with medd, accord. to Kr: and also faDFI↓ and fiSFI, with fet-h and with kesr, the former of these like HalaqN as pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of HaloqapN, and the latter like bidarN as a pl. of badorapN; occurring in different relations of a verse of 'Adee Ibn-Er-Rikáa. (M in art. fDI, and TA.)
faDaMCN is an inf. n.: (M, K, TA:) and is expl. by Aboo-'Alee El-Kálee as signifying Width, or spaciousness. (TA.)
[It is also used as an epithet:] see faADK.

And [as a subst., or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] it signifies A court, an open area, or a yard, of a house; syn. saAHapN: (S, K:) and a wide, or spacious, tract of land: (ISh, S, M, K:) or a plain and wide expanse of land: (Sh, TA:) the pl. is OafoDiypN. (ISh, TA.)

fiDaMCN Water running upon the ground: (K:) or, accord. to Aboo-'Alee El-Kálee it is [in measure, but not exactly in meaning,] like HisaMCN [a pl. of HisoIN], signifying water running upon the surface of the earth; [or rather waters &c.; for he adds,] and its sing. is faDiyRapN↓: in the M, [in art. fDI,] it is said to be a pl. of faDoyapN, [q. v.,] on the authority of Kr. (TA.)
faDiyRapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
faADK (Msb, TA) and mufoDK↓ (M, * TA) Wide, or spacious, (M, * Msb, TA,) as also faSaMCN↓, (Az, Er-Rághib, Mgh, Msb, TA,) open and plain, and vacant. (TA.)
[The first of these words, in the present day, pronounced faADiI, is commonly used in the sense of faArigN as meaning Unoccupied, unemployed, or at leisure.]
mafoDFI i. q. mutRasaEN [A place of width or spaciousness, &c.]. (TA.)
mufoDK: see faADK. [And see also its verb, 4.]
mufoDaApN: see 4, last sentence,
1. faTaOahu is like HaTaOapu in its [various] meanings. (K.) Like the latter it signifies He struck him on the back. (AZ, S, O.)
And He broke it, or crushed it. (S, O, K.)

And faTaOahaA, (S, O, TA,) aor.
faTaAa
, inf. n. faToCN, (TA,) He compressed her; (S, O, TA;) namely, a woman. (TA.)
And faTaOa bihi AlOaroDa He threw him down, or prostrated him, on the ground, (S, O.)
And faTaOa bisaloHihi He cast forth his excrement, or ordure; sometimes occurring with v; (S, O;) which is a dial. var.; or an instance of mispronunciation. (O)

And faTaOati Alganamu biOawolaAdihaA The sheep, or goats, brought forth their young ones. (S, O.) And laEana QllRehu OumRaA faTaAtN bihi May God curse a mother who cast him forth [from her womb]: like XaTaOato bh. (TA in art. XTO.)
And faTiOabihaA He broke wind [app. with a sound; like HTaOabhA]. (S, O.)
faTaOa Alqawoma He did to the people, or party, what they did not like. (O, K.)
And faTaOa Zahora baEiyrihi He loaded his camel with a heavy burden, so that his back became hollow, or depressed. (K.)

faTiYa, aor.
faTaAa
, (K,) inf. n. faTaON, (TA,) [app., i. q. faTisa, i. e. He had the bone of his nose wide and depressed; or depressed and expanded; or he had his nose spreading upon his face: see faTaON below.
And] He had a hollow back, and a protuberant breast, or chest. (K.)
And faTiYa AlbaEiyru The camel was, by nature, low, or depressed, in his back. (S, O.)
4. AfTO He copulated much, or often. (IAar, O, K.)
And He became ample in his state, or circumstances. (IAar, O, K.)
And His nature, or disposition, became evil, after having been good. (IAar, O, K.)
AfTOhu He fed him; gave him to eat; or gave him food. (O, K.)

6. tfATO, (K, TA,) said of a man, (TA,) is syn. with taqaAEasa [q. v.; app. in a sense similar to the senses here following]: or it signifies more than tqAEs. (K, TA.) tfATO Eanohu means He held back, or receded, from him, or it (K, * TA.) And tfATO Eanohumo He was defeated, and retreated from them, (O, K,) after he had charged, or made an assault or attack, upon them. (O.)

faTaON [mentioned above as inf. n. of faTiYa, and in the O erroneously written fuTaAC,] i. q. faTasN [i. e. A depression and expansion of the bone of the nose; or a spreading of the nose upon the face]; (S, * O, * K;) and faTaOapN↓ is syn. with faTasapN [which is a subst. signifying as above] (S, O: but in one of my copies of the S, the former of these words is written faToOap; and in the O, the latter is written faTosap.)
And Hollowness of the back, (K, TA,) or, as some say, of the middle of the back, (TA,) and protuberance of the breast, or chest; as also faToOapN↓. (K, TA.)
fuToOapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
faTaOapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

OafoTaOu i. q. OafoTasu [i. e. Having the bone of his nose depressed and expanded; or having his nose spreading upon his face]. (S, * O, * TA.) It is said that Museylimeh the Liar was OafoTaO, (O,) or OafoTaOu AlOanofi: so in a trad. (TA.)
And Having a hollow back, and a protuberant breast, or chest. (K.) And OafoTaOu AlZRahori A camel low, or depressed, in the back, by nature. (TA.)

1. faTaHahu, (S, K,) aor.
faTaHa
, (K,) inf. n. faToHN; (S;) and fTRHhu↓, (S, * K,) inf. n. tafoTiyHN; (S;) He made it broad, or wide. (S, K.)

And faTaHa AlEuwda wagayorahu, (K, TA,) inf. n. as above; and fTRHhu↓, inf. n. as above; (TA;) He pared, or fashioned by cutting, the stick, or piece of wood, &c., and made it broad, or wide. (K, TA.) And faTaHa AlHadiyodapa, and fTRHhA↓, He made the piece of iron broad, or wide, and even, or flat, for a misoHaAp, or a miEozaq, or some other thing. (L.)
And faTaHa biAlEaSaAZahorahu, (K, * TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He struck his back with the staff, or stick. (K, * TA.)
And faTaHato biAlwaladi, said of a woman, i. q. ramato bihi [She cast forth the child, or the fœtus]. (K, TA.) [Compare TafaHato.]

faTiHa, aor.
faTaHa
, inf. n. faTaHN, [app., He (a man) had a broad, or wide, head: (see OafoTaHu:) or it signifies, or signifies likewise, and so app. fuTRiHa↓, inf. n. tfoTiyHN, (see faTaHN below, and OafoTaHu,)] said of the head, and of the end of the nose, It was, or became, broad, or wide. (TK.)
faTiHa AlnRaxolu The palm-trees became fecundated. (Kr, K.)
2: see the preceding paragraph, in four places.

faTaHN [inf. n. of faTiHa, q. v.: and, as a simple subst.,] Breadth, or width, of the head, (S, K, TA,) in the middle; as also tafoTiyHN: (TA:) and breadth, or width, of the end of the nose, (L, K,) so that it sticks close to the face; as in the bull, which is termed OafoTaHu. (L.)
faTuwHN A she-camel bulky in the belly, (K, TA,) broad, or wide, in the ribs. (TA.)

OafoTaHu A man having a broad, or wide, head. (S.) And A broad, or wide, head; (A, L;) as also mufaTRaHN↓ (S, A, L) and mafoTuwHN↓. (A.) And OaronabapN faToHaMCu A broad, or wide, end of a nose: (A, L:) and so qadamN [i. e. foot]. (A.)
AlOafoTaHu The bull: so called because of the breadth of the end of his nose: (L, K:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (L.)
And The chameleon (K, TA) whose back and colour the sun makes to glisten so that it becomes white by reason of the heat thereof. (TA.)
And AlfaToHaMCu The broad, or wide, part of a bow. (L.)
Also i. q. OafodaEu [q. v.]. (K.)
mufaTRaHN: see the next preceding paragraph.
mafoTuwHN: see the next preceding paragraph.

AlfiTaHolu, (S, O, K,) and accord. to the expositors of the Fs, AlfaTaHolu also, (TA,) [or zamanu AlfaTaHoli,] A [or the] time in which mankind had not as yet been created (lamo yuxolaqo fiyhi baEodu): (S, O, K:) or the time of Noah: (K:) or a [or the] time in which the stones were moist, or soft: (S, O, K:) thus said Ru-beh, when asked respecting it; (TA;) and thus the Arabs of the desert accord. to AO: (S, O, TA:) a poet said,

[In the time of the fTHl, when the stones were moist, or soft]: (TA:) and El-'Ajjáj is related to have said, (S,) or, correctly, Ru-beh, as in the O, or Ru-beh Ibn-El-'Ajjáj, in replying to a woman whom he desired to take to wife, and who had asked him what was his age, and what was his property, &c., (TA,)

[And I said, If I were made to live the life of the new-born young one of the dabb (which is said to be seven hundred years), or the life of Noah in the time of the fitahl, when the rocks were moist like the clay of the mire, I should become the pledge of a grave or of slaughter]: (S, * O, TA: but the last has haramK in the place of jadavK:) and one says, kaAna celika zamana AlfiTaHoli [That was in the time of the fitahl]; a prov., in which the last word is said to have the first, or the third, of the meanings expl. in this art.; and which is said of a thing that happened long ago; (Meyd: [see also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 340:]) and Oatayotuka EaAma AlfiTaHoli, and Alhidamolapi, expl. by AHn as meaning [I came to thee] in the time [or year] of abundance of herbage, and of food and drink. (TA.)
And fiTaHolN also signifies A torrent. (Sh, O, K.)
And A camel large, big, or bulky. (Fr, Sh, K.)
And Plump and big. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.)

1. faTarahu, (S, M, K,) aor.
faTura
, (M, K, TA,) and, accord. to the K,
faTira
also, but this latter form requires consideration, for it is related by Sgh, from Fr, in another sense, that of milking a camel, and not unrestrictedly, (TA,) inf. n. faTorN; (S, M;) and fTRrhu↓, (M, TA,) inf. n. tafoTiyrN; (TA;) [but the latter is with teshdeed to denote muchness, or frequency, or repetition, of the action, or its application to many objects;] He clave, split, slit, rent, or cracked, it. (S, M, K.)

Hence, (S,) faTara, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
faTura
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. faTorN (Msb, K) and fuTuwrN, (K,) It (the tooth called nAb, of a camel,) came forth; (S, K;) it clave the flesh and came forth. (TA.)
See also 7.

faTarahu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
faTura
, inf. n. faTorN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) He (God, Msb, K) created it, (S, Msb, K,) namely, the creation: (Msb, K:) he caused it to exist, produced it, or brought it into existence, newly, for the first time, it not having existed before; originated it; commenced, or began it; (S, M, A, Mgh, K;) as also AftTrhu↓, relating to an affair. (TA.) I'Ab says, I did not know what is [the meaning of] AlsRamewaAti faATiru↓ [The Originater, or Creator, of the heavens] until two Arabs of the desert came to me, disputing together respecting a well, and one of them said OanaA faTarotuhaA, meaning, I originated, or began, it. (S.) fuTira EalaI AlXRaIoCi: see TubiEa. [The explanation there given is confirmed by explanations of fiTorapN.]

faTara AlEajiyna, (Lth, S, K,) aor.
faTura
, inf. n. faTorN; (S;) and fTrRhu↓; (Ks, TA;) He made the dough into bread, or baked it, without leavening it, or leaving it until it should become good [or mature]; (K;) he kneaded the dough and made it into bread, or baked it, immediately; (Lth;) he hurried the dough, or prepared it hastily, so as to prevent its becoming mature. (S.) You say faTarat QlomaroOapu AlEajiyna HatRaI QsotabaAna fiyhi AlfaToru↓ [The woman hurried the dough, or prepared it hastily, so that immaturity, or want of leaven, was manifest in it]. (S.)
And in like manner, faTara AlTRiyna He prepared, or kneaded, the clay, or mud, [without leaving it until it should become mature,] and plastered with it immediately. (Lth, TA.)
And faTara Aljiloda, (IAar, K,) inf. n. faTorN; (TA;) and AfTrhu↓; (K;) He did not saturate the skin with the tanning liquid: (IAar, K:) or he did not put it therein. (A.)

And faTara, (Fr, O, K,) aor.
faTura
and
faTira
, (Fr, O, K, * TA,) inf. n. faTorN, (Fr, S, O, K,) He milked a she-camel, (Fr, S, O, K,) and a ewe or goat, (TA,) with the fore finger and the thumb: (Fr, S, O, K, TA:) or with the ends of the fingers: (K, TA:) or, as one does in indicating the number thirty, i. e., with the two thumbs and the two fore fingers: [but this is app. a mistake for what next follows:] (L, TA:) or, accord. to IAth, with two fingers [and] with the end of the thumb. (TA. See also DabRa AlnRaAqapa.)
And [hence, app.,] faTara OaSaAbiEahu He pressed, or squeezed, his fingers. (TA.) And He struck his (another's) fingers so that they burst forth with blood (AinofaTarato damFA). (TA.)
See also 2:
and 4, first sentence.
2. fTRrhu: see 1, first sentence.

Also, (inf. n. tafoTiyrN, S,) He made him to break his fast; or to eat and drink; (S, * Mgh, * K;) as also AfTrhu↓, and faTarahu↓: (K:) he gave him breakfast: he, or it, (namely, the action termed UisotimonaMCN, and a clyster, [&c.,] Msb,) broke, or vitiated, his fast. (Msb.) And you say also hecaA kalaAmN yufoTiru AlSRawoma, [and, more commonly, yufaTRiruhu,] This is speech which breaks, or vitiates, the fast. (TA.)
fTRr AlEajiyna: see 1.

4. AfTr He broke his fast; (S, * Mgh; *) he breakfasted; he ate and drank after fasting; (Msb, * K;) as also faTara↓, (K,) aor.
faTura
, (TA,) inf. n. fuTuwrN: (Msb, TA:) his fast became vitiated. (Msb.) AfTr as quasi-pass. of faTRarotuhu is extr., (Sb,) like OaboXara as quasi-pass. of baXRarotuhu. (Sb, Mgh.) You say AfTr EalaI tamorK [He breakfasted upon dates, or dried dates;] he made dates, or dried dates, his breakfast, after sunset [in Ramadán]. (Msb.) In the saying SuwmuwA liruWoyatihi waOafoTiruwA liruwoyatihi [Fast ye after the sight of it, namely, the new moon commencing Ramadán, and break ye your fast after the sight of it, namely, the new moon commencing Showwál], the l is in the sense of baEod, i. e., baEoda ruWoyatihi. (Msb.)

It was time for him to break his fast: (K:) he entered upon the time of breaking his fast; (Mgh, Msb, K;) like OaSobaHa and OamosaI as meaning “ he entered upon the time of morning ” and “ upon the time of evening: ” (Mgh, * Msb:) or he became in the predicament of those who break their fast, and so though he neither ate nor drank: whence the trad., OafoTara AlHaAjimu waQlomaHojuwmu The cupper and the cupped place themselves in the predicament of those who break their fast: or it is time for the cupper and the cupped to break their fast: or it is used after the manner of a harsh expression, and an imprecation against them. (IAth.)
AfTrhu: see 2.
AfTr Aljiloda: see 1.
5: see the next paragraph, in six places.

7. AnfTr, and tfTRr↓, (S, M, K,) and faTara↓, (M,) [but the second is with teshdeed as quasi-pass. of 2, to denote muchness, or frequency, or repetition, or application to many subjects of the action, as is indicated in the S by its being expl. by taXaqRaqa,] It became cleft, split, slit, rent, or cracked. (S, M, K.) UicaA QlsRamaMCu QnofaTarato [in the Kur lxxxii. 1] means When the heaven shall become cleft. (Bd, TA.) And minohu takaAdu AlsRamewaAtu yatafaTRarona↓ [in the Kur xix. 92] The heavens are near to becoming repeatedly rent in consequence thereof. (Bd.) And qadamaAhu tafaTRarato↓ His feet became cracked: [or much cracked.] (TA, from a trad.) And tafaTRarati↓ AlOaroDu biAlnRabaAti The earth became cracked [in many places by the plants coming forth]. (TA.) And AlXRajaru biwaraqK tafaTRara↓ [The trees broke forth with leaves; as also AnfTr, often occurring in this sense; see Har p. 58; and see fiTorN]. (S and K, voce raAHa; &c.) And qadamaAhu damFA tafaTRarato↓ [and AnfTrt (see 1, last sentence but one,)] His feet [burst forth or] flowed with blood. (TA.)
And AnfTr AlSRuboHu (assumed tropical:) The dawn broke. (TA in art. SdE.)
8: see 1. And see also 8 in art. XrE.
faTorN [as an inf. n.: see 1:

as a subst.,] A cleft, split, slit, rent, or crack: (K:) or, accord. to some, a first cleft &c.: (MF:) pl. fuTuwrN: (K:) occurring in the saying halo taraI mino fuTuwrK [Dost thou see any clefts?], in the Kur [lxvii. 3]. (TA.)

'Omar, being asked respecting [the discharge termed] AlmacoI, answered, It is AlfaToru: (O, K:) thus as related by A 'Obeyd: (TA:) it is said that he likened it, in respect of its paucity, to what is drawn from the udder by means of the milking termed AlfaToru: (O, K:) or, as some say, it is from tafaTRarato qadamaAhu damFA [expl. above]: (TA:) or he likened its coming forth from the orifice of the cakar to the coming forth of the naAb of the camel: or, as it is related by En-Nadr, he said AlfuToru↓, with damm: meaning the milk that appears upon the orifice of the teat of the udder. (O, K.)
fuTorN Such as has broken forth [with buds or leaves] (maA tafaTRara), of plants. (TA.) See also fiTorN.

And, (S, K,) as also fuTurN↓, (K,) the latter used in poetry, (TA,) [The toadstool;] a species of kamoOap [or fungus], (S, K,) white and large, (S,) and deadly: (K:) [so called] because the ground cleaves asunder from it: (TA:) n. un. fuTorapN. (S.) [Also applied in the present day to The common mushroom; agariens campestris. And Any fungus.]
[Also, the former, Immaturity, or want of leaven, in dough:] see the explanation of faTarati AlmaroOapu AlEajiyna.

And fuTorN and fuTurN↓ signify also Somewhat of that which remains of milk [in the udder], which is then milked: (L, K:) or a small quantity of milk when it is milked: (TA:) or milk at the time when it is milked. (AA, TA.) See also faTorN, last sentence.
fiTorN Grapes when the heads thereof appear; (K, TA;) [so called] because the [fruit-] stalks [then] break forth (tanofaTiru); (TA;) as also fuTorN↓. (K, TA.)

Also a subst. from OafoTara; (S;) [as such] it signifies The breaking of a fast; contr. of SawomN. (TA.) [Hence, Eiydu AlfiTori The festival of the breaking of the fast, immediately after Rama- dán; sometimes called AlfiToru alone.] AlfiTorapu↓ means Sadaqapu AlfiTori [The alms of the breaking of the fast], (O, K, TA,) which is a SaAE [q. v.] of wheat: the prefixed noun (Sdqh) is rejected, and p is affixed to its complement (AlfTr) to indicate that such has been done: but it is a word used by the lawyers; not of the classical language. (TA.)
See also mufoTirN.
fuTurN: see fuTorN, in two places.
fiTorapN Creation: (Msb:) the causing a thing to exist, producing it, or bringing it into existence, newly, for the first time; originating it. (TA.)

The natural constitution with which a child is created in his mother's womb; (AHeyth, K;) i. q. xiloqapN. (S, Mgh.) It is said to have this signification in the Kur xxx. 29. (TA.) And so in the saying of Mohammad, kulRu mawoluwdK yuwladu EalaI AlfiTorapi Every infant is born in a state of conformity to the natural constitution with which he is created in his mother's womb, either prosperous or unprosperous [in relation to the soul]; and if his parents are Jews, they make him a Jew, with respect to his worldly predicament; [i. e., with respect to inheritances &c.;] and if Christians, they make him a Christian, with respect to that predicament; and if Magians, they make him a Magian, with respect to that predicament; his predicament is the same as that of his parents until his tongue speaks for him: but if he die before his attaining to the age when virility begins to show itself, he dies in a state of conformity to his preceding natural constitution, with which he was created in his mother's womb. (AHeyth, TA.) [See another explanation of the word, as occurring in this trad., below.]
Nature; constitution; or natural, native, innate, or original, disposition, or temper or other quality or property; idiosyncrasy. (Th, TA.)

The faculty of knowing God, with which He has created mankind: (TA:) the natural constitution with which a child is created in his mother's womb, whereby he is capable of accepting the religion of truth: this is a secondary application: and this is [said to be] the signification meant in the trad. mentioned above. (Mgh.)

Hence, The religion of el-Islám: (Mgh:) the profession whereby a man becomes a Muslim, which is the declaration that there is no deity but God, and that Mohammad is his servant and his apostle, who brought the truth from Him, and this is (AHeyth, TA) religion. (AHeyth, K, TA.) This is shown by a trad., in which it is related that Mohammad taught a man to repeat certain words when lying down to sleep, and said faUinRaka Uino mutRa mino layolatika mutRa EalaI AlfiTorapi [And then, if thou die that same night, thou diest in the profession of the true religion]. (AHeyth, TA.) Also by the saying, qaSRu AlOaZofaAri mina AlfiTorapi The paring of the nails is [a point] of the religion of el-Islám. (Mgh.)
Also i. q. sunRapN [app. meaning The way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, or the like, pursued, and prescribed to be followed, by Mohammad]. (TA.)
In the Kur xxx. 29, accord. to some, The covenant received, or accepted, from Adam and his posterity. (Bd.)
The pl. is fiTaraAtN and fiToraAtN and fiTiraAtN. (TA.)
See also fiTorN.
AlUiymaAnu AlfiToriIRu [The faith to which one is disposed by the natural constitution with which he is created]. (Msb.)
fuTaArN A sword having in it cracks; (S, Z, O, K;) and (K) that will not cut: (IAar, O, K:) or recently made. (TA.)
faTuwrN (S, Msb, K) and faTuwriIRN↓, (S, K,) as though the latter were a rel. n. from the former, (S,) A breakfast; a thing [i. e. food or beverage] upon which one breaks his fast. (S, Msb, K.)

faTiyrN Dough unleavened; or not left until it has become good [or mature]; contr. of xamiyrN: (S, TA:) and in like manner clay, or mud. (TA.)
