[Hence,] Eiydu AlfaTiyri [The feast of unleavened bread; also called, of the Passover;] a festival of the Jews, [commencing] on the fifteenth day of their month niysaAn, and lasting seven days. (Msb. [See also AlfiSoHu.])

Anything prepared, made, or done, hastily, or hurried, so as to prevent its becoming mature: (Lth, S, K:) fresh; recent; newly made: (S, TA:) pl. faToraI: (Sgh, IAth, TA:) for OaToEamahu faToraI, in the K, expl. as meaning [He fed him] with faTiyr, is a gross mistake, a mistranscription of OaToEimapN faToraI, as the phrase stands in the handwriting of Sgh himself, in wellformed letters, and with the syll. signs, meaning meats [newly prepared, &c.]. (TA.) You say EinodiI xubozN xamiyrN waHayosN faTiyrN [I have leavened bread, and] fresh, recent, or newly made, Hys [q. v.]. (S, TA.) You say also UiyRaAka waAlrRaOoIa AlfaTiyru (tropical:) Beware thou of a hastily formed, immature, opinion. (S.) And XarRu AlrRaOoIi AlfaTiyru (tropical:) [The worst opinion is the hastily formed, and immature]. (TA.)
A skin not saturated with the tanning liquid: or not put therein: (TA:) a whip not tanned: not softly tanned: (TA:) or not newly tanned. (L.)
Also A calamity; syn. daAhiyapN. (O, K, TA.)
faTuwrapN: see what next follows.
faTiyrapN and faTuwrapN↓ A sheep, or goat, that is slaughtered on the day of [the festival of] the fiTor: (K, TA:) mentioned by Sgh, and in the B. (TA.)

fuTaAriIRN A man possessing neither good nor evil; (IAar, O, K, * TA;) such as is termed fadom [impotent in speech or actions, heavy, or dull; &c.]: (TA:) from fuTaArN applied to a sword, meaning that will not cut. (IAar, O, TA. *)
faTuwriIRN: see faTuwrN.
faATirN A camel whose naAb [or tush] is coming forth, (S,) or cleaving the flesh and coming forth. (TA.)
faATiru QlsRamewaAti waQlOaroDi [in the Kur xlii. 9, &c.,] means The Originater [or Creator] of the heavens and of the earth. (I'Ab, S, * TA.) See 1.
fuwTiyrN a subst. for AljimaAE, in Syriac. (TA.)
OufoTuwrN, and the pl. OafaATiyru: see the next paragraph.

tafaATiyru, a word similar to taEaAXiybu and taEaAjiybu and tabaAXiyru [q. v.], none of which four words has a sing., Pimples that come forth in the face of a boy or young man, and of a girl or young woman; as also nafaATiyru↓: thus correctly, with t and n: the author of the K, following Sgh [in the O], says that OafaATiyru↓ is the pl. of OufoTuwrN↓, and signifies a cracking, or chapping, in the nose of a young man, and in his face. (TA.)

Also, thus correctly, with t, The first of [the herbage of the rain called] the wasomiIR [q. v.]; and in this sense also it has no sing.: but it is said in the K that nafaATiyru↓ is pl. of nufoTuwrapN↓, with n; [in the O, that it is pl. of nufoTuwrN↓;] and [in both] that it signifies scattered herbage; (TA;) and Lh says, as is stated by AHn, that mino EuXobK nafaATiyru↓ means small quantities of herbage in land: (O, TA:) it is also added in the K, in explanation of nafaATiyru↓, or it signifies the first herbage of [the rain called] the wasomiIR: (TA:) [and it is said that] tafaATiyru nabaAtK signifies what break forth of, or from, plants, or herbage. (TA voce tabaAXiyru.)

mufoTirN A man breaking his fast; eating and drinking after fasting: (S, * Msb, * K, TA:) pl. mafaATiyru, (Sb, S, Msb, K,) like as mayaAsiyru is pl. of muwsirN, (S,) and mafaAliysu of mufolisN: (Msb:) and fiTorN↓ signifies the same, as sing. and pl., (S, Msb, K,) being originally an inf. n. (S, Msb.)

munofaTirN is used in the Kur [lxxiii. 18], in the phrase QlsRamaMCu munofaTirN bihi [The heaven shall be with rents by reason of it], in the manner of a possessive noun, [not as an act. part. n.,] like muEoDilN in the phrase dajaAjapN muEoDilN. (TA.)
nufoTuwrN and nufoTuwrapN, and the pl. nafaATiyru: see tfATyr, in six places.

1. faTasa, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
faTisa
(S, Msb, K) and
faTusa
, (Msb,) inf. n. fuTuwsN, (S, M, &c.,) He died; (S, M, &c.;) as also Tafasa: (TA:) or he died without disease: (M:) or without any apparent disease. (TA.)

faTasa AlHadiyda, (A, O, K, TA,) aor.
faTisa
, (K, * TA,) inf. n. faTosN, (TA,) He made the iron broad (A, O, K) with the great hammer called fiTRiys: (A:) or he beat the iron. (TA.)
And AlfaTosu signifies The treading vehemently, or the compressing vehemently. (M, TA: the word thus doubly rendered is AlwaToCu.)
And you say, faTasotuhu Eano kacaA meaning I repelled him in a most evil manner from such a thing: and likewise I beat him [app. away from such a thing]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

And faTasahu biAlkalimapi, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) and biAlxabari, (Ibn- 'Abbád, O,) aor.
faTisa
, (K,) He uttered in his face [the word, or sentence, and the tidings, or information]; as also fTRshu↓, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) inf. n. tafoTiysN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

fiTisa, aor.
faTasa
, inf. n. faTasN, (S, M, A, K,) He had the bone of his nose wide and depressed; (M;) or depressed and expanded: (S, A, K:) he had his nose spreading upon his face. (A, K.) [And faTiYa app. signifies the same.]
2. fTRshu He killed him. (Msb.)
See also 1.
faTosN (with fet-h, O, in a copy of the M written fuTos,) The berries of the myrtle: n. un. with p. (Lth, M, O, K.)
faTasN: see faTasapN.
faTosapN The skin of an animal that has not been slaughtered in the manner prescribed by the law. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
[See also faTosN.]

Also A certain bead used for fascinating and restraining [men]; (Lh, S, M, K;) one of the beads of the Arabs of the desert, with which women are asserted by the Arabs to fascinate and restrain men. (O.) They (i. e. women, O, K) say,

[I captivated and restrained him by means of the fatseh, by means of yawning and of sneezing]: (S, O, K: [in some copies of the S and K biAlvRuWabMCi:]) they shorten AlvwbMC on account of the metre, which is rajaz with the third foot of each hemistich suppressed. (O.)

faTasapN a subst. from faTisa [as such signifying A state of depression and expansion of the bone of the nose; or a spreading of the nose upon the face]: (S, O, K:) or the same word, (M, L,) or faTasN↓, (TA, [but this is the inf. n. of faTisa, and seems to be here a mistranscription,]) the place of a width and depression of the bone of the nose. (M, L, TA.)
fiTRiysN A great hammer, (S, M, A, O, K,) such as is used by a blacksmith: (A, TA:) or, (K,) accord. to IDrd, (O,) it is either Greek or Syriac, (O, K,) not genuine Arabic. (O.)
And A great faOos [i. e. hoe or adz or axe]. (M, TA.)

fiTRiysapN The snout of the swine; as also finoTiysapN↓: (S, M, * K:) or its nose with what is next thereto: (IDrd, O, K:) and, (K,) accord. to Th, (O,) it [app. meaning the lip] is [called] the Xafap of man, and of camels the miXofar, and of beasts of prey the xaTom and the xuroTuwm, and of the swine the finoTiysip↓, (O, K, * [in the latter of which it is plainly stated that fiTRiysapN is used in relation to man and to camels and to beasts of prey, whereas Th seems evidently to mean that what is called the Xafap of man, and of camels the maXofar, &c., is called the fanoTiysap of the swine,]) which word fnTysp he [thus] mentions, with n, as of the measure finoEiylapN, the n being augmentative. (O.)
faATisN Dying, or dead. (IAar, M.)
finoTiysapN: see fiTRiysipN, in two places: and see also art. fnTs, in two places.

OafoTasu A man (S) having the bone of his nose wide and depressed; (M;) or depressed and ex-
panded: (S, K:) having his nose spreading upon his face: (K:) fem. fTosaMCu. (M, K.) And it is also applied as an epithet to the nose itself [as meaning Having its bone wide and expanded; &c.]. (A in art. nfs.)
tamorapN faTosaMCu means A date small in the drupe, having the base cleaving [to it]. (TA.)

1. faTamahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
faTima
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. faTomN, (Msb, * TA,) He cut it, or severed it; (S, Msb, K, TA;) namely, a rope, (S, Msb, TA,) or a stick, or piece of wood, and the like. (TA.)

And faTamahu, (K,) or faTamatohu (S, Msb) said of a mother (S) or of a suckling woman, (Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Msb, TA,) He, (K,) or she, (S, Msb,) weaned, or ablactated, him, (S, Msb, K,) namely, a child, (S, K,) or suckling. (Msb.) And fuTimati AlsRaxolapu The lamb, or kid, was weaned, or ablactated. (K.) [And in like manner one says of other animals.]

And [hence, or] from the first of the significations expl. above, (Msb,) one says, faTamotuhu Eano EaAdatihi (tropical:) I [weaned him, or] disengaged him, (TA,) or withheld him, (Msb,) namely, a man, (S, Msb, TA,) [from his custom, or habit.] And laOafoTimanRaka EamRaA Oanota Ealayohi (tropical:) [I will assuredly wean thee from the state in which thou art, or from that which thou art pursuing: or] I will assuredly cut short thy eager desire. (TA.)
4. AfTm He (a child) entered upon the time for his being weaned, or ablactated. (Msb, TA.) And in like manner one says of a lamb, or kid. (IAar, K, TA.)

6. tfATmwA Their lambs, or kids, (bahomuhumo, [in the CK, erroneously, buhomuhumo,]) kept to their mothers after the weaning, or ablactation; (K, TA;) therefore this [person] gave, or delivered, his lambs, or kids, to this; and this [person], his lambs, or kids, to this. (TA.)
7: [AnfTm He (a child, or young one,) was, or became, weaned, or ablactated: commonly used in this sense in the present day.
And] AnfTm Eanohu (tropical:) He desisted from, or left, or relinquished, him, or it. (K, TA.)
fiTaAmN The act of weaning, or ablactation, of a child or young one: (S, Msb, * K:) a subst. in this sense. (K.)

And [it is also, app., an epithet:] you say nAqp fTAm [app. naAqapN fiTaAmN, like as you say naAqapN faATimN, q. v.], meaning A she-camel whose young one has been weaned from her: thus in the A. (TA.)
[And hence it seems to be used as a proper name of a woman; like faATimapu; for it is said,] and the woman is named fiTaAmN, like kitaAbN, [in form]. (TA.)

faTiymN A child weaned, or ablactated; (S, Msb, K;) as also mafoTuwmN↓: (K:) pl. of the former fuTumN, (S, Msb, K,) which is of a rare form as pl. of an epithet of the measure faEiylN, and more particularly of such as is used in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN. (IAth, TA.) And saxolapN faTiymN [in the CK faTiymapN] and faATimN↓ and mafoTuwmapN↓ A lamb, or kid, weaned, or ablactated, (K, TA,) which is the case two months from its birth, and it ceases not to be thus termed until it becomes a jafor [q. v.]. (TA.)
faTiymapN [a subst., rendered so by the affix p,] A sheep, or goat, weaned, or ablactated. (TA.)
faATimN [act. part. n. of 1, q. v.]

[Hence,] faATimapN A suckling woman weaning, or ablactating, a suckling. (Msb.) And faATimN A she-camel whose young one has become a year old and been weaned, or ablactated. (S, TA.) And A she-camel that weans, or is weaning, from her, her young one. (TA.) [See also fiTaAmN.]
[Hence,] in a trad. cited voce muroDiEN [q. v.], AlfaATimapu signifies (assumed tropical:) Death. (TA in art. rDE.)
See also faTiymN.
mafoTuwmN; and its fem., with p: see faTiymN.

1. faTina, [aor.
faTana
,] inf. n. fiTonapN and faTaAnapN and faTaAniyapN [&c. as in the next sentence, He was, or became, intelligent, understanding, knowing, sagacious, or skilful: see the explanations of fiTonapN below]; (S;) and faTuna signifies [the same, i. e.] he became such as is termed faTin. (Lth, TA.) You say, faTina lahu, (Msb, K,) and Uilayohi, and bihi, (K,) aor.
faTana
; (Msb, K;) and faTana, aor.
faTuna
; (Msb, K;) and faTuna, aor.
faTuna
; (K;) inf. n. faTonN (Msb, K) and faTonN and fuTonN and faTanN and fuTunN (K) and fiTonapN and fiTaAnN (Msb) and fuTuwnapN and faTaAnapN and faTaAniyapN; (K;) He was, or became, [intelligent, understanding, knowing, or sagacious, respecting it; (agreeably with explanations above;) or] skilled of it, i. e. skilful in it; (K;) namely, an affair: (Msb:) [and he understood, or knew, it; often used in this sense:] and sometimes they said faTanahu, making the verb trans. by itself, because it implies the meaning of fahima; (TA;) or faTanotu AlXRaIoCi, with fet-h, signifies I understood, or knew, the thing: (S:) and some say that faTaAnapN [as inf. n., agreeably with analogy, of faTuna, which see in what follows,] signifies [the possessing] excellence in respect of readiness of intelligence for the perception of what comes to one from another. (TA.) [faTana lahu also signifies He took notice of, or paid attention to, him, or it: see Har p. 626, and Ham p. 695.] And faTuna signifies [also] He became one of whom fiTonap [i. e. intelligence, &c., as expl. below,] was a sajiyRap [meaning faculty, or quality, firmly rooted in the mind]. (Msb.)

2. fTRnhu llOamori, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. tafoTiynN, (K, TA,) He made him to understand, or know, the affair: (K, * TA:) or he made him knowing in the various modes of the affair, and skilful therein. (Msb.) Hence the prov., laA yufaTRinu AlqaArapa UilRaA AlHijaArap i. e. [Nothing will make] the she-bear [to understand, except stones]. (TA.) And fTRnhu AlmuEalRimu means The teacher rendered him faTin [i. e. intelligent, &c.,] by the disciplining of his mind and the correcting him. (TA.)

3. mufaATanapN is of the measure mufaAEalapN from faTina: (S:) [as such it signifies The contending, or vying, one with another, in intelligence, understanding, knowledge, sagacity, or skill; whence faATanotuhu is used in the K (in art. Hjw) as a syn. of HaAjayotuhu, q. v.: or] it signifies [sometimes] the showing intelligence, understanding, knowledge, sagacity, or skill, one with another. (PS.) [Agreeably with the former explanation,] one says, faATanahu fiI AlkalaAmi i. e. He held a dialogue or colloquy, or a disputation or debate, with him [with the view of trying which of them would prove superior in intelligence, &c.]; syn. raAjaEahu. (K) [See also 3 in art. lHn.]
5. tfTRn lahu He understood it, or knew it, [quickly, or] with quickness of intelligence; namely, what was said. (TA.)
faTonN: see what next follows.
faTunN: see what next follows.

faTinN (S, Msb, K, KL) and faTunN↓ (S, K, KL) and faTonN↓ and faTiynN↓ and faTuwnN↓ and faATinN↓ (K) are epithets (S, K, TA) applied to a man, (S, TA,) signifying Intelligent, understanding, knowing, sagacious, or skilful; (S, * K, * KL;) the first expl. by Lth as signifying possessing fiTonap respecting things: (TA:) and it signifies one of whom fiTonap has become a sajiyRap [meaning faculty, or quality, firmly rooted in the mind]: (Msb:) the pl. [of this] is fuTonN, (K,) or fuzunN, with two dammehs, (Msb,) or both: (TA:) and the fem. is faTinapN. (K.) faTinN bixuSuwmatihi means A man knowing in the various modes of his disputation, or litigation, and skilful therein. (Msb.)

fiTonapN [mentioned above as an inf. n. seems to be regarded by some as a simple subst., and] signifies Intelligence, understanding, knowledge, sagacity, (S, * KL, PS,) or skill; (K, KL, PS;) contr. of gabaAwapN: (TA:) or, accord. to some, such [intelligence, &c.,] as is instinctive [or natural; infused into the mind by God]; not acquired. (TA.) [See also cihonN.]
faTuwnN: see faTinN.
faTiynN: see faTinN.
faATinN: see faTinN.

1. faZRa, (Msb,) sec. pers. faZiZota, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. faZaAZapN (S, M, Msb, K) and faZaZN, (M, K,) but the former is the more common because of the difficulty of pronouncing the doubled letter in the latter, (M,) and fiZaAZN↓ is syn. with these, (M, K,) and so is faZaAZN↓, but these two are simple substs., (M,) He (a man) was, or became, such as is termed faZRN [i. e. rough, coarse, rude, &c., as expl. below]; (S, M, Msb, K; *) or rough, &c., so as to be unduly feared. (Msb.)

faZRapu, (M, K,)
aor.
faZuZa
, inf. n. faZRN; (TK;) and AftZRhu↓; (M, K;) He let it out, namely the water termed faZRN, by cutting open the stomach [of a camel]: (M, TA:) or he pressed it, or squeezed it, out, namely the water so termed, (M, K,) from the stomach, (M, TA,) and drank it: (TK:) and kariXa baEiyrK AftZR↓ he slaughtered a camel, and pressed out, or squeezed out, the water of its stomach, and strained it: (Esh-Sháfi'ee, T:) or AftZR↓ signifies he gave his camel to drink, then bound his mouth in order that he might not ruminate, and, when attacked by thirst, cut open his belly, and pressed out, or squeezed out, the fluid of the feces of his stomach, and drank it: (S:) and AlkariXa OafoZaZotu↓ I pressed out, or squeezed out, the water of the stomach. (Z, TA.)
4: see faZRahu.
AfZRhu, inf. n. UifoZaAZN, also signifies He turned him back, or away, from the object of his desire. (TA.)

And AfZRhu is also said of a man when he has inserted the thread into the eye of the needle: [if the affixed pronoun refer to the eye of the needle, the meaning is, He inserted the thread into it: if to the thread, he inserted it into the eye of the needle:] mentioned by AA. (TA.)
8: see faZRahu, in three places.

faZRN, applied to a man, (T, S, M, &c.,) Rough; coarse; rude; unkind; hard; churlish; uncivil; surly; hard to deal with; incompliant; unobsequious; (S, M, O, K, and Bd in iii. 153;) evil in disposition; illnatured; (O, K, and Bd and Jel ubi suprà;) hard-hearted; hard, or severe; rough, coarse, or the like, so as to be unduly feared; (Msb;) rough, or coarse, in speech; (Lth, T, M, K;) sour, or austere, therein: (Lth:) [said in the T to be from the same word in the sense next following; but accord. to the M, the reverse seems to be the case:] pl. OafoZaAZN. (M.) You say, UinRahu lafaZRN baZRN [Verily he is rough, coarse, or the like]; the latter word being an imitative sequent; (M, K;) as such we regard it because Th, who mentions it, does not explan it; (M;) and faZiyZN↓ baZiyZN [app. signifies the same]. (TA in art. bZ.)

Also The water of the stomach [of a camel], (T, S, K,) which is pressed, or squeezed, out, and drunk, (T, K,) on an occasion of want of water, (T,) in the waterless deserts; (T, K;) the water that comes forth from the stomach [of a camel]; because it is a coarse, or bitter, beverage: (M:) it may not be used for the purpose of religious purification: (Esh-Sháfi'ee, T:) also, the urine of horses which is drunk on an occasion of thirst: pl. fuZuwZN: thus used by Mutemmem Ibn-Nuweyreh. (M, L.)
faZaAZN and fiZaAZN: see 1, first sentence.

faZiyZN The seminal fluid of a woman: or of a stallion: (M, K:) so they assert: but it is not of established authority: (M:) and so say IDrd and Fr: (TA:) accord. to Kr, the seminal fluid of a stallion, in a she-camel's womb: (M, * TA:) or this is the explanation given by Fr: (T:) and fuZaAZapN↓ is of the measure fuEaAlapN from this word; (K;) as signifying the seminal fluid of a stallion, or the water of the stomach; but El-Khattábee disallows the latter meaning; or from faZRN: (TA:) and hence the saying of 'Áïsheh to Marwán, walekinRa QllReha laEana OabaAka waOanota fiI Sulobihi faOanota fuZaAZapN mino laEonapi QllRehi [But God cursed thy father when thou wast essentially in his loins; so thou art seed of the object of the curse of God]; (K;) i. e., nuTofapN minohaA; (TA;) or EuSaArapN minohaA [produce thereof, as though expressed therefrom]: (Z:) or, accord. to one relation, fuDuDN; (K;) pl. of faDiyDN, which means water such as is termed gariyD: or, accord. to another relation, faDaDN, meaning nuTofapN: and accord. to another, faDiyDN. (TA.)
See also faZRN.
fuZaAZapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
huwa OafoZRu mino fulaAnK He is [more rough, coarse, rude, or the like, (see faZRN,) or] more difficult in disposition, evil in disposition, illnatured, or perverse, than such a one. (TA.)

1. faZuEa AlOmoru, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
faZuEa
, (O,) inf. n. faZaAEapN, (S, O, Msb,) and perhaps faZaEN [respecting which see faZiEa]; (Mbr, TA;) as also AfZE↓; (S, O, Msb, K;) The affair, or event, was, or became, hard, difficult, or distressing; bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly; excessive, or exorbitant: (S:) or excessively bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly. (O, Msb, K.)

And faZiEa AlOamora, (K, TA,) thus in the copies of the K, and in like manner in the O, [where I find, AZ says, faZiEotu AlOamora, aor. OafoZaEuhu,] but [SM says] in the “ Nawádir ” of AZ, faZiEa biAlOamori, inf. n. faZaAEapN, (TA,) He reckoned the affair, or event, or judged it to be, great, hard, difficult, or distressing, syn. AisotaEoZamahu, (K,) or was made to fear, or be frightened, and was overcome, by it, (AZ, O, TA,) and trusted not that he had power to accomplish it, or to bear it: (AZ, O, K, TA:) it is said in a trad., Ouriytu OanRahu wuDiEa fiI yadaIRa sawaAraAni mino cahabK fafaZiEotuhumaA [I was made to see, meaning I imagined, or dreamt, that two bracelets of gold were put upon my arms, and I regarded them with fear]; in which instance, as IAth says, the verb is thus made trans. in accordance with its meaning, which is OakobarotuhumaA, and xifotuhumaA: but the phrase commonly known is faZiEotu bihi and minohu: (TA:) you say, faZiEonu bikacaA I was unable to do, or accomplish such a thing: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K: *) and faZiEotu biOamoriI occurs in a trad. as meaning [I found that] my affair, or case, was hard, difficult, or distressing, to me, and I regarded it with fear, or dread: faZiEa biAlOamori, inf. n. faZaAEapN and faZaEN, means He saw the affair, or event, or case, to be faZiyE [q. v.]: Mbr says, faZaEN is an inf. n. of faZiEa bihi: or it may be an inf. n. of faZuEa, like as karamN is of karuma: but I have not heard it save in the saying of the poet,

L.foreign: qdo EiXotu fiI AlnRaAsi OaTowaArFA EalaI xuluqK

sense.s: [I have lived among men during several periods, conforming to disposition differing in kind, (EalaI xuluqK XatRaI being like the phrase UinRa saEoyakumo laXatRaI, in the Kur xcii. 4, meaning AnR masaAEiykumo laOaXotaAtN, as is said in the Ksh and by Bd,) and I have endured therein softness and hardness]. (TA.)

faZiEa, (O, K,) aor.
faZaEa
, inf. n. faZaEN, (O,) said of a vessel, (K,) It became full. (O, K.)

2. fZRE, inf. n. tafoZiyEN, accord. to Freytag, signifies He described a thing as great: but for this he names no authority: by “ great ” is here meant hard, difficult, or distressing; &c.: see 1, first sentence.]
4. AfZE as intrans.: see 1, first sentence.

OafoZaEaniI AlOamoru The affair, or event, made me to fear, or frightened me: made me to fall into a hard, difficult, or distressing, case: (TA:) made me to be without power, or strength, or ability; disabled, or incapacitated, me. (Ham p. 32.)
And OufoZiEa He (a man, S, O, Msb) suffered the befalling of a hard, difficult, or distressing, event. (S, O, Msb, K.)
See also 10.
5: see what next follows.
10. AstfZEhu (S, O, K) and AfZEhu↓ (S, K) and tfZREhu↓ (O, K) He found it (a thing, S) to be faZiyE [i. e. hard, difficult, or distressing; &c.]. (S, O, K.)
faZiEN: see faZiyEN.
Also Full; applied to a vessel. (O, TA.)

faZiyEN (S, O, Msb, K) and mufoZiEN↓ (S, Msb, TA) and faZiEN↓, which last is a possessive epithet, (TA,) applied to an affair, or event, Hard, difficult, or distressing; bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly; excessive, or exorbitant: (S, TA:) or excessively bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly. (O, Msb, K. *)
And the first, Much, or abundant: so in the saying of 'Amr Ibn-MaadeeKerib,

[And Umámeh wondered that she saw me such that much, or abundant, hoariness had spread in, or overspread, my hair descending below the ears, or upon the shoulders: fiI is app. understood before limRatiI]. (O, TA.)
faZiyEN applied to water signifies Sweet: (Lth, O, K:) or clear; limpid; or cool, sweet, and clear or limpid. (IAar, O, K, TA.)
mufoZiEN: see faZiyEN.

1. faEalahu, (S, O, Msb, K, *) aor.
faEala
, (S, O, K,) inf. n. faEolN (S, O, Msb, K) and faEaAlN, (S, O, Msb,) and fiEolN↓ is the subst. therefrom, (S, O, Msb, K, *) but, accord. to Ibn-Kemál, it has become commonly used as the inf. n.; MF, however, says that its being thus used requires consideration; and it is said that there is no instance like faEalahu, aor. yafoEaluhu, inf. n. fiEolN, except saHarahu, aor. yasoHaruhu, inf. n. siHorN; or, to these may be added as sometimes occurring, xadaEa, aor. yaxodaEu, inf. n. xadoEN and xidoEN, and SaraEa, aor. yaSoraEu, inf. n. SaroEN and SiroEN; (TA;) [He did it]; namely, a thing (S, O. [For further explanation see fiEolN below.]) [In the Kur. xxi. 73,] some read waOawoHayonaA Uilayohimo faEola QloxayoraAti [And we suggested to them the doing of good works]; (Lth, S, O;) others reading fiEola↓ AlxyrAt. (Lth, O.)

And one says also faEala bihi [He did to him something]. (TA.) [faEala QllRehu bihi is a form of imprecation, meaning May God do to him what He will do; i. e. may God punish him: see an ex. voce OaZolamu.
And faEala biAlmaroOapi often occurs in trads. &c. as meaning He compressed the woman.]

2. tafoEiylN [inf. n. of fERl] is used by IJ as metonymically signifying The scanning of a verse; because the names of the measures of its feet, all of them, have the letters f and E and l for constituents, as when you say faEuwluno and mafaAEiylno and faAEilaAtuno and faAEiluno &c. (TA.)
3: [faAEalaA, inf. n. fiEaAlN, if used, app. signifies They two did a thing together.] See fiEaAlN below.

7. AnfEl quasi-pass. of 1: you say, faEalotuhu faQnofaEala [I did it, and it was done]; (S, Msb;) like your saying kasarotuhu faQnokasara. (S.) [AlAinofiEaAlu signifies The suffering, or receiving, the effect of an act, whether the effect is intended by the agent or not: or, accord. to some, particularly when the effect is not intended: for it is implied in a passage in the TA, that it is held by some to be used particularly in cases in which the effects are such as the blushing in consequence of confusion, or shame, affecting one from the seeing a person, and the emotion, or excitement, ensuing from the hearing of singing, and the agitation of the passionate lover at his seeing the object of his love: as a term of logic, it is one of the ten predicaments, i. e. passion, or suffering.] It is said that to every fiEol there is an AinofiEaAl, except to the act of creation, which proceeds from God; for this is the bringing into existence from a state of nonexistence, not from matter [already existing to receive the effect of the act]. (TA.)
8. AftEl Ealayohi kacibFA (Mgh, * O, Msb, * K) and zuwrFA (O) He forged against him a lie. (Mgh, * O, Msb, * K.)
Hence the phrase AlxuTuwTu tufotaEalu i. e. [Handwritings] are forged, or falsified. (Mgh.)

And [hence] it used to be said, OaEocabu AlOagaAniI maA QfotuEila i. e. [The sweetest of songs is] such as has been composed with originality, not in imitation of any model: and OaZorafu AlXRiEori maAQfotuEila [The most eloquent of poetry is such as has been so composed]. (TA.)
faEolN an inf. n. of 1. (S, O, Msb, K.)
And The vulva of the she-camel, and of any female. (K.)

fiEolN: see 1, in two places: [as a subst. from faEalahu] it signifies [A deed, or an action: or] a motion (HarakapN) of a human being: (K:) or, as Sgh says, the origination of anything, whether it be what is termed EamalN [which means work or labour or service as well as a deed or an action] or other than it; so that it is more general in application than EamialN: (TA:) or it is a metonymical term for any Eamal [meaning deed or action] that is transitive (M, K, TA) or intransitive (M, TA:) or a mode that is accidental to the producer of an effect upon another [person or thing] by reason of the producing of the effect at the first; as the mode that ensues to the cutter by reason of his being cutting: or, as Er-Rághib says, the production of an effect considered with reference to an agent thereof; and it is common to that which is by his, or its, origination or otherwise, and to that which is with knowledge or otherwise, and to that which is by intention or otherwise, and to what proceeds from the human being or the animal [of any kind] or the inanimate thing; and EamalN and SunoEN are more particular in application: El-Harállee says that the fiEol is what has become apparent in consequence of a motive of the efficient, whether from knowledge or otherwise, by reason of premeditation [for litadayRun (an obvious mistranscription in my original) I read litadabRurK] or otherwise: and El-Juweynee says that it is what is within the limits of a small space of time, without repetition, or reiteration, whereas the Eamal is what has been repeated, or reiterated, and whereof the time has been long; but this is repugned by the trad. [in which occurs the saying], maA faEala AlnRuigayor [expl. in art. ngr]; (TA:) the pl. is fiEaAlN (S, O, Msb, K) and OafoEaAlN [a pl. of pauc.], (O, TA,) [and OafaAEiylu is app. a pl. pl., i. e. pl. of OafoEaAlN, like OqaAwiylu pl. of OaqowaAlN which is pl. of qawolN, and many other instances]: you say, UinRa AlrRiXaA tafotalu AlOafaAEiyla watunosiI UiboraAhiyma waUisomaAEiyla [Verily bribes do great deeds, and cause the receivers to forget the principles of Ibráheem and Ismá'eel, who are esteemed models of true religion]. (TA. [This saying is written in my original without any vowel-signs, perhaps because well known: and it is there added that AlAfAEyl may be pl. of AfEwl (which has been altered by the copyist and is probably a mistranscription for OafoEuwlapN) or of AfEAl; with other remarks equally doubtful and unimportant.]) [Hence, biAlfiEoli meaning Actually; as opposed to biAlquwRapi i. e. potentially, or virtually.]

As used by the grammarians, it means [A verb; i. e.] what denotes a meaning in itself together with any one of the three times [past and present and future: but it should be observed that it includes the maSodar, or infinitive noun; and also that there is what is termed fiEolN nAqiSN an incomplete, i. e. non-attributive, verb (as kaAna coordinate to SaAra, &c.); as well as what is termed fiEolN taAmRN a complete, i. e. attributive, verb]. (TA.)

faEolapN A single fiEol [i. e. deed or action], (Msb, TA,) with fet-h. (Msb.) Thus in the saying in the Kur [xxvi. 18], wafaEalota faEolataka QARatiI faEalota [lit. And thou hast done thy one deed that thou hast done]; as though the speaker said, fatalota AlnRafosa qatollataka: in which Esh-Shaabee read fiEolataka↓ [thy kind of deed], with kesr, as meaning fatalota Alqitolapa AlRatiI qado EarafotahaA: so says Zj; but he adds that the former reading is better. (TA.) And [hence also] one says, kaAnato minohu faEolapN HasanapN or qabiyHapN [A good single deed proceeded from him or a bad one]. (S, O, TA.)
fiEolapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
faEilapN A custom, manner, habit, or wont. (K.)
[fiEoliIRN Of, or relating to, a verb.]
[fiEoliyRapN The quality of a verb.]
faEaAlN, like nazaAli, has sometimes occurred as meaning AifoEalo [Do thou]. (O, K. *)

faEaAlN, (O, K,) accord. to Lth, (O,) is a name for A good doing, such as liberality, or bounty, (O,) and generosity, (O, K, [the only meaning assigned to it in the S,]) and the like of these: (O:) or, (O, K,) accord. to IAar, (O,) the doing of a single person, peculiarly, [as distinguished from fiEaAlN, q. v.,] (O,) relating to good and to evil; (O, K;) one says, fulaAnN kariymu AlfaEaAli [Such a one is generous in respect of doing or doings], and fulaAnN laYiymu AlfaEaAli [Such a one is mean in respect of doing or doings]; (O: [and the like is said in the T and in the Msb;]) and Az says that this is the correct explanation: not that of Lth; and Mbr [likewise] says, it is used in commendation and in discommendation: (O:) and it is used only of a single agent. (O, K.)
It is also an inf. n. (S, O, Msb. [See 1, first sentence.])
fiEaAlN, as distinguished from faEaAlN, signifies A doing that is between two [agents]; (IAar, O, K, TA;) and therefore it is an inf. n. of faAEala↓ [a verb of which I have not found any ex.]. (TA.)
It is also a pl. of fiEolN. (S, O, Msb, K.
Also The handle, (K,) or piece of wood that is inserted into the hole, (IAar, IB, O,) of the axe, or adz, or hoe: (IAar, IB, O, K:) pl. fuEulN. (K.)
fuEaAlapu (with damm, O, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, faEAlapu,]) A metonymical appellation substituted for xuzaAEapu, (O, K, TA,) the well-known tribe [thus named]. (TA.)
faERaAlN [Wont to do]. (Kur xi. 109 and lxxxv. 16. [Thus in the phrase faERaAlN limaA yuriydu Wont to do what He willeth: relating to God.])

faAEilN [act. part. n. of 1, Doing: and, used as a subst., a doer: and hence] a carpenter is thus
called; accord. to IAar: but it is now peculiarly applied to such as works with clay, [and builds, and plasters,] and digs foundations: (TA:) and [the pl.] faEalapN, (Mgh, K, TA,) as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, is applied to workers in clay and digging and the like; (K, TA;) or such as work with their hands in clay or building or digging; like EamalapN [pl. of EaAmilN]. (Mgh.)

wakunRaA faAEiliyna, in the Kur [xxi. 79], means And we were able to do what we willed. (O, TA.) And waQlRaciyna humo lilzRakewpi faAEiluwna, in the same [xxiii. 4], means And who give the ckwp [or poor-rate]: (Zj, O, TA:) or, as some say, who do that which is good, or righteous. (O, TA.)
mufotaEalN A writing forged, or falsified. (Mgh.)
And Poetry composed with originality, not in imitation of any model. (TA.)

jaMCa biQlomufotaEali, meaning It produced a grievous, or distressing, effect, (K, TA,) is a phrase mentioned by IAar, as used by Ed-Dubeyree when asked respecting a wound that he had received and that rendered him sleepless, and as used by him in respect of anything [unprecedented]: thus one says, EacRabaniI wajaEN OasoharaniI fajaMCa biQlomufotaEali i. e. [A malady that rendered me sleepless, tormented me,] and produced pain that had not been known before. (TA.)

1. faEuma, aor.
faEuma
, inf. n. faEaAmapN and fuEuwmapN, It was, or became, full; said of the saAEid [or fore arm]; (S, K;) and of a vessel. (K.)
And faEumato, said of a woman, She was, or became, full-formed, and thick in her shank. (K.)
See also 4, in three places.
2: see what next follows.

4. AfEm; [like OafoOama;] (S, K;) and so Afgm; (K in art. fgm;) as also fERm↓; (thus in some of the copies of the K;) or faEama↓, (thus accord. to other copies of the K and accord. to the TA,) aor.
faEama
, inf. n. faEomN; (TA;) He filled a vessel; (S, K, TA;) and exceeded the usual degree, or strove, or laboured, or did not fall short of what was requisite, in filling it. (TA.)

And OafoEamotu Albayota biriyHi AlEuwdi [I filled the house, or chamber, or tent, with the odour of aloes-wood]. (S.) It is said in a trad., lawo Oano QmoraOapF mina AlHuwri AlEiyna OaXorafato laOafoEamato maA abyona AlsRamaMCi waAlOaroDi riyHa Almisoki i. e. [If a woman (or Paradise) of those having eyes like the eyes of gazelles rose into view,] she would fill [the space between the heaven and the earth with the odour of musk]: thus related: and also laOafogamato, and lafagamato: but Az says that the right relation is lAfEmt, with E. (TA in this art. and in art. fgm.) And one says, AfEm Almisoku Albayota The musk filled with its odour, (S,) or perfumed, (K,) [the house, or chamber, or tent.]

And AfEm AlrRajula He filled the man with anger; (S, TA;) mentioned by Az on the authority of Aboo-Turáb: (TA:) or he angered him: or he filled his nose with odour, (K, TA,) i. e. with sweet odour: (TA:) as also faEimahu↓ and faEamahu↓, aor. of both
faEama
, (K, TA,) inf. n. faEomN; but better known with the pointed g. (TA.)
And AfEmhu and Afgmhu He filled him with joy, or happiness. (Aboo-Turáb, TA.)
12. AifoEawoEama It became full, and overflowed. (K.)
And AfEwEm TiybFA It (a house, or chamber, or tent,) became filled with perfume. (TA.)

faEomN Full; applied in this sense to a saAEid [or fore arm]; (S, K;) and to a vessel; as also faEomalN↓, in which the l is augmentative: (K:) and full of flesh; applied to the place of the anklet. (TA.) It is said of the Prophet, in a trad., kaAna faEoma AlOawoSaAl i. e. He was full in respect of the limbs. (TA.) And one says AimoraOapN faEomapN A woman full-formed, and thick in her shank. (K.) And HaADirN faEomN A [great] tribe filled with its people. (TA.) [See also mufoEamN: and see OafoEamu.]
And A species of tree: or the rose. (K.)
faEomalN: see the next preceding paragraph.
OafoEamu Full [like faEomN]: or overflowing by reason of fulness. (TA.)

mufoEamN Filled; applied in this sense to a skin for water or milk; as also mufoOamN: but as to mafoEuwmN↓, IAar asserts that he had not heard it except in a verse of Kutheiyir: Az, however, mentions it as signifying full [like faEomN], applied to a river, or rivulet: and Aboo-Sahl cites an ex. of it from the verses of the Fs as signifying full of flesh. (TA.)

The phrase sayolN mufoEamN may be of the same category as hamRN naASibN [for hamRN cuw naSabK], the meaning being A torrent having the quality of filling; though the possessive epithet in most instances has the form of the act. part. n., such as TaAliqN [for caAta TalaAqK] and muroDiEN [for caAtu raDiyEK]: or it may be that mafoEamN in this case is expressive of muchness, or abundance, like the latter word in the phrase XiEorN XaAEirN and in mawotN maAYitN. (Ham p. 106.)
mafoEuwmN: see the next preceding paragraph.
1. faEaA XayoYFA i. q. ftth [so in my original, app., if not a mistranscription, fatRatahu i. e. He crumbled a thing much]; said of a man. (TA.)
2. fERI, inf. n. tafoEiyapN, He branded a camel with a mark in the form of the viper (AlOafoEaI). (TA.)
4. AfEI He (a man) became possessed of [or characterized by] evil after good or goodness. (TA.)

5. tfERI He (a man, S) became like the viper (AlOafoEaI, S, K) in evil: (S, TA:) or, as in the A, he made himself to resemble the viper (taXRabaha biAlOafoEaI) in the evilness of his disposition. (TA.)
faAEK Angry and foaming [with anger]. (IAar, M, K.)
And [the fem.] faAEiyapN A woman (TA) wont to calumniate; syn. namRaAmapN. (K, TA: in the CK AlvRumAmapu is put for AlnRamRaAmapu.)
faAEiyapN [as a subst.] The flower of the HinRaMC [i. e. Lawsonia inermis, or Egyptian privet]: (K:) [said to be] a dial. var. of faAgiyapN [q. v.]. (TA.)

OafoEFI, (S, Msb, K) of the fem. gender, but with tenween, (S, Msb,) because it is a subst., not an epithet; (Msb;) [said in the S and Msb to be like OarowFI; but this is a mistake, for ArwI is without tenween;] or it is an epithet and a subst.; (K, TA;) but mostly a subst.; (TA;) [if used as an epithet, it is without tenween, written OafoEaI, being also of the measure of a verb;] A certain serpent, (S, Msb, K,) of a malignant kind; [i. e. the viper;] also called OufoEuwRN↓, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, AufoEuwAn, which see in what follows,]) occurring in a trad., in which it is said that there is no harm in the killing of the OufoEuwR and the HuduwR by the muHorim, the [final] alif being changed into w in both of these words in the dial. of El-Hijáz: (TA:) it is spotted, black and white; slender in the neck; broad in the head; it is said that it will not quit its place; (TA;) always coiling itself round; and neither antidote nor charm is of any avail against it: (Msb, TA:) sometimes it has two horns [i. e. it sometimes signifies the cerastes, or horned viper]: (TA:) OufofuwaAnN↓ signifies the male: (S, Msb, TA:) [see also xiXaAXN:] the pl. is OafaAEK. (S, Msb, K. * [In the K, the pl. is written OafaAEiI, which, when indeterminate, is wrong.])
[Hence,] by way of comparison [to vipers], (TA,) AlOafaAEiI signifies (tropical:) Certain veins (Euruwq) that branch off from the HaAlibaAni [q. v.]. (K.)
OafoEMCN [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] Sweet, or pleasant, odours. (IAar, M, K.)
OufoEuwRN, and OufoEuwAnN: see OafoEFI.
OaroDN mafoEaApN A land in which are vipers (OafaAEK): or, abounding therewith. (K.)
mufaERFI A camel branded with a mark in the form of the viper (AlOafoEaI): (K:) and [the fem.] mufaERaApN camels (UibilN) branded therewith. (TA.)
mufaERaApN [as a subst.] A brand in the form of the viper (AlOafoEaI). (S, K.)

1. fagara, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
fagara
(Msb, K) and
fagura
, (AZ, K,) inf. n. fagorN (Msb, TA) and fuguwrN, (TA,) He opened his mouth; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also Afgr↓. (Zj, Sgh, K.)

[Also, both verbs, fagara and Afgr↓, He, or it, made, or caused, to open the mouth. And hence,] fagara AlnRajomu, (T, TA,) or AlnRajomu Oafogara↓, (S, O,) i. e., AlRurayRaA, (T, S, O,) The
asterism, meaning the Pleiades, became overhead: [lit., made one to open his mouth:] (T:) this is in the winter: (S, O:) for when the Pleiades are in the midst of the sky, he who looks at them opens his mouth: (T, S, O:) or the Pleiades began to rise [after sunset, so as to be overhead in the middle of the night], in the winter. (TA.)
fagara also signifies It (the mouth) opened; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also Anfgr↓: (K:) and the latter is said of a blossom, or flower, in the same sense. (S, Msb, TA.)

And fagarati AlsRinRu (assumed tropical:) The tooth showed its point; as though it broke forth to grow: but some say that its f is substituted for v, and Az inclines to think so [though vagara differs much in meaning from fagara]. (TA.)
4: and 7: see 1; the former in three places.
huwa waAsiEu fagori Alfami He is wide in the opening of the mouth. (Lth, O, K.)
And accord. to Lth, (O,) fagarN signifies also A rose when it opens: (O, K:) but it is thought by Az to be, in this sense, a mistake for fagowN, with w. (O.)
wulida biQlofagorapi He was born at the commencement of the rising of the Pleiades [after sunset]; (O, K;) which is in the winter. (TA.) See 1.
fugorapN The mouth of a valley: pl. fugarN. (O, K.)
TaEonapN fagaAri, the latter word like qaTaAmi, [A spearwound, or the like,] that passes through. (O, K.)

faAgirN, an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, (TA,) A [certain] duwayobRap [i. e. small animal, or small creeping thing, or insect], (O, K, TA,) always opening its mouth: (O, TA:) and another, black and white in the Oanof [or snout], that stings men. (TA.)

faAgirapN A sort of perfume: (S, K, TA:) or (K, TA) the roots of the [lotus called] nayoluwfar [q. v.] (S, K, TA) of India: (S, TA:) or the kabaAbap [or cubeb] (K, TA) of China; because, when a man eats it, he opens his mouth. (TA.)
mafogarapN A wide tract of land. (S, K.)
And An opening, or a hollow, in a mountain, smaller than a kahof. (K.)
fagofuwriIRN [China-ware, or porcelain,] the [sort of] xazaf that is brought from China; so called from fagofuwr, [the title of] the king of China: vulgarly farofuwriI. (TA in art. fr.)

1. fagamahu AlTiybu, (S, K,) aor.
fagama
, inf. n. fagomN and fuguwmN, (K,) The perfume stopped the air-passages of his nose. (S, K.)
And fagamati AlrRaAYiHapu AlsRudRapa The odour opened the obstruction of the nose: thus the verb has two contr. significations. (K.)
See also a trad. cited in art. fEm, conj. 4.

fagama said of a rose, or flower, (S, TA,) aor.
fagama
, inf. n. fuguwmN, (TA,) It opened; as also tfgRm↓. (S, TA.)
fagama, (S, K, TA,) inf. n. fagomN; (TA;) and fAgm↓, (S, * K, TA,) inf. n. figaAmN (S, TA) and mufaAgamapN; (S;) He kissed (S, K, TA) him, or it, (S,) or a woman. (K, TA.)
And fagama said of a kid, (K, TA,) inf. n. fagomN, (TA,) He sucked (K, TA) the dug of his mother. (TA.)

fagima bihi, (S, K,) aor.
fagama
, (K,) inf. n. fagamN, (S,) He was, or became, attached to it, fond of it, or eagerly desirous of it. (S, K.) And fagamN Alkalobi signifies The dog's being attached, or accustomed, or habituated, to the chase. (TA.)
And fagima biAlmakaAni, (K, TA,) inf. n. fagamN, (TA,) He resided, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place; and kept, or clave, to it; (K, TA;) not quitting it. (TA.)
3: see the preceding paragraph.
4. Afgm He filled a vessel: (K:) and so AfEm. (TA.)
And It filled its place with its odour; (K;) as also AfEm [q. v.]. (TA.)
5: see 1.
7. Anfgm, said of a zukaAm [or defluxion from the head], It was, or became, removed, cleared away, or dispelled; syn. Ainofaraja; (K;) as also Aftgm↓. (TA.)
8: see what next precedes.

fagomN What one extracts from the interstices of his teeth, (K, TA,) of what has clung thereto. (TA.) It is said in a trad., kuluwA Alwagoma waQToraHuwA Alfagoma [Eat ye the wgm and throw ye away the fgm]; in which, accord. to IAth, by the fgm is meant what is expl. above; and by the wgm, what falls, portion after portion, of the food: but some, he adds, say that the converse is the case. (TA.)

fugomN and fugumN↓ The mouth, altogether: or the chin with the two lateral portions of its jaw; (K, TA; [i. e. bilaHoyayohi; for which the CK has bliHoyatihi;]) and so fuqomN: (TA:) or, accord. to Sh, fugomN signifies the nose: but accord. to Kr, it is fagomN↓ that has this meaning. (TA.) Oaxaca bifugomihi, a phrase mentioned by AZ, is expl. as meaning He took hold of his chin together with the two lateral portions of its jaw: or, accord. to Sh, it means he took hold of his nose: (TA:) or it means (assumed tropical:) he distressed, afflicted, troubled, or molested, him. (K, TA.)
fagamN: see the next preceding paragraph.

huwa fagimN bihi (S, TA) and bihi mufogamN↓ (K, TA) He is attached to it, fond of it, or eagerly desirous of it. (S, K, TA.) And kalobN fagimN EalaI AlSRayodi [A dog attached, &c., or accustomed, or habituated, (see 1,) to the chase]: (S:) or kalobN fagimN [alone] a dog eagerly desirous of the chase. (TA.)
fugumN: see fugomN.
fagomapu AlTRiybi The odour of perfume: (S, TA:) and so fagowatuhu. (TA.) And fagomapu riyHi Alxamori The fragrance of the odour of wine]. (Z, TA voce EaSofapN.)
mufoguwmN: see fagimN.
mafoguwmN A thing perfumed with aromatics. (TA.)
And [A man] affected with a zukaAm [or defluxion from the head]. (TA.)
1. fagaA, (K, TA,) inf. n. fagowN, (TA,) It (a thing) became revealed, disclosed, or divulged; syn. faXaA. (K, TA.)

And Its odour became perceptible, or perceived: occurring in a trad. in this sense, said of saffron: or, as some relate it, the verb in that instance is AfgI↓, which means it flowered, or blossomed. (TA.)
And, said of seed-produce (zaroE), It dried, became dry, or dried up. (K.)

fagiIa, aor. yafogaI, inf. n. fagFA, said of dates (tamor), i. q. HXf, [app. a mistranscription, unless there be such as HaXifa, which seems to be not improbable, as one says tamorN HaXifa, and HaXafN also; but it can hardly be doubted that the meaning is, They became bad, such as are termed HaXifN or HaXafN, or, which is nearly the same, such as are termed fagFA]: so says Aboo-'Alee El-Kálee. (TA.)
4. AfgI It (a plant, S, [app., accord. to the K, the plant HinRaMC,]) put forth its faAgayp [i. e. flower, or blossom]. (S, K.) See also 1.
Afgt AlnRaxolapu The palm-tree became in a bad, or corrupt, state [with respect to its fruit, as is implied in the S: i. e. bore dates such as are termed gafFA]. (S, K.)

And [hence, app.,] AfgI (said of a man, TA) He became poor after being rich: and He became ugly after being handsome: and He rebelled after being obedient: (K, TA:) all from IAar: as though his state became bad, or corrupt, like as do unripe dates. (TA.)
And, said of a man, He kept constantly to the eating of fagFA, (K, TA.) i. e. unripe dates in an altered state. (TA.)
And AfgI fulaAnFA He angered such a one. (K, TA.) One says, maAAlRaciI OafogaAka [What is it that angered thee? or, hath angered thee?]. (TA.)
fagowN: see faAgiyapN.

fagFA [or fagFI] i. q. gafFA [or gafFI] in its several meanings (K, TA) that have been mentioned [in art. gfw and gfI]: and among these it has that of The bad of anything. (TA.) And The [refuse termed] HuvaAlap [q. v.] of wheat. (TA.) And A dust that comes upon unripe dates, spoiling them, and rendering them [in the skin] like the wings of the [locusts, or the like, called] janaAdib [pl. of junodab]. (TA.) And Unripe dates [themselves] (S, TA) such as are bad and mugobarR [i. e. of a hue like dust]; (S;) or such as are mutagayRir [i. e. altered for the worse]. (TA.)
And fagaA AlUibili The small, or young, of camels. (TA.)

And accord. to the K, AlfagaA signifies AlElbp wAljfnpwamayalN fiy Alfami; but this is a mistake; correctly it signifies mayalN fiI Alfami waAlEulobapi waAljafonapi, meaning fiI AlEulobapi waAljafonapi [i. e. A distortion in the mouth, and in the kinds of bowl called Eulobap and jafonap], as expl.
by ISd: Kr says that it signifies a certain malady, which ISd thinks to be a distortion in the mouth, an explanation given by IAar. (TA.)
fagowapu AlTRiybi The odour of perfume; like fagomatuhu: (TA in art. fgm:) or the state of spreading of the odour of perfume. (TA in the present art.)

faAgiyapN and fagowN↓ The flower of the HinRaMC [i. e. Lawsonia inermis, or Egyptian privet]; (Fr, S, K;) as also faAEiyapN: (K in art. fEw or fEI:) or both signify the flower, or blossom, of anything [i. e. of any plant, or, app., of any fragrant plant: see Ham p. 713]: or, as is said in a trad., the fAgyp is the prince, or chief, of the sweet-smelling plants of Paradise: Sh says that Alfagowu↓ signifies nawor wraAYiHap TayRibap [a flower, or blossom; and a sweet odour: but I think that we should read naworN cuw raAYiHapK TayRibapK a sort of flower, or blossom, having a sweet odour]: and IAar says that the fAgyp is the best and the most fragrant of sweetsmelling plants: (TA:) or it is the flower produced by a branch of the HinRaMC that has been planted inverted, and which is sweeter than [that of] the [common] HinRaMC. (K.)

1. faqOa AlEayona, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) aor.
faqaAa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. faqoCN, (S, Mgh, O,) He put out the eye; or blinded it; or made it to sink in its socket; syn. baxaqahaA; (Lh, S, O, K;) as also fqROhA↓, (S, O, K,) inf. n. tafoqiYapN: (S, O:) or, accord. to the Msb, baxaSahaA; which is said by Es-Sarakustee to mean he put his finger into the eye and pulled it out; and by IKtt to mean he extinguished its light; and by some to mean he slit it, or rent it: (TA:) or he slit, or rent, the portion of the eye that is surrounded by the white thereof: (Mgh:) or i. q. qalahaA; (K, TA;) i. e. [he pulled out the eye; or], as some say, he pulled out the portion of the eye which is surrounded by the white, and with which one sees: (TA: [and the like is said in the Mgh in explanation of AlqaloEu, but this is there said to differ from AlfaqoCu:]) or, as some say, he put his finger into the eye and so slit, or rent, it: (TA:) or he broke, or ruptured, the eye; syn. kasarahaA; and so Albavorapa [the pimple, or the small, or purulent, pustule]; and the like of these: (K: [and to all of these the two other explanations mentioned above as from the K are likewise there, improperly, made to relate:]) this last explanation, in the K, is said by MF to be unknown; but it is mentioned in the A and L, and by more than one of the leading lexicologists: (TA:) [accord. to Mtr,] faqaOotu Albavorapa means I slit the pimple, &c., or rent it [open]. (Mgh, Msb.) Among the Arabs in the Time of Ignorance, when a man's camels amounted to a thousand, he put out (faqaOa) an eye of one of them (a baEiyr), and set it free to pasture where it would, and made no use of it. (TA.)

faqaOa QllRehu Eanoka Eayona AlkamaAli is a tropical saying [app. meaning May God prevent from seeing thee the fatal eye: the term Eyn AlkmAl being applied to an eye believed to have the power of killing by its glance]. (A, TA.)
And faqaOa naAZirayohi, (O, K,) likewise said to be a tropical phrase, (TA,) means (tropical:) He dispelled his anger. (O, K.)

And faqaOEayonahu also means [sometimes] (tropical:) He struck him; or struck him vehemently with a broad thing, or with anything; or slapped him with his hand: or he was rough, rude, or ungentle, to him in speech. (TA in art. Eyn.)

And faqaOati AlbuhomaI, inf. n. fuquwoCN, (O, K, TA,) or, accord. to the L, faqoCN, (TA,) The [barleygrass termed] bhmI was rendered dusty by rain, or by a torrent, so that the cattle would not eat it until it became clean: (O, K, TA:) and in like manner one says of any plant. (O, TA.) [See also 1 in art. fqO.]
And, as some say, (TA,) or tfqROt↓, (S, O, TA,) (tropical:) The envelopes [or glumes] of the buhomaI burst open so as to disclose (S, O, TA) its fruit [or seeds], (S, O,) or its flower. (TA.)
2: see 1, first sentence.

laA yufaqRiYu AlbayoDa, (IJ, TA,) or AlbayoDa laA yatafaqRaOu↓, (A, TA,) (assumed tropical:) [He will not break, or burst, eggs, or the eggs,] is said of a weak and quiet man, (IJ, TA,) or of an impotent man. (A, TA.)
4. AfqO His breast, or chest, became depressed (Ainoxasafa), in consequence of a malady, or an accident; (IAar, O, TA;) said of a man. (IAar, O.) [But see faqaON and OafoqaOu.]
5: see 7, in two places.

It is also said of the corpse that has lain long upon the field of battle, meaning It rent, or burst. (Mgh.) And one says, tafaqRaOotu XaHomFA (assumed tropical:) [I almost burst with fat]: (S:) [and] tafaqRaOati AlXRaApu XaHomFA [the sheep, or goat, almost burst with fat]: (O:) XHmA being in the accus. case as a specificative. (S, O.) And Oakala HatRaI kaAdabaTonuhu yatafaqRaOu (assumed tropical:) He ate until his belly almost burst. (A, TA.) And Oakala HatRaI kaAda yanofaqiYu↓ (assumed tropical:) [He ate until he almost burst]. (O: in the TA with bakaI [he wept] in the place of Akl, and with baTonuhu after ynfqY.)
And tafaqRaOati AlsRaHaAbapu Eano maAYihaA (tropical:) The cloud burst with its water. (S, * O, * TA.)
See also 1, last sentence.
And see 2.

7. AnfiqOt AlEayonu and tfqROt↓, quasi-pass. vs., [the former] of faqaOa AlEayona and [the latter] of faqRaOahaA as expl. in the first sentence of this art.; (K, TA;) [thus signifying The eye became put out; or blinded; or made to sink in its socket: &c.: or it broke; or became broken, or ruptured:] and so Albavorapu [the pimple, or the small, or purulent, pustule]: and the like of these: (K, TA:) the former, (Mgh,) or each, (Msb,) said of a bavorap, means it [broke, or] rent, or burst: (Mgh, Msb:) and thus tfqRO↓ said of [a pustule such as is termed] a dumRal, (S, Mgh, O,) and of [such as is termed] a qaroH. (S, O.)
See also 5.

8. AftqO Alxaroza is expl. in the K as meaning OaEaAda Ealayohi wajaEala bayona Alkulobatayoni kulobapF OuxoraI; [and in like manner in the O, except that the latte has Alkuloyatayoni and kuloyapF; and so have several copies of the K;] but this meaning is assigned by Lh to AqtfO, which see for a fuller explanation. (TA.)

faqoCN (S, O, K) and (O, K) accord. to Ks and Fr (O) fuqoOapN↓ [in the CK fuqaOp] and faqaOapN↓ (O, K) and in some copies of the K fuqRaMCap↓ (TA) and faAqiyaMCu↓, (K,) originally faAqiYaMCu, (TA,) The [membrane called] saAbiyaMC (S, O, K) which comes forth EalaI raOosi Alwaladi [upon the head of the young one, meaning at the time of bringing forth,] (S, O,) or which rends open from off the head of the young one [at the time of bringing forth]: (K:) pl. [of the first] fuquwCN: (TA:) or a small, thin, piece of skin, which is upon the nose of the young one, and which, if not removed from it, (O, K,) at the birth, (O,) causes its death, (O, K,) is thus termed, (K,) or is termed fuqoOapN↓, by IAar: (O:) or, accord. to As, the water [or fluid] that is EalaI raOosi Alwaladi [app. meaning that is discharged at the time of the birth (see 2 in the arts. rbq and rmd)]: and accord. to IAar, the water [or fluid] that is in the maXiymap [or membrane enclosing the fœtus in the womb] is termed faqoCN and suxodN and suxotN and nuxoTN: (TA:) it is also said that faqowN signifies a certain white thing that comes forth from the woman or the she-camel in parturition, and which is an envelope wherein is much water or fluid; mentioned by A 'Obeyd as with hemz [i. e. written faqoCN], and said by him to be the saAbiyaMC [q. v.]. (TA in art. fqw.)

And faqoCN signifies also A small hollow, or cavity, in stone, or a rugged place, that collects water: (K:) or it is [a hollow, or cavity,] like a xuforap or juforap, in the midst of a [stony place such as is termed] HarRp, (Sh, O, TA,) or in the midst of a mountain: (TA:) and faqiIoCN↓ signifies the same: (K:) the pl. (of the former, O, or of the latter, TA) is fuqoMnN. (O. TA.)
faqaON A protuberance, or swelling out, (O, TA,) of the back, (O,) or of the breast, or chest. (TA.) [But see 4, and see also OafoqaOu.]
fuqoOapN: see faqoCN, in two places.

Also (tropical:) A cloud in which is neither thunder nor lightning, and the rain of which is mutaqaArib [app. meaning drawing near: as though likened to the membrane thus called]. (O, * TA. [In the former written, in this instance, faqoOapN, which I think to be a mistranscription by the copyist.])
faqaOapN: see faqoCN.
faqoOaI: see the next paragraph.

faqiIoCN A he-camel affected with a disease termed Haqowap [q. v.], in consequence of which he voids not his urine nor his dung; (O, K; *) and sometimes, or often, his veins and his flesh become choked with blood, and swollen; and if slaughtered and cooked, the cooking-pot becomes full of blood; and sometimes, or often, his stomach becomes so much inflated, or swollen, that it rends, or bursts: and it is likewise applied to a she-camel: (O:) and faqoOaI↓ signifies the same applied to a she-camel. (K.)

Also (i. e. faqiIoCN) The disease above-
mentioned, itself. (O, K.)
See also faqoCN, latter sentence.
fuqRaMCapN: see faqoCN.
faAqiyMCu: see faqoCN.
OafoqaOu Having a protuberant breast, or chest. (IAar, TA in art. fsO.) [But see 4, and see also faqaON.]
mufaqRYapN Valleys, or water-courses, or torrent-beds, (OawodiyapN,) that cleave the earth. (O, K.)
1. faqaHa: see 2.
Said of a plant, It became tall, or full-grown, and blossomed. (K.)
faqaHa fulaAnFA He, or it, hit, or struck, such a one in his faqoHap [q. v.]. (K.)

And faqaHa AlXRaIoCa, (K,) aor.
faqaHa
, inf. n. faqoHN, (TA,) i. q. safRahu [i. e. He took the thing into his mouth, not moistened,] like as one does medicine: (K, TA:) of the dial. of ElYemen. (TA.)

2. fqRH, (S, K,) inf. n. tafoqiyHN, (S,) He (a whelp) opened his eyes for the first time; (S, K;) as also faqaHa↓, aor.
faqaHa
, (K,) inf. n. faqoHN. (TA.) It is said in a trad., faqRaHonaA waSaOoSaOotumo (S, TA) (tropical:) We have opened our eyes for the first time, and ye have kept your eyes closed; (TA;) meaning the truth has become manifest to us, and ye have been blind to it; (AO, A, * TA;) or we have seen our right course, and ye have not seen [yours]. (IB, TA.) And fqRH AlXRajaru The trees burst their buds, and made the extremities of their leaves to appear. (L.)

5. tfqRH It opened; syn. tafatRaHa: (K:) it is said in this sense of a rose, (S, A, TA,) and of any flower, or blossom: (TA:) some say that it signifies tftRH absolutely: others, peculiarly fI AlklAm. (Az, as quoted in the L. [See tafatRaHa fiI AlkalaAmi (a well-known phrase) in art. ftH: but fI klAm in the present case appears, from what precedes, to be evidently a mistranscription for fiI AlkimaAmi, i. e., in relation to calyxes.])
6. tfAqHwA They put [or turned] their backs one towards another; (S, K;) [from faqoHapN, q. v.;] like as you say taZaAharuwA [and tadaAbaruwA] and [in the contr. sense] taqaAbaluwA. (S, TA.)
faqoHapN: see fuqRaAHN.

Also The anus: (S, K:) because it opens in the case of need: (Ham p. 677:) or a wide, or an ample, anus: (K, MF:) or a wide dubur: or a dubur with what it comprises: and afterwards, by reason of frequency of usage, applied to signify any dubur: (L:) pl. fiqaAHN. (S, K.)
And The palm of the hand; as also faqaAHapN↓: (K:) of the dial. of El-Yemen: so called because of its width. (TA.)
And The napkin (minodiyl) of AlUiHoraAm [i. e., which is used by one performing the rites of the HajR or of the Eumorap]: (K:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)
faqaAHapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

fuqRaAHN A certain herb, (K, TA,) resembling the OuqoHuwaAn [or chamomile] in its growth and its place of growth; n. un. with p: it is one of the plants growing in the sands; and it is said that its flower is more contracted than that of the chamomile, and that the dust, or earth, sticks to it as it does to the [herb called] HamaSiyS: (TA:) or the flower of the Uicoxir [or juncus odoratus]; (S, K, TA;) said by Az to be a sort of perfume, sometimes put into medicine, called fuqRaAHu AlUicoxiri; and it is the flower of the Uicoxir when its calyx opens: (TA:) or the flower, or blossom, of any plant, (K, TA,) when it opens, whatever be its lawon [i. e. colour, or kind]; (TA;) as also faqoHapN↓, (K, TA,) thus with fet-h and sukoon. (TA. [Written by Golius fuqoHapN.])
Also (tropical:) A woman of goodly, or beautiful, make, or form. (Kr, K, TA.)
EalaI fulaAnK HulRapN fuqRaAHiyRapN Upon such a one is a HulRapN [q. v.] of the colour of the rose when it is about to open. (S.)
huwa mutafaqRiHN lilXRarRi (assumed tropical:) He is in a state of preparation for evil, or mischief.

1. faqadahu, (S, A, MA, Mgh, O, L, Msb, K,) aor.
faqida
, (S, A, O, &c.,) inf. n. faqodN and fiqodaAnN (S, MA, O, L, Msb, K) and fuqodaAnN (S, O, F) and fuquwdN; (IDrd, O, L, K;) and Aftqdhu↓; (S, A, MA, Mgh, O;) He found it not, (L, TA,) lost it, (MA, PS, &c.,) saw it not, (JK in explanation of the latter verb,) [missed, or failed of finding or seeing, it,] it was, or became, absent from him, (Mgh,) or he had it not, was destitute of it, was without it, lacked it, or wanted it, syn. Eadimahu; (Msb, L, K;) but accord. to Er-Rághib, Alfaqodu has a more special signification than AlEadamu, this latter being the contr. of Alwujuwdu; (TA;) [whereas] Alfaqodu [as inf. n. of fuqida, though often used as meaning the being non-existent, properly] signifies the thing's being absent from the range of perception by sense so that its place is not known. (Bd in xii. 71.) [fuqida signifies It was not found, was lost, was not seen, &c.] It is related of Abu-dDardà that he said, yafoqido mano yatafaqRado↓, [lit. He who seeks will not find,] meaning he who seeks after good in mankind will not find it; for he saw good to be rare in mankind: or he who seeks to acquaint himself with the circumstances of men will not find what will please him. (L.)

4. Oafoqadahu QllRehu UiyRaAhu God caused him to lose, or fail of finding, him, or it. (L, K.) One says, Oafoqadaka QllRehu kulRa jamiymK [May God cause thee to lose every relation, or loved and loving relation]. (A.) [Or] AlUifoqaAdu is not of established authority: as to the saying Aljunuwnu yufoqidu Xahowapa AljimaAEi [meaning Insanity causes to lose, or annuls, the desire of coïtus], the correct word is yuEodimu or yuziylu. (Mgh.)

5. tfqRdhu He sought it, or sought for it or after it; or did so leisurely or repeatedly; (A, * Mgh, L;) as also Aftqdhu↓: (Mgh, L:) or he sought it, or sought for it or after it, it being absent from him; (S, O, L, Msb, K;) as also Aftqdhu↓: (K:) or he sought, or sought leisurely or repeatedly, to obtain knowledge of it, having lost it: so accord. to Er-Rághib and many others; but this expression and tEahRadahu are used, by some, each in the place of the other, and the latter, accord. to Er-Rághib and many others, [properly] signifies he sought, or sought leisurely or repeatedly, to obtain knowledge of it, having known it before. (MF.) You say, maA tafaqRadotuhu munocu Qfotaqadotuhu↓, meaning mnc faqadotuhu [i. e. I have not sought for, or after, him, or it, since I lost him, or it. (B, TA.) See also 1, last sentence.
[Also He investigated it.]
6. tfAqdwA means faqada baEoDuhumo baEoDFA [i. e. They lost one another]. (S, O, K.)
8: see 1:
and see also 5, in three places.

Alfaqodu, (O, K,) by Az, (K,) or in a number of the copies of the work of Az, (O,) erroneously written Alfaqadu, (O, K,) A certain plant, (K,) resembling the [species of cuscuta, or dodder, called] kaXuwv: (TA:) and a beverage prepared from raisins or honey or [the plant] kXwv, as also Alfuqodudu↓: (K:) or, as AHn says, a certain plant which is thrown into the beverage of honey, which beverage consequently becomes strong, and is then called Alfaqodu: he says, the faqod is what is called in Pers. fanojanokuXot: IAar says, Alfiqodapu↓ [or AlfaqodapukXwv? then. un.] is the kXwv: and a beverage prepared from raisins and honey; and it is said that a beverage (nabiyc) is made of honey, and then the faqod is thrown into it, and causes it to become strong: so says Lth: and he says that the faqod is a plant resembling the kXwv: and Alfuqodudu↓ is the nabiyc of the kXwv. (O.)
Alfiaqodapu: see the next preceding paragraph.
Alfuqodudu: see Alfaqodu, in two places.

faqiydN and mafoquwdN↓ signify the same, (O, Msb, K,) [Not found, lost, not seen, missed, non-existent,] absent from one, (Mgh in explanation of the latter,) not had, lacking or lacked, wanting or wanted. (Msb, K.) One says, maAta gayora faqiydK walaA HamiydK, (A, K,) and walaA maHomuwdK gayora mafoquwdK↓, (A,) [He died unmissed and unpraised; or,] without his loss being cared for [and without being praised]. (A, K.)

faAqidN [as act. part. n. of 1 signifies Not finding a thing, losing it, not seeing it, missing it, not having it, being destitute of it, lacking it, or wanting it; or having failed to find it, having lost it, or having failed to see it.

And hence,] A woman who is bereft of her child [by death]: (A 'Obeyd:) or who loses (tafoqidu) her husband or child: (S, O:) or whose husband, or child, (L, K, TA,) or relation, or loved and loving relation, (TA,) has died: (L, K, TA:) or who marries after the death of her husband. (Lth, L, K.) The Arabs say, laA tatazawRajanRa faAqidFA watazawRajo muTalRaqapF [Do
not thou marry a woman whose husband has died, but [rather] marry thou a divorced woman]. (Lh, L.)

And in like manner, (O,) it is applied also to a she-gazelle, (S, O, L,) and to a cow [app. a wild cow], (O, L, K,) as also faAqidapN, (O,) meaning Whose young one has been devoured by a beast, or bird, of prey; (O, L, K;) and to a pigeon (HamaAmap) likewise. (L.)
mafoquwdN: see faqiydN, in two places.

1. faqara, (TA,) [aor., app.,
faqura
and
faqira
,] inf. n. faqorN, (O, K, TA,) He dug the ground; (O, * K, * TA;) as also fqRr↓, (TA,) inf. n. tafoqiyrN. (K, TA.) And He dug a well to draw forth the water. (TA.)

And faqorN signifies The boring, or perforating, of beads for the purpose of stringing; (K;) [as also tafoqiyrN; for one says] faqRarotu↓ [as well as faqarotu], meaning I bored, or perforated, beads. (S.)
And The act of cleaving, slitting, or rending. (O.) [See also 8.]

And faqara Oanofa AlbaEiyri, (S, O, K, *) [and faqara AlbaEiyra also, as is indicated in the TA,] aor.
faqura
and
faqira
, inf. n. faqorN, (K,) He made an incision in the nose [or muzzle] of the camel, (S, O, K, TA,) the beast being refractory, (TA,) with an iron instrument, (S, O, TA,) so as to reach to the bone, (K, TA,) or nearly so, (TA,) then put upon the place of the incision the [cord called] jariyr, (S, O, TA, *) with a [string such as is termed] watar wound upon it, (S, O,) to render him tractable, or to train him, thereby: (S, O, K, TA:) sometimes the refractory camel has three incisions made in his muzzle; and when his owner desires to render him tractable, and to prevent him from being brisk above measure, he puts the jryr upon the incision that is next to his lip, and in consequence he governs him as he will; and if he be between the refractory and the tractable, he puts the jryr upon the intermediate incision, and in consequence he exceeds in his pace; and if he desire that he should stretch forth and go without inconvenience to his owner, he puts the jryr upon the uppermost incision. (Aboo-Ziyád, L.) [The incision above mentioned is termed fuqorapN↓.

Hence, app., by a tropical usage, faqara signifies (assumed tropical:) He stigmatized a man: Freytag has mentioned it as occurring in the Deewán of the Hudhalees, and meaning “ satyra perstrinxit eius vitia commemorans aliquem. ”]

[faqarahu, aor.
faqura
, inf. n. faqorN, He, or it, broke the faqaAr (or vertebræ) of his back.

Hence the phrase,] faqaratohu AlfaAfqirapu, (S, O,) or AldRaAhiyapu, aor.
faqura
, inf. n. faqorN, (Msb,) [lit.] The calamity broke the vertebræ of his back: (S, O:) [meaning] the calamity befell him. (Msb.)

faqura, with damm, [aor.
faqura
,] He had a complaint of his vertebræ: and faqira, aor.
faqara
, inf. n. faqarN, He had a complaint of his vertebræ arising from fracture or disease. (Msb.)
faqura or faqira in the sense of Aifotaqara: see 8.
2: see 1, first and third sentences.

fqRr lilowadiyRapi, (S, TA, *) or lilofasiylapi, (K, TA,) inf. n. tafoqiyrN; [and accord. to Golius, tfqRr↓, but for this I have not found any authority;] He dug a hollow such as is termed faqiyr [q. v.] for the shoot, or offset, of a palm-tree. (S, K, TA.)
And fuqRira, said of anything, It was incised, or notched; and impressed, or marked. (TA.)
Lth has erroneously assigned to tafoqiyrN, a meaning belonging to taqofiyzN, q. v. (TA.)

4. Afqr He (a colt) became fit for riding upon his faqaAr [or vertebræ]; like Oarokaba: (O:) or he (a colt, Msb), or it (the back of a colt, L), became [strong in the vertebræ and] fit for being ridden. (L, Msb.)

Afqrhu naAqatahu, (S, O,) or baEiyrahu, (ISk, K,) or Zahora baEiyrihi, (TA,) or baEiyrFA, (Mgh,) or daAbRatahu, (A 'Obeyd, TA,) or Almuhora, (Msb,) He lent him the vertebræ [meaning the back] of his she-camel, that he might ride thereon: (S, O:) and he lent him the back of his camel (ISk, K, TA) during a journey, (ISk, TA) for carrying a burden, and for riding, (ISk, K, TA,) to be returned afterwards: (ISk, TA:) and he lent him a camel, that he might ride thereon; from faqaAr signifying the “ vertebræ ” of the back: (Mgh:) and he lent him his beast to ride as long as he pleased during a journey and then to return it to him: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) and he lent him the colt to ride upon its vertebræ [or back]. (Msb.)
Hence, Afqrhu OaroDahu (tropical:) He lent him his land for sowing. (TA, from a trad.)

Oafoqaraka AlSRayodu means The object of the chase has enabled thee to have its vertebræ within thy power; therefore shoot it, or shoot at it: (O, TA:) or has enabled thee to have its side [which is sometimes termed fuqor] within thy power: (K:) or has become near to thee. (TA.) [The Khaleefeh] El-Weleed the son of Yezeed the son of 'AbdEl-Melik is related to have said, Oafoqara baEoda masolamapa AlSRayodu limano ramaI i. e. The object of the chase has enabled the shooter at it to have its vertebræ within his power after Meslemeh; meaning that, since the death of his paternal uncle Meslemeh, the territory of the Muslims had become assailable to him who might attempt it. (TA.)
Afqrhu also signifies He (i. e. God, S, O, K, or a man, Msb) rendered him faqiyr [meaning poor, or needy, &c.]. (S, O, Msb, K.)

maA Oafoqarahu [i. e. How poor, or needy, &c., is he!] and maA OagonaAhu [which has the contr. meaning] are [said to be] anomalous; for their [respective primitive] verbs are Aifotaqara and AisotagonaI, from either of which the verb of wonder is not properly [or regularly] formed. (S, O. [But see 8.])

5. Zahara qabolanaA naAsN yatafaqRaruwna AlEiloma, occurring in a trad., as some relate it, means [There appeared before us men] eliciting what was recondite, or obscure, of knowledge, and opening what was closed thereof; from faqarotu AlbiYora meaning “ I dug the well to draw forth the water: ” but the reading commonly known is [yataqafRaruwna, q. v.,] with the q before the f. (IAth, TA.)
See also 2.
6. tfAqr He feigned the lowliness, or submissiveness, of poverty, humbling, or abasing, himself with men. (K * and TA in art. bOs.)

8. Aftqr He clave, slit, or rent; and opened: [see also 1, fourth sentence:] hence its usage in a trad. of 'Omar, in which, after his saying that Imra-el-Keys was the foremost of the poets, and had made the source of poetry to well forth abundantly to them, [see xasafa,] he is related to have added, waQfotaqara Eano maEAnK EuwrKOaSaHRa baSarK: in saying this, he attributed a sound and an opened sight to the poetry, [which he thus personified,] and in like manner he described obscure and occult meanings by applying to them the epithet Euwr [generally meaning “ blind of one eye ”]: he meant that Imra-el-Keys had made the meanings of poetry clear and perspicuous, and unveiled them, and shunned substitution and obscure diction: Eano with what is [to be understood as] antecedently connected with it occupies the place of a noun in the accus. case as a denotative of state: it is as though he said, fataHa lilXRiEoriOaSaHRa baSarK mujaAwizFA lilomaEaAniI AlEuwrimutaxaTiyFA lahaA [lit. He opened, to poetry, a most sound vision, passing over half-blind meanings]. (O.)

Also, (O,) He was, or became, faqiyr [meaning poor, or needy, &c.]; (S, O, Msb, K, &c.;) and so faqira↓, aor.
faqara
, inf. n. faqarN; (Msb;) and faqura↓, aor.
faqura
; (K;) or they said Aftqr, (Sb, Msb, TA,) like as they said AiXotadRa, (Sb, TA,) but they did not say faqura, (Sb, Msb, TA,) like as they did not say Xaduda, (Sb, TA,) Aftqr serving them instead of faqura; (Msb;) nor did they use any unaugmented form of this verb. (Sb, TA.)
And one says, Aftqr Uilayohi He, or it, wanted, needed, or required, him, or it; [a phrase of frequent occurrence; like faqiyrN Uilayohi;] i. q. AiHotaAja Alyh. (TA in art. Hwj.)
10. Astfqr baEiyrFA [He borrowed, or asked for the loan of, the back of a camel, for carrying a burden or for riding]. (See Oaromalu.)

faqorN and fuqorN↓ signify the same, (S, O, Msb, K,) but the latter is bad, (Lth, TA,) and sometimes they said fuqurN↓, (MF, TA,) Poverty, want, or need; contr. of ginFI: (K:) or the state of a man when he has [only] what suffices for his household, or those who dwell with him and whose maintenance is incumbent on him: (ISd, K:) [other meanings are indicated by explanations of the epithet faqiyrN, q. v.:] mafAaqiru↓ [signifying needs, or wants,] is said by some to be a pl. of faqrN, anomalous, like maXaAbihu [pl. of XabahN] and malaAmiHu [pl. of lamoHapN]: or it may be a pl. of mufoqarN↓, an inf. n. of Oafoqarahu; or pl. of mufoqirN↓; or it has no sing.: (TA:) you say, sadRa QllRehu mafaAqirahu↓ God rendered him, or may God render him, free from want; (S, Msb, K;) [lit.] God supplied, or may God supply, his various needs, or wants. (S, K.)

And faqorN signifies also Anxiety; or disquietude, or trouble, of mind: pl. fuquwrN: (O, K, TA:) one says, XakaI Uilayohi fuquwrahu He complained to him of his anxieties; &c.:
and it means also, his circumstances, and wants: (TA:) [for,] accord. to IAar, the phrase fuquwru AlnRafosi is like XuquwruhaA. (O.)
See also faqorapN.
fuqorN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Also The side: pl. fuqarN, (K, TA,) which is extr. [in respect of analogy]: mentioned by Kr. (TA.) [See Oafoqaraka AlSRayodu.]
faqurN: see faqorapN.
faqirN: see faqiyrN, former half, in two places.
fuqurN: see faqorN.
faqorapN: see faqaArN.

Accord. to the K, it signifies also A certain plant; and its pl. [or rather the coll. gen. n.] is faqorN↓: but the sing. [or n. un.] is correctly faqurapN↓, with fet-h and then damm, mentioned by Sb as a word of a rare form, of which the pl. [or coll. gen. n.] is faqurN↓, as it has no broken pl.; and expl. by Th. (TA.)
fuqorapN A hollow dug in the ground: pl. fuqarN. (O, K, TA.)

And The [incision termed] quromap (IAar, O, TA) that is made in the nose [or muzzle] (IAar, O) of the camel, (IAar, O, TA,) [in order to render him tractable, (see 1, near the beginning,)] after which [if necessary] another is made, [above it,] and then another, until he becomes gentle: (IAar, O:) pl. [of pauc. OafoqurN, occurring in the L, evidently as a pl. of fuqorapN in this sense, and, of mult., but also used as a pl. of pauc.,] fuqarN. (O, TA.) Hence the saying of 'Aacute;ïsheh, in relation to [the murder of] 'Othmán, [app. alluding to its involving three violations, namely, the violation of the sacredness of the city in which it was perpetrated and of the month in which it occurred and of the person of the Khaleefeh,] balagotumo minohu Alfuqara AlvRalaAva, meaning (tropical:) Ye have done to him the like of your deed to the camel above mentioned [upon which ye have inflicted the three fuqar]: thus expl. by AZ. (TA.) Accord. to AHeyth, fuqarN means (assumed tropical:) Great, or grievous, or formidable, events. (O.) And the three fuqaraAt of the son of Adam are said to be (assumed tropical:) The day of birth and the day of death and the day of resurrection. (O.)
Also The part, of a shirt, that is the place into which the head is inserted. (K.)
Also Nearness. (K.) And one says, huwa minRiI fuqorapF, meaning He is near to me. (K, * TA.)
See also mufoqirN.
fiqorapN: see faqaArN.

[Hence] AlfiqaraAtu is a name of (assumed tropical:) The star [or stars] in the xarazaAt [meaning joints of the tail] of Scorpio. (Kzw in his descr. of Scorpio.) And fiqarN signifies (assumed tropical:) Certain ornaments, moulded, or fashioned, in the form of the vertebra of the back: (A, KT, TA, and Har p. 34:) one of which is termed fiqorapN. (Har ibid.)
And hence, (KT,) or as being likened to a vertebra of the back, (S, O, KT,) (tropical:) The best verse in an ode is termed fiqorapN. (S, O, K, KT.)

And hence, as being likened to the best verse in an ode, fiqorahN means (tropical:) (tropical:) Any choice phrase or sentence: (KT:) one says, maA OaHosana fiqara kalaAmihi i. e. [How beautiful are] the points, or points of wit, (sukat [pl. of nukotapN]) of his speech, or language! (A, TA.)
And in like manner it is applied to signify (assumed tropical:) The end [or final word] of every verse of an ode and [of every clause] of a xuTobap [which is in rhyming prose]. (Msb.)
And (assumed tropical:) [A pair of clauses of rhyming prose, both ending with the same rhyme; i. e.] the fiqorap is that which in [rhyming] prose is like the verse in poetry. (Kull p. 208.)
Also A piece of land, such as is termed qaraAH [q. v.], for sowing. (O, K.)

And A thing that serves as a mark, or sign, (Lth, K, TA,) to men contending, or competing, in shooting, or casting, (Lth,) such as a mountain, (K,) or such as a hill, or a hollow dug in the ground, (Lth.) or a hadaf [or butt, &c.], (Lth, K, TA,) and the like: (K, TA:) they say, in such contending or competing, OuraAmiyka mino OadonaI fiqorapK [I will contend, or compete, with thee in shooting, or casting, from the nearest fqrp] and mino OaboEadi fiqorapK [from the furthest fqrp]. (Lth, TA.)
faqurapN: see faqorapN.
fuqoraI [The lending one a camel, &c., to be ridden or to carry a burden;] a subst. [similar to ruqobaI and EumoraI] from Oafoqarahu naAqatahu (S) or baEiyrahu. (K.)

faqaArN The vertebra of the back; (S, * Msb, K;) the bones of the spine, which are set in regular order, one upon another, from the part where is the kaAhil to the Eajob: (K, * TA:) [it is sometimes used as a sing., as in the S and O and K voce TabaqN: but properly] the sing., (Msb, K,) or n. un., (S, TA,) is faqaArapN↓, (S, Msb, K,) for which one should not say fiqaArapN, with kesr: (ISk, Msb:) and fiqorapN↓, of which the pl. is fiqarN and fiqoraAtN and fiqaraAtN and fiqiraAtN, signifies the same as faqaArapN; (S, Msb, K:) as does also faqorapN↓. (K.)
[Hence,] faqaAru AljawozaMCi (assumed tropical:) The three very bright stars [d and e and z] disposed obliquely in the midst of the constellation AljwzMC [i. e. Orion]. (Har p. 456. [See art. jwz.)

And [hence also,] cuw AlfaqaAri (assumed tropical:) the name of A [celebrated] sword of the Prophet, (S, O, K,) and afterwards, of 'Alee: it had previously belonged to El-'As Ibn-Munebbih, who was slain at Bedr, (O, K,) by 'Alee, by whom his sword was given to the Apostle: (O:) accord. to Abu-l-'Abbás [i. e. Th]. it was thus named because there were in it small beautiful hollows [app. meaning small scallops in the edge, such as some modern swords have, for the more easy cleaving of coats of mail]: it is also, accord. to some, called cw AlfiqaAr; but this is said by El-Khattábee to be vulgar. (TA.)
It (i. e. cuwAlfaqaAri) is also used, metaphorically, as meaning (tropical:) The spear. (TA.)

faqiyrN A hollow that is dug around the shoot, or offset, of a palm-tree, when it is planted: (S, O:) or a well [or the like thereof] in which the shoot, or offset, of a palm-tree is planted, (K, TA,) then alluvial soil with dung of camels or the like is pressed down around it: (TA:) pl. fuqurN, with two dammehs: (K, TA:) or this [app. the pl., but accord. to the TA the sing.,] signifies wells, (K, TA,) three, and more, together, (TA,) or communicating, one with another.
