(K, TA.) The sing. signifies also A well: (Mgh, O:) or an old well: (O:) or a well having little water: (TA:) pl. as above. (Mgh.)

And A plain, or soft, place, in which wells are dug forming a regular series. (O, K,) And rakiyRapN faqiyrapN signifies A dug well. (TA.) And faqiyru baniI fulaAnK fiI AlrRakaAyaA is expl. by A 'Obeyd as meaning The share of the sons of such a one of the wells. (TA.)
Also The mouth, (K, TA,) or the place whence the water issues, (S, O, TA,) of a subterranean channel, or conduit: (S, * O, * K, * TA:) pl. as above. (TA.)
And it is said to signify A [hollowed] trunk of a palm-tree, by means of which one ascends to an upper chamber: but the word commonly known in this sense is naqiyrN [q. v.], with n. (IAth, TA.)

As an epithet applied to a camel, it means Having an incision [or two incisions or three] made in his nose [or muzzle] in the manner explained in the first paragraph of this art.; and so mafoquwrN↓. (K, TA.)

Also, applied to a man, (TA,) Having the vertebræ of the back broken; (S, O, K, * TA;) and so faqirN↓ and mafoquwrN↓: (K:) or having a complaint of the vertebræ of his back, arising from fracture or from disease: (Msb:) or having his vertebræ pulled out from his back, so that his spine is interrupted: (T, L:) and faqirN↓, a man having a complaint of his vertebræ: (S, O, TA:) and fqyr and mafoquwrN↓, a man afflicted [lit. having the vertebræ of his back broken] by a calamity. (Msb.)

Hence, as though having the vertebræ of his back broken, (IDrst, TA in art. jbr,) [but said to be irregularly formed from Aifotaqara, like maA Oafoqarahu, q. v.,] Poor: or needy; contr. of ganiIRN; (as implied in the K;) having [only] what suffices for his household, or those who dwell with him and whose maintenance is incumbent an him: (ISd, K:) or one who finds food sufficient to sustain life: (K:) or one who possesses only what is sufficient for life: (ISk, S, K: *) or one whose property is, or has become, little: further expl. in art. skn: (Msb:) or one who has what to eat; (Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà;) differing from misokiynN, which signifies one who possesses nothing; altogether destitute: (Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà, ISk, S, O, K:) or both mean destitute, i. e. possessing nothing: (IAar, S, O:) Aboo-Haneefeh holds the opinion of ISk, (TA,) who cites the following verse from a poem of Er-Rá'ee in praise of 'Abd-El-Melik Ibn-Marwán;

L.foreign: wafoqa AlEiyaAli falamo yutorako lahu sabadu

sense.s:
[As to the fqyr whose milch camel was sufficient for his household, and nothing (more) was left to him:] (S, O, TA:) As says that the mskyn is better in condition than the fqyr: and Yoo says that the fqyr is better in condition than the mskyn; and adds, I asked an Arab of the desert, Art thou fqyr? and he answered, No, by God, but rather mskyn: (S, O, TA:) or the former signifies needy, needing, or wanting; a needer; and the latter, one abased by need or want, or otherwise; (Ibn-'Arafeh, O, K;) who, if abased by need or want, may lawfully receive of the poor-rate; but if abased otherwise than by
need or want, he may not receive of the poorrate; for he may be rich: (Ibn-'Arafeh:) [Alfaqiyru UilaI QllRehi the needer of God, i. e., of God's help, &c., and Alfaqiyru UilaI raHomapi QllRehi the needer of the mercy of God, are epithets which a man often writes before his name:] it is said in the Kur [xxxv. 16], Oanotumu AlfuqaraMCu UilaI QllRehi waQllRehu huwa QloganiIRu QloHamiydu, which is explained as meaning Ye are the needers, or they who stand in need, of God: [and God, He is the Self-sufficient, the Praised in every case:] (O, * TA: [see also the Kur xxviii. 24:]) or fqyr signifies one who is crippled, or deprived of the power of motion, by disease, or who suffers from a protracted disease, being weak, and who has no trade; and one who has a mean trade that does not suffice for his need; and mskyn, a beggar, who has a trade that stands in some stead, (HirofapN taqaEu mawoqiEFA,) but does not cause him and his household to be without want; (Esh-Sháfi'ee, T, O, K;) so that the former is in a harder condition than the latter accord. to Esh-Sháfi'ee; (T;) and it seems that he is called fqyr because of crippleness, or protracted disease, which prevents his freely employing himself in making gain: (Khálid Ibn-Yezeed:) As also says that the latter is in a better condition than the former; (S, O, K;) and so says Ahmad Ibn-'Obeyd: (TA:) and as to the verse of Er-Rá'ee, cited above, it is said to mean that the person there mentioned had a milch camel in former times, but possessed it no longer, and that lamo yutorako lahu sabad means that nothing was left to him: (Mgh:) the pl. of the latter epithet is also applied in the Kur xviii. 78 to men possessing a ship, or boat, which is worth a considerable sum; (Mgh;) whence Aboo-Bekr holds the opinion of As to be correct: (TA:) but it is urged in reply, that these men were hirers, not owners, of the vessel, as appears from one reading, [app. yuEamRaluwna for yaEomaluwna,] with teshdeed: (TA:) or the former signifies one who has neither property nor gain that suffices for his need; and the latter, one who has property or gain not sufficient for him: or, as some say, the converse is the truth: (Bd in ix. 60:) or both signify the same, (IAar, S, K,) one who possesses nothing: (IAar, S:) or when they are used together, they differ in signification; and when used separately, they both [sometimes] signify the same: (El-Bedr El-Karáfee:) [see more voce misokiynN:] fem. with p: (Msb, K:) pl. masc. fuqaraMCu; (Msb, K;) pl. fem. faqaAYiru, (K,) and fuqaraMCu (Lh, Msb, TA) like the masc., [said to be] the only instance of the kind except sufahaMCu as pl. of safiyhapN; (Msb;) [though fuqahaMCu, and perhaps some other instances, should be added;] but ISd says, I know not how this is. (TA.)
faqaArapN: see faqaArN.
fayoqarN: see the next paragraph.

faAqirapN [An act that breaks, or will break, the vertebræ of the back: and hence,] (assumed tropical:) a calamity, or misfortune; (S, O, K;) as also fayoqarN↓: (S, O, K:) or, accord. to Lth and others, such as breaks the vertebræ of the back: (TA:) pl. fawaAqiru. (Har p. 399.) Eamila bihi AlfaAqirapa is a prov., meaning He did to him an act breaking, or that would break, his vertebræ; or a calamity, or misfortune, as in the Kur lxxv. 25: (Meyd:) [or, accord. to J, it app. means he did to him that which would render him tractable; for he says,] it is from the phrase faqarotu Oanofa AlbaEiyri. (S. [This phrase in the S has been strangely misunderstood by Golius; who has consequently, after mentioning the meaning “ infortunium, ” added “ et Habena seu capistrum, de quo in Conj. 1. ”])
And [hence] AlfaAqirapu signifies (assumed tropical:) The resurrection. (TA.)
Oafoqaru [More, and most, poor or needy &c.: said to be formed irregularly from Aifotaqara, not from an unaugmented form of the verb; like maA Oafoqarahu]. (See Ham pp. 573-4.)
mufoqarN: see faqorN.

mufoqirN, applied to a man, (O, TA,) Strong (O, K, TA) in the vertebræ of the back; (TA;) and thus mufaqRarN↓, applied to a camel; and [in like manner] cuwfuqorapK↓, so applied, strong to be ridden: (O, TA:) and mufoqirN signifies also strong in the back; applied to a colt: (TA:) and, thus applied, that has attained to the time when he may be ridden. (K.)

And [hence] one says, UinRahu lamufoqirN lihecaA AlOamori (assumed tropical:) Verily he is equal to this affair, possessing firmness of mind, or strength, or power, for it; (ISh, O, L, K;) and lhcA AlEazomi for this determination, or resolution; and lhcA Alqironi for this adversary, or opponent. (L.) And rajulN mufaqRarN↓ (assumed tropical:) A man sufficient for everything that he is ordered to do; (O, K, TA;) as thought by reason of the strength of his vertebræ. (TA.)
See also faqorN.
mufaqRarN A sword having notches, or indentations, in its maton [q. v.], (S, K,) forming depressions therein. (K.)
See also mufoqirN, in two places.
mafoquwrN: see faqiyrN, in three places.
mafaAqiru: see faqorN, in two places.
OaroDN mutafaqRirapN Land in which are many fuqar, meaning hollows. (O, K.)
mutafaAqirN A man asserting himself to be in a state of faqor [i. e. poverty, or need, &c.]. (A, TA.)

1. faqaSa, aor.
faqiSa
, (Lth, Lh, M, O, K,) inf. n. faqoSN; (Lth, Lh, IDrd, M, O;) He broke; (Lth, Lh, M, O, K;) or crushed; (Lh, O, K;) an egg, (Lh, IDrd, M, O, K,) and the like thereof, (IDrd, O,) and any hollow thing; (Lth, M, O;) as also fqRS↓, inf. n. tafoqiySN: (M, TA:) and he (a bird) broke asunder an egg from over the young bird: (A and TA in explanation of the former verb:) and faqasa, aor.
faqiSa
, inf. n. faqosN, signifies the same as faqaSa. (Lh, O.)
faqaSa fulaAnN bayoDa Alfitonapi [lit. Such a one broke asunder the eggs of sedition, or the like,] is a tropical phrase [meaning (tropical:) such a one originated sedition, &c.]. (A, TA.)

[Golius has assigned to faqaSa, constr. with an accus., another signification (“ assecutus fuit rem ”), as on the authority of the K; app. from a mistranscription in the explanation of AlmifoqaAS, in a copy of that lexicon.]
2: see the preceding paragraph.
5: see what next follows.
7. AnfqSt AlbayoDapu and tfqRSt↓ The egg broke [or broke asunder] Eani Alfaroxi [from over the young bird].
bayoDapN faqoSapN: see mafoquwSapN.
faqiySN as an epithet: see its fem. voce mafoquwSapN.

Also An iron thing like a ring, among the apparatus of the tiller of land, (Lth, O, K,) which clasps together [app. at the upper parts, so as to form a support like a trevet, for his provisions &c.,] several separate sticks, or pieces of wood, set over against one another. (Lth, O.)

faqRuwSN, (Lth, O, K,) or faqRuwSapN, (M,) [the former a coll. gen. n., and the latter its n. un.,] A melon (biTiyxpN) before it has become ripe: (Lth, M, O, K:) a word of the dial. of Egypt: (Lth, O, K:) [but now applied in Egypt to the cucumis sativus (or common cucumber); (Forskål's Flora Aegypt. Arab., pp. lxxvi., 169;) or, particularly, cucumis sativus fructu albo: (Delile's Floræ Aegypt. Illustr., no. 929:)] also mentioned as with s for the last letter. (TA.)
mifoqaASN [A kind of mace;] a thing like a pomegranate, at the end of an iron rod, that breaks, or crushes, everything that it reaches. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.)
bayoDapN mafoquwSapN and faqiySahN↓ (IDrd, O, K) and faqoSapN↓ (CK [but not found by me elsewhere]) An egg broken, or crushed. (IDrd, O, K.)

1. faqaEa, aor.
faqaEa
and
faquEa
, inf. n. fuquwEN (S, O, K) and faqoEN, (K,) said of the colour of a thing, (S, O,) It was intensely yellow: (S, O, K:) or its yellowness was free from admixture. (K, TA. [See also faqoEN below.]) [And] faqaEa said of a skin, or hide, or a tanned, or red, skin or hide, (Oadiym,) It was beautiful and clear [in colour]. (Ham p. 562.)

faqaEa said of a boy, He became active, and grew, grew up, or became a young man; (K, * TA; [in both of which it is implied that the aor. of the verb in this and the next two senses is
faqaEa
and
faquEa
, as above;]) and so tfqRE↓. (TA.)
And faqaEa (K, TA) said of a man, (TA,) He died from, or in consequence of, the heat. (K, TA.)
faqaEati AlfawaAqiEu fulaAnFA The calamities of time, or fortune, crushed such a one. (K, * TA.)

faqaEa, aor.
faqaEa
, (K,) inf. n. faqoEN, (O,) He stole. (O, K. [Accord. to the TK, trans. in this sense.])

And He emitted wind from the anus, with a sound; (K, TA;) in which sense the inf. n. is
likewise faqoEN; accord. to some, peculiarly said of an ass: and bihi faqRaEa↓, and bimifoqaEK↓, and bimifoqaAEK↓, inf. n. tafoqiyEN, he did so vehemently. (TA.)
faqiEa, i. e. like fariHa, (K, TA,) inf. n. faqaEN, (TK,) said of a man, (TA,) He became red. (K, TA.)
2. fqRE, (TA,) inf. n. tafoqiyEN, (O, K, TA,) He twisted the sides of his mouth, or opened his mouth and was diffuse, in speech, (O, K, TA,) and uttered speech that had no meaning. (TA.)

And fqRE OaSaAbiEahu, (S, O, * TA,) inf. n. as above, (S, O, K, TA,) i. q. faroqaEahaA, (S, O, * K, * TA, *) [He cracked the joints of his fingers;] i. e. he pressed his fingers so that a sound was heard to proceed from their joints: (TA:) the action signified thereby is forbidden to be performed in prayer: (O, TA:) [but it is said that] this is the contracting of the fingers to the inner side of the hand and making a sound with the outer side [app. by pressing the fist upon the ground so as to make the joints of the fingers crack, when rising; for I think that any action more irregular than this would be too obviously wrong to need prohibition]. (O.)

And fqRE Alwarodapa, inf. n. tafoqiyEN, He made the rose into a round form (OadaArahaA), and then struck it so that it rent open, or asunder, producing a sound: (O:) or AltRafoqiyEu signifies the striking a rose with the hand, (O, K,) or the making a rose-leaf into a round [and app. hollow] form, and pressing it with the fingers, (TA,) so that it produces a sound, (O, K, TA,) when rending open, or asunder. (TA.)
[And fqRE signifies also It cracked with a sound: and it crackled: said of a flint-stone in fire: see SawRaAnN: and said of salt thrown into a fire: see naArN.]
See also 1, last sentence but one.
fqRE AlOdiyma, (O, TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He made the hide red. (O, K, TA.)
4. AfqE, (TA,) inf. n. UifoqaAEN, (O, K, TA,) He was, or became, poor, or needy: (TA;) or in an evil state or condition. (O, K, TA.)
5: see 1.

[Reiske, as stated by Freytag, has explained this verb as signifying It was, or became, contracted; said of a hand: but probably, I think, in consequence of his having found tafaqRaEat erroneously written for taqafRaEat.]
6. tfAqEt EayonaAhu His eyes became white: (O, K, TA:) or became cleft, or fissured: or had in them foul, or foul white, matter. (TA.)
7. AnfqE It became cleft, or fissured, or rent open or asunder. (O, K.)
faqoEN [an inf. n., of faqaEa, q. v. Used as a subst.,] Intense whiteness. (TA.) [But it seems to signify more commonly, Intense yellowness: or yellowness free from admixture: see 1, first sentence.]
And i. q. HuSaASN [app. as meaning An emission of wind from the anus, with a sound]. (S, O, TA. [See 1, last sentence but one.])

Also, and fiqoEN↓, (S, O, K,) the latter mentioned by ISk, (S, O,) A species of kamoOap [or truffles]; (S, O;) accord. to A 'Obeyd, (S, O,) the white and soft thereof: (S, O, K;) which is the worst thereof; or, as IAth says, a species of the worst [kind] of kmOp, accord. to AHn, it comes forth from the ground so as to appear, white, and is bad; the good being that which is extracted by digging: Lth says, It is a kamoC [or truffle] that comes forth from the base of the plant called Uijorid [q. v.], and is of the worst of kmOp, and the quickest in becoming corrupt: (TA:) the pl. is fiqaEapN, (S, O, K,) which is of both forms of the sing.; (S, O, TA;) and faqoEN, with fet-h, has for pls. OufoquEN [a pl. of pauc.] and fuquwEN [a pl. of mult.]. (AHn, TA.) A vile man is likened thereto: (S, O, K: *) one says, huwa OacalRu mino faqoEi qaroqarK, (S,) or mino faqoEK bqaroqarapK, (O, K,) [He is more vile than the fqE of, or than fqE In, a low and soft tract of ground,] because the beasts kick it along, (S,) or because it offers not resistance to the gatherer thereof, or because it is trodden with the feet, (O, K,) and the beasts kick it along. (O.)

[From a mention of the pl. faquwEN in art. cOn, and in the present art. in the TA, it appears that faqoEN is also applied to The species of fungus called cuWonuwn, and to the species called Turovuwv, &c.]
And [hence, perhaps,] faqoEN [as a coll. a.] signifies also (assumed tropical:) Pointed toes (xaraATiym of a sort of boots (O, TA.)
fiqoEN: see the next preceding paragraph.
faqaAEK; see what next follows.

fuqaAEK; (O, and thus in my MS, copy of the K; in other copies of the K fuqaAE or fuqaAEN; and in all the copies is added bAlDRamRi karubaAE or karubaAEK; [but there is no such word as rubaAEK. nor rubAEN; whence it seems to be meant that we should read karubaAEa; i. e. fuqaAEu, like rubAEu, imperfectly decl.; but see what follows;]) so says Ibn-Buzurj: (O:) or, (O, K,) accord. to AZ, (O,) fqAEK↓, (O, K, *) like rubaAEK, (O.) [i. e.] with fet-h, like vamaAnK (kavamaAnK): (K:) [which suggests that karubaAEK may be an early mistranscription for karbaAEK, and that fuqaAE is wrong, and only faqaAEK right, though it is said in one place in the TA that faqaAE is like saHaAb, i. e. that it is faqaAEN:] or it is faqiyEN↓, like OamiyrN; (K, TA;) so accord. to El-Jáhidh, as mentioned by Az: (TA:) applied to a man, as meaning Red; (O, K, TA;) intensely so; by reason of UigoraAb [i. e. app., goodliness of condition]: (O, TA:) and fuqaAEiyRN↓, as an epithet applied to a man, signifies red. (TA.)

faqiyEN, (so in the O,) or fiqRiyEN↓, like sikRiytN, (K,) but the former, like OamiyrN, is the right, [a coll. gen. n.,] and its n. un. is with p, (TA,) The white, of pigeons; (K, TA;) said by El-Jáhidh to be such, of pigeons, as are like the SiqolaAbiIR [or Sclave] of men; (O, TA;) a kind of white pigeon; so called as being likened to a [white] species of truffle [i. e. the faqoE]. (TA.)
OaboyaDu faqiyEN, (so in the O,) or AbyD fiqRiyEN↓, like sikRiytN, (K,) White that is intense (O, K) in whiteness. (O.) [See also faAqiEN.]
faqiyEN as an epithet applied to a man: see fuqaAEK.
fuqRaAEN: see fuqaAEK:
and see faAqiEN, in two places.
faqRaAEN One who emits wind from the anus, with a sound, much, or frequently. (TA.)
And Strong, or vehement; and bad, corrupt, or wicked. (Lth, O, K.)

fuqRaAEN. 1 certain beverage, (S, O, L, K,) [a sort of beer.] made from barley: (L, TA:) [but there are several sorts thereof, perhaps peculiar to postclassical times: (see De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, see, ed., vol. i., pp. 149-154:)] so called because of the froth that rises upon its head. (O, K. [See fuqRaAEapN.])

And A certain plant, (AHn, O, K.) such as is termed mutafaqRiEN↓, i. e., (AHn, O, K. *) which, when it dries up, becomes hard, and as though it were horns. (AHn, O, K.) [Now applied in North-Western Africa to The toadstool, which is called in other parts fuTorN.]
fiqRiyEN: see faqiyEN, in two places.

fuqRaAEapN, like rumRaAnapN, sing. of faqaAqiyEu, (TA,) which signifies The bubbles that rise upon water, (S, O, K, TA,) and upon wine, (O,) [&c.,] round, [or globular.] (TA,) like qawaAriyr [or vessels of glass]. (S, O, TA.)
fuqRaAEiIRN A seller of [the beverage called] fuqRaAE. (TA.)

faAqiEN (S, O, K) and fuqaAEiIRN↓ (K) Yellow intensely yellow; (S, O, K;) thus both signify: (Lh, K, TA:) or red intensely red: (K:) or red free from an admixture of whiteness: or purely red: (TA:) or faAqiEN is applied to white and to any other colour as signifying free from admixture; (K;) and fuqaAEiIRN↓ is applied in this sense to white: (TA:) and OafoqaEu↓, of which the pl. is fuqoEN, signifies intensely white. (K.)
faAqiEapN A calamity, or misfortune: (S, O, K:) pl. fawaAqiEu. (S, O, K. *)
OafoqaEu; pl. fuqoEN: see faAqiEN.

faqorN mufoqiEN, accord. to the K, signifies mudoqiEN [as though meaning Poverty causing to cleave to the dust or earth]: but the right phrase is faqiyrN mufoqiEN, signifying mudoqiEN [i. e. a poor person cleaving to the dust or earth: for OadoqaEa is intrans. as well as trans.]; which denotes the worst condition, like majohuwdN. (TA.) [See 4.]
mifoqaEN and mifoqaAEN↓ [The anus (as being the instrument) with which wind is emitted vehemently, with a sound]: see 1, last sentence but one.
xafRN mufaqRaEN i. q. muxaruTamN (O, K) i. e. A boot having its fore part pointed. (TA in art. xrTm.)
AlmufaqRiEapu A certain black bird of which the base of the tail is white, (O, K,) that pecks camels', or similar, dung. (O.)
mifoqaAEN: see mifoqaEN; and 1, last sentence but one.
mutafaqRiEN: see fuqRaAEN.

1. faqima, (S, K, * TA,) aor.
faqama
, (TA,) inf. n. faqamN, It, or he, was, or became, full: (S, K, TA:) it is said of a vessel: (TA:) and one says [also] OaSaAba mina AlmaMCi HatRaI faqima [He obtained, or took, of the water until he became full]; mentioned by IDrd. (S, TA.)
And Oakala HatRaI faqima He ate until he became affected with indigestion, or oppressed by much eating. (K.)
faqima maAluhu His property, or wealth, became much, or abundant: or it has the contr. meaning, i. e., passed away; came to an end; or became spent, exhausted, or consumed. (K, TA.)

faqima, aor.
faqama
, (K, TA,) inf. n. faqamN (S, K, TA) and faqomN, (K, TA,) He had the lower central incisors prominent, (S, TA,) so that they did not close against the upper, (S,) or so that the upper did not close against them when he (the man) closed his mouth: so in the L: or he had the lower jaw long and the upper short: but accord. to the K, he had the upper central incisors prominent, so that they did not close against the lower: (TA:) the epithet applied to him is Oafoqamu↓; (S, K, TA;) fem. faqomaMCu. (TA [in which it is added that one says rjl fuqomN; but rjl is app. here a mistranscription for rijaAlN].)

And [hence] faqima falaAnN i. q. baTira and OaXira (tropical:) [i. e. Such a one exulted; or exulted greatly, or excessively; and behaved insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: &c.]: (K, TA:) because AlbaTaru and AlOaXaru are departure from the limit of rectitude. (TA.)

And faqima AlOamoru, (K, TA,) aor.
faqama
, (TA,) inf. n. faqamN and faqomN and fuquwmN, (tropical:) The affair did not proceed in a right course. (K, TA.)
And faqima and faquma are syn. with tfAqm, q. v. (K.)
And faquma signifies also It (a thing) was, or became, wide, or ample. (TA.)
faqama AlmaroOapa: see 3.
faqama Atkaloba He took hold of the fuqom [i. e. muzzle] of the dog; (K;) as also tfqRmhu↓. (Z, K.)
3. fAqm AlmaroOapa, (S, * K, TA,) inf. n. mufaAqamapN and fiqaAmN, (S, TA,) He compressed the woman; (S, K, TA;) as also faqamahaA↓. (K.)
5: see 1, last sentence.

6. tfAqm It (an affair, or a case,) was, or became, great, or formidable; (S, Mgh, K, TA;) and hard, or difficult; (Mgh;) said of what is disliked, or hated; (TA;) and faqima↓ and faquma↓ signify the same. (K.)
faqomN: see what next follows.

fuqomN (S, K) and faqomN↓ (K) The laHoI [meaning lateral portion of the lower jaw]; (S, K;) or either one of the laHoyaAni. (K.) Hence the trad., mano HafaZa maA bayona faqomayohi warijolayohi daxala AljanRapa [He who keeps from evil what is between his two lateral portions of the lower jaw (i. e. his tongue), and what is between his two legs (i. e. his cakar), enters Paradise]. (S, * TA.)
[And] The upper part [of the interior] of the mouth: the lower part is the Hanak. (IAar, T in art. Hnk.)
See also fugomN.
fuqumN The mouth. (Sh, K, TA. [See also fugomN.])
Oafoqamu; fem. faqomaMCu: see 1.
Hence, (assumed tropical:) Anything crooked, distorted, or uneven. (TA.) And OamorN Oafoqamu (tropical:) An affair, or a case, of a crooked kind; contrary to what is right. (S, * K, * TA.)
[And Freytag adds, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees, Difficult, as an epithet applied to a thing:
and, as a signification of the fem., A calamity, or misfortune.]

1. faqiha, aor.
faqaha
, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. fiqohN, the verb being like Ealima and the inf. n. like EilomN, in measure and in meaning, (TA,) or faqahN; (JK; [and the same seems to be implied in the Msb and the K;]) and faquha; (Msb, K;) He had, or possessed, what is termed fiqohN, meaning understanding, (S, K,) and knowledge, and intelligence, and especially knowledge of the law (Eilomu AldRiyni): (K:) or both are syn. with Ealima: (Msb, TA:) or faquha, of which the inf. n. is faqaAhapN, (S, TA,) or fiqohN, (JK,) signifies [peculiarly] he had, or possessed, knowledge of the law (Eilom AlXRariyEap): (S:) or this latter verb signifies he had, or possessed, what is termed fiqopN as a faculty firmly rooted in his mind: (Msb, TA:) or, accord. to IB, i. q. tafaqRaha↓ [q. v., as intrans.]: and he was, or became, [a faqiyh, q. v., or] equal to the fuqahMC. (TA in art. Elm: see Elm.) One says, fulaAnN laA yanoqahu [which may be rendered Such a one will not understand nor comprehend: but the two verbs are exactly syn.]. (S.) And to the witness one says, kayofa faqaAhatuka limaA OaXohado naAka [app. meaning How is thy understanding of (or how understandest thou) what we have made thee to witness?]: it is not said to any other than the witness: (K, TA:) thus in the M: (TA:) or, accord. to Z, it is said to other than the witness. (K, * TA.)

And faqihahu, (Mgh, K,) aor.
faqaha
, inf. n. fiqohN, (K,) He understood it, (Mgh, K,) namely, a meaning, (Mgh,) or a thing that one explained to him; (TA;) as also tfqRhhu↓. (K.)
See also 3.

2. fqRhhu, (S, K,) inf. n. tafoqiyhN, (K,) He (God) made him to know or have knowledge [or to understand, or instructed him], or taught him; (S, * K, TA;) and (K) so Afqhhu↓, (Msb, K,) or he made him to understand. (S, Mgh.) It is said in a trad., AallRehumRa EalRimohu AldRiyna wafaqRihohu fiI AltRaOowiyli i. e. O God, teach him Aldyn [app. here meaning the science of the law] and [instruct him in] the tOwyl [or interpretation, &c.,] and the meaning thereof. (TA.) And you say, AlXRaIoCa Oafoqahotuka↓ I made thee to understand, (S, Msb, *) or I taught thee, (Msb,) the thing. (S, Msb.) And Oafoqanotuhu↓ I explained to him the learning of Alfiqoh [meaning the science of the law]. (T, TA.)

3. fAqhhu He searched with him into [matters of] science, disputing with him, (S, K,) fafaqahahu↓, aor.
faquha
, [inf. n. faqohN,] and he overcame him therein. (K.)
4: see 2, in three places.

5. tfqRh He learned knowledge, or science: (M voce sawRada:) [and particularly] he learned Alfiqoh [meaning the science of the law]: (JK:) or he took, or applied himself, to the acquisition of Alfiqoh [meaning thus]. (S, TA.) And tfqRh fiI AlEilomi is like taEalRama [meaning He became, or made himself, learned, or thoroughly learned, in science]. (Msb.) liyatafaqRahuwA fiI AldRiyni, in the Kur ix. 123, means That they may task themselves to obtain understanding in AldRyano [i. e. the law, or religion in general], imposing upon themselves the difficulties attendant on the acquisition thereof. (Ksh, Bd.) See also 1, in two places; in the latter of which it is mentioned as transitive.

fiqohN [as a simple subst.] signifies Understanding (S, Msb, K) of a thing; (Msb, K;) and knowledge thereof; (Msb, K;) and intelligence: (K:) accord. to IF, any knowledge of a thing is thus termed: (Msb:) [hence fiqohu AllRugapi The science of lexicology is the title of a work written by him; and of another work, by Eth-Tha'álibee:] and, as used by the lawyers [and others], Alfiqohu denotes a particular science; (Msb;) it signifies particularly, (S, TA,) or predominantly, (K, TA,) The science of the law; [jurisprudence;] (S, K, TA;) syn. Eilomu AlXRariyEapi, (S, TA,) or Eilomu AldRiyni, [which is the same as Elm AlXryEp,] because of its preëminence (K, TA) above the other kinds of science: (TA:) and more particularly, the science of the furuwE [or derivative institutes] of the law. (TA.)
faquhN; and its fem., with p: see the next paragraph.

faqiyhN Any one possessing knowledge of a thing. (TA.) fafiyhu AlEarabi signifies The EaAlim [or man of knowledge] of the Arabs; (TA;) and was an appellation given to El-Hárith Ibn-Keledeh (AlHerivu bonu kaladapa), who was also called Tabiybu AlEarabi [as is said in the S in art. Azm], because this appellation is syn. with the former; but IKh and El- Hareeree do not mean by fqyhA lErb any particular person. (Mz, close of the 39th nwE.)

[Particularly and predominantly,] faqiyhN signifies One possessing knowledge of the law; [a lawyer;] (S, K;) as also faquhN↓; (Msb, K;) fem. faqiyhapN and faquhapN↓: pl. [of faqiyhN] fuqahaMCu; and [of fafiyhapN] faqaAYihu and fuqahaMCu;
(K;) the last of these pls. mentioned by Lh, and anomalous, as applied to women: ISd says, “ in my opinion, he, of the Arabs, who says fuqahaMC [in speaking of women] takes no account of the fem. p: it is like fuqaraMCu applied to women. ” (TA.) [In Egypt, the appellation fiqiI, a vulgar corruption of faqiyh, is now applied to A schoolmaster; and to a person who recites the Kur-án &c. for hire.]
faHolN faqiyhN means A stallion [camel] expert in covering, (K, TA,) that knows well the she-camels that are lusting, and the pregnant. (TA.)

Almusotafoqihapu The female companion of the wailing woman, who responds to her (K, TA) in what she says; because she catches and retains quickly, and understands, what she [the former] says, and to reply to it: [as though it signified “ she who seeks, or desires, to understand: ”] it is said in a trad. that each of these persons is cursed by God. (TA.)
1. faqawotu Oavarahu or Uivorahu I followed his track, or footsteps; i. q. qafawotuhu; (K, TA;) mentioned by Yaakoob among the words formed by transposition: so in the M. (TA.)
faqowN: see its syn. faqoCN, in art. fqO.

fuqowapN The fuwq [or notch] of the arrow; (S, K, TA;) i. e. the part which is the place of the bowstring: (TA:) [also called fuwqapN, from which it is app. formed by transposition, like the other words mentioned in this art.:] pl. fuqFI, (S, K,) also written fuqFA. (TA.) An ex. of the pl. occurs in a verse cited in art. Erqb, voce EuroquwbN. (S.)

1. AlfakRu, accord. to Er-Rághib, primarily signifies AltRaforiyju [i. e. The opening a thing; and particularly by diduction, or so as to form an intervening space, or a gap, or breach]. (TA.) You say, fakRa, first pers. fakakotu, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
fakuka
, inf. n. fakRN, (O, Msb,) He separated (S, O, Msb, K) a thing (S, O, K) from another thing; and any two things knit together, or intricately intermixed: (S, O:) or fakakotuhu I separated one part of it from another part thereof: (Msb:) and tafokiykN↓ likewise signifies the separating two things knit together, or intricately intermixed. (Lth, S, TA.) And He broke [or broke open] a seal, i. e. a sealed piece of clay or wax; (Mgh, Msb, * TA;) in relation to which yafotakRuhu↓ occurs as meaning yafukRuhu, though we have not heard it [as a classical expression in this sense]. (Mgh.)

And fakRa AlEaZoma, (Mgh, Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Msb,) He dislocated the bone; put it out of joint. (Mgh, Msb.) [This, or the like, is what is meant by its being said that] AlfakRu in the hand, or arm, is [i. e. denotes] less than Alkasoru. (K.)
And fakRa yadahu, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He opened, or unclosed, his hand from what was in it: (K, TA:) so in the M. (TA.)

And fakRa AlrRahona, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) aor.
fakuka
, (TA,) inf. n. fakRN and fukuwkN; (K;) and AftkRhu↓; (S, Mgh, O, K;) (tropical:) He redeemed the pledge; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, TA;) got it out from the hand of him to whom it was pledged. (Mgh.)
And fakakotu signifies also I loosed, set loose or free, or let go, anything. (Msb.)

[Hence,] fakRa AlOasiyru, (Msb, K,) aor.
fakuka
, (TA,) inf. n. fakRN and fakaAkN and fikaAkN, (K,) (tropical:) He liberated, or set free, the captive. (Msb, K, TA.) And fakRa AlrRaqabapa, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
fakuka
, inf. n. fakRN, (TA,) [lit. He loosed the neck,] means (tropical:) he emancipated [the slave]. (S, O, Msb, K, TA.) fakRu AlrRaqabapi is expl. in a trad. as meaning (assumed tropical:) The assisting in paying the price [of the slave when one is unable to pay the whole of the price]. (O, TA.) In the Kur [xc. 13], fakRu raqabapK is said by some to mean (assumed tropical:) The emancipating of a slave: and by some. (assumed tropical:) the man's emancipating himself from subjection to God's punishment by the confession of the unity of God and by righteous doing and then by teaching the same to others. (TA,) fukRa fulaAnN means (assumed tropical:) Such a one was set free, and at rest, from a thing. (IAar, Th, TA.)
[Hence also,] one says, huwa yafukRu AlmaXaAkila (assumed tropical:) [He solves] the things, or affairs, that are dubious, or confused. (TA in art. Xkl.)

qadofakRa wafarRaja is said of a very old man, meaning farRaja laHoyayohi [i. e. He has parted his jaws, by hanging the lower jaw in consequence of weakness]; as is the case in extreme old age. (S, O,) And [hence.] fakRa, (AZ, S, O, K,) aor.
fakuka
, inf. n. fakRN and fukuwkN, (AZ, S, O,) said of a man, means (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, extremely aged, or old and weak. (AZ, S, O, K.) [Or fakRa thus used may be from AlfakRu signifying “ the jaw: ” and so what next follows.]
fakakotu AlSRabiIRa I put medicine into the mouth of the boy or young male child [opening his jaws for that purpose]. (S, O.)

qado fakikota, [third pers. fakRa,] aor. tafakRu, inf. n. fakakN, Thou hast become such as is termed OafakRu i. e. one whose manokib [here meaning shoulder-bone] has become unknit, or loosened, (Ainofaraja,) from its joint, in consequence of weakness and flaccidity. (S.) [See also fakakN below.]

And qadofakikota, aor. tafakRu; (S, O, K;) and fakukota, (O, K,) a verb of a very rare form, [respecting which see damRa, last sentence,] (MF, TA,) aor. tafukRu; (O, K;) inf. n. fakRapN (S, O, K) and fakRN also; (TA;) (tropical:) Thou hast become foolish, or stupid, and soft, flaccid, or languid. (S, O, K, TA.)
2: see the preceding paragraph, second sentence.

4. AfkRt She (a camel) being near to bringing forth, her SalawaAni [app. meaning two parts on the right and left of the tail (see SlFA in art. Slw)] became lax, or flaccid, and her udder became large; (K, TA;) and so Oafokahat; (TA;) so too tfkRkt↓: or this last signifies she became vehemently desirous of the stallion. (O, K.)
And AfkR mina AlHibaAlapi He (a gazelle) got loose from the snare into which he had fallen. (TA: also mentioned, but not expl., in the O.)
5. tfkRk It (a thing) became much, or widely, separated: and became unclosed. (O, TA.)
tfkRkt AlsRafiynapu The ship parted asunder; became disjointed; became separated in its places of joining. (Mgh in art. xlE.)
See also 7.
And see 4.

You say also, huwa yatafakRaku meaning (tropical:) He is [or acts] without power of self-restraint, in consequence of stupidity, or unsoundness of intellect, (S, O, K, TA,) in his gait, and in his speech: (TA:) or tafakRaka in walking is syn. with taxalRaEa, (S and K and TA in art. xlE,) i. e. [he was, or became, loose in the joints; or] he shook his shoulder-joints and his arms, and made signs with them. (TA in that art.)
7. AnfkR It became separated: you say, AnfkR AlXRaIoCu mina AlXRaIoCi The thing became separated from the thing: (O, TA:) and Ainofakakotu minoka [I became separated from thee]. (TA.)

And, said of a bone, It became dislocated, or out of joint; (MA, Mgh, * Msb; *) it unknit, or loosened, and separated; syn. Ainofaraja wQnofaSala; as also tfkRk↓. (Mgh.) [And it is also used in relation to a member of the body:] one says, saqaTa fulaAnN fQnofakRato qadamuhu Oawo UiSobaEuhu i. e. Ainofarajato wazaAlato [Such a one fell, and his foot, or his finger, became unknit, or loosened, and dislocated]: (S, O:) [or] AnfkRt qadamuhu means zaAlato [i. e. his foot became dislocated; and AnfkRt USobaEuhu means Ainofarajato [i. e. his finger became unknit, or loosened in a joint]. (K.)
One says also, AnfkRt raqabatuhu mina AlrRiqRi, meaning (tropical:) He became freed [lit. his neck became loosed] from slavery. (S, * O, * TA.)
And AnfkR Eano Eahodihi (assumed tropical:) [He became released from his compact, engagement, or promise]. (TA voce Ainofaraka.)
And laAyanofakRu Eano quboHi fiEolihi (assumed tropical:) [He will not desist from his evil doing]. (O and K in art. Erf.)

[It is also used in the sense and manner of the non-attributive verb zaAla; respecting which see art. zyl.] One says, maAQnofakRa fulaAnN qaAYimFA, meaning maAzaAla qaAYimFA [i. e. Such a one ceased not to be, or continued to be, standing]. (S, O.) And maAQnofakakotu Oacokuruka, meaning maAzilotu Oacokuruka I ceased not, or I continued, remembering thee]. (Fr, TA.) And it occurs in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh, immediately followed by UilRaA, which is [said by As and IJ and others to be] redundant. (S, O. [See that verse, and the remarks upon it, in art. AlA. p. 78, col. i.])
8: see 1, former half, in two places.

AlfakRu The laHoI [meaning jaw; and also either of the two lateral portions of the lower jaw], (S, O, Msb, K,) i. e. (Msb) each of the laHoyaAni;
(Mgh, Msb;) as also AlOafakRu↓: (O, K:) or this latter signifies the majomaE [or part in which is the commissure] of the xaTom [generally meaning muzzle]; (Lth, O, K;) as also AlfakRu; (TA;) that is, (Lth, O, in the K “ or ” [as if to denote a different meaning],) [the part in which is the symphysis] of the fakRaAni [or two lateral portions of the lower jaw]: (Lth, O, K:) [see Alfaniyku:] and AlfakRaAni is said to mean the place [on either side with that on the other side] where the two jaws meet [and are articulated] next the temple, above and below; of a human being and of a horse or the like: (TA:) and, in the Bári', (Msb,) or in the T, (TA,) the place of meeting of the two sides of the mouth (mulotaqaI AlXRidoqayoni) on both sides: (Msb, TA:) [but this last explanation is strange, and app. little known:]) pl. fukuwkN. (Msb.) One says, maqotalu AlrRajuli bayona fakRayohi [which may be best rendered The man's slayer is between his two jaws, or two lateral portions of his lower jaw]; (S, O, TA;) meaning the man's tongue: (TA:) a prov., in which mqtl may be [properly] an inf. n., or a noun of place, or an inf. n. used in the place of an act. part. n.: accord. to the third of these explanations, [which most nearly denotes the meaning intended,] it is as though one said, qaAtilu AlrRajuli bayona fakRayohi. (Meyd. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 597.]) See also fakakN.
fakRapN [an inf. n.: see 1, last sentence].

AlfakRapu is the name of One of the northern constellations, [Corona Borealis,] (Kzw,) certain stars, (S, O, K,) eight stars, called in Pers. kAsh drwyXAn, (Kzw,) behind AlsRimaAk AlrRaAmiH [i. e. Arcturus], (S, O, K,) [near] behind the staff of AlSRayRaAH [which is a name of Bootes], (Kzw,) having a circling form, (S, O, K, and Kzw,) but with a gap, or breach, in the circling, for which reason, [agreeably with the Pers. appellation mentioned above,] it is called qaSoEapu AlmasaAkiyni [the bowl of the paupers], (Kzw,) this being the name given to it by the children. (As, S, O, K.)
fakakN An unknit, or a loosened, state (AinofiraAj) of the manokib [or shoulder-joint]. (K. [But see 1, last explanation but one, where it is mentioned as an inf. n.])

And (K) A state of dislocation of the foot: (S, O, K:) hence the phrase, in a verse of Ru-beh, kamunohaADi AlfalakN: (S, O: *) but (in this instance, O), accord. to As, Alfalak is used by poetic license for AlfakR [meaning “ the jaw, ” so that the phrase signifies like him whose jaw has become broken after its having been set]. (S, O.)
And A state of fracture of the jaw: (K, TA:) or of dislocation thereof. (TA.)

fakaAku AlrRahoni and fikaAkuhu, (S, O, Msb, * K,) the latter mentioned by Ks (S, O, Msb) and ISk, (Msb,) That wherewith the pledge is, or is to be, redeemed: (S, O, Msb, * K:) so in a verse cited voce galaqa. (S, O.)
fakRaAkN [One who separates, &c., much, or often].
[And hence,] fakRaAkN hakRaAkN (tropical:) One who does not make his words and their meanings congruous, or consistent, by reason of his foolishness, or stupidity. (Z, TA.)
faAkRN [as an act. part. n., Separating, &c.

And] (assumed tropical:) Extremely aged, or old and weak; applied in this sense to a man; (AZ, S, O, K;) and also to a camel: (K:) or, applied to a camel, disabled, or fatigued, by leanness, or emaciation: fem. with p. (En-Nadr, TA.)

And (tropical:) Foolish, or stupid: (S, O: *) or very foolish, or stupid: (IAar, K, TA:) and you say faAkRN taAkRN, (IAar, S, O, TA,) making tAkR an imitative sequent: or, accord. to Yaakoob, you say XayoxN faAkRN wataAkRN: thus he makes tAkR a substitute, not an imitative sequent. (TA.) And OaHomaqu faAkRN wahaAkRN (tropical:) [A foolish, or stupid, person,] one who talks of that which he knows and of that which he knows not, and is more, or oftener, incorrect than correct. (El-Hoseybee, TA.) Pl. fakakapN and fikaAkN. (IAar, K.)

OafakRu, (S, K,) or OafakRu Almanokibi, (K,) One whose manokib [here meaning shoulder-bone] has become unknit, or loosened, (Ainofaraja,) from its joint, in consequence of weakness and flaccidity. (S, K. * [See also maforuwkN.])
And rajulN OafakRu [A man having the jaw broken]. (TA. [There expl. as signifying masokuwru AlfakRi; a mistranscription, for makosuwruAlfakRi: see fakakN, last sentence.])
See also AlfakRu.
mufikRapN, applied to a she-camel, part. n. of OafakRat [q. v.]: (O, TA:) and mufokihN and mufokihapN are syn. therewith. (TA.)
mutafakRikapN A mare desiring the stallion, (AO, O, K,) not offering opposition to him. (AO, O.)

munofakRiyna in the Kur [xcviii. 1], (O, TA,) followed by the words HatRaI taOotiyahumu QlobayRinapu, (O,) means, accord. to Mujáhid (O, TA) and Zj, (TA,) In the condition of desisting (O, TA) from their infidelity; (TA;) or, as Akh says, ceasing from their infidelity: (TA:) or, accord. to another, (O,) namely, Niftaweyh, (TA,) quitting the present state of existence, (O, TA,) i. e., sharing, one with another, in perdition, until the evidence came to them (O, TA) that had been affirmed to them in the Towráh, with respect to the description of Mohammad &c.; taOotiyahum being lit. an aor., but in its meaning a pret.: (O:) Az says that it is not from maA QnofakRa meaning maA zaAla, but from AinofikaAku AlXRaIoCi mina AlXRaIoCi meaning “ the thing's becoming separated from the thing: ” accord. to IAar, as mentioned by Th, fukRa fulaAnN means “ Such a one was set free, and at rest, from a thing; ” and hence mnfkRyn in the Kur means experiencing rest: accord. to Er-Rághib, it means separated, or separated into several parties; for all [to whom the word, preceded by a negative, relates] were assenting to error. (TA.)

1. fakara fiyhi, (O, * Msb, K,) aor.
fakura
, (O, TK,) or
fakira
, (Msb,) inf. n. fakorN; (S, O, Msb, K; *) and Oafokara↓; (S, O, Msb, K;) and fkRr↓, (S, O, K,) [which is more common than either of the first and second,] inf. n. tafokiyrN; (O, TA;) and tfkRr↓; (S, O, Msb, K;) and Aftkr↓, (Msb, TA,) but this last is vulgar; (TA;) He thought upon it, considered it, or examined it [mentally]; (Msb;) he considered it in order to obtain a clear knowledge of it; (S, O, * TA;) he employed his mind, (M, TA,) or his consideration, (K, TA,) upon it. (M, K, TA.) [See also fikorN.]
2: 4, 5, and 8: see the preceding paragraph.
fakorN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.].

layosa liI fiI hecaA AlOamori fakorN, (Yaakoob, S, O, K, *) which is more chaste than fikorN↓, [in this case,] (Yaakoob, S, O,) but the latter is sometimes used, (K,) means I have no want, or need, of this thing: (Yaakoob, S, O, K: *) or, as is said in the A, laA fakora liI fiI hecaA i. e. I have no want, or need, of this, nor do I care for it. (TA.)

fikorN and fikorapN↓ (S, O, Msb, K) and fikoraI↓, (Lth, O, K,) are simple substs., (S, O, Msb, *) but the last is of rare occurrence, (Lth, O,) signifying Thought, consideration, or [mental] examination, fiI OamorK [respecting a thing]; (Msb;) consideration [of a thing] in order to obtain a clear knowledge [of it]; (S, TA;) the employment of the mind, (M, TA,) or of the consideration, (K, TA,) upon a thing: (M, K, TA:) or repeated consideration for the purpose of seeking [to discover] meanings: or the arranging of things in the mind in order, by them, to arrive at some object of which the attainment is desired, though it be but a preponderating opinion: (Msb:) or the arranging of known things [in the mind] in order to attain to [the knowledge of] an unknown [thing]: (KT:) pl. of the first OafokaArN: (IDrd, K;) but Sb says that neither fikorN nor EilomN nor naZarN has any pl.: (TA:) the pl. of fikorapN↓ is fikarN. (Msb.) One says, lifulaAnK fikarN kulRuhaA fiqarN [Such a one has thoughts all of which are points of wit]. (A, TA.)
See also fakorN.
fikorapN: see the next preceding paragraph; the former in two places.
fikoraI: see the next preceding paragraph; the former in two places.
fikRiyrN [Thoughtful;] having much fikor; (IF, S, O, K;) as also fayokarN↓. (Kr, K.)
fayokarN: see what next precedes.
8. Aftkl fiI fiEolihi i. q. AiHotafala [He strove, laboured, or exerted himself, &c., in his doing]; (IAar, O, K;) said of a man. (IAar, O.)

Oafokalu A tremour, (S, O, K,) from cold or from fear: (S:) hence, in a trad., OaxacaniI Oafokalu [A tremour seized me]: (S, * O:) and in another, fabaAta walahu Oafokalu [And he passed the night having a
tremour, or shivering]: (O:) thus used, as indeterminate, it is perfectly decl.; but if used as a [proper] name of a man, it is imperfectly decl. because determinate and also of the measure of a verb: (S, O:) some say, (IF, O,) no verb is formed from it; (IF, S, O;) but such is not the case, for they said rajulN mafokuwlN [which shows that it had a verb though none is known to have been in use]. (IF, O.) [Oaxacato biI naAqatiI OafokalFA mina AlsRayori is a saying mentioned in the O and K, (in the former as from Ibn-'Abbád,) but the meaning is not expl., nor indicated by the context, in either of them; and the strangeness of its phraseology convinces me that it presents a mistranscription: I believe that the first word is mistranscribed for OaHodavato, and, consequently, that the meaning is, My she-camel produced in me a tremour arising from the rate of journeying: some copies of the K, as is stated in the TA, for mina AlsRayori, have mn AlsRaboqi, from the outstripping.]

Also The [bird commonly called] XiqirRaAq [generally meaning the green wood-pecker]; (O, K;) because they regard it as of evil omen; so that when it presents itself to them, they are frightened at it, and tremble. (O.)

And A company, or collective body, of men: one says, jaAWuwA biOafokalihimo They came with their company [i. e. all together]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) OafaAkiylu [is app. a pl. thereof, and, as such,] signifies OafowaAjN [pl. of fawojN, q. v.]: thus in the phrase OafaAkiylu mino kacaA [app. meaning Multitudes of such a kind of thing]: (K:) [or] thus in the saying, mentioned by Ibn-'Abbád, Einodahu OafaAkiylu mino kalaAmK [app. meaning He has multitudes of sayings, or words; for kalaAmN (q. v.) is used in a pl. sense as well as in a sing. sense]. (O. [The difference of these two exs. in respect of the last word suggests that there may be in one of them a mistranscription.])
mafokuwlN [the pass. part. n. of a verb which is not mentioned,] Affected with a tremour. (IF, O, K, TA. [See Oafokalu, first sentence.])

1. fakiha, aor.
fakaha
, inf. n. fakaAhapN (S, Mgh, K) and fakahN, (K, TA,) [the latter inf. n. correctly thus, agreeably with a general rule, in the CK with the k quiescent, but said in the TA to be bAltHryk,] (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, cheerful, happy, or free from straitness; (S, Mgh, K;) jocose, or given to jesting, (S, Mgh,) and to laughing: (Mgh, K:) or one who talked to his companions and made them to laugh. (K.)
See also 5.
2. fakRahahumo, inf. n. tafokiyhN, He brought to them faAkihap [i. e. fruit]. (K.)
And [hence] fakRahahumo bimulaHi AlkalaAmi, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He entertained them in a novel manner with facetious sayings or talk. (K, TA.)

3. fAkhhu, (K,) inf. n. mufaAkahapN, (S,) (tropical:) He jested, or joked, with him; (S, K, TA;) indulged in pleasantry with him. (TA.) It is said in a prov., laA tufaAkiho OamapF walaAtabulo EalaI OakamapK (tropical:) [Jest not thou with a female slave, and make not water upon a hillock, i. e. and publish not what is secret of thine affair: see art. Akm]. (S, TA.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce tazanRada.]

4. Oafokahato She (a camel) yielded her milk plentifully on the occasion of eating the [herbage called] rabiyE, before her bringing forth: (S, TA:) or she being near to bringing forth, her SalawaAni [app. meaning two parts on the right and left of the tail (see SalFA in art. Slw)] became lax, or flaccid, and her udder became large; like OafakRat. (TA in art. fk. [See also the part. n., below.])

5. tfkRh He ate fruit (faAkihap): (Msb, K:) and He took fruit with his hand, [he helped himself to it;] syn. tanaAwala AlfaAkihapa: and hence, as is said in the A, (TA,) the saying in the Kur [lvi. 65], faZalotumo tafakRahuwna is ironical, meaning [And then ye would be in the condition of] making your fruit to be your saying UinRaA lamugoramuwna Verily we are burdened with debt (which words occur in the next verse)]: or tafakRaha here [or rather in a case of this kind] means He threw away from himself the fruit: thus says Ibn-'Ateeyeh, (K, TA,) in his exposition: (TA:) [but see other explanations in what follows:] and it signifies also He abstained from fruit: thus it bears two contr. meanings. (K.)

And sometimes [it means (tropical:) He amused himself with talk; like as one amuses himself with the eating of fruit after a meal; i. e.] AltRafakRuhu is metaphorically used as meaning AltRanaqRulu biAlHadiyvi. (Bd in lvi. 65.)
And (assumed tropical:) He affected jesting, or joking. (TA.)
And tfkRhwA bifulaAnK (assumed tropical:) They spoke evil of such a one; or did so in his absence; and defamed him; and did thus with jesting, one with another. (TA.)
And tfkRh bihi (assumed tropical:) He enjoyed it: (S, Msb, K:) and [particularly] (Msb) he enjoyed the eating of it. (Mgh, Msb.)

And tfkRh also signifies (assumed tropical:) He wondered, (S, Msb, K,) minohu at it; and so fakiha↓, followed likewise by mnh. (K.) And hence [accord. to some] the saying in the Kur cited above, faZalotumo tafakRahuwna i. e. (assumed tropical:) [And then ye would be in the condition of] wondering at what had befallen you in respect of your seed-produce. (TA.)

And He repented, grieved, lamented, or regretted: (IAar, S, K:) and the words of the Kur cited in the last sentence above, (S, TA,) as expl. by some, (TA,) mean [And then ye would be in the condition of] repenting, &c.: (S, TA:) and so tafakRanuwna, which is of the dial. of 'Okl; or, accord. to Lh, Temeem say tatafakRanuwna, and AzdShanoo-ah say tatafakRahuwna. (TA.)
6. tafaAkuhN signifies The jesting, or joking, [or indulging in pleasantry, (see 3,) of a number of persons,] one with another, (K.) [You say, tfAkhwA They jested, &c., one with another.]
fakihN Eating, or an eater of, faAkihap [i. e. fruit]; (K, TA;) a possessive epithet; applied to a man. (TA.)

Also, (S, Mgh, K,) and faAkihN↓, (K, TA, in the CK faAkihapN,) and fykhAn↓ [app. fayokahaAnN or fayokihaAnN, like tyRahaAnN], (AZ, TA,) (assumed tropical:) Cheerful, happy, or free from straitness; (AZ, S, Mgh, K;) jocose, or given to jesting, (AZ, S, Mgh,) and to laughing: (Mgh, K:) or the first, (K, TA,) and second, (K,) one who talks to his companions and makes them to laugh: (K, TA:) and fakihaAtN, applied to women, cheerful, happy, or free from straitness. (TA.)

And fakihN signifies also (assumed tropical:) Exulting, or rejoicing above measure; or exulting greatly, and behaving insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: (S, TA:) and thus the pl. fakihiyna signifies in the Kur (S, Mgh) xlix. 26 [as some there read]: (S:) faAkihiyna↓ [is the more common reading and] means enjoying an easy and a pleasant life; or enjoying case and plenty. (S, Mgh.)
And (assumed tropical:) Wondering: and thus some explain the pl. fakihuwna in the Kur xxxvi. 55. (TA.)
huwa fakihN biOaEoraADi AlnRaAsi means (tropical:) He is one who delights in speaking evil of men, or in doing so in their absence. (K, TA.)
[fakiyho is said by Golius to signify “ Qui proloqui non potest, ” on the authority of the KL: but in my copy of the KL, I find that the word to which this meaning is assigned is fahiyhN.]
fukaAhapN, a subst. [as distinguished from the inf. n. fakaAhapN], (S, K,) A jesting, or joking; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also fakiyhapN↓. (K.)
fakiyhapN: see what next precedes.
faAkihN Possessing faAkihap [i. e. fruit]; (K, TA:) an epithet of the same class as taAmirN and laAbinN: or, accord. to Aboo-Mo'ádh the grammarian, one whose fruit has become abundant. (TA.)
See also fakihN, in two places.

And [the fem.] faAkihapN, (assumed tropical:) A palm-tree (naxolapN) inducing wonder, or admiration, and pleasure, or joy; or pleasing, or rejoicing; [app. by its having much fruit;] syn. muEojibapN. (K.)

faAkihapN a word of well-known meaning, (S,) Fruit, of any kind; (K;) a thing, or things, the eating whereof is enjoyed, (Mgh, Msb,) whether moist or dry, as figs and melons and raisins and pomegranates: (Msb:) [the words, of the Kur lv. 68, fiyhimaA faAkihapN wanaxolN warumRaAnN have caused it to be much and vainly disputed whether dates and pomegranates be, or be not, included among the things termed fAkhp: it seems to be the general opinion of the lexicologists that they are included; but the contrary opinion is held by many of the lawyers, and by the Imám Aboo- Haneefeh among them:] the pl. is fawaAkihu, meaning kinds thereof. (S.)
And (by way of comparison [thereto], TA) (tropical:) Sweetmeat; syn. HalowaMC; (K;) which is also applied by some to “ fruit ” (fAkhp), (T in art. Hlw,) or to “ sweet fruit. ” (K in that art.)
And faAkihapu AlXRitaMCi [lit. The fruit of winter] is metonymically used as meaning (tropical:) the fire. (Har p. 594.)
faAkihiIRN: see faAkihaAniIRN.
fykhAn: see fakihN, second sentence.
faAkihaAniIRN A seller of faAkihap [i. e. fruit]; (S, K;) as also faAkihiIRN↓; (TA;) but not fakRaAhN. (Sb, TA.)
kaAna mino Oafokahi AlnRaAsi occurs in two trads. [as meaning (assumed tropical:) He was of the most cheerful and jocose of men]. (TA [in which the meaning is indicated by the context].)
OufokuwhapN i. q. OuEojuwbapN (assumed tropical:) [A wonderful thing]. (K.) You say, jaMCa fulaAnN biOufokuwhapK (assumed tropical:) [Such a one did, or uttered, a wonderful thing]. (TA.)

mufokihN (AZ, S, K) and mufokihapN (K) A she-camel whose milk is thick, (K, TA,) like biestings: (TA:) or that yields her milk plentifully on the occasion of eating the [herbage called] rabiyE, before her bringing forth: (S:) or whose milk pours forth on the occasion of parturition, before her bringing forth: or, accord. to Sh, the meaning is that indicated by the second explanation of the verb, 4 [q. v.]. (TA.)

1. falRahu, (M, K,) aor.
falula
, inf. n. falRN, (M, TA,) He broke it, or notched it, in its edge, (M, K,) namely, [a sword or the like, or] anything; (M;) and so fllRehu↓, (K, TA,) [or this signifies he did so much, or in many places,] inf. n. tafoliylN. (TA.)

And i. q. kasarahu [app. as meaning He broke it, in an unrestricted sense; as well as in another sense; as will be shown by what follows]. (S.) walaA falRuwA lahu SaqApF, i. e. [lit.] Nor did they break a stone (kasaruwA HajaraA) belonging to him, was said by 'Áïsheh in describing her father: she alluded thereby to his strength in religion. (TA. [See also qaraEa SafaAtahu, in art. Sfw; and see also magomazN.]) And [in like manner] one says, garobahu AstflR↓ meaning kasarahu [i. e. (assumed tropical:) He broke his sharpness, or vehemence, or valour]. (TA.) And falRa AljayoXa, (S, O, Msb,) or Alqawoma, (M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M, O, Msb,) He defeated (hazama, S, M, O, K, or kasara, Msb) the army, or military force, (S, O, Msb,) or the people, or party. (M, K.) And mano qalRa calRa wamano OamirafalRa, (S, Meyd, O,) a prov., (Meyd, O,) meaning He who has few aiders is overcome, [or becomes abased], and he who has many relations [or who possesses authority to command] defeats (falRa) his enemies. (Meyd. [In Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 683, a different (and I think a wrong) reading is given, with qalRa in the place of falRa; though the reading with falRa is added.]) XajRaki Oawo falRaki Oawo jamaEa kulRFA laki, in the story of Umm-Zara, is said to mean, Whether he wound thee by smiting thy head, or break a limb [of thee], or combine the two deeds to thee: or by flRk is meant altercate, or wrangle, with thee: (TA, in two places:) or the meaning [of flRk] is defeat thee [so I render kasaraki]; or take away thy property; or defeat thee (kasaraki) with his altercation and his censure. (O.)

falRa Eanohu Eaqoluhu, aor.
falala
, [in the CK (erroneously)
falula
,] His intellect, or intelligence, departed from him, and then returned. (M, K.)
2: see above, first sentence.

tafoliylN [as inf. n. of the pass. v. fulRila] means The state of being broken, or notched, [much, or in many places,] in the edge of a knife, or in the edges of the teeth, (T, TA,) and the like, (T,) [i. e.] and also in [the edge of] a sword. (TA.)
4. AflRt AlOaroDu The land became such as is termed filR [q. v.]. (AHn, M.)

And OafalR, (Fr, T,) and OafolalonaA, (S, O,) He (a man, Fr, T,) and we, (S, O,) became in a land such as is termed filR, (Fr, T, S, O,) upon which rain had not fallen: (Fr, T:) or the latter means we trod a land (M, K) such as is termed filR (M) or such as is termed falR. (K.)
And AflR (assumed tropical:) He (a man, S, M, O) lost, or became deprived of, his property: (S, M, O, K:) from filRN applied to land. (M.)
And in like manner, one says, AflR AldRhoru maAlahu (assumed tropical:) [Time, or fortune, deprived him of his property]. (O.)
5: see the next paragraph, in three places:
and see also R. Q. 1, in two places [in each of which the verb is most probably, I think, mistranscribed].

7. AnflR It became broken, or notched, in its edge; as also AftlR↓, and tflRl↓; (M, K, TA;) said of [a sword or the like, or of] anything; (M;) the first quasi-pass. of falRahu, as is also the second; but the third is quasi-pass of flRalahu [and implying that it was so much, or in many places, or said of several things or of several parts of a thing]; (TA;) [therefore] one says [of a sword], maDaAribuhu tafalRalato↓, meaning takasRarato [i. e. Its edges (for the swords of the Arabs in the older times were generally two-edged), or its parts for striking, became broken, or notched, much, or in many places]; (S, TA;) and one says, AnflR sinRuhu, (T, TA,) meaning [simply] His tooth became broken, or notched, in its edge. (TA.) And AnflRwA They became defeated; (S, * M, Msb, K;) as also tflRlwA↓ [but this has an intensive signification]. (M, K.)
8: see the next preceding paragraph.
10: see 1, former half.

AstflR AlXRaIoCa He took of the thing the least portion, (M, K,) because of its difficulty (liEusorihi), (M,) or such as the tenth part thereof (kaEuXorihi): (K:) or AlAistifolaAlu signifies the obtaining a little thing from a difficult place; from a place of the seeking of a right, or due, or of a gift; it having no other object than a thing of little account. (T.)

R. Q. 1. falofala He walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side; (T, O, TA;) as also tafalofala↓: (TA:) or both signify he walked thus, with short steps: (K:) or tflfl↓ signifies [simply] he went with short steps; (En-Nadr, O;) or so tflRl↓. (T accord. to the TT.)
And He rubbed and cleaned his teeth with the [stick called] siwaAk; (T, O, K;) as also tflfl↓; (IAar, O, K;) or so tflRl↓. (T accord. to the TT.)
flfl AlTRaEaAma and AlXRaraAba He peppered the food and the wine or beverage. (M.)
[And flfl AlXRaEara He made the hair very crisp, or such as we term woolly, like that of the negro: see the pass. part. n., below.]
R. Q. 2. tafalofala: see R. Q. 1, in three places.
Said of the hair of a negro, It became very crisp [or such as we term woolly]. (M, TA.)
And tflfl qaAdimataA AlDRaroEi The two anterior teats of the udder became black. (S, O, K.)

yaA fulu, (S in this art. and in art. fln, and K and TA in the latter art.,) meaning yaA fulaAnu [O such a one], (S &c.,) with refa and without tenween, (TA,) is sometimes said to one person, [i. e. to a man,] and yaA fulaAni to two persons, and yaA fuluwna to a pl. number; and yaA fulapu to a female, and yaA fulataAni to two females, and yaA fulaAtu to a pl. number of females, (K, TA,) and sometimes yaA fulaApu, (K, * TA,) thus correctly, of the dial. of some of the tribe of Temeem, in the copies of the K erroneously written yA fulaAtu, (TA,) is said, and some say yaA fula, [in the CK yAflu, but correctly yAfula, i. e., as is said in the TA, binaSobi AllRaAmi,] meaning yaA fulapu: (K, TA:) [J says,] yaA fulu, without teshdeed, said in calling to a person, is apocopated from yaA fulaAnu; not formed in the way of taroxiym, for if it were an instance of trxym they would say yaA fulaA: (S in this art.:) [or,] accord. to Sb, yaA fulu is not held to be an instance of a word from which is elided something that is retained when it is not [thus] used in calling to a person, but the noun in this case is made to be of two letters in the manner of damN [which is originally damawN or damFI or damoIN], and it is thus made to be of two letters because a word that is used in calling to a person or thing is a subject for elision: (M in this art.:) and sometimes ful was used otherwise than in calling to a person, by poetic license, as in the saying of Abu-n-Nejm,

L.foreign: fiI lajRapK Oamosiko fulaAnFA Eano fuli

sense.s:
(S and M in this art.,) meaning En fulaAnK [i. e. In, or amid, a multitude of cries, or noises: (thus expl. in the S:) withhold thou such a one from such a one]: (S in art. fln:) and Sb disallowed the saying fulu as meaning fulaAn [in the CK (erroneously) yA fulu as meaning yA fulaAnu] except [in the vocative form of speech and] in poetry: (M and K and TA in art. fln:) [but] they said [also] fulu bonu fuli, [said to be] an instance of an elision, (T and M in art. fln,) i. e. of the elision of a final w [accord. to some, who hold fulaAnN to be originally fulowaAnN]; (T;) like as they said haIRu bonu baIRK: (T, M:) and OaIo fulo, with the l quiescent, occurs in a trad. respecting the resurrection; meaning yaA fulaAnu: (TA:) Ibn-Buzurj
says that some of the tribe of Asd [i. e. Asd or Asad] say yA fl [app. yaAfulu, without any variation,] in calling to a man and to two men and to a pl. number of men and to a female: (TA in art. fln:) accord. to As, one says yaA fulu and yaA fulaAho; he who says yaA fulu saying thus [when he pauses after it and] when he goes on, making the noun marfooa without tenween; whereas he who says yaAfulaAho says thus when he is silent after it, retaining the h [which is termed the h of pausation]. but when he goes on he rejects the h and makes the noun to be mansoob, saying [for ex.] yaA fulaA qulo [O such a one, say]. (T and TA in art. fln.) [See also muDamRanN (in art. Dmn), last sentence.]

falRN A break, or notch, in the edge, (ISk, T, S, M, O, Msb, K,) of a sword, (ISk, T, S, O, Msb, K,) [or the like,] or of anything; (M;) and so falRapN↓ [i. e. a single break, or notch, in the edge,] of a sword: (TA:) pl. of the former fuluwlN, (ISk, T, S, M, O, Msb, K,) of which an ex. occurs in a verse cited voce bayoda: (O, TA:) it has been said that fuluwlN is an inf. n.; but it is more correctly said to be pl. of falRN. (M.)
And A portion that has fallen off from a thing, like the filings of gold and of silver, and the sparks of fire: (M, K, TA:) pl. fuluwlN. (M, TA.)
And A company (M, K, TA) of men; (TA;) as also faliylN↓: (M, K, TA:) pl. of the former fuluwlN. (TA.)

And it is [an epithet] applied to a number of men, (S, M, O, K, [in the CK in this case, erroneously, fulRN,]) and to a single man, (S, O,) signifying Defeated; (S, M, O, K;) and fulRaI↓ also signifies thus, applied to a katiybap [i. e. a military force, or troop, &c.]; (AA, T, O, K;) like furRaI: (AA, T, O:) one says rajulN falRN and qawomN falRN, and sometimes [when speaking of a number of men] they said fuluwlN and filaAlN; (S, O;) accord. to the copies of the K, the pl. is fuluwlN and OafolaAlN; but correctly the latter is fulRaAlN, like rumRaAnN, as in the M; (TA;) [i. e.] the pl. is fuluwlN and fulRaAlN: and [of falRN used in a pl. sense it is said that] it must be either a quasi-pl. n. or [originally] an inf. n.: if the former, the sing. should by rule be faAlRN, the case being like XaAribN and XarobN, [of which the former is a sing, and the latter is a quasi-pl. n.,] and faAlRN is of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: and flwl is not necessarily pl. of falRN, but is rather pl. of faAlRN; for the pl. of the quasi-pl. n. is extr., like the pl. of the pl.: (M, TA: *) and as to falRaAlN, it is necessarily pl. of faAlRN, for faEolN is not of the forms that have fuERaAlN as the measure of a pl.: (M, TA:) if it [i. e. falRN] be [originally] an inf. n., [this accounts for its being applied alike to a number of men and to a single man, which is not mentioned in the M, or] it is like nasojN in the sense of manosuwjN in the phrase nasoju Alyamani. (M.)

Also Land affected with drought or barrenness; as also filRN↓: or [i. e. the former accord. to the K, but app. each accord. to the text of the M as given in the TT,] such as is rained upon but does not produce plants or herbage: (AO, M, K:) or such as the rain has failed to fall upon during several years: or such as is not rained upon between two lands that have been rained upon: (M, K:) or, accord. to AO, this is termed xaTiyTapN; flR having the second of the meanings expl. in this sentence: (M:) or upon which rain has not fallen: (TA:) [in this sense, in the TT, as from the T, written fil [for filR↓]: and so in the same, as from the T and M, in the sense here following:] or in which is nothing; (T, M, * K; *) so says IAar; whence, he adds, AlfalaApu; but [Az says] I do not think that it is taken thence: (T:) the pl. is like the sing., [or rather the word used as a sing. is likewise used as a pl.,] and OafolaAlN, (M, K,) this pl. form being sometimes used: (M:) or the pl. of AlfilRu↓ is OafolaAlN; and one says also OaroDN OafolaAlN. (T.)
And A sort of cloth made of the hard fibres of flax. (TA.)

falRN a term for yaAsamiyn muDaAEac [Double jasmine], which is [rendered so] either biAltRarokiyb [an expression meaning, as used in the present day, by grafting], or by slitting the stem thereof and inserting into it the [additional] jasmine [app. meaning by budding]: it is a flower of pure whiteness; and the rubbing oneself with its leaves perfumes the body: (TA:) [this name, or, more commonly, filR↓, is now applied to the Arabian jasmine (jasminum sambac), or, as Forskål says (Flora Aegypt. Arab. p. cii.), nyctanthes sambac, mentioned by him among the plants cultivated in El-Yemen.]
[Freytag, misled by the CK, has assigned to this word a meaning belonging to falRN.]
filRN Land in which is no herbage; (K;) or land not rained upon, and in which is no herbage. (S, O.) See also falRN, in three places.
gadaA filRFA mina AlTRaEaAmi, with kesr, means [He went forth early in the morning] devoid of food. (O.)
And filRN mina Alxayori occurs in a verse, (S, O,) in the poetry of 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Rawáhah and in that of Hassán, (S, O,) meaning Devoid of good. (S, TA.) [See EalRN.]
And Such as has become thin, of hair. (K.)
See also fulRN.
falRapN: see falRN, first sentence.
falalN, in a sword [or the like], The state of having breaks, or notches, in the edge. (S, O.)
faliylN: see OafalRu.
Applied to the tusk, or canine tooth, of a camel, Broken (S, M, O, K) in the edge. (S, O.)
See also falRN, first quarter.

Also, and faliylapN↓, a quantity of hair collected together: (S, M, O, K:) the two words are either of the class of salRN and salRapN [which are exactly syn., each with the other,] or are an instance of the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] that does not differ from its sing. [or n. un.] except in [its not having] the [affix] p: (M:) in one instance, occurring in a trad., the latter is said to signify a kubRap [or portion convolved, or glomerated, or formed into a ball] of hair, or, as Z says, app. of [the silk called] dimaqos: the pl. [of either] is falaAYilu. (TA.) Hence, (O,) faliylapN↓ signifies also The mane of the lion. (O, TA.) In the saying of Sá'ideh Ibn-Ju-eiyeh,

[And he was left remaining, and a hyena having stripes upon its arms, (thus mucarRaEapN as used in this verse is expl. in the TA in art. cdE, q. v.,) a young mother, (Oumayoma being an instance of taroxiym, used by poetic license, for Oumayomapu, a dim. of OumRN,) and therefore unusually fierce, having a mane, or having convolved, or glomerated, hair, came to him at night, or in the beginning of the night], the last word is expl. by Suh, in the R, as meaning the Earof [so in my original, an obvious mistranscription for Eurof, with damm]; but by Skr as meaning XaEar makobuwb. (TA.)

And faliylN signifies also [The membranous fibres that grow at the base of the branches of the palm-tree, called] liyf: (M, K:) so in the dial. of Hudheyl: (TA:) and fulifulN↓ signifies the same. (K.)
faliylapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
fulRaI: see falRufilRyRapN, in the former half.

filRiyRapN, (T, * K, TA,) like EilRiyRapN, (TA,) or falRiyRapN, (O, *) [in the TT, as from the T, and in the O. written without the sign of teshdeed to the l (app. because it is sufficiently indicated by the heading of the art. and by the pl. of this word), and in the CK, erroneously, filoyap,] Land upon which the rain [that should have been that] of its year has not fallen until the falling of the rain of the next year upon it: pl. falaAliIRu: (ISh, T, O, K:) [and Az says,] I have heard them call thus (i. e. by the sing.) land in which is nothing; like filRN as expl. by IAar. (T.)

fulofulN, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) also pronounced filofilN↓, (K,) but the vulgar pronounce it [thus] with kesr, (O,) and the pronouncing it with kesr is said to be not allowable, (Msb,) a word of Pers. origin, (M,) arabicized, from PiloPil, with kesr, (O,) [or PuloPul; i. e. Pepper;] a sort of berry, (HabRN, S, O, K,) brought from India, (O, K, *) well known, (S, M, O,) not growing in the land of the Arabs, but often mentioned in their language: AHn was informed by one who had seen it that its tree is just like the pomegranate; (M, TA;) but Dáwood the hakeem adds that it is taller; (TA;) between the pair of leaves thereof are two fruit-stalks, regularly disposed, each fruitstalk of the length of the finger; and it is green, and is then plucked, and spread in the shade, and becomes black and shrivelled; and it [the tree] has thorns, like those of the pomegranate: when it [i. e. the fruit] is fresh and moist, it is preserved
with water and salt until it becomes mature, when it is eaten like as preserved herbs are eaten upon the tables of food, and it is a digestive: the n. un. is fulofulapN↓ [app. meaning a peppercorn, like HabRapu fulofulK: and HabRu fulofulK means peppercorns, collectively]: (M, TA:) Dáwood says, in the “ Tedhkireh, ” that its leaves are thin, red next the tree and green in the other direction, and its wood is lank and soft: and it is white and black: (TA:) the white is the better. (TA.) [A long description of its properties, with additions in the TA, some of them well known and others fanciful, I omit as being needless.]

daArufuloful, or daArufilofil↓, (accord. to different copies of the K,) [app. daArufulofulN, or perhaps daArafulofulN, a compound of two words (both originally Pers.) made one, as such written in the K with the article (AldRArflfl), and perfectly declinable, because (although a compound of two nouns) it is not a proper name,] is The tree of the fuloful when it first bears fruit, accord. to the K; but several writers declare that the tree of [the] dAr flfl is not the same as the tree of the flfl: (MF, TA:) [dAr flfl is one of the names now applied to long pepper, and is commonly pronounced daArofilofilo:] it is [generally] known in Egypt by the name of Eiroqu AlcRahabi, [another term, now used, for long pepper,] and is called in Pers. PlPl drAz [i. e. PuloPildaraAz, the latter of which words signifies “ long ”]: (TA:) it increases the venereal faculty, causes the food to digest; removes colic, (K, TA,) and flatulence; (TA;) and is beneficial as a remedy against the bite, or sting, of venomous reptiles, applied as a liniment, with oil. (K, TA.)

fulofulN is also a name sometimes applied to The fruit of the barowaq [q. v., in art. brq]; likening it to the fulofulN mentioned before [i. e. to peppercorns]: he who pronounces it, when thus applied, filofilN↓ errs; for this signifies the fruit of certain trees of the [kind called] EiDaAh; and the people of El-Yemen call thus [particularly] the fruit of the [species of EiDaAh. termed] gaAf [q. v.]. (M.)
fulofulu AlmaMCi is the name of A certain plant growing in the neighbourhood of water, lank, soft, or smooth, in the leaves, having berries (HabRi) in bunches. (TA.)
fulofulu Alquruwdi is The same as HbR Allym [but what this is I do not find]. (TA.)
fulofulu AlSRaqaAlibapi is What is called [in Pers.] fnjnkXt [i. e. fanojanokuXot: see Alfaqodu]. (TA.)

[falaAfilu is pl. of fulofulN.] And falaAfilu AlsRuwdaAni is the name of Certain berries (HabR), round and smooth, in sheaths, or cases, (guluf,) and in receptacles (OaboyaAt) like the Sanawobar [or cone of the pine, app. in form]. (TA.)
See also faliylN, last sentence.

fulofulN signifies also A sharp, or clever, servant; (T, O, K;) and filofilN↓ is said to signify thus likewise by Mullà 'Alee, in his “ Námoos, ” and even more commonly: but this requires consideration. (MF, TA.)
filofilN: see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence: and the same again, in three places.
fulofulapN n. un. of fulofulN; q. v., former half.

OafolRu, applied to a sword [or the like], (T, S, O, K,) Having breaks, or notches, in its edge; (T, S, * O; *) or broken, or notched, in its edge; as also mafoluwlN↓ and munofalRN↓. (M, K.) AlOafalRu was the name of a sword of 'Adee Ibn-Hátim (O, K) Et- Tá-ee. (O.)
mufalRalN, applied to a naDiIR [app. as meaning an arrow-head] Broken by having hit stones. (S.) And, applied to front teeth (vagorN) Serrated. (T.)
mafolawlN: see OafalRu.
munofalRN: see OafalRu.

mufalofalN, applied to food, (TA,) and to wine, (T, TA,) [Peppered, i. e.] having fuloful put into it, (T, M, * TA,) and consequently burning the tongue: (T, TA:) or wine that burns [the tongue] like fuloful. (S, O, K, TA.)

And A garment, or piece of cloth, figured with round forms resembling fuloful [or peppercorns] in roundness and smallness; (T, O, TA;) i. e. (TA) figured with the like of the SaEaAriyr [pl. of SuEoruwrapN] of fuloful. (M, K, TA.)
And Very crisp hair, [such as we term woolly,] (T, O, K, TA,) like that of the negro. (TA.)
And A hide worn, or eroded, by the tan, (nahiakahu AldRibaAgu, M, K, in the CK nahakahu AldRabRAgu,) the like of fuloful [or peppercorns] appearing in it. (TA.)
1. falata, intrans. and trans., syn. with Oafolata, q. v. (Msb.) See also 8.
3. fAlthu bihi, (A, TA,) inf. n. mufaAlatapN (A, O, TA) and filaAtN, (O, K, TA,) He came upon him suddenly, at unawares, or unexpectedly, with it. (A, O, * K, * TA.)

4. Aflt, (T, S, O, Msb, TA,) inf. n. UifolaAtN; (T, Msb, TA;) and Anflt↓; (T, S, O, TA;) and tflRt↓; (S, O, TA;) and falata↓, aor.
falita
, inf. n. falotN; (Msb;) signify the same; (T, S, O, Msb, TA;) i. e. He, or it, (a bird, &c., Msb, or a thing, S, O,) escaped; got away; or became, or got, loose, clear, quit, free, or at liberty; (O, Msb, TA;) [or did so] suddenly: (TA:) or UifolaAtN and AinofilaAtN↓ and tafalRutN↓ signify a thing's going forth suddenly: (Mgh:) or Anflt↓ signifies he, or it, went forth quickly: (Msb:) and one says OafolataniI, (M, K,) for Aflt minRiI [he escaped, &c., from me]; (Sgh, TA in art. jrE;) and mnRI tflRt↓, and Anflt↓; (M, K;) all signifying the same. (TA.) [See exs. voce juroEapN; and another ex. in art. HS, conj. 7.]
See also 5.

Aflthu; (T, S, M, O, Msb, K;) and ↓2, aor.
falita
, inf. n. falotN; both verbs being trans. as well as intrans.; (Msb;) He made him, or it, [and he suffered him, or it,] (namely, a man, M, or a bird, &c., Msb,) to escape, or get away, or to become, or get, loose, clear, quit, free, or at liberty; he set him, or it, loose, free, or at liberty; (T, M, O, Msb, TA;) he saved him, or freed him, from destruction. (T, TA.) [See, again, HuroEapN.]
5: see 4, in three places.

tflRt EalayonaA, (Mgh,) or Ealayohi, (O, K, TA,) He seized, (Mgh, O, K, TA,) or came suddenly, (TA,) upon us, (Mgh,) or upon him. (O, K, TA.) Hence, in a trad. of Umm-Háni, fatafalRata EalayohimaA liyaqotulahumaA [And he seized upon them both to slay them]. (Mgh.)

And tflRt Uilayohi He was desirous of it, or he longed for it; (M, O, K, TA;) as also Oafolata↓; namely, a thing. (M, TA.) Hence the saying, OaraAhu yatafalRatu UilaI SuHobatika [I see him to be desirous of thy companionship]. (TA.) And one says, laA OaraIlaka Oano tatafalRata UilaI hRcaA walaA Oano tataflRata Eanohu [I am not of opinion that thou shouldst be desirous of this, nor that thou shouldst be averse from it]. (TA.)
7: see 4, in four places.

8. Aftlthu He took it quickly, or hastily; namely, a thing: (M, TA:) or he seized it, or carried it off, by force; or took it hastily and openly; or snatched it at unawares. (As, O.) And it is doubly trans.: you say, AifotalatahaA QllRehu nafosahaA [God took away from her suddenly her soul]: and hence, Aufotulitato nafosahaA [lit. She had her soul taken away from her suddenly]; (O, TA;) a phrase occurring in a trad., (T, O, TA,) meaning she died suddenly, without disease: (T, TA:) you say, Aufotulita nafosahu, meaning He died suddenly; (M, TA;) and Aufotulita nafosuhu; (S, TA;) with the nfs in the accus. case and in the nom. case; (TA;) and Aufotulita alone; meaning he died suddenly. (S4, O, K, TA.) [See also AufotuYita, in art. fOt; and Aufotiyta in the same.] And Aifotalatahu Almawotu; and falatahu↓; as also lafatahu; Death took him away suddenly. (IAar, T, TA.)
And Aufotulita biOmori kacaA He was taken suddenly by such a thing, before his preparing for it. (O, K, TA: omitted in the CK.)
And Aufotuilta Ealayohi The affair was decided against him exclusively of him [i. e. without his having any part in the decision]. (TA.) [See also 8 in art. fwt.]
Aufotulita also signifies It (any affair) was done without pausing. (T, TA.)
And one says, Aifotalata AlkalaAma, meaning He extemporized the speech; spoke it without consideration, or thought, or preparation, or without pausing, or hesitating. (S, M, O, K.)
falatN Escape: one says, layosa laka mino hecaA AlOamori falatN There is no escape for thee from this affair, or event, or case. (En-Nadr, T, K, * TA. *)
fulatN and fulRatN: see falataAnN.

falotapN A sudden, or an unexpected, event; or a thing that comes upon one suddenly, or at unawares: and anything done without consideration: (IAth, L, TA:) and an affair, or event, that happens without its being soundly, thoroughly, or well, performed or effected: pl. falataAtN: it has no broken pl.: (M, TA:) and falataAtN signifies
slips, or faults, of an assembly, or a company of men sitting together. (T, O, K, TA.) One says, maAta falotapN [He died suddenly]. (M.) And kaAna celika falotapF That (meaning an affair, or event, S, O) was sudden, or unexpected; (S, M, O, Msb, K, TA;) without premeditation, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) and without a wavering in opinion: (S, O, K, TA:) or, as some say, it was [like] a thing hastily and forcibly seized, or snatched: (L, TA:) and, accord. to some, it is derived from falotapN in the sense next following. (O, * TA.)

The last night of any of the sacred months, of which night people differ as to whether it be lawful to war therein or not, wherefore the avenger of blood hastens to obtain retaliation.
