fawojN A company, congregated body, party, or group, of men; (S, A, O, L, Msb, K; *) as also faAYijN↓, (L,) and faAYijapN↓, (K,) and fayojN↓, (O, K, and Msb in art. fyj, q. v.,) which last is said by Az to be originally fayRijN, from faAja, aor. yafuwju, like hayRinN from haAna, aor. yahuwnu, for which they say also hayono: (O, and Msb * in art. fyj:) or a crowd, or dense company &c.: (so accord. to an explanation of the first of the following pls. by Z in the Ksh and by Bd, both in Kur cx. 2:) or a company, &c., of the followers, or dependants, of chiefs: or a great crowd of men: (L:) [and app. (assumed tropical:) a multitude of things: (see an ex. voce Oafokalu, in art. fkl:)] pl. [of pauc.] OafowaAjN [also used as a pl. of mult.] (S, O, Msb, K) and [of mult.] fuWuwjN and pl. pl. OafaAwiyju (S, O, Msb, K) and OafaAwiju (S, O, K) and OafaAYiju, as though pl. of OafiyjapN. (O.)
fayojN: see the next preceding paragraph:
and see also art. fyj.
faAYijN: see fawojN. One says, marRa binaA faAYiju waliymapi fulaAnK, meaning The company (fawoj) of those that were at the repast of such a one [passed by us]. (TA.)
It is said that faAYijN, applied to a she-camel, signifies Fat: or such as is termed HaAYil, and fat: but the word commonly known [thus used] is faAYijN [q. v.]. (TA.)
faAYijapN: see fawojN:
and see also art. fyj.

1. faAHa Almisoku, (Msb, K,) aor. yafuwHu and yafiyHu; (Msb;) or faAHato riyHu Almisoki, aor. tafuwHu and tafiyHu; (S;) inf. n. fawoHN (S, Msb, K) and fuWuwHN and fawaHaAnu, (S, K,) and fayoHN (S, Msb, K) and fayaHaAnN; (S, K;) The musk diffused [or exhaled] its odour; (Msb, K;) or the odour of the musk diffused itself [or became exhaled]; and fAH AlTRiybu the perfume diffused [or exhaled] its odour; (S;) or this last signifies the perfume became perceptible; or it clung and remained; [in a garment or person;] syn. Eabiqa: (Msb in art. fyH:) the verb is not used in relation to a foul, or disagreeable odour or thing: (S, A, Msb, K:) of such an odour one says habRato: (Msb:) or the former verb is common to both: (K:) but this assertion is outweighed [by the other]: (TA:) fawoxN signifies the giving forth, and exhaling, a sweet, or pleasant, odour: (KL:) and the perceiving such an odour: Fr says that faAHato riyHuhu and faAxato are syn.; but AZ says the fawoxN is attended by sound. (TA.)
For other significations of this verb, see art. fyH.
4. AfAH: for this verb, see art. fyH.

entry.xml:id: nazalonaA fiI busotaAnK tanaAwaHato OaToyaAruhu watafaAwaHato OanowaAruhu

form.orth: nazalonaA fiI busotaAnK tanaAwaHato OaToyaAruhu watafaAwaHato OanowaAruhu

sense.s: 6. nazalonaA fiI busotaAnK tanaAwaHato OaToyaAruhu watafaAwaHato OanowaAruhu [We alighted in a garden the birds of which warbled plaintively, one to another, and the flowers of which exhaled sweet odours, one with another]. (A.)
fawoHN AlHayoDi The chief and first portion of the menstrual discharge. (L.)
fawoHapN [A spreading, or an exhalation], of perfume. (TA in art. ESr.)

1. faAxati AlrRiyHu, aor. tafuwxu, inf. n. fawaxaAnN; (K;) as also fAxt, aor. tafiyxu, (K in art. fyx,) inf. n. fayoxN and fayaxaAnN; (TA in art. fyx;) The wind, or odour, rose, or diffused itself: (K:) you say, faAxato minohu riyHN TayRibapN, aor. tafuwxu and tafiyxu, a sweet odour diffused itself from him, or it; like fAHt: (AO, As, S:) or fAxt AlrRiyHu, aor. tafuwxu, (AZ, S, K,) inf. n. fawoxN (AZ, TA in art. fwH,) or fawaxaAnN, (AZ, TA in the present art.,) signifies the wind made a sound, or noise, (AZ, S, K, TA,) in its blowing. (AZ, TA.)
And fAx AlHarRu The heat became allayed, or assuaged. (L.)
See also the next paragraph, in two places.

4. AfAx, (AZ, S, K,) inf. n. UifaAxapN, (Lth, AZ, S, IAth,) He (a man) emitted wind, (Lth, AZ, S, K,) with a sound, (AZ, S,) from the anus; (Lth;) and fAx↓, aor. yafuwxu, inf. n. fawaxaAnN (K, TA) and fawoxN, (TA,) signifies the same: (K, TA:) or the former, he voided excrement with an emission of wind: (IAth, TA:) [mentioned also in art. fyx:] and he (a man, or a beast,) emitted wind in voiding urine: (ISh, S:) and fAx↓, aor. yafuwxu, it (the emission of excrement) made a sound. (L.)
AfAx bibawolihi He emitted his urine from a dilated aperture. (L.) And AfAxt She (a camel) made a sprinkling with her urine. (L.)

AfAx AlzRiqRa, inf. n. as above, He opened the mouth of the zqR [or skin for wine &c.] to give vent to the air within it: thus accord. to Fr; who says that he heard a sheykh, of those having knowledge in the Arabic language, explain this phrase as meaning he smeared the inside of the zqR with rubR [or rob]. (L.)

Oafixo Eanoka mina AlZRahiyrapi, (L, TA,) in the K EanRaA, but correctly Enk, as in other lexicons, (TA,) [as also OafiH,] means Oaborido, (L, K,) i. e. Stay thou until the mid-day heat shall have become assuaged, and the air be cool. (L, TA.)

1. faAda, aor. yafuwdu, (S, Mgh, O, K, and T in art. fyd,) inf. n. fawodN; (AA, K, and T in art. fyd;) as also faAda, aor. yafiydu, (S, O, K, and T &c. in art. fyd,) inf. n. fayodN; (IAar, K, and T in art. fyd;) He died. (T, S, Mgh, O, K.)

And fAd, aor. yafuwdu, (M,) inf. n. fawodN, (K,) It (property) continued, or belonged, or appertained, syn. vabata, (M, K,) liSaAHibihi to its owner; (M;) as also fAd, aor. yafiydu, (S, L, K, in art. fyd,) inf. n. fayodN: (K:) or (so in the K) it went away, passed away, or departed; (K;) as also fAd, aor. yafiydu, (K in art. fyd,) inf. n. fayodN. (K. [See also art. fyd.])

fAdhu, (As, Yaakoob, T, M, L,) aor. yafuwduhu, (Yaa- koob, M, * L,) inf. n. fawodN, (K,) He mixed it, (M, L, K,) namely, saffron [&c.], (M, L,) or perfume &c., (As, T,) or moistened it with water &c.; (L;) syn. daAfahu; (As, Yaakoob, T, M, L;) from which it is formed by transposition [accord. to the lexicologists; but not accord. to the grammarians, because it has an inf. n.]: (M, L:) and so fAdhu, aor. yafiyduhu, (S, L, K, in art. fyd,) inf. n. fayodN. (L. [See also art. fyd.])
4. Oafadotuhu I killed him; destroyed him. (O, K. [See also art. fyd.])
And I gave him property. (M, L, K.) It belongs to this art. and to art. fyd [q. v.]. (L.)
See also 10.
5. tfwRd fawoqa Aljabala He (a mountain-goat) ascended (OaXorafa) upon the mountain. (O, * L, K.)

6. humaA yatafaAwadaAni AlEiloma (ISh, K) is a phrase used by the vulgar, (ISh,) but the correct expression is yatafaAyadaAni, meaning They two impart knowledge, each to the other: (K:) or ytfAydAn baAlomaAli bayonahumaA They two give, of the property, each to the other; or profit, or benefit, each other therewith: (ISh:) or, in the opinion of MF, each is allowable. (TA. [See also art. fyd.])

10. AstfAdhu, (M, L, K,) and AfAdhu↓, (M, K,) [respecting which latter see 10 in art. fyd,] as also tqyRd, (K, [but this belongs to art. fyd only,]) He gained it, acquired it, or got it, for himself, namely, property [&c.]. (M, L, K.) [See more in art. fyd.]

fawodN Each of the two sides of the head: (As, S, M, A, O, L, Msb, K:) pl. OafowaAdN: (M, L, Msb:) one says, badaA AlXRayobu bifawodayohi [Hoariness appeared in the two sides of his head]. (S, O, L.) And The main, or chief, portion of the hair of the head, next the ear; (M, L, K;) or of the hair that descends below the lobe of the ear, next the ear: (IF, L, Msb:) or fawodaAni signifies [two locks, or plaited locks, of hair, such as are termed] DafiyrataAni (ISk, S, O, L, Msb) of a man (ISk, S, O, L) and of a woman. (O.)

(assumed tropical:) The side (K, TA) of anything; (TA;) each of the two sides (M, L) of a thing. (L.) You say, AirofaEo fawoda AlxibaMCi (tropical:) Raise thou the side of the tent. (A.) And nazaluwA bayona fawodaIi AlwaAdiI (tropical:) [They alighted, or abode, between the two sides of the valley]. (A.)

(tropical:) Each of the two equiponderant halves of the load of a beast: (S, M, O, L, K, TA:) one says, qaEada bayona Alfawodayoni (tropical:) [He sat between the two equiponderant halves of the load of the beast]. (S, O, L, TA.) And [hence, app.,] (assumed tropical:) A [sack such as is termed] juwaAliq. (K.)

(assumed tropical:) The part that is abundant in plumage of each of the wings of the eagle: (M:) [or each of the wings; for] one says, Oaloqati AlEuqaAbu fawodayohaA EalaI Alhayovami (tropical:) [The eagle cast] its wings [upon, or over, the eaglet]. (A.)
One says also, jaEalotu AlkitaAba fawodayni, meaning (tropical:) I doubled the upper part of the letter, or writing, over the lower part, so that it became two halves. (A, O.)
And Aisotalamotu fawoda Albayoti (tropical:) [I touched, by kissing, or with the hand,] the corner of the House [of God; i. e., of the Kaabeh]. (A.)
Also A company, congregated body, party, or group, of men; or a crowd, or dense company &c.; or a great crowd of men; syn. fawoj: (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K:) pl. OafowaAdN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)
fawaAdN, (O, K,) with fet-h to the f, (O,) like saHaAb [in form], (K,) i. q. fuWaAdN [generally meaning The heart (see other explanations in art. fOd)]; (O, K;) a dial. var. of the latter word. (O.)
faAYidapN a subst. from faAda AlmaAlu, (M, K, and L in art. fyd,) in the sense of vabata: (M, and L in art. fyd:) it belongs to this art. and to art. fyd. (TA. [See the latter art.])
mafuwdN, applied to perfume &c., i. q. maduwfN [Mixed, or moistened with water &c.]; (As, T;) as also mufiydN. (S and O and L in art. fyd.)
rajulN mitolaAfN mifowaAdN A destructive man; as also mifoyaAdN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

1. faAra, (M, Msb, K,) aor. yafuwru, said of water; (Msb;) and faArato, aor. tafuwru, said of a qidor [or
cooking-pot]; (T, S;) inf. n. faworN and fawaraAnN (T, S, M, Msb, K) [the latter of which is the more common] and fuWuwrN (M, K) and fuwaArN; (M, TA;) It boiled, or estuated. (T, S, M, Msb, K.)
[fAr said of a liquor, It fermented. (See nabiycN.)
Said of blood, and of wine, It flushed, or mantled, in the cheeks or head.]
fArt nafosuhu His soul [or stomach] heaved; or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; i. q. vArt [q. v.]. (T in art. vwr.)
fAr faAYiruhu↓ i. q. vAr vaAYiruhu (T, S, K) His anger boiled [or became roused or excited]; (S;) or he was, or became, angry. (TA.)

[And ↓the same phrase is expl. in the M, accord. to the transcript in the TT, as signifying AinotaXara gaDabuhu; but I think that the right reading is evidently EaSabuhu; and the meaning, His sinews became swollen; said of a horse or the like: see art. nXr; and see also faAYirN, below.]

fAr AlEiroqu, inf. n. fawaraAnN, The vein became excited, or in a state of commotion, and flowed forth [with blood]: (M, K, TA:) to which is added in the K, waDaraba; but this is a mistake, occasioned by a false reading of the next words in the M, which are waDarobN fawRaArN ragiybN waAsiEN. (TA. [See fawRaArN.])
faworu AlEiroqi, in a horse means The vein's having inflations, or knots, [or a varicose condition,] apparent in it; which is disapproved. (ISk, TA.)
fAr said of water signifies also It welled, and came forth, from the earth, or ground: (Mgh:) it appeared, pouring forth, from the spring, or source. (TA.)
fArwA is said of men assembled in market-places [app. as meaning They bustled, or were in a state of commotion]. (TA.)
fAr Almisoku, inf. n. fuwaArN and fawaraAnN, [The odour of] the musk spread. (M, K.)
furotuhu: see 4.
Also (furotuhu) I made for it, i. e. the balance, what are termed fiyaAraAni [dual of fiyaArN, q. v.]. (Th, M, K.)
2. fwRr lilnRufasaMCi He made what is termed fiyrap [q. v.] for the woman in the state following childbirth. (M, K.)
4. Oafarotuhu and furotuhu↓ I made it to boil, or estuate. (IAar, M, K.)

AlfaAru The muscles of a man: (M, K:) also mentioned in art. fOri, as written with C. (TA.) Oaborizo naAraka waUino hazalota faAraka [Put forth thy fire, that passengers may see it and be attracted by it, though thou make lean thy muscles,] is a saying meaning (assumed tropical:) give food though thou injure thy body [by doing so]. (M, L.)
See also faOorN (with which it is syn. in other senses), in art. fOr.
faworN [originally an inf. n.: see 1.] The burning, or heat, and boiling, of Hell. (TA.) And Intenseness, or vehemence, of heat; (TA;) as also faworapN↓. (S.)
faworu AlXRafaqi The remains of the redness in the western horizon after sunset: as also vaworuhu. (TA.) [See also faworapN.]

And A time: (TA:) [or rather] the present time in which is no delaying. (Msb.) Thus in the saying, AlXRufoEapu EalaI Alfawori [The right of pre-emption is to be had] in the present time in which is no delaying. (Msb.)

And hence, A state in which is no delay. (Msb.) You say, jaMCa fulaAnN fiI HaAjatihi vumRa rajaEa mino faworihi [Such a one came for the object of his want,] then returned immediately, or at once: or, as some say, with the same motion with which he came, not ceasing from motion after it; properly, conjoining what was before the coming with what was after it, without tarrying. (Msb.) And OatawoA mino faworihimo, meaning mino wajohihimo [i. e., app., They came in a headlong manner; like the phrase maDaI EalaI wajohihi]; (M, K, TA; but the M has jaAWuwA instead of OatawoA;) and this is said by Zj to be the meaning of mino faworihimo in the Kur iii. 121: (M, TA:) or qabola Oano yasokunuwA [before their resting, or ceasing from motion]: (K, TA:) or mino faworihimo in the Kur ubi suprà means in the commencement of their procedure: (O:) or in, or at, their instant of time; (Ksh, Bd;) i. e. [in, or at, the same instant, or] immediately: (Bd:) and Oatayotu fulaAnFA mino faworiI, meaning qabola Oano Oasokuna [i. e. I came to such a one before my resting, or ceasing from motion]. (S, O.) And you say, faEalotuhu mino faworiI, meaning I did it at once, or instantly. (T, TA.)

fuwrN Gazelles: (T, S, M, K:) a word having no sing.; (T, S, M, TA;) accord. to IAar and Yaakoob: (TA:) or its sing. is faAYirN↓; (M, K, TA;) accord. to Kr. (TA.) One says, laA OafoEalu kacaA maA laOolaOati Alfuwru I will not do such a thing while the gazelles wag their tails. (IAar, T, S.)

faArapN Almisoki The odour of musk: or the bag, or receptacle, [i. e. the follicle, or vesicle,] thereof: (M, L:) [Sgh says that] this and what next follows have been mentioned in art. fOr, [q. v.,] but should more properly be mentioned in the present art., both being from faAra, aor. yafuwru. (O.)
faArapu AlUibili means The sweet exhalation from the skins of the camels when they are moist after returning from the water. (M, K.)
faworapN: see faworN:
and fuwaArapN.
Also An ebullition of anger, rage, or passion; syn. haAYijN. (S and K in art. hyj.)
And Freshness, or newness: so in the saying Oaxacotu AlXRaIoCa bifaworatihi [I took the thing in its fresh, or new, state]. (TA.)
[And hence,] faworapu AlnRahaAri The first part, or beginning, of the day. (T, TA.) And faworapu AlEiXaMCi The time [next] after the EiXaMC [or nightfall]. (S, TA.)
faworapu AlnRaAsi The place where people congregate, and where they bustle, or are in a state of commotion, (yafuwruwna,) in their market-places. (TA.)
faworapu Aljabali The higher, or highest, part; and the elevated and hard, or elevated and plain or level, part; of the mountain. (K.)
fuwrapN i. q. fuWorapN [expl. in art. fOr] meaning A certain flatus in the pastern of a horse [&c.]. (O, K.)
And i. q. kuwfapN [A round piece, or collection, of red sand; or a piece, or collection, of sand mixed with pebbles; &c.]. (Kr, M, K.)
fiyrapN Fenugreek (HulobapN) mixed [in the manner described voce faYiyrapN (q. v.) in art. fOr] for the woman in the state following childbirth. (M, K.)

fiyaArN sing. of fiyaAraAni, (T,) which signifies The two things (T, S, M, O, K) of iron (M, K) between which is the tongue of the balance: (T, S, M, O, K:) originally with w in the place of the I, (M, O,) changed into I because of the kesreh before it. (O.)

fuwaArapN The froth, or foam, that boils, or boils over, of a cooking-pot: (S and K in this art. * and voce TubaAxapN:) and mafaAwiru↓ signifies the same, mentioned by Ibn-'Abbád. (O.) And [in like manner] faworapN↓ signifies The mantling foam upon the surface of wine. (TA.)
fawRaArN [an intensive epithet from faAra; signifying Boiling much; &c.:
and Water, &c., welling forth abundantly; gushing].
[Hence,] DarobN fawRaArN A smiting [that inflicts a wound] such as is wide, (IAar, M, TA,) so that the blood flows [abundantly]: (M:) a poet says,

(IAar, M, TA. [The text of the M as given in the TT, for taraI AldRama, has yurI Aldm; and for Oano yaEiyXaA, it has Aw yEyXA: and the right reading of the first hemistich seems to be, biDarobK tuxafRitu fawRaArapK; for an inf. n. is sometimes made fem.: see an instance of Darob as fem. in the EM p. 157: the poet means, With a smiting that silences, or kills, inflicting a wide and gushing wound; and a piercing with the spear in consequence of which thou seest the blood sprinkled: when they slay a horseman of you, we are responsible for him after it that he shall live: i. e., as is said in the M, his blood shall be revenged, so that he will be as though he had not been slain: and it is also there said that by yxfRt fwRArh is meant lnhA wAsEp fdmhA ysyl wlA Swt lh; in which the two fem. pronouns and the fem. epithet all relate to the word Darob, agreeably with what I have stated to be in my opinion the right reading of the first hemistich.])
fayRuwrN Sharp, as an epithet applied to a man; syn. HadiydN. (O, K.) See also TayRuwrN.

fawRaArapN, (accord. to the K,) or fuwRaArapN↓, (accord. to a copy of the M,) A source, or spring, of water: (M, K:) [the latter word is app. the right in this case; for] IAar says that fuwRaArapN↓ is applied to a wave: and to a birokap [i. e. watering-trough, or the like; or basin, pool, pond; &c.]: and fawRaArapN, to anything that is not water: and in one place he says that dawRaArapN and fawRaArapN are applied to anything that does not move nor turn round; and duwRaArapN and fuwRaArapN↓ to such as moves and turns round. (T,
TA.)

fawRaArapu Alwariki, with fet-h and teshdeed, signifies The hole, or perforating aperture, of the wrk [or haunch]: (S, O:) or the fawRaArap, (K,) or fuwRaArap↓, (so in a copy of the M,) is an aperture in the warik [or haunch], to the belly, or interior of the body, not obstructed by bone: (M, K:) [these two explanations plainly apply to the sacroischiatic foramen: but what here follows is consistent with what precedes, though somewhat less clear:] or the fawRaArataAni, (K,) or fuwRaArataAni↓, (accord. to a copy of the M,) are [two parts, in the region of the pelvis, described as being] sikRataAni [a word which I do not find to have any proper meaning that would be here apposite, but which seems to be applied in this case, by a kind of catachresis, to two parts through which a weapon or the like may pass,] between [each of] the haunch-bones or hip-bones (bayona Alwarikayoni) and the quHoquH [or ischium], towards the side of the warik [or hip-bone], (M, K,) not intervening as obstacles in the way to the belly, or interior of the body; and they are what become in a state of commotion in the act of walking, or going along. (M.) [See also AlfaAYilu, in art. fyl] And accord. to Lth, the term fawRaArataAni, (O, and so in a copy of the T,) or fuwRaArataAni↓, (so in another copy of the T,) is applied to Two appertenances of the kariX [or stomach, properly of a ruminant animal], having within them two small nodous lumps (gudRataAni), which latter are not eaten, and each of which is a piece of flesh in the midst of red flesh. (T, O.)
fuwRaArapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in six places.
faAYirN [part. n. of 1:
hence, faAra faAYiruhu]: see 1, in two places.

Applied to a beast, of the equine and other kinds, Swollen in the sinews; syn. munotaXiru AlEaSabi. (K. [In the TA, this is said to be a mistake for mntXr AlgaDabi, and thus I find it to be written in the L, and in a copy of the M accord. to the TT: but see what I have said, in the first paragraph of this art., respecting the phrase above mentioned.])
See also fuwrN.
mafaAwiru: see fuwaArapN.

1. faAza, aor. yafuwzu, inf. n. fawozN (S, A, O, Msb, K) and mafaAzN and mafaAzapN, (TA,) He attained, acquired, gained, or won, good, or good fortune, (S, A, O, Msb, * K,) or his wish or desire, or what he desired or sought; (Bd in iii. 182, and TA;) he met with, or experienced, that for which one would be regarded with a wish to be in the like condition, without its being desired that it should pass away from him; he became far from what was disliked, or hated, or evil: (TA:) he succeeded, or was successful: he won, or gained the victory: (Msb:) [he had his arrow drawn, or] his arrow came forth [from the ribaAbap], in the game called Almayosir: and (tropical:) it (an arrow) won; or came forth before its fellow [or fellows in that game]. (O, * TA.) You say, faAza bihi He attained it, acquired it, gained it, or won it; (Kh, A, O, Msb, K;) namely, good, or good fortune; (Kh, O;) or reward: (A:) and he took it away, went away with it. (S, K.)

He became safe, or secure; he escaped. (S, A, O, Msb, K.) You say, faAza minhu He became safe, or secure, from it; he escaped it; (A, O, K;) namely, evil; (TA;) or punishment. (A, O, TA.) And TuwbaI limano faAza biAlvRawaAbi wafaAza mina AlEiqaAbi A happy end is his who gains reward and escapes punishment. (A.)

And faAza, (S, O, K,) aor. yafuwzu, (TA,) inf. n. fawozN, (S, A, K,) (tropical:) He perished: (S, A, K:) he died; and so fawRazN↓: (S, A, O, Msb, K:) thus the former bears two contr. significations: (A, K:) but IB says that, accord. to some, the latter is not used in this sense unless preceded by another phrase such as in the following ex.: fulaAnN baEodahu maAta fulaAnN wafawRaza↓ [Such a one died and such a one died after him]: and accord. to others, fwRz↓ signifies (tropical:) he became in the mafaAzap [or state of temporary safety] which is between the present life and that which is to come. (TA.) [This last signification is given in the A.]
See also 2.

2. fwRz (assumed tropical:) He went, or his course brought him, to the mafaAzap: (IAar, TA:) or (tropical:) he went upon the mfAzp: (A, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) he went away. (IAar, O, K:) or (tropical:) he went away into the mfAzp: (A:) and faAza↓ signifies (assumed tropical:) he traversed the mfAzp. (Msb.) You say, fwRz biUibilihi (S, A, O, K) (tropical:) He entered upon the mfAzp with his camels. (S, O, K.)
Also (assumed tropical:) He went forth from one land or country to another: and tfwRz↓ signifies the same as fwRz. (TA.)
See also 1, latter part, in three places.
And, said of a road, It was, or became, apparent: (O, K:) and Sgh adds. [but not in the O,] and it stopped, or came to an end. (TA.)
4. AfAzhu bikacaA He (God, S, O, K, or a man, Msb) caused him to attain, acquire, gain, or win, such a thing. (S, O, Msb, K.)
5: see 2.
faAzN: see what next follows.

faAzapN A [tent such as is called] miZalRap, (S, K.) with two poles, (K,) or that is extended with a pole: (S; in which is added, “ it is in my opinion an Arabic word: ”) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] faAzN↓. (ISd, TA.)

faAYizapN (tropical:) A thing that rejoices one, and by which one attains good or the object of his desire: you say, faAza bifaAYizapK (tropical:) He attained, acquired, gained, or won, a thing that rejoiced him, &c. (A, O, * TA.)
mafaAzN: see the following paragraph, near the end.

mafaAzapN A place of safety, security, or escape. (S, A, O, K.) So in the Kur [iii. 185], falaA taHosibanRahumo bimafaAzapK mina AlEacaAbi [Do thou by no means reckon them to be in a place of security from punishment]: (S, A, * O:) or, accord. to Fr, the meaning here is, far from punishment. (TA.)

A cause, or means, of prosperity, or success, or of the attainment or acquisition of that which one desires or seeks, or of what is good, or of that whereby one becomes in a happy or good state; syn. mafolaHapN. (A.)
(tropical:) [The state of temporary safety which is between the present life and that which is to come. See 1, last signification.]

(tropical:) A place of perdition, or destruction: (Msb, K: *) or i. q. falaApN: (A:) [i. e.] a desert; syn. barRiyRapN; any [desert such as is called] qaforN: (TA:) or a desert in which is no water: (ISh, O, K:) and a desert in which is no water for the space of a journey of two nights or more: when there is none for the space of a journey of a night and a day, it is not thus called. (ISh, O, TA:) or a tract in which two wateringplaces are so far apart that camels are kept from drinking two days, with a portion of the day preceding them and of the day following them, [accord. to that which is generally preferred of the explanations of the term riboEN which is here employed,] and other animals [that journey quicker] drink on alternate days; as also falaApN: or such as is between that in which camels are kept from drinking two days &c. as above, and that in which other animals drink on alternate days; as also fayofaApN: (TA:) so called to prognosticate good fortune, and safety. (As, IF, S, A, O, Msb,) as meaning a place of safety, (A,) from faAza signifying “ he became safe: ” (Msb:) or from fawRaza, (IAar, S, O, * Msb,) or faAza. (AHei, TA.) signifying “ he perished, ” (IAar, S, O, * AHei,) or “ he died: ” (Msb, TA:) AHei condemns the former of these assertions; but Az and ISd say that it is the more commonly approved, though the latter is the more agreeable with analogy: (TA:) or it is so called because he who comes forth from it, having traversed it, is safe: (IAar, TA:) the pl. is mafaAwizu: (S:) and mafaAzN↓ signifies the same as mafaAzapN. so in a trad. of Kaab Ibn-Málik; faQsotaqobala safarFA baEiydFA wamafaAzFA [And he saw before him, or looked forward to, a far journey and a desert, or a waterless desert, &c.]. (TA.)

3. AlmufaAwaSapu signifies The being clear, or perspicuous, syn. AlbayaAnu, (S, O, K,) in talk or discourse (fiI AlHadiyvi). (S. [In the O, and K, mina AlHadiyvi; and hence it is said in the TK that faAwaSa AlHadiyva signifies bayRanahu He made the talk, or discourse, clear, or perspicuous: but for this I do not find any authority.]) Some say AlmufaAyaSapu. (IB, TA in art. fyS.) [See also 4 in art. fyS.]
4. maA OafaASa bikalimapi: see art. fyS. [It seems to be indicated in the S that this is from AlmufaAwaSapu, expl. above: and the like of this is app. said by IB.]

6. AltRafaAwuSu signifies AltRabaAyunu [The being, or becoming, separated, one from another]; from Albayonu, not from AlbayaAnu: (O, K:) originally AltRafaAyuSu; mentioned also [in a different sense] in art. fyS. (TA.) See the latter art.

2. fwRD Uilayohi AlOamora, (S, M, A, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. tafowiyDN, (Mgh, O, Msb,) He committed to him the thing, affair, or case; syn. radRa (S, A, O, K,) or SayRara, (M,) or salRama; (Mgh, Msb;) abstaining from contention, or litigation; (Mgh;) and made him arbiter thereof. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [xl. 47], (TA,) waOufawRiDu OamoriI UilaI AllReh (A, TA) And I commit my case unto God, making Him arbiter thereof. (TA.)

AltRafowiyDu fiI AlnRikaAHi, (S, O,) or nikaAHu AltRafowiyDi, (TA,) is The giving [a woman] in marriage without [requiring] a dowry. (S, O, TA.) You say, fwRD AlmaroOapi He gave the woman in marriage without [requiring] a dowry. (K.) And fawRaDato buDoEahaA UilaI zawojihaA, (Mgh,) or fawRaDato nikaAHahaA UilaI AlzRawoji, (Msb,) She married herself to her husband without a dowry: (Mgh, Msb:) or fawRaDato signifies She gave up, or renounced, the ordinance of the dowry. (Msb.)

3. mufaADapN signifies The being copartner, or copartners, in everything; (O, K;) [as though each of two persons, or every one of more than two, committed all that he had to the other, or others;] as also tafaAwuDN↓. (K.) [See 6.] Hence, (TA,) Xirokapu AlmufaAwaDapi Copartnership in everything; (Lth, M, S, A, * Mgh, * TA;) in which everything is common property; (Lth, M, TA;) opposed to Xirokapu AlEinaAni, which is copartnership in one thing: (Lth:) or copartnership of two persons in all that they possess: (Msb:) or copartnership of two persons in all that is in their hands, or that they may afterwards acquire; which is null and void accord. to Esh-Sháfi'ee, but allowable accord. to Aboo-Haneefeh and his two companions [Aboo-Yoosuf and Mohammad]. (TA.) You say, XaArakotuhu Xirokapa mufaAwaDapK I was copartner with him in all the property that we both together possessed. (Az, TA.) Hence also, (TA,) mufaAwaDapu AlEulamaMCi The conversing and conferring of the learned on matters of science; each of two persons receiving what the other had [to communicate], and giving what he himself had to the other; as though each committed what he had to his companion. (O, * TA.)
The commixing [in social intercourse]. (A.)
The being coequal. (A, O, K.)

The competing (mujaAraApN) in an affair. (K.) You say, faAwaDahu fiI Oamorihi, (S, O, TA,) or fiI kacaA, (Mgh,) He competed with him, (jaAraAhu, S, Mgh, O, TA, [for which Golius has read jAzAh, whence he has been led to assign to fAwD a wrong meaning, which Freytag has inadvertently copied,]) and did like as he did, (Mgh,) in his affair, (S, TA,) or in such an affair. (Mgh.) And faAwaDotuhu I competed with him; syn. jaArayotuhu: and kaAna bayonahumaA mufaAwaDapN [There was, between them two, competing]. (A.)
6: see 3. You say, tafaAwaDa AlXRariykaAni fiI AlmaAli The two partners were sharers in the property altogether: (S, O, TA:) or tfAwD AlXrykAn signifies the two partners were coequal. (A, Mgh.)
[Hence, tfAwDwA They conversed and conferred together; every one receiving what the others had to communicate, and giving what he himself had to the others: see 3.
And They mixed together in social intercourse: see, again, 3.]
tfAwDwA AlHadiyva They [discoursed together; or] began, or commenced, or entered upon, discourse. (M, Msb.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. zhw.]
Also, tfAwDwA fiI AlOamori They competed (faAwaDa baEoDuhumo baEoDFA, [every one doing like as the others did,]) in the affair. (S, O, K.)
fawoDapN a subst. from mufaAwaDapN (O, TA) [signifying, app., Copartnership: &c.].

qawomN fawoDaI A party, or company, of men who are equals, having no chief: (S, O, Msb, K:) or separated, or in a state of dispersion; (Lth, O, K;) fwDI being pl. of faAYiDN, which is not in use: (Lth, O:) or mixed, (S, O, M, K,) one with another; (S, O, K;) in which sense, also, fwDI is applied to a number of ostriches: (S, O:) or having no commander, nor any to collect them together: (M:) or mixed, and having no commander over them. (A.) You say, AlnRaAsu fawoDaI fiI hecaA The people are equals in this; there is no distinction to be made between them. (Mgh.) And jaMCa Alqawomu fawoDaI The party, or company, of men came mixed together. (S.) And AlwaHoXu fawoDaI The wild animals are in a state of separation, or dispersion, (O, TA,) going to and fro. (TA.) OamowaAluhumo fawoDaI bayonahumo Their possessions are property which they share among themselves; as also fayoDuwDaMCu and fayoDuwDaI. (S.) And mataAEuhumo fawoDaI bayonahumo, and fawoDaI faDFA, Their goods are common property among them. (M.) And AlmaAlu fawoDaI bayonahumo The property is promiscuous among them: whosoever desireth of them a thing taketh it. (Msb.) And kaAnato xayobaru fawoDaI Kheyber was promiscuous (Mgh) common property (Mgh, Msb) among the Companions; not divided. (Msb.)

Oamoruhumo fawoDaI, and fawoDaMCu↓, (M,) or fawoDaI bayonahumo, and fayoDaI, (TA,) Their case is mixed, or promiscuous: or is equal among them: (Lh, M, TA:) or Oamoruhumo fawoDaI bayonahumo, (AZ, O, K,) or bayonahumo fawoDuwDaMCu↓, (TA,) or both, (O, TA,) Their case is mixed, or promiscuous, (AZ, O, K,) every one of them making free use of that which belongs to another, (K,) one wearing the garment of another, and one eating the food of another, none of them consulting his companion respecting that which he does without his order. (AZ, O.) [See a similar phrase voce maXowarapN.]
fawoDaMCu: and see fwDI, last sentence.
fawoDuwDaMCu: see fwDI, last sentence.
tafowaADapN Remains of life: (O, TA:) so in the saying, raOayotu AltRafowaADapa lifulaAnK (O) or bifulaAnK (TA) [I saw the remains of life pertaining to, or in, such a one].

mufawRiDapN A woman who marries herself to her husband without a dowry: (Mgh, Msb:) or who gives up, or renounces, the ordinance of the dowry: (Msb:) or, accord. to some, the word is mufawRaDapN, (Mgh, Msb,) meaning married by her guardian without the naming of the dowry: (Mgh:) or meaning having the affair of the dowry committed to her by the law, so that she may make it obligatory or annul it: (Msb:) or meaning married without the mention of a dowry, or on the condition of her having no dowry. (KT.)
2. fwRThu, inf. n. tafowiyTN, He clad him, or attired him, with a fuwTap. (TA.)

fuwTapN sing. of fuwaTN, which signifies Cloths that are brought from Es-Sind, (Lth, O, K, TA,) thick, or coarse, and short, used as waistwrappers: (Lth, O, TA:) or striped waistwrappers: (K:) Az says, I have not heard this word in aught of the language of the Arabs, and I know not whether it be an Arabic word or of the language of the foreigners, but I have seen in El-Koofeh striped waist-wrappers, which are sold, and are bought by the camel-drivers and the Arabs of the desert and the servants and the people of the lowest sort, who use them as waist-wrappers, and call them thus; sing. fuwTapN: IDrd says that it is not an Arabic word: (O, TA:) it is added in the K, or it is a word of the language of Es-Sind: Sgh says, (TA,) fwTh is a word of the language of Es-Sind, arabicized, from Puwtah, with a dammeh not fully sounded: (O, TA:) [and SM adds,] it is called with us in El-Yemen, OazohariyRap: and by reason of frequency of usage, they have derived from it the verb above-mentioned. (TA.) The dim. of fuwTapN is fawayoTapN↓. (Har p. 294.) [See also De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, see. ed., i. 195.]

It (the pl.) is also applied to Short napkins, with striped extremities, woven at El-Mahalleh ElKubrà, in Egypt, which a man puts upon his knees to preserve himself therewith [from being soiled] at meals [and with which the hands are wiped after washing]. (TA.)
fuwTiIRN Blue, but not of a clear blueness. (TA.)
fuwayoTapN dim. of fuwTapN, q. v.
fawRaATN A weaver, or seller, of fuwaT, pl. of fuwTapN. (TA.)
mufawRaTN A man clad, or attired, with a fuwTap. (TA.)
1. faAZa, aor. yafuwZu, inf. n. fawoZN and fawaAZN: see faAZa in art. fyZ.

1. maA faAfa bixayorK, (T, M, O,) or maA faAfa EanRiI bixayorK, (K.) walaA zanojara, (T, O, K,) aor. yafuwfu, (K,) inf. n. fawofN, (T, M, O, K,) [may be rendered He did
not benefit, or he did not benefit me, with what might be taken between the nail of his thumb and that of his forefinger, nor did he with what might be taken by the inside of the nail of the thumb from the extremity of the fore tooth; i. e., with a thing inconceivably small; or with anything; being] a phrase meaning one's answering (T, M, O, K) a person who has asked for a thing (T, O, K) by putting his thumb-nail upon the nail of his fore finger, (T, M, O, K,) and by taking away the inner side of the nail [of the thumb] from the extremity of the fore tooth, (T, O,) and saying “ Not [even] this [will I give thee], ” (T, O, K,) or “ Not [even] the like of this. ” (M.)
fawofN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

fuwfN The whiteness that is upon the nails of young persons; (S, M, O, K;) as also fawofN↓; (T, M, K;) the latter mentioned by Fr, but not known by IAar; (T;) or the former is the more common: (K:) n. un. with p↓; (M, K;) meaning a portion thereof. (M.)

And The integument [or pellicle] that is upon [what is termed] the core of the heart, and the stone of the date. (EalaI HabRapi Alqalobi waAlnRawaApi,) beneath the flesh [or pulpy substance] of the date: (M, K:) of the white grain [i. e. the embryo, which resembles a white grain,] in the interior of the date stone, from which the palm-tree grows forth [or germinates]: and it is said that fuwfapN↓ signifies the integument [or pellicle] that is upon the date stone (S, O:) [i. e.] the thin integument that is upon the date-stone; also called the qiTomiyr. (T.)

[Hence, or from one of the significations mentioned above,] one says, maA OagonaI EanRiI fuwfFA i. e. [He (a man, S, O) did not avail me] aught. (S, O, K.) And maA caAqa fuwfaA [He tasted not] aught. (T, K.)
And fuwfN signifies also Any integument; (M, K;) and so fuwfapN↓. (K)
And The bladder of an animal of the bovine kind; as also fawofN↓: (K.) mentioned by Sgh in the TS. (TA.)

Also A sort of the [garments called] baruwd of El-Yemen: (M, K:) thin, variegated, or figured, garments of El-Yemen: (IAar, T:) and one says also burodN fuwfiIRN↓, and vuwviIRN, which is formed by substitution, and mentioned by Yaakoob, and burodu OafowaAfK meaning a burod having white stripes. (M.) and so burodN mufawRafN↓; (S, M, K;) or this last and burodu OafowaAfK signify a thin burod; (S, O, K, TA;) and in like manner one says HulRapu OafowaAfK. (TA.) OafowaAfN is pl. of fuwfN: (S, O:) and accord. to Lth, the OafowaAf are of the [buruwd called] EaSob [q. v.] of ElYemen. (O.)
Also Flowers or blossoms, syn. zahorN: [in the CK zahar;] used in this sense by Ibn-Ahmar; being likened by him to the garments called fuwf. (T, K, TA.)
And Portions of cotton: (O, K, and so in some copies of the S:) [perhaps meaning] a white thing [resembling cotton] which is in the EuXar [q. v.]. (Ham p. 784.)
[And Freytag mentions its signifying The extreme portion of the penis; as on the authority of the K: but he seems to have confounded fuwfN with fuwqN.]
fuwfapN the subst. denoted by the verb faAfa: (M, TA:) [as such,] it is coupled by a poet with zinojiyr [which is similar to it is meaning: see this last word]. (S, O, TA.)
Also n. un. of fuwfN. (S, M, O, K.) See this latter word, in three places.
burodN fuwfiIRN: see fuwfN, latter half.
burodN mufawRafN: see fuwfN, latter half.

gurofapN mufawRafapN, the mention of which occurs in a trad. of Kaab, means [An upper chamber] whereof one brick is of gold and another of silver [i. e. constructed of gold and silver bricks alternately]. (TA.)

Anfwfl, (K, [there said to be biAlDamRi waAlfatoHi, app. indicating that it is Alfuwfulu and Alfawofalu, but accord. to the CK and TK Alfuwfalu, and thus only, as though it were said to be baAlDRamRi faAlafotiH.]) or XajarapN Alfawofali, (thus written in the O, [in the TT, as from the M, Xjr Alfwfl, thus, without the affix p to the former word, and without any vowel sign,]) accord. to AHn, (M,) or Aboo-Ziyád, (O,). A palm-tree, [the areca catechu, or betel nut palm,] like the cocoa-nut palm, that bears racemes upon which are the fwfl, resembling dates, (M, O, K,) of which some are black and some are red, not of the growth of the land of the Arab: (O:) [in one of my copies of the S, the fwofal (thus the word is there written) is said to be a tree like the cocoa-nut not in the other copy it is not mentioned:] the fwfl is said by AHn to be the fruit of a certain palm-tree, hard as though it were wood: (M:) in the Tedhkireh of Dáwood it is said to be a fruit like the Syrian jawoz [or walnut], of an astringent quality, found upon trees resembling the cocoa-nut: (TA:) it is good for hot and gross humours, (K, TA.) prepared as a liniment; (TA;) and for inflammation of the eye, (K, TA,) as a dressing and collyrium; and has great efficacy for drying up the seminal fluid, and as a digestive. (TA.)

1. faAqahumo, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) derived from fawoq as signifying the contr. of taHot, Mgh.) aor. yafuwquhumo, (S, O.) inf. n. fawoqN (O, K) and fawaAqN (K) and fawoqaAnN, (CK.) He (a man, S, O, Msb) was, or became, above them, or superior to them, or excelled them, or surpassed them, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) namely, his companions, (S, O, Msb, K,) or others (Mgh) in eminence, or dignity, or nobility. (S, O, K;) and he overcame them; (Msb, TA:) and did so in, or by, an argument fuqotu fulaAnFA I became better than such a one, and higher, and more eminent or noble; as though above him in station.(TA.) And faAqati AljaAriyapu biAljamaAli The young woman excelled in beauty, or comliness]. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., HubRiba UilaIRa AljamaAlu HatRaI maA OuHibRu Oano yafuwfaniI OaHadN biXiraAki naEolK [Comeliness has been made lovely to me so that I love not that any one should excel me in the thong of a sandal] (TA.)

fAq, (S, O, K,) aor. yafuwqu, (O,) inf. n. fuwaAqN, (S, O, K,) said of a man, (S,) means that The wind rose from his chest; (S, O, K;) [i. e. he hiccoughed, or hickuped; a signification indicated by its being said that] fuwaAqN means the reiterating of an overpowering [or involuntary] sobbing sound: (Msb, TA:) and fuwaAqN↓ [as a subst.] signifies also the wind [itself] that rises from the chest (S, O, K) of a man. (S, O)

And, accord. to Az, (Msb,) fAq, (Msb, TA,) aor. yafuwqu. (Msb,) inf. n. fuwaAqN (Msb, TA) and fuWuwqN, (TA.) He was affected, or taken with a panting, or breathing [shortly, or] uninterruptedly. (Msb, TA.)

And fAq binafosihi, (S, * O, K,) aor. yafuwqN, (S, O,) inf. n. fuwuwqN [or fuWuwqN (S, O, K) and fuwaAqN. (K,) said of a man, (S.) His spirit was about to pass forth: (S, O, K:) or he gave up his spirit. (S, * O, * K:) as also fAq [alone] aor. yfyq (IAar, O and K in art. fyq:) or he died. (K;) or fuwaAqN↓ [is app. held by some to be a simple subst., and] accord. to IAar signifies death itself: (TA:) or it signifies, (S, O, Msb,) or signifies also, (K.) an affection [i. e. a gasping, or show catching of the breath,] incident to a man at the point of death: (S, O, Msb, K:) and one says [of the man], fAq, aor. yafuwqu, inf. n. fwq [app. fawaqN]; the verb being of the class of Talaba of which the inf. n. most commonly used is Talaba; or, if the saying that the verb is of the class of Talaba be not meant to indicate the form of its inf. n. as well as that of its aor., fwq may be a mistranscription for fuWuwqN or fuWuwqN] (Msb.)

fAqt, (O, K,) aor. tafuwqu, inf. n. fuwaAqN, (TA.) She (a camel) had in her udder the fiyqap, or milk that had collected between two milkings. (O, K, TA;) and (K) so OafaAqato↓ (S, O, K) or the latter verb signifies she (a camel) attained to the time for the being milked: and the inf. n. is UifaAqapN and quasi-inf. n.] fuwaAqN↓: (IAar, TA:) or UifaAqapN in relation to the she-camel means her being driven, or led back from the pasturing, and left until she rests, and recovers [her milk]. (ISb, TA:) and UifaAqapN AldRirRapi signifies the returning of the milk. Zeyd Ibn-Kethweh, TA.) [See also fuwaAqN, below.]

fawoqN signifies A bending, or [thus in the TA is from the K, but in copies of the K "and,"] a breaking. (K, TA,) in the notch (fiI Alfawqi) (K,) or in one of the two cusps of the notch, (TA.) of an arrow: (K, TA:) or its verb said of an arrow, is fAq, aor. yafaAqu, inf. n. faAqN and fawoqN, in which the w is then made movent with fet-h. [so that the word becomes fawqN,] because this verb is of the class of faEila, aor. yafoEalu: (K, TA.) or one says of an arrow fawiqa, [aor yafowaqu,] inf. n. fawaqN, meaning its notch broke: (Msb;) and AnfAq↓ said of an arrow signifies thus; (S, Msb;) or its notch became much broken. (O, K, TA;) or became split, or cracked. (TA.)
And fuqotu AlsRhom, (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. fawoqN, (Msb,) I broke the notch of the arrow. (S, O, Msb, K.) And fAq AlXRaIoCa, aor. yafuwqu, He broke the thing. (TA.)
fAq in the sense of AftAq [from faAqapN] is not allowable. (S, O.)
2. fwRqhu, inf. n. tafowiyqN, He made him, or judged him, to excel, or to have excelled. (TA.)

fwRq AlfaSiyla, (S, O, K,) inf. n. as above, said of the pastor, (TA,) He gave to the young unweaned camel to drink the quantities of milk that had collected in the udder between two milkings time after time. (S, O, K, TA. [See fuwaAqN.])

And [hence] one says, fawRaqaniI AlOamaAniIRa waOaroDaEaniI OafaAwiyqa↓ birRihi (tropical:) [He made me to obtain on repeated occasions the things wished for, and nourished me with the recurrent supplies of his bounty]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. of 'Alee, UinRa baniI OumayRapa layufawRiquwnaniI turaAva muHamRadK, meaning (assumed tropical:) [Verily the sons of Umeiyeh] give to me by little and little of the property [constituting the heritage of Mohammad]. (TA.)
See also 10.
fwRq AlsRahoma, (inf. n. as above, Msb,) He made to the arrow a fuwq [i. e. notch for the bow-string]. (S, O, Msb, K.)
And [hence,] fwRq AlmaroOapa (assumed tropical:) He slit the vulva of the woman. (TA in art. sws.)
See also the next paragraph, last sentence.

4. UifaAqapN, (O, K, TA,) some say, (O, TA,) signifies A resting; (O, K, TA;) from fuwaAqN↓ signifying a resting between two milkings; (O, TA;) which latter meaning, as well as the former, the K erroneously assigns to the former word. (TA.)
And OafaAqato said of a she-camel, signifies the same as faAqato expl. above: see 1, latter half, (O, K, TA.)

And [hence, perhaps,] AfAq mino maraDihi, (S, O, K, TA,) and mino sukorihi, (S, O,) and mino gaXoyatihi, (O, TA,) inf. n. UifaAqahu; (TA;) and AstfAq↓; both signify the same; (S, O, K;) i. e. He returned to a healthy, or sound, state [of body and of mind, from his disease, and from his intoxication, and from his swoon, or fit of insensibility]: (O, K, TA:) or one says of the diseased, AfAq and AstfAq↓ meaning he became convalescent; or recovered, but not completely, his health and strength: and the subst. [or quasi-inf. n.] is fuwaAqN↓: (TA:) and one says of the insane, or possessed, AfAq, inf. n. UifaAqapN, meaning he recovered his intel-ligence; and of the intoxicated, likewise, AfAq, originally AfAq mino sukorihi, like as one says AisotayoqaZa mino nawomihi: (Msb:) [and it is said that] AlAisotifaAqapu↓ as syn. with AlUifaAqapu is derived from fawoq meaning the contr. of taHot, like as taEalRaI mino maraDihi and tamaAvala are from AlEuluwRu and Almuvuwlu: (Har p. 132:) but accord. to 'Alee Ibn-'Eesà, AstfAq↓ signifies he sought, or desired, AlUifaAqap. (Ham p. 541.)
And [hence,] AfAq AlzRamaAnu (tropical:) The time became abundant in herbage after barrenness or drought. (O, K, TA.)

Oafaqotu AlsRahoma, (inf. n. UifaAqapN, Msb,) I put the fuwq [or notch] of the arrow upon the bowstring, (S, O, Msb, * K,) to shoot with it; (S, O, Msb;) as also Oawofaqotuhu: but Oafowaqotuhu is extr., (S, O, K,) and should not be said, (S, O,) or, accord. to Yoo, one says Oafowaqotuhu also: (O:) and, accord. to the A, AlsRahoma fwRq↓ signifies [in like manner] he put the bow-string into the notch of the arrow on the occasion of shooting. (TA.)
5. tfwRq EalaI qawomihi He exalted himself above his people, or party. (O, * K, * TA.)
tfwRq said of a young unweaned camel, He drank [or sucked] the quantities of milk that had collected in the udder between two milkings time after time. (S, O, K.)
And tafawRaqahaA He milked her, namely, a camel, drawing from her the quantities of milk that had collected in her udder time after time; (O, K;) as also AstfAqhA↓. (K. [But see this latter below.])

Hence the trad. respecting Aboo-Moosà, that he was discoursing with Ma'ádh, of reciting the Kur-án, and said, OamRaA OanaA faOatafawRaquhu tafawRuqa AllRaquwHi [As for me, I draw it forth in the manner of the drawing forth of the milk of the milch camel at the times when it has collected in her udder], meaning (tropical:) I do not recite my set portion at once, but piecemeal, in my night and my day. (S, O, TA.)

One says also tfwRq XaraAbahu i. e. (tropical:) He drank his wine, or beverage, part after part. (TA.) Sb has mentioned that yatajarRaEahu and yatafawRaqahu are said of that which is not a labouring to do a thing at once, but is an act after an act, performed in a leisurely manner. (O, TA.)
7. AnfAq It (a thing) broke, or became broken; quasi-pass. of faAqa AlXRaIoCa meaning kasarahu. (TA.)
See also 1, near the end.
Said of a camel, He became lean, or emaciated:
and He perished, or died. (O, K.)
8. AftAq He was, or became, poor, or in want, or need: (S, O, Msb, K:) faAqa in this sense is not allowable. (S, O.)
And He died with much fuwaAq [which may here mean either hiccoughing (which often occurs at the close of a fatal fever &c.), or gasping, or short catching of the breath]. (O, K.)
10: see 4, in four places.

AstfAqhA: see 5. [It signifies as there explained: or it signifies, or signifies also,] He delayed the milking her, namely, a camel, until her milk collected in her udder, or in order that it might collect; and so fwRqhA↓, inf. n. tafowiyqN. (TA.) One says, Aisotafiqi AlnRaAqapa Milk not thou the she-camel before the time. (O, * K.)

And maA yasotafiyqu mina AlXRaraAbi He does not abstain [from drinking wine]: (O, K, TA:) or he does not drink it in the set time: or he does not appoint a time for drinking it, but drinks it always. (TA.)
faAqN A [large bowl such as is termed] jafonap, filled with food. (Lth, T, O, K.)
And Cooked olive-oil. (O, K, TA.) So in the saying of Shemmákh, (O, TA, *) describing the hair of a woman, (TA,)

[She stood showing to thee hair abundant and luxuriant, or abundant and long, in respect of growth, let down, like the black serpents that have been anointed with cooked olive-oil]: or, as some say, meaning AlOanofaAq, meaning fresh olive-oil [from UinofaAq, a Pers. word signifying “ olive-oil ”]: or, as AA relates it, the poet said, qado XudRixona biAlfaAqi [that have been crushed in the fAq]; and accord. to him the last word has the meaning here next following. (O, TA.)
And The desert; syn. SaHoraMCu: (O, K, TA:) so says AA: and on one occasion he says that AlfAq means a certain land: (O: a meaning also mentioned in the K:) or a certain wide land. (TA.)
It is also expl. as signifying baAn [i. e. Oil of ben]: and also A comb: on the authority of Th: and it may have either of these meanings in the verse cited above. (TA.)

And accord. to the K, it signifies Tall, and incongruous in make; and so fuwqN↓ and fuwqapN↓ and fiyqN↓ and fuwaAqN↓ and fuyaAqN↓: but these words are all correctly, in this [or a similar] sense with two káfs. (TA.)
Also, accord. to the K, A certain aquatic bird, long in the neck: but this, likewise, is correctly with two káfs. (TA.)

fawoq is the contr. of taHot; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) [primarily signifying The location that is above, or over;] and is an adv. n. (Mgh, Msb, K) of place; (Mgh, Msb;) and a simple noun, indecl., [with dammeh for its termination, when the noun to which it should be prefixed is suppressed, and the meaning of this is intended to be understood, but not the word itself;] but when it is prefixed to another noun [which is either expressed or itself (and not merely its meaning) meant to be understood, and when the noun to which it should be prefixed is suppressed and neither this nor its meaning is meant to be understood,] it is declinable. (K. [For the words yakuwnu QsomFA waZarofFA maboniIRN, the reading of the K in the TA and CK, my MS. copy of the K (which I follow in this case) has ykwn ZrfA wAsmA mbnyRA.]) One says, zayodN fawoqa AlsRaToHi [Zeyd is above, or rather upon, the house-top]. (Mgh, Msb.) And AlEimaAmapu fawoqa AlrRaOosi [The turban is above, or upon, the head]. (Mgh.) And TafaA fawoqa AlmaMCi It floated upon the water. (S &c. in art. Tfw.) Ks has mentioned the saying, Oafawoqa tanaAmu Oamo Oasofala [Dost thou, or wilt thou, sleep in the part that is above of the house &c., or in the part that is below? i. e., in the upper part, or in the lower part?] with fet-h, as suppressing the noun to which fwq is [meant to be understood as] prefixed. (TA.) Lth says that he who uses it as a Sifap [by which (like other old writers) he means an adv. n. of place] should use the accus. case, as when one says, Eabodu QllRehi fawoqa zayodK ['Abd-Allah is above Zeyd]: but if you make it simply a noun, you use the nom. case, and say, fawoquhu raOosuhu [His superior (meaning upper) part is his head]; for in this instance it is the head itself, and you make each to be governed in the nom. case by the other. (TA.) In the saying in the Kur [xvi. 28], faxarRa Ealayohimu QlsRaqofu mino fawoqihimo [And the roof fell on them from above them], the utility of the phrase mn fwqhm is hardly apparent,
because Elyhm sometimes serves in its stead: but IJ says that mn fwqhm may here have a useful office; for EalaI is sometimes used in relation to deeds [or events] that are difficult, and deemed onerous; [for instance,] you say, qado sironaA EaXorFA wabaqiyato EalayonaA layolataAni [We have journeyed ten nights and the journeys two nights have remained as though incumbent on us]; &c.; so that if it were said fxrR Elyhm Alsqf without the adding mn fwqhm, it might be supposed to be like the saying Ealayohimo daAruhumo qado xaribato [Their abode had become in a state of ruin as a punishment upon them]; but when He [referring to God] says mn fwqhm, that meaning which was supposable ceases to be so; and the meaning becomes this, that it [the roof] fell when they were beneath it. (TA.) Uico jaAWuwkumo mino fawoqikumo wamino Oasofala minokumo [When they came to you from above you and from below you], in the Kur [xxxiii. 10], relates to Benoo- Kureydhah, who came to them from above them; and to Kureysh and Ghatafán, who came from the district of Mekkeh, from below them. (TA.) waQlRaciyna QtRaquwA fawoqahumo yawoma QloqiyaAmapi, in the Kur [ii. 208], means (assumed tropical:) [But those who have been careful of their religious duties] shall be above them in station [on the day of resurrection]. (O.) And one says, [agreeably with what has been stated in the first sentence of this paragraph, Oaxacahu mino fawoqu, and Oaxacahu mino fawoqK, [meaning (assumed tropical:) He overcame him, or overpowered him, and in like manner OataAhu mn fwq, as expl. in the Ham p. 128. i. e. qaharahu namely, his adversary; and so a hawk, his pr? or quarry. (M and K in an expl. of OadalRa Ealayoh, in art. dl.) And [in a similar manner] fawoq is metaphorically used as denoting excess, (Mgh, Msb.) and excellence: (Msb:) thus one says, AlEaXarapu fawoqa AltRisoEapi (Mgh, Msb) i. e. (tropical:) Ten is above nine; meaning ten exceeds nine: (Msb:) and hecaA fawoqa caAka (Mgh, Msb) i. e. (tropical:) [This is above, or superior to, that;] meaning this is more excellent than that; (Msb:) and hence, (Mgh, Msb,) in the Kur iii. 24], (S, O,) baEuwDapF famaA fawoqahaA i. e. (tropical:) [A gnat and] what exceeds it (Mgh, Msb) in smallness, or in largeness; (Mgh, Msb, K;) what is smaller than it, (AO, S, O,) or what is larger than it, by the latter being meant the fly [mentioned in the Kur xxii. 72] and the spider [mentioned in xxix. 40], (Fr, S, O,) and the phrase as expl. in the former sense being like the reply to him who says “ Such a one is small ” celika wafawoqa i. e. (assumed tropical:) And smaller than that: (AO, O:) hence also, in the Kur iii. 12], faUino kunRa nisaMCF fawoqa Qvonatayoni (Mgh, Msb) i. e. (tropical:) [And if they are women,] exceeding two. (Msb.)

fuwqN The part, of the arrow, which is the place of the bow-string; [i. e. the notch thereof;] (S, O, Msb, K;) as also fuwqapN↓: (Msb, K;) the former is masc., and also, like the latter, fem. (IAmb, Msb:) and AlfuwqaAni signifies the zanamataAni [or two cusps of the fuwq, between which is put the bow string]; (O, K;) thus these are termed by the tribe of Hudheyl; but a poet who has used the dual form is said by AO to has mead thereby a single fuwq: (O:) the pl. [of mult.] is fuwaqN and [of pauc.] OafowaAqN; (S, O, Msb, K;) or, accord. to ISk, these are pls. of fuwqapN; (TA;) and qufFA also is a pl., formed by transposition; [see an ex. in a verse cited voce EuroquwbN;] (K, TA;) one says fuqowapN and fuqFA [for fuwqapN and fuwaqN]. (TA.) sahomN cuw fuwqK means An arrow rendered complete by its having a fuwq:

and hence caA fuwqK occurring in a trad. [as meaning (assumed tropical:) A complete share; for sahomN signifies “ a share ” as well as “ an arrow ”]. (A'Obeyd, O.) And OaEolaAhumo fuwqFA, meaning (tropical:) He, or they, of them, haring the largest share of religion, is a metaphorical phrase, from the fuwq of the arrow. (TA.)

And they say, Oaqobilo EalaI fuwqi nabolika, [or, app., fuwaqi nabolika, for nabolN is a coll. n., meaning “ arrows, ” or “ Arabian arrows, ”] meaning (assumed tropical:) Betake thyself to thy affair, and that which concerns thee. (TA.)
And ramayonaA fuwqFA, (O, K,) or fuwqFA waAHidFA, (TA,) meaning riXoqFA [i. e. (tropical:) We shot in one direction; or we shot one bout, in one direction], (O, K, TA.)
[Hence, app.,] one says, kAn fulaAnN liOawRali fuwqi, meaning (tropical:) Such a one was [for the first discharge from the bow, i. e.,] the first shot and dying. (A, TA.)

And [hence, perhaps.] fuwqN signifies also (tropical:) A mode, or manner, of speech: (A, O, K:) pl. fuwaqN. (TA) One says to a man when he enters upon a mode, or manner, of speech, xaco fiI fuwqi OaHosana minohu (tropical:) [Enter upon a mode, or manner, of speech better than it]. (A, TA.)
And (tropical:) The first way (AA, O K, TA.)
Hence. app., [they say, AirojaEo Uin XiYota fiI fuwqK (tropical:) Return thou, if thou wilt, to the state of close, or loving, communion in which we were. (Ibn-'Abbád, Z, O,TA.)
And the Arabs say, in imprecating, fuwqihi laA rajEa fulaAnN UilaI i.e.(assumed tropical:) May such a one die: so says AA; and he cites the following verse of El-'Uleykim El-Kindee,

L.foreign: vumRata laA yarojiEo lahaA mino fuwqihaA

sense.s: meaning (assumed tropical:) [What is the case of my wife that she is choked by her spittle? Then, or afterward,] may it (her spittle) not return to its channel [i. e. her throat, the way whence it came so that she may be suffocated). (O.)
And one says (O, K) or a man when he has gone away, (O,) maA QrotadRa EalaI fuwqihi, meaning (assumed tropical:) He went away and he did not return [ to the place whence he departed] (O, K)

fuwqN also signifies, (O, K.) accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, (O, TA.) (assumed tropical:) The vulva of a woman: (O, K. TA) but As says that this is with q [in the place of the f]: (TA:) [it is, however, also said that] fuwqu AlrRaHimi signifies (tropical:) the rima of the vulva, by way of comparison [to the notch of the arrow]. (TA, in the supplement to this art.)
[And app. (assumed tropical:) The front edge of the lobe of the ear: see 1 in art Hrm, when it is mentioned in such a manner as seems to preclude its being a mistranscription for qawf]

And (as Ibn-'Abbád says, O) (assumed tropical:) The place of opening (maforaj, O. TA, in the K erroneously, maxoraj, TA, and jawobap, O, K, TA) of the mouth: or (as some say, O) the extremity of the tongue. (O, K, TA.)
And (assumed tropical:) The uppermost part of the penis, (En-Nadr, O, K, TA,) or of the glans thereof. (TA.)
And, accord. to the K, A certain bird; mean ing a certain aquatic bird: but this is correctly [quwqN,] with two káfs. (TA.)
See also faAqN, last sentence but one.
fiyqN [originally fiwoqN]: see fiyqapN.
Also, as mentioned in this art and in art. fyq, in the K: see faAqN, last sentence but one.
fayaqN and fiyaqN: see mufiyqN.
faAqapN Poverty, (S, O, K,) want, or need. (S, O, Msb, K.) One says, huwa cuw faAqapK He is one who is in [poverty or] want or need. (Msb.) (See 8.] It has no (unaugmented] verb. (TA.)
fuwqapN: see fuwqN, first sentence.
And see also faAqN, last sentence but one.
fawaqapN: see faAYiqN [of which, as a part. n., it is a pl.].
fayoqapN: see what next follows.

fiyqapN, (S, O, &c.,) originally fiwoqapN, (TA,) the w having become I because of the kesreh before it, (S, O, TA,) The milk that collects (S, O, K) in the udder (K) between two milkings: (S, O, K:) and srAj [or this is a mistake for Aibon AlsRarRaAj] has mentioned AlnRaAqapi fayoqapN↓, with fet-h: but ISd says, “ I know not how that is: ” (TA:) pl. fiyqN↓ (S, O, K.) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n. and faAqapN is its n. un.,] and fiyqN (IB. K) and fyqaAtN (K.) and OafowaAqN, [a pl. of pauc.,] (S, O, K.) or this may be pl. of the pl. fiyaqN. (IB. TA.) and OafaAwiyqa, (S. O, K,) which is a pl. pl. (O, K) [or pl. of OafowaAqN]. [See also EuraAkapN.]
See also above, conj. 2, an ex. of OafaAwiyq in a tropical sense.
OafaAwiyqu also signifies (tropical:) The water that has collected in the clouds and then falls in rain. (S, O, K, TA? time after time. (S, K. TA.)

Also, i. e. OafaAwiyqu, (tropical:) The greater part of the night: (Lh, O, K, TA) so in the saying, xarajnaA baEoda OafaAwiyqa mina AllRayoli We went forth] after the greater part of the night had passed: (Lh, O:) or, accord. to Th, after pertions (OaqoTaAE) of the night. (TA.)

fiyqapu AlSRuHaI means (tropical:) The period of the [early portion of the forenoon called the] DHI when the sun has become high: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, TA:) or, accord. to Z, the first part of the DHI. (TA.)

fawoqaAniIRN [Of, or relating to, the location that is above, or over; superior; upper;] rel. n. of fawoq, like as taHotaAniIRN is of taHot: A and n being very often added in the rel. n. (TA. in art. tHt.)

And [hence, but more commonly fawoqaAniyRapN,] A garment worn by a man over that which is next the body; [an upper-coat; generally long, reaching to the heels, ample in width, and with long sleeves: it seems to have been formerly peculiar to men of the learned professions:] of the dial. Mekkeh: posts-classical. TA [See Dezy's Dict. des Noms des Vétements chez les Arabes, p. 343]).
fawaAqN The returning supply of milk after sucking or milking. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph, in three places.
fuwaAqN: see 1, former half, in two places:
and see 1 again, latter half:
and 4, in two places.

Also (tropical:) The time between two milkings; (S, O, Msb, K;) for the she-camel was milked, and then left a little while for her young one to suck her in order that she might yield her milk copiously, after which she was milked again; (S, O;) and likewise the time between two suckings; (Ksh in xxxviii. 14;) and fawaAqN↓ signifies the same; (S, O, Msb, K:) or, (Msb, TA,) accord. to IF, (Msb,) the fwAq of the she-camel is the retuning of the milk into the udder after the milking: (Msb, TA:) or fuwaAqN signifies the time between the opening of one's hand and the grasping with it the udder (K, TA) of the camel: or when the milker grasps the udder and then lets it go, in milking: (TA:) the pl. is OafowiqapN and MfiqapN; (O, K;) and Fr says that fwAq has for its pl. OafiyqapN, originally OafowiqapN, the kesreh of the w being transferred to the f, and the w being then changed into I because of the kesreh before it; and OafowiqapN has for its pl. OafowiqaAtN. (TA.) One says, maA OaqaAma Einodahu UilRaA fuwaAqFA (tropical:) [He did not remain at his abode save as long as the time between two milkings]. (S, O, TA.) And it is said in a trad., AlEiyaAdapu qadoru fuwaAqi AlnRaAqapi (assumed tropical:) [The period of the visiting of a sick person is the space of time between the two milkings of the she-camel]. (S.) And in a trad. of 'Alee occurs the saying, qaAla lahu AlOasiyru OanoZironiI fuwaAqa naAqapK i. e. (assumed tropical:) [The captive said to him,] Grant thou me a delay, or respite, as long as the time between two milkings [of a she-camel]. (TA.) maA lahaA mino fawaAqK↓ and fuwaAqK in the Kur [xxxviii. 14], accord. to different readings, (S,) the latter the reading of the Koofees except 'Ásim, and the former that of the rest, (O,) means (assumed tropical:) [There shall not appertain to it] any postponement, or delay, and resting: (S:) or, accord. to AO, the latter is the meaning of the former reading; and the latter reading means, any waiting, or expecting: (TA:) or [both mean] any pausing as much as the time between two milkings, (Ksh, Bd,) or two suckings: (Ksh:) or any returning, and repeating; (I'Ab, Ksh, Bd;) from OafaAqa “ he (a sick man) returned to a healthy, or sound, state ”; and the fwAq of the she-camel, when the supply of milk returns to her udder; (Ksh;) or because in it [i. e. the fwAq] the milk returns to the udder; (Bd;) i. e. the blast [to which the words refer] shall be one only; it shall not be repeated. (Ksh.) The saying (Mgh, O, TA) of the Prophet, (O,) related in a trad., (O, TA,) qasama ganaAYima xayobara Eano fuwaAqK, (Mgh,) or qasama AlganaAYima yawoma badorK Eano fawaAqK↓ (O, TA) and fuwaAqK, (TA,) means (assumed tropical:) He divided the spoils [of Kheyber, or on the day of Bedr,] in the space of the rest between two milkings of a she-camel: (TA:) or quickly; (Mgh, O;) En fwAq meaning SaAdirFA Eano suroEapK [i. e. qasomFA SaAdirFA Eano suroEapK with a dividing proceeding from quickness]: (Mgh, O: *) or, as some say, the meaning is, making some of them [i. e. of those who composed his army] to be more highly distinguished (Oafowaq↓) than others (O, TA *) in the proportion of their spoils and of the trial undergone by them. (TA.)
See also faAqN, last sentence but one.
fuyaAqN, mentioned in this art. in the K: see faAqN, last sentence but one.

faAYiqN Superior, excellent, or surpassing: (Mgh, Msb: *) anything excellent, or choice, (O, K, TA,) and pure, in its kind. (TA.) You say, huwa faAYiqN fiI AlEilomi [He is superior, excellent, or surpassing, in knowledge], and fiI AlfinaI [in wealth, &c.]. (Mgh.) And jaAriyapN faAYiqapN [A young woman excelling in beauty, or comeliness]. (Msb.) And fawaqapN [an irreg. pl. of faAYiqN, like as xawanapN is of xaAYinN, for by rule these pls. should be faAqapN and xaAnapN,] signifies Elegant scholars, and orators. (IAar, O, K.)
Also The place of junction of the neck with the head: (S, O, K:) therefore when this is high, the neck is long. (S, O.)
Oafowaqu: see fuwaAqN, last sentence but one.

Also An arrow of which the fuwq [or notch] is broken: (S, O, Msb, K, TA:) [and] an arrow having no fuwq: (L voce OaqacRu:) pl. fuwaqN [perhaps a mistranscription for the regular form of pl., i. e. fuwoqN; or it may be that the w is with fet-h to distinguish it from fuwqN signifying “ a notch ” of an arrow]: but IAar explains this as signifying arrows of which the heads have fallen. (TA.) One says, rajaEa fulaAnN biOafowaqa naASalK (assumed tropical:) Such a one returned with an arrow having a broken notch and without a head upon it; meaning, with an incomplete share of good fortune: (S, O:) or, disappointed of attaining what he desired, or sought: a proverb. (TA.) And radadotuhu biOafowaqa naASilK (assumed tropical:) [I turned him back, or away, with a paltry benefit; or] I made his share of good fortune to be little, or incomplete. (TA.) And maA balilotu mino fulaAnK biOafowaqa naASilK, expl. in the first paragraph of art. bl.

maHaAlapN fawoqaMCu [A large sheave of a pulley] of which every sinR [or tooth, perhaps meaning cog, though I do not remember to have met with any description of a cogged mHAlp,] has two cusps (fuwqaAni), (O, K,) like the fwqAn [of the notch] of the arrow. (O.) [The strangeness of this explanation induces me to think that fawoqaMCu is here a mistranscription for fawohaMCu, (see maHaAlapN fawohaMCu, in art. fwh,) and that the explanation is partly conjectural.]
And kamarapN fawoqaMCu A glans of a penis whereof the extremity is tapering in form, (O, K,) like that which is termed HawoqaMCu. (O.)

mufiyqN and mufiyqapN A she-camel having in her udder the milk that had collected between two milkings: (AA, S, O, K:) pl. mafaAwiyqu (S, O, K) and mafaAwiqu, (Akh, TA,) and fuyuqN↓ also is pl. of mufiyqN signifying as expl. above, mentioned by AA in the third vol. of his “ Nawádir, ” and said by IB to be, accord. to analogy, pl. of fuwuwqN, and to be originally fuwuqN; but accord. to one relation of a verse in which it occurs, it is fiyaq↓, which is more agreeable with analogy. (TA.)
And the former, applied to a poet, is syn. with mufoliqN [i. e. One who poetizes admirably, or wonderfully.]. (Aboo-Turáb, K. [But its verb is mentioned in the O and K in art. fyq.])
mufawRaqN (tropical:) Food, and beverage, that is taken by little and little. (IAar, O, K, TA. [See its verb.])
Applied to an arrow, [Having a notch made for the bow-string. (See 2.)
And] Having the bow-string put into its notch on the occasion of shooting: [see 4, last sentence:]

whence the saying, laA zilota Alxayori muwafRaqFA wasahomuka fiI Alkarami mufawRaqFA (assumed tropical:) [Mayest thou not cease to be rightly disposed in beneficence, and thine arrow made ready with the bow-string put into its notch in generosity]. (A, TA.)
musotafiyqN A man who sleeps much: (O, K, TA:) mentioned by IAar; but this is strange.

fuwlN [Beans; or the bean; faba sativa of Jussieu; vicia faba of Linnæus; i. e.] i. q. baAqilRFI [q. v.]: (T, IF, S, Msb:) or i. q. HimRaS [i. e. chick-peas; or the chick-pea]: (so in one of my copies of the S: [in most of the copies of the S, this word is mentioned at the end of art. fyl; but in the older of my copies, before that art.:]) or a certain grain, or seed, (HabR,) like the HimRaS: but with the people of Syria [and of Egypt], i. q. baAqilRFI: or (as some say, M) specially the dry [thereof]: n. un. with p: (M, K:) mentioned by Sb. (M.)
fawRaAlN A seller of fuwl. (TA.)
fuwlaAcN: see art. flc.
2. fawRamotu Alxuboza I made bread, or the bread. (IJ, M.) [And] fawRimuwA lanaA Make ye bread for us: (T, S:) a phrase said by Fr to have been heard from the Arabs as meaning thus. (T.)

fuwmN, a word occurring in the Kur ii. 58, (T, S, M, &c.,) is expl. as signifying the same as vuwmN [which generally means Garlic; but is said to have also the meaning here next following]; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) said to be a dial. var. of the latter word, but app. [if meaning “ garlic ”] formed, as IJ says, by the substitution of f for v; (M;) and 'Abd-Allah [Ibn-Mes'ood] read [in the Kur ubi suprà] wavuwmihaA [instead of wafuwmihaA]: (Fr, T, S:) it is also expl. as signifying wheat; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) which is said by Lh to be a meaning of vuwm and fuwm; and if Ibn-Mes'ood read the word as vwm, the meaning is fwm, i. e. “ wheat; ” (T;) accord. to Fr, it is an old word, signifying thus, (T, S, *) and also bread; (T, S, K;) Zj says that there is no difference of state-
ment among the lexicologists as to its having the former of these two meanings, that it is said to have the latter also, and that it also signifies the other grains, beside wheat, whereof bread is made [which last meaning is also mentioned in the K]; (T;) and IJ holds that it is rightly expl. as having the first of these three meanings (i. e. “ wheat ”) and the last of them: (M:) another meaning assigned to it is HimRaSN [i. e. cicer arietinum; or chick-peas]; (S, K;) which is of the dial. of Syria: (S:) and it signifies also any Euqodap [app. meaning head of a plant, such as that] of an onion, or of a garlic: or a great gobbet of food: (K: [for Oawo luqomapK EaZiymapK in the CK, I read Aw luqomapN EaZiymapN as in other copies of the K:]) in the dial. of Azd-es-Saráh, it is applied to ears of corn; and fuwmapN↓ is its n. un.; (M;) this latter signifying an ear of corn, (S, K, TA,) as expl. by IDrd: (TA:) fuwmN has fuwmaAnN [of the measure fuEolanaAnN] for a pl., this being [virtually] a pl. pl.; mentioned by IJ, who says that the dammeh in fuwmN is different from the dammeh in fuwmaAnN. (M, TA.)
fuwmapN: see the next preceding paragraph, near the end.
Also A thing that one carries between his two fingers. (K.)
qaTaEuwA AlXRaApa fuwamFA fuwamFA (M, K, *) means [They cut the sheep, or goat,] into a number of pieces; (M;) like fuWamFA. (K.)

faAmiIRN, altered from fuwmiIRN, A seller of fuwm [app. 3]. in any of its senses, but accord. to the TA as meaning wheat, or chick-peas]: (S, K:) [or] a seller of fruit: (MA:) accord. to Az, (TA,) AlfaAmiIRu means AlsRukRariIRu, (Mgh, TA,) who is called by the vulgar AlbayRaAEu [generally signifying the seller, or vender; perhaps here meaning the seller of sugar, though I do not anywhere find AlsRukRariIRu thus explained]; (Mgh;) but he says, “ I do not think it genuine Arabic. ” (TA.)

1. faAha bihi, (S, Msb, K,) aor. yafuwhu (S, Msb) and yafiyhu also, (ISd, TA,) inf. n. fawohN, (MA,) [and inf. n. of unity fawohapN, (see Har p. 434,)] He uttered it, or pronounced it, (S, Msb, K,) namely, a saying; (S;) as also tfwRh↓. (S, K.) One says, maA fuhotu bikalimapK, and mA tafawRahotu↓, i. e. I opened not my mouth with a word, or sentence. (S.) faAha lisaAnN, a phrase used by El-Hareeree, the Arabs did not say: they only said, fAh AlrRajulu bikacaA [The man opened his mouth with such a thing, i. e., with such a saying, &c.]. (Har p. 191.) And hecaA OamorN maA fuhotu Eanohu, inf. n. fuwuwhN [or fuWuwhN?], is a saying mentioned by Fr, as meaning This is a thing, or an affair, which I mentioned not, or have not mentioned. (TA.)
See also 2.

fawiha, aor. yafowahu, [inf. n. fawahN,] He (a man) had what is termed fawahN↓, (S, TA,) which means width of the mouth, (S, K, TA,) and largeness thereof: (TA:) or protrusion and length of the upper central incisors: (S, TA:) or length of all the teeth; length of the upper central incisors being termed rawaqN: (IB, TA:) or protrusion of the teeth from the lips, with length thereof. (K, TA.)
2. fwRhhu He (i. e. God) made him to be Oafowah [or wide in the mouth, &c.]. (S, K.)

XadRa maA fawRahota fiI hecaA AlTRaEaAmi, [thus accord. to the TA, but an explanation of mufawRahN seems to show that the right reading is fuwRihota, in the pass. form,] and tafawRahota↓, and fuhota↓, means XadRa maA Oakalota [app. Much indeed, or greatly indeed, didst thou eat, or hast thou eaten, of this food; see XadRa: and see also 10]. (TA.)

3. fAwhhu, (K, TA,) inf. n. mufaAwahapN; (TA;) and faAhaAhu, [formed from the former by transposition,] (K, TA,) inf. n. mufaAhaApN; (TA;) He talked, or discoursed, with him: [see also 6:] and he contended with him for superiority in glory, or excellence. (K, TA.)
5. tfwRh He spoke. (KL.) See also 1, first and second sentences.
And see 2.

tfwRh AlmakaAna (assumed tropical:) He entered the fuwRahap of the place; (K, TA;) i. e., the mouth thereof; likened to the fam [properly thus called] as being the first place of ingress to the interior thereof. (TA.)
6. tfAwhwA They talked [app. one to another: see 3]. (K.)

10. AstfAh, (S, K,) inf. n. AisotifaAhapN and AisotifaAhN, (K,) the latter mentioned by Lh, (TA,) He (a man, S) ate, (S, K,) or drank, (K,) vehemently, after scantiness, (S, K,) or after weakness; (so in a copy of the S;) but seldom used in relation to drinking: or you say, AstfAh fiI AlTRaEaAmi, meaning he ate much of the food: so says IAar, not particularizing the act as being after scarcity or not. (TA.) [See also 2.]
And He quenched his thirst by drinking. (K.)
faAhN: see what next follows: and see the next paragraph again, in the latter half:
and the same word, and faAhK, (the latter in two places,) see voce faAwuwhapN.

fuwhN and faAhN↓ and fiyhN↓ (K, TA) and, accord. to the copies of the K, fuwhapN, [or, as in the CK, fawohap,] but correctly fuwRahapN↓, (TA,) and famN, all signify the same [i. e. The mouth]: (K, TA:) the pl. is OafowaAhN, (S, K, TA,) pl. of fuwhN, (S, TA,) and as such its case is plain; as pl. of fiyhN, it is like OarowaAHN as pl. of riyHN; as pl of faAhN, it is allowable as having w for its original medial radical; but as pl. of fuwRahapN, it is anomalous: (TA:) and another pl. is OafomaAmN, (K, TA,) said by some to be pl. of fumRN or famRN, with teshdeed, of which an ex. occurs in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. fm; but some disallow this pl.; and accord. to some, (TA,) it has no sing. (K, TA) agreeable with rule, (TA,) for famN is originally fawahN, (K, TA,) with the w movent by fet-h, or [fawohN, as in some copies of the S,] with the w quiescent, on the authority of IJ; (TA;) the h is elided, and the w becomes a movent final, therefore it must be changed into A, because of the fet-hah preceding it, so the word becomes fA; but a noun may not be of two letters whereof one is [the n of] the tenween, (K, TA,) thus the passage is expressed in the M, but MF remarks that correctly we should say whereof one is the A, (TA,) and therefore a hard letter is substituted for it, one similar to it in kind, which is m, for they are both labials, and in the m is a sort of humming sound (hawiIRN, in the CK huwiIRN,) in the mouth, [or rather in the nose,] resembling [the sound of] the prolongation of the w: (K, TA:) [several similar disquisitions, added in the TA, respecting the change from fwh to fm, I omit, regarding them as needless: what is said on this subject in the S, in art. fm, I have mentioned in that art.:] in the present art., J says that the m of fm is a substitute for the h, not for the w, of fwh; but this is a mistake: (IB, TA:) the dual of famN is famaAni and famawaAni (IAar, S, Msb, K) and famayaAni, the second and third of which are anomalous: (IAar, K:) of the second, which occurs in a verse of ElFarezdak, [and respecting which see the first paragraph of art. fm,] Sb says that it is used by poetic license. (TA.) In using it as a prefixed noun, in the phrase hecaA fuwhuhu, they deemed the combination of the two hs difficult in respect of utterance; therefore they suppressed the [radical] h thereof [in this case, and then in other, similar, cases], and said, hecaA fuwhu, and fuw zayodK, and raOayotu faA zayodK, and mararotu bifiI zayodK: and when prefixing it to [the pronoun denoting] thyself, thou sayest, hecaA fiIRa; and this thou dost alike in using it in the nom. case and in the accus. and in the gen., because the w [of fuw] is changed into I and is then incorporated [into the pronominal I]: (S, and the like is said in the Msb:) and sometimes, though rarely, they did the like in other cases, when not prefixing it; for instance, faA occurs at the end of a verse of El-'Ajjáj, without an affix, in this case for faAhaA. (S.)

In the saying kalRamotuhu faAhu UilaI fiIRa, meaning I spoke to him, his mouth being near to my mouth, fAh is in the accus. case as a denotative of state: (S, TA: *) or by reason of the derivative [mukalRimFA] meant to be understood: or, as Sb says, it is an instance of one of the nouns that are put in the place of inf. ns., and it is not to be separated from what should follow it, so that you may not say kalRamotuhu faAha [alone], for you tell of your nearness to the person, and that there is not any one between you and him: and if you will, you may use the nom. case, meaning wahecihi HaAluhu [this being his state], (Sb, TA,) i. e. fuwhu UilaI fiIRa [his mouth was near to my mouth], the clause [following klRmth] occupying the place of a denotative of state. (TA.)

The saying faAhaA lifiyka, (Meyd, K, TA,) which is a prov., (Meyd, TA,) means May God make the mouth of misfortune to cleave to thy mouth; (Meyd, K, * TA;) [but lit. signifies, only, her, or its, mouth
to thy mouth; and is [likewise] an instance of one of the nouns that are used in the manner of inf. ns. expressive of imprecation, by reason of a verb not mentioned: Sb says, fAhA is without tenween, meaning faA AldRaAhiyapi, as is shown by the saying,

L.foreign: ni yarohabuhaA AlnRaAsu laA faA lahaA

sense.s: [Many a misfortune is there, of the misfortunes of time, which men fear, that has no mouth, wherewith to bite]: (Sb, TA:) A'Obeyd says that its primary meaning is, may God make the ground to be in thy mouth; that it is like the sayings bifiyka AlHajaru and bifiyka AlOavolabu; (S, Meyd;) and [hence] it means disappointment [cleave] to thee: (S, * Meyd:) a man of Belhujeym, (S, Meyd,) cited by A'Obeyd, (S,) addressing a wolf that sought to get his she-camel, (Meyd,) says,

L.foreign: qaluwSu QmoriYK qaAriyka maA Oanota HaAciruhu

sense.s: [And I said to him, fAhA lfyk, for she is the youthful she-camel of a man who will give thee as a guest's entertainment that which thou fearest]; (S, Meyd; but in the S, as IB has observed, faUinRahu is erroneously put for faUinRahaA;) i. e.
