[who will entertain thee with] the shooting of arrows; (Meyd;) [by qaAriyka] he means yaqoriyka, from qiraI AlDRayofi: (S:) it is also said that faAhaA is metonymically used as meaning the dust of the earth, which is termed the mouth of the earth because it drinks the water; and it is as though the saying meant the dust be in thy mouth: (Meyd:) Sh is related to have said, I heard IAar say lifiyka faAhFA↓, with tenween, meaning may God make thy mouth to cleave to the ground; [or rather, ground to thy mouth; lit., simply, a mouth to thy mouth;] and some say faAhaA lifiyka, without tenween, as an imprecation meaning (assumed tropical:) may God break thy fam [i. e. thy teeth, to which fam is often metonymically applied, as is also fuwh]. (TA.)

One says also, saqaI fulaAnN Uibilahu EalaI OafowaAhihaA, meaning (tropical:) Such a one drew for his camels the water when they came to it, while they were drinking; not having stored it for them in the drinking-trough: and jarRa fulaAnN Uibilahu EalaI OafowaAhihaA (tropical:) Such a one suffered his camels to pasture while going along [by his driving them gently: see art. jr]: so says As: and so accord. to the A and other lexicons; but the author of the K, by an omission, has assigned the latter explanation to the former phrase. (TA.)
lawo wajadotu Uilayohi faA kariXK, meaning OadonaI TariyqK, (K, TA,) has [with other, similar, phrases] been explained in art. krX [q. v.]. (TA.)

fuw farasK HamirK [Mouth of a horse that is suffering indigestion in consequence of his having eaten barley and so made it to stink] is an appellation applied to him who has stinking breath. (TA. [An ex. of it occurs in a verse of Imra-el-keys cited in the TA in art. Hmr as in Ahlwardt's “ Divans of the Six Ancient Arabic Poets, ” p. 125; and differently in De Slane's “ Diwan d'Amro-'kaïs, ” p. 36 of the Arabic text.])

And fuw juradK [Mouth of a large fieldrat] and fuw dabFA [Mouth of a sort of small wingless locust, or perhaps correctly fuw dabaApK mouth of a small wingless locust,] are nicknames applied to a little man. (TA.)
One says also, laA fuDRu fuwhu, meaning (tropical:) May his teeth, or front teeth, not be broken. (K, * TA.) And saqaTa fuwhu (assumed tropical:) His teeth fell out. (TA in art. fD [q. v.])

And maAta lifiyhi i. e. liwajohihi [meaning (tropical:) He died upon his face; prone: like saqaTa liwajohihi (assumed tropical:) He fell upon his face: the l in both being used in the sense of EalaI; as it is in the phrase xarRuwA liOacoqaAnihimo (expl. in art. xr), &c.]. (A, K, TA. [The explanation in the TK, being somewhat ambiguous (though correct), has misled Freytag in this case.]) And [in like manner, using li in the sense of ElI,] kbRahu QllRehu lifiyhi, one of their forms of imprecation, meaning (assumed tropical:) May God cause him to die: or prostrate him [upon his face; as also kabRahu liwajohihi]. (TA.)
[See also fuwRahapN as syn. with fuwhN; like which it has OafowaAhN for a pl.]

fuwhN also, having for its pl. OafowaAhN, and pl. pl. OafaAwiyhu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) [which last is of very frequent occurrence,] signifies Perfume, or an odoriferous substance: (Mgh, Msb:) or a thing, or substance, with which a perfume, or an odoriferous substance, is compounded or prepared (yuEaAlaju); like as tawaAbilu signifies things, or substances, with which sorts of food are compounded or prepared: (S, Mgh:) or the tawaAbil [or seeds used in cooking] with which food is compounded or prepared (yuEaAlaju) are also called OafowaAhu AlTRiybi: (Msb:) [the pl. and pl. pl. are now generally applied to spices, or aromatics:] or AlOafowaAhu, the pl. mentioned above, signifies [the seeds called] AltRawaAbilu: and also what diffuse fragrance [I read nawaAfiHu, as in my MS. copy of the K, pl. of naAfiHN, q. v., instead of nawaAfiju (with jiym), the only reading that I find in other copies of the K, regarding the latter as indubitably a mistranscription,] of perfumes, or odoriferous substances: (K:) and the sorts, or species, of flowers; (K, TA;) thus says AHn; and in one place he says that AlAfwAH signifies what are prepared for perfume, of sweetsmelling flowers; and sometimes they are of herbs, or leguminous plants: (TA:) and also sorts, or species, of a thing [app. of any kind]: (K:) and one says, huwa mino OafowaAhi AlTyb, and OafowaAhi Albuquwli, meaning It is of the sorts, or species, and of the mixtures, or compounds, of perfume, and of herbs, or leguminous plants: (Mgh:) but fuwhN is not applied to anything that is termed EaqRaArN. (AHeyth, TA in art. Eqr.)
fawahN: see 1, last sentence.
Also The quality of a maHaAlap [or large sheave of a pulley] such as is termed fawohaMC, fem. of Oafowahu, q. v. (TA.)
fiyhi: see its syn. fuwhN.
fuwhapN: see fuwRahapN, in five places.

fuwRahN Certain slender, long, red roots, with which one dyes; beneficial for the liver and the spleen and the nasaA [app. as meaning sciatica or the sciatic nerve] and pain of the hip and of the flank, powerfully diuretic, and kneaded with vinegar and applied as a liniment it cures the [leprosy termed] baraS: (K, TA:) but the word was not known to Az in this sense, [which is the only meaning, except one which I think doubtful, that I find assigned to it;] and it is said to be the fuwRap [which see in art. fw, i. e. madder]. (TA.)
See also fuwRahapN.
fayRihu, originally fayowihN: see mufawRahN.
fuwRahapN: see its syn. fuwhN.

[Hence] it signifies also (tropical:) The fam [i. e. mouth] of a place; likened to the fam [properly so called] as being the first place of ingress, or entrance, to the interior: (TA:) [and so too as being the place of egress, or exit, from the interior:] it is of a river, or rivulet, (Lth, S, Msb, TA,) and of a valley, or water-course, or torrent-bed, (K, TA,) and of a street, and of a road; (S, Msb, K, TA;) signifying the fam [or mouth]; as also fuwhapN↓, (K, TA,) without teshdeed; mentioned by IAar: (TA:) or it signifies thus in relation to a river, or rivulet; (Lth, Msb, TA;) the foremost part thereof: or, as some say, the place of its pouring into the kiZaAmap [q. v.]: and accord. to Lth, in relation to a valley, or water-course, or torrent-bed, its raOos [or head, as though in this case having one, or each, of two contr. meanings, unless, as I believe it to be, the mouth, or outlet, of a valley or water-course or torrent-bed be sometimes called its rOs as being its foremost part]: (TA:) and of a street, it is the place of egress, or exit; (Msb;) the foremost part thereof: (TA:) and of a road, it is the fam [or mouth], which is the upper part thereof (AElAh): (Msb: [thus in my copy; but I think that AElAh is a mistranscription, in my copy, for OawRaluhu, and that the correct meaning is therefore the foremost part thereof, agreeably with what is said above in relation to a road and to a river or rivulet:]) but accord. to some, fuwhapN↓, without teshdeed, is not allowable; and one should say, AlTRariyqi qaEada EalaI fuwRahapK, and fuwRahihi↓ [probably, I think, a mistranscription for fwhihi, with the w quiescent, both meaning He sat at the mouth of the road]; not fuwhatihi↓, without teshdeed: (TA:) and fuwRahapN signifies also (assumed tropical:) the first, or foremost, part, of a thing; (K, TA;) like that of the street and that of the river or rivulet: [whence] one says, TalaEa EalayonaA fuwRahapu Uibilika i. e. (tropical:) The first, or foremost, portion of thy camels [came to us, or came forth upon us]; like the phrase fuwRahapu AlTRariyqi: (TA:) the pl. of fuwRahapN is OafowaAhN, (Ks, S, Msb, TA,) which is anomalous, (S, Msb, TA,) and (TA) fuwRahaAtN [in the CK fuwohAtN] and fawaAYihu. (K, TA.) [Hence] one says, daxaluwA fiI OafowaAhi Albaladi waxarajuwA mino Oarojulihi, (A, K, * TA,) in the copies of the K OarojulihaA, which is wrong, (TA,) i. e. (tropical:) They entered into the foremost parts of the country, or town,
and went forth from the hindermost parts thereof: (A, K, TA:) the sing. of OafowaAh as here used is fuwRahapN. (TA.)

It signifies also A say, or saying, or speech; (S, K, TA;) from 1 in the first of the senses assigned to it above: hence one says, UinRa radRa AlfuwRahapi laXadiydN (S, TA) Verily the retracting of that which has been said is difficult: (Har p. 434:) and [hence] one says also, huwa yaxaAfu fuwRahapa AlnRaAsi [He fears the say, or speech, of men]. (TA.)
And The Muslims' rending one another's reputation by evil speech, or by backbiting; (K, TA;) as also fuwhapF↓. (TA.)
UinRahu lacuw fuwRahapK means Verily he is strong in speech, and free, or unconstrained, in tongue. (TA.)

And one says, maA OaXadRa fuwRahapa baEiyrika fiI hecaA AlkalaOi, meaning [How vehement is] thy camel's eating [of this herbage]! and in like manner, fuwRahapa farasika [the vehement eating of thy horse]: whence their saying OafowaAhuhaA majaAsRuhaA [which may be well rendered as it has been in art. js, q. v.], meaning Their good eating shows thee their fatness, causing thee to be in no need of feeling them to test their condition. (TA.)
And Milk, as long as there remains in it the taste of sweetness; (K, * TA;) as also fuwhapN↓; and sometimes correctly said with q, i. e. [quwhapN,] without teshdeed. (TA.)

faAwuwhapN A man who reveals, or discloses, everything that is in his mind; as also faAhK↓, (Fr, S, TA, [but omitted in one of my copies of the S,]) and faAhN↓: (Fr, TA:) and bijuwEihi faAhK↓ one who reveals his hunger; originally faAYihN, like as they said haArK and haAYirN. (TA.)

Oafowahu Having what is termed fawahN, meaning as expl. in the last sentence of the first paragraph [i. e. width of the mouth, &c.]; fem. fawohaMCu; (S, K, TA;) the former applied to a man, and the latter to a woman; (S, TA;) and in like manner to horses. (TA.) fawohaMCu XawohaMCu, applied to a woman, means Wide-mouthed, ugly: and, applied to a mare, wide-mouthed, long-headed: or sharp in spirit. (TA.)
[Hence,] biYorN fawohaMCu A widemouthed well. (K.)
And TaEonapN fawohaMCu A wide wound made by piercing. (K.)

And maHaAlapN fawohaMCu [A large sheave of a pulley] (S, K, TA) that is wide (K, TA) and (TA) whereof the teeth between which runs the well-rope are long. (S, TA.) [See also maHaAlapN fawoqaMCu, in art. fwq.]

mufawRahN and fayRihN↓, (S, K,) the latter originally fayowihN, (S,) Eloquent; (S, K, TA;) and so fayRihapN applied to a woman; (S, TA;) able in speech; an able speaker: or fayRihN signifies good in speech; a good speaker: (TA:) or both signify good and eloquent in speech; as though taken from Alfawahu meaning “ width of the mouth: ” (IAar, TA:) or having an inordinate desire, or appetite, for food; a vehement eater; (K, TA;) applied to a man and to other than man: (TA:) and the latter (fayRihN), having an inordinate and insatiable desire, or appetite, for food: (TA:) and this also signifies a man who eats much; syn. OakuwlN; (S, K;) and so does musotafiyhN↓: (K [in some copies of which, kwfI is strangely put in the place of Akwl in the explanation here given]:) or musotafiyhN↓ signifies a man eating vehemently after scantiness, (S,) or after weakness: (thus in a copy of the S:) and mufawRahN is also expl. as meaning a man who eats vehemently. (TA.) And one says minoTiyqN mufawRahN (K, TA) meaning [Very] eloquent in speech: (TA:) and manoTiqN mufawRahN (K, TA) Good, or excel-lent, speech, or diction. (TA.)
XaraAbN mufawRahN means [Beverage, or wine,] perfumed (K, TA.) with [the odoriferous substances called] OafaAwiyhu [pl. pl. of fuwhu, q. v.]. (TA.)
And vawobN mufawRahN (Lth, K) and mufawRFI (K) A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed with fuwRah [or fuwRap, i. e. madder]. (Lth, K.)
musotafiyhN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
fiI is a particle governing the gen. case [and used in the manners and senses expl in what here follows]. (T, S, M, Mughnee, K.)

It relates to a receptacle; (Sb, S, M;) and, when used in a wider sense, to that which has some near resemblance thereto; (Sb, M;) [i. e.,] and also to what is considered as a receptacle: (S:) [in other words,] it denotes inclusion, or inbeing, (Msb, Mughnee, K, TA,) either in relation to place or in relation to time: (Mughnee, K, TA;) properly and tropically. (Msb, Mughnee, TA.) gulibati QlrRuwmu fiI OadonaI QloOaroDi wahumo mino baEodi galabihimo sayagolibuwna fiI biDoEi siniyna [The Greeks have been overcome in the nearer, or nearest, part of the land, and they, after the overcoming of them, shall overcome in some few years], in the Kur [xxx. 1 — 3], is an ex. of its relation to place and to time. (Mughnee.) And walakumo fiI QloqiSaASi HayewpN (tropical:) [And there is, to you, in retaliation, life, or an advantage, (respecting the meaning of which see art. HI,) in the Kur ii. 175,] is an ex. of its being used tropically, (Mughnee.) Oadoxalotu AlxaAtama fiI OuSobaEiI is an ex. of its relation to place, but the proposition is inverted [i. e. the meaning is I inserted my finger into the signet-ring]. (Mughnee.) [Using it properly,] you say, AlmaMCu fiI AlUinaMCi [The water is in the vessel]: (S:) and huwa fiI AljiraAbi [It is in the wallet,] and fiI Alkiysi [in the purse]: and huwa fiI baToni OumRihi [He is in the belly of his mother]: and huwa fiI AlgulRi [He is in the shackle for the neck]: (M:) and zayodN fiI AldRaAri [Zeyd is in the house], (S, M, * Msb,) or within the house, and in the midst of it, for fiI AldRaAri, means daAxilihaA, and wasoTahaA: (T:) and [using it tropically, you say,] AlXRakRu fiI Alxabari (assumed tropical:) [Doubt, or uncertainty, is in the information]. (S.) The saying fiyhi EayobN [In him is a fault, or blemish], if relating to a real Eayob, is proper; and if relating to an ideal Eayob, tropical: the former is such as the amputation of the hand of the thief, and the redundance of a hand; and the latter, such as the runningaway of a slave. (Msb.) [When relating to time, it may in some cases be rendered In, or during; as in the phrase fiI OayRaAmK maEoduwdaAtK, in the Kur ii. 139, i. e. In, or during, certain numbered days. UinRa OaSoHaAba QlojanRapi Qloyawoma fiI XugulK faAkihuwna, in the Kur xxxvi. 55, may be rendered (assumed tropical:) Verily the inmates of Paradise this day shall be in the midst of diverting occupation, cheerful, or happy. The phrase OamRaA qawoluhu kacaA fiyhi maA fiyhi, lit. (assumed tropical:) As to his saying thus, in it is what is in it, is used as a polite expression of objection, or contradiction; like fiyhi taOamRulN, q. v. In many instances, fiI may be rendered Of, or concerning, or in respect of; as in qaAla fiyhi kacaA (assumed tropical:) He said of, or concerning, him, or it, thus; for qaAla fiI cikorihi kacaA (assumed tropical:) He said in mentioning him, or it, thus, or fiI waSofihi in describing him, or it; or the like hence, for ex., one says kataba kitaAbFA fiI Eilomi AllRugapi (assumed tropical:) He wrote a book of, or concerning the science of lexicology: and hence, in the Kur ii. 133, OatRuHaAjRuwnanaA fiI QllRehi (assumed tropical:) Do ye argue with us concerning, or in respect of, God?]

It also denotes concomitance, (Mughnee, K,) and (K) in this ease (Mughnee) it is syn. with maEa. (Msb, Mughnee, K.) Thus in the phrase, qaAla QdoxuluwA fiI OumamK [He shall say, Enter ye with peoples]. (Msb, Mughnee, TA,) in the Kur [vii. 36]: (Msb, TA:) or, as some say, the meaning is, fiI jamaAEapi OumamK [in the company of peoples]. (Mughnee.) Thus. too, in the phrase, in the Kur [xlvi. 15], fiI OaSoHaAbi AljanRapi [With the inmates of Paradise]. (Msb, TA.) [Or in these and similar instances, fiI may be rendered, more agreeably with the primary signification, as meaning Among.] In the K, the meaning as denoting concomitance and that which is identical with maEa are made distinct: and it has been said that bi denotes the continuance of concomitance and maEa denotes its commencement; though this is not invariably the case. (MF, TA.) [Hence it is used to denote a combination of two qualities: as in the phrase TuwlN fiI QsotiroxaMCK (assumed tropical:) Length together with laxness: (occurring in the K voce TanabN:) and sawaAdN fiI HumorapK (assumed tropical:) Blackness blending with redness: and the like. And in like manner it is used to denote the combination of the length and breadth of a thing: as in the phrase Tuwluhu EiXoruwna ciraAEFA fiI valaAvi OacoruEK EaroDFA Its length is twenty cubits with (or as we say by) three cubits in breadth: in which case the number of square cubits is expressed by the phrase EiXoruwna fiI valaAvK as though meaning Twenty as a multiplicand with three as its multiplier; i. e. twenty multiplied by three: see Daraba as signifying “ he multiplied. ”].

It also denotes the assigning of a cause. (Msb, Mughnee, K.) Thus in the phrase fiI OarobaEiyna XaApN i. e. On account, or because, of completing [the possession of] forty sheep or goats, [the giving of]
a sheep or goat [for the poor-rate] is incumbent [on the possessor: or this may be rendered, in the case of the possession of forty, a sheep or goat is to be given]. (Msb.) And thus in the saying, [in the Kur xii. 32,] facelikunRa QlRaciI lumotunRaniI fiyhi [And that is he because of whom ye blamed me]. (Mughnee.) Thus also in the saying, in a trad., UinRa QmoraOapF daxalati AlnRaAra fiI hirRapK HabasatohaA [Verily a woman entered the fire of Hell because of a she-cat which she confined without food]. (Mughnee.) [And thus in the phrase Oasolafa fiI kacaA He paid in advance, or beforehand, for, or on account of, such a thing.]

It also denotes superiority; (Mughnee, K, TA;) i. e. (TA) it is used in the sense of EalaI. (T, S, M, Msb, TA.) Thus in the saying, in the Kur [xx. 74], walaOuSalRibanRakumo fiI jucuwEi QlnRaxoli [And I will assuredly crucify you upon the trunks of palm-trees]. (T, S, Msb, Mughnee, TA.) And so in the verse of 'Antarah cited voce saroHN. (T, M, Mughnee, TA.) And Yoo asserts that the Arabs say, nazalotu fiI Oabiyka, meaning Ealayohi [i. e. I alighted, or descended and stopped, &c., at the abode of thy father]. (S.)
It is also syn. with bi, (T, S, M, Mughnee, K,) sometimes. (S.) Thus in the saying of Zeyd-el-Kheyl,

(S, Mughnee, TA,) meaning, biTaEoni AlAbAhr wAlklI [i. e. And horsemen skilful in piercing the aortas and the kidneys ride in the day of fear therein]. (S, TA.) And thus in a verse cited by Fr, Oarogabu is made trans. by fiI and Eano instead of bi and Eano. (T, TA.) [Thus, also, layosa fiI XaIoCK is sometimes used for layosa biXaIoCK, meaning It is nought; or not of any account or weight; &c.: see more in art. XyO.]
It is also syn. with UilaI. (Mughnee, K.) Thus in the Kur [xiv. 10], faradRuwA Oayodiyahumo fiI OafowaAhhm [And they put their hands to their mouths]. (Mughnee, TA.)

It is also syn. with mino. (M, Mughnee, K, TA.) Thus in the Kur [xxvii. 12], fiI tisoEi MyaAtK [Of, or among, nine signs]. (M, TA.) And in the saying, xuco liI EaXorFA mina AlUibili fiyhaA faHolaAni [Take thou for me ten of the camels; of, or among, them let there be two stallions. (M, TA.) [Thus too in the saying huwa fiI OaSoli qawomihi He is of, or among, the purest in race, &c., of his people: and the like thereof.]

It also denotes comparison; and this is when it occurs between a preceding [mention of a] thing excelled and a following [mention of a] thing excelling: as in the saying, [in the Kur ix. 38,] famaA mataAEu QloHayewpi QldRunoyaA fiI QloMxirapi UilRaA qaliylN [But the enjoyment of the present life, in comparison with that which is to come, is no other than little]. (Mughnee, K.)

It is also used for compensation; and this is when it is redundant as a compensation for another [fiI] which is suppressed: as in the saying, Darabotu fiymano ragibota for Darabotu mano ragibota fiyhi [I beat, or struck, him whom thou desiredst]: (Mughnee, K:) but this is allowed by Ibn-Málik alone. (Mughnee.)
And it is used for corroboration: (Mughnee, K:) this is when it is redundant without its being for compensation: and this El-Fárisee allows in a case of necessity in verse; citing as an ex.,

L.foreign: OanaA OabuwA saEodK UicaA AllRayolu dajaA

sense.s: [I am Aboo-Saad; when the night becomes dark, thou imagining its blackness to be black leather]. (Mughnee.) And it is thus used in the saying, in the Kur [xi. 43], waqaAla QrokabuwA fiyhaA [for QrokabuwhaA, i. e. And he said, Embark ye therein, the like of which occurs also in xviii. 70 and xxix. 65], (Mughnee, K,) accord. to some. (Mughnee.)
fiI as a prefixed noun in the gen. case, syn. with fam, and fiIRa as syn. with famiI, see voce fuwhN, in art. fwh.

faIRa is a word expressive of wonder: they say, yaA faIRa maA liI OafoEalu kacaA [O my wonder! What has happened to me that I do thus?]: or it is expressive of regret on account of a thing that is passing away [so that this exclamation may be rendered Oh! What has happened to me &c.]: Ks says that it is not to be written withC [though it is so written in several of the lexicons in art. fyO, i. e. faIoCa]; and that it means yaA EajabiI [as first expl. above]: and in like manner one says, yaA faIRa maA OaSoHaAbuka [O my wonder! What are thy companions? i. e. what manner of men are thy companions? mA here denoting interrogation respecting qualities, or attributes; as in the Kur xxvi. 22]: and he says that mA in this case occupies the place of a noun in the nom. case. (M, TA.) Ks is also related to have said that some of the Arabs express wonder by faIRa and haIRa and XaIoCa; and some add maA, saying yaA fayRamaA and yaA hayRamaA and yaA XayoYamaA, meaning How good, or beautiful, is this! the K is faulty here; mentioning only yaA fayRamaA, and explaining it as denoting wonder. (TA.)
tafiyRapN: see tafiyoYapN, in art. fyO.

1. faMCa, aor. yafiIoCu, inf. n. faIoCN (S, O, Msb) and fuyuwoCN, (O,) He (a man, Msb) returned; (S, O, Msb;) and so AfMC↓, and AstfMC↓: (M, TA:) faIoCN, as also fayoYapN↓ and fiyYapN↓, [or the former of these, accord. to analogy, is an inf. n. of unity, and the latter an inf. n. of modality,] and UifaMCapN and AistifaMCapN al' signify rujuwEN: (K:) or, accord. to some, faMCa signifies particularly he returned to a good state or condition. (MF, TA.) One says, faMCa mino gaDabihi He returned [to a good state, or recovered, from his anger]: (M, TA:) and fulaAnN sariyEu AlfaIoCi mino gaDabihi [Such a one is quick in respect of the returning &c. from his anger]: (S, M, * O:) and UinRahu lasariyEu AlfiyoYapi↓, (M,) or laHasanu AlfiyoYapi↓, (S, O,) i. e. [Verily he is quick, or good, in respect of] the returning [to a good state, or from his anger, or in respect of the manner of returning &c.]: (S, M, O:) and huwa sariyEu AlgaDabi sariyEu AlfiyoYapi↓ [He is quick in respect of anger, quick in respect of returning, or recovering, therefrom]. (A, TA.) And faMCa UilaI AlOamori, and faMCahu [i. e. faMCa AlOamora], inf. n. faIoCN and fuyuwoCN, He returned [to the affair, or to the command, i. e. to that which was commanded]. (M, TA.) HatRaI tafiIoCa UilaI Oamori QllRehi , in the Kur xlix. 9, means Until it [referring to a party (TaAYifap) before mentioned] return to the ordinance of God, or to that which God has commanded: (Bd:) or until it return (T, Msb) to obedience, (T,) or to that which is right. (Msb.) And faMCa UilaI AlOamori, inf. n. faIoCN, signifies also He reconsidered the affair, or case. (TA.)

faMCa AlmuWoliI (M, Msb, K) mini QmoraOatihi, (M, K,) inf. n. faIoCN, (TA,) or fayoYapN↓, (Msb,) means The man who had sworn to abstain from conjugal intercourse with his wife expiated his oath and returned to her. (M, Msb, * K. [See Kur ii. 226.]) But MF observes that this usage of faMCa to signify He expiated an oath belongs to the conventional language of the law. (TA.) In the case of a man who has sworn that he will abstain from conjugal intercourse with his wife, a period of four months is appointed to him in the Kur-án; and if he have such intercourse with her in the four months, it is said of him, qado faMCa, meaning He has returned [or reverted] from his oath, to the doing that which he swore that he would not do, and is bound to expiate his oath: if he have not had such intercourse with her until the end of the four months from the day of his swearing, then, Ibn-'Abbás and a number of the Companions pass upon her a single sentence of divorce, making the [said sentence of] divorce to have effect at the end of the months; but many of the Companions and others say that in this case he must return, and expiate his oath, or he must divorce. (T, TA.) And [hence] one says lahu EalaI QmoraOatihi fayoYapN↓ He has the right of returning to his wife: (Msb, TA:) and huwa yamoliku fayoYatahaA↓ He possesses the right of returning to her; namely, a wife whom he has divorced. (A, TA.)
AlfaIoCu EalaI ciI AlrRaHimi occurs in a trad. as meaning The being favourably inclined, or affectionate, to the relation; and returning to kind treatment of him. (TA.)

faMCa said of the shade, (M, Msb,) aor. yafiIoCu, (Msb,) inf. n. faIoCN, (M, Msb, K, *) It shifted, or removed; (M, K; *) or [rather] it returned from the side of the west to the side of the east: (Msb:) and AlZRilaAlu tafayRaOati↓ The shades became changed in their manner of being; (S, O;) or [rather] they returned [towards the east] after midday. (T, TA. [See the Kur-án xvi. 50.])

And faMCati AlXRajarapu; and tfyROt↓; (M;) and fyROt↓, inf. n. tafiyoYapN; (S, O, TA;) The tree had much shade. (M, TA.) faMCati AlHadiydapu The iron implement became blunt after its being sharp. (T, TA.)
fiYotu Alganiymapa, (mentioned, but not expl., in the K,) inf. n. faIoCN, (TA,) means I took the spoil. (TK.) [See also 10.]
2. fyRO AlZilRa, and AfMChu↓ He (God) made the shade to return [in the afternoon]. (El-Khafájee, MF, TA.)
qayRaOat said of a tree: see 1, near the end.
Said of the wind, It put in motion the seed-produce, or standing corn, and the trees. (M, TA.) And, said of a woman, She put in motion her hair, from self-conceit, or vanity. (M, TA.)
4. OafaOotuhu I made it to return. (O.) See also 2.

[Hence,] one says, OafaMCa QllRehu EalaI Almusolimiyna maAla AlkufRaAri [God restored to the Muslims, as though it were theirs by right, or gave to them as spoil, the property, or wealth, of the unbelievers]; (S, O;) inf. n. UifaMCapN. (S.) And OafaMCa QllRehu Ealayohimu AlganaAYima [God restored, or gave, to them the spoils]. And OafaMCa EalaI qawomK fayoYFA He took for a party the spoil of another party and brought it to them: and he took for a party spoil that had been taken from them. (T, TA.)
And OafaOotu kacaA I made such a thing to be a faIoC [or spoil]. (TA.)
And OafaOotu fulaAnFA EalaI AlOamori I turned him to the thing, or affair, when he had desired another thing, or affair. (AZ, T.)
See also 1, first sentence.
5. tafayRaOati AlZRilaAlu:
and tfyROt AlXRajarapu: see 1, near the end.

tfyRO fiyhi means He shaded himself in it; i. e., in the shade termed faIoC. (M.) One says, tafayRaOotu fiI faIoCi AlXRajarapi [I shaded myself in the afternoon-shade of the tree]. (S, O.) And tfyRO biAlXRajarapi [He shaded himself by means of the tree; or] he entered into the OafoyaMC [or afternoon-shades] of the tree: (MA:) and [it is said that] tafayRaOotu AlXRajarapa signifies I entered into the OafoyaMC of the tree, and shaded myself thereby: (Har p. 500:) and Aboo-Temmám has made it trans. by itself [i. e. without a prep.] in his saying,

[as though meaning And I protected myself from the sun by its shade, when it was extended]: but [perhaps he has thus used the verb in the last of the senses here following, for] it is said that this is irregular. (TA.)
[Hence] one says, tafayRaOotu bifayoYika meaning (tropical:) I have had recourse to thee for protection. (A, TA.)

tfyRO is said of a branch or twig [as meaning It bent, in a languid manner]. (T, M, L, K, voce taraORada; &c.) And one says, tfyROt lizawojihaA, meaning She bent herself over her husband, and affected languor, or languidness, to him, feigning coyness, or opposition, and threw herself upon him: (T, * TA:) from AlfaIoCu signifying “ the act of returning: ” and some say tqyROt, with q; but Az says that this is a mistake, and that it is correctly with f (TA.)

tfyRO signifies also tatabRaEa [He sought a thing time after time, or repeatedly, &c.]. (Har p. 500.) And one says, fulaAnN yatafayRaOu AlOaxobaAra and yasotafiyWuhaA↓ [app. meaning Such a one seeks after news, or tidings, time after time, or repeatedly, &c.]. (A, TA.)
10. AstfMC He took as spoil. (S, M, * O, K.) One says, AisotafaOotu hecaA AlmaAla I took this property as spoil. (S, O.)
See also 5.
As intrans., see 1, first sentence.

faIoCN Afternoon-shade; shade after the declining of the sun from the meridian; (T, * S, O;) [i. e.] the faIoC is what was sun, and has been annulled, or superseded, by shade; (M, K;) or that from which the sun has departed: so called because of its “ returning ” from side to side: (S, O: [see 1, first sentence:]) ISk says, (S, O,) the ZilR is what sun has annulled, or superseded; [correctly, what sun annuls, or supersedes; (see ZalRN;)] and the faIoC is what has annulled, or superseded, sun: (S, Mgh, O:) but AO says, on the authority of Ru-beh, that on which the sun has been and from which it has departed is faIoC and ZilR; and that on which the sun has not been is ZilR: (S, O:) [see more under this latter word:] pl. [of pauc.] OafoyaMCN and [of mult,] fuyuwoCN. (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K.)

And Spoil, booty, or plunder; syn. ganiymapN [q. v.]; (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) thus called, by the inf. n., because it returns from one party to another; (Msb;) and fayRN in this sense is not allowable; (Mgh, Msb;) nor is it in the preceding sense: (Mgh:) or such as is obtained without difficulty: and therefore likened to shade. (MF.) And The [tax, or tribute, termed] xaraAj [q. v.]: (S, O, K:) frequently occurring in trads. as meaning such, of the possessions of the unbelievers, as accrues to the Muslims without war: (TA:) or such as is obtained from the believers in a plurality of gods after the laying-down of arms: (A 'Obeyd, Mgh and Msb voce ganiymapN:) or such as God has restored [as though it were theirs of right] to the people of his religion, of the possessions of those who have opposed them, without fighting, either by the latter's quitting their homes and leaving them vacant to the Muslims, or by their making peace on the condition of paying a poll-tax or other money or property to save themselves from slaughter: such is termed faIoC in the Kur-án. (T. [See more under ganiymapN.])
Also A flock of birds: (O, K:) [or a number of birds disposed in a row:] also termed EaraqapN and SafRN. (O, TA.)

yaA faIoCa, (M, O, K, in the CK [erroneously] yA faIoCu,) or, accord. to Ks, correctly yA faIRa [q. v.]. (M,) [Oh! or O my wonder?] an expression of regret, (M, O, K,) accord. to most, (TA,) or of wonder, (Ks, M, K, TA,) meaning yaA EajabiI. (Ks, M.) [See XaIoCN, last three sentences.]

fiYapN A [party, portion, division, or distinct body, of men, such as is termed] TaAYifap: (S, O, K, TA:) or a company (Msb, TA) of soldiers who fight in the rear of an army, and to whom the latter has recourse in the case of fear or defeat: (TA:) or a company of men who [in war] have recourse, for aid, one to another: (Er-Rághib, TA:) a word having no proper sing.: (Msb, TA:) originally fiIoCN; (S, O, K;) the p being substituted for the medial I, which is dropped: (S, O:) or its original form is fiYowN [or fiYoIN or fiYowapN or fiYoyipN (see art. fOw and fOI)]; the final [radical] letter being that which is elided; for it is from faOawotu [or faOayotu] “ I divided; ” and fiYapN is syn. with firoqapN: (IB, L, TA:) pl. fiYaAtN and fiYuwna, (S, O, Msb, K,) in which latter the w and n are for the making good what is deficient [in the sing.]. (Msb.)
fayoYapN: see 1, in four places.
[Hence] cuw fayoYapK a term applied to Date-stones (nawaI AltRamori) when they are hard: [because,] being given as fodder to cattle, and eaten by them, they pass forth as they were at first. (T, TA.)
Also A time; syn. HiynN. (K.) One says, jaMCahu baEoda fayoYapK He came to him after a time. (TA.)
And The HidaOap [or kite], that seizes as its prey the chickens from the dwellings: (O:) or a certain bird resembling the eagle, (L, K,) which, when it fears the cold, migrates to El-Yemen. (L.)
fiyoYapN: see 1, first quarter, in four places.

tafiyoYapN, (M and K in art. tfO,) as also tafiyRapN, both mentioned by Lh, and the latter reckoned as a dial. var. of the former, (M in that art.,) and taYifRapN and UifRu and UifRapN and OafRapN and UifRaAnN and OafRaAnN, (see art. Af,)] The time of a thing: (M and K in art. tfO:) one says, Oatayotuhu EalaI tafiyYapi celika I came to him at the time of that: (M in that art.:) and [by extension of the signification] one says, daxala EalaI tafiYapi fulaAnK meaning Oavarihi [i. e. He entered near after such a one; as though treading in his footsteps]: (K in the present art.:) the t in tafiyoYapN is an augmentative letter; the word being [originally] of the measure tafoEilapN, but formed by transposition: Z says that the t would not be augmentative if the composition of the word were as it is here, without transposition: that it is not of the measure tafoEilapN from AlfaIoCu; for, if it were, it would be of the same measure as tahoyiYapN [i. e. it would be tafoyiYapN]; therefore, if not formed by transposition, it would be of the measure faEiylapN [i. e. it would be from tfO, as some hold it to be], because of the UiEolaAl [or alteration for the sake of alleviating the sound, such as takes place in yasiyru for yasoyiru, which cannot be in a noun of the measure tafoEilapN from a triliteral root like fyO, whose medial radical is infirm], the last radical being hemzeh: but its formation by transposition from taYifRapN [originally taOofifapN] to tafRiYapN, which is then changed to tafiyoYapN, as Z says in the “ Fáïk, ” is what determines the t to be augmentative, and the [original] measure to be tafoEilapN. (L and TA * in arts. tfO and fyO.)

mufaMCN A thing that has been made a faIoC [or spoil, &c.]. (TA.) And A person whose country,
or province, or town, has been conquered, and become a faIoC to the Muslims. (IKt, O, TA.) It is in a trad. of some of those who have gone before, laA yuWamRaru mufaMCN EalaI mufiIoCK↓, meaning An emancipated slave shall not be made governor over an Arabian; (K, TA;) or, as in the Nh [and O] and L, lA yaliyanRa [shall by no means rule]; (TA;) as though it were said, none of the people of the Sawád (which was conquered by force and became a faIoC to the Muslims) shall rule over the Companions (O, TA) and their next successors. (TA.)
mufiIoCN A person who makes a thing [or a country or the like] to be a faIoC. (TA.) See also mufaMCN.
mafiyoYapN: see the paragraph here following.
mafoyaOapN: see the paragraph here following.

mafoyuWapN A place of faIoC, i. e. of the shade thus termed; [a place of afternoon-shade;] (M, K;) as also mafoyaOapN↓; (K;) and, as AAF says, on the authority of Th, mafiyoYapN↓; (M, L, TA;) and so mafoyuwoCapN↓, like masomuwEapN [in measure]: (L, TA:) accord. to Lth, (TA,) mafoyuWapN is syn. with maqonuWapN, (S, TA,) which signifies a place on which the sun does not come: so says Az; and he adds that it is probably correct, but that he had not heard it on any other authority than of Lth. (TA.)
mafoyuwoCN i. q. maEotuwhN [Idiotic, or an idiot, i. e. deficient, or wanting, in intellect; &c.]: so called from his keeping long [or much] in the shade. (M, TA.)
mafoyuwoCapN: see mafoyuWapN.
1. faAjato birijolihaA, aor. tafiyju, She (a camel) kicked with her hind legs, backwards. (TA.)
4. AfAj, mentioned in the O and L and Msb in this art.: see art. fwj.

fayojN A foot-messenger; a courier who journeys on foot: (S:) or a Sultán's foot-messenger: (L, Msb:) or one who journeys with letters: (L:) or a quick courier who carries tidings, or communications, from one town, or country, to another: (Nh, TA:) originally Pers., (S, O,) arabicized, (S, O, K,) from Payok: (O, K:) pl. fuyuwjN. (S, TA.) It is also expl. as meaning One going, or journeying, alone: thus in a verse of 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, in which it is opposed to zaraAfapN meaning “ a company [of men]. ” (TA.) And [the pl.] fuyuwjN, (O, K,) as used in a verse of 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, (O,) means Men who enter the prison and go forth from it, keeping guard. (O, L, K: in some copies of the K, and keep guard.)
And A company [of men]; (Msb;) syn. with fawojN: (O and K in art. fwj:) and sometimes applied to a single person: pl. [of pauc.] OafoyaAjN and [of mult.] fuyuwjN. (Msb.)
Also A low, or depressed, place, such as is termed wahod, of the earth, or ground. (AA, O, K.)
And A state of dispersion; as also fiyjN↓. (TA. [See 4 in art. fwj.])
fiyjN: see what next precedes.
fayRaAjapN A she-camel that kicks with her hind legs [much or often], backwards. (TA. [See 1.])
faAYijN A wide [expanded and even tract such as is termed] basaAT, of land. (AA, O in art. fwj.)

faAYijapN A wide tract between two elevated portions, (S, O, K, all in art. fwj,) of rugged ground, or of sand: (S, O:) or what has the form of a valley between two mountains, or between two rugged tracts containing stones and sand and earth, like a xaliyf [q. v.], but wider: thus expl. by ISh: pl. fawaAYiju. (TA in art. fwj.)
1. faAHa, aor. yafiyHu, inf. n. fayoHN and fayaHaAnN: see art. fwH.

fAH AldRamu, inf. n. fayoHN (L, Msb) and fayaHaAnN, (L,) It poured out, or forth: (L:) or it flowed; as also AfAH↓, inf. n. UifaAHapN: or, accord. to AZ, the latter is trans., and signifies as expl. below in relation to blood. (Msb.)
And faAHati AlXRajRapu, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. tafiyHu, inf. n. fayoHN, (TA,) (tropical:) The wound upon the head spirted forth blood; (S, Msb, K;) or poured forth much blood. (A.)

And fAH AlHurRu, aor. yafiyHu, inf. n. fayoHN; and aor. yafwHu, inf. n. fawoHN; (assumed tropical:) The heat rose, or diffused itself, and raged vehemently. (L.) It is said in a trad., XidRapu AlqayoZi mino fayoHi jahanRama (tropical:) [The intenseness of the heat of summer is from the vehement raging of the heat of Hell]. (TA.) And one says, AlHumRaI mino fayoHi jahanRama (tropical:) The fever is from the vehemence of the heat of Hell. (A.)
And faAHati Alqidoru, (S, K,) aor. tafiyHu (S, TA) and tafuwHu, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The cooking-pot boiled; (S, K, TA;) as though it were the fire of Hell, in its heat. (TA.)

And faAHati AlnRaAru (assumed tropical:) The fire spread. (Msb.) And [hence, app.,] faAHati AlgaArapu, aor. tafiyHu, i. e. (tropical:) [The troop of horsemen making an attack, or incursion, upon a people] spread themselves. (S, TA.) See fayaAHi.

And fAH, (L, Msb, TA,) aor. yafaAHu, (L, TA,) [inf. n., app. fayaHN, which signifies “ width ” accord. to the S and K, and is agreeable with general analogy in this case, as the aor. of the verb is originally yafoyaHu, though it seems to be implied in the Msb that the aor. is not yafaAHu, but yafiyHu,] It (a sea, S, * L, K, * TA, and a place, L, or a valley, Msb) was, or became, wide. (S, * L, Msb, K, * TA.)

entry.xml:id: lawo madakota AldRunoyaA lafayRaHotahaA fiI yawomK waAHidK

form.orth: lawo madakota AldRunoyaA lafayRaHotahaA fiI yawomK waAHidK

sense.s: 2. lawo madakota AldRunoyaA lafayRaHotahaA fiI yawomK waAHidK means (tropical:) [If thou possessedst all that the world contains,] thou wouldst dissipate it, or squander it away, in one day. (A, TA. *)
4. AfAH He poured forth, spilled, or shed, blood. (S, Msb, K.) See also 1, first sentence.
AfAH Alqidora (assumed tropical:) He made the cooking-pot to boil. (S, K.)

OafiHo Eanoka mina AlZRahiyrapi i. q. Oaborido, (K,) i. e. (assumed tropical:) Stay thou until the mid-day heat shall have become assuaged, and the air be cool: (M, L, TA:) [as also Afixo:] the medial radical letter is both w and I. (M.)

fayoHN and fuyuwHN↓ Abundance of herbage of the [rain, or season, called] rabiyE, with ample extent of land: (K:) [accord. to the TK, both are inf. ns., of which the verb is faAHa, and the agent is AlrRabiyEu: but this, I think, is rendered doubtful by what here follows:] fywH occurs in a verse [as some relate it]; but accord. to the relation of IAar, it is fatuwH, with t, [and with fet-h to the f,] and this, which signifies “ rain, ” is said by Az to be the right reading: the pl. [of fayoHN] is fuyuwHN. (TA.)
fayaAHN: see OafoyaHu.

fayaAHi, like qaTaAmi, [indecl.,] (T, S, L, K,) of the fem. gender, (L,) a name for The gaArap, (T, S, L, K,) meaning troop of horsemen making a hostile attack, or incursion, upon a people. (T, L.) fiyHiI↓, fayaAHi, (S, A, K, &c., [in the CK, erroneously, fayoHiI,]) said by the people of the Time of Ignorance, (S,) when they impelled horses making a hostile attack, or incursion, and they spread out, (L,) means Spread out, O attacking troop of horsemen: (S, A, K:) or spread out upon them, or against them, and disperse yourselves, &c. (Sh, L.)
fuyuwHN: see fayoHN.
fayRaAHN: see OafoyaHu, in two places.
Also (tropical:) Profuse in bounty: (S, A:) so in the saying, UinRahu lajawaAdN fiyRaAHN (tropical:) [Verily he is liberal, munificent, or generous; profuse in bounty]. (S.)
And naAqapN fayRaAHapN (tropical:) A she-camel that yields much milk, (A, K,) and has a large udder. (K.)

OafoyaHu A sea, (S, L, K,) and a valley, (Msb,) and any place, (L,) wide, or extensive; (S, L, Msb, K;) as also fayRaAHN↓: (S, L, K:) fayRaAHN↓ occurs in the story of Umm-Zara, accord. to A 'Obeyd, applied to a bayot [i. e. house, or tent]; but accord. to others, it is fayaAHN↓, without teshdeed: (L:) [the fem. of OafoyaHu: and pl. fiyHN:] one says daArN fiyoHaMCu A wide, or an ample, house or abode: (S, K:) and in like manner rawoDapN [a meadow, &c.]. (L, Msb.)
And fayoHaMCu signifies also A sort of thin cooked food, such as is supped, or sipped, (HasaMCu,) seasoned with seeds such as are used in cookery. (S, K.)

1. faAxati AlrRiyHu, aor. tafiyxu, inf. n. fayoxN and
fayaxaAnN: see 1 in art. fwx. Accord. to Kr and the K, fayoxN signifies A spreading, or becoming diffused; like fiyoHN: (TA:) but ISd expresses doubt of the correctness of this: (L, TA:) it is [said to be] an inf. n. in this sense. (TK.)
See also 4.
2. fyRx AlEajiyna He made the dough like the sukurRujap [or fayoxap (q. v.) in form]. (TA.)

4. AfAx, (L,) inf. n. UifaAxapN, (L, K,) He (a man, L) emitted wind from the anus, with a sound; (L, K;) as also faAxa↓: (L:) or he voided excrement with an emission of wind. (L, K.) [See also art. fwx.]
AfAx, said of a man, signifies also suqiTa fiI yadihi [i. e. He repented of what he had done; &c.]. (K.)
And AfAx mino fulaAnK He (a man, TA) turned away from, avoided, shunned, and left, such a one; syn. SadR Eanohu. (K.)
fiyoxapN A state of dilatation of the place of exit of the urine. (IAar, K.)
And A tangled, luxuriant, or dense, and abundant, state of herbage. (K.)
And Vehemence, or intenseness, of heat. (K, TA.)
And A [kind of small saucer, or cup, such as is called] sukurRujap [q. v.]: (K:) pl. fayoxaAtN. (O and K voce XufaArijN.)

1. faAdato lahu faAYidapN, (T, S, A, O, L, Msb, K,) aor. tafiydu, (S, A, O, &c.,) inf. n. fayodN, (Msb,) [Profit, or advantage, or the like, (see faAYidapN,)] accrued to him; (T, * S, * A, O, * L, * Msb, K;) or came to him. (IKtt, TA.)

And fAd, aor. yafiydu, (T, S, M, O, L, K,) inf. n. fayodN, (M, O, L,) said of property, It continued, or belonged or appertained, syn. vabata, (T, S, M, O, L, K,) lahu to him; (T, S, M, O, L;) as also fAd, aor. yafuwdu, (M in art. fwd,) inf. n. fawodN: (K in that art.:) or went away, passed away, or departed. (K. [But this last meaning, which I find only in the K, in relation to fAd, in this art. and in art. fwd, may be taken from what next follows, and relate to property as applied to cattle.])

And fAd, aor. as above, (T, M, L, K, and S &c. in art. fwd,) and so the inf. n., (IAar, T, L, and K in art. fwd,) He (a man, M, TA) died; (T, M, L, K, and S &c. in art. fwd;) as also fAd, aor. yafuwdu, (S and K &c. in art. fwd,) inf. n. fawodN; (K &c. in that art.;) and so faAza and faAZa; (TA;) i. q. faAta. (A.) One says, maA faAda HatRaI balaga rizoquhu AlnRafaAda, meaning maA faAta [i. e. He did not die until his means of subsistence became exhausted]. (A.)

And fAd, aor. as above, (S, M, O, L, K,) and so the inf. n., (S, O, L,) He walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side; (S, M, O, L, K;) as also tfyRd↓. (T, S, M, L, K.)
And, (M, L, K,) accord. to some, (M, L,) He was cautious of a thing, and turned aside from it. (M, L, K.) [See also 2.]
fAd said of saffron, and of the plant called warosa, It became pulverized, or reduced to powder by its being bruised or brayed. (IKtt, TA.)

fAdhu, aor. yafiyduhu, (S, L, K,) inf. n. fayodN, (L,) He mixed it, (namely, saffron, K,) or moistened it with water &c.; syn. daAfahu; (S, L, K;) from which it is formed by transposition [accord. to the lexicologists; but not accord. to the grammarians, because it has an inf. n.]; (TA;) as also fAdhu, aor. yafuwduhu, (T, M, L, &c., in art. fwd,) inf. n. fawodN: (K in that art.:) and he bruised, or brayed, it, (namely, saffron, and the plant called waros,) and then wetted it with water: (L in art. fwd:) and faAdatohu she (a woman) rubbed it (namely perfume) in water, in order that it might dissolve. (M, L.)

Eani fAd AlmalRapa Alxubozapi, inf. n. fayodN; and AfAdhA↓; He removed the hot ashes from the cake of bread; syn. OazaAlahaA (TK. [In the O and K, this meaning of these two verbs is vaguely intimated, only by the words, Alfayodu Oano tufiydu biyadika AlmalRapa Eani Alxubozapi.])
2. fyRd mino qironihi (Th, M, L) He turned away from, or avoided, his adversary: (Th, L:) or he fled from him. (M.) [See a similar meaning of fAd, above.]
And fyRd, (T, O, K,) inf. n. tafoyiydN, (L, K,) He augured evil from the cry of the [bird called] fayRaAd. (T, O, L, K.)

4. AfAdhu He gave it, namely, property, (AZ, Ks, T, S, M, O, L, K,) to another: (AZ, Ks, T, S, M, L:) and AfAdhu maAlFA, inf. n. UifaAdapN, He gave him property. (Mgh, Msb.) It belongs to this art. and to art. fwd. (L in art. fwd.)

[Hence, also, AfAd said of a word, and a phrase, It had, or performed, a useful office, as expressive of a meaning, or as contributing to the expression thereof, or as adding to a meaning previously expressed. And hence, It imported, or conveyed, a meaning; and particularly, when said of a phrase, a complete meaning, so that a pause might be well made after uttering it; faAYidapF being understood.]
See also 10.
And see 1, last signification.
Also, AfAdhu, inf. n. as above, He killed him; destroyed him; slaughtered him; namely, a man, and a beast. (T, * L, and K * in art. fwd.)
5. tfyRd, as intrans.: see 1, latter half.
tfyRdhu: see 10.

6. humaA yatafaAyadaAni biAlmaAli bayonahumaA They two give, of the property, each to the other; or profit, or benefit, each other therewith: (ISh, T, O, K:) you should not say yatafaAwadaAni: (K:) and hmA ytfAydAn AlEiloma They two impart knowledge, each to the other: (K in art. fwd [q. v.]:) or, in the opinion of MF, both of these verbs are allowable. (TA.)

10. AstfAdhu (T, S, M, &c.) He gained it, acquired it, or got it, for himself, namely, property [&c.]; (T, * M, * Mgh, Msb, and L and K in art. fwd;) and AfAdhu↓ is syn. therewith, (S, M, A, Mgh, O, L, Msb, K,) as used by some, (Msb,) having two contr. significations, (K,) though disallowed by others, (Msb,) or it is more chaste than the former; (Mgh;) and tfyRdhu↓ signifies the same. (M, and K in art. fwd.)
[And He derived it, learned it, or inferred it.
fayodN Saffron: (IAar, TA voce malaAbN:) or the leaves of saffron: (L:) or saffron mixed, or moistened with water &c. (S, O, L, K.)
And The hair upon a horse's lip. (T, S, O, K.)
[fayiydN expl. by Golius as signifying (on the authority of Meyd) Vir pusillanimus pavidusque, is app. a mistake for faYiydN.]

fayRaAdN (T, S, M, A, O, L, K) and fayRaAdapN↓, (T, S, O, L, K,) in which latter the p is added to render the epithet intensive, (T, L,) A man who walks with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side. (T, S, M, A, O, L, K.) One says, fulaAnN yamoXiI EalaI AlOaroDi fayRaAdFA mayRaAdFA [Such a one walks upon the ground] with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, &c. (A.)
Hence, AlfayRaAdu is said to signify The lion. (O.)
And The male of the buwm [or owl]: (T, S, M, O, K:) or i. q. AlSRadaI [which is also said to signify the male of the buwm: for other explanations see SadFI] (S, O.)
And fayRaAdapN↓, (M,) or this and fayRaAdN, (T, S, O, K,) One who collects together what he can, and eats it. (Lth, T, S, M, O, K.)
fayRaAdapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

faAYidapN a subst. from faAda AlmaAlu, (M, L, and K in art. fwd,) in the sense of vabata; (M, L;) or an act. part. n. from faAdato lahu faAYidapN; (Msb;) Profit, advantage, benefit, or good, which God bestows upon a man, and which he [the latter, consequently] gains, or acquires, and which he produces: (T, L:) an accession which accrues to a man: (Msb:) what one gains, or acquires, of knowledge, (S, A, O, L, Msb, K,) and polite accomplishments, (Msb,) and property: (S, A, O, L, K:) what one has recently acquired, of property, of gold or silver, or a slave, or the like: (AZ, Msb:) and [simply] profit, advantage, benefit, or utility: and good: and knowledge: and wealth, or property: (KL:) pl. fawaAYidu: (T, O, L, Msb, K:) it belongs to this art. and to art fwd: (TA:) some improperly derive it from AlfuWaAdu. (MF.)

[Hence, Utility as expressive of a meaning, or as contributing to the expression thereof, or as adding to a meaning previously expressed, or a word or phrase. And hence, A meaning, or an import, of a word or phrase; and particularly a complete meaning of a phrase, such that a pause may be well made after the uttering thereof.]
mafiydN [Perfume, &c.] mixed, or moistened with water &c.; (S, O, L;) as also mafuwdN. (As, T in art. fwd.)
rajulN mitolaAfN mifoyaAdN A destructive man; as also mifowaAdN. (Ibn-'Abbád and O and K in art. fwd.)
fiyruwzajN [an arabicized word from the Pers. fiyruwzahu or Piyruwzahu The turquoise;] a well-known kind of stone. (TA.)
And A certain sort of dye [probably of the colour of the stone so called]. (TA.)

1. faAXa, (O, K,) aor. yafiyXu, inf. n. fayoXN, (O, TA,) He gloried, or boasted, (O, K,) and magnified himself, imagining [in himself] what he did not possess; (K;) as also faXRa; like as you say caAma, aor. yaciymu; and camRa, aor. yacumRu; (TA;) he was boastful, or proud, pretending to possess a thing and not being as he pretended; (TA;) and fAyX↓ [signifies the same; or] he gloried, or boasted, vainly, and praised himself for that which was not in him. (AHeyth, in L, art. Trmc.) [See also 5.]
fAX AlOataAna, aor. as above, (IDrd, O, K,) and so the inf. n. (IDrd, O,) He (the ass) mounted the she-ass: (IDrd:) said by Yoo to be from AlfayoXapu. (O, K. *)
3. qAyXhu, (TA,) inf. n. fiyaAXN (S, O, K) and mufaAyaXapN, (O, K,) He vied, or contended, with him in glorying, or boasting, or in glory, or excellence. (S, * O, * K, * TA.)
Also, (TK,) inf. n. mufaAyaXapN, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) He threatened him much in fight, and then was pronounced a liar. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K, TK.)
See also 1.
5. tfyRX AlXRaIoCa He arrogated the thing falsely; (Ibn-'Abbád, * O, * K, * TA;) without merit. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, TA.)
tfyRX Eani AlXRaIoCi He turned back from the thing (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K) through weakness and impotence; (TA;) like AnfXR. (TA.)

fayoXN and fayoXapN↓ The head [or glans] of the penis: (S, O, K:) or a swollen penis: (TA:) or ↓the latter word has the former meaning; and fayoXN is its pl., [or rather coll. gen. n.,] like as tamorN is of tamorapN: (O:) and fayoXalapN↓ signifies the same as fayoXapN; and some say that its l is augmentative: (TA:) or fayoXN signifies a weak fayoXalap. (Lth, TA.)
fayoXapN: see fayoXN, in two places.
Also The uppermost part of the head. (TA.)
fiyaAXN: see fayoXuwXapN.
[See also 3.]
fayuwXN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

fayRaAXN A man who glories, or boasts, and magnifies himself, imagining [in himself] what he does not possess; (K;) vainly boastful, without merit; (TA;) who contends for superiority in that which he does not possess; (K;) and [in like manner] fayuwXN↓ one who pretends to possess a thing, not being as he pretends; (TA;) both signify one who glories, or boasts, vainly, and praises himself for that which is not in him: (AHeyth, in L, art. Trmc:) and ↓the latter is said to signify a cowardly and weak man. (TA.)
Also, A chief, or lord, abounding in excellence, or generosity, or bounty, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) who vies with others in glory. (TA.)
faAXuwXN A weak and lax man. (TA.)
fayoXuwXapN Weakness and laxness; (O, K;) and so fiyaAXN↓. (TA.)
fayoXalapN: see fayoXN.
1. faASa fiI AlOaroDi, aor. yafiySu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. fayoSN, (TA,) He went away into the country, or in the land. (S, O, K.) In the following verse of Imra-el-Keys,

respecting which As said, I know not what is [the meaning of] yafiyDu, this word is said to be from fAS signifying as expl. above: (S, O:) [but I do not see what meaning that would be apposite in this case could be thence derived without straining:] but fAS signifies also it shone, or glistened; syn. baraqa; (TA;) and some say that yfyS in this verse means yaboruqu; (O, TA;) and the pronoun in manaAbituhu relates to the front teeth; (O, * TA;) by EacobN yafiyDu being meant the lustre (maMC) thereof: (O:) [accordingly, the verse may be rendered, The places of growth thereof, i. e. their gums, were like the (garment called) suduws, and their colour was like the thorns of the sayaAl (q. v.), so that they were sweet and glistening: (see the context in “ the Divans of the six ancient Arabic poets, ” edited by Prof. Ahlwardt:) or, as some relate the verse, the last word is yufiySu↓, (IB, O, TA,) from maA OafaASa bikalimapK [q. v.], (O,) so that it is a denotative of state, the meaning being EacobN fiy HaAli kalaAmihi [i. e. sweet when [displayed in] speaking; or rather, clearly uttering; but it will be seen below that yafiySu, as well as yufiySu, may, accord. to the M and K, be used in this sense:] (IB, TA:) see 4.
maA QsotaTaEotu Oano OafiySa minohu, meaning I was not able to turn aside, or away, from, or to avoid, him, or it. (S, O.) [See also mafiySN: and see 4.]

And waQllReh maA fiSotu, like as one says wAllReh mA bariHotu [perhaps meaning By God I did not quit my place; as well as I did not cease:] (S, O, K: *) mentioned on the authority of AHeyth: (TA:) [that it has the latter meaning is clear; for] one says, maA fiSotu OafoEalu I did not cease (maA bariHotu) doing [such a thing]: (M:) and AstfAS↓, likewise, signifies bariHa. (IB, TA.)
3: see 3 in art. fwS.

4. AfAS AlDRabRu Eano yadihi [The lizard called DbR escaped, or slipped, from his hand, is expl. as meaning] his fingers became unclosed (Ainofarajat) from [the grasp of] the DbR, so that it escaped from him. (M, TA.) And one says, qabaDotu Ealayohi falamo yufiSo I grasped him and he did not escape, or get loose. (AHeyth, TA.) And qabaDotu EalaI canabi AlDRabRi faOafaASa mino yadiI HatRaI xalRaSa canabahu [I grasped the tail of the DbR and it slipped from my hand so that it freed its tail]: (Lth, S, O, TA:) [but in the O, mino is omitted before yadiI; not intentionally, for the verb before mn is there masc., as above:]) this is when thy fingers become unclosed (tatafarRaju) from the grasp of its tail: (Lth, O:) and this [state of the fingers] is termed AltRafaAwuSu↓. (TA.) [It is also said that] OafaASati Alyadu signifies The fingers of the hand became unclosed (tafarRajato) from the grasp of the thing. (K, TA. [But I doubt the correctness of this.])

And AlUifaASapu signifies The being clear, or perspicuous; syn. AlbayaAnu; (O, K;) like AlmufaAwaSapu, expl. in art. fwS;] and the being fluent. (O.) [And also The making speech clear, or perspicuous.] One says, fulaAnN cuw UifaASapK UicaA takalRama Such a one is a person endowed with clearness, or perspicuity, and fluency, when he speaks. (O.) And AfAS lisaAnuhu biAlkalaAmi His tongue made speech, or the speech, clear, or perspicuous; and so faASa↓, aor. yafiySu; (M;) and maA yafiySu bihi lisaAnuhu, (K, TA,) inf. n. fayoSN, (TA,) his tongue does not make it clear, or perspicuous (K, TA.) And maA OafaASa bikalimapK He did not make clear, or distinct, or perspicuous, a word, or a sentence. (Yaakoob, S, O, TA.) See also 4 in art. fwS: and see 1 in the present art. [And it is said that maA OafaADa bikalimapK signifies the same. Or, accord. to Mtr, if he be correctly cited in Har p. 447, the verb in this sense, and app. as thus used in all the phrases mentioned above, is correctly with D, and not so with S: but this I greatly doubt.]
One says also, AfAS bibawolihi He ejected his urine: (O, K:) or AfAD bh. (ElGhooree, in Har ubi suprà.)

6. AltRafaAyuSu is said to be the original and regular form of AltRafaAwuSu, which signifies The speaking, talking, or discoursing, each to another, or each with another: the I being changed into w because of the dammeh. (M in this art. and in art. fwS, and TA.)
See also another explanation in art. fwS: and see 4 in the present art.
10: see 1, last sentence.

maA Eanohu mafiySN There is not any place to which to turn aside, or away, from it: or there is not any turning aside, or away, from it: syn. maHiydN [which may be meant either as a n. of place or as an inf. n.]: (As, S, O, K:) or maEodilN. (IAar, M.)

1. faADa, (S, M, Mgh, &c.,) aor. yafiyDu, inf. n. fayoDN (S, M, O, Msb, K) and fayoDuwDapN (S, O, K)
andfuyuwDN (M, O, K) and fiyuwDN and fuyuwDapN (M, K) and fayaDaAnN, (M, O, K,) It (water) overflowed: poured out, or forth, from fulness: (Mgh:) it (water, S, O, K, or a torrent, Msb) became abundant, (S, O, Msb, K and flowed from [over] the brink of the valley, (Msb,) or so as to flow over the side of the valley, (S, O,) or so as to flow like a valley; (K;) and AfAD↓ signifies the same: (Msb, TA:) it (water) became abundant: (TA:) [contr. of gaADa, aor. yagiyDu:] it (water, and that of the eyes, and the like, M, or anything fluid, Msb) ran, or flowed: (M, Msb:) or it poured out, or forth; or poured out, or forth, vehemently; gushed out, or forth: (M:) and it (water, and blood,) fell in drops. (Msb.)

It (a vessel) became full: (Msb:) [or it overflowed: for you say,] faADa AlnRahoru bimaAYihi The river overflowed with its water: and faADa AlUinaMCu bimaA fiyhi The vessel overflowed with what was in it: (Msb:) and a poet says,

[I complained; and complaint is not a custom of the like of me; but the cup overflows on the occasion of its being full]. (A) You say also faADato Eayonuhu, aor. as above, inf. n. fayoDN, The eye flowed [with tears]. (TA.) And faASa EaraqFA, said of a man, [He sweated;] sweat appeared upon his body, on an occasion of grief. (IKtt)

(assumed tropical:) It (a thing) was, or became, much, abundant, many, or unmerous. (O, K.) You say, faADa AllRiYaAmu (assumed tropical:) The mean became many: (S, O:) opposed to gaADa, q. v. (S and A in art. gyD.) And faADa Alxayoru (tropical:) Good, or wealth, &c., became abundant, (A, Msb,) fiyhimo among them. (A.)

Aor. as above, (S,) inf. n. fayoDN, (TA,) (tropical:) It (a piece of news, or a story,) spread abroad; (S, M, K;) as also AstfAD↓; (S, M, A, Msb, K, TA;) it spread abroad among the people. (Msb and TA in explanation of the latter verb,) like water. (TA.) ↓The latter is also said of a place, meaning (tropical:) It became wide, or ample. (A.) And you say, faADa Ealayohi AldRiroEu (tropical:) [The coat of mail spread over him; or covered him]. (A.)

Aor. as above, inf. n. fayoDN and fuyuwDN, (tropical:) He (a man, S, O, K) died: (S, M, O, K:) and, (S, M, O, K,) in like manner, (S, O,) faADatN nafosuhu, (S, M, A, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (M,) inf. n. fayoDN, (M, Msb,) (tropical:) his soul departed, or went forth; (S, M, A, * Mgh, * O, Msb, K;) of the dial. of Temeem; (S, M, O;) on the authority of AO and Fr; and AZ says the like; but As says that one should not say, fAD AlrRajulu, nor fADt nfsh, for fAD is only said of tears and of water: (S, O:) to which is added in the O, but one says, faAZa, with Z, [as is also said in the Mgh,] as meaning “ he died, ” and not fAD, with D, decidedly: (TA:) [see, however, the remarks of IB below:] or the more chaste expression is fAZ, with Z, without the mention of the nfs; and some do not allow any other: (Msb:) but in the L we find as follows: IAar says. fAD Alrjl and fAZ, meaning “ the man died: ” and Abu-l-Hasan says, fAZt nfsh, the verb relating to the nfs; and fAD Alrjl and fAZ: but As says, I heard AA say that one should not say, fAZt nfsh, but fAZ, meaning “ he died; ” and not fAD, with D, decidedly: IB, however, says that what IDrd has cited from As is different from that which J has ascribed to him; for IDrd cites the words of As thus: the Arabs says, fAZ Alrjl, meaning “ the man died; ” but when they speak of the nfs, they say fADt nfsh, with D; and he quotes the ex.

[And an eye was put out, and a soul departed]: and he [IB] adds that this is what is commonly known to be the opinion of As: but J has committed and error; for As quotes from AA that one should not say, fAZt nfsh, but fAZ, meaning “ he died; ” not fAD, decidedly and he also says, nor does it necessarily follow from what he relates that he firmly believed it: AO says that fAZt nfsh is of the dial. of Keys; and fADt, of the dial of Temeem and AHát says, I heard AZ say that Benoo-Dabbeh alone say, fADt nfsh: in like manner also El-Mázinee says. on the authority of AZ. that all the Arabs say, fAZt nfsh. except Benoo-Dabbeh, who say, fADt nfsh with D. (TA.) [See also art. fyZ. It is further said, that] AlfayoDu signifies Death: (A, K;) as occurring in a trad respecting Ed-Dejjál, where it is said, vumRa yakuwnu EalaI Oavari celika AlfayoDu [Then shall be, after that, death] (A, TA:) Sh says, I asked El-Bekráwee respecting this, and he asserted AlfyD, in this case, to signify “ death; ” but I have not heard it from any other; unless it be from faADato nafosahu signifying His slaver collecting upon his lips at the departure of his soul [flowed]. (TA.)

You say also faADa Sdoruhu mina AlgayoZi (tropical:) [His bosom overflowed with wrath, or rage], (A, TA.) And faADa Sadoruhu biAlsRirRi His bosom disclosed, or concealed, the secret; (S, O, K;) his bosom could not conceal the secret; (M;) his bosom was full with the secret, and disclosed it, not being able to conceal it. (TA.)
And fayoDN is used as meaning (assumed tropical:) God's suggesting (UiloqaMC) [of a thing]: what the Devil suggests (yuloqiyhi) is termed Alwasowasapu. (Kull p. 277.)
faADa AlbaEiyru bijirRatihi: see 4, latter half.
4. AfAD: see 1, first sentence.
He filled a vessel so that it overflowed: (S, M, O, K:) or [simply] he filled a vessel, (M, Msb,) accord. to Lh; but the former. [says ISd,] in my opinion, is the correct signification. (M.)

He made water, and tears, and the like, to run, or flow; or to pour out, or forth; or to pour out, or forth, vehemently; to gush out, or forth: (M:) he poured [water &c.] out, or forth: (A, TA:) or he poured water out, or forth, copiously. (Mgh.) You say, AfAD AlmaMCa EalaI nafosihi, (S, O, K,) or ElI jasadihi, (Msb,) He poured the water (S, O, Msb, K) upon himself, (S, O, K,) or upon his body. (Msb.) And AfAD dumuwEahu, (S,) or damoEahu, (Msb,) He poured forth his tears. (Msb.) And AfADt AlEayonu AldRamoEa [The eye poured forth tears]. (TA.)
AfAD QllRehu Alxayora (tropical:) God made good, or wealth, &c., to abound. (Msb.)
AfAD Ealayohi AldRiroEa (tropical:) He put on him the coat of mail: like as you say SabRahaA [lit he poured it]. (A, TA.)

OafaADuwA mino EarafaAtK (tropical:) They pushed on, pressed on, or went quickly, syn. dafaEuwA, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) or AinodafaEuwA, (M, A,) with multitude, (M, Mgh, O,) from 'Arafát, (S, M, A, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) to Minè, (S, M, O,) exclaiming labRayoka: (M:) or they returned, and dispersed themselves from 'Arafát: (O, K:) or they hastened from 'Arafát to another place: (K:) the last rendering is taken from Ibn-'Arafeh; and agreeably with all of these renderings, the phrase in the Kur [ii. 194], faUicaA OafaDotumo mino EarafaAtK, has been explained: (TA:) and [in like manner,] you say AfADwA mina minaI UilaI makRipa (tropical:) They returned from Mine to Mekkeh; on the day of the sacrifice: (Msb:) UifaADapN signifies (tropical:) the advancing, and pushing on, or pressing on, in journeying, or pace, (A, * TA,) and the like, (A,) with multitude, and is only after a state of separation and congregation: (TA:) it is from the same word as signifying the “ pouring out, or forth; ” (A, O, TA,) or from AfAD AlmaMCa signifying “ he poured the water out, or forth, copiously ” (Mgh:) and the original expression is AfAD nafosahu. or raAHilatahu; but they omit the objective complement, and hence the verb resembles one that is intrans.: (O, TA:) or AfADp signifies the quickly impelling or urging [a beast] to run, with one's foot or leg, or feet or legs: and AfAD, he (a rider) made his camel to exert himself beyond measure, to go a quick run, between the utmost rate and what is less than that; AfADp denoting the half [of the full rate] of the run of camels having riders upon these; and being only applied when they have riders upon them: (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh:) and every dafoEap [or act of pushing on, or pressing on,] is termed UifaADapN. (S, Msb, K.) Hence, TawaAfu AlUifaADapi, signifying The circuiting [around the Kaạbeh] on the return from Mine to Mekkeh; (Msb, TA) on the day of the sacrifice: (TA:) or the circuiting of visitation. (Mgh.)

AfADwA fiI AlHadiyvi (tropical:) They pushed on, or pressed on, in discourse; syn. AinodafaEuwA: (Lh, S, M, A, O,) they entered thereinto; launched forth, or cut, thereinto: (Lh, M, O;) they were large, or copious, or profuse, therein; (O, TA:) or they dilated therein (M:) or they began, commenced, or entered upon, discourse: (Msb;) as also AstfADwhu↓, (M, Msb,) accord. to some; (Msb;) but this latter is disallowed by most; (M;) or by the skilful, (Msb.) You say also, AfAD fiI EamalK (assumed tropical:) He entered into an action, or employment; and pushed on, or pressed on, therein: (Bd in x. 62:) or he began it, commenced it, or entered upon it. (Jel, ibid.)
AfAD baAlXRayoCi He impelled, or thrust, with the thing: (M:) he cast, or threw, the thing. (M, TA.)

AfAD AlbaEiyru bijirRatihi, (Lh, S, M, A, O,) and (S, O) AfAD alone, (S, O, K,) and bijirRatihi faADa↓, (TA,) (tropical:) The camel propelled his cud (Lh, S, M, A, K) from his inside,
(Lh, M, A,) or from his stomach, (S, K,) and expelled it, or ejected it: (S:) or cast it forth in a scattered and copious state: or it means [he made to be heard] the sound of his cud, and of his chewing. (M.)
maA AfAD bikalimapK (assumed tropical:) He did not make clear, or distinct, or perspicuous, a word, or sentence. (Msb, TA.) [And mA AfAD bklmp signifies the same.]

AfAD biAlqidaAHi, (S, M, A, O, K,) and EalaI AlqidaAHi, meaning biAlqidaAHi, for prepositions stand in the places of other prepositions, (S, O,) and AfAD AlqidaAHa, (O, K,) (tropical:) i. q. Daraba biAlqidaAHi [which has two significations: He turned about, or shuffled, the gaming-arrows: and he played with the gaming-arrows]: (S, M, A, O, K:) and OajaAlahaA [which has the former of the above significations]: or he dealt them forth. (TA.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says, describing a [wild] he-ass and his she-asses,

(S, TA) (tropical:) [And it was as though they were a bundle of gaming-arrows, and as though he were a shuffler thereof, shuffling or] dealing out the arrows, and deciding, and making known what he produced: (TA:) or, accord. to Kh, and speaking with his loudest voice, saying “ The arrow of such a one has won, ” or “ This is the arrow of such a one: ” or, accord. to some, distributing, or dispensing, by means of the arrows: (TA in art. SdE:) by EalaI AlqidaAHi is meant biAlqidaAHi. (S voce EalaI.) One relation of this verse substitutes yaxuwDu for yufiyDu. (TA.) Az says that UifaAD [a mistranscription for UifaADapN] is always a consequence of a state of separation, or dispersion, and abundance, or copiousness. (TA.)

Hence the saying in a trad. respecting a thing picked up from the ground, vumRa OafiDohaA mino maAlika, [app. a mistake for fiI maAlika,] i. e. (assumed tropical:) Then put thou, or throw thou, it, and mix it, among thy property. (TA.)
OufiyDato She (a woman) became wide in the belly: [as though spread out:] or she became large in the belly, and flabby in flesh. (M.)

AfAD AlmaroOapa He made the masolakaAni [i. e. vagina and rectum] of the woman to become one, on the occasion of devirgination; (M;) i. q. OafoDaAhaA [from which it is app. formed by transposition, as is indicated in the M.]. (O, TA.)
5. tfyRD It flowed. (Har p. 610. [But this I do not find elsewhere.])
10. AstfAD He asked for the pouring out (UifaADap) of water, (K, TA,) &c. (TA.)
Said of a piece of news: and of a place: see 1, in the first half of the paragraph. You say also, AstfAD AlwaAdiI XajarFA (tropical:) The valley became wide, and abundant in trees. (S, O, K, TA.)
AstfADwA AlHadiyva: see AfADwA fiI AlHadiyvi. [It seems to be indicated in the S and O that it signifies They spread abroad the story among the people; as used by some: see musotafiyDN.]

fayoDN A river, (M, TA,) in general: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OafoyaADN and [of mult.] fuyuwDN: the pluralization thereof shows that it is not an inf. n. used as a subst.: (M, TA:) [and a river, or water, that overflows.] AlfayoDu is [hence] applied to The Nile of Egypt: (S, O, K:) or, accord. to the Tekmileh, to a place in the Nile of Egypt: (TA:) and to the river of El-Basrah: (As, S, K:) or this last is called fayoDu AlbaSorapi, because of its greatness. (M.) You say also OaroDN caAtu fuyuwDK Land in which is water: (Lh, M:) or in which are waters that overflow. (S, K, TA.)
A horse (tropical:) that runs much; (S, M, O, K;) that is fleet, or swift; (M;) that runs vehemently; likened to water pouring forth; as also sakobN. (Eth-Thaalebee, in TA, art. skb.)
A man (tropical:) bountiful, or munificent; as also faAYiDN↓, (A,) and fayRaADN↓: (S, O:) or, as also ↓the last, a man abounding [or profuse] in beneficence or bounty. (M.)
Much, or abundant, water. (M.)
(tropical:) Much, or abundance: as in the saying, OaEoTaAhu gayoDFA mino fayoDK (tropical:) He gave him little from much. (S, M, O.) Anything much in quantity. (KL.)
(assumed tropical:) A large gift: [and simply a gift, favour, or grace:] pl. fuyuwDN. (KL.)
[See also 1, last sentence but one. Hence biTariyqi AlfayoDi meaning (assumed tropical:) By way, or means, of instinct; instinctively.]
(tropical:) Death: [as being the outpouring of the soul:] see 1. (Sh, on the authority of El-Bekráwee; and K.)
cahabonaA fiI fayoDi fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) We went with the corpse and bier of such a one. (M.)
faADapN: see mufaADN.
Oamoruhumo fayoDaI bayonahumo: i. q. fawDaI, q. v. (TA in art. fwD.)
Oamoruhumo fayoDuwDaI bayonahumo, and fayoDiyDaI, and fayoDuwDaMCu, and fayoDiDaMCu, and fayuwDaI↓, i. q. fawoDaI, q. v. in art. fwD. (AZ, K.)
fayuwDN: see mufaADN.
Oamoruhumo fayuwDaI bayonahumo: see fayDuwDaI.
fayRaADN A river containing much water: (S:) or that flows much. (Ham p. 375.)
Applied to a man: see fayoDN, in two places.
faAYiDN A watering-trough full: a sea, or great river, [overflowing: see 1: or] pouring, or pouring vehemently. (TA.)
Applied to a man: see fayoDN.
mufaADN pass. part. n. of 4 [q. v.].

HadiyvN mufaADN fiyhi (tropical:) Discourse in which people have pushed on, or pressed on: (K:) [or into which they have entered: or in which they have been large, or copious: or in which they have dilated: or begun: see 4; and see also musotafiyDN.]

diroEN mufaADapN (tropical:) A wide, or an ample, coat of mail; (S, M, A, O, K;) as also faADapN↓ (IJ, M) and fayuwDN. (M.) [In the CK, this word is erroneously written mufAwaDap, as applied to a coat of mail and to a woman.] mufaADN applied to a man, (tropical:) Wide in the belly: fem. with p: (M:) or the latter, a woman large in the belly, (S, M, A, O, K,) and flabby in flesh, (M, A,) and, as some add, inordinately tall: (TA:): or, as some say, the latter signifies a woman having her masolakaAni [i. e. vagina and rectum] united; as though formed by transposition from mufoDaApN: (M:) and, accord. to some, mufaADN signifies having a fulness. (TA.) It is said of the Prophet, kaAna mufaADa AlbaToni, meaning (tropical:) He had the belly even with the breast: (O, K:) or he had a fulness in the lower part of the belly. (TA.)
musotafaADN: see the next paragraph
musotafiyDN One who asks for the pouring out (UifaADap) of water &c. (S, O.)

A story, or a piece of news, (tropical:) spread abroad (S, M, A, * O, Msb, K) among the people, (S, O, Msb,) like water; (TA;) as also musotafaADN fiyhi; (S, O, K;) but you should not say musotafaADN [alone], (As, Fr, ISk, and the lexicologists in general, and Az, S, O, Msb, and K,) for this is a mistake of the inhabitants of the towns and villages: (As, Fr, ISk, &c., and Msb:) or this last is a word of weak authority: (K:) it is, however, used by some; (S, O;) for instance, by Aboo-Temmám; (TA;) as meaning begun, commenced, or entered upon; but most disallow it unless followed by fiyhi. (M.)

1. faAZa, aor. yafiyZu, inf. n. fayoZN (ISk, T, S, M, K) and fuyuwZN and fayaZaAnN (S, M, K) and fayoZaAnN (Lh, TA) and fayoZuwZapN, (Lth, M, K,) He (a man, S) died; (ISk, T, S, M, K;) as also, (sometimes, S) faAZa↓, aor. yafuwZu, inf. n. fawoZN (ISk, T, S, M, K) and fawaAZN; (S, K, TA; but in the CK, fuwaAZN, and there said to be with damm;) or, accord. to IJ, only the inf. n., fawoZN, of the latter verb is used, though the verb itself is allowable on the ground of analogy. (M.) You say also, HaAna fayoZuhu and fawoZuhu↓, [in the CK fuwoZuhu,] The time came for his dying. (M, K.) In like manner, (S,) you say also, faAZato nafosuhu His soul departed, or went forth; Lth, T, S, M;) on the authority of AO and Ks; and the like is related on the authority of AZ; (S;) aor. tafiyZu, (M,) inf. n. fayoZN (Lth, T, M) and fayoZuwZapN; (Lth, T;) and [accord. to some,] faAZato nafosuhu, inf. n. fawoZN: (M:) or, when the nfs is mentioned, you say, faADato, with D: (K:) As says, I heard Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà say that one should not say faAZato nafosuhu, (T, * S, M, *) but fAZ, (S, M,) meaning “ he died; ” and not faADa, with D, decidedly; (S;) or not faADato: (T:) [but what was said by As respecting these two verbs has been stated more fully, and variously, in art. fyD, q. v.:] AO says that fAZt nafosuhu is of the dial. of Keys; and fADt, of the dial. of Temeem: Fr says that the people of El-Hijáz and Teiyi say the former; and Kudá'ah and Temeem and Keys say the latter: AHát says, I heard AZ say that Benoo-Dabbeh alone say the latter; and ElMázinee relates the like on the authority of AZ.
(TA.)
You say also, faAZa nafosahu, (Ks, S, M, K,) aor. yafiyZu, (Ks, T,) He vomited forth his soul: (Ks, S, M, K:) the verb being trans. as well as intrans. (Ks, S.)

4. AfAZhu He (God) caused him to die. (K, TA.) And you say also, Darabotuhu HatRaI OafaZotu nafosahu [I beat him, or smote him, until I made his soul to depart, or go forth]. (S.) And laOufiyZanRa nafosaka [I will assuredly cause thy soul to depart, or go forth] (M.) And AfAZhu QllRehu nafosahu [God caused him to vomit forth his soul]. (Ks, T, S, M.)

tfyRZwA Oanofusahumo They constrained themselves to vomit forth their souls. (S, TA.) [But in one copy of the S, I find yufiyZuwA Oanofusahumo, expl. as meaning They cause to vomit forth their souls; which suggests that the right reading may perhaps be yufiyZuwA: or it may be yafiyZuwA, from faAZa nafosahu.]

fayofN A place that is even, level, or flat: (S, O, K:) or, (K,) accord. to Lth, (T, O,) a waterless desert, (T, M, O, K,) such as is even, level, or flat, and wide, or spacious; (T, O;) and fayofaApN↓ and fayfaMCu↓ (M, K) and fayofaI↓ (K) also signify [thus, or] a waterless desert: (M. K:) and, (K,) accord. to El-Mu-arrij, (T, O,) fayofN signifies a portion of the earth that is a place whereof the winds are variable; (T, O, K;) and this is the explanation that is preferred by Sh: (T:) and accord. to AA, it signifies [also] any road between two mountains: (T, TA:) its pl. is OafoyaAfN [a pl. of pauc.] and fuyuwfN [a pl. of mult.]. (T, S, M, O, K.)
fayofaI: see the preceding paragraph.
fayofaApN: see fayofN: and see also mufaAzapN, in art. fwz.

fayofaMCu is syn. with fayofN, q. v.: therefore its A is augmentative, (S, M,) accord. to Sb (M) and Mbr: (S:) and it signifies (S, M, O,) also (M) a smooth [desert such as is termed] SaHoraMC: (S, M, O:) its pl. is fayaAfK. (S, M, O, K. [In the CK, this pl. is written fiyAfN, as though it were a pl. of fayofN.])
1. faAqa, aor. yafiyqu: see fAq binafosihi, in art. fwq.
4. Oafiyqa, said of a poet, i. q. Oafolaqa: (K:) or an imitative sequent thereto. (Aboo-Turáb, O.)
fiyqN: see art. fwq.
fuyuqN and fiyaqN: see art. fwq.
fayoqapN and fiyqapN: see art. fwq.
fuyaAqN: see art. fwq.
mufiyqN: see art. fwq.

1. faAla raOoyuhu, aor. yafiylu, (S, M, O, K,) inf. n. fuyuwlapN, (S,) thus in some copies of the K and in the A, (TA,) or fayoluwlapN, (M, O,) thus in other copies of the K, (TA,) and fayaAlapN, thus in the O, but in the copies of the K fayolap, (TA,) His judgment, or opinion, was weak, (S, M, O, K,) and erroneous; (M, K;) as also tfyRl↓; (M, Z, K, TA;) and [in like manner] fiI raOoyihi fayRala↓ [not fuyRila] he was incorrect in his judgment, or opinion; and fayRaluwA↓ occurs in a trad. as meaning fAl raOoyuhumo: (TA:) [and faAla alone, said of a man, signifies the same as fAl raOoyuhu, as is shown by a verse of El-Kumeyt cited in the T and M and O and TA: but it seems from what here follows (taken from a passage unconnected with the foregoing) that the first and third of what are mentioned above as inf. ns. are regarded by some as simple substs.:] and one says, fiI raOoyihi fayaAlapN↓, (T, M, K, TA,) the last word like saHaAbapN, (TA, [in the CK, erroneously, fI riwaAyapK fiyaAlapN,]) and fuyuwlapN↓, (M, K, TA,) meaning [In his judgment, or opinion, is] a weakness. (TA.)
And fAl signifies also He (a man) magnified himself, and became like the elephant (Alfiyl); or he showed a morose aspect: (TA:) [or it may so signify: IAar cites the following verse:

L.foreign: mina AlnRaAsi OaqowaAmN UicaA SaAdafuwA AlginaI

sense.s: which may mean [Of mankind are folks who, when they find riches, turn the back, and] magnify themselves and become like the elephant [to the friend, and aggrandize themselves] or show a morose aspect to the friend [&c.]; for the elephant is morose in aspect. (M.)
2. fyRl raOoyahu, (S, M, K,) inf. n. tafoyiylN, He declared [or esteemed] his judgment, or opinion, to be weak, (S.) or bad, and erroneous. (M, K.) Umeiyeh Ibn Abee-'Áïdh says,

L.foreign: falawo gayorahaA mino wulodi kaEobi boni kaAhilK

sense.s: meaning lamo yufayRalo raOoyuka (SKr, M) i. e. [But hadst thou praised other than her, of the children of Kaab Ibn-Káhil, with a true saying,] thy judgment, or opinion, would not have been declared weak. (SKr.)
See also 1, in two places.
3. faAyala, [inf. n. mufaAyalapN and fiyaAlN, (see AlfayaAlu below,)] He played [at the game called AlfayaAl: see its part. n. below]. (O.)
5. tfyRl: see 1.
Also He (a man, K, [or a camel, as is indicated in the O,]) became fat, (O, K,) as though he were a fiyl [or an elephant]. (O.) [See also 10.]
And, said of youth, or young manhood, (AlXRabaAb,) It increased, (Lth, T, M, O, K,) and became in its prime and fulness. (Lth, T, O.)
And, said of herbage, It became tall, and full-grown; or became of its full height, and blossomed. (Th, M, K.)
