10. Aisotafoyala He (a camel) became like the fiyl [or elephant] (M, K, TA) in bigness: (TA:) mentioned by IJ among the class of AsotaHowaca and the like: part. n. musotafoyilN. (M.) [See also 5.]
faAlN: see fiylN, latter half:
and the paragraph commencing with faAYilu AlrRaOoIi, near its end:
and see also faOolN, in art. fOl.
fayolN: see the paragraph here following.

fiylu [The elephant; Pers. Pyl;] a certain animal, (TA,) well known: pl. [of pauc.] OafoyaAlN and [of mult.] fuyuwlN and fiyalapN; (S, M, O, Msb, K;) not OafoyilapN: (ISk, S, O, Msb:) accord. to Sb. fiylN may be originally of the measure fuEolN, (S, M, O,) pronounced with kesr because of the I, like as they said OaboyaDu and byDN; but Akh says, this is not the case in the sing, but only in the pl.: (S, O:) fem. with p. (M, K)

Hence, layolapN mivolu lawoni Alfiyli [lit. A night like the colour of the elephant;] meaning a night that is black. (M, TA,) and dust-coloured; (M;) in which one knows not the right course to pursue: the colours of the fyl being of this kind. (M, TA.)

[Hence, also, daMCu Alfiyli The disease called by us the tumid Barbadoes leg; because the leg of the patient resembles that of the elephant by reason of its enormously-swollen state: not (as some have supposed it to be) elephantiasis; this latter being termed jucaAm (q. v.) [
And hence, likewise, used as an epithet,] fiylN signifies also (tropical:) Heavy [or dull]; and low, ignoble, or mean. (K, TA.)

And one says rajulN fiylu AlrRaOoIi, meaning A man weak in respect of judgment, or opinion; (T, S, M, O, K;) and so fiyoluhu↓; (M, K;) and faAYiluhu↓: (T, M, O, K;) and fayRiluhu↓, (ISk, T, S, M, O, K,) of the measure fayoEil; (O:) and faAluhu↓, (T, M, O, K,) and faAlN alone. (S, K.) meaning weak in respect of judgment, or opinion; (T, S, M, O, K;) erring in insight: (S:) pl. of the first] OafoyaAlN: (S, M, O, K:) but AO says, the faAYil↓ is one who, inspecting, forms an opinion and errs; if he err after examining a horse in all its states or conditions and forming an opinion respecting it from his inspection, [not while doing so,] he is not reckoned to be fAYl. (TA.)

AlfayaAlu and AlfiyaAlu, (Lth, T, M, O, K) the former a subst, and the latter an inf. n. [of 3], (Lth, T, O,) and AlmufaAyalapu↓ [which is likewise an inf. n. of 3], (M, K,) A certain game, (Lth, T, M, O, K,) well known, (O,) of the children, (T,) or of the youths, or young men, of the Arabs (M, K) of the desert, (M,) with earth, or dust: (Lth, T, M, O:) a thing is hidden in earth, or dust, which is then divided (T, M) into two portions; then the hider says to his companion, In which of them twain is it? (T;) and if he [who is thus questioned] mistake, the hider says to him faAla raOoyuka: (T, M, * K; *) ISk termed it AlfiYaAlu, with C; (O;) and it has been mentioned before in art.
fOl: (T, O, K:) accord. to some, (TA,) this game is called AlTRabanu and AlsudRaru. (T, TA. [But see the former of these two words.])
fayaAlapN: see the first paragraph.
fuyuwlapN: see the first paragraph.
fayRilu AllRaHomi A man having much flesh: (T, O, * K:) some pronounce it with C, (T, O,) saying fayOal, (T,) or faYil; (O;) both mentioned before [in art. fOl]. (TA.)
fayRilu AlrRaOoIi: see fiylN, latter half.
fayRiAlN The attendant, or master, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) or the keeper, or driver, (MA, KL,) of the fiyl [or elephant], (S, MA, O, Msb, KL,) or of the fiylap. (So in the M and K.)
faAYilu AlrRaOoIi: see fiylN, latter half, in two places.

AlfaAYilu [as a subst.] signifies The flesh that is upon the xurobap, (S, O,) or xurob, (K, [in the M, accord. to the TT, Hrf, app. a mistranscription,]) of the warik; (S, M, O, K;) [which, I think, will be plainly seen from what follows to mean the flesh that is upon the sacro-ischiatic foramen; though xurobapu Alwariki and xurobu Alwariki are said in the TA, in art. xrb, to mean “ the hole where the head of the thigh-bone is inserted; ”] so says A 'Obeyd: (S, O:) or, (S, M, O, K,) as some say, so adds A 'Obeyd, (S, O,) a certain vein (T, S, M, O, K) in the xurobap of the warik, descending into the leg, (T,) or in the thigh: (S, O:) As says, in “ the Book of the Horse, ” in the warik is the xurobap, which is a nuqorap wherein is flesh, no bone being in it; and in that nuqorap is the faAYil, and there is no bone between the said nqrp and the belly, but only skin and flesh; (T, * S, O;) and he cites the saying of El-Aashà,

L.foreign: qado naxoDibu AlEayora fiI makonuwni faAYilihi

sense.s: [Oft we stain the ridge of the spear-head in what is concealed in the interior of his fAYl, and oft the man of valour dies by means of our spears]; makonuwnu AlfaAYili means his blood: he says [by implication], we are skilful in respect of the place of piercing: (S, O:) but As said mino in the place of fiI; and AA, qado naToEunu; which has been pronounced to be wrong: (O:) or the faAYilaAni, (T, M,) or the faAYilataAni↓, (so in the K, [app. a mistranscription,]) are two veins entering into the interior parts of the thighs (T, M, K,) in the hinder parts thereof; (M, K;) and they adduce as an evidence thereof the verse of El-Aashà cited above, saying that the epithet mknwn would not have been used if the fAYl were not a vein; but others say that [the poet meant that] he made the spear-head to become concealed in the furthest part of the flesh; and if the fAYl were a vein, it would not have been mentioned as it has been in a phrase of Imra-el-Keys which will be cited in what follows: (M:) [hence it is said,] or they are two portions of flesh [between which is the lower part of the os sacrum, i. e.] the lower parts of which are upon the SalawaAn [dual of SalFA], from the region of the lower portions of the HajabataAni to the Eajob, bordering upon the EuSoEuS on either side, descending in the two sides of the two thighs; [so in a human being,] and thus in the horse: (M, K: [for the meanings of the words that I have here left untranslated, I must refer to their several proper arts.; as they are variously explained:]) AlfaAlu↓ is a dial. var. of AlfaAYilu; (M, K, TA;) which is expl. by Sgh [in the O] as meaning a certain vein issuing from the fawRaArap of the warik [i. e. from the sacro-ischiatic foramen]: (TA:) [but the assertion that AlfAl is a dial. var. of AlfAYl seems to be founded only upon what here follows:] Imra-el-Keys says, [describing a horse,]

(S, M; or ElI AlfaAliI, as in the O and TA;) [i. e. He has edges of the haunch-bones projecting above, or beyond, the fAYl; for] he means ElI faAYili, having altered the latter word by transposition. (T, S, O, TA.)
faAYilapN: see its dual in the next preceding paragraph, near the middle.

Oafoyalu [More, and most, weak, or erroneous; relating to a judgment, or an opinion]. Oafoyalu mina AlrRaOoIi AldRabariIRi is a prov., meaning [More weak] than an opinion that is given after the affair [to which it relates] has passed. (Meyd.)
mufaAyilN [in the S and O in art. fOl, with C, i. e. mufaAYilN,] Playing at the game called AlfayaAlu. (M, O.)
AlmufaAyalapu expl. as a subst.: see AlfayaAlu.
mafoyuwlaMC [a quasi-pl. n. (like maXoyuwxaMCu &c.), but one of which the sing. (if it have one) is not mentioned,] The young ones of the fiyl [or elephant]. (O, K.)
musotafoyilN part. n. of 10, q. v. (M.)
1. faAna, aor. yafiynu, (K,) inf. n. fayonN, (TA,) He, or it, came. (K.)

fayonapN A time; syn. waqotN, or waqotN mina AlzRamaAni; (T;) or HiynN; (T, S, M, K;) and saAEapN. (S, K.) You say, laqiytuhu Alfayonapa baEoda Alfayonapi [I met him time after time]: (AZ, S, M, K; but some copies of the K omit the words bEd Alfynp:) and laqiytuhu fayonapa [I met him at a certain time]: (AZ, S, M, K; but in some copies of the S and K, fayonapF:) thus fynp is made determinate in two different ways; by its having the article Al prefixed to it [in the former case], and as a proper name [in the latter case; with which compare what is said of bukorapa &c.]: (AZ, M:) and you say, UinRiI laMtiI fulaAnFA Alfayonapa baEoda Alfayonapi i. e. [Verily I come to such a one] time after time; not continually repairing to him: (AZ, T:) and, accord. to ISk, maA OaloqaAhu UilRaA Alfayonapa i. e. [I do not meet him save occasionally, or] time after time. (TA.) [See also fanRapN.]

fayonaAn Having beautiful and long hair: (K:) or so fayonaAnu AlXRaEari; applied to a man: (S:) fayonaAn [is also applied as an epithet to hair; and] has been mentioned in art. fn q. v.: (K:) if it be from fananN, meaning “ a branch, ” it is [of the measure fayoEaAlN, and therefore] perfectly decl. when indeterminate, and likewise when determinate [as a proper name]; but if from fayonapN, meaning “ a time, ” [which seems to be hardly reasonable,] it is [of the measure faEolaAn, and therefore] perfectly decl. in the former case and imperfectly decl. in the latter case. (Lh, T.)
One says also ZilRN fayonaAnN, meaning Wide, extensive, shade. (TA.)
OafoyuwnN, also written OufoyuwnN and UifoyawonN, held by some to belong to this art. and by others to belong to art. Afn, has been mentioned in page 70.
1. faAha, aor. yafiyhu: see faAha, aor. yafuwhu, in art. fwh.
fayohajN A wine-measure: (S, O, K:) a Pers. word arabicized [and therefore all its letters are regarded as radical]. (S.)
And A strainer (O, K, TA) for wine. (TA.)

And (sometimes, S, O) a name for Wine: (S, K:) or clear wine: (O, TA:) or an epithet applied to wine [app. signifying clear]: (TA:) or wine such as is mxtlq [app. a mistranscription for muxalRaq, a word now used as signifying aromatized]; like qinodiydN [q. v.] and OumRN zanobaqK. (IAmb, TA.)
